title: Philadelphia Women Win
description: GLADWYNNE, Pa., May 31  The Philadelphia women's golf team regained the Griscom Cup today for the first time since 1976 with a score of 32 points to 23 for New York, the defending team, and 7 for Boston at the Philadelphia Country Club. It was the 72d renewal of the series.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 President Carter has been asking everybody to suggest ways to conserve energy, and since he obviously needs help these days, herewith a few proposals:

title: Death Toll Up to 174
description: CHICAGO, May 31 (AP)  The death count has risen to 274 in the Chicago air disaster, and medical examiners say they have positively identified 17 victims.

title: For Children
description: ANNUAL WEST 93D STREET BLOCK PARTY, a salute to the upper West Side of yesteryear, with ccny rides, games, arts and crafts, baked goods from ),:co shoos and music by the Sweet Adelines, Saturday, noon to S P.M:, (rain date: Sunday), between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive. Free admission.

title: 27 Thai Soldiers Killed by Mine
description: UDON, Thailand, May 31 (AP) Twentyseven Thai soldiers were killed yesterday when their truck hit a mine planted by rebels in northeast Thailand, a military officer said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The Nets acquired a second firstround choice in the National Basketball Association college draft when they traded Harvey Catchings, who alternated as starting center, to the Milwaukee Bucks yesterday. They received John Gianelli and Milwaukee's firstround choice, the eighth pick in the draft.

title: Jazzmen Salute Mingus at Carnegie Concerts
description: The music of Charles Mingus, the renowned jazz bassist and composer who died last January, will be celebrated at two concerts at Carnegie Hall tonight and tomorrow evening, played by musicians who were, in one way or another. close to him.

title: Peace Activists Attack Vietnam on Rights
description: LOS ANGELES, May 31  Advertisements placed in five newspapers this week carried the names so familiar from the battles of the 60's, the names of antiwar activists who had supported North Vietnam  Joan Baez, Daniel J. Berrigan, Allen Ginsbenz and others.

title: Connally Hoping to Inter Ghosts of His Past
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 31 When John B. Connally's supporters and aides speak of baggage, they are not talking about the travel gear that the Republican Presidential candidate stows in his chartered jet. Mr. Connally's baggage is the ghost of Presidents past and his highly publicized trial on bribery charges in 1974.

title: Court Seeking to Resolve Torsney Case
description: ALBANY, MAY 31 The Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal, heard new arguments today in an effort to break its deadlock over whether Robert Torsney should be released from the custody of state mental health officials. Mr. Torsney is a white New York City police officer who was acquitted by reason of insanity in the 1976 shooting death of a black teenaver.

title: British Penalized Over Rhodesia
description: ACCRA, Ghana, May 31 In what may be the start of a campaign to discourage Western powers from recognizing or lifting economic sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia, the Nigerian Government has told a British company that its bid for a $200 million port project in Lagos will not be considered, diplomats here said.

title: Deaths
description: SPITZERJacqueline. On May 30, 1979 of Forest Hills, N.Y. Wife of the tale Francis A. E. Spitzer. Mother of the late Rev. Francis, Philip and Michel. Grandmother of Francis, Michael, Daniel, Anne.lise, ThierrY, Karine, Geoffrey and Kathleen. Memodal Service St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, Saturday June 2 at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Citizens Campaign for New APPreaches, Ch.fogue St, Quogue, N.Y. 11959 would be appreciated. STEINERElizabeth, beloved wife of Alexander. Services Sunday, June 3, 11:30AM The Riverside, 76 SI and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Kennedy Asks Tighter Bail Rules to Protect the Public
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  In a speech prepared for delivery tomorrow, Senator Edward M. Kennedy has aligned himself with conservatives on one issue by calling for stringent new measures to crack down on defendants who commit crimes while they are free on bail.

title: At the Movies
description: THAT a film titled The Elephant Man has been scheduled for production this fall is scarcely surprising in one respect. The Bernard Potnerance play of the same title has been a critical and boxoffice success in London and, currently, in New York, and the screen has historically looked to the stage for inspiration, rather than the other way around.

title: Weizman Backs View West Bank and Gaza Are in Land of Israel
description: JERUSALEM, May 31  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman declared today that the West Bank and Gaza Strip areas were parts of the land of Israel from historical, spiritual and, without a doubt, a defense point of view.

title: TOugh Choices Await New Juvenile Agency
description: The view from the office of Peggy Davis, the city's Deputy Coordinator for Criminal Justice, is down over City Hall, the parks around it and out past Pace University to the approach to Brooklyn Bridge. While Mrs. Davis and a visitor talked in her office one recent morning, two policemen brought a slim youngster in a red running suit around from the park on the east side of the building and thrust him, hands manacled behind his back, into the rear seat of an unmarked police car.

title: Bond Prices Take a Sharp Drop
description: The credit markets, having fully anticipated a sharp drop in the Government's Index of leading economic indicators, yesterday registered their bignest decline in four weeks. Then they began to speculate that the Federal Reserve would raise the discount rate, possibly as soon as this afternoon.

title: Mandatory System Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Following are excerpts from today's decision by Judge Barrington D. Parker of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, finding that President Carter exceeded his Constitutional authority in seeking to impose wage and price guidelines:

title: Paige Gains in N.C.A.A. Trials of 800, 1,500
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 31  Don Paige began his quest for a middledistance double at the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships today by qualifying for the final in the 1,500meter run and surviving his first test at 800 meters.

title: The Pop Life
description: WE live in a period, however brief, in which the airwaves and record stores are filled with new artists, and it's part of the task of criticism to keep up with what's new. But old perennials have their place, too  artists who release new recordings with a measured regularity, providing few surprises but a steady, satisfying sort of nleasurp.

title: BROWN OFFERS PLAN ON TRANSIT AND FUEL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. announced today that he would ask the California Legislature to spend $1.8 billion, raised in partby new taxes on oil companies, for mass transit and public energy conservation programs over the next five years.

title: The U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Taking Over America
description: WASHINGTON  Foreign acquisition of American industry, banking, and farmland is proceeding rapidly. The American business community dismisses this development on tne ground that it is a small share of total American assets and that any constraints on foreign investment would jeopardize the fargreater share of Atherican investment abroad.

title: COMMODMES
description: Precious metals futures prices surged upward yesterday on news of oil price increases by Iran and Saudi Arabia. The volatile metals had been settling back the past two sessions following record mice levels last week. cioia ana sliver prices moved sharply higher in early trading on the New York Commodity Exchange before easing off in latesession adjustments.

title: May ChainStore Sales Reflect Slower Buying
description: Sales results for the month's first four weeks showeea wide range: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, reported a 6.7 decline from the year before, its ninth consecutive monthly drop, but the WalMart Stores, a Southern discounter, registered a 44 percent gain.

title: Scholarship Limited to Men Is Target of Discrimination Suit
description: In a case believed to be without precedent in New York, the State Attorney General will cite sex discrimination a petition today to the Westchester County Surrogate revise terms of a will that left $190,000 for, college scholarships but limited them to young men.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DORIC (Home). Lett Bermuda May 31; due B A.M. W.S.Stls Street.

title: Screen: 'Phantasm,' a Horror Story:Heebee Jeebee
description: IF you've ever listened to a bright, imaginative 8-year-old child make up a ghost story, you'll have some idea of what it's like to watch "Phantasm," Don Coscarelli's giddy horror movie that does its best to scare its audience but, instead, scares itself senseless. It's thoroughly silly and endearing."Phantasm," which opens today at Loew's State 2 and other theaters, is about two orphaned brothers, Hardy Boys types though they do curse freely. Mike (Michael Baldwin), who is in his early teens, and Jody (Bill Thornbury), in his early 20's, live near Morningside Mortuary and Cemetery, a spooky establishment run by a tall, ashen-faced fellow who doesn't like people until they are dead. You might call him the mortician's mortician. He not only will embalm your nearest and dearest, he'll kill him first.When Mike and Jody investigate the Morningside premises, at first separately, then together, they are attacked by all sorts of unlikely creatures and objects, including something that looks like an aluminum baseball that flies on its own through the air and attacks the foreheads or victims with what seems to be a corkscrew."I do know one thing," Jody says after one narrow escape, "something weird is going on up there.""Phantasm" is the sort of breathless tale whose chapters are bridged with the movie equivalent to the "and then. . . ." of prose fiction. What happens next is never more logical than what happened before, but at least something is happening, which often necessitates that characters and facts be suddenly introduced (or dropped) with the kind of heedless enthusiasm that only 8-year-old raconteurs can muster.I've no idea how old Mr. Coscarelli is, but he is apparently very young and energetic. He wrote and directed "Phantasm," in addition to being its director of photography and its editor. There's nothing great about the performances but they are adequate and the movie looks pretty good. The house that stands in for the spooky mortuary is the same Victorian pile that was used in "Burnt Offerings." Being old and picturesque, it could become to horror movie sets what Vincent Price is to horror movies.

title: Deaths
description: HYMANBenlamin I. Beloved husband of Anfia. Cherished father of Randy, Kerry and Michael Leaf. Dear brother of Morris, and Pearl Goldstein. Wonderful friend. Died Wednesday, May 30. Funeral was held on Thursday, May 31. Shiva at residence.

title: Bridge:
description: Four tough teams, long on experience, battled last night in the first half of the Reisinger knockout team semifinal at the Beverly East Bridge Club in Manhattan.

title: Art People
description: ART criticism is a funny business. No one ever learned to do it by passing an exam. As to the qualifications for it, no two people are ever agreed. You can start at any aee. if you can persuade an edifor to let you. You can be wonderful at it one year and quite hopeless the next. The last good critic is usually the worst model for the next good critic.

title: The New York Times/Sera Krulwich
description: GALA MARKS RETURN OF RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL: Before start last night's show, guests gathered In the refurbished main lobby. Page C1.

title: U.S. Rally Takes Walker Cup Golf
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 31 (UPI)  The United States, with Scott Hoch leading the way, won seven of eight singles matches this afternoon and rolled to a 15to8 victory over Britain and Ireland in the Walker Cup amateur golf tournament. It was the 24th victory for the United States in 27 meetings.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the Auctions column of Weekend last Friday, the figure of $9.3 million given for Christie's New York sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art inadvertently represented the gross total. The net was $6.6 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Ambac Industries, a subsidiary of United Technologies, has named Edward J. Rapetti president and chief executive officer.

title: Beaths
description: ABRAMSJack of 1835 Franklin St, San Francisco, Calif. Formerly of Great Neck, N.Y. He was a former owner of Progressive Coat CoRegal Manor Clothes. Died on May 24, 1979. Survived by wife, Hannah, son, Norman, daughter, Henrietta.

title: Buyer Had No Financial Obstacle
description: When the Joseph E. Seagram & Sons distillery company acknowledged last February that it was seeking a qualified buyer for its famous Park Avenue headquarters, it stressed that only the wealthiest institutions need apply  the stringent conditions it was placing on the sale would, it said, rule out any buyer who would require outside financing.

title: Trial On in Penn Dixie Case
description: Charges that Penn Dixie Industries Inc. was defrauded of millions of dollars in a Florida land sale were described yesterday in the opening statements at the criminal trial of the company's former chief executive, Jerome Castle, who was accused of conspiracy and fraud.

title: Camp David 'social Planned
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)  President Carter will entertain a relatively small number of House Democrats and their leaders at Camp David, Md., this weekend, the White House press secretary, Jody Powell, announced today. It's primarily social, said Mr. Powell.

title: Cabaret: Carol Fredette
description: BUCKY PIZZARELLI, the will o the wisp guitarist who can sometimes be caught on the wing in his constant movement around New York, has settled in for three weeks. through June 16 at the French Quarter Lounge of the Sheraton Center Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 52d Street, with the two regular members of his trio, Tony Monte, guitarist, and Ron Naspo, bassist.

title: Associated Press
description: MEMORIAL SERVICE FOR MARY PICKFORD: Charles (Buddy) Rogers being escorted by the Rev. William H. D. Hornaday after service for his wife, Mary Pickford, the actress, who died Tuesday. About 100 friends attended the private service yesterday at Forest Lawn Memorial Park In Hollywood.

title: Soviet Official Said to Deny Pledge on Emigration
description: MOSCOW, May 31 Jewish dissidents said today that a Soviet official had denied any knowledge of a pledge to free 12 wouldbe emigrants now serving terms or otherwise ease emigration curbs. the dissidents were responding to reports of a promise said to have been made last week by Aleksei I. Shibayev, the Soviet trade union chief, to Robert Hawke, the visiting Australian union leader. There had been no confirmation.

title: Dances By Weaver Of Dreams
description: The Guggenheim Museum will be, turned into a theater tonight and Saturday, with the audience seated on chairs and pillows under that ramp spiralling to the sky. It won't be the first time for the Guggenheim. The Dance Theater of narfem ana mereann Monk have performed there, and so has the jazz musclan Jimmy Giuffre. There seems to be some question, however, as to what to call the work of Sylvia Palacios Whit. man, whose new South will be seen at the museum this weekend. Critics have described her vignettes  in which men and women move slowly across the stage bearing enormous cloth and paper props  as everything from minimal circus to tiny machines of consciousness. Others hedge their bets by categorizing her, in uptodate critical terminology, as a performance artist. Perhaps, most simply, Miss Whitman is a weaver of dreams.

title: Two Festivals in Queens
description: The Borough of Queens dons the mantle of municipal master of revels Sunday, with a pair of overlapping festivals to beguile New Yorkers who enjoy following the springtime trail of weekend galas around the city.

title: The City; Officer Loses a Leg When Struck by Van; Boy Drowns in Pool While Chasing a Ball; Garbage Problem; Council Winding Up Budget Negotiations; A Jumbo Joke?; City Is Establishing Lending Corporation; Elderly Patients Called Victimized
description: A New York City police officer who lost his right leg yesterday when he was struck by a van that pinned him against his patrol car was reported in stable but serious condition after an eightandahalfhour operation at Bellevue Hospital to save his left leg.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar followed a hilly path in world markets yesterday. After sinking in early trading abroad in delayed reaction to Wednesday's trade deficit figures, it rose in late New York trading on hopes that a slowing economy would narrow the gap in future months, dealers said.

title: Highlights of Plan To Decontrol Oil
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Following are the highlights of President Carter's plan to decontrol oil prices:

title: Young Congressmen Making Gains For Forgotten 2 Vietnam Veterans
description: WASMNGTON, May 31 For a long time Washington tried to forget Vietnam, btd this week the capital remembered In part because of a group of young legislators, call themselves Vietnam Veterans in Congress whose selfappointed mission has been to get the country to talk about the war and to care for the men who fought it.

title: U.S. Lists the Doctors Convicted for Frauds In MedicareMedicaid
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)  The Government released for the first time today the names of doctors, dentists and others who it says have been convicted of defrauding the Medicare and Medicaid system.

title: Small Hands, Big Hearts Brighten Lighthouse
description: Students at the Grace Church Nursery School of Brooklyn Heights spent yesterday away from the classroom putting a new coat of paint on the Little Lighthouse under the George Washington Bridge in Manhattan. Distressed by the eraffiti they saw covering the lighthouse during a field trip earlier this spring, they decided to paint it. With permission of the Park Department, the youngsters returned, armed with brushes and paint, and, with the help of some adults, gave the little beacon a new shine.

title: Misses Ivers, Campbell Combine for 66 in L.I. Golf
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 31 Nancy Ivers of North Hempstead and Kim Campbell of Creek posted a winning 66, six strokes under par, today in the Women's Long Island Golf Association BetterBall Tournament at Piping Rock Club. Edna Gall of North Hempstead and Molly Pierpont of Piping Rock were second with 68.

title: Fletcher Martin, Artist of Action
description: Fletcher Martin, a selftaught artist who captured his moods and memories as hobo, sailor and lumberjack on canvases that would be hung in some of the nation's leading museums, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home at Guanajuato, Mexico. He was 75 years old and had recently divided his time between Mexico and a home in Sarasota. Fla.

title: Police Seeking Clues In the Fatal Stabbing Of a Woman Student
description: The police tried unsuccessfully yesterday to learn the final activities of Amanda Field, a 19yearold Baruch College student who was found stabbed to death in her apartment in the Park Slope area of Brooklyn. Late yesterday, they reported no leads or definite clues to the killer except that there was no sexual angle.

title: RopeJumping To Be Its Best In City's Finals
description: It was not a helicopter revving up in the gymnasium of Public School 56 on Henry Street  it was Patrice Boemio jumping double Dutch.

title: Record of Safety at Nuclear Plants Led to Complacency, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Harold R. Denton, the director of regulations for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said today that Federal officials had become somewhat complacent about reactor safety before an accident crippled the nuclear power plant at Three Mile Island.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursdim May 31. 1272

title: Parent Retires
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP)  Bernie Parent, one of the National Hockey. League's best goaltenders ever, retired today after 14 years in the league because of an eye injury suffered last season.

description: FOXMilton, beloved husband of Ronda, devoted father of Sydney Storman of Denver, Col., Jacqueline Forlani of Purdys, N.Y., Curtis, Eric and Maureen Fox, dear brother of Sally Kopitko, Jesse Fox of Los Angeles, Sylvia Kuichin of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Belle Silverman of Vineland, N.J., grandfather of Susan and Alexandra Sherman, Maura Fox, Willis and Lyla Forlani. A resident of Manhattan and North Salem, N.Y.. he was President of Gelfo Manufacturing Co. and Sea Fashions of California, divisions of Athlone Industries. He was Vice President of Temple Shaaray Tetila and Past Chancellor of AtlasFloman Lodge *300 of the Knights of Pythias. Funeral services will be held at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 79 St. and 2d Ave. In Manhattan, Sunday morning at 10:30, and the family will be at The Riverside, Amsterdam Ave. and 76 St., Saturday evening from 7.9.

title: Berger Would Halt HalfFare Plan On Weekends on the City's Transit
description: The weekend halffare on New York City subways and buses would be abolished under a proposal to come before the Metropolitan Transportation Authority this morning.

title: Books of The Times
description: MR. TREVANIAN, whose first name and whose real name are withheld froin Us, explains rather late. in the mUrderotis game of his new thriller, ShibUmi, that only in Japan was the classical moment simultaneous with the medieval. In the West, philosophy, art, political and social ideal, all are identified with periods before or after the medieval moment, the single exception being that glorious bridge to God, the cathedral. Only in Japan was the feudal moment also the philosophic moment. We of the West are comfortable with, the image of the warrior priest, or the warrior scientist, even the warrior industrialist, But the warrior philosopher? No, that concept irritates our sense of propriety.

title: Iran Raises Crude Oil Surcharge
description: In a move that industry sources interpreted as a new and sharp gain in world oil prices, Iran increased the surcharges on its crude oil yesterday by between $1.10 and $1.30 a barrel.

title: FreeSpirited Residents of Canyon Fear Its Development
description: TOPANGA, Calif., May 31  Up the winding Topanga Boulevard from the Pacific Ocean, motorists heading for the San Fernando Valley must pass through this mountain village of 5,000.

title: Youth Admits Part in SoHo Slaying
description: Earvin Edwards Jr., one of two youths accused of killing Irene Maxwell, a Scottish fashion designer, in the SoHo section of Manhattan last. December, pleaded guilty yesterday to a reduced charge of manslaughter in the first degree.

title: $1 Billion Sales for Top Black Concerns
description: The top 100 blackowned businesses had more than $1 billion in sales for the first time last year, according to the annual survey by Black Enterprise magazine. The sales total for 1978 was $1.05 billion, compared with $896 million for 1977, the magazine reported in its June issue.

title: Panel Votes for Restricting Use Of TaxExempt Housing Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI)  The House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to impose restrictions on the use of municipal taxexempt industrial development bonds to finance multifamily housing oroiects.

title: New Lizht on Diabetes
description: There are about 10 million diabetics in the United States and the disease is the third leading cause death, after heart disease and cancer. Diabetes also causes blindness and contributes to kidney failure and gangrene, requiring the amputation of limbs. his grim toll explains the importance of the recent report in The New England Journal of Medicine that a specific virus has been identified as the cause a case of human diabetes. The finding does not, unfortunately, promise relief and prevention by vaccines, as in the case of polio. Diabetes is really a complex family of diseases, and genetic and immunological defects appear to cause some varieties. But the new data are an encouraging confirmation of the perception of diabetes that has emerged from recent research. A probable viral link, in fact, was discovered even before the latest finding and a genetic connection was uncovered in part from research on organ transplants.

title: Law Firm Is Indicted in Visa Fraud
description: MIAMI, May 31  The law firm of David M. Walters, who was President Carter's personal representative to the Vatican, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury in an alleged conspiracy to illegally provide United States visas for its foreign clients.

title: Around the Nation
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 31 (UPI) Eight seniors at the United States Naval Academy have been barred from graduation because of their alleged involvement in what could become the academy's largest drug scandal in recent years, academy officials said today.

title: Seagram to Sell Building For $85.5 Million to Fund
description: The Seagram Building, the 38story bronzeandglass Park Avenue tower widely acclaimed as New York City's finest postwar skyscraper, is being sold for $85.5 million to a teachers retirement fund under the stringent maintenance and preservation conditions set three months ago when the building was placed on the market.

title: Commodity Tables Explained
description: Next to each commodity in the table is a key the exchange on which it is traded, the minimum contract size and the monetary units represented by the figures in the table. Open interest is the number of contracts outstanding each month and not liquidated by delivery of the commodity or by an offsetting contract. The exchange keys are:

title: IN THE NATION
description: Before a North Vietnamese invasion toppled the cruel Cambodian regime of Pol Pot, that regime had established itself as one of the most ruthless in history. And there was a rising chorus in this country to suggest that those whc had opposed the war in Indochina were not only blind to the atrocities in Cam. bodia but responsible for them This inversion of history developed mostly from the fact that doves in and out of Congress opposed the Ford Administration's final request for $222 million in military aid to the Lon Nol Government then on its last legs in Phnom Penh. Soon after that request was defeated, Cambodia fell to the Khmer Rouge and the nightmare of the Pol Pot regime began.

title: Robber Slays Girl Because She Kept On Crying in Fear
description: A terrified 14yearold Brooklyn girl was shot to death during a grocery holdup Wednesday night by a gunman who fired on her at pointblank range when she would not stop crying, according to the police.

title: New York Agrees on Antibias Rule And Now Will Get Federal Money
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  The Treasury Department announced today that it had won compliance! from New York City on an antidiscrimination order and was therefore freeing $300 million in Federal revenuesharing funds that it had withheld earlier this month.

title: World News Briefs
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, May 31 (Reuters)  Policemen guarding Shah Mohammed Rim Pahlevi said today that he planned to leave tomorrow for an undisclosed destination.

title: Leo Ritter, 72, Prominent Furrier
description: Leo Ritter, a leading figure in the American fur industry who had an international clientele for his luxurious apparel, died Wednesday in his Manhattan home at 1125 Park Avenue of a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

title: U.S. PLANS TO APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  A Federal judge ruled today that President Carter's efforts to enforce wage and price guidelines through the Government's purdias. ing power were unlawful and must be reiected.

title: The MaandPa Javits Store
description: So it turns out that Marion Javits, the wife of New York's senior Senator, solicited rather than merely received a public relations account from the Shah of Iran four years ago. And she and the Shah merely feigned campaign to promote Iran Air when in fact she was selling the benevolence of his reeime. And the Iranians, it seems, cared little for her skill if the deal would pour money in the pocket of Mrs. Javits. An unseemly business. But after reading of it in Iranian documents just come to light, our interest fastens more on the sociology than the politics of the arrangement.

title: Higuera, Ross Tied for Lead
description: DENVILLE, N.J., May 31  Mike Higuera, the pro at the Edgewood Club in Riverdale, N.J., and Bob Ross, the pro at Baltusrol in Springfield, N.J., shared the lead at 68 as the 16th annual Dodge open began today at the Rockaway River Country Club.

title: TV Weekend
description: THE major offering on commercial television will be broadcast live from Broadway's Shubert Theater this Sunday at 9:30 P.M. The 33d Annual Tony Awards are being carried on CBS. The hosts are Jane Alexander, Henry Fonda and Liv Ullmann. On the agenda is a musical salute to Richard Rodgers, who will be given a special lifetimeachievement award. Also on the networks this Sunday, on NBC at 10 P.M., is a news documentary: This one, with Tom Snyder as host, is called The Incredible Shrinking Gasoline Pump.

title: German Bank Rate Up
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, May 31, (Reuters)The West German central bank announced today that it was raising the interest rate at which it lends funds to commercial banks to 5.5 percent from 5 percent, effective tomorrow.

title: Mortgage Halt By Coast Unit
description: California law sets an rate ceiling of 10 percent on loans by mortgage bankers and life insurance companies and one of 12 percent on loans by savings and loan associations and commercial banks.

title: Theater: 'saints Alive!
description: SAINTS Alive! is a relentlessly cheerful, quickly depressing comedy about St. Anthony, Jesus, St. Christopher, Father O'Brien, Annie, Satan and God. They all live in Brooklyn, except for God. He is a voice over the sound system. The play is at the Actors PlayCharles Carmello, the author, has the kindest of intentions with this play; he even has serious ones. He is addressing himself to questions that children sometimes address themselves to, and that theologians forever address themselves to: questions about good and evil, the nature of saints, and what does God have in mind for us, anyway? Mr. Carmello has found answers no better or worse than anyone else's, and every so often they are provocative. But better Mr. Carmello should be offering them somewhere else than in a theater.

title: AMTRAK GAINS HOPE OF AVOIDING BIG CUT
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Buoyed by the swift increase in Amtrak patronage, Congressional supporters of the financially troubled national rail passenger system hope to save additional routes and trains that the Department of Transportation earmarked for the scrap heap.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Prof. Eugene V. Rostow's May 21 letter suggests that the United States put SALT II on the shelf, rebuild our nuclear and conventional deterrent and proceed with the Soyiets to negotiate on the basis of the agenda for SALT III. Apart from the sardonic aspect of a proposal to turn back the clock 10 years, it proceeds from a false assumption, statedbut not explained.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE decision of United States District Judge Barrington D. Parker that President Carter had overstepped his constitutional powers by using economic sanctions to enforce his wageprice guidelines confronts the President with the necessity of deciding how to rescue his foundering antiinflation Program.

title: McGee Shoots a 61; Lightning Halts Golf
description: CHARLOTTE,.N.C., May 31 (AP) Jerry McGee, who was discouraged and considering leaving the PGA Tour, responded to a pep talk from his wife by shooting an 11underpar 61 and taking a oneshot lead today after the first round of the $350.000 Kemper Open.

title: New Report Puts Worth Of Carter Over $1 Million
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  The White House released a new net worth stateMeat today showing that President Carter is worth more than $1 million dollars.

title: Federal Reserve
description: Wednesday, May 30, 1979

title: Customer Fatally Shot in Dispute On Line at Brooklyn Gas Station
description: A man waiting in line for gasoline at an Amoco service station in Brooklyn was shot last night after an argument with another customer over a place in line and died hours later.

title: World Oil Problems Strain Old Alliances
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  When comes to oil and the international scene, disarray reigns. Old relationships and old alliances seem on the verge of breaking down, with consumer and producer nations alike apparently convinced that the best strategy is to get all they can individually, whatever the side effects might be.

title: Magic Flute to Be Sung By Opera in Progress
description: Mozart's The Magic Flute will be sung in German and spoken in English by Opera in Progress this weekend at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 346 West 20th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

title: The Boy Is Growing Up
description: John Patrick McEnroe Jr., the thirdbest tennis player in the world, has a mass of tan curls that he restrains with an Alice in Wonderland bandeau when he is on the court. His eyes are blue and the barely discernible darkness of his upper lip is either the optimistic beginning of a mustache or testimony that he has not yet begun to shave. He also has a bankroll of $326,000 won during the first five months of 1979, playing a game he has enjoyed for 12 of his 20 years. That's about $4,000 less than the earnings of Bjorn Borg, the No. 1 player, and $14,000 less than Jimmy Connors has collected.

title: Publishing: Robards On the Touch of O'Neill
description: IF Jason Robards, our most illustrious O'Neill actor, can ever put some free time together, he may well finish that autobiography he has promised Nan Talese and Simon & Schuster, of which she is a vice president. Autobiography may not be the precise word. however.

title: Food Chain In F.T.C. Pact
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) The Howard Johnson Company will no longer require its licensed restaurants to purchase most of their food from the parent company, with the exception of ice cream, fried clams and a few other products, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Stage: 'strider, a Tolstoy Adaptation
description: Two years ago Robert Kalfin, producing director of the Chelsea Theater Center, saw Mark Rozovsky's stage adaptation of Tolstoy's short story Strider: The Story of a Horse at the Gorky Theater in Leningrad. Mr. Kalfin's English version of this epic, written in collaboration with Steve Brown, had its American premiere last night at Chelsea's Westside Theater. It is easy to understand why the play continues to be so popular in the Soviet Union and what motivated the enterprising Mr. Kalfin to adapt it for American audiences.

title: Market Marks Time While Some Oils, Golds and Gambling Issues Post Gains
description: Selective strength in domestic oils, golds and gambling issues shared honors with the takeover sector yesterday in producing price advances. Meanwhile, popular market averages showed a mixture of token gains and declines.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Fri. Sat. Get Out Your Handkerchiefs), 3, 5, 7,9,11.

title: Film: Olmi's 'The Tree of Wooden Clogs' Opens:Peasants of 1900
description: THE awkwardly titled "The Tree of Wooden Clogs," Ermanno Olmi's fine Italian film (and winner of the top Cannes festival prize last year), has almost nothing going for it except that it may well be a masterpiece.If the title doesn't put you off in the way it suggests tulip-time in Holland, Mich., then the subject will. Here is a leisurely paced, appreciative, somberly beautiful movie, acted by non-professionals, about peasant life in northern Italy at the turn of the century. It's a movie in which no one dies and no one can see into the future, a movie with no particular narrative line and whose politics are never made explicit. Yet there's more political content in almost any one sequence of "The Tree of Wooden Clogs" than there is in all of Bernardo Bertolucci's grandiose "1900."Perhaps the worst handicap carried by the film is that it will be impossible to talk about in trend-conscious New York without sounding as if one had just discovered the joys of Rosa Bonheur. Someone is bound to say, "You can't be serious."Like Terrence Malick's "Days of Heaven," Mr. Olmi's film is almost too beautiful for its own good. In lesser films  and I'll probably be castigated for including some of Flaherty's work in this category  such density and clarity of image have a way of obscuring harsh subject matter or rendering it sentimental. Beauty is full of peril for the film maker. It can make reality seem exotic by putting it at a distance.However, Mr. Olmi ("The Sound of Trumpets," "The Fiancs," etc.) is a rigorous director. He photographs his films straight-on, at eye-level. He admires these peasants without patronizing them or inflating the scope of their lives. Further, just as he chooses not to impose unlikely political consciousnesses on his characters, he refuses to use the tricks of melodrama to hold our attention. Instead, he has made a film that follows the lives of the farmers much as they follow the course of the seasons.The film covers approximately a year and focuses on the members of three peasant families who live a communal existence on a large estate owned by a landlord who, though a resident, could not seem more absentee if he lived in Southern California. As they are faceless functions in the landlord's life, so is he the still unquestioned authority in theirs.Mr. Olmi, who is his own cameraman as well as writer, director and editor, moves through these lives in the manner of someone remembering a long-gone past, though Mr. Olmi, who was born in 1931, could only be remembering the memories of others. Instead of shaping this material with hindsight, he allows us in the audience to interpret it ourselves. The movie thus involves us in ways far more moving than do those films that insist on telling us everything we are supposed to feel (and probably don't).Though Mr. Olmi shoots his films at eye-level and always sticks closely to the details of specific events, the effect of the film is of knowledge gained obliquely. The movie, which runs slightly more than three hours, is an accumulation of dozens of experiences of children, adults, old people, village idiots, of harvest times and plantings, of moments of boredom and jealousy, celebrations, fatigue, brief pleasures and mysterious ones. It moves so effortlessly, often with great humor and always with compassion, that it seems much shorter than most 90-minute films.The quality of the performances of the huge cast is staggeringly good. The faces are beautiful without being pretty. You may be particularly taken by some of the children, all of whom look a bit underfed and undersized, and by the relationship of an especially tiny little girl and her ancient grandfather who grows tomatoes by his own secret formula. Near the end there's a sequence that more or less exemplifies Mr. Olmi's method. It's a day-long trip by river boat to Milan where a young farm couple, on their honeymoon, witness a series of violent street demonstrations and never once question the reasons for the unrest. Politics are beyond them, though not Mr. Olmi."The Tree of Wooden Clogs," which opens today at Cinema Studio I, is a profoundly serious film that stands outside time and fashion.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation today urged the Government to direct the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to purchase at least onethird of its operating equipment from suppliers other than those in the Bell System.

title: New Bill for Arms Aid to Turkey Faces Strong House Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  The Carter Administration began a drive today to win House approval for a $50 million militaryaid grant to Turkey, but it encountered strong opposition to the measure, which the Senate adopted by a 2to1 margin last week.

title: Design/ Research Store Starts Its Final Sale
description: The end of Design/Research International, the pioneering home furnishings chain, will be marked by a clearance sale that starts this morning in New York, Cambridge, Mass., and Philadelphia. Already closed are the chain's stores in Westport, Conn., and Chestnut Hill, Mass., as are the four shops on the West Coast.

title: The Region
description: BOUND BROOK, N.J. (AP)  Sixteen employees were overcome by toxic cloud of chlorine gas at the American Cyanamid Company here yesterday. Four were hospitalized in critical condition.

title: Tigers Top Blue Jays As Brothers Duel, 10
description: TORONTO, May 31 (AP)  Pat Underwood was rooting for his brother, Tom, and Tom was rooting for Pat, and when they finished pitching tonight, Pat and the Detroit Tigers had a 10 victory over Tom and the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Local Persons on the List
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI)  Following is a list of New York and New Jersey physicians, dentists and others currently suspended from the Government's Medicaid and Medicare programs following fraud or abuse findings or convictions. The Government Sistine included no Connecticut practitioners.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Transformation 6:00(5)New Zoo Revue

title: Brass Proud Opens Summergarden at Modern
description: Jazz musicians don't like to wait around when they are ready to play, so, when only five trumpet players and a rhythm section had showed up for band rehearsal a few years aeo. they started jamming. It sounded so good, they stayed together.. They're called Brass Proud, they call their style freebop, and they will play tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden, opening the ninth annual Summergarden season. of free weekend performances.

title: Smoking Out Auto Emissions
description: Since the Clean Air Act was passed in 1970, New York, like other states, has been struggling to meet the Federal standards. Washington has grown increasingly impatient and warned New York either to initiate auto emission inspections soon or face the loss of some Federal transportation aid. Convinced that the threats are serious, Governor Carey has now offered a plan to begin automobile emission inspections in 1980. !Lis sensible and necessary start.

title: Europe Officials Protest U.S. HeatingOil Subsidy
description: PARIS, May 31 Western European officials are expressing outrage at President Carter's decision to grant a temporary $5abarrel subsidy to United States imports of homeheating oil.

title: Deaths
description: S PE LMANDr. James P. On May 29, 1979. Retired Dentist. Served in WWII as Commander, U.S. Navy. Uncle of Robert, Thomas and William Spelman and Lawrence O'Brien. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, Third Avenue and 85 Street, Friday 7PM9:30PM.

title: Critic Says Arms Pact May Threaten Safety Of American Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  A leading critic of an accord with the Soviet Union to limit strategic nuclear weapons asserted today that the treaty was likely to force the Carter Administration to select an inferior system of protecting United States intercontinental missiles from destruction.

title: Aide Says Pol Pot Regime Is Ready To Join Old Foes Against Vietnam
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, May 31  Former Prime Minister Poi Pot of Cambodia, now leading a resistance movement against Vietnamese invaders from a mountaiirredoubt, is ready to enter into a coalition with his former rightwing enemies. his too aide said today.

title: Associated Press
description: KIIURRAMSHAHR, Iran, May 31ProGovernment forces appeared to have gained control of this troubled port city today despite sporadic outbursts of gunfire from angry Arabs.

title: A Pastime That Grew Into a Profusion of Sweaters
description: You might say the sweater business came about because her husband likes to ski. Its not that Carolyn Eve Birnbach knits ski sweaters. It's just that her husband, Mark, who is dentist, wanted to live in a place with ski slopes nearby rather than several hours away. That's how they came to settle in Boulder. Cnln.

title: Pilot in Maine Crash Had Told Controllers of Trouble
description: OWLS HEAD, Me., May 31 (AP) James Merryman, Downeast Airlines most experienced pilot, asked for clearance to use another airport shortly before his DeHavilland Otter crashed in heavy fog on the coast of Maine last night, killing 17 people, the authorities said today.

title: Money
description: THURSDAY, MAY 31, 1979

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter's wageprice guidelines were dealt a severe blow by Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker, who ruled in Washington that the President had established a mandatory system of wage and price controls unsupported by law in trying to enforce his standards by withholding Federal contracts from violators. He ruled on a motion by the A.F.L.C.I.O. and nine of its member unions, which said the program interfered with collective bargaining. The White House said the Administration would seek an expedited appeal of the ruling. Organized labor praised the decision, while business warned against turning to mandatory controls. [Page A1.]

title: United's CutRate Fares Worry Its Competitors
description: CHICAGO, May 31  United Airlines, anxious to fill seats emptied by its costly 58day strike, is aggressively promoting a discount strategy borrowed from soap sellers and coffee mercnants. In the process, it is giving up prospective revenues at a pace that is worrying major competitors, who have been forced to respond with their own cutrate fares.

title: Geo Dynamics Settles Charges
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that Geo Dynamics Oil and Gas Inc. and three of its officers had settled agency charges that the company defrauded more than 2,000 wealthy investors in a taxshelter scheme worth more than $80 million.

title: ODELLA B. CROWELL
description: Odella Birkestrand Crowell, an assistant treasurer of the Chemical Bank of New York, died Wednesday at her home in Chatham, Mass., after a long illness. She was 63 years old and also had a residence in Tudor City in Manhattan.

title: $1 Billion Lawsuit Filed
description: The mother of a Schenectady man killed in the air crash sued American Airlines and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation yesterday for $1 billion in damages, The Associated Press reported.

title: Expos 1, Phillies 0
description: MONTREAL, May 31 (AP)  Scott Sanderson hurled a sixhitter and made Warren Cromartie's firstinning sacrifice fly stand up today as the Montreal Expos beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 10, to complete a threegame shutout sweep of the threetime National League East champions.

title: George Segal Takes World Of Plaster To Whitney
description: THE George Segal retrospective exhibition the Whitney Museum is likely to prompt every seasoned visitor to think back to the time when he first saw a sculpture by George Segal. If it was in the mid1960's, it came as a shock. Figurative sculpture at that time was something that people produced by methods that had hardly changed since the days of Donatello. Not only did George Segal flout that convention, but he sited his figures in reallife locations.

title: Egypt Airmen to Study In U.S. Before F4 Sale
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 The Defense Department disclosed today that it was planning a onemonth language course for 56 members of the Egyptian Air Force, in advance of an expected sale of F4 Phantom iets to Cairo.

title: Braths
description: CROWELLOdella (Birkestrand). Of 63 Capri Lane, Chatham, Mass. and New York. Age 63. At her home after a long illness. She was wife of the late Lorenzo Crowell and mother of Elee Crowell of Boston, and Lorenzo, Jr. of Palmer Lake, Colorado. Also one grandchild. Funeral services will be held at the First Congregational Church, Chatham. Mass, Friday June 1 at 2 PM. Burial will be in Union Cemetery, Chatham.

title: Music: Tammy Wynette
description: TAMMY WYNETTE, who was the star of a countrymusic package show at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night, sings ballads and gospelderived uptempo numbers exceptionally well. Unlike many countrysingers who tend to stay at one decibel level, Miss Wynette has mastered dynamics. The fullbodied richness of her voice is present even when she is singing very softly, and her intonation remains impeccable. She commands lot of vocal firepower, but she uses it sparingly.

title: Vietnam Refugees Say Attacks on Communists Continue in Highlands
description: HONG KONG, May 31  Small groups of former South Vietnamese soldiers and mountain tribesmen are still carrying on sporadic resistance to the Communists in the Central Highlands, according to several Vietnamese refugees who recently arrived here by boat.

title: G.P.U. Net Down 5% In Quarter
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation, the parent company of the three utilities that own the illfated Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania, yesterday announced a 5 percent decline in quarterly earnings.

title: Brewer Rally Beats Yanks
description: MILWAUKEE, May 31  The Milwaukee Brewers needed a checkedswing double and a bouncing single through a drawnin infield, but they finally figured out how to beat the newest Yankee relief ace Ron Davis Gorman Thomas's double drove in the tying run and Paul Molitor's single sent home the winning run as  the Brewers edged the Yankees, 54, with threerun rally in the ninth inning.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indi cafes stock Is fisted on the New You Stock Exchange, (A) the Americar Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Auctions
description: THE Benjamin Sonnenberg collection of art and antiques one of the largest (1,762 lots) and most valuable (it may total $3 to $9 million) ever sold at auction in America  goes on view today and under the hammer Tuesday through Saturday at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. The presale exhibition, which will be open today through Monday, 10 A.M. to P.M., is the most sizable ever held in the auction concern's commodious quarters. Envision the contents of a fivestory, 37room, generously appointed town house jammed into Sotheby's eight galleries. Much of what this publicrelations executive collected was highly theatrical, weighty, boldly carved and colorful. Among the English 18thcentury antiques there are, for example, generously scaled partner's desks, hunt tables, boo cases, rent tables and cupboards.

title: Jean Chauvel of France; A Diplomat for 42 Years
description: PARIS, May 31  Jean Chatiyel, who represented France at the United Nations from 1949 to 1952, died here this morning after an operation for an undisclosed ailment. He was 82 years old.

title: Police Seeking Missing Boy Still Lack a Good Lead
description: The police still had no meaningful leads yesterday as they completed a. week of searching for Etan Patz, the 6yearold SoHo boy last seen on Prince Street walking to his school bus.

title: President Asks Oil Leaders to Join Common Effort to Close Fuel Gap
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  President Carter told oil industry executives today that we're all in this together in the eyes of the public and would share either the blame for continued fuel shortages or the credit for solving the problem.

title: News Summary
description: Reconcilation among Cambodians was sought by the regime deposed early this year by the Vietnamese invasion. The foreign affairs leader of the former Government, now mounting a resistance movement from a mountain redoubt, said that it was ready to join in a coalition with its former rightwing enemies and possibly cede leadership to them. [Page A1, Columns 23.]

title: Music Hall Arches: Theater Incarnate
description: AS surely as the pointed top of the Empire State Building means the New York skyline, the great, goldcolored arches around Radio City Music Hall's proscenium call to mind all the power and drama that the stage can summon up. The arches are a symbol of Radio City, and Radio City itself is a symbol of all that the experience of being in a theater could ever mean. The arches  as well as the rest of Radio City fell on hard times in the last few years. The hall looked the same, but it didn't feel the same  it became dirty, dingy, illkempt, rather like a grand dame who had kept her wardrobe after she had lost her looks. Everything had an air of age to it that it shouldn't have had so soon as Its fifth decade. Radio City's management, Rockefeller Center Inc., hadn't the slightest idea of what to do with the great hall, and the state of the place reflected this completely.

title: Restaurants
description: IF we had to wish for only one cookbook to be added to the hundreds already on bookstore shelves, it would be for a work by Hisae Vilca, the extraordinary Japanese woman who has invented an original and highly successful cuisine. Combining cooking elements of Chinese, Japanese, Italian and vegetarian kitchens, she has come up with an unconventional but savory series of menus served in her restaurants, of which there are now four. In addition to the first Hisae's Place on Cooper Square and Hisae's Lobster House on East 37th Street, she has recently opened Hisae's Fish House on 58th Street between Madison and Park Avenues and Hisae's Chelsea Place on Eighth Avenue near 19th Street. The 58th Street location is her largest, poshest and most ambitious effort and it already has the earmarks of a winner. The Chelsea establishment, though still in need of tuning up as far as both cooking and service are concerned, shows considerable promise. All feature primarily fish and vegetable dishes, plus only a few meats.

title: A ConfidentLooking Pope Builds Image as Own Man
description: >ROME, May 31 Like most initiatives by Pope John Paul II since his election six months ago, his visit to Poland, scheduled to begin Saturday, is his own idea. The same could be said of his first encyclical, on theological principles; his decision to build a swimming pool at his summer residence, and his letter to priests cautioning them against dropping out.

title: Broadway
description: EVER since Dracula, it has been a certainty there would be Frankenstein. How could there not be a Frankenstein? It was as inevitable as a Wednesday matinee. The Frankenstein we are supposed to see next season will be produced by Joe Kipness, who saw it a few Months ago at the LorettoHilton Repertory Theater in St. Louis, and bought it immediately. It is by Victor Gialanella, who is now deep into his rewrites, and it will star Keith Jochim, who will play the monster, or, as he is called in the play, the Creature. Mr. Kipness says that when he saw Mr. Jochim's Creature in St. Louis it scared the goodness gracious out of him, even though it looked nothing like the monster that Boris Karloff and Lon Chaney Jr. played in the movies. Actually, it couldn't because a movie company owns the rights to the, makeup. Mr. Jochim created his own.

title: Events and Openings
description: SUNNYSIDE, directed by Timothy Gallas; starring Joey Trayolta, at the National and other theaters. THE TREE OF WOODEN CLOGS, an Italian film with English subtitles directed by Errnanno Olmi, at the Cinema Studio I Theater.

title: GasAdditive Makers Cited for Price 'signaling
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  The Federal Trade Commission today accused the four companies that make antiknock additives for gasoline of engaging in anticompetitive pricing practices.

title: Computer Finds Absent Parents, Welfare Cheats
description: ALBANY, May 31  Oneforth of the 23,471 parents being sought for abandoning their families to the welfare rolls have been identified as wage earners in a study released today by the state's Department of Taxation and Finance.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: A former sales clerk who patented a socket Wrench that was sold by Sears, Roebuck & Company won a big ruling yesterday in Federal court in Chicago. All profits made on the sale of this wrench, which his lawyer said could amount to more than $60 million, were ordered returned to the inventor. Sears disputed the amount and said it would appeal the ruling.

title: Advertising
description: A MAN of quiet dignity, J. Donald McNamara looks like and dresses like what he is, a proper lawyer.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 11, 8 P.M. RadioWINS, 7:50 P.M.)

title: Combatants in Lebanon Agree to Informal Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 31 A ceasefire went into effect in southern Lebanon today, giving President Elias Sarkis and his aides time to work on strategy to be followed at the United Nations Security Council meeting on the conflict.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Train Dispatchers and Railroads Reach Settlement to Avert Strike
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)  The White House announced today a contract settlement between train dispatchers and 52 railroads, averting the possibility of nationwide rail strike.

title: Umpire's Injury Is Minor
description: MILWAUKEE, May 31  Cliff Johnson of the Yankees has become baseball's Joe Btfsplk. Catastrophe always accompanied the Li'l Abner comicstrip character with the black cloud over his head, and the same seems to be happening to Johnson and those around him.

title: Supplier of Pipe For L. I. Sewers Guilty of Fraud
description: A major contractor for the Southwest Sewer District in Suffolk County, the former president of the company and the plant superintendent were convicted yesterday in Federal District Court in Westbury, L.I., of a charge of conspiring to defraud the Government by making and suppling substandard concrete.

title: Cards Down Crippled Mets, 96
description: ST. LOUIS, May 31 Joe Torre celebrated his second anniversary as manager of the New York Mets today, although celebrated may not be exactly the right word.

title: Economic Indicators Off Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)  The Government's index of leading economic indicators, considered a key measure of the nation's economic health, dropped a record 3.3 percent in April, the Commerce Department reported today, adding to fears that a recession is ahead.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Honor Moore, the poet, feels strongly about the importance of workshops for women writers: They are a way to increase the number of women who write and create an audience for them. Miss Moore herself has been leading writing workshops for women since 1976 at the Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack. To help keep this program going, she will give a benefit performance, reading from her own works, tonight at 8. Tickets are $4. From New York, take the Palisades Parkway to Exit 5; go north on Route 303 to Route 59 east. The Rockland Center is at 2729 Old Greenbush Road, off the service road. Information: (914) 3580877.

title: Richard Henney, 60; Served as the Director Of Duke Endowment
description: Richard B. Henney, executive director of Duke Endowment, a large, private philanthropic foundation, died Wednesday at. New York Hospital after a short illness. He was 60 years old.

title: 3 Firms Agree In Homex Pact
description: The brokerage firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith and the accounting firms of Peat Marwick Mitchell & Company and Harris Kerr Forster & Company said yesterday that they have agreed to a $10.5 million settlement of claims by stockholders of the bankrupt Stirling Homex Corporation.

title: Business and the Law
description: WHEN Wall Street law firms and lawyers have reached such celebrity status that they are considered to be suitable copy for gossip columns it is probably time to pause for reflection. The latest example of hype occurred in the past week when The American Lawyer. an iconoclastic new publication about lawyers, carried an article about five law firms on the way down. In the spirit of balance, the article was gracious enough to suggest ways these firms can reverse their fortunes. But the hype was there. First came a mass mailing promoting the article. Then came a mention in a gossip column or two in newspapers of general circulation.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Concerto for Trumpet.and Strings, Vivaldi; Lohengrin, Prelude to Act 1, Wagner; Sink:Dia for 4 Trumpets, Oboes, and Strings, Torelli.

title: HARRY H. WOLF SR.
description: Harry H. Wolf Sr., who was chairman of Jockey International Inc., of Kenosha, Wis., died Monday in Chicago. He was 89 years old. He served with the company for 49 years and was its chairman emeritus of the board of directors. He joined the underwear manufacturing concern as a board member in 1930 and served as chairman from 1958 to 1976. In 1915, he and his brother, George D. Wolf, founded Wolf and Company, a Chicagobased accounting firm. Mr. Wolf also established the Wolf Management Engineering Company, a consulting firm also based in Chicago, in 1942.

title: Nation of Zimbabwe Rhodesia Is Proclaimed and Muzorewa Hails Black Victory
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Friday, June 1 A quarter of a million reluctant and uncertain whites formally ended nearly nine decades of domination today and came under a limited form of majority rule. They are honing that blackled coalition Goverrimint can somehow end a devastating guerrilla struggle and restore to them the colonialstyle prosperity that the war has sapped.

title: Market Place
description: THOSE high interest rates on shortterm money instruments may taper off soon, as many expect. If they do, investors will have to decide on a course of action as their securities fall due.

title: DC.10 Returns to Kennedy Airport
description: In what the authorities described as a routine incident, a National Airlines DC10 widebodied jet bound for Amsterdam with 237 persons aboard lost power in its port engine 19 minutes after taking off from Kennedy International Airport last night, but returned on the power of its tail and starboard engines and landed safely.

title: Goodbye, Little Chips
description: EXETER, N.H.  It's a day when we find ourselves lost in reflection.

title: GUIDELINES WILL STAY
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Even though it appeared to have lost the withholding of Government contracts as an enforcement device, the White House declared today that it would carry on with its voluntary standards for price and pay restraints.

title: Neil Jacoby, 69, Dies
description: Dr. Neil H. Jacoby, a prominent economist who taught at the University of California at Los Angeles and served on President Eisenhower's Council of Economic Advisers, died of a heart attack yesterday at the U.C.L.A Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Connors Sharp in Easy Victory
description: PARIS, May 31  Jimmy Connors played impeccable tennis today, winning his second match of the French open, 61, 61, 69, from 18yearold Ramesh Krishnan of India.

title: U.S. Gets Nigerian Warning
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)  State Department officials said today that Nigeria had sent a diplomatic note warning the United States of an appropriate response it it lifted economic sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia. The officials said the note had not mentioned specifically a halt in Nigerian oil deliveries, but they did not discount such a possibility.

title: Kostelanetz to Conduct An AllRussian Concert
description: Alexander Konstantinovich Glazunov, Sergei Vasilevich Rachmaninoff, Reinhold Moritzovich Gliere and Igor Fyodorovich Stravinsky are the composers whose works make up the allRussian program being played by the New York Philharmonic at 8 tonight and tomorrow in Avery Fisher Hall. The program was put together and is being conducted by Andre Kostelanetz, himself of Russian birth, who was on speaking terms with three of them and corresponded with the fourth.

title: Dodgers 12, Giants 10
description: LOS ANGELES, May 31 (AP) Steve Garvey slugged a homer, double and single and drove in four runs and Dave Lopes walloped three doubles as the Los Angeles Dodgers pounded San Francisco, 1210, today, handing the Giants their sixth consecutive setback.

title: Key Bedford Hills Murder Suspect May Have Worked in the Vicinity
description: One of the principal suspects in the murder of four residents of the suburban village of Bedford Hills once worked as handyman in the affluent northern Westchester County area, a member of the task force investigating the crime said yesterday.

title: Business Loans Up a Bit in New York
description: Commercial and industrial loans at the 10 leading New York City banks rose by a paltry $4 million in the week ended May 30, in sharp contrast to rise of $1.04 billion in the comparable week last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York renortM vperprflny Meanwhile, borrowings by nonfinancial companies in the commercial paper market declined by $866 million in the week ended May 23, according to the Fed. In the same week, business loans outstanding at all large banks in the United States outside New York were up $122 million.

title: New Face: Treat Williams He Didn't Get Into a Role, but Under It
description: MORE than one performer broodingly carries his fictional alter ego around inside his head. But when Treat Williams was filming Hair, he had to carry the character of Berger, the Medusatressed counterculture chieftain, around painfully on top of his head.

title: Savings Bank Aides Meet Carter Officials on Rates
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Carter Administration officials are meeting with representatives of mutual savings banks in New York City amid growing concern over the impact on savings banks of yesterday's Federal decision to raise interestrate ceilings on passbook savings accounts.

title: F.G. Rohatyn Weds Elizabeth Vagliano
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, a senior partner in the investment banking house of Lazard Freres & Company, and Elizabeth Vagliano were married last evening at the bridegroom's apartment. Surrogate Millard L. Midortck performed the ceremony.

title: Greyhound Sold For $60,000
description: Joe Fallon used to drive a bulldozer at the city dump in Silver Springs, Fla. He retired four years ago to raise racing greyhounds, and one of the first litters he bred was born on April Fool's Day. He named one of the pups Joe Dump.

title: About Real Estate
description: Alfred Tredway White, the 19thcentury Brooklyn merchant and philanthropist, would be pleased. The model workmen's tenements that he built in the 1870's around a landscaped inner courtyard in Cobble Hill are in the midst of a rehabilitation oroiect.

title: Indonesia Gets Loan Package
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (Reuters)The World Bank and its affiliate, the International Development Agency, today announced loans and credits for Indonesia totaling $368 million to help finance three major development protects.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.1A.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: For Long Island, Gasoline Crisis Is Changing a Way of Life
description: The continuing shortage of gasoline and its rapid rise in price are seriously altering the economy and way of life on Long Island, where the facts of geography and the history of development have set its 2.8 million residents apart from the rest of the state in their heayy dependence on the automobile.

title: SOVIET SAID TO ASK SPACE SHUTTLE HALT
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Government officials said today that the Soviet Union had called for a halt in the development of the American space shuttle, virtually ruling out the possibility of an early accord limiting antisatellite weapons.

title: Kennedy Speaks Before 3 Groups In a Visit to City
description: With talk of a challenge to President Carter at its height, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, made three politically significant appearances in the New York area yesterday, all the while disclaiming any Presidential ambitions.

title: 450,000 Volkswagens Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)  Volkswagen is recalling 450,000 standard transmission models of its 19751978 automobiles because of a defect that could cause the cars to start themselves and begin moving. The recall of Rabbit and Scirocco models was undertaken after the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration received 15 complaints of burned or shorted wires in the engine compartment.

title: Asseciated Press
description: MOUNTAINEERING TRAGEDY IN ALASKA: Workers placed the bodies of two Korean mountain climbers aboard an Army helicopter Wednesday, preparing to remove them from Mount McKinley. The climbers died after 2,500foot falls at the 17,000foot level Tuesday while descending the 20,320foot peak. They were members of sixman expedition that climbed the mountain Tuesday. Mount McKinley is the highest peak in North America.

title: Pat Bradley's 66 Leads Tourney
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 31 Pat Bradley shot a magnificent 66 and equaled a Ladies Professional Golf Association record with a frontnine 29 today to take a onestroke lead after the first round of the Golden Lights tournament at the Wykagvl Country Club.

title: Stage: IRemember Mama
description: DSPITE all the large and estimable names that are or have been associated with I Remember Mama, the result is not a marriage but a divorce of talents.

title: Padres 3, Braves 1
description: SAN DIEGO, May 31 (UPI)  Dave Winfield hit his 11th home run and raised his leagueleading total to 41 runs batted in and Eric Rasmussen and Rollie Fingers combined to pitch a fivehitter today to help the San Diego Padres post a 31 victory over the Atlanta Braves and a sweep of a fourgame series.

title: Ballet: Baryshnikov In Balanchine Jewels
description: HAPPINESS is George Balanchine's threepart plotless ballet Jewels when it is danced as excitingly as it was Wednesday night at the New York State Theater by the. New York City Ballet.

title: Lift the Sanctions On Rhodesia, Gradually
description: Should the United States lift the'economic sanctions on Rhodesia? Yes, but gradually, as Zimbabwe is further democratized by its new black Government.

title: Irene Worth Finds Beckett Uplifting
description: Irene Worth had just come from costume fitting. Or was it a scenery fitting? In Samuel Beckett's Happy Days, which begins previews tonight at 8 at the Public Theater in a production directed by Andrei Serban, Miss Worth plays the indefatigable Winnie. In the first act she is buried up to her waist in a mound of earth; in the second act she is buried up to her neck. That afternoon, during a break in rehearsal, she had been measured for the mound.

title: Twins 13. A's 2
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 31 (AP)  Ron Jackson drove in four runs and seven other Twins had at least one run batted in as Minnesota routed the Oakland A's, 132, today.

title: Country Fair at Purchase
description: Purchase has long been a small part of the Town of Harrison, but its annual Country Fair  tomorrow and Sunday from 11 A.M. To 4 P.M., rain or shineis rapidly becoming a major part of Westchester's spring season of events. ucxea into the treeshaded campus of Manhattanville College, the twoday festival offers displays and demonstrations, games of luck and skill, an antiques flea market with 120 dealers, sales of books and records, jazz and marching bands and, of course, varieties of good things to eat.

title: U.S. IMPOSES QUOTAS ON CHINESE TEXTILES
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  The United States imposed quotas today on five categories of textile imports from China after Robert S. Strauss, the Administration's special trade negotiator, failed to win the agreement of the Chinese to limit sales in this country.

title: PROBLEMS DETECTED IN ENGINE MOUNTING ON 37 DC10 PLANES
description: Airline mechanics have found problems in the engine mounts of 37 of the 137 DCb jetliners operated by United States airlines, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

title: Accounting Data Urged On Inflation
description: Harold M. Williams, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, criticized industry leaders yesterday for resisting accounting changes that he said might help investors understand the effects of inflation on profits.

title: U. S. Allies Welcome Arms Treaty But Seek Bigger Role in New Talks
description: THE HAGUE, May 31 The Western allies said today that they welcomed the latest SovietAmerican treaty limiting strategic arms but insisted in private that they be allowed to play a more active role in formulating policy when the next round of arms talks begins next year.

title: Topics Culture Gaps
description: The Jewish Museum has raised an issue that need not have been raised at all, certainly not by the museum and not in New York City, which, if it is nothing else, is a community so committed to freedom that it sometimes tolerates license.

title: Absolution for Our Playwrights
description: I Iwould like to absolve our hardworking playwrights of one charge that is lately being leveled at them. Everywhere I go, it seems, I hear a little sneer. Contemporary playwrights deliberately restrict their acting companies to a measly two or  at most  three people in order to keep costs down and thereby guarantee themselves a production. People at parties say it, intelligent university students say it, it's the current fashion in polite slander.

title: Miss Mason, 19 Jazzmen In Concert at 92d Street Y
description: Nineteen jazz musicians from the metropolitan area will appear with Marilyn Mason, the singer, in a concert on Sunday at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, Lexington Avenue at 92d Street.

title: Hawke Sees Issue Being Studied
description: GENEVA, May 31. Robert Hawke, the Australian labor leader, who is attending a session of the International Labor Organization here, said today that the eased emigration conditions he had discussed in Moscow were apparently still under consideration.

title: Exxon Supply Level Set
description: HOUSTON, May 31 (Reuters)  The Exxon Corporation's Exxon USA subsidiary, the nation's largest supplier of gasoline, said yesterday that it would provide about the same amount of gasoline to customers in June as it did in May, and that June supplies would total almost 93 percent of the amount sold in the same month last year.

title: Notes on People
description: When Kay Boyle finally got hold of her security files recently, under the Freedom of Information Act, she read in the nearly 2,000 pages that she had a clandestine affair with Ezra Pound before World War I, she said yesterday.

title: Miss Hutton, R. J. Murphy Have Nuptials
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday, Cynthia Lyon Hutton and Robert John Murphy, 1979 alumni of Boston College, were married by Msgr. James C. Wildem.

title: Nancy Lopez TakesLead by 3 on 70137
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 1 Nancy Lopez established herself as the best player on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour last year when she won nine tournaments as a rookieand set an L.P.G.A. moneyearnings record. She had a game so strong that it hardly seemed to need improvement.

title: Teamster Movers and Shakers
description: The recent conviction of two New York teamster union officials, who demanded bribes to permit a moving company to do business with workers of another union, was a welcome blow against labor racketeering in this region. But the case also exposed a distressing deficiency in New York State law that makes it difficult to prosecute comparable but less direct forms of extortion.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Entertainment Events
description: Entertainment

title: I Hate Him. I Wish I Could Kill Him.
description: WASHINGTON  I am scared all the time now when I am on the streets.

title: VacaValley Park Sold in California
description: ForemostMcKesson Inc. said its subsidiary, the Crocker Land Company, had sold its 1,700acre industrial park site known as VacaValley Industrial Park for $9 million to the Chevron Land and Development Company, Chevron U.S.A. and the Standard Oil Company of California.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Charismatics to Rally for Day of Prayer
description: Large rallies are scheduled for today at Shea Stadium and Giants Stadium as part of an international day of prayer by charismatic renewal groups, a Christian movement emphasizing the spirit of God among men.

title: Fox's Alien Grosses 4.7 Million in First Week
description: LOS ANGELES, June 1  Alien 20th CenturyFox's sciencefiction movie about a monstrous life form let loose aboard a spaceship has grossed $4,758,639 during its first week, a staggering average of $52,292 for each of the 91 theaters in which it is playing. In

title: Going Out
description: SHORE THING Seasonal entertainment will start tomorrow at the South Street Seaport Museum, the historical area around Fulton and Front Streets, with a variety program of musicians, magicians, clowns, dancers and other specialists performing free for visitors from noon to 5 P.M. on the museum's new Pier 15. The 700foot structure juts out into the East River, flanked by two standby ships, the fourmasted Peking and the Wavertree.

title: 2 American Airlines 727 Jetliners Land Despite Cockpit Difficulties
description: SYRACUSE, June 1 (AP)  Two American Airlines 727 jetliners landed safely here last night after experiencing trouble with landinggear indicator lights in their cockpits during final approaches to Hancock Airport, a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman said today.

title: Argentine Economy Growing Again, But the Price Is Renewed Inflation
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 1  The Argentine economy has emerged from the recession that blighted growth last year, but at a high price in terms of renewed inflation.

title: Crane's Tactic: Defense of Oil Industry
description: AMES, Iowa, May 31  Representative Philip M. Crane, the selfstyled early bird of the Republican Presidential race who also has faced the campaign's first major staff upheaval, is trying to show that the resignations of many on his staff have not made his candidacy an endangered species, a victim of the longest campaign.

title: Arab Ayatollah Says Iran Mistreats All Minorities
description: KHURRAMSHAHR, Iran, June 1 (Reuters)  The spiritual leader of Iran's Arabs accused the Government today of depriving all minorities of their rights, as shooting broke out between Arabs and proGovernment forces for the third consecutive day.

title: Sambo's Expects Loss for Quarter
