description: Sambo's Resturants Inc, a fullservice restaurant chain, said it expected net loss for the first quarter ended March 31 of 20 cents to 25 cents a share, compared with a profit of 23 cents share in the similar period last year.

title: College Will Study the Drinker
description: SEATTLE, June 1 (AP)  Drinks are on the house at the University of Washington's new $12,000 cocktail lounge.

title: Dance: Many Moods of Bruce Michael Weitzmon
description: Bruce Michael Weitzmon's dances often had interesting beginnings. But they seldom had interesting middles or came to interesting conclusions.

title: China Reported Canceling Pacts
description: TOKYO, June 1 (AP)  China has asked for the cancellation of two of the 22 contracts with Japanese concerns that it froze in February after a major redirection of the Chinese economic plan, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported today.

title: Murder Inquiry in Boy's Death
description: An 8yearold boy found dead yesterday in a bathtub in a vacant apartment in the Bronx building where he lived apparently was murdered, the authorities said. An autopsy was to be performed today. The boy, Tony Dinkins of 2119 Valentine Ave. nue, was found nude in the bathtub, said the police, who thought at first that he had drowned. But an associate medical examiner found injuries on the boy's body, and the case is now being treated as a homicide, Dr. Michael M. Baden, the city's chief medical examiner said.

title: Hedley Donovan, the Chief At Time Magazine, Retires
description: In the late 1950's, when Henry R. Luce was still editor in chief of Time Inc. and Hedley Donovan was managing editor of Fortune, Mr. Luce arrived at a lunch with his colleagues in great good humor, explaining that he had spent all morning arguing with Mr. Donovan about a taxreform story. With great satisfaction Mr. Luce announced to his colleagues, I couldn't budge him an inch.

title: BUSINESS
description: The Economy

title: Finance Is New Star of Moviemaking
description: CANNES, France  Multimillion. dollar deals are as commonplace here as topless starlets on the beach. During the recent Cannes Film Festival the air hummed with talk of coproductions, foreign tax shelters, intricate distribution sales and multinational productions.

title: Lockheed Guilty on Payments
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  The Lockheed Corporation pleaded guilty today to having concealed $2.6 million in payments from 1972 to 1974 to Japanese Government and business officials, including a $1.8 million payment that allegedly went to the office of Kakuei Tanaka, then the Prime Minister.

title: Council Moves to Add Funds for Schools and Libraries
description: The City Council countered Mayor Koch's budget proposal with one of its own yesterday, calling for more money for the Board of Education, the FIre Department and the city's libraries.

title: MAY'S JOBLESS RATE IS LEVEL DESPITE DIP IN ECONOMY'S VIGOR
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  The level of unemployment remained unchanged last month, Indicating that the recent slowing of the nation's economic growth has still not caused any appreciable loss of jobs.

title: New Construction Rose 1% in April
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) New construction in April rose 1 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $214.9 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Dow Slips by 1.12 Points; Volume Off, at 24.6 Million
description: Strength in oil stocks and possible takeover situations continued to steal the spotlight on Wall Street yesterday as bluechip issues moved slightly lower.

title: Pilot Walks Away From East 60th Street Heliport Crash
description: A fourpassenger Augusta 109 helicopter after it crashed yesterday afternoon at the East 60th Street heliport on the East River. The pilot, Elias D. Ullmann Hialeah, Fla., walked away from the crash with superficial facial wounds. The helicopter's tail was sheared by the impact. Flamedousing foam surrounds the craft.

title: William Simmons Weds Gale Duncan
description: Gale Duncan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Duncan of New York and Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to William Barry Simmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. William Simmons of Pasadena, Calif. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: 3 Women Share Golf Prize
description: CONVENT STATION, N.J., June 1Mrs. Peter Winans of Canoe Brook, Mrs. Lee Beard of Essex Fells and Mrs. Percy Pyne of Somerset Hills shot 84's today to share the top prize in a Women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament at the Morris County Golf Club. Mrs. Richard Smith of the host club took the net on a 912071, two strokes better than Mrs. Dennis Brown of Rumson (881573).

title: Around the Nation
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 1 (UPI) William A. Spradley and Roy McLemore, the two Houston men held in Colombia on charges of violating that country's air space, have paid $60,000 in fines, lawyers fees and hospital bills and were planning to return to the United States on the first available plane, Mr. McLemore said in a telephone interview today.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 1 (AP) The Kaiser Steel Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its share of an Australian ironoreproducing company for $207.5 million to Conzinc Riotinto of Australia.

title: Business Chiefs Call Guidelines Ineffective
description: Business leaders said yesterday that the removal of economic sanctions from the Administration's program of wage and price guidelines would make little difference to the program. But they reiterated their pledge to comply with the guidelines  and expressed the belief that the program had not been effective.

title: Salvador Leftists Free 6 Embassy Hostages, Then Leave Country
description: SAN SALVADOR, June 1 (AP)  Leftwing rebels of the Popular Revolutionary Bloc ended their occupation of the French and Venezuelan Embassies today and freed the French Ambassador and five other hostages held since May 4. The leftists were then flown out of the country.

title: U.S. Assails Rises In Prices for Lead
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) The Government charged today that major producers of lead had used technicalities to get around its antiinflation price guidelines and had put into effect price increases that were clearly inflationary.

title: France to Seek Accords Governing Delivery of Plutonium for Industry
description: PARIS, June 1  France has decided to seek international agreement on rules governing plutonium deliveries for industrial use, Foreign Minister Jean FranoisPoncet said yesterday.

title: Old Male Ways Change at West Point
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., June 1  The old soldiers of the United States Military Academy marched slowly and proudly across the parade grounds today, as they do at this reunion period every year, to the tune of When Johnny Comes Marching Home. It is the high point of June Week, but this is the last June Week.

title: Labor Drifting Back Into Carter's Camp
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  Organized labor, often at swords points with the Carter Administration, is starting to drift back into the President's political camp.

title: McGrawHill And ABC Sued
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 1 (UPI)The American Broadcasting Companies and two other companies were sued today for $33 million by a television station that lost its ABC affiliation to another outlet.

title: Very Regal Togs
description: If Rowes of Bond Street Limited has its way, young New Yorkers will be walking around looking like proper English children this fall and winter. Jill Savage, a representative of the venerable London shop, Is in town until June 10 to take orders for the custommade smocked dresses, romper suits and matching overcoat and hat combinations that are its stock in trade.

title: Scott Vincent, 57, an Announcer On WABCTV Eyewitness News
description: Scott Vincent, an announcer for WABCTV's Eyewitness News show and other programs, died Thursday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. He was 57 years old.

title: Suspect Accused Of Slaying Man In Gasoline Line
description: A 23year student bartender was arrested yesterday on charges of fatally shooting another motorist at a gasoline. station while jockeying for a place in line to buy gasoline in Brooklyn Thursday night.

title: U.S. Judge Who Ruled Against Carter No Novice in Curbing Those in Power
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  When Judge Barrington Daniels Parker ruled yesterday that the way President Carter was trying to enforce wageprice guidelines was illegal, it was not the first time that he had moved against the Goverment on constitutional grounds.

title: Photoengravers and Newspapers Plan 11th-Hour Talks on Monday
description: The Publishers Association of New York City and Photoengravers Union IP have scheduled a bargaining session for Monday, on the eve of a threatened strike against The Daily News and The New York Times that has been set for 12:01 A.M. Tuesday.

title: MOSCOW SAYS NIECE OF DISSIDENT CAN GO
description: MOSCOW, June 1  The Soviet Union said today that a niece of Georgi P. Vins, one of five dissidents involved in a prisoner exchange with the United States in April, would be allowed to Join him.

title: Seatrain to Sell 4 Euroclass Ships
description: Seatrain Lines said that it had agreed to sell four Euroclass container ships for $56 million to a German shipowning company managed by the C.F. Akrenkiel Company.

title: PBS Is Planning Specialized TV Networks
description: The concept of Blue and Red networks that originated with the National Broadcasting Company when it operated two radio services has been borrowed by public television in a plan for a radical restructuring of the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: 4 WRITERS IN SOVIET DEFEND OUSTED PAIR
description: MOSCOW, June 1  Four prominent writers have informed the official Union of Soviet Writers that they will resign unless two younger colleagues suspended for taking part in a challenge to censor ship are reinstated, one of the four said today.

title: Danish Ballet Seats Go on Sale Monday
description: Tickets go on sale at the City Center box office on Monday for Soloists of the Royal Danish Ballet, to be seen at City Center from June 19 through July 1. Eleven members of the Danish company will perform full ballets and excerpts from the work of August Hournonville, the 19thcentury Danish choreographer, the centenary of whose death will be celebrated in Copenhagen by the full Royal Danish Ballet in November. Details of the Copenhagen celebration will be announced in New York next Friday.

title: Branding Organ Donors.
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  I am very disturbed by something happening in my home statesomething I can only hope is not a harbinger of things to come across the nation. Here in Rhode Island, the smallest state, we have big plans: our Government is attempting to register all potential organ donors.

title: Cosmos Dismiss Firmani as Coach
description: The Cosmos announced yesterday that Eddie Firman had been dismissed as coach of the North American Soccer League team.

title: Steel Imports Continue Fall
description: PITTSBURGH, June 1 (AP)  Steel imports continued to drop in the first four months of this year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: LAWRENCE T. BARTLETT

title: Muzorewa Urges Black Guerrillas To Accept His Hand of Fellowship
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, June 1 (AP)  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa offered the hand of fellowship to black nationalist guerrillas today only hours after the nation of Zimbabwe Rhodesia was proclaimed.

title: Tenants Fighting Ouster Express Fear
description: In terms of blocks, the building at 129 East 97th Street is not far from the highrise, highrent luxury world of Manhattan's Upper East Side. But, according to the tenants who are resisting the landlord's attempts to vacate the building and demolish it, life there is not unlike life in the South Bronx.

title: Schultze Defends HeatingOil Subsidy
description: PARIS, June 1 The Carter Administration denied today accusations by European and Japanese allies that it was unfairly subsidizing United States oil imports during a time of tight world supplies by reducing the cost of foreign heating and diesel fuels sold in the United States by $5 a barrel.

title: Article 1 - No Title
description: LOOKS FORWARD TO SUMMIT MEETING: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, holding a teddy bear that he presented to the children of a Budapest kindergarten yesterday as he ended a threeday visit to Hungary. Before leaving for Moscow, Mr. Brezhnev made a pledge for an active and constructive dialogue with President Carter in Vienna later this month. He also indicated that the Kremlin may be ready for talks with China.

title: At Store's Final Sale, Credit Slips Rejected
description: Shoppers who went to the Design/ Research store goingoutofbusiness sale, which started yesterday, found that the store would not honor its credit slips or gift certificates. The policy led to confusion and anger among some consumers and illustrated a problem that forthcoming legislation is intended to diminish.

title: For PropertyTax Relief.
description: SPRING. VALLEY,. N.Y.  New York state's property tax is regressive and unfair, but how many people are aware that the New York State Constitution irrationally prevents any consideration of the obvious way to make it fairer?

title: Czechs Upset Ashe, Miss Wade in Paris
description: PARIS, June 1  Upsets were the order of the day at the $485,000 French open tennis tournament today as Virginia Wade, Sue Barker and Arthur Ashe, all seeded players, were beaten.

title: Homosexual Job Rights Upheld
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 (UPI)  The California Supreme Court, in a 4to3 decision handed down yesterday, ruled that the state's public utilities could not discriminate against homosexuals in hiring practices. The court said that a suit brought by the Gay Law Students Association and the Society for Individual Rights had been improperly dismissed by a San Francisco Superior Court. It ordered a new trial. The lawsuit asserts that the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company discriminated against homosexuals in its employment and hiring practices.

title: Supersonics Settle A YearOld Score
description: LANDOVER, Md. June 1  For the Seattle SuperSonics, the sweet smell of champagne and, the sweet feel of vindication filled their dressing room tonight after they became the National Basketball Association champions.

title: May Lines at the Gas Pumps Run Into June
description: Motorists were hoping that a nea month would bring plentiful supplies of gasoline, but many found long lines an short supplies when they got to their neighborhood service stations yesterday. I've got this feeling it's going to be like this all summer, said Anne Greene, as she maneuvered her small car into line at a Mobil station on Northern Boulevard in Great Neck, L.I.

title: League's Offices Shifting to Tunis From Cairo Despite Previous Disputes With Bourguiba
description: TUNISIA, May 28  Tunisia, which a decade ago boycotted the Arab League, is reluctantly becoming the disputatious organization's new host, largely because Arab states that ostracized Egypt from their councils could not agree on any other location for a new headquarters.

title: U.S. Indicts 7 Ship Lines, 13 Executives on Pricing
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury indicted five major American and European shipping companies, two consortiums and 13 executives today on pricefixing charges.

title: VOTELAW CHARGES AT PAPER DISMISSED,
description: DULUTH, Minn., June 1 (AP)  A judge has dismissed indictments charging The Duluth Herald and NewsTribune, its parent company and several top management officials with violations of the election law.

title: Three Mile Island Nuclear Plant Was Exempt From Radiation Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  The Three Mile Island nuclear power plant was exempt from a set of Federal rules that had been revised and strengthened to prevent radiation leakage during reactor accidents, Nuclear Regulatory Commission officials said today.

title: About New York
description: Dear Friend, Buck Rogers wrote on blue stationery 35 years ago in return for a label. It is a real pleasure to send you my cutout book and radio stage. But what pleases me more is the fact that you are drinking Cocomalt.

title: A Retirement Home That Retains a Bit Of Hollywood Dazzle
description: WOODLAND HILLS, Calif.  They stop and stare, bent figures with white hair, searching for a glimpse of their careers in some of the many faded movie posters that decorate the rooms at the Motion Picture Country Home.

title: Earnings Results
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Concert: Russian Ballet Suites
description: Although no dancers were present at the New York Ph'harmonic's Music in May concert conducted by Andre Kostelanetz in Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, it came close to being an allballet evening. The program, exclusively Russian, included suites from two scores written for ballets, Glazunov's The Seasons and Stravinsky's The Firebird, plus Rachmaninoff's Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini, which has served as the basis for two ballets, both called Paganini. The one other piece presented was Glire's Concerto for Coloratura Soprano and Orchestra, which, for all this writer knows, may have been used for a ballet, too, even if the prospects seem unlikely.

title: Mets Turn Back Braves in 11 Innings, 54
description: ATLANTA, June 1 Ed Glynn used to sell hot dogs in Shea Stadium. Until noon today he was a pitcher in the Minor leagues. Tonight he took the mound for the Mets and held off the Braves in Atlanta Stadium to pick up a save in his major league debut.

title: Amoco Cutting June Deliveries
description: CHICAGO June 1 (Reuters) The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the nation's biggest domestic oil refiner, announced today that it would reduce its gasoline deliveries in June because of a shortage of crude oil.

title: Allocation of Gas Under Attack
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  Gasoline has become a prized commodity in some parts of the country, as evidenced by the long filling station lines that have occurred in California. But in Atlanta and other places gasoline remains plentiful and stations still stay open late into the night.

title: Mary Jarman Wed To G.M. Grosvenor
description: Mary Helen Wiley Jarman was married in Washington yesterday to Gilbert M. Grosvenor, editor of National Geographic magazine. Bishop John T. Walker of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul (the Washington Cathedral).

title: CARTER CASTIGATES MOBIL ON DECONTROL
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  President Carter today called the Mobil Corporation perhaps the most irresponsible company in America for opposing phased decontrol of domestic oil price.

title: Aides Say Carter Is Urged To Replace Schlesinger
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  Senior members of President Carter's staff have advised him that his Secretary of Energy, James R. Schlesinger, has become a political liability and should be replaced, according to Administration officials.

title: Stage: Gilda Radner Sets Broadway Debut
description: Gilda Radner will make her Broadway debut in Live From New York, opening Aug. 1 at the Winter Garden Theater. Miss Radner appeared Off Broadway four years ago in The Na tional Lampoon Show and has since become known for her Saturday Night Live television appearances on NBC.

title: Notes on People.
description: Ernest L. Boyer has put in an early. resignation as United States Commissioner of Education to avoid running up against a new law intended to prohibit former Government regulatory officials from getting jobs with companies and institutions they formerly regulated.

title: Suit Settlement Set by Argent
description: The Argent Corporation said it had agreed with some holders of its 10 percent sinking fund subordinated debentures to increase the interest rate on the debentures and create a cash fund of $300,000 in settlement of a classaction suit filed in Delaware.

title: Off Center Theater Plans Two June Productions
description: Biting the Apple, a comedy about neighberhood improvement featuring F. Murray Abraham, and Just for Fun  the Music of Jerome Kern are the next two presentations of the Off Center Theater.

title: Your Money VariableRate Mortgage Rules
description: MOVES taken earlier this week by Federal regulatory authorities, if they they are not overturned by Congress, will modestly increase interest rates paid to small savers while introducing a new and somewhat confusing element into the national mortgage field.

title: Red Brigades in Genoa Burn Car Of Woman They Covered in Glue
description: GENOA, Italy, June 1 (AP)  Red Brigades terrorists set fire today to the car of Rosella Sborgi, the Christian Democrat councilor they humiliated last week by covering with glue and then robbing and leaving handcuffed with a sign around her neck.

title: Washington Star to Start A Morning Edition July 9
description: The competition between the morning Washington Post and the afternoon Washington Star intensified yesterday as The Star announced that it would begin publication of a morning edition July 9, joining a trend toward allday newspapers.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: GIATTISanta. On May 31, 1979. At Boca Raton Florida. Formerly of Ridgewood New Jersey & New York City. Wife of the late Valentino Giatti, dear aunt of Louis Ferrera. Friends may call at The Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th St, Garden City, Saturday & Sunday 25 & 79PM. Funeral mass St. Thomas The Apostle Church, West Hempstead, Monday 11AM. Interment Hohokus New Jersey.

title: French Name Cup Entry
description: PARIS, June 1 (Reuters)  The Alsacian Club of Strasbourg won the French soccer championship tonight and gained a berth in next year's European Cup.

title: Autos Are Barred From Warsaw And Altar Is Built for Papal Visit
description: WARSAW, Tuesday, June 2  The Polish capital was sealed to all private traffic at midnight as the authorities braced for the arrival of Pope John Paul II later today.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS BEGIN MAJOR DRIVE
description: MEXICO CITY, June 1  After months of simmering civil war, Nicaragua's powerful guerrilla movement has opened a longexpected offensive to overthrow the Government of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: White House List For Energy Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)  Following is a list released by the White House of those who were invited to today's con- sumer energy meeting:

title: ExG.S.A. Worker Gets 6 Months on Kickbacks
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)  A Federal judge sent a former General Services Administration employee to jail today for his role in the agency's nationwide kickback scandal.

title: Nehemiah Takes Title Swiftly
description: CHAMPAIGN, ILL., June 1  It was the fastest high hurdles time in history under automatic timing conditions, an astonishing 12.91 seconds. If a slight gust of wind had not blown down the track halfway into the race, Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah would have set another world record tonight.

title: Bridge:
description: Two favored teams took narrow leads into the second half of the Reisinger semifinals at the Beverly Hotel yesterday with 28 boards to play. The team of Peter Leventritt of New York City led that of John Roberts, also of New York City, by 70 to 57, and the team of John Schwenke of North Palm Beach, Fla., had a 95to80 lead over that of Paul Trent of New York City.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: SHUTOUT FORM: Ron. Guidry on his way to winning a 40, twohit shutout for Yankees against the White Sox last night at the Stadium.

title: Local TV and Terrorism Alter Itaiian Campaigns
description: ROME, June 1  Photographers have injected a touch of humor into the Italian election campaign.

title: Guidry's TwoHitter Stops White Sox, 40
description: Perhaps if Ron Guidry had had good night's rest he might have done better. without sleep for 48 hours, thanks to one of those allnight trips that sometimes plague professional sports teams, the lefthander spun a twohitter last night, striking out 10 batters in the Yankees 40 victory over the Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadium.

title: Queries and Answers on Airplane Design Standards
description: LOS ANGELES, June 1  Like all modern jet transports, the DC10 airliner that crashed last week in Chicago was designed as a compromise between economics, performance, rigid attention to safety, technical tradeoffs, and at least a statistical gamble involving the lives of the people it carried.

title: Panel Votes for Restricting Use Of TaxExempt Housing Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI)  The House Ways and Means Committee agreed Thursday to impose restrictions on the use of municipal taxexempt industrial development bonds to finance multifamily housing projects.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, June 2

title: Money
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 1, 1979

title: The City
description: Police officials said yesterday that three men who speak Spanish with a Panamanian accent were suspects in the murder of 19yearold Diane Johnson, who was shot to death Thursday because she cried during the robbery of a Brooklyn grocery store.

title: Eric Partridge, Expert on English And Lover of Its Quirks, Is Dead
description: Eric Partridge, the noted lexicographer whom Edmund Wilson called the word king, died yesterday in his home in southwest England. The New Zealandborn, Oxfordtrained expert on slang, catch phrases, clichs, first names and other ornaments and oddments of the English language was 85 years old.

title: 2 Astronomers Report Milky Way Is Circled By Cloud of Hot Gas
description: MADISON, Wis., June 1 (UPI)  Discovery of a cloud of very hot gas surrounding the Milky Way Galaxy has been announced by astronomers at the University of WisconsinMadison.

title: Mexico to Allow Shah To Visit for 3 Months After Leaving Nassau
description: MEXICO CITY, June 1  The Mexican Government announced today that it had authorized the exiled Shah of Iran to visit Mexico on a tourist visa valid for three months.

title: Spain Reassures Vance on NATO But No Date Is Sets for Membership
description: MADRID, June 1  Spain reassured the United States today that it intended to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization but gave no indication when it would make formal application.

title: Life on the Pond: Wading Until the Wings Grow Strong
description: A pair of swans with their brood, foraging yesterday in a pond on the outskirts of Highland, N.Y. For the past four years, when pond thaws, a pair of swans has come to have their brood and feed on the bounty of the pool and the generosity of the townspeople. The cygnets are born around Mother's Day and paddle about the pond until October, when they are taught to fly. When winter turns, the family leaves, and the following year, another pair returns.

title: Ad Touts Mausoleum's Mileage
description: Death and the Gasoline Shortage is the subject of an advertisement placed by Trinity Church, the 300yearold Episcopal parish in lower Manhattan, to help sell final resting places in its new 5,100space high rise mausoleum at 153d Street and Riverside Drive, overlooking the Hudson River.

title: 'sweeney and Elephant Man Win Top Drama Desk Awards
description: Sweeney Todd and The Elephant Man won several awards in the 197879 Drama Desk's voting. The Drama Desk, an association of New York drama reporters, editors and critics, selected Bernard Pomerance's The Elephant Man as the season's outstanding riew play and the Stephen Sondheim musical Sweeney Todd, as the best production of a musical.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: GIVE TO THE FRESH AIR FUND

title: Club Pros Get a ChanceTo Play in Dodge Open
description: DENVILLE, N.J., June 1Club professionals spend the bulk of their time teaching the game of golf to club members, running their pro shops and seeing to it that the members are happy with the playing conditions of the courses.

title: NASA Reports on Plans To Control Skylab's Fall
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that it is proceeding with plans that could give it some control over where the Skylab space station will fall when it reenters the atmosphere in the next four to seven weeks.

title: Barn 13 Is Home For Bid
description: Bud Delp moved the Bid & Bud talk show from Maryland to New York yesterday, but the monologue remained unchanged.

title: 10 Jailed for Athens Bomb Blasts And for Forming Terrorist Group
description: ATHENS, June 1 (UPI)  Ten people, including an American citizen, were convicted by an Athens court today of forming a rightwing terrorist organization and setting off bomb explosions. They were sentenced to prison terms of from 10 months to life. One defendant, a junior army officer, was acquitted.

title: Soviet Soldier Flees in Berlin
description: WEST BERLIN, June 1 (Reuters) 21yearold Soviet soldier fled to West Berlin two weeks ago, it was disclosed here today. West Berlin sources said that the soldier, wearing civilian clothes, had reached the American sector of the divided city by crossing the border wall at a construction site. The soldier said dissatisfaction with living conditions was the reason he decided to defect, the sources said.

title: Pope Returning to Poland Today At a Crucial Time for Its Church
description: WARSAW, June 1  On a mission that is expected to have a longlasting impact on his homeland, Pope John Paul II will pay a visit to Poland tomorrow, the first by a Pope to a Communist country. Church leaders and public officials expect the nineday visit, which will take the Pope to eight cities and towns, to touch off outbursts of emotion. While all are doing their best to play down the social and political aspects of the visit, which is technically to close a synod that the Pope opened as Archbishop of Cracow, it is likely to have profound effects on the life of the church and its role as a dynamic force for change in Eastern Europe.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: MILTON FOX

title: Boston: City of Culture With Unusual Racial Woes
description: BOSTON, June 1  The picture of itself that Boston likes best is that of an urbane and cultured city of manageable size that had some trouble with race relations a fete years ago but is now probably no better and no worse in that regard than most 1 other American cities.

title: Holdup Defendant Is Released
description: Joseph Marino, the alleged getaway driver in the $2.2 million robbery of a Wells Fargo truck on Staten Island last December, has been released on $100,000 bail over the objections of prosecutors.

title: Norman Fein Is Stepping Down As News Director of WNBCTV
description: Norman Fein, the news director of WNBCTV, announced to the station's news staff Thursday that he was stepping down.

title: Bedford's Police Seeking to Link Deaths, Suspects
description: Teams of policemen spent another day yesterday knocking on the doors of the estates in Bedford Hills, an affluent village in northern Westchester County, asking residents if they could identify photographs of the men suspected of having murdered four residents three weeks ago.

title: Freighter, Abandoned by Crew, In Nautical Limbo Off Brooklyn
description: She sloughed into port in New York a month ago, a battered, darkhulled mystery freighter with a ragtag crew, an unknown cargo and an unknown mission. No one knows where she came from or where she was bound. It was to be only a brief layover, perhaps overnight.

title: A Partridge Sampler
description: CLICHE. A clich is an outworn commonplace; a phrase (or virtual phrase) that has become so hackneyed that scrupulous speakers and writers shrink from it because they feel that its use is an insult to the intelligence of their auditor or audience, reader or public. A coin so battered by use as to be defaced (George Baker). They range from flyblown phrases (explore every avenue) through sobriquets that have lost all point and freshness (Iron Duke), to quotations that have become debased currency (cups that cheer but not inebriate), metaphors that are now pointless, and formulas that have become mere counters (far be it from me to ...).

title: Syracuse Varsity Eight Qualifies for Regatta Final
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y.. June 1  The Syracuse University varsity crew qualified today for the finals of the intercollegiate rowing championships and thus established a rooting interest tomorrow for many in the crowd of 25,000 expected to fill the verdant park along the shore of Onondaga Lake.

title: China May Lei foreigners Own Plants
description: HONG KONG, Tune 1  In an important step to attract more foreign investment for its modernization program, Peking is prepared to consider 100 percent foreign ownership of joint ventures in China, an American legal expert says.

title: New Radio City Music Hall Format Draws Crowds
description: Radio City'Music Hall looked yesterday morning as it did in its early, best, years as patrons formed lines to buy tickets for the 2:30 P.M. show on the first full day of business since its reopening. At the afternoon show. there were 3,500 customers in the 6,200seat auditorium. For the evening performance, the entire mezzanine of reserved seats was sold out by late afternoon. The theater had opened after a yearlong period during which it faced destruction, received landmark status and finally triumphed with renovation.

title: OBSERVER
description: There was a piece in the paper about a man who opined. I forget what he opined. Something about politics or oil, probably. That didn't matter. Being a student of mammalian noises, I called him up and asked him to opine a few times on the telephone.

Padula of Massapequa, L.I., was married there yesterday to Andrew James Schofer, son of Andrew Victor Schofer, also of Massapequa, and the late Dorothy Schofer. The ceremony was perrormeu in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Robert Hyatt.

description: DAYS. By Mary Robison. 180 pages. Knopf. $8.95.

title: Sonics Triumph, Win N.B.A. Title
description: LANDOVER, Md., June 1  Thhe Seattle SuperSonics, born as an expansion team for the 196768 season and plagued by problems for much of their existence, won their first National Basketball Association championship tonight by defeating the Washington Bullets, 9793, before a capacity crowd of 19,035 at the Capital Centre.

title: Firestone President To Retire
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 1  Mario A. Di Federico, president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, which has had difficulties because of a huge recall of its 500 line of steelbelted radial tires, has unexpectedly announced that he will retire July 1.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 38.

title: U.S. Assails Rises In Prices for Lead
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) The Government charged today that major producers of lead had used technicalities to get around its antiinflation price guidelines and had put into effect price increases that were clearly inflationary.

title: Smith and Kovach Get New Posts With Times In Washington Office
description: New management positions in the Washington office of The New York Times were announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Aide Says Curbs on Export Of Technology to Soviet Are Lax
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  A Commerce Department official responsible for monitoring the sale of advanced technology to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries has told a Congressional subcommittee that the Government's system of export controls is a total shambles.

description: The judge, though sightless, had gotten to the conference on time, having taken the right subway, unlike his sighted assistant. Which just goes to show, said Justice Gilbert Ramirez with a grin, that with a little luck even a blind Puerto Rican can go pretty far.

title: News Summary
description: The Pope arrives in Poland today for his first visit to his native land as the leader of the Roman Catholic Church a visit that is expected to have an immense impact on Eastern Europe. The nineday trip to eight cities, the first by a Pope to a Communist country, is expected to touch off an intense emotional reaction. [Page 1,Columns 23.]

title: JILL SENFT GUTMAN
description: Jill Senft Gutman, a magazine writer and editor, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. Mrs. Gutman, who lived at 570 Park Avenue, was 34 years old.

title: Congress Puts a Lid on Itself
description: Congress has an abiding reputation as the profligate branch of Government, where legislators put pleasing their own constituents ahead of national fiscal needs. That reputation no longer applies. Proposition 13, which dramatized voter hostility to big government, has moderated Congressional zeal for costly spending programs. So has doubledigit inflation.

title: John Barry, Designer, Won Academy Award For 'star Wars Film
description: John Barry, the filmproduction designer whose credits included Star Wars, Superman and Clockwork Orange, died unexpectedly yesterday while at work on The Empire Strikes Back, a sequel to Star Wars scheduled to be released next spring. Another of Mr. Barry's projects, Saturn III, for which he wrote the original story, was also currently in production.

title: Rubber Union Chief Optimistic on Uniroyal Contract
description: DETROIT, June 1 The president of the United Rubber Workers union, Peter C. Bommarito, said today that he was very optimistic about the prospects of winning a contract with Uniroyal Inc., in view of a Federal judge's ruling yesterday that apparently defused one of the company's arguments for resisting the union's contract demands.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: A Loophole for Optimism
description: We were awed by the news that a loophole has been discovered in the famous Second Law of Thermodynamics. To scientists this must be a remarkable development. Philosophically, it's dazzling. But the idea is also so inviting that we can almost predict intellectual trouble. Soon, we fear, it will be snatched up to justify all manner of social, psychological, political and simply crackpot convictions.

title: The Region
description: NORWALK, Conn. (AP)  The House Ethics Committee in Washington has asked Representative Stewart McKinney, Connecticut Republican, to give it information on a 1973 Washington realestate . sale, to determine whether he violated financialdisclosure rules. Mr. McKinney said the sale involved property that he sold for a net profit of less than $5,000 and that he therefore did not include it in his disclosure statements. He said the House disclosure rules applied only to capital gains of more than $5,000 unless the Congressman lived in the house.

title: Move to End Weekend Half Fares On Subways and Buses Is Rejected
description: An attempt to abolish weekend half fares on New York City subways and buses was rejected yesterday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority amid warnings that both the lower rate and the regular 50cent fare were in danger.

Also shown are closing listed market prices best overthecounter dealertodealer asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percent age differences (discount or premium) between the net asset value and the asked.

title: Dodge Heir's ExWife Pleads Guilty to Grand Larceny
description: Dora Dodge Moran, the former wife of one of the heirs to the Dodge Motor Company fortune, pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to three counts of grand larceny.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, June 1 (UPI)  The Soviet Union said today that a war between Pakistan and Marxistruled Afghanistan appeared to be taking shape and warned that Moscow would not stand by indifferently.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, June 1, 1979

title: Flaws in Engine Mountings Found in Half of DC10's
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, revising previous figures upward, said yesterday that problems had been found in underwing engine mounts on nearly half of this country's 138 DC10's.

title: New York's Jobless Rate Declined To 6.4% in May, and Jersey's Rose
description: New Jersey's jobless rate rose to 7.7 percent after reaching a fiveyear low of 5.9 percent in April, Mr. Bienstock reported. But he said the onemonth change did not indicate a reversal of the trend toward lower unemployment rates in the metropolitan area in the last several years.

title: Winds Delay Nuclear Test
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 1 (AP)  An underground nuclear test scheduled for this morning was delayed at least until Monday by high altitude winds over the Nevada test site. The weaponsrelated test, hiving a yield of 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT, will be the fifth annunced test this year. Not all tests are announced.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Screen: Sibling 'Sunnyside':The Cast
description: Joey Travolta, an older brother of John, has the family smile, the family walk, the family haircut and the family derrire. He may also have some portion of the family acting talent, but a movie like "Sunnyside"  designed almost entirely to capitalize on Mr. Travolta's resemblance to his brother  makes it hard to hazard a guess. He's a lot more appealing than his surroundings. But these are so dismal that almost anything would look bright by comparison.Mr. Travolta plays the paradoxical role of a saintly gang leader, a baaaad Boy Scout. He lives in a tough neighborhood, wants to move away with his nice girlfriend, and meanwhile spends a lot of time either squabbling with his family at the dinner table (remember "Saturday Night Fever"?) or strutting down the street (see note above). He handles the role's minimal and predictable demands well, though, especially in view of the camera's determination to shoot him only in long shot or in profile. These angles aren't designed to make the most of his performance; they mean to camouflage the fact that in full-face he doesn't look quite as much like John.Another promising actor lost in "Sunnyside" is Andrew Rubin, who makes a character named Reaper appropriately oily. A third player, who is crucified in one of the film's most graphically ugly moments, does a fine job up until then.I couldn't catch his character's name because, at yesterday's first show at the Embassy II theater, the house had been taken over by a gang of kids who consumed a fifth of something-or-other, slammed seats around, made a wide range of grunting noises and screamed catcalls at the movie. Sex scenes made them particularly noisy; scenes in which gangs drew up war plans, on the other hand, held their rapt attention. The theater's management made only halfhearted efforts to keep the movie audible and the situation under control.

title: Letter: On Saccharin's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON THE patent output was cut almost in half this week. Only 650 invention patents were granted, as compared with a weekly average of 1,170 in the last few months.

description: In percent

title: Art: Russian Modernists Shown on Gigantic Scale
description: PARIS, June 1 The most comprehensive exhibition of the modernist movement in Russia ever mounted In the West, or indeed anywhere, opened here today at the Pompidou Center under the title ParisMoscow. It is a show on a gigantic scale, embracing thousands of items from the period 190030, and ranges over a vast variety of artistic, cultural and political endeavor. It is a show that will form the basis of our understanding of the Russian avantgarde, both before and after the 1917 revolution, for many years to come.

title: The Golden Gate to America's Left Hand
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif.  The East Coast papers are whining. The slick national magazines are upset. California, they say, San Francisco in particular, is a looney bin, a satrap of boobies and coneheads, a cloudcuckoo land.

title: 2 Elderly Sisters, Fearing Swindle, Jump to Deaths But Police Say the Scheme Had Been Thwarted
description: Two elderly sisters, despondent over their finances, leaped to their deaths yesterday, one after the other, from the top fire escape of the sixstory Bronx apartment house where they lived.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: There is plenty of ammunition for both sides in the heated discussion that commonly follows the release of information on corporate profits.

title: Foreign Influx: the Role of Schools
description: AKorean rock band gave a concert at a New Rochelle high school, and several other students showed off the fashions of Sri Lanka. In Dobbs Ferry, nursery school children brought dolls of Asia and Africa for show and tell.

title: Milestones of FourHand Music
description: As the late Ernest Lubin remarks in his book The Piano Duet, music for two pianists at one keyboard had a relatively brief vogue. Composers only began writing it around the time the piano itself was introduced in the late 18th century. Broadly speaking, they stopped around the turn of the 20th century. But for per haps 100 years, few forms of collaborative musicmaking seem to have been as widely practiced.

title: Computer That Sends News Items to Homes Is Shown to Publishers
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev, June 2 (UPI)  A new service that can provide electronic delivery of local newspaper articles to any home computer was demonstrated today by United Press International.

title: Maria Lucca Bride Of Richard Carrier
description: Maria Cecilia Lucca, a graphic designer, was married yesterday to Richard Kipling Carrier, a student at Fordham University. The ceremony was performed in St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Nyack, N.Y., by the Rev. Donald Whalen. He was assisted by the Rev. Raymond Schroth, professor of communications at Fordham and newly appointed dean of Rockhurst College in Kansas City, Kan.

title: Spenkelink Is Eulogized At Service in California
description: BUENA PARK, Calif., June 2 (AP) John A. Spenkelink, the executed murderer, was eulogized today as a man who had confronted his plight without bitterness. Outside the memorial chapel, a small group of opponents of capital punishment stood quietly by.

title: A. T. & T. Land Purchases Are Stirring Uneasiness
description: MENDHAM TOWNSHIP FOR about as long as anyone can remember, the largest building in the rolling hills and hollows of the Ralston Valley here has been Joe Backer's cow barn.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Somewhere in the middle of Rooster Cogburn, the cheerfully flimsy spinoff from True Grit, Eula Goodnight (Katharine Hepburn), the sharptongued spinster, says to the boozy old Rooster (John Wayne) while they're resting on the trail and he's at target practice, Shooting cornbread in a meadow is not taking us anywhere. Which more or less describes our attempts to get a fix on the extraordinarily longlived career of John Wayne and on what he represents to the American public. No matter how carefully we talk about him, we wind up shooting cornbread in a meadow.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to the Yukon, where pickup trucks appear to outnumber cars, you will find most drivers use their headlights day and night. They often check with the mounted police detachment on road conditions and weather ahead. In the summer they clean their air filters frequently.

title: STAMPS
description: Endangered flowers and plants appear likely from now on to be sharing the philatelic spotlight in the increasing number of issues devoted to the efforts for protection and conservation of an environment beset by dangers from all sides.

title: Tower Approved For West 57th Despite Vote Of Local Board
description: The New York City Planning Commission voted last week to Overrule a Manhattan community board and permit a revised plan for a $40 million mixeduse tower on West 57th Street.

title: Fiscal Watchdogs Reemerging to Analyze Koch's Budget
description: Two of the fiscal critics who helped drive Mayor Beame from office are mapping a report on Mayor Koch's proposed budget, even as the final maneuvers on proposed amendments take place.

title: Stage: Angels and Hooters by 2 Seattle Troupes
description: SEATTLE  It can be a risky business dropping in on theaters around the courtly if the timing depends on those odd weeks when there is a lull in New York. No deity is assigned to see that it is precisely during such weeks that a particular resident theater will be doing its best work.

title: POLITICS Gas Station Lobby: New Power Source
description: HARTFORD STATE legislators are used to dealing with lobbyists those folks, usually men, in threepiece suits in the corridors outside the Senate and House of Renresentatives  for a variety of businesses and causes. When you have to vote on steady stream of bills flowing through your chamber, the lawmakers say, it is handy to go to a lobbyist.who can give quick answers to questions on a bill.

title: Housing Aid Said to Depend on Mt. Kisco Vote
description: Mourn Kisco APROPOSAL to build 130 units of federally subsidized housing here has prompted a serious and politically charged reconsideration of future development in the village, the commercial hub of northern. Westchester. Hanging on the outcome of the debate is the future allocation of Federal housing funds to the 25 communities that make up the Westchester Urban County Consortium.

title: Music Notes: A New Festival Lure`Gas
description: These are the days when the thoughts of musiclovers turn to summer festivals. This year those thoughts are being complicated by the problem of how to get to them. Most festivals are off the beaten track, in the countryside or in small. outoftheway towns. They can only be reached by automobile. Will it be possible to buy enough gasoline to make such trips possible?

title: If You Go . . .
description: ... in search of a narrow gauge excursion, you will find two other lines in Colorado that do not follow original working routes but do offer short rides. One, the High Country Railroad, is a twofooter like the Cripple Creek & Victor, and may be ridden at a shopping area called Heritage Square, in Golden.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: If you don't have the good luck to be in Paris this first weekend in June, the next best thing is to go see the 87 French 18thcentury drawings from the Musee Carnavalet which are on view right here in New York City through the end of this month at the National Academy of Design. (Just in case you have not been to the Academy lately, it stands on Fifth Avenue between 89th and 90th Streets and is located in one of the most elegant New York town houses of its date. Ogden Codman had few rivals when it came to designing a house of this kind and size).

description: ONE of the grand yet still economical pleasures of life is to stroll through a city's open market, laying hands on the vegetables, examining a curious jar of some exotic condiment, noshing here and there or taking lunch at a small restaurant in the neighborhood.

description: PATERSON AFTER running a gantlet of misadventures, including an international incident, Old 299 will make a triumphant return Wednesday to the city where it was built.

description: WARSAW, June 2  Only the heat and the ice cream men were left to connect Poland's two different worlds today.
