title: Ideas & Trends
description: Driving home from Washington, D.C., where he had just attended a short course on identifying air disaster victims, E. Steven Smith, a dentist, heard the announcement the DC10 crash at O'Hare Field on his car radio. By evening American Airlines had reached him at his home in a Chicago suburb and he was at work on the scene of the accident.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY construction projects around the house that require framing out with 2by4's or similar lumber call for a technique known as toenailing. For example, where vertical studs ??utt up against a 2by4 sole plate (the piece that lays flat on the floor) or up against the top plate (the horizontal 2by4 that goes across the top of the wall's framework).

title: How Networks Test For Audience Impact
description: HOLLYWOOD The coming season's war between the networks promises to be more fierce than ever. Will ABC, unaccustomed to the top spot, be able to maintain its position over secondplace CBS? Will Fred Silverman, the new commander of beleaguered NBC, be able to deliver on his recent prediction that by Christmas his network will overtake at least CBS? While the results will only begin to come into focus this fall, what is clear now is that all three of the networks have enlisted an arsenal of weapons to help gain the upper hand in the fray. Of those weapons, one that is becoming increasingly relied upon is ASI (Audience Studies Incorporated), an influential entertainment testing organization headquartered in Preview House on Sunset Boulevard.

title: Early Jazz Classics From Commodore
description: Back in the 1930's, information about jazz was hard to come by. Almost the only way to learn about it was to experience it. Until the end of the decade, very little was written on the subject  the first knowledeable American book on Jazz, Jazzmen, edited by Frederic Ramsey, Jr., and Charles Edward Smith, was not published until 1939. And there was no such thing as a course on jazz.

title: ATESTS CITED ANEW IN DEATHS OF SHEEP
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  The sheep started dying in 1953, and to the ranchers around the Government's Atomic Test Site in Nevada, the cause seemed obvious radiation. But in 1956, the courts did not agree and the case was dismissed.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: It began one sunny afternoon in Rome in the summer of 1965. My wife and I were sitting at an outdoor cafe near the Vatican, and I said to myself, I wonder what the hell goes on inside those walls,  Walter F. Murphy recalls. Thus began the detective work that led to his first novel, The Vicar of Christ, which culminates in the reign of the first American Pope.

title: Recession Watch Gets Some Fresh Debating Points
description: If there is a place lower than way down, that's where the national economy seemed headed last week. The index of leading indicators showed a 3.3 percent drop in April, the sharpest ever. April's orders for manufactured goods fell 6.1 percent, the steepest slide in 10 years. Such superlatives kept alive the debate over whether there is a recession. But they also took attention away from other statistics which, to the Carter Administration, were more encouraging.

title: Nancy H. Stratton Is Married To Henry Utter 2d, a Teacher
description: Nancy H. Stratton and Henry Edwin Utter 2d, alumni of the University of New Hampshire, were married yesterday afternoon in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Nathan Adams performed the ceremony in the Stanwich Congregational Church.

title: Hyssop for Perky Edges
description: The handsome herb hyssop should grow in more gardens. It is a shrubby plant or little bush that grows about 20 inches tall. It has small, thinpointed, brightgreen leaves which are strongly aromatic.

title: The Robust Artistry of Alberta Hunter
description: A year and a half ago, Alberta Hunter, an obscure, retired nurse, set out to resume her previous career as a jazz and blues singer, a career she abandoned more than 20 years ago in order to study and practice nursing. Miss Hunter's remarkable comeback at age 82 was officially launched in October of 1977 at Barney Josephson's Cookery when she began a limited engagement that has become an indefinite run. Moreover, Miss Hunter's new career is running at full throttle with television appearances (60 Minutes, The Mike Douglas Show, Camera Three and the recent Kennedy Center gala), and a new Columbia soundtrack recording of the film Remember My Name.

title: U.S. Lists Veterans on Payroll
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)  More than 345,000 Vietnam era veterans work for the Federal Government, according to statistics compiled by the Federal Office of Personnel Management. The agency said that Vietnam era veterans accounted for 12 percent of the total Federal work force of 2,750,000 and more than 27 percent of the veterans employed by the Government. About 45 percent of Federal employees, 1,250,000 persons, are veterans.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: This is in response to the article A Shelter for Dogs Stirs Ire [May 20]. I must take exception to the fact that William Glaser, president of the Huntington Hills Civic Association, of which I am a member, states that our association is against this shelter on Pinelawn Road. I was never polled on this issue, nor notified of any vote taking place. I am not against this shelter, but am totally for it.

title: Health
description: Anesthesiologists have become multiskilled specialists who monitor the vital signs of patients before, during and after surgery.

title: ART
description: TRENTON IT USED to be that painters remained primarily painters and that sculptors were faithful to sculpture. But now artists feel free to express themselves in many media. It's not unusual to see painting, sculpture and prints  and even movies  by the same person.

title: The Mechanics of the World Keep It Running
description: A MAN came to pump out my septic tank and I was surprised to see that he was young, handsome, even elegant. Tall, slender, with a casual grace of movement, he might easily have passed for a count or an actor. His, voice was melodious, his speech precise, though slightly tinged with an accent.

title: 2D CASINO IN JERSEY ACCEPTS STRICTURES
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 1  Caesars World received a temporary permit this week to open Atlantic City's second casino, but at the cost of what New Jersey officials called extraordinary state intervention in the conduct of company business, including stipulations that leave in doubt whether the sixmonth permit will be succeeded by a more permanent license.

title: New Jersey/ This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  The Fantasticks, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through June). $3.5045.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50; group rates. (201) 9297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Melanie A. Taylor Bride in South
description: At Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church in Greensboro, N.C., yesterday, Melanie Anne Taylor, daughter of Kathleen Bryan Edwards of Greensboro and Ray Howard Taylor Jr. of Atlanta. was married to Christopher Simpson Farland of Alexandria, Va. He is a son of Joseph Simpson Farland of Winchester, Va., former Ambassador to the Dominican Republic, Panama, Pakistan and Iran, and the late Virginia Christopher Farland. Msgr. Hugh Dolan performed the ceremony.

title: Vera Stewart, a Consultant, Married to John Q. Jennings
description: Vera Stewart, a consultant with the Butterick Fashion Marketing Company, and John Q. Jennings, president of his own international economic consulting concern, were married yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Richard Cosnotti performed the ceremony.

title: Pilot Program Fights Career Criminals
description: WHITE PLAINS WE don't accept pleas on any of our cases, says Kevin Kitson, an Assistant District Attorney assigned to the county's new Career Criminal Bureau.

title: Deaths
description: AUGENSTEIN  Hyman, beloved husband of the late Sophie. Beloved father of Frances. Devoted fatherinlaw of Henry Shields. Dear brother of Mollie Helkin. Loving grandfather of Eileen. Services Sunday 2PM Jeffers Funeral Home, 18810 Hillside Ave, Hollis, NY

title: Ropes Fly, Feet Pound As 300 Vie for Honors In DoubleDutch Skill
description: The sound of pounding feet mingled with the sound of splashing water at the Lincoln Center plaza fountain yesterday as nearly 300 girls competed for trophies and titles In the sixth annual World Invitation Double Dutch Championship, an urban tournament for rope jumpers.

title: If You Go . . .
description: ... traveling with children, buy inexpensive souvenirs generously. It makes them put up with a lot of sightseeing work.

title: Music: Purna Das Benefit
description: Ravi Shankar wasn't the only Indian musician to captivate hip Westerners in the 1960's. Puma Des did that, too, and his benefit concert Friday night for and at the Alternative Center for International Arts made one realize that his success owes as much to his personal charisma as to his considerable gifts as a musician.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The success of a recordjacket photograph  for instance, the Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band photograph included in the exhibition The Altered Photograph at P.S. 1 through June 10  is fairly easy to judge. Does it convey the spirit of the music? Will it attract attention in a store display? Will help sell the record? If the answer to these questions Yes, the jacket photograph is a success.

title: Paul Butler Jr. Weds Holly Friant
description: Holly Melinda Friant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Olin Chester Friant Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Paul Mulholland Butler Jr., son of Mrs. Butler of South Bend, Ind., and the late Mr. Butler. a lawyer who was chairman of the National Democratic Committee from 1954 to 1960. The Rev. Kenyon Wildrick performed the ceremony in the Community Congregational Church.

title: Deaths
description: FOXMilton. The Officers and Trustees of Temple Shaaray Tefla deeply mourn the passing of its esteemed and devoted Vice President, Milton Fox. His memory will be forever cherished. Hearts go out to his beloved wife, Ronda, dear children, Curtis, Eric, Maureen, Jackie, Sydney and the late Lyle and the entire family. H. Roger Spiegel, President Harvey M. Tattelbaum, Rabbi

title: Support Network
description: WALK into almost any Westchester corporation these days and you're likely to find a woman, or even two, in highermanagement levels. Women have been making strides in business.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: LOS ANGELES  When the mail arrives, Frank A. Grisanti approaches it clinically, looking for symptoms of corporate turmoil, shifts in top management, clues to financial crises. I could probably name 50 companies that may need my help, he said. They are not in trouble now, but they may be soon.

title: An Easier Ride for You and Your Bike
description: Gasoline is in short supply, but the fuel for footpower still can be found in everything from seaweed to lamb chops. Except for the huff and puff, bicycling remains a free ride  after you get to the territory you want to explore. If you cannot or do not want to use your car to get there, public transportation is the answer. In many cases your bicycle can travel with you on airlines, buses and trains, making it unnecessary to take up with a strange rented bike at your destination.

title: What Price BigTime TV? (And Would It Work Here?)
description: WE'D all like to see bigtime television back in New Jersey again. But uprooting a New York station against the wishes of its investors, employees, advertisers and viewers would ultimately prove an embarrassment. New Jersey simply is not a natural center for commercial broadcasting.

title: PARADE
description: The annual Salute to Israel Parade will begin at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street at 11 A.M. today and move up the avenue to 86th Street and then east to Third Avenue.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 2 (UPI)  Nicaraguan troops, planes and gunboats pounded guerrilla positions near the Costa Rican bonier today in a major counteroffensive.

title: Underground Music Surfaces for a NineDay Festival
description: Starting this coming Friday and continuing through June 16, there will be a music festival in New York that most musiclovers won't even be aware of. But it promises to be one of the most sienificant musical events of the season, a cry of selfassertion by a whole variety of underground musics.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: SURROUNDED by the dismal atmosphere of some of South Norwalk's more tumbledown streets, the jaunty waterfront cottages hugging the shoreline in the area known as Harbor View never used to be easy to sell. But this year the demand is so strong that prices are beginning to top $100,000. )

title: PARKING KEGULATIONS
description: Alternateside parking regulations are not in effect today, a Sunday. Tomorrow they will be in effect only in Manhattan and Queens, where the Sanitation Department will work on refuse accumulated in the streets during the tugboat strike.

title: On Reading Between the Lines Of Those Typographiacl Errors
description: THERE are many things that rile me when I read my morning or evening newspaper, but few are more aggravating  to me, at least  than typographicla errors.

title: Events Today
description: Queens Day Activities: Antioue airplanes, music, sports, cultural and circus events, fireworks; 9 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, Queens. (Complete schedule of events will be distributed at all entrances the park.)

title: There's More to Pisa than a Tower
description: From the moment when Bonnano Pisano saw that an unexpected subsidence in the ground was causing his bell tower to lean toward the south, the shadow of that tower has tended to obscure everything else in Pisa. Bonnano began construction of his campanile in 1174 and had reached the fourth level before the fatal incline manifested itself. He aftempted to right the structure but to little avail. Pisa's destiny was set.

title: Dr. Martha Jean Macdonald Is Betrothed To Dr. Richard N. R, Harvard Professor
description: Dr. Martha Jean Macdonald, a clinical fellow in dermatology at the Harvard Medical School, and Dr. Richard Noel R, an assistant professor of medicine there, plan to be married in August.

title: To Send a Child to the Country ...
description: I am very concerned about the poor children, writes Christina, herself a child but more fortunate, and would like very much to help them. I am sending in 15 dollars which I earned by doing babysitting, errands and tidying up, hoping to send a child to the country for 3 or 4 days.

title: Long Wharf Restoration Project Revitalizing Downtown Sag Harbor
description: SAG HARBOR, L.I. An enterprising young developer has brought the harbor back to Sag Harbor this season with multimilliondollar restoration project that is revitalizing the downtown waterfront area.

title: Westchester/ThisWeek
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Pippin, starring Dennis Angulo. Today and next Sunday at 2 P.M. Thursday to Saturday 8 P.M. $5.50 to $7.50. Discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rte. 6 and 118. 6281169.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: John Leggett is a triplethreat man: as director of the Writer's Workshop at the University of Iowa, he teaches young novelists; he brings many of the country's best writers to the campus for a stint of teaching; and he writes novels himself  his new one, Gulliver House, is about publishing. Mr. Leggett is obviously the man to ask about today's campus writers.

title: The Nation
description: Should the nation's fleet of McDonnell Douglas DC10 jumbo jets be kept on the ground until any weaknesses anywhere are positively identified and cured? And is the Federal Aviation Administration, which is responsible for deciding whether a plane is airworthy, itself suffering from flight fatigue? These questions are causing unease amore Government and industry officials responsible for trying to find out why an American Airlines DC10 crashed as it took off from Chicago at the start of the Memorial Day weekend.

title: Thomas Glynn 3d Weds Marylou Batt
description: Marylou Batt, director of communications at Action, the Federal agency for volunteers, was married in Washington yesterday to Thomas P. Glynn 3d, director of the Vice President's Task Force on Youth Employment. The Rev. Michael J. Doody performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Stephen Martyr Roman Catholic Church.

title: Fisherman Prizes Sport's Personal Quality
description: FISHING is a personal sport. It's something that a man can learn from his father, teach his children and, if he's lucky, enjoy with his grandchildren. A man can age gracefully with fishing, growing in skill even as his hair grays and his reflexes slow.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING ROSALYNN
description: It is Tuesday, Jimmy Carter's day for his weekly working luncheon with his closest friend and adviser. The Federal table in the private family dining room on the second floor of the White House is set with the Lincoln china, the purple eagles mellowing with age. Underneath are starched linen place mats. Burnished silver and fine crystal sparkle in the sunlight that flows in through windows that look out onto Pennsylvania Avenue and the strollers in Lafayette Park. Liveried waiters hover unobtrusively near side tables.

title: The Knicks' Case
description: If hindsight is 20/20, the Knicks deserve a 50/50 chance of winning their appeal to Federal Judge Robert L. Carter in the Marvin Webster case. Ever since Larry O'Brien, the potentate of the National Basketball Association, awarded Lonnie Shelton, the Knicks number one choice in the June 25 college draft and $450,000 to the Seattle SuperSonics as freeagent compensation for the 7foot1inch center, the Knicks front office has howled about the excessive value of the package. Mike Burke, the Knicks president, kept shouting that Lonnie Shelton alone made the Sonics whole. And now the Sonics are the champions of the whole N.B.A. with Lonnie Shelton at forward, which is more than they could achieve last year with Marvin Webster at center.

title: The Ace Of Aces
description: RICKENBACKER'S LUCK An American Life By Finis Farr. Illustrated. 366pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.95.

title: Assassination Panel's Final Report Backs Theory of Plot on Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  The House Select Committee on Assassinations has gone substantially beyond the findings of the Warren Commission and has concluded that a conspiracy, perhaps involving organized crime figures, led to the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: Plan for L.I. Job Authority Moves Ahead
description: TRYING to insure continuation of a program that has been major help to Long Island business and industry, the State Legislature last week approved a measure that would create a Long Island Job Development Authority, the only one of its kind in the state.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: $700,000 in Donations to Enable Antioch University to Stay Open
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)  Officials of Antioch University announced today that $700,000 in private donations has insured that the school will operate this fall.

title: ART VIEW
description: BARCELONA It was to be expected that the end of the Franco era in Spain would bring profound changes in the country's cultural life, and in many fields where political censorship formerly placed severe limits on what could be said or shown in public, the changes have indeed been swift and startling. The spectacle of teenage Spanish girls giggling their merry way through an exhibition of Picasso's erotic art at the Picasso Museum here in Barcelona, for example, leaves one with a very vivid sense of the change that democracy has brought to the cultural scene. And newsstands heaped with pornography of every sort offer eloquent testimony to the fact that this shift in the cultural atmosphere is by no means of an elitist sort.

title: Dallas Woman's Report of Theft Of Art Collection Is Questioned
description: DALLAS, June 2  What happened last Sept. 24 in the home of Mrs. John W. Christner in the exclusive Dallas suburb of Highland Park has been described as the largest residential robbery in the history of Dallas County.

title: Lopez Maintains Golf Lead
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 2 Nancy Lopez broke her streak of 13 consecutive rounds of golf at par or better today when she shot a oneoverpar 73 in the third round of the $100,000 Golden Lights tournament at Wykagyl Country Club, but maintained her dimestroke advantage with a 54hole total of sixunder 210 with one round to go in the 72hole event.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Joan M. McAnaney And David B. Fay Are Married in Rye
description: Joan Margaret McAnaney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. McAnaney of Rye, N.Y., and Ocean City, N.J., was married yesterday to David Brian Fay, son of Capt. and Mrs. Peter Donald Fay of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye by Msgr. Thomas McMahon.

title: Tate Stops Knoetze in 8th Round
description: MMABATHO, Bophuthatswana, June 2 (AP)  Unbeaten John Tate of Knoxville, Tenn., stopped Kallie 1Cnoetze of South Africa in the eighth round of a scheduled 12round heavyweight bout today.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: When Louise Fitzhugh published Harriet the Spy 15 years ago, children recognized immediately that here was an author who was on their side. The adults in the book, with few striking exceptions, are bumbling, boring or simply absurd. Harriet, on the other hand, manages life with efficiency, originality and an irreverent wit. Young readers hoped that Harriet would go on forever; unfortunately, after writing one sequel Louise Fitzhugh died.

title: Less Oil Now for Troubled Waters
description: Seek no scapegoats has been the base line in the ups and downs of President Carter's pronouncements on the energy crisis. But last week, as Arab oil prices went up again, domestic gasoline allocations went down and worldwide competition for supplies intensified, accusing fingers in the Administration were pointing at James R. Schlesinger, the Energy Secretary.

title: Roger Mgroz to Marry Wendy Leland Walker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Leland Walker of Barrington, R.I., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Leland Walker, to Roger Huntington Mgroz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Mgroz of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Stratton Mountain.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Dr. John C. Lilly has been working with dolphins for more than 20 years, and this book is the summation of his research to date. It is not, however, laid out very clearly. The chapters do not flow consecutively into one another. There are reprints of papers and articles; it is highly technical in parts. There is an enormous annotated bibliography, a scientific abstract about interspecies communication, and related appendices, some of which recapitulate material to be found in the text.

title: A Writer's Lament to Graduates: What I Would Give to Square a Root!
description: EVER since this early and esoteric study, I have spent long hours musing on what a liberal education should be or, rather, what I wish my education had been. In terms of presentday curricula. I am barely literate, for I have never read sociology, nor have I had academic courses in sex or in the psychology revolution. I have never studied Education and I have never studied creative writing and do not know what creative writing is unless I am to take it as the opposite, or perhaps the counterpart, of destrutive writing.

title: When Two + Two Equals Six Figures
description: MARTIN BORIS of Woodmere is one of those people who have done a little bit of everything. What he is doing now is making money  a lot of it.

title: LEADING LANDLORD AGREES TO REFUNDS
description: New York State's Attorney General announced yesterday that the Parman Company, a major New York City real estate concern, had agreed to pay rent refunds totaling several hundred thousand dollars to tenants it had overcharged and to review its rent records for the last two years.

title: Explosion Cuts Power in Boston
description: BOSTON, June 2 (AP)  An explosion in a manhole cut electrical power today to sections of East Boston and nearby Chelsea, forcing Logan International Airport to use emergency power. There were no injuries in the explosion, a spokesman for Boston Edison said. Firefighters were called to several buildings to free people trapped in elevators. The cause of the explosion was not known immediately.

title: Underdog Carter
description: The Washington word of the week, perhaps of the season, seems to be blame. Who's to blame for soaring inflation? For the stern signs of recession? For leapfrogging oil prices? For gasoline allocationsand lines? Many people have come to believe the answer is easy. They point their fingers at the White House. But increasingly, that answer is too easy.

title: Deaths
description: HARTLEYWilliam H., on June 1, 1979, beloved husband of Edith G. Hartley. Funeral services, Tuesday, June 5, 10 AM, at the Colonial Funeral Home, Inc., 4870 Broadway, NYC (204th St.). Interment Ferncliff. Visiting Sunday, Monday, 25 and 79:33 PM.

title: Sunday Observer
description: There are more machines than women in my life. Beside my bed stands a machine that tells me what time it is. It almost always lies. Such a petty thing to lie about. If you had a woman standing there to tell the correct time she certainly wouldn't lie about it. But you can't get women to handle these jobs.

title: 4 From Metropolitan Area On Junior Davis Cup Team
description: Four players from this area were among twelve named yesterday to the Junior Davis Cup tennis team. The team, under the auspices of the United States Tennis Association, will compete in national and international tournaments.

title: Smith Steps Out  But Plot Far
description: Zimbabwe Rhodesia laid on the scarlet and gold pageantry last week for its first black Prime Minister, Bishop Abel T. Muzorevra, but the continuing role of his predecessor and apparent eminence blanche, Ian D. Smith, attracted more attention.

title: Shortage Fuels Country Schemes
description: While it may seem small comfort come the sweltering summer weekends, the yearround New Yorker may be taking a guilty bit of secret pleasure these days in the discomfiture of those privileged country homeowners currently trying to cope with the gasoline shortage.

title: For Sag Harbor
description: SAG HARBOR AN enterprising young developer has brought the harbor back to Sag Harbor this season with a multimilliondollar restoration project that is revitalizing the downtown waterfront area.

title: Beethoven Museum
description: While Czechoslovaks do not claim Ludwig van Beethoven as a native son, they can now claim him affectionately as an adopted one since they have dedicated a museum to him.

title: Amish Polio Cases Cause New Alarm
description: Compared with the grim swath polio used to cut, the numbers from Pennsylvania  six confirmed cases since Januarymight not seem all that important. After all, before an effective polio vaccine came to be widely used in the mid1950's, the annual toll in the United States was counted in the tens of thousands.

title: Mary Jane Doyle Is Wed to William Driscoll
description: At the Roman Catholic Shrine of St. Elizabeth Ann Seton yesterday, Mary Jane Doyle was married to William J. Driscoll. The Rev. John B. Breslin performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Unexpected Linkages
description: WHEN Fairfield Porter died in 1975, writes Rackstraw Downes, he was known as one of the best painters in America. lila own opinion was that he was stronger as a critic.

title: Weird Glassboro Takes Frisbee Title
description: STATE COLLEGE, PA. THEY said they would, and they did. The weirdest team won. They chanted. They danced. They worshiped their idols and hexed their opponents.

title: ART
description: YONKERS REPETITION of a motif in art can be a dangerous business. If the repetition is not employed in an effective manner, the work can look eminently boring and immediately lose the attention of the observer.

title: Miss Kruesi, D.W. Lincoln Married in R.I.
description: The marriage of Katherine Kimball Kruesi, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Oscar Rogers Kruesi of Bernardsville, N.J., and Tinmouth, Vt., to Daniel Wardwell Lincoln took place yesterday in Newport, R.I. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brayton Lincoln of Padanaram, Mass. Canon D. Lorne Coyle performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: County Fees for Parks and Swimming Rise But Officials Still View Them as Bargains
description: COUNTY residents will find the cost of a parks pass this summer up a dollar from last year and higher fees for the county's four swimming pools and four beaches. But officials of the Parks, Recreation and Conservation Department say their facilities still represent a recreation bargain within the reach of only a gallon or two of gasoline.

title: It's a Girl! It's a Boy! It's a Father For the First Time at Age 47!
description: TODAY was a big day. We received our first photographs of the baby  they were taken from an ultrasonic image of the fetus  and I proudly signed a form on the line above Father. All this in the 16th week after conceiving our first child.

title: Letters: Some Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Kaufman Wed to James Vreeland Jr.
description: Nancy Rose Kaufman, a freelance dance and theater critic in Austin, Tex., was married yesterday to James Morton Vreeland Jr., an archeologist. The ceremony was performed in St. John on the Mountain Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J., by the Rev. Edwin H. Cromey, headmaster of the St. John Baptist School in Mendham, N.J.

title: F.D.A. Planning Scientific Study Of Possible Saccharin Substitute
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI)  The Food and Drug Administration plans to conduct its first scientific inquiry into aspartame, a new artificial sweetner that is a possible substitute for saccharin.

title: Two Inmates Shot Dead by Police In Escape Attempt at a Jersey Jail
description: Police officers shot and killed two inmates of the Cumberland County Jail in Bridgeton, N.J., and critically wounded a correction officer yesterday in what authorities called an aborted jailbreak by a handful of prisoners who seized a cellblock and took two guards hostage in a twoandahalfhour siege.

title: One Woman Surviving
description: N her first novel, Ellease Southerlandrecipient of the Gwendolyn Brooks Award for Poetry in 1972 and author The Magic Sun Spins, a collection of poetry published in 1975 traces the life of Abeba Williams from her childhood in the South during the earlier part of this century to her later years in New York City. It is a tale told with subtle images and precise language, and, despite its brevity, Miss Southerland evokes the tenor and atmosphere of both the small, rural town in Carolina where Abeba was born illegitimately and raised by a midwife, and the cramped, fastpaced life of Brooklyn, where she rejoins her mother and grows to adulthood.

title: SALISBURY CHARGES PLOT TO KILL LEADER
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, June 2  Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa's blackled Government appeared to be heading into its first major crisis tonight with confirmation that the police were investigating a plot to assassinate the 54yearold prelate by supporters of his chief rival inside the country, the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole.

title: Peace Corps Program Is Alive and Well in Ecuador
description: QUITO, Ecuador  Is the Peace Corps still alive? is the question that 23yearold Julie Tucker, of Owatonna, Minn., remembers hearing when she told friends she was going to become a volunteer.

title: Setback for a Feelgood Pill
description: There is a curious little company in Las Vegas known as RomAmer Pharmaceuticals Ltd. that has had all kinds of trouble getting off the ground. With a kind of evangelical fervor, the company sells cierovital, a Rumanian drug that is said to dispel the discomforts of aging; some of its adherents, in fact, believe it reverses the aging process altogether. From the start, RomAmer has had to battle skeptical state and Federal authorities. Then, two years ago, the company came in from the wilderness  it won the right to manufacture and sell the drug in Nevada and since the first of the year it has quietly been prospering.

title: Robert Wilson's Edison To Be Seen In Progress
description: Robert Wilson's new theater piece, Edison, will be seen in public for the first time in a series of eight in progress performances June 1924 at the Lion Theater, 422 West 42d Street.

title: Lee A. Wolfe Bride Of Mark R. Carson
description: Lee Ann Wolfe and Mark Reese Carson of Daytona Beach, Fla., partners in Tropical Design, tropicalplant dealers and transporters, were married yesterday in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Harry Haines, a Methodist minister, perfonned the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Legislature Approves Lending Unit To Help Increase L. I. Employment
description: Trying to insure continuation of a program that has been a major help to Long Island business and industry, the State Legislature last week approved a measure that would create a Long Island Job Development Authority, the only one of its kind in the state.

title: 15Year Dispute Over Lease for Coney Island Steeplechase Continues
description: As the Coney Island amusement area opened for the summer last weekend, one of its main attractions, Steeplechase Park, remained entangled in a dispute over its lease arrangement with New York City.

title: Going Abroad With Children: The Rigors, The Rewards
description: Everyone knows that Europe is at its best when you are newly adult and can experience the riches of the past combined with open personal adventure  a time when the Continent vibrates with new possibilities both erotic and intellectual.

title: The Dalton Brothers Ride Again
description: HE Dalton brothers, those notorious outlaws of the old Wild West, ride again in Desperadoes, Ron Hansen's beautifully fashioned first novel. Oddly, the book begins Hollywood. The year is 1937, and Emmett Dalton, the last survivor of the gang, is now a realestate broker,

title: 3 Pintos By Weber To Be Sung
description: The first American performance of The Three Pintos, an opera by Carl Maria von Weber that was completed by Gustav Mahler, will be given Wednesday night by the Opera Theater of St. Louis at the LorettoHilton Theater of Webster College. Although started by the composer in 1821, it was never completed by Weber. His grandson showed the unfinished sketches to Mahler in 1886, when he was a young conductor in Leipzig, and he decided to reconstruct it.

title: College Democrats Back Carter
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)  The College Democrats of America, the student wing of the Democratic Party, has passed a resolution endorsing the reelection of President Carter. The resolution was passed at the spring National Executive Board meeting of the College Democrats of America.

title: Headliners
description: Even Stephen Foster couldn't have done much with the Stanislaus River. So it may have to be remembered as the place where Mark Dubois, an angry vegetarian, hid among the poison oak and the rocks, chained himself to a ledge and made the Army Corps of Engineers open the floodgates of a new dam. It happened in California, of course. Mr. Dubois was acting on behalf of rafters and lovers of the outdoors who claimed that irreparable damage would be done to the Stanislaus River Canyon if the Corps continued to let snow runoff accumulate. The Army, which says it only wanted the extra water to test its generators, couldn't find Mr. Dubois hiding place, so it pulled the plug late last month and Mr. Dubois unchained himself.

title: Six Arrested in House Filled With Furniture Linked to Store Thefts
description: Two police officers, acting on a hunch, staked out a Brooklyn apartment house yesterday that police said turned out to be a vast storehouse for furniture stolen from stores in the New York area.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TOKYO, June 2 (UPI)  Shigeru Kasamatsu of Japan and Stella Zakharova of the Soviet Union took the lead at the halfway point in the World Cup gymnastics championships today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY,June 3

title: The Fear of Reprisals Postpones
description: TEHERAN  Hardly anybody comes around the gate of the Prime Minister's palace looking for favors anymore.

title: WASHINGTON Moynihan And The Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 In the last few days, the Supreme Court of the United States has ruled that the State of New Jersey cannot constitutionally provide a special income tax deduction for parents who send their children to religious or other private schools.

title: Jim Wann In Revue
description: Jim Wann has become an old hand at presenting cabaret performances at the Manhattan Theater Club. Last year, he put on Jim Wann's Country Cabaret, the year before Jim Wann's Original Coney Island Hotdog Revue. This year he calls his offering which runs through today, Jim Warm, Cass Morgan and Friends, but it is not far removed from either the Country Cabaret or the Coney Island Hotdog Revue. which runs through today, Jim Warm, Cass Morgan and Friends, but it is not far removed from either the Country Cabaret or the Coney Island Hotdog Revue.

title: Ruxton Is Champion In Devon Horse Test
description: DEVON, Pa., June 2  Gussie Busch, owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, sat in a box at the Devon Horse Show today and chuckled softly while the regular working hunter stake was being run off in the ring.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: AllAmerica Roses

title: Suzanne Otto Bride Of Steven D. Carter
description: Carolyn Suzanne Otto, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Otto of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Steven Duncan Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Carter of Rowayton, Conn., and Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Cox's Nomination to Bench Stalled by 3Way Battle
description: BOSTON, June 2  The nomination of Archibald Cox, the former Watergate special prosecutor, to a newly created position on the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit here has become stalled in a quiet, threeway tugofwar among the White House, the Department of Justice and Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: SOME GAS STATIONS IN CITY ARE FOUND DOUBLING MARKUPS
description: Many service stations in New York City have more than doubled their markups on gasoline since September, resulting in sharply higher profits and prices that often violate President Carter's voluntary guidelines, according to an unreleased city study.

title: ANTIQUES When the Game Was Worth the Candle
description: GRANBY UNTIL kerosene was patented in 1854, all those maxims praising the wisdom of going early to bed and being early to rise, or the practicality of making hay while the sun shines, made the best of sense. Candlelight has a connotation of romance for many today; unfortunately then as now that was about all that could be pursued successfully by its flickering flame  at least without lot of squinting.

title: Barbara Williams Is Wed To Peter Julian Horneffer
description: Barbara Williams, who graduated Thursday from Johns Hopkins University, was married in Glyndon, Md., yesterday to Peter Julian Homelier, a student at the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. The Rev. Philip Roulette performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: If You Go ...
description: ... to Pisa by car, two Autostrade from the north lead to the city: from Genoa, along the Italian Riviera by way of La Spezia; and from Milan, bearing west at Parma for La Spezia, or continuing through Bologna to Florence before proceeding westward to the coast.

title: Deaths
description: TAUBERRosalind. The Sisterhood of the Avenue Z Jewish Center mourns the passing of our beloved Rebitzen, whoic dedication to the community, loyalty to the Syna gogue and service to the Sisterhood will long be remembered.

title: CRIME
description: It is hard to pin Stephen Geller's GAD (Harper & Row, $9.95) to one of the conventional genres. Perhaps Mr. Geller has invented a new kind of novel: parapsychological espionage.

title: Claims on Cult Total $1.4 Billion
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 (UPI)Court records show that claims totaling $1.4 billion have been filed against the People's Temple. Most of the claims were filed on the ground of wrongful death, a spokesman for the courtappointed receiler, Robert Fabian, said. More than 900 members of the cult died last November at the temple's commune in Guyana.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: If the buying habits of the American consumer are, indeed, a harbinger of the nation's economic health, the evidence is mounting  a declining rate of automobile sales and small gains in retail sales  that the country is already in a recession.

title: Theater in the Me Decade
description: Perhaps the most distinctive characteristic of recent American drama (at least when compared with recent British and Continental drama) is its utter indifference public life. American plays, by and large, are concerned with personal problems: private neuroses, identity crises, marital discord, sibling rivalries, Oedipal struggles most everything except issues of social or public consequence.

title: Suffolk Arts Dispute Flares Up
description: AYEAR after going into operation, Suffolk County's new method of financing the arts continues to spark controversy. As the first round of 1979 grantmaking comes up for consideration on Wednesday, the conflict that arose last December, when it was disclosed that the county had failed to distribute more than onefifth of its 1978 arts budget, has broken out again.

title: McGee and Stadler Tied For Kemper Open Lead
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 2 (UPI) Jerry McGee, after a blistering sixunderpar 30 on the front nine, ran into bogey trouble today and had to settle for a tie with Craig Stadler for the 54hole lead at 12under 204 in the Kemper open golf tournament.

title: Fresh Air Fund Summer Offers Widened Outlook
description: Straight out of kindergarten, 14 summers ago, Kenneth Gary had no idea what lay ahead when his mother packed him onto a train leaving New York City for Schenectady, N.Y., and twoweek Fresh Air Fund vacation.

title: Sonics Put Together The Right Chemistry
description: Minutes after the Seattle SuperSonics won their first National Basketball Association championship Friday night, Wes Unseld, the Washington Bullets captain, and Paul Silas, the Sonics forward, embraced in the Seattle dressing room, where champagne flowed freely.

title: The Death of Mauritania's Prime Minister Last Week Added Uncertainty
description: TUNIS  Buffeted by a sandstorm, a small plane crashed in the sea off Dakar, Senegal last week killing Lieut. Col. Ahmed Ould Bouceif, the Prime Minister of Mauritania. The accident was a harsh blow to his bankrupt, racially split nation whose fate is supremely important to Morocco, Algeria, Libya and the Saharan guerrillas of the Polisario Liberation Movement.

title: Mets, Ahead by 50, Lose to Braves, 76
description: ATLANTA, June 2 More pitching miseries were heaped on the New York Mets tonight when they blew a fiverun lead and dropped a 76 decison to the Atlanta Braves, a lastplace team that had just lost five consecutive games.

title: Hired Farm Workers' Pay Rises
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)  Hired farm workers on the average are getting about 10 percent more in cash wages than they did a year ago, according to the Agriculture Department. The latect quarterly survey, made in the week of April 814, showed that farm workers paid on the basis of hourly cash wages averaged $3.42 an hour, up 11 percent from $3.08 a year earlier. The survey showed that 1.05 million hired workers were employed on the nation's farms, a decline of 7 percent from almost 1.1 million a year earlier.

title: CALENDAR
description: Friday through Sunday. Stamford Antiques Show. Yacht Haven West, Washington Boulevard: 100 exhibitors.

title: Soviet Is Said to Refuse Visa for Ginzburg Son
description: MOSCOW, June 2 (Reuters)  The wife of Aleksandr Ginzburg, an exiled dissident, said today she would refuse to join her husband in the United States until the Soviet authorities allowed the couple's foster son to leave as well.

title: Dr. Vanaja V. Ragavan Married
description: Dr. Vanaja V. Ragavan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vijaya Ragavan of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert J. Berrier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Benier of Scottsdale, Ariz. The ceremony was performed at the Wilton Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Douglas S. Lind. It was followed by a Hindu ceremony performed by Dr. N.D. Potti, a Brahmin priest, at the Ragavan home.

title: 11 States Back Marijuana Use
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI)  Four more states have passed legislation legalizing controlled access to marijuana for medical purposes, the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws said today. It said that legislation passed in Iowa, Minnesota, Texas and Oregon brought to 11 the number of states that permit patients with such diseases as glaucoma and cancer access to the drug.

title: Financial Specialists Find Profits Of Oil Companies Not Excessive
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson, the Washington Democrat, once labeled them obscene, President Carter has called them excesfive and, according to opinion polls, many people believe they are plainly outrageous. But, despite the widely held opinion that the big oil companies profits are much too great, the findings of financial specialists, including those at several leading banks, almost uniformly indicate otherwise, according to interviews with many analysts.

title: Cholera Kills 134 in Java
description: BANDUNG, Indonesia, June 2 (Reuters)  Cholera has killed 134 people in West Java in the last two weeks, officials reported here today.

title: Births
description: BOCKSTEIN

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Ellen Theresa MacMahon Wed
description: The marriage of Ellen Theresa MacMahon, widow of Myles MacMahon, to Edward J. Lenihan, vice president of public relations for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, took place yesterday in West Orange, N.J. The Rev. James F. McCloskey performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The bride, daughter of Mrs. George C. Maguire of Verona, N.J., and the late Mr. Maguire, attended St. Petersburg Junior College and Rutgers University. Mr. Lenihan, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John J. Lenihan of Nutley, N.J., graduated from Seton Hall University and received an M.B.A. from New York University.

title: PROFESSIONALS' ADS DEBATED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, June 2  Supporters of a bill in the New York State Legislature that would provide, guidelines for advertising by professionals say the measure will protect consumers from deception. Opponents say it will hurt consumers by restricting competition.

title: How the Interest Arbitration Law Works And Why the Effect of Caps Is Unclear
description: AS A laborrelations attorney representing many police and firefighter bargaining units in New Jersey, I read Mayor Gibson's article [Opinion Page, May 13] on the interrelationship of New Jersey's interest arbitration and cap laws with great enthusiasm. [The author of the article was Kenneth A. Gibson, the Mayor of Newark.]

title: A Guide to Summer Dance Festivals
description: BALLET TROCADERO DE LA KARPOVA  For its first summer residency season, this threeyearold company of allmale dancers will perform the premiere of three works by Antony Basses, June 810, 1517. (Choreoground Theater, 69 West 14th Street, New York, N.Y. 10011. Phone: 2421903)

title: PLAN IN PITTSBURGH ON BUILDING FOUGHT
description: PITTSBURGH, June 2  A proposal by PPG Industries to erect a $100 million, 40story headquarters building in downtown Pittsburgh has touched off a controversy with merchants who would be displaced by the project.

title: DINING OUT Fine if by Sea, but Not if by Land
description: MANY of the diners at La Merenda, small new restaurant tucked into a side street in Baldwin, seemed to be regular patrons. Comments about how nice it to have this place in the neighborhood could be overheard. Everyone, whether habitu or newcomer, given a friendly welcome and gracious service.

title: Pupils and Pentagons
description: HILLSDALE, N.Y.  Until now, a 200yearold tradition has separated military training from the American public school classroom. It is a tradition that insists the values of the military, in large measure, are incompatible with the values of education in a democratic society.

title: Japan in the U.S.: The Kawasaki Story
description: LINCOLN, Neb.  An American flag flaps wildly in the wind alongside the modem redandwhite factory on the outskirts of town. Inside the plant, away from the gusts that sweep the Great Plains, the workers appear younger and their surroundings seem cleaner and more cheerful than in the many Midwestern factories. But the physical plant is not all that different from any other modern, automated factory.

title: ReReRemaking a Temple Classic
description: LOS ANGELES Walter Matthau is singing Over There in the fruity Italian accent of Enrico Caruso. There is no particular reason for him to impersonate Caruso, since his current film is not an opera, but making movies is an excruciatingly dull business and Mr. Matthau has a reputation as a clown to defend. Bellowing The Yankas are acoming . . ., he flings out his stomach like the baritone in a thirdrate company.

title: Callaghan Is,
description: LONDON  For 11 of the last 15 years, the Labor Party has been in power in Britain. Now it must relearn the subtle arts of opposition, where it is almost certain to be until 1984.

title: Groom at Roosevelt Forsakes Plush Life
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 2 Every morning at dawn as sunlight skims Long Island Sound and touches elegant Great Neck homes with added luster, 19-year-old Gary Machlz, the son of a millionaire, forsakes his comfortable home for a 10mile drive to a damp, haystrewn stable at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: U.S. Sees Modest Gains at CarterBrezhnev Parley
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  Administration officials said today that, when President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev meet in Vienna to sign the new armslimittation treaty, the United States expects only modest progress on SovietAmerican issues and other armscontrol measures.

title: 10,000 Dutch Conduct a Protest Against Plan for Atomic Wastes
description: GASSELTE, the Netherlands, June 2 (Reuters)  More than 10,000 people demonstrated here today against the development of nuclear energy and particularly against the storage of radioactive waste.

title: Brown Crew, in Upset, Takes First I.R.A. Title
description: SYRACUSE, June 2  The Brown crew of intellectual giants who do not have much time for sport won the Intercollegiate Rowing Association varsity heavyweight championship today for the first time in its history.

title: Lynn Carroll Townshend Fiance of Robert Black
description: Mr. and Mrs. Curtis S. Townshend of Fair Haven, NJ., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Carroll Townshend, to Robert Farlin Black, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Black of Sea Girt, N.J.

title: On the Virtues Of Sunny Marigolds
description: Marigolds have many virtues. They have sunny bright flowers. The require little care. Their flowering season goes on practically forever  at least until the first frosts nip tender buds.

title: Spring Youth Soccer League Growing Fast
description: THE newspaper advertisements proclaimed, Cosmos Present the World's Greatest Soccer Team at Giants Stadium! And at that stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands May 16. in a curtain raiser before the Cosmos game, 10,000 soccer fans watched the seventhgrade Scarsdale Strikers eke out a 10 victory over the Larchmont Soccer Club's 12to 14yearold All Stars.

title: Infants and Toddlers Learning to Swim In Special Classes
description: MIDDLETOWN O.K., now! Let's all give a cheer for Christopher! Yeaaa! Christopher beams, and turns his head from side to side to acknowledge the cheers.  is sopping wet but obviously pleased with himself and the attention he is getting.  has just been dunked by his mother in the pool. Christopher is 3 months old.

title: Delp's Only Fear Is the Weather
description: Spectacular Bid's trainer pondered the question for at least three seconds before responding.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: June starts busting out all over today at the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts in Roslyn Harbor, where an Arts Jubilee of four special Sunday celebrations begins with Youth Sunday for the Young at Heart. The day starts at 10 A.M. with a session of bird watching and then features kite flying (noon), aerial balloon works by the artist Gene Thompson (1 P.M.), performances by the Long Island Youth Orchestra (2 P.M.) and the McDonald Jazz Ensemble (4:30 P.M.), theatrical productions by the Enchanting Theater in the Woods (3 P.M.) and the AfricanAmerican Heritage Association of Long Island (9 P.M.) and a young people's art exhibition (1 to 5 P.M.).

title: STAGE VIEW
description: When I first saw Marsha Norman's technically accomplished and vigorously acted Getting Out in a Phoenix Theater workshop production last fall, I left the theater irritated with myself for having, in the end, become hritated by the play. Surely my discontent was unreasonable in the face of all that was admirable here. The author had elected to show us two facets of a girl's personality  played by two actresses of markedly different ages and temperments  by letting them share the same stage space, with their paths crossing often enough, and intimately enough, for one to pause to light the other's cigarette. The younger, thrashing willfully about in baseball cap and sneakers, roamed the stage fitfully, now hugging the bedclothes of her childhood home in Kentucky, now tilting a chair and rocking in sassy rhythm as she gave a psychiatrist short shrift, now setting fire to the cell in which she'd landed after the fatal shooting of a gas station attendant.

title: New Grist for Safety Mills
description: Federal bureaucrats lust after taking the free out of the freeenterprise system; businessmen profiteer off the backs of endangered employees. So the extremes of debate often go when yet another set of Federal jobsafety regulations appears to be taking shape. And so it currently echoes in a dispute over who can best keep grain elevators from exploding  Uncle Sam or the companies that run the elevators.

title: Firmani,  Snubbed by Club, Says Farewell
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 2  Eddie Firmani wanted to talk to the the players in the dressing room this morning, but he did not get inside Giants Stadium. The management of the Cosmos denied him access to the locker room.

title: U.S.JAPANESE PACT ON SALES IS REACHED
description: TOKYO, June 2  The United States and Japan agreed today to try to give American companies a better chance of filling orders of Japanese Governmentrun companies for billions of dollars in telecommunications equipment and other sophisticated machinery.

title: Prisoners Lose An Appeal About Parole
description: It is not just in old movies  James Cagney in Each Dawn I Die, for example  that prisoners eligible for parole often get a hard time. Last week the Supreme Court ruled that inmates have limited rights and states can set their own parole procedures.

title: THEATER
description: THE belief that all theater critics understand every show they see is a fallacy that must have been started by a critic. Who else could profit from the notion? I know that, as I sat at a table at Comdie Cabaret with two other critics, we were all baffled by some of the proceedings.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The American Numismatic Society of this city has just acquired a remarkable collection of copper coins of Vermont mintage. The collection was formed by the late Count Alexandre Orlowski of Poland, who settled in Castleton, Vt., where he lived for many years.

title: Getting Married
description: The smart bride will start her beauty ritual at least three months before the wedding day, states Mr. Bandy. The skin needs proper rest, nutrition and exercise to look its best and, to me, the skin is the single most important element in beauty.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Richard Nixon said a President had to have confidentiality to get the nation's work done. The Supreme Court wouldn't let him have it.

title: Unions Move to Organize Illegal Aliens in the West
description: LOS ANGELES, June 2  Cecilia Martinez is shy and cannot speak English.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Leonard Hall Dies; State and National G.O.P. Leader
description: Leonard Hall, a former Republican national chairman and a force in New York State politics for decades, died yesterday at the Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 78 and had suffered two strokes in the last several months. He had been hospitalized for three weeks.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: AVON  Selected works by young artists from Farmington Valley High Schools, auspices Connectieut Conimiesion on the Arts. Farmington Valley Arts Center through Saturday. Today 1 to daily 11 to 4, closed Monday. 6781887:

title: Higuera, in Playoff, Takes Dodge Open
description: DENVILLE, N.J., June 2Mike Higuera, the 40-year-old club pro from Edgewood in River Vale, N.J., won the 16th annual Dodge open today, beating Bob Ross of Baltusrol on the second hole of a playoff.

title: Dr. Janet Morahan, Teacher, Is Manied To Dr. C.H. Martin
description: Dr. Janet May Morahan of Brookline, Mass., assistant professor of psychology at Bryant College in Smithfield, R.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Curtis Harmon Martin of Wellesley, Mass., assistant professor of political science and chairman of the political science department at Metrimack College in North Andover. Mass.

title: In Convention Center Area, Hopeful Sellers Lift Prices
description: Heavy buying and selling has not begun in the area around the old Penn Central yards, where the new convention center will be built. But some owners of real estate there are already finding themselves in the unaccustomed position of having to decide whether to hold on to property they already own, seek bargain parcels in the neighborhood or sell out altogether.

title: Getting Married;
description: It is a marvelous ornament, as oldfashioned and sentimental as a lace valentine. In architectural circles, the tiered, marble structures with elaborate rococo designs may provoke a laugh or a groan. But before this traditional month of marriage reaches its end, countless thousands will be baked, mostly in professional ovens, to celebrate that happy stage of matrimony.

title: The New Leon Spinks
description: As soon as his plane unloaded at La Guardia Airport, unswerving Irving Rudd headed for a phone booth. His news was too hot to hold till he got home. He had discovered, he said breathlessly, a new Leon Spinks. Anyone familiar with unswerving Irving's attitude toward people knows that if he had been around Chalons surMarne in A.D. 951 he would have been telling friends: Look, the guy has changed. His real name is At tila the Hon. And he's a sweet guy.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: MAGNOLIA, a Camden County community that bills itself as One Square Mile of Friendliness, has run into an unfriendly act from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: U.S. Talks to Muzorewa Aides
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  The State Department disclosed today that two officials of its Bureau of African Affairs recently discussed developments in Zimbabwe Rhodesia with two representatives of Prime.Minister Abel T. Muzorewa's political organization.

title: Revised County Plan Urged for Passaic
description: PATERSON TROUBLED with fiscal problems and charges of widespread nepotism and patronage in the ,gppointment of county officials, leaders in the 16 communities of Passaic County are pushing for a new form of county government through a referendum on the November ballot.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Messa di Gloria

title: A Harsh Cure for Savings Banks
description: The State Savings and Loan Association of Columbus, Ohio, with assets of $480 million, is a notably sound, wellrun operation. In one sense, certainly, it seems to be doing particularly well. Its revenues  mainly interest payments on homeowners mortgages have been rising at a healthy clip of $50,000 a month.

title: Notes: A Random Sampling
description: Along with June flowers, summer festivals seem to be blossoming all over the place these days, and they have a brilliance and variety all their own. Among other things, they afford visitors an opportunity to take in a wild pony roundup in Virginia, dance a polka in the Catskills, or down a shoofly pie in the Pennsylvania Dutch Country.

title: The World
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia  The cast changed here last week but the basic plot remained the same. A black Prime Minister took office with a Cabinet that was more than twothirds black, but the military and economic problems that gravely weakened the Government under white leadership did not relent when Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa moved into the spacious Prime Minister's residence, named Independence, and Ian D. Smith moved out. The ceremonies of sticcession were in a sense dominated by two men who were outside the country plotting the violent downfall of the Bishop and his men.

title: Christopher Isherwood: Man and Work
description: CHRISTOPHER ISHERWOOD A Critical Biography. By Brian Finney. Illustrated. 336pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $13.95.

title: The Michigan Bottle Law: Model for a Federal Ban?
description: DETROIT In Michigan, a sixpack of beer costs at least 15 percent to 30 percent more than it did six months ago. In fact, beer prices are so high that the Farmer Jack supermarket chain has begun selling a nobrand beer to cut costs. Inflation has been bad, of course, but something else is obviously at work.

title: On Moving Day, the Past Comes Along
description: WE are moving. It was 11 years ago, on Lincoln's Birthday, that we moved into this house. My daughter became 4 that spring and her baby brother 1. It would be four more years, again in the spring, that my younger boy would be born. and it would be eight and a half years from that moving time that my father would die. I was still in my 20's then, and it was the first time I owned and lived in a house.

title: Deaths
description: DICKEYJoan B., widow of James B. Dickey, suddenly in Boca Raton, Fla. Memorial contributions may be made to Eastern Tennis Association, White Plains, NY.

title: Music: chamber Works With Mrs. Grant, Pianist
description: Berengere Grant presided over a program of chamber music in Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night. Mrs. Grant, who is the granddaughter of the noted French composer Vincent D'Indy, began her career in France some time ago as an operatic soprano, but the piano has been her chief interest since she took up residency in the United States.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: These recently published volumes may enhance the pleasures of summer.

title: The Heart Law Deserves to Die
description: Even the most cynical New Yorker would agree that firemen and policemen live dangerously much the time. But it is hard to find a physician, however sentimental, who agrees that the dangers and exertions of their work should automatically be presumed responsible for the heart disease among them.

title: Realty News
description: The Consumer Credit Division of Chase Manhattan Bank has leased the former department store building at 1400 Union Turnpike in Lake Success, L.I., in an expansion move.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: DINING OUT
description: PEGASUS, the recently opened restaurant complex on the fourth floor of the grandstand at Meadowlands Race Track, is not about food. It's about money. About $13 million of the $76.3 million bond issue floated by the Sports Authority has gone into outfitting this marblelined and glasswrapped facility.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Just for Fun Weekend returns to the county Thursday through Sunday. It will represent a joint effort by the Westchester Department of Parks and Recreation and several corporations and nonprofit organizations to provide a broad spectrum of entertainment and a modicum of togetherness for county residents. Ethel Merman heralds the opening in no uncertain tones at 8 P.M. Thursday with a concert at the County Center in White Plains. Tickets are $6 to $10; call 9498900.

title: Topics
description: New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority wants to go all the way with halffares.

title: Picking Your Own Fruits and Vegetables on Long Island
description: The strawberries are right on time this year, despite the shortage of sunny days in May. In western Suffolk County and the Riverhead area of Long Island, most of the fields, are open now. Farther to the east, the crop ripens later, with a delay of another week or so on the North and South Forks.

title: All Aboard for Colorado's Narrow Gauge Railroads
description: When the engineer pulls the cord and the whistle sings out and the smoke billows forth in great black clouds, there is little else that rail enthusiasts could ask for. They know they are about to embark on a ride on a narrow gauge train.

title: IN A ROYAL LIMBO
description: The King of Albania is 6 feet 8 inches tall and always carries a gun. He'd probably have to use it if he ever showed his face in Albania. The Communist regime doesn't think much of the royal family, and the king has done nothing to endear himself. He spends his days commanding a National Army for the Liberation of Ethnic Albania.

title: McDonnell's Fateful Merger With Douglas
description: LOS ANGELES  It is a standard business strategy. A company that does all its business in a single market, selling whips for buggies, for example, has a problem if the market collapses. Worse off still, theoretically, is the company that deals with a single customer. That is why, 12 years ago, the

title: COALITION IN HOUSE LEADS SHIFT TO RIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  When Congress passed a tentative Federal budget last week, the measure projected less spending and a lower deficit than originally proposed by President Carter. Moreover, the resolution put Congress on record as favoring a balanced budget for the fiscal year 1980.

title: Mazzilli: The Mets' Major Asset a Matinee Idol
description: ATLANTA THE New York Mets have scant power, little pitching, limited attendance and not much chance of escaping last place in the National League Eastern Division. But they also have some corporate assets that include a pet mule, a team song, Casey Stengel's old uniforms and, as growing numbers of teenage girls insist, a sex symbol from Brooklyn's Sheepshead Bay.

title: Jeffrey Hipple, Catherine Irwin Wed in Jersey
description: The marriage of Catherine Cartwright Irwin and Jeffrey David Hippie, alumni of Franklin and Marshall College, took place yesterday in Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. James F. Loughlin of St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Caldwell, N.J., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Hayward Irwin 2d. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Hippie of Lancaster, Pa.

title: M.E. Zmuda Weds Maureen J. O'Brien
description: The Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Haworth, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Maureen Joan O'Brien and Michael Edward Zmuda. The Rev. Carl Hinrichsen performed the ceremony.

title: Marijean Raffetto Bride Of Frederick Stevens Jr.
description: Marijean E. Raffetto, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Raffetto of Sea Girt, N.J., and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Frederick E. Stevens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens of Spring Lake Heights, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the Episcopal Church of St. Uriel the Archangel in Sea Girt by the Rev. Edward C. Raffetto Jr. of Croom, Md., a cousin of the bride.

title: Presidential Declarations
description: WASHINGTON  Whether they do it at the National Press Club or in front of City Hall at Russell, Kan., presidential candidates have only one moment in the early stages of a campaign when they can count on conveying a national message pretty much the way they want to send it  when they announce their candidacy.

title: State Honors Residents for Achievement in the Arts
description: CONNECTICUT honored its artists and the arts yesterday, at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, where the state's second annual Arts Awards were bestowed upon eight individuals and institutions.

title: Aging Stunt Man Takes to Grave for Penultimate Repose
description: PHENIX CITY, Ala., June 1  Time was, Digger O'Dell would bury himself alive for any usedcar dealer with a few bucks, but nowadays it takes a major national issue to stir the Digger to re- pose.

title: Brock to Be AllStar
description: ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP)  Lou Brock is not on the AllStar ballot, but Tom Lasorda, the Los Angeles Dodgers manager, says the St. Louis Cardinal star will wear a uniform in the July 17 game.

description: Of Special Interest
