description: BROOKVILLE  Paintings, photographs by Barbara Sugarman; 2 to 5 P.M. today; C.W. Post Art Gallery, The Dome.

title: Late TV Listings
description: Noon (Channel 2) Newsmakers: Governor Carey.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Rising prices for imported oil and growing signs an economic downturn combined with oil shortages last week to send the Dow Jones industrial average tumbling to its lowest level in three months. After 10point loss Wednesday, the Dow finished at 821.21 to show a net decline of 15.07 points.

title: TV VIEW
description: Only my an envious lout or vindictive clod could fail to have a modicum of sympathy for Fred Silverman, one of this season's major media events. The president of the National Broadcasting Company has been subject to the kind of press scrutiny normally reserved for revolutions, tornados and Hollywood starlets. Through a combination of expertise and fortuitous timing, he achieved a reputation as a programming wunderkind at both CBS and ABC. Then, last year NBC, which had plummeted into the ratings cellar, hired Mr. Silverman away from the topranked ABC at a reported annual salary of $1 million. Like Barbara Walters before him, Mr. Silverman became headline fodder. One year later, NBC still at the bottom of the ratings heap, and the executive, now in his early 40's, remains in the headlines because he failing to perform, relatively overnight, the miracles predicted in his overheated press clippings. The cycle feeds upon itself unto infinity.

title: Clerical Walkout Ends at L.I.U.
description: An agreement has been reached between Long Island University and 450 clerical workers, ending a 27day walkout, according to a spokesman for Federal mediators.

title: Other World Events
description: Disclosure of foreign bribes by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation forced a Japanese Prime Minister from office, discredited a Dutch prince and led to the resignation of an Italian President. Last week, Lockheed was punished. It was fined $647,000. The fine was imposed after the corporation pleaded guilty to covering up $2.6 million in bribes, including $1.8 million paid to the office of the former Japanese Prime Minister, Kakuei Tanaka, who has been on trial in Tokyo for the past two years.

title: Carole Shelley  Transformed By The Elephant Man
description: This is the most extraordinary year for me  really a mixture of the best of times and the worst of times  and it's only just begun. The play that I was going to do Off Broadway for four weeks at $130 a week is now the hottest thing on Broadway. I lost my mother, who was both a dear parent and a friend. I reach a major age plateau, the big four0, in August  000f, talk about your plateaus! And I've been nominated for a Tony Award. God!

title: Grete Waltz Sets Record in Park Run
description: More than 4,100 women temporarily solved the energy crisis yestprday, on an occasion called the eighth L'eggs Mini Marathon, a 10,000meter (6.2mile) run in Central Park. If there really is a shortage, the women  from 7 years old to 65, from 38 states and five countries  created their own energy. It could not be sold by the gallon or halfgallon. It could not be bottled, gouged, inflated or siphoned. And there were no meltdowns.

title: Connors and Mrs. Lloyd In French Quarterfinals
description: PARIS, June 2  Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert Lloyd advanced today to the quarterfinals of the $185,000 French open tennis championships, but not without struggles. And 10thseeded Brian Gottfried was toppled by Gene Mayer of New Jersey in five sets after holding a twoset lead.

title: Some Recommendations for Easing The Tough Law on Juvenile Offenders
description: THE state's Juvenile Offender Law is not, in its present form, the proper solution to the problem of juvenile crime. The law is uniquely harsh in its treatment of younger juveniles. More seriously, its impact is uneven, unjust and sometimes ineffective. Major changes are necessary.

title: Around the Nation
description: LANCASTER, Pa., June 2 (UPI)More than 30,000 residents of Amish communities were immunized against polio today because of six confirmed cases of the disease in recent weeks. The outbreak was the largest since 1972.

title: GARDENING
description: OF all flowers, few, if any, have had a longer or closer association with man than the rose. Most regions habitable for plants in the northern hemisphere have their own species of wild rose, but it is thought that they were first cultivated in China during the Shen Nung Dynasty from 2737 to 2697 B.C.

title: Defeat for the Guidelines Last Week Affects Crucial Labor Talks
description: WASHINGTON  One thing you can say about the President's inflation fightersthey keep trying.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: With stories like Little Red Riding Hood! and The Three Little Pigs of limitless longevity, it's been some time since the wolf has had a good press. Last March the Alaska Department of Fish and Game added another charge to the traditional ones against the toothy wolf: moose killing.

title: Excerpts From Pope's Greeting
description: WARSA W, June 2 (UPI) Following are excerpts from the Vatican's translation of remarks by Pope John Paul II to President Henryk Jablonski of Poland, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski and the Polish people on his arrival here today:

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS
description: A funny thing happened to the Government on its way to the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals, where it will reiterate its arguments that an article about thermonuclear weapons should not be published in The Progressive magazine because it might help foreign governments build hydrogen bombs.

title: Volunteerism: New Paths
description: It was once assumed that when young woman married, she would leave her mother's home but take along her mother's ties to the world of volunteerism. Like a hove chest containing the accouterments of family life, the affiliation with the bandage rolling group, the church auxiliary or the synagogue sisterhood was automatically passed on. Members of Hadassah still boast that theirs is a fivegeneration organization.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Travel time. In summer, not all the bestselling paperbacks are light novels intended for poolside reading. Most booksellers report that some of their most soughtafter wares are guides for travel here and abroad. Most wellstocked stores have shelvesful of volumes designed for every taste and destination. All are collaborative efforts, researched, written, edited and published in ways as diverse as two of the past season's top sellers  the Rand McNally Road Atlas ($3.95), which for generations has been helping Americans discover the wonders of their own continent, and Let's Go! A Budget Guide to Europe (Dutton, $5.95), the present college generation's favorite counselor in coping with the ways of the Old World.

title: A Second Opinion On Agent Orange
description: Between 1961 and 1970, the United States sprayed the Vietnamese countryside with 12 million gallons of Agent Orange, a defoliant containing dioxin, the most poisonous of all chemicals. A guinea pig fed a single dose equal to less than one billionth of his body weight will die within a few days. The substance is also known to cause birth defects, tumors and miscarriages in animals. Nevertheless, the Veterans Administration has ruled that there is no positive evidence linking Agent Orange to longterm health difficulties in human beings, and it has turned down the claims of 500 veterans who say they suffer from disabilities caused by exposure to the herbicide.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: GOVERNMENT can be a barrel of laughs  or at least it can mix its serious business with little fun. That proposition is being tested in the village of North Tarrytown, which last week kicked off Secession Week to draw attention to its efforts to secede from the Town of Mount Pleasant and reconstitute itself as an independent town/village.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHEN Dr. John Maguire, the president of the State University at Old Westbury, is awarded an honorary degree Thursday by his alma mater. Washineton and Lee University

title: Lights On to Be Held June 10
description: Lights On, the 31st annual allstar show sponsored by Fight for Sight, will be held June 10 at Avery Fisher Hall. Funds realized will help Fight for Sight in its program of international research. The organization has raised more than $7 million, distributed to 200 medical colleges and eye centers in the United States and abroad. Tickets, from $7.50 to $50, may be obtained from the organization's founder, Mildred Weisenfeld, at 139 East 57th Street, New York, N.Y.

title: Kathleen L. Young Fiance of Teacher
description: Kathleen Lillian Young, a nurse at Mount Sinai Hospital, and David R. Trower, chairman of the religion department at the Collegiate School, plan to be married Aug. 11 at the Chapel of the Cross (Lutheran) in St. Louis.

title: Portrait of An Editor
description: WHEN I began my imprint I described the venture, halfjokingly, as the wave of the past, Henry Robbins said, I don't really think it is, though, and I can't say that I'm surprised by my success. With more and more publishing houses becoming parts of conglomerates, personal publishing might seem to have become an anachronism. I don't think it has. The essential ingredient of good publishing is still strong and competent editors who have good relationships with their authors.

title: California, Alabama Baiiking Cases Reflect Tough fury Attitudes
description: Whitecollar criminals, once neglected or treated lightly by prosecutors, judges and juries, are increasingly being treated like real criminals.

title: AdventureSeekers Have Wide Choices
description: How would you like to:

title: Temple in Brooklyn Is Vandalized
description: A Brooklyn synagogue was vandalized early yesterday shortly after one of its members was assaulted and slightly injured by two youths, the police said. The vandals broke several secondstory windows of the synagogue, Temple Shalom of Flatbush at 2075 East 68th Street, and used paint, from spray cans to deface temple walls and several cars in the ternple's parking lot with antiSemitic and obscene phrases.

title: Chase Exhibition Delights With Its Happy Mood
description: SOUTHAMPTON RARELY does an exhibition of paintings reveal its mood immediately. It must be observed and absorbed until its mood is slowly, at times insidiously. established: The mood, however, in a display of works by William Merritt Chase and his contemporaries at the Parrish Art Museum Is a sudden revelation. 1t strikes quickly.

title: ART A Camera's Account of a Gilded Life
description: NEW HAVEN PRIVATE means may not be a prerequisite for great art, but they help. As a struggling painter once remarked, Even Van Gogh didn't have to take a job. Photography, especially during the 19th and early 20th centuries, was the beneficiary of numerous affluent amateurs and its history would scarcely exist without their contributions.

title: New Jersey's Plan For Private School Aid Is Invalidated
description: The Supreme Court last week put an end to a political dodge in New Jersey by declaring unconstitutional a law granting a $1,000 state income tax deduction to parents of children in nonpublic schools. The Court affirmed a Federal Appeals Court ruling holding that the deduction had the primary effect of advancing religion and thus violated the constitutional principle of churchstate separation.

title: Lifting The Spirit
description: PHILADELPHIA  Last Nov. 1, Martin E. Marty wrote in Christian Century that the election of a Polish Pope would seriously curtail the circulation of Polish jokes in the United States. Whether Mr. Marty was right depends on which barroom, street corner or Roman Catholic parish the canvasser chooses to visit. The one thing that is certain is that the ascendancy of John Paul II has gone a long way toward shoring up the confidence of an ethnic minority that has been put upon in this country for ages.

title: SHOULD AMERICAN BUSINESS PULL OUT OF SOUTH AFRICA?
description: He was one of the most prosperous merchants in Soweto. Prosperous is a relative term in that sprawling, shapeless township on the outskirts of Johannesburg (the name Soweto is actually an acronym for southwest townships). There, those in authority, who are white, allow the residents, who are black, to operate only small mom and pop businesses that cannot compete with the white merchants in Johannesburg.

title: ITALIAN POLITICIANS MAKE FINAL APPEAL
description: ROME, June 2  The Italian election campaign was officially closed today as leaders of all parties issued their last appeals to the voters before they elect a new Italian parliament Sunday and Monday.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: PORT WASHINGTON HE was laughing and her bicycle was wobbling back and forth in the road. She was teenager coming back from the park, and she was closer to dying than she could imagine.

title: Moynihan Draws Liberals' Rebuke on School Tax Credit
description: The Liberal Party policy committee repudiated Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan yesterday over his support of tuition tax credits for parents of privateschool students.

title: L.I. Schools Publishing Center Teaches More Than Just Reading
description: WEST ISLIP, L.I. The challenge that Dr. Gayle Pescuma faced was a universal one among teachers: develop pupils languageart skills and stimulate their interest in reading for pleasure. So two years ago, the sixthgrade teacher initiated a program in the West Islip School District that she called the three P's performing, processing and publishing.

title: CAMERA
description: The photographer who is interested In taking pictures of wild animals does not necessarily have to go on a safari to Africa or a camping trip to the wilds of South America  he or she can get excellent pictures at any zoo. In addition to the many public zoos located in most of the large cities of the United States, there are also the various safari type privately owned parks where animals roam freely while visitors ride through in their automobiles, plus the sea worlds and aquariums where aquatic species may be seen and photographed in action.

title: Bourguiba's Heir Apparent Ponders Tunisian Aims
description: TUNIS, May 30  His name is hardly a household word outside his small nation, and for almost a decade he has labored purposefully in the long shadow of Habib Bourguiba, the ailing President. But Hedi Nouira is certainly the leading candidate to succeed the 75yearold Mr. Bourguiba.

title: Hunter Is Annoyed At Uncertain Status
description: Catfish Hunter, who has been (a) healthy, (b) rusty, or (c) injured, was scheduled to hurl today for the Yankees against the Chicago White Sox at the Stadium. It was to be his third appearance in three weeks.

title: CAREY UNIT WARNS ON CITY'S ECONOMY
description: ALBANY, June 1An economic task force appointed by Governor Carey warned today that the economy in the New York City area has been and is declining and said that absent strenuous effort, these trends will continue and may accelerate  particularly if there is a national recession.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 3, 1979

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: MY recent close encounters with the Westchester public school system were of the worst kind, pros tell me, because I am a substitute teacher.

title: U.S. and States Seeking to Shift Blame for Regulation
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  Sensitive to growing public criticism of government regulation, Federal officials are trying to deflect the attacks onto states and localities, which they say are increasingly responsible for the reaulatory burden.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: AFTER THE FIRST DEATH. By Robert Cormier. (Pantheon. $7.95. Ages 12 and Up.) Written in lean and graphic proseand without a happy ending  a novel of terrorism and counterterrorism in which a busload of small children is held hostage.

title: For the Garbage Problem, No Magic Solution
description: HARTFORD UNTIL last week, it seemed that a bitter feud between Norwalk and Westport over garbage had been resolved. There was agreement that Norwalk

title: ADVENTURES INTO CHILDHOOD
description: The flap of the letter box rattled and a terrible smell pervaded the hall. I picked up the envelope gingerly and swung the front door open. A fairhaired boy, handsome and eightish, was creeping up the steps next door, another envelope in his hand.

title: A Top Islamic Leader Who Supported Sadat Is Murdered in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, June 2  An Islamic leader in the Israelioccupied Gaza Strip was stabbed to death last night and his assailants escaped. A Palestinian guerrilla group in Beirut said he had been murdered because he supported Egypt's peace treaty with Israel.

title: INVESTING
description: It's a shadowy business. Dealers won't name names; collectors won't admit to participating and it's a rare promoter who will confess to organizing them. Still, investment syndicates for works of art and collectibles ranging from antique furniture to Persian rugs, are reportedly springing up among professional and business groups in this country as yet another way to beat rising inflation.

title: Nancy Jacqueline Shepherd Is Married to David Webb
description: Nancy Jacqueline Shepherd and David Webb of New York, who have M.B.A.'s from the Colgate Darden School of the University of Virginia, were married yesterday at the Convent of the Sacred Heart. The Rev. Kenneth G. Jadoff performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Carter Says Public's Fears Impede Solutions on Energy and Inflation
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 2  President Carter said today that a pervasive public fear of being misled and cheated was hampering efforts to control inflation and deal with the energy crisis.

title: Stylish Backcourtmen Put Sonics on the Road to N.B.A. Glory
description: GUS WILLIAMS is flashy on the court and quiet off the court. Dennis Johnson is more subdued on the court, but his offcourt ways are those of a young man in a hurry. Together, Williams and Johnson famed, the delicate backcourt blend that brought the Seattle SuperSonics their first National Basketball Association championship Friday night.

title: Auto Racing Groups Set Separate Routes
description: Nov that the Indianapolis 500 has passed, so has the forced peace between the United States Auto Club and Championship Auto Racing Teams in their battle over the control of Indy car racing.

title: They Wouldn't Let Him Go
description: The vice chairmanship of the New York Stock Exchange is somewhat like the vice presidency of the United States: It can be real job, or it can be purely ceremonial. John J. Phelan Jr. has made such an impact in his four years as the vice chairman and top elected officer of the Big Board that all of Wall Street, it seemed, was alarmed this spring when he said he wanted out.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Musicology is no less mutable than any of the other artistic or scientific disciplines. Bits of knowledge are added to bits of knowledge and the result, when put together, often overturns received opinion. A recent hefty publication with an equally hefty title, Ornamentation in Baroque and PostBaroque Music, With Special Emphasis on J.S. Bach, by Frederick Neumann (Princeton University Press), is not only the definitive book on the subject to date. It will also make many scholars and musicians revise some of their pet ideas.

title: Votes in Congress
description: (Not in session)

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: Alyson Haley Has Nuptials
description: Alyson Rea Haley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Haley of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan to Arthur Vernon Woodworth 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodworth Jr. of Dover. Mass The Rev Dr Jacob Trapp, a retired Unitarian minister of Santa Fe, N.M., performed the ceremony.

title: South Korean Accident Kills 20
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 2 (Reuters)  About 20 people were killed today when a bus toppled over a cliff after colliding with a truck near Sarnchok in ??astem South Korea, the police said. More than 20 others were injured, some critically.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY construction projects around the house that require framing out with 2by4's or similar lumber call for a technique known as toenailing. For example, where vertical studs butt up against a 2by4 sole plate (the piece that lays flat on the floor) or up against the top plate (the horizontal 2by4 that goes across the top of the wall's framework).

title: It's Primary Time
description: ONE of those times when discretion is the better part of valor is just before an election, like the primaries coming up on Tuesday.

title: Fish Mortality Hearings to Pit Utilities vs. Environmentalists
description: ACURTAIN of fog hung heavily over the banks of the Hudson River on a recent morning as Crawford Tucker, a Verplanck fisherman, examined his nets and discovered a large striped bass tangled in the mesh. This was a normal occurrence, a sign of the beginning of the spring spawning season when thousands, perhaps minions, of striped bass swim up the river from the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Text of Pope's Homily for Mass
description: WARSAW, June 2 (UPI)  Following is the English text of Pope John Paul ll's homily during the openair mass at Warsaw's Victory Square this afternoon:

title: London Subway Strike Called
description: LONDON, June 2 (Reuters)  London subway workers voted today to reject a 10.3 percent pay increase offer and called for a strike to begin June 18. The strike would be the first serious labor action faced by the new Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: Official Asserts Firmani Failed To Get the Most Out of Cosmos
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., June  Despite winning nine of their 11 games so far this season in the North American Soccer League, the Cosmos were not playing as a team and not improving, according to Rafael de la sierra, executive vice president of the team. He cited those reasons today for the dismissal of Eddie Firmani as head coach at a news conference in Giants Stadium.

title: Leonard Hall Dies
description: Leonard Hall, former national chairman of the Republican Party and a force in New York State politics for decades, died at the age of 78. Page 36.

title: DINING OUT Good Things Italian
description: THERE are places one goes for dishes that are so good that one never gets around to the lesser ones; for the excellence of a few, the mediocrity of the rest is forgotten. La Conga d'Oro is a standard Italian restaurant in Mount Vernon that sticks pretty close to familiar items, but a few are special enough to bring one here again and again.

title: Marriages>
description: CARTERBRAUTIGAM

title: The Region
description: Nine years ago, the Health and Hospitals Corporation was created to streamline New York City's unwieldy municipal hospitals system, cut down on political tampering, and bring the 17 individual institutions under a central authority.

title: Study of Dying Disputes Idea That Doctors Prolong Life at Any Cost
description: In a rare analysis of how doctors treat people dying of chronic diseases, a physician and statistician have studied the medical records of nine nursing homes in Seattle to further public discussion about when and for whom full treatment should be withheld.

title: What' Doing Around BRIGHTON
description: SUSSEX  C.E.P. Brooks, in his book Climate in Everyday Life, asserted that, for allround activity, the southeast of England probably has the finest climate in the world. Visitors caught in an English summer downpour may be tempted to argue with him, but the variety of activities going on in Sussex has been phenomenal. The area has been a home for royalty, philosophers and rakes, novelists and statesmen, pioneers and conquerors, and its coast has been one of Britain' most popular resort areas since the Prince Regent fell in love with Brighton' s bracing air, created his Royal Pavilion and made the town fashionable more than 150 years ago.

title: Bronx Boy Found Dead in a Tub Was Slain and Sexually Molested
description: An 8yearold boy who was found dead Friday in the bathtub of a vacant apartment in the Bronx building in which he lived had been strangled, drowned and sexually molested, according to Dr. Michael R. Baden, the city's Chief Medical Examiner, .whose office began an autopsy yesterday.

title: Letter T 0 T H E E D I T 0 R
description: My congratulations to Patrick Huyghe and David Konigsberg for their article on the Grim Legacy of Nuclear Testing (April 22). We need to hear more about these matters, as well as about the current situation of our nuclear power plants and that of plants in other countries. If we wait for Washington to give us data on these matters, we shall find it is too late. We need responsi- ble and intelligent journalists, such as Mr. Huyghe and Mr. Konigsberg, to get the news to the people of this country.

title: Soil Erosion Laying Illinois River and Lakes to Waste
description: HAVANA, III.  The Illinois River and its contiguous bottomland lakes once supported one of the most produc- tive commercial fisheries for fresh- water species in the nation, and were famous for their superlative sport an- gling. Now they are dying.

title: SUMMER READING ISSUE
description: V.S.PRITCHETT is not much given to quarreling with other critics, but at one point in his new collection of essays he does allow himself to rebuke a professor who has been going in for some particularly jawbreaking jargon, subjecting Flaubert to a barrage of velleities and volitations. Literary criticism, he insists, does not add to its status by opening an intellectual hardware store.

title: Questions/Answers
description: What is the proper thing to do with grass clippings? Rake them up, bag them while mowing or leave them on the ground? P.M., Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Striking Similarities to Situation in Iran Causing Concern to Indonesian Regime
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 25  Indonesia's head of internal security, Adm. Sudomo, called a meeting of provincial governors and mayors of major cities here recently to warn them of the threat that the example of the Iranian revolution posed to this country, according to a wellinformed general.

title: Poor New York Teachers Called Difficult to Dismiss
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 2 New York City principals and supervisors at their annual convention here told top state and city education leaders today that they were having trouble ridding their schools of incompetent teachers.

title: Book and Film Worlds Play the Contract Game
description: LOS ANGELES, June 2  The incestuous relationship between books and movies was superficially glanced at last week at the American Booksellers Convention here. In deference to the fact that the convention was being held in Los Angeles, three movie company vice presidents, two movie producers, one agent, one author and the president of Bantam Books pondered The Dusty Book and the Silver Screen  A True Romance for a panel discussion without even grazing the skin of the subject.

title: Brascan Bows Out
description: When Brascan Ltd., the Canadian holding company, abandoned its effort to take over the F.W. Woolworth Company last week, the curtain fell on one of the most Byzantine corporate confrontations of the year. The action, however, wasn't over.

title: THEATER
description: BRIDGEPORT THE belief that all theater critics understand every show they see is a fallacy that must have been started by a critic.., Who else could profit from the notion? I know that as I sat at a table at Comedie Cabaret with two other critics, we were all baffled by some of the proceedings.

title: Miss Schmidt To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Schmidt Jr. of Beverly Hills, Calif. and Whitefield, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Justine Hayward Schmidt to Robert Russell Bloomingdale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred. S. Bloominedale of Inc Anoplpa

title: BUDDHISM IN AMERICA
description: The father's words reflected the pain in his face, as he talked about his teenage son.

title: A Stroll With an Existing Nonconformity
description: AT the Town Hall they classify my house an existing nonconformity. That means my home, like many others in Old Greenwich, was put up before the first building code went into effect in 1926.

title: Human Rights Investigation in Argentina Delayed
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 2  An investigation of human rights violations in Argentina by an interAmerican commission is being delayed, with the apparent intention of avoiding a debate on the situation at the General Assembly of the Organization of American States.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: The HarvinPerkins Duo, heard Mondy night at Carnegie Recital Hall, may not be the most polished or imaginative violinpiano team around, but the partners, both teachers at Middle Tennessee State University, are clearly skilled musicians. Jerry Perkins. the pianist, is a poised, unusually accurate player. Laurence Harvin, the violinist, did run into some pitch problems and patches of scrawny tone. For the most part, however, his work was equally fluent and communicative.

title: Investigation of Policeman's Slaying Under Inquiry
description: In an unusual rebuke, the Queens District Attorney's office has begun an inquiry into the Police Department's investigation of the murder of an offduty police officer.

title: Pay Is Up 7.8% in Year; Consumer Prices 10.2%
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) Straighttime wages of a typical American worker rose 7.8 percent in the 12 months ended in March, the Government has reported, but consumer prices in the same period rose by 10.2 percent.

title: Donald Frank Luke Weds Arm E. Lian
description: Ann Elizabeth Lian, a graphic designer, was married yesterday in the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Donald Frank Luke, a lawyer with the New York firm of Rogers & Wells. The Rev. J. Scottie Griffin performed the ceremony

title: GARDENING
description: LAWNS have never been better. The abundance of moisture last month has greened them up to sumptuous velvet. Even those who have taken little care of their lawn  and expect little from it  have been rewarded.

title: The Nation
description: Question. What rides on a railroad car in a 20mile concrete trench and costs $30 billion? Answer. Enough United States Senators to ratify the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty maybe.

title: Report Says Too Many Doctors Are Prescribing a Powerful Drug
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI)  Physicians are continuing to write too many prescriptions for chloramphenicol, a powerful antibiotic that has potentially fatal side effects, according to Congressional researchers.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Light Up the Sky Lights Englewood
description: ENGLEWOOD MOSS HART'S Light Up the Sky, written without the collaboration of George S. Kaufman, remains a thoroughly entertaining work, and it lights up the stage of the production currently being offered by the Center Stage company.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Yankees end their series with the Chicago White Sox at 2 P.M., Yankee Stadium today. The Kansas City Royals come into the Stadium tomorrow and Tuesday night at 8 o'clock. The Minnesota Twins arrive for games at 8 P.M. Wednesday and 2 P.M. Thursday. The Mets face the Houston Astros at 8 P.M. Friday and 2 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday in Shea Stadium.

title: The GoldmanDiLorenzo Empire And the Toss of a Coin
description: How do you divide a Manhattan real estate empire consisting of hundreds of office buildings, high, mid and lowrise apartment buildings, parking lots, vacant buildings and storefront properties?

title: Robert K. Landis 3d Weds Robin Taylor
description: Robin Lee Taylor and Robert K. Landis 3d were married yesterday in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Dayton, Ohio. The Rev. Robert Fenwick performed the ceremony.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Bad News: The Times Stays Still
description: LONDON  It is now six months since The Times of London ceased publiCation, and its prospects of recovery are still discussed like an illness in the family. For it is not just a newspaper that is missing; it is the notice board of the Establishment.

title: ART
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON FLOWERS are a subject with special appeal for both artists and their audience, especially now, as we eagerly await the lush garden displays of June In a salute to spring, the Elaine Benson Gallery inaugurates its 14th season with an exhibition in which 30 artists offer personal responses to the question What is a flower?

title: Fun Without Fuel. For Summer Months
description: WITH gasoline in short supply and expensive, vacation and weekend plans for the summer months may have to be adjusted. Even a car that gets 20 miles to the gallon will use a tank and a half of gasoline getting from Bergen County to the Berkshires and back for a music or dance festival (not counting side trips for sightseeing, antiquing and looking for parking space). And at $1 a gallon, that can eat significantly into the funandgames budget.

title: Legal Dispute Over Howard Hughes's Newly Profitable Empire Is Approaching Climax
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 2  The climactic months are just ahead for Howard R. Hughes's relatives, who must repel a determined takeover bid by some of his former executives and stand off the tax collectors before sharing what is thought to be the largest estate ever left for division without a will.

title: Leslie S. Nedurian Bride Of John Hayes, Designer
description: Leslie S. Nedurian and John Fox Hayes, alumni of the Philadelphia College of Art, were married yesterday afternoon in Ridgefield, N.J. The Rev. Vahrich Shirinian performed the ceremony in the St. Vartanantz Armenian Apostolic Church.

title: Responsibility Could Be a Factor in Today's Italian Election
description: ROME  The Italian Communists are running scared and are expected to lose votes in a national election for the first time since the end of World War II. While the opinion polls on the eve of today's election were wildly contradictory, as always in Italy, most analysts now expect Communist losses to be limited, maintaining the balance between the leading parties, Christian Democrats and Communists.

title: Auto Insurance: The Byrne Proposal
description: TRENTON OF THE 4.9 million motor vehicles registered in New Jersey, state traffic experts say that 600,000 will be involved in accidents this year, ranging from fender benders to multicar wrecks with multiple deaths.

title: Charles Stevenson Weds Joanne Hale
description: Joanne Williams Hale and Charles Scott Stevenson, cum laude alumni of Williams College, were married yesterday afternoon in Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Richard E. Ryder, assisted by the Rev. Alfred D. Moore, performed the ceremony.

title: FOOD An Excursion That Will Bear Fruit
description: THE strawberries are right on time this year, despite the shortage of sunny days in May. In western Suffolk and the Riverhead area, most of the fields are open now. Farther to the east, the crop ripens later, with a delay of another week or so on the North and South Forks.

title: CHARISMATIC RALLIES ATTRACT THOUSANDS
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 2Tens of thousands of charismatic Christians gathered at rallies here, around the nation arid in eight foreign countries today in a celebration of their credo, which emphasizes the spirit of God among men.

title: Connecticut After the Weicker Withdrawal and the Ribicoff Retirement
description: HARTFORD  Connecticut may be the land of steadyhabits, as Gov. Ella T. Grasso likes to call it, but its political parties have been shaken in a way that may have blurred the state's political picture for 1980.

title: DINING OUT
description: OLD GREENWICH ARESTAURANT named Tracks is, as one might expect, situated near a railroad station, in this instance across the road from the Old Greenwich station. This proximity and a few railway pictures and railroad lanterns are the only recognition given to the ironhorse theme.

title: ANTIQUES
description: WESTFIELD ARE you in the market for oak or wicker furniture for that spare room or summer cottage? An amethyst brooch for that special anniversary or birthday? Cut glass to accent a dressy table setting? If so, the antiques shops here may have just what you're looking for.

title: Preserving Open Spaces Through Land Trusts
description: Earl Smith owned about a tenth of an acre of land in New Canaan, Conn. It wasn't much, but it adjoined a waterfall and a mill pond in a rural part of the town, and he loved it. Although the corner property sits in a oneacre residential zone, Mr. Smith knew that if it were sold after he died it could be connected with another small piece next to it to form a building lot. He didn't want that to happen.

title: Salinger Was Playing Our Song
description: T'S the start of a just appreciation of J. D. Salinger to note how well, after all these years, we remember so much of what he wrote. Some of his visions, it seems, have turned out to be indelible. Holden Caulfield, for instance, his red hunting cap, unwilling to throw a snowball because everything looks so nice and white; Seymour Glass telling the little girl at the seashore that it's a perfect day for bananafish, then putting the gun to his temple an hour later; Zooey's blue eyes, which were a day's work to look into, or Franny muttering the Jesus Prayer under her breath. As a class, those who were young and literate in the Eisenhower and Kennedy years can be said to have received such pictures with utter credulity and in a state of mind resembling awe. Some of us founded not only our literary taste but also a portion of our identity on Holden Caulfield or on Franny Glass: we were smart kids in dumb world or sensitive kids in a phony one, and Salinger was playing our song.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Fuel Supply Concerns Boatmen
description: Boatmen escaped the 1974 fuel crisis primarily because it occurred during the winter and was solved by summer. But now, the crunch has arrived at the Waterfront. The boating industry estimates that there are 560,000 more powerboats on American waterways this year than last, yet there is 20 percent less fuel available.

title: GARDENING
description: NOW that June has arrived on the scene, I have begun to notice that the edges, of some of my flower borders look a bit dull. If you are weary of edging your garden beds with rows of ageratum or prim, plump marigolds, consider some of the uncommon, but decorative, edging plants, including several vegetables and fruits that look  and are good enough to eat.

title: Manhattan Cityscape
description: PAUL GOLDBERGER'S new guide to the architecture of Manhattan is without doubt the best thing of its kind yet to appear. It is a wonderful book  perceptive, entertaining, useful, refreshingly free of jargon and, in this reader's view, an important testament to the most important city in the land.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: There is a need for greater accountability today from the educational bureaucracy at all levels. In Connecticut not only is there poor use of the state financial resources, but also a failure by the State Department of Education to tighten certification standards and to enforce them. In 1977 one large city had 377 uncertified teachers on the payroll.

title: Instant Nostalgia For Auto Buffs
description: As if recalls and gas lines weren't enough, Detroit is increasingly losing business to companies that make cars that look like the ones that Detroit used to make.

title: Finding Fulfillment in a High Position
description: THE other day, sitting at my office desk 20 floors above the street, I recognized the window washer strapped outside my window, squeegeeing.

title: Readers in 6th Grade Are Also Publishers
description: WEST ISLIP THE challenge that Dr. Gayle Pesmuna faced was a universal one among teachers: Develop pupils languageart skills and stimulate their interest in reading for pleasure. So two years ago. the sixthgrade teacher initiated a program in the West Islip School District that she called the three P's performing, processing and publishing.

title: Pope Gets Big Welcome in Poland, Offers Challenge to the Authorities
description: WARSAW, June 2  Pope John Paul II returned home to Poland to a tumultuous welcome today and immediately pledged the Roman Catholic Church to serve people in the temporal dimension of their life and existence.

title: The World
description: France has been a daughter of Greece, but now she becomes a sister, said French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing. With such familial historical allusions, Greece last week was admitted to the European Economic Community.

title: This Band's Audience Sings, Too
description: BELLMORE IN the parking lot outside the Music Box here on a recent night, many of the cars and vans were plastered with blackandwhite bumper stickers whose legend read Get Vandalized. Rather than being an invitation to destruction, the stickers were demonstrations of fans enthusiasm for the Freelance Vandals, a quintet that has amassed a sizable following on the local bar circuit, playing mostly original material.

title: Meredith Malmberg Bride of Richard Crew
description: Meredith Ann Malmberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Earl W. Malmberg of Dallas, was married yesterday in the Princeton (N.J.) University Chapel to Richard Malcolm Crew, son of Dr. and Mrs. Malcolm C. Crew of Brookside, N.J.

title: White Sox Down Yanks On Kravec's 3Hitter, 70
description: Ken Kravec, a streak pitcher who loads up on carbohydrates like a marathon runner, yielded only three hits to the Yankees last night as the White Sox posted an easy 70 victory at Yankee Stadium.

title: Pay TV in Spanish Will Start Sept. 1
description: Galavision, a Spanishlanguage paytelevision service, will be offered to cable systems across the country starting next Sept. 1.

title: Quam Regains Bearings, Wins Offshore Race
description: FREEPORT, L.I., June 2  Despite getting lost three times on the 179mile course in the Atlantic Ocean, Howard Quam found his bearings in time to guide Flapjack to victory in the second annual Guy Lombardo/Halter Offshore Powerboat Classic today.

title: U.S. Soccer Team In Must Game
description: Things are going so poorly for the United States Olympic soccer team that at its last game the West German national anthem was played instead of the StarSpangled Banner.

title: Iowa Takes a Breather in Dispute Over Theories of Human Origins
description: DES MOINES, June 2 (UPI)  An emotioncharged controversy that prompted rallies on the Statehouse steps, protests at Iowa State University and anxiety among state officials has been laid to rest, at least for this year with the adjournment of the Legislature.

title: States Reluctant to Reduce Environmental Outlays
description: Despite public pressures for governmental belttightening, states still seem disinclined to cut back on outlays to improve the environment.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE Celebrated Jumping Frog Contest, for 23 years a dependable sign of springtime for youngsters in Hartford, has taken a giant leap into oblivion, prodded by the consciences of natural scientists and the public.

title: Famous First, Last Words
description: Call me Ishmael are the first words, of course, of Moby Dick. Ulysses ends,... yes I said yes I will Yes. But what novel begins: Call me Jonah? And what novel ends:  Now vee may perhaps to begin. Yes?'

title: GARDENING Zoysia, Not for All Lawns or Seasons
description: LAWNS have never been better. The abundance of moisture last month has greened them up to a sumptuous velvet. Even those who have taken little care of their lawn  and expect little from it  have been rewarded.

title: An Umpire's Motivation: Preserve Integrity
description: INTEGRITY on a major league baseball field is an elusive quality. Watching the action, you just assume it is there, but if you stop to look, you will be hardpressed to find it.

title: The Trip to the Brickworks With Coco:
description: We were watching La Guerre Est Finie on television one night, understanding about half the dialogue and much less of the plot, when there was a knock on the door. Standing in the doorway was Bernard GiraudTelme, known by all the 1,000odd inhabitants of SaintBonnet en Champsur  the French alpine village in which we make our home  as Coco. Coco owns a bus, a taxi and a large, battered, openbacked truck; in fact,,he is transportation in SaintBonnet.

title: Look Your Best: An Expert's Tips
description: SKIN is the single most important beauty feature. Fora smooth texture, try using a sheer, waterbased foundation, matching the color to the skin tone of your neck.

title: Kathleen Mary Savard Married
description: Kathleen Mary Savard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley J. Savard of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church to Robert Vincent Prestyly Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Prestyly of Huntington, L.I. Msgr. Robert J. Fox performed the ceremony. The bride is an alumna of C.W. Post College. Her husband graduated from La Salle Military Academy and Tarkio College in Missouri.

title: KHOMEINI IS ACCUSED BY NATIONAL FRONT OF A DICTATORSHIP
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 2  In personal criticism of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini unprecedented in postrevolutionary Iran, the liberal, secular National Democratic Front accused him today of dictatorship.

title: Quake Shakes Western Australia But Damage Is Said to Be Slight
description: PERTH, Australia, June 2 (AP) moderate earthquake in Western Australia shook merchandise from store shelves and sent residents of Perth scurrying into the streets early this evening. Two people were reported to have died of heart attacks in the excitement.

title: Deaths
description: NOBLERobert Edward, on June 1, 1979. of Lulherville. MD, and Pilot Knob, NY, devoted husband of Diane Lee Noble (nee Davis), and loving father of Kathleen Anne Vittengl, Judith Ann, Thomas Edward and Mark Elliott Noble, dear sort of Edward and Margaret Trainor Noble of Deerfield Beach, Fla., loving grandfther of Eric. Michael and Tatum Elizabeth Vittengl. The family will receive friends at the LemmonMitchellWlerjefeld Funeral Home, 10 W. Padonia Rd., Timonium. MD, on Sunday from 24 and 79 PM. Mass of Christian burial in the Immaculate Conception Church, Towson, MD, on Monday at 10 AM. Interment in Evergreen Cemetery, Lake George, NY, on Tuesday at 2PM.

title: After 40 Years in Politics, the Senator
description: WASHINGTON  An almost beatific smile broke over the normally somber face of Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff as he read the note that had just been handdelivered to his office. Please reconsider. We need you, was the message scrawled on the heavy stationery, and it was signed Jimmy. An hour earlier. the Connecticut Democrat had told two television interviewers that he had not notified President Carter in advance of his retirement because I didn't want any discussion about it. But the message from the White House, after the fact, obviously gave him great satisfaction.

title: Brooklyn Tech Is Victor In P.S.A.L. Track Event
description: Brooklyn Tech, helped by a strategic but controversial move by its coach, Ed Zarowin, completed a sweep of Public Schools Athletic League track and field titles yesterday by winning the outdoor championship at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: JumboSize Trouble For the Airlines
description: Most DC10 jumbo jets were flying again late last week after inspections for engine mount flaws, the cause of an American Airlines crash that killed 273 persons in Chicago on May 25. Grounding of the planes meant only minimal inconvenience for travelers, but it turned up so many deficiencies that the Government tightened inspection requirements for the 138 DC10's owned by United States airlines.

title: Church and State  The Poles Can't Separate Them
description: On the whole, the Communist Government of Poland was pleased to see the election of the first Polish Pope; in Rome, Communist officials thought, Karol Jozef Wojtyla would be too busy shepherding the world's 720 million Roman Catholics to give special heed to the faithful at home. Now, they may wish he had stayed in Rome.

title: Scot Terrell  Weds Marilyn Murphy
description: Marilyn Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Murphy of New York and Block Island, R.I., was married yesterday in St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church on Block Island to Scot Alfred Terrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Terrell Jr. of Port Washington, L.I., and Key West, Fla. The Rev. Robert J. Randall performed the ceremony.

title: Legal or Not, SingleFamily Homes Adding Apartments
description: Many suburban communities in the New York metropolitan area are looking for legal ways to divide singlefamily houses into apartments.

title: A Change Of Pace In the sun
description: PITTSTOWN FOR two weeks this summer, three innercity youngsters will try their hand again at milking cows, stacking hay and feeding chickens on a farm in this Hunterdon County community. They also will swim in a nearbypond, go horseback riding or just take the opportunity to breath some clean, fresh air.

title: Two Arrested on Assault Charge After AcidThrowing Injures Nine
description: A Newark man and a Manhattan woman were arrested yesterday in lower Manhattan on assault charges after each accused the other of throwing acid, the police said. Only the man was seriously hurt.

title: Anne H. Warden Plans July 7 Bridal
description: Mrs. H.H. Hugo Fries of Wilmington, Del., and Herbert W. Warden 3d of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Hubbard Warden, to Mark Crawford Sinkinson of Marblehead, Mass. He is a son of the Rev. and Mrs. George E. Sinkinson Jr. of Farmington, Me. A July 7 wedding planned in Colebrook, Conn.

title: On Language
description: The Kook is dead; long live the Flake.

title: Glastonbury's Howe Dynasty
description: SPORTS

title: Miss Runstedler, Michael B. du Pont Are Married on L.I.
description: St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Ann Runstedler and Michael Belfield du Pont. The Rev. Charles G. Newberg performed the ceremony.

title: The Big Money in Soot
description: If you haven't decided What you want to be when you grow up, or if you've al- ready grown up and have decided you want to be something else, then you might consider a career area that is much in demand these days among energyconscious homeowners  chim- neysweeping.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Automatons. Wind them up or flip a switch and see what wonders they perform. A jaguar stalks, a lion roars and an elephant lumbers along with a sultan on his back. Clowns tumble. Monkeys jump, ride a tricycle or crank out a tune on an organ. A peasant feeds, a truffle to a pig. A rabbit emerges from a cabbage wagging its furry ears. And a black musician nods ands blinks while he plays the banjo.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review of May 27 on international lending agencies stated that World Bank expenditures on professional staff in fiscal 1978 were higher than net disbursements. Actually, the bank's personnelrelated expenses were oneeighth of net disbursements, or about $200 million as against $1.6 billion.

title: Under the Wraparound Sky of the Yukon Territory
description: Ordinary travelers seeking ordinary vacations should not go to the Yukon. It is not reachable by ordinary Interstate highway. There are no ordinary amusement parks, no ordinary tall towers with ordinary revolving restaurants, and no ordinary sumptuous hotels with ordinary Olympicsize swimming pools. Ordinary tourist attractions are few and far  very far between. Ordinary food is hard to come by; there is not even a McDonald's in the whole territory.

title: BRIDGE
description: Tournament bridge in North America is almost entirely an amateur occupation, and the winners have to be content with prestige, master points, modest prizes in kind, and perhaps a step on the road to world championship honors. But in many parts of Europe money becomes important to the experts. Substantial cash prizes are awarded, just as they are in chess tournaments; and players of the highest class can hope to cover their expenses, which are considerable.

title: Mailbox: Giant Draft Ignored Basic Needs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Freeing Children From the Cult of Activity
description: LAST year seven high school students from an exclusive New York suburban community attempted suicide, all within six months. Two succeeded, five failedone after another during a twoweek period  by overdosing on prescription or household drugs.

title: Albany Reverses 4 Fish Hatchery Closings
description: ALBANY, May 31  Bowing to the State Legislature, the Department of Environmental Conservation has reversed its decision to close four of its 14 fish hatcheries.

title: Leaving Rome, the Pope Stresses Need for Restraint
description: WARSAW, June 2 Pope John Paul II told reporters during his twohour flight from Rome to Warsaw today that he had deep emotions about the trip, but he added that he felt a need to contain his excitement over his return to his homeland.

title: Pilot Errors Blamed in Most smallPlane Collisions
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI)  Two models of private aircraft were involved in nearly half of all midair collisions of singleengine, fixedwing planes over a fiveyear period, but the great majority of the collisions were caused by pilot error, a report of the National Transportation Safety Board says.

title: CHESS
description: What was called une petite combinaison by the brilliant Cuban Jos Raul Capablanca, world champion from 1921 to 1927, was a brief tactical sequence featuring an ingenious turn that he so often used to win a game.

title: Performance Art: 'south
description: Sylvia Palacios Whitman began presenting her series of tableautype events before they could come under the category of performance art, an umbrella term now currently in vogue. Whatever one calls it, Miss Whitman's concert Friday night at the Guggenheim Museum had all the indefinite characteristics of the new genre in that it was neither theater nor happening or dance but could have been any of these in a loose sense.

title: SEMINAR IN EUROPE VIEWS U.S. AS WEAK
description: PARIS, June 2  Worried European complaints about American weakness and harsh criticism of the Carter Administration's policies emerged this week at an Atlantic Institute seminar here unabashedly titled, What is wrong with EuropeanAmerican relations?

title: Fashion
description: After a decade of hopping a cab to City Hall or traipsing about a country meadow at dawn, more and more couples are making the formal march down the aisle. That means bridal gowns. And from the stately department stores of Fifth Avenue to smalltown bridal shops, business is booming.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: MANY construction projects around the house that require framing out with 2by4's or similar lumber call for a technique known as toenailing, For example, where vertical studs butt up against a 2by4 sole plate (the piece that lays flat on the floor) or up against the top plate (the horizontal 2by4 that goes across the top of the wall's framework).

title: More Heat on Oil Prices
description: The President appeared preoccupied last week with energy. He met with oil executives one day and on another with consumer representatives who oppose decontrol of domestic oil prices. He signed an executive order giving governors authority to regulate gasoline sales. At the meeting with consumer advocates, Mr. Carter had harsh words for the Mobil Corporation. According to several who attended, he called it perhaps the most irresponsible company in America for opposing decontrol.

title: RomeWashington: The Road Is Long
description: EARLIER this year, I attended the Puebla Conference in Mexico as a consultant to Time magazine. The purpose of that crucial gathering, which Pope John Paul II attended, was to chart a course for the Roman Catholic Church in Latin America.

title: Steel to Soy Sauce: 200 Japanese Factories
description: No one knows exactly how many Japanese factories there are in the United States, but the U.S.Japan Trade Council says they exceed 200. Most are probably in California, but there are many in Georgia and elsewhere in the relatively nonunionized Southeast, which is also the heart of the textile industry in which Japanese companies are well represented.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: BEFORE the mortgage interest rates were lifted to 10 percent last month, the air was thick with dire and contradictory predictions about what the effects of such a step would be on housing in New Jersey.

title: Building Flaws Embitter Greenwich Condominium
description: PURCHASERS of luxurious new $200,000 townhouse condominiums in Greenwich are threatening to withhold their property taxes and mortgage payments because they maintain that at least one of the four buildings in the development is rapidly sinking into marshland and no one is prepared to come to their aid or accept responsibility for the expected structural collapse.

title: Singer With Suitcase Of Surprises
description: MUSIC is a reality, but it's also an illusion, said Lou Stevens, a 30yearold Rocky Point resident who has spent 15 years developing an onstage persona that combines the two elements. Drawing from an assortment of more than 300 original songs and an open suitcase of personally meaningful curiosities that I just want to share with people, Mr. Stevens aims to ease his audience into an illusionary state that facilitates profound ruminations, quick laughter and openended flights of fancy.

title: Miss Serrell And a Lawyer Have Nuptials
description: At the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Patricia Wainwright Semen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Paul Serrell of Greenwich, was married to John Emile Schmeltzer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Schmeltzer Jr., also of Greenwich. The Rev. Robert P. Noble, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Thomas P. Guinan of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Books For Summer Reading; AUTOBIOGRAPHY & BIOGRAPHY
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of December 1978. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from the Book Review.

title: Fishing: Mixed Bag
description: THE outlook for the New Jersey angler this week is mixed, as summer fish continue to arrive and winter species leave the warming coastal waters for colder depths.

title: Editors' Choice
description: A BEND IN THE RIVER, by V. S. Naipaul. (Knopf, $8.95.) The ordeals and absurdities of living in new third world countries, precisely observed by a toughspirited novelist.

title: Confirmations
description: CARSILLO

title: A PATIENT'S PROGRESS: FROM
description: Most patients have their First contact with an anesThesiologist on; the day before their operation. It is at this time, after a brief examination and, the taking of a short medical history; that a decision is made as to whether or not the operation will actually take place. The sur

title: Paige Captures N.C.A.A. Double
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., June 2  Don Paige is America's man of the moment in the middle distances. Any doubts. about that were dispelled today when the 22yearold Villanova junior won the 800 and the 1,500meter runs 40 minutes apart during the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships.

title: A Golden Clasp
description: I COULD learn it really well, says Ernest Hemingway's worldweary colonel in Across the River and Into the Trees, contemplating the everbeguiling topography of Venice on his return to the city after the war. I could learn it really well, and then I'd have that.

title: Stage: New York Summer, Musical
description: A New York Summer, which opened Thursday at the refurbished and renamed Radio City Music Hall Entertainment Center and will run through Sept. 5, is a spectacular multimedia blitz of color. song and dance that celebrates the city and the Music Hall, one of New York's bestloved landmarks.

title: Design
description: See Dick and Jane. They're about to be married, and they are flush with high hopes for what their first apartment will be like. They amble through stores, eyeing sofas, rejecting chairs, until, finally, they come across a piece of furniture that is perfectly suited to them. They glance at the price tag and wince. It's steep, all right, but so what, this is a lifetime investment, right?

title: Horse Owners Find They Can Bet on Dr. Gandal
description: WE'RE the doctors who still, go out and make house calls, says Charles Gandal, a Briarcliff Manor veterinarian who specialize.s in largeanimal medicine. For veterinarians with largeanimal practices, patients are all creatures great, mostly cows and horses, and for Dr. Gandal, they're horses.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: President Carter's voluntary wage and price guidelines have never been popular. Businessmen and workingmen alike have been reluctant to exercise restraint while their costs kept on rising. But the guidelines are, atter all, the Administration's principal weapon against everunpopular inflation. And last week the President's program received a blow from the courts, one that may immobilize it altogether.

title: DANCE MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: Immortal Nominations
description: Among the few works of recent literature I have read there is only one that might qualify  Elsa Morante's La Storia [published in English as History: A Novel']. The ambiguity of the Italian title indicates the book's range: It is a story but also the history of the last years of Fascism as endured by a frightened, abandoned woman, her sons and their dogs. It is an epos of politics and war transformed into the reality of the slum dwellers nightmares. I believe that this grippingly authentic story will grow to become indeed the story as the historical events behind it recede in time.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS Five Ladies in Search of a Play
description: EAST FARMINGDALE PAUL ZINDEL writes sensitive novels for adolescents and hateful plays for adults. Confessions of a TeenAge Baboon and The Undertaker's Gone Bananas are the most recent additions in an impressive array of books characterized by catchy titles and an uncanny empathy for preteenagers. Mr. Zindel's Pig Man and My Darling, My Hamburger, two of his most popular, are just the type of book that can bring reading right back into style for the junior high school set.

title: Stunt Man Still Buried In Vault in Gas Protest
description: PHENIX CITY, Ala., June 3 (UPI) Herbert Digger O'Dell Smith was six feet under the ground today, chatting with onlookers from a sweltering vault where he vows he will remain buried until gasoline prices come down.

title: Marriage Announcement 6 -- No Title
description: Dr. Jane F. Karp, Psychiatrist, Bride

title: 2 Picassos, Other Art Defaced
description: LOS ANGELES, June 3 (AP) Someone using a metal object defaced eight paintings, including two by Picasso, at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, its officials have reported. Aguars wscovered the damage after closing Friday evening. The damaged works were Picasso's Courtesan and Weeping Women"; Baker's Children"; Luks's The Secret"; Neal's After the Hunt"; Prentize's Still Life"; Rouault's Christ and Wood's Arbor Day.

title: Barbara Milstein Bride Of David W. Zalaznick
description: Barbara Susan Milstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Milstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Wayne Zalaznick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Zalaznick of Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky of Temple Israel Center in White Plains performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: ULSTER'S FUGITIVES CREATING PROBLEM
description: DUNDALK, Ireland, May 30  Two guerrillas shot and killed a British infantryman in Northern Ireland one rainy afternoon not long ago, then raced across the border that runs just north of here and disappeared into the countryside of the Irish Republic.

title: Pollsters at Meeting Air Doubts On How Business Is Conducted
description: BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa.; June 3 You don't have to do arithmetic to know that 28 and 27 are the same, said one pollster to another. He was talking about margins of error.

title: Kison Settles for a OneHitter
description: PITTSBURGH, June 3 (UPI) Many pitchers would be happy after pitching a onehitter, but Bruce Kison of Pittsburgh was angry about a scoring decision that he felt deprived him of a nohitter.

title: De Gustibus
description: For a long time I have assumed that the term Bundt pan was an ordinary generic terni like cake pan, tube pan, black iron skillet and so on. Therefore it came as a bit of a surprise to discover that it is a copyrighted name just like Tabasco and Saran wrap.

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: YOUTH HARVEST Scholastic Magazine's annual display of prizewinning creative art by several hundred students in junior and senior high schools is always a stimulating sight in the Big Apple. This year's ton selections are 464 works in painting, drawing, printmaking, design, sculpture and crafts. They can be seen tomorrow through June 27 in the lobby of the Union Carbide Building, 270 Park Avenue at 48th Street.

title: Rio Mayor Says Former Capital Is Going Broke
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 3  The new Mayor of Rio de Janeiro says he hopes to create a free trade zone here to help restore the city to the financial health it enjoyed before it ceased being the capital of Brazil in 1960.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Deaths
description: Bausch, Carl Katz, Irving

title: Jan Kadar, Movie Director, Dies; Shop on Main Street. Got Oscar
description: Jan Hadar, the expatriate Czechoslovak director whose acclaimed movie The Shop on Main Street won the Academy Award for the best foreign film of 1965 as well as the New York Film Critics Award, died last Friday at CedarsSinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 61 years old and had lived in recent years in Hollywood and New York

title: WATERFRONT AGENCY SUSPENDS NIGH AIDE
description: The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has secretly suspended a highranking investigator on charges that he may have disclosed confidential information to Anthony M. Scotto. the Rrunklyn International Longshoremen's Association leader, while Mr. Scotto was under investigation by Federal and state agencies.

title: Jazz: Abdullah Ibrahim and Band
description: ABDULLAH IBRAHIM, the South African jazz pianist and composer, formerly known as Dollar Brand, was introduced to American audiences under the auspices of Duke Ellington. Several years later he was championed by Ornette Coleman. These are impressive endorsements, and in general, Mr. Ibrahim has lived up to them, although his numerous albums as a solo pianist and leader of various small groups have not always done justice to his talent.

title: Waya Returns $3.80 For Belmont Victory
description: In a race moved from grass to dirt less than an hour before post time because of heavy rains, Peter Brant's Waya captured the $109,075 Saratoga Springs Cup Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: The City
description: Drivers. for the Pioneer Bus Company went on strike at midnight, cutting off service to Manhattan for 10,000 Brooklyn commuters.

title: Bridge:
description: The team headed by John Schwenke of North Palm Beach, Fla., captured the Reisinger Trophy for New York's major knockout team event by outdistancing a group of international experts headed by Peter Leventritt of New York City, 117105, in the final of the weeklong tournament at the Beverly Hotel Saturday.

title: Pop: Dionne Warwick Returns
description: DIONNE WARWICK has never seemed to be an exceptionally competitive singer. During the middle and late 60's, when she was recording the compositions of Burt Bacharach and Hal David exclusively, her manner of floating a phrase, her command of the subtlest variations in timbre and the ease with which she negotiated Mr. Bacharach's sometimes serpentine melodies contributed to the impression that she was above it all.

title: Realty Concern Fighting Offer

State and give the Profs their second straight National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III championship.COLLEGE STATION, Tex., June 3 (UPI)  With no yellow caution flags to slow him down, Darrell Waltrip drove his Chevrolet at a record average

title: Soviet TV: Pope but No Crowds
description: MOSCOW, June 3 (AP)  Soviet television viewers had their first glimpse of Pope John Paul II's visit to Poland today and were told that some church leaders were trying to use the event for antistate purposes.

title: Coast Boy, 14, Dies of Shootings That Killed Mother and a Friend
description: LOS ANGELES, June 3 (AP)  Noah Cotsen, the 14yearold son of Lloyd Cotsen, an executive of a soap company, has died of injuries he suffered when masked gunman shot him, his mother and a guest in their Beverly Hills home. Officials at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center said the boy died at 8 P.M. Friday.

title: China Expects OilExploration Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  China's highest economic official says he expects to sign agreements with American companies in the coming few days to use their technology in expanding the very great potential of China's oilfields.

title: Car PlateViolators Caught
description: BOSTON, June 3 (AP)  A crackdown on Massachusetts car owners who register their vehicles out of the state has caught more than 12,000 violators and earned the state and local communities more than $2 million, Registrar Richard E. McLaughlin has reported to state tax', collectors and assessors, McLaughlin said 12,675 motorists have converted from out of state to Massachusetts registration under the four-month-old caranaign.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  William Miller has been to the Federal Reserve Board what Stansfield Turner has been to the C.I.A.: a disaster.

title: Market Place
description: Some time ago, the Japanese created a securits with many of the attributes of American convertible securities but of even better quality, or so some ana?? lysts believe.

title: The Region
description: NEW HAVEN (AP)  Mayor Frank Logue formally announced his candidacy for a third term as mayor, saying he wanted to keep New Haven moving forward.

title: Borg, Gerulaitis in Quarterfinals
description: PARIS, June 3  Topseeded Bjorn Borg, improving his play in each round, today advanced to the quarterfinals of the French open tennis tournament by defeating Gilles Moretton of France, 75, 64.62.

title: Letters
description: Your editorial of May 25 concerning corporate mergers seems to rely on a single economist's view that the economic arguments of conglomerate mergers cancel each other out. The vast majority of economic and legal opinion, as evidenced in the ongoing hearings before the U.S. Senate Subcommittee on Antitrust and Monopoly, is that most mergers make good economic sense and that antimerger legislation will have negative economic consequences for our nation.

title: WNETTV Officials List 3 Meetings Open to Public
description: Officials at WNETTV will hold three meetings this month that will be open to the public.

title: Stage: Ntozake Shange's Dramatic Poetry in 'spell #7 at Public
description: IN Spell #7 Ntozake Shange has gone back most fortunately to the loosely linked dramatic poetry that she used in For Colored Girls. From the results, it is clear that she had not exhausted either the content or the form.

title: Advertising
description: MARKETERS who have an absolute fixation with the 18to49 age group are overlooking a far richer set, the 45 to 65's. These are people who have made it if they are going to make it. People who have reached their peak earnings. Folks who are in their prime time

title: TV: 'soHo Programs on Video Art
description: IN the last couple of months, at forums ranging from New York's Museum of Modern Art to San Francisco's Video Free America, I've been finding signs of renewed vigor in tile sprawling category that calls itself Video Art. Some of this art has been shown on regular television. Some was made and kept in outof-the-way lofts for the guarded delectation of a privileged few.

title: McGee Triumphs By Stroke on 68272
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 3 (UPI) Jerry McGee sank a pair of long birdie putts on the 17th and 18th holes, and Jerry Pate carded his only bogey at the 17th to give McGee a onestroke victory today in the Kemper open golf tournament. McGee and Pate each posted 68's, with McGee's 72hole total 272 and pate's 273.

title: Robert Montgomery Donaldson, Former Executive in Advertising
description: Robert Montgomery Donaldson, an account executive with Young & Rubicam, the New York advertising agency, during the 1950's, died Saturday at his home in Huntington, L.I. He was 64 years old.

title: Long Series of Legal Battles Plagues Doctor
description: CHICAGO, June 3  In 1957 a Milwaukee physician named Milton Margoles challenged the Internal Revenue Service over a $33,716 civil assessment he contended he did not owe.

description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Question Box

title: The Sikhs of Washingtn: Family Life and Prosperity
description: WASHINGTON  In a darkened row house 10 blocks from the White House, two dozen whitegarbed men, women and a scattering of children gather daily at 4 in the morning. For two-andahalf hours they chant, meditate and contort their bodies. This is the fastbreathing, Kundalini yoga exercise.

title: Supplementary Over-the-Counter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: White's Hit. Wins For Yanks in 11th
description: Roy White's twoout single past a diving Don Kessinger near second base scored Thurman Munson with the winning run as the New York Yankees beat the Chicago White Sox, 32, in 11 innings yesterday at the Stadium.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Despite the recent downward trend in statistics about the economy, the dominant view among credit market analysts remains pessimistic about fixedincome securities prices; most are convinced that interest rates are still headed unward.

title: Young Cautions U.S. on Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  Andrew Young, the United States delegate to the United Nations, warned today that African states might retaliate against the United States if it lifted sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia and recognized the Government of the new black Prime Minister. Abel T. Muzorewa.

title: Hypnosis Added to Crime-Fighting Arsenal
description: Hypnosis Added to CrimeFighting Arsenal

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The oil outlook calls for an extremely fragile balance between supply and demand over the next year and for more spot shortages and rising prices, according to Carter Administration officials and private oil analysts. The balance, they say, will be vulnerable to almost any new disruptions In world oil supplies not now foreseen, including possible new cutbacks in production in Iran. [Page Al.]

title: POPE PLEDCES UNITY WITH THE CHRISTIANS OF EASTERN EUROPE
description: GNIEZNO, Poland, June 3  Pope John Paul II, applauded by immense crowds, traveled to this site of Poland's first Christian capital today to pledge his solidaritywith what he called the often forgotten Christians of Poland's Soviet_ bloc neighbors.

title: Gas Usage: How Much Give?
description: Although Americans have continued to line up at filling stations to buy gasoline, even with the recent spate of price increases, economists in general agree that in the long run higher prices will tend to hold down consumption.

title: Underground Quarters for NATO
description: BRUSSELS, June 3 (AP)  The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is moving its European military command headquarters underground, the Belgian Defense Ministry reported. The underground complex, near Casteau in southern Belgium, is scheduled for completion in 1983 and is expected to cost about $58.5 million.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON ALTHOUGH anything can happen and usually does in tax legislation, it looks as if President Carter will. finally get his windfall profits tax on oil companies through Congress. The current sentiment is to toughen it when the House Ways and Means Committee begins drafting the bill later this week. In the Senate, it may well be weakened and, in the end, it may not depart too much from the original Administration proposal.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Roger Milliken, president of Deering, Milliken & Company, the big textile manufacturer based in Spartanburg, S.C., was in New York last week  as he has been around this time of the year for the last 26 years. That is when his baby, the Milliken Breakfast Show, now a Seventh Avenue tradition, is presented to apparel retailers and manufacturers.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Battle by California and Nevada On Tahoe May Bring a U.S. Role
description: LOS ANGELES, June 3  Like steelyeyed frontier poker players, California and Nevada are pushing out the last of their chips in the protracted struggle over environmental degradation at scenic Lake Tahoe, the Sierra Nevada mountain resort area that is bisected by the state boundary.

title: Books of The Times
description: LlOYD ERSKINE, the narrator of John Leggett's new novel, Gulliver House,? decides at his father's deathbed to become book publisher. Being bright and sure

title: NUCLEAR INSPECTORS UNEASY, POLE SNOWS
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  Three out of five of the Federal employees responsible for inspecting miclear reactors believe that many of their supervisor's practice a don'trocktheboat philosophy and that decision are often made by Government officials unfamiliar with the actual problems.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alfin Fragrances Inc. has named Andre Ponzelli executive vice president.
