description: CAIRO, June 6 (Reuters)  Egyptian voters will elect a new Parliament tomorrow in the first multiparty general election since King Farouk was deposed in 1952.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Retarded Boy Dies After Beating
description: Three retarded youths are to be charged with homicide in the fatal beating of another boy at a training school for the retarded in Vineland, N.J., the police there said.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The price of gold reached new highs yesterday while the dollar gained abroad but declined at home.

title: Carter's Policy: Storm Clouds Grow
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 With the nation's economy cooling off faster than the White House had expected only a few weeks ago, the Administration faces the danger that its conservative policy of fighting inflation at the risk of creating more unemployment will be attacked by traditional Democratic constituencies, jeopardizing Mr. Carter's chance for reelection. One of those constituencies. organized labor, is already at odds with Mr. Carter over wage restraint.

title: Agence FnancePresse/United Press International
description: MARKING THE 35th ANNIVERSARY OF DDAY: General of the Army Omar Bradley at a ceremony in Bayeux, France, commemorating the World War II invasion of Normandy. He led U.S. forces in the landing on June 6,1944.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 Eighteen months from now, a newlyelected President will be going over recommendations to appoint a group of foreign and defense policy professionals who operate Just below the top, who have grown up reading and criticizing and helping each other, and who frame most of the farreaching decisions made by the men in the limelight.

title: Retired Executive Carries On
description: Most people who retire disappear, said Thomas F. Murray, who retired three years ago as executive vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. They buy a condominium in Florida and get lost. Not me, I didnt want to join the rockinghorse brigade.

title: Exit to Persian Gulf: Choke Point for West's Economy
description: KHASAB, Oman, June 1 A tanker bound for the oil ports of the Persian Gulf plowed out of the heat haze that hung low over the Strait of Hormuz. To the southwest, a larger tanker turned northeastward, skirting the coast of the United Arab Emirates.

title: Backgammon:
description: The California open, under the direction of Sidney Jackson, was held last weekend in Los Angeles with more than 250 players competing. Aram Kouleyan, the winner of the recent Black and White Classic in Pebble Beach, triumphed again by defeating Shabaz Noorvash in a fastpaced 23point final. Kouleyan rallied from behind, 15to6, to tie the score, 22to22, and then won the final game at double match point. Topseeded Charles (Chuck) Papazian defeated Jeff Mervin in the consolation. Roy Springer won the last chance.

title: Architects Hedonistic Bent Attacked
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 6  The seeking of visual pleasure at the expense of other goals of architecture was attacked by two keynote speakers at the American Institute of Architects convention here. The meeting has brought more than 4,000 architects to this city for a fiveday session that will end tomorrow.

title: Hers
description: WE'RE white with black shutters and a granite hitching post . . . past the field with a few horses, beyond a long tox00AD; bacco shed, first house on the hill. Directions from our hostess. Oh, the lure of a week end in the country to city folks  escape from the world or subway stops and elevators, the civilized maneuvers of apartment life; escape from the concerts we honestly don't attend, the movies we must catch up on and our shame at avoiding the rich fare of the theater season. Simplicity, fresh air, a view from the hilltop. No cultural event more pressing than a snooze over a bedside book, comfortable chatter, long walks. Can it be that we have not learned from experience, from all our past observation of country snobbery?

title: U.S. Aides See Failure by Chinese In Vietnam and Risk of Bigger War
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Six weeks after the ChineseVietnamese border war, American specialists believe that China failed to achieve most of its objectives, raising the danger of another, larger border conflict in the next year or so.

title: Jim Turness Gains Final
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 6  Jim Turnesa, a member of one of the East's most famous golfing families, won two matches todayto reach the final round of the 60th annual Westchester amateur championship at the Surmingdale Golf Club.

title: Ebb Tide for Italy's Communists
description: There were no real winners in the Italian election this week but there was a loser  the Communists. After the 1976 parliamentary election, the Communists seemed the wave of the future. Now it appears that the Red tide has begun to ebb. After the vote, as before, no party or likely coalition of parties has a solid majority in parliament and instability is likely to continue.

title: Bridge:
description: The zonal stage of the Grand National Team Championship will be a threeteam roundrobin between groups representing New York City, Westchester and New England. Play will be tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday at the Y.W.C.A., 515 North Street, White Plains, and the winners will.advance to the national quarterfinals in Las Vegas, Nev., next month.

title: Dr. Werner Forssmann,
description: SCHOPFHEIM, West Germany, June 6 (Reuters)  Dr. Werner Forssmann, a 1956 Nobel Prize winner, has died after a heart attack at the age of 73.

title: MACCHIAROLA MOVES TO CLOSE 25 SCHOOLS
description: Plans to close as many as 25 elementary schools and leased facilities in 15 of New York City's 32 school districts moved ahead yesterday despite growing protests by parents and local school boards across the city.

title: China Chemical Plant
description: TOKYO, June 6 (AP)  Asahi Chemical Industries, a major Japanese manufacturer of synthetics, said today that China had agreed to go ahead with a $63 million contract for it to build a plant in Honan Province to produce nylon cords for tires. The contract, agreed upon last Dec. 27, was among 22 that China froze earlier this year because of a shortage of foreign currency and a rearrangement of its economic priorities.

title: Tens of Thousands of Indigents Jam New York Criminal Courts
description: Alberto Garcia stares bleakly up at Judge Milton L. Williams. Judge Williams stares back. Then the judge looks at the people who stand around Mr. Garcia: the policeman who arrested him a few hours earlier, the courtappointed defense lawyer, the prosecutor.

title: A RetailMinded Banker
description: Many New York banks are shying away from the maninthestreet customer, but to Elliott Averett, chairman of the venerable Bank of New York, the retailbanking market makes good sense. Of course, you have to consider the location of the consumer business, the head of the 195yearold bank said yesterday, and we've been in super markets.

title: Lyman Bradley, N.Y.U. Professor
description: Lyman R. Bradley, who in 1997 was suspended as chairman of New York University's German department and sentenced to three months in jail because he refused to respond to subpoenas by the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities, died in a nursing home in San Francisco last Monday after a stroke. He was 80 years old and had moved to San Francisco five years ago.

title: U.S. Oil Subsidy Upsets Europe
description: PARIS, June 6 America's Western allies are stepping up their pressure on President Carter to drop the controversial $5abarrel subsidy on American imports of homeheating oil.

title: When Nothing But the Best Will Do
description: TOO seldom does reality, for most of us, measure up to the esthetic ideal. Not so, however, in the case of Martin J. Davidson. Indeed, he makes no bones about it: I want nothing but the best, he says. And I have it. Mr. Davidson, 34 years old, is slim and fashionably bearded. A Brooklyn High School graduate who attended art school at night and by the age of 27 owned his own graphics design business, he has been moving as fast and as emphatically as a 20hour work day and a handful of successful tax shelters will permit.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Continuing the exuberant performance that began Tuesday, the credit markets snapped up a heavy volume of new bond issues again yesterday and paid little heed to a report that consumer credit remained heavy in April. Bond prices climbed sharply and yields dropped.

title: PRESIDENT PROPOSES REVISED PAY SYSTEM FOR U.S. EMPLOYEES
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 President Carter proposed a farreaching revision of the Government's pay system today in an effort to bring the salaries and fringe benefits of Federal civilian employees more closely in line with those of workers doing similar jobs in private industry.

title: About New York
description: An ignorant layman staggers away from a visit to the four floors of computer equipment on display at the Coliseum, and his heart leaps at the sight of the first fully comprehensible business tool he has seen all day  a set of sandwich boards worn by Sonny Monosson to advertise the used computers he is hawking on the sidewalk to the horde of passing conventioneers.

title: TV: The Last Giraffe, On Location in Kenya
description: THE Last Giraffe, to be shown on CBSTV at 9 o'clock this evening, is a twohour movie drama featuring some stunning footage of wildlife in Kenya and saddled with one of the season's more irritating scripts. .

title: Sound
description: NOT surprisingly, most audio. customers feel safer in buying brandnew components, which are presumed to be living up to their published specifications and covered by their manufacturers warranties. Yet in snubbing secondhand equipment, these custoMers pass up possible bargains and the chance to assemble a better system than they could otherwise afford. Used equipment generally sells for around half the price of equivalent new Items, and, if it is bought from a reliable dealer, performance is often guaranteed for 90 days. This may not seem very long, but the reassuring point is that, if the equipment works well for three months, it is likely to keep working well for much longer.

title: Coast Opera Picks Head
description: Terry McEwen, executive vice president of London Records, will succeed Kurt Herbert Adler as general director of the San Francisco Opera at the beginning of 1982. The announcement is being made today by Walter M. Baird, president and chief executive officer of the company.

title: Eight New City Judges Are Sworn in by Koch
description: With 5yearold Alexandra McGinley holding the Bible for her father and seven other judgestobe, Mayor Koch swore in six new Criminal Court Judges and two Family Court judges yesterday in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall.

title: Japan Says Soviet Is Building Up Arms on Disputed Kurile Islands
description: TOKYO. June 6 (Reuters) The Soviet Union is believed to be increasing arms supplies to two disputed islands in the Ku rile chain off northern Japan, Japanese Defense Agency sources said today.

title: Movie Captioned for the Deaf Closes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 6  After only a oneweek showing, MetroGoldwynMayer last week closed what it says was the first commercial run in this country of a feature film specially captioned for the deaf.

title: Chinese Tennis Stars in U.S.
description: Four of China's most promising young tennis players, invited to the United States under a program designed to upgrade the sport in their homeland, underwent tests in Southern California yesterday to prepare them for a tour on the American professional satellite circuit.

title: Home Beat
description: HE calls himself a Bronx boy and indeed he is. Since 1946, when Manny Dubinsky, left, came back from the United States Army in Europe, he's been in what be describes as the service bust. ness. Initially, he said, he repaired zippers on anything, then started cleaning, processing, and altering leather and suede garments of all kinds. Requests to care for patio umbrellas led to the manufaeture of prototype umbrellas for architects and designers, as well as specially designed and Silkecreened umbrellas for promotional campaigns. Now his company holds several patents on outdoor products, inchiding the E.Z. Reach rain cover, a slipcover with a hidden rigid rod that, according to Mr. Dubinsky, permits one to put a cover on an outdoor umbrella without having to stand on a chair or table. The cover comes in brown, yellow or white and is $15 at ZipJack Outdoor Products, 678 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers 10704, (212) 2990298 or (914) 4235000. Mr. Dubinsky did the Promeeade Cafe umbrellas at Rockefeller Center and umbrellas for Smirnott and Camped. He is now making the SunSquare I, shown at left, a scaleddown versiasof an Italian market umbrella that was inspired by a project for George Nelson, the industrial designer. The SunSquare I is a sixfoot square umbrella made of unbleached cotton dock fabric, with inch oak ribs and an oak or ash wood pole. It's $275 at BalleyNuebner at Henri Bendel. A smaller, fivefoot square versiOn can be ordered for $225.

title: British Voters Cast Listless Eye at Europe
description: REDCAR, England, June 6 Ernest Wistrich was doing all he could to sell himself to the people of Redcar.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: MANY variety stores and hardware stores have adjustable screens that fit into an open window and keep out dust and flies, but there are some unusual screens available that may have escaped your notice.

title: Figures Reflect Safety
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)  Despite the recent plane crashes in Chicago and San Diego, the National Safety Council considers commercial airlines one of the safest transportation forms.

title: Theater: Kevin Kline Stars in Loose Ends
description: L00SE ENDS is in many respects a wellmade play; it is absorbing for a good deal of the time; it is often funny; it is acted with considerable distinction; and yet at its heart it is a statistic.

title: America's Library, 50Volume Project, Due
description: The range of the American experience as expressed in its writings in history, belles lettres, fiction, memoirs and significant documents will be the substance of a new 50volume project,

title: Hundreds Said to Die in Coup
description: LAGOS, Nigeria June 6 (UPI) , June 6 (I.JPI)  A television reporter who fled Ghana just before the border was closed said today that hundreds of lives were lost in Monday's coup. He also said that forces loyal to the former leader, Lieut. Gen. Frederick W. K. Akuffo, were reorganizing near Akosombo, 60 miles northeast of Accra.

title: U.S. HALTS DC10'S INDEFINITELY, DEMANDING NEW SAFETY TESTS; TRAVEL IS DISRUPTED FOR 60,000
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 The Government ordered an immediate, indefinite halt today to flights of all 138 DC10 jumbo jets operated by United States airlines, suspending the craft's design certificate in the most farreaching response yet to the DC10 crash In Chicago on May 25.

title: Pope John Paul Goes Home to Cracow and Receives Emotional Welcome
description: CRACOW, Poland, June 6  Pope John Paul H returned today to Cracow, the community he served for 20 years, and the city rose in rapture to greet him.

title: Haggling Starts On Big Increase In Carey Budget
description: ALBANY, June 6  Convinced that there is more money available than Governor Carey has admitted, fiscal aides for the Democraticled Assembly and the Republicanled Senate began bargaining in earnest today on a supplemental budget that apparently will be quite a bit larger than Mr. Carey wanted or expected.

title: Begin Says Israel Would Quash a Palestinian State
description: TEL AVIV, June 6  Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that if an Arab administrative council to be set up in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip under a proposed autonomy plan proclaimed a Palestinian state, its members would be promptly arrested and the Israeli military government brought back.

title: Let's Buy Congress Back
description: In 1974, when a bill to reform campaign financing first came up in the House, PAC's  political action committees for special interests  handed out $12.5 million to Congressional candidates. The bill lost, but came up again in 1976, a year in which PAC's gave out $22.6 million. Last year, when the measure lost in the House by 17 votes, PAC contributions had climbed to $35 million. And the big growth lies ahead, as corporations discover the art form. In four years, the number of corporate PAC's has jumped from 89 to 821. Unless campaign financing is changed by 1980, it may be too late. Congress may already be sold.

title: Calendar: A Country Auction
description: Saturday will be a landmark date for Ivy Hail, one of the oldest historic homes in New Jersey. Its furnishings, a mixture of 18thand 19thcentury French, English and American antiques, family heirlooms, oil paintings, Country Auction of Ivy Hall, held by Christie's Auction House, Piscataway, N.J.

title: New York's Budget Retreat
description: Before the New York City Charter was changed in 1976, final decisions on the budget were made by the Mayor during an annual retreat. He would go into seclusion, in the Municipal Building, and weigh the competing demands on always.insufficient revenues.

title: WEVDAM Sold to Religious Group
description: WEVDAM has been sold by the Forward Association Inc., publisher of the Yiddishlanguage Daily Forward, to a group that specializes in Christian religious broadcasting. The Forward will retain its FM frequency.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)  Two of the nation's most powerful food industry unions completed a merger today to form a 1,250,000member giant that becomes the largest union in the American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations.

title: Bonn Central Bank Discloses Theft
description: BONN, June 6 The West German Bundesbank, or central bank, the country's respected guardian of the currency, has made the somewhat embarrassing discovery that some of what it guards is missing $1.2 million worth, in fact.

title: Nicaragua Declares a State of Siege
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 6 (AP) President Anastasio Somoza Debayle today declared a state of siege, a form of martial law, to help combat a general strike and guerrilla war.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Standard Brands Admits Payments
description: Standard Brands Inc. yesterday became the latest big American company to admit making questionable payments overseas to government employees, suppliers and union officers.

title: United Press International
description: LATE THROW: Art Howe of Astros forced Phils Bake McBride, but failed to complete fourthinning double play at Houston Tuesday night. PhiHies defeated Astros, 80.

title: Handmade Linens With a Reputation
description: AMERICANS, it seems, are very skittish when it comes to gold and silver threads  at least when they run through their tablecloths and place mats. Guida Arruda declares herself profoundly perplexed by this, but she is not about to let it get her down.

title: Upholstery Fabrics Play a Fashion Role
description: IN New York design circles, it's a long way from Seventh Avenue to Third. But when the Resources Council, a national nonprofit organization of home furnishings manufacturers, decided to sponsor Collaboration 79, its intent Was not only to raise money for the American Cancer Society but to bring tot. gether the fashion and home furnishings industries. The idea,, admittedly, is net new, but most of the 60 fashion designers approached their projects with verve and enthusiasm, using textiles from about 60 decorative fabric houses. The benefit fashion show is being held today at the Plaza Hotel

title: Moving? DieselFuel Pinch Delaying Vans
description: AS though it weren't bad enough to spend vacation time or weekends packing boxes, some of the 4.3 million Americans planning interstate moves this summer can also expect frustrating delays in pickups and deliveries, caused by shortages of diesel fuel.

title: First L.I.R.R. Female Conductor Runs Train On Time
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 6 Today was Deirdre Hickey's first day on the job, and it was a great satisfaction to the conductor on the Long Island Rail Road's 4:35 from Port Washington that the train not only left on time this afternoon but that it got to Penn Station a minute early.

title: Financial Analysts Expect Grounding Order to Cost Airlines Millions
description: When the first grounding order for DC10's was issued last week, the domestic airlines that use the planes were able to minimize the impact by juggling schedules and rerouting passengers. But financial analysts who follow the industry say that those measures will not be as effec. tive this time around, and that DC10 owners will probably lose millions of dollars to carriers that don't use the McDonnell Douglas plane.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: Albums

title: Harried Air Agency Chief
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 He drives around town in his silver Governmentowned Dodge Aspen, with the proudly displayed bumper sticker that reads, Impeach Langhorne Bond.

title: Dow Up 4.16 in Heavy Trading
description: Energy issues continued to lead the market higher yesterday in the heaviest trading in two months. Domestic and Canadian oil and gas stocks showed particular strength.

title: German Jobless Rate Falls
description: NUREMBURG, West Germany, June 6 (AP)  West Germany's unemployment rate fell to 3.4 percent in May, the lowest percentage since October 1974 when the unemployment rate was 3 percent, the Government said today.

title: The Stonors Reclaim Stonor Park Page C6
description: STONOR,ENGLAND

title: Article 111035720 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY DE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAIN 90.5300; NASS J CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 669.1800: CONNECTICUT (203) 487767.

title: Reliance Electric Net Up
description: CLEVELAND, June 6 (Reuters) The Reliance Electric Company, object of a $1.17 billion takeover bid by the Exxon Corporation, reported today that profits in its fiscal second quartir rose to $29.3 million, or $1.79 a share; from $18.3 million, or $1.13 a share, irt the yearearlier period. Sales in the quarter, ended April 30, rose to $293 million from $250.1 million.

title: Portuguese Railroads Struck
description: LISBON, June 6 (UPI) About 500,000 travelers and commuters scrambled for alternate means of transportation today as railroad unions began a 24hour strike that halted nearly all of Portugal's trains. Lisbon and Oporto were swamped by autos trying to get commuters to factories, offices and businesses.

title: New Census Chief Defends Plans For Listing Blacks and Hispanics
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The man newly appointed to head the Census Bureau denies that plans for the 1980 census are inadequate to obtain a full count of blacks, Hispanics and other minority group members.

title: 2d Reading Test Disrupted in District 3
description: A second citywide reading test was given yesterday to 460,000 publicschool students in New York City. But the School Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola, said that it might be invalidated for the 12,000 students in District 3 on Manhattan's West Side because the resistance of the community school board and some parents there had disrupted the testing process.

title: Senator Baker Asserts Deadline Diplomacy May Hurt Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The Senate minority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, expressed concern today that deadline diplomacy might become a factor in the armslimitation talks with the Soviet Union because, he said, major issues remained to be resolved before the June 18 signing deadline in Vienna.

title: Pecci Topples Vilas, Connors Ousts Dibbs
description: PARIS, June 6  Unseeded Victor Peed powered his way to an exciting victory in the French open tennis championships today, upsetting thirdseeded Guillermo Vilas, 60, 61, 75.

title: Two Killed in Ship Explosion
description: SEATTLE, June 6 (AP) An explosion ripped through an empty containership in Seattle yesterday, killing two workers who were painting inside the vessel. The ship arrived Monday from Anchorage. Most of the 40 crew members were ashore at the time of the explosion. The identities of the victims were not immediately released.

title: Deaths
description: ANASTASIOAlfonso J. of Merrick on June 6, 1979. Beloved husband of Stasha, devoted father of Marie Tabor and Jon Anastasio, brother of Rose Hughes, Josephine Geiger, Frances Gambino, Ralph and Andrew Anastasio, grandfather of Allison Anastasio. Funeral from the N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Ave., Merrick. Mass of Christian Burial Cure of Ars R.C. Church, Friday, 9:45 a.m. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: GARDENING
description: BEANS occupy a lowly position in most home gardens, one that is totally unwarranted. Beans are highly productive, easy to care for and relatively problemfree. And these days, with ethnic foods in vogue and meat prices so high, proteinpacked beans make more sense than ever. It is not too late to plant them now.

title: Deaths
description: GREENBERGLillian. The Brandeis Community mourns the death of a generous supporter of our institution. To her son, Frank S. Greenberg, an esteemed member of our Board of Fellows, and the bereaved family, we extend heartfelt condolences.

title: Tips on Making a Move
description: If you move... plan early, avoid holiday weekends and the last week of every summer month.

title: Senate Rebukes Carter Over Ending of Taiwan Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 The Senate rebuked President Carter today for moving to terminate the mutual defense treaty with Taiwan by voting overwhelmingly that such an action requires Senate consent.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Japan Retail Sales Up
description: TOKYO, June 6 (UPI)  Retail sales at major Japanese department stores and other retail outlets in April totaled $3.9 billion, up 8.4 percent over April 1978, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry reported today. After seasonal adjustments, April sales rose by 2.5 percent over March, the ministry said.

title: Japanese Steel Profits Increase
description: TOKYO, June 6 (UPI)  Japan's big five steelmakers showed a 2.7 percent increase in sales and an 8.5 percent profits gain for the 1378 business year ending March 31, according to a compilation of their financial statements released today.

title: Pop: Rod Stewart
description: ROD STEWART has always been an almostbutnotquite rock superstar. In commercial terms, to be sure, he's already long since a fullfledged superstar, in the sense that he's proven triumphantly that his choice for a solo career after his years with the Faces was a smart move, that his records can sell in the millions, that he can keep abreast of the latest fads in pop music, that his songwriting is eminently viable in the marketplace, and that he can regularly sell out large arenas  as he's doing this week at Madison Square Garden, where he opened a fournight engagement Tuesday. The remaining concerts are tonight through Saturday.

title: Events
description: Music

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Updegraff Captures Golf Title
description: RYE, N.Y., June 6  Dr. Edgar Updegraff, a 57yearold urologist from Tucson, Ariz., became the United States Seniors Golf Association champion today at Apawamis in his first year in the 75yearrold tournament.

title: Error Detailed In Carrier Bid
description: The United Technologies Corporation, now under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for alleged irregularities in its attempt to take over the Carrier Corporation. disclosed yesterday that three major institutions shared in a mistake last December that resulted in the purchase of only 16.2 million Carrier shares instead of the 17 million it had sought.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Mets Triumph
description: CINCINNATI, June 6  The New York Mets ignored the doomsayers again today, produced 12 hits off five pitchers, scored four runs in the seventh inning and overpowered the Cincinnati Reds, 53, to complete their first winning road trip in a year.

title: Marian Devotions: An Ecumenical Upsurge
description: CZESTOCHOWA, Poland, June 5 The monastery at Jasna Gora here, known for its veneration of Mary ever since it came into possession.of the Black Madonna said to have been painted by St. Luke, has become a focal point for a reNews Analysis newal of interest in Marian devotions among the world's Catholics.

title: Fatal DC10's Safety File Includes
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, June 6 (AP)  The American Airlines DC10 that crashed in the nation's worst air disaster was the subject of 17 service difficulty reports in five years, according to Federal Aviation Administration records on file here.

title: Design Notebook
description: The Empire State Observatory now gives prominence to the view.

title: Mrs. Miller Leads Field In New Jersey Golf Event
description: NORTHFIELD N.J., June 6  Mrs. Harold Miller of Ridgewood posted a 41, 4283 that was converted to a net 69 for the firstround lead today in the Women'sNew Jersey Golf Association Eubelacher Memorial Tournament at Atlantic City Country Club.

title: Trudeau's Fatal Charm
description: OTTAWA  As Pierre Elliott Trudeau leaves office after 11 years as Prime Minister, he is still a lonely Canadian whom no one knows very well.

title: Inventories of Gasoline Rose Sharply in Holiday Week
description: Although motorists had to scurry around over the Memorial Day holiday searching for gasoline, the oil industry's inventories actually increased last week, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: A Judge Tours
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., June 6  Clad from head to foot in a breathing mask, white protective suit, and yellow plastic boots, Judge Harold A. Ackerman of Superior Court in UnionCounty today inspected a chemical waste storage facility from which state officials said they had removed more than 250 pounds of illegally stored high explosives.

title: Technology
description: WHAT has happened to the home computer? What was once thought to be a billiondollar, massmarket item that would revolutionize our lives seems suddenly to have lost its luster.

title: Writer Criticizes Design of DC10
description: GENEVA, June 6 (AP)  John Godson, the BritishAustralian aviation writer who wrote a critical book about the DC10 five years ago, said today that he doubted whether modifications could fix all of the plane's problems and that is was a basically badly designed aircraft.

title: Gary Player's Son Upsets Siderowf in British Golf
description: SOUTHPORT, England, June 6 (UPI)  Dick Siderowf, the United States Walker Cup captain, felt the full impact of the precocious talent of Wayne Player on the par72 Hillside course today and was beaten, 5 and 4, in the third round of the British Amateur golf championship.

title: Israel Continues to Hold American In Alleged Attack on Arab Homes
description: JERUSALEM, June 6  A magistrate today authorized the detention of an American citizen for another week in an investigation of alleged attacks on Arab homes and householders in the ancient West Bank city of Hebron.

title: Palestinians Pulling Out of Towns In Lebanon to Stop Israeli Strikes
description: BEIRUT. Letanon, June 6  The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it had begun closing down its offices in the port town of Tyre and pulling its guerrillas out of villages in southern Lebanon to head off Israeli attacks against Lebanese civilians.

title: Lyme Arthritis Linked to NewFound Tick Species
description: NEW HAVEN, June 6  Symptoms of Lyme arthritis, which was first diagnosed in 1975 when it afflicted children and adults in southeastern Connecticut, can be more complicated and severe than was originally reported, researchers at the Yale School of Medicine said yesterday.

title: Fed to Ease Bank Rule
description: The Federal Reserve Board said yesterday that it would allow banks to branch across state lines in order to conduct international business. At the same time, however, the board postponed determining the restraints under which such branches would be permitted to operate.

title: Poorest Man in Fairfield
description: FAIRFIELD, CONN. YEARS ago, I asked an acquaintance whose father I had never met what kind of man he was. My friend thought for a moment and said: He's the kind of man who, when he walks in the street, always keeps his eyes on the ground, looking for money.

title: House Committee to Review Election Commission
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The House Administration Committee plans to conduct hearings next month on the workings of the Federal Election Commission, with an eye to revising the Federal election law before the 1980 campaigns.

title: Ullman Sees OilTax Plan Adding $6.6 Billion in 1982
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee agreed today that the tax they would approve on windfall profits of oil companies would be measurably stronger than the one recommended by President Carter.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O)overthecounter.

title: News Summary
description: Mao Zedong's second wife reemerged as a member of an organization of nonCommunist groups and personalities supporting the Peking regime. The woman, He Zizhen, had not been mentioned publicly since Mao divorced her about 40 years ago. Her reappearance seems to be part of an effort to reconstruct a biography of Mao without his third wife, who was purged after his death in 1976. [Page A2, Columns 36.]

title: Market Place
description: AIRLINE analysts are wondering just how seriously profits will be affected by the grounding of the McDonnell Douglas DC10 in the wake the Chicago accident that claimed 275 lives on May 25, a grounding that took on a more ominous look yesterday when the plane lost its Federal Aeronautics Administration certification.

title: Auto Union Head Urging Critics Not to 'savage Carter
description: DETROIT, June 6  Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that he was urging union activists not to savage President Carter although he still found overwhelming membership enthusiasm for Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts for President and growing support for Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.

title: Jamesway to Buy Shares
description: The Jamesway Corporation, which operates a chain of discount stores, said yesterday that its board of directors had voted to allow the company to purchase up to 100,000 shares of its common stock. The shares purchased will be used for general corporate purposes.

title: Photoengravers Gain Pact, Ending Strike at The News
description: Striking photoengravers reached agreement late yesterday with The Daily News on a new threeyear contract, clearing the way for the paper to resume publication with today's editions. The first edition, with 128 pages, had a press run that started at 10:20 last night, nearly three hours later than usual.

title: Loral Company to Build Bigger Plant in Yonkers
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 6  The Loral Corporation, a leading developer of electronicwarfare equipment for United States and NATO aircraft, announced today a major expansion that is to create more than 1,000 jobs in Yonkers and 900 in the Bronx.

title: Problems of DC10 Focus Attention on U.S. Certification Procedures
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The problems with the DC10 have focused new attention on the procedure by which the Federal Aviation Administration, the Government air safety agency, assures Itself that all new pieces of aviation equipment are safe and airworthy.

title: I.M.F. Sells Gold At Average $280.39
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) The International Monetary Fund said today that it had sold 444,000 ounces of gold at a record average price of $280.39 an ounce at its regular monthly auction.

title: Amex Earnings Increase 72.5%
description: The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday a 72.5 percent earnings jump in the first quarter of this year to $383,000 from $222,000 in the 1978 quarter. Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman, attributed the higher earnings to Increased equity and options trading volume and larger communications income.

title: How New York City's Budget Maneuvering Went Wrong
description: Gloomily, Mayor Koch sat watching a television show  Dick Cavett interviewing Gerald R. Ford in subdued color while, elsewhere in City Hall, the process of passing a city budget turned into chaos.

title: Bethlehem Steel Suit
description: PITTSBURGH, June 6 (AP)  The Bethlehem Steel Corporation failed to support a $100 million suit filed against a shipbuilder for allegedly refusing to build orecarrying vessels, it was ruled today. Bethlehem had filed suit against

title: IRAN AIDE EXPLAINS REJECTION OF ENVOY
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 6  Foreign Minister Ibrahim Yazdi indicated today that Iran had rejected Walter L. Cutler as the United States Ambassador because of alleged American intervention in Africa, where he had previously been stationed.

title: Japanese Loan to Soviet
description: TOKYO.June 6 (AP)  Japan's Sakhalin Oil Development Company signed an agreement today to lend $70 million to the Soviet Union to help finance two oil drilling projects off the coast of Russia's Sakhalin Island, the Kyodo News Service reported.

title: What to Do About Rain? Start Pruning
description: IN case gardeners think they have seen a lot of rain, they have. During the month of May there were 15 days with, some measurable form of precipitation. According to National Weather Bureau figures, May was the fifth consecutive month with abovenormal precipitation. Normal precipitation figures would be just over 16 inches for the fivemonth period. The region had 29.7 inches.

title: Canon Dennis Elected New Suffragan Bishop Of Episcopal Diocese
description: Canon Walter D. Dennis, who is known for his strong stands on civil rights for homosexuals and on legalized abortion and marijuana use, won an upset election as suffragan bishop of the Episcopal diocese of New York yesterday. He easily defeated three official nominees and two others.

title: PANAMA IS ACCUSED OF AIDING SANDINISTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Two Nicaraguan officials told a House committee today that Panama was both a direct supplier of arms and a conduit for Cuban arms delivered to the Sandinist guerrillas who are trying to overthrow the Government of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: Ohio Air Pollution Rules Are Relaxed to Save Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  President Carter, acting on the isssue of jobs versus clean air, announced today that air pollution standards for Ohio would be relaxed to permit two Cleveland power plants to burn dirty coal mined within the state.

title: N.F.L. Tries to Discourage Dangerous Chop Block
description: At the final session of the National Football League's spring meeting here yesterday, it was decided to try to outlaw the socalled chop block by a pass blocker not through rules legislation but by appealing to the coaches to discourage the tactic.

title: Political Gift by Hongisto A Threat to Confirmation
description: ALBANY, June 6  A political campaign contribution by Richard D. Hongisto to a member of the State Senate panel considering his nomination as Correctional Services Commissioner appeared today to put his alreadytroubled nomination in serious jeopardy.

title: Cosmos Lose, 10, Before 70,134
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June  The new roles of Coach Ray Klivecka and Prof. Julio Mazzei began to take shape tonight even though the Cosmos lost, 10, to the World Cup champion Argentine team in an exhibition game.before 70,139 fans at Giants Stadium.

title: Goodbye Girl Grooms for TV Serial
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6  Neil Simon's The Goodbye Girl, an Academy Award nominee for best picture of 1977, has been added to the growing number of recent movies that are on their way to being turned into television series.

title: Calvados, a Winless Colt, Is First in Yonkers Race
description: Yonkers, June 6  Calvados, a colt with only one previous career victory, and Mountain Kilt, a maiden, won the two divisions of the $190,920 John Froehlich Trot for 3yearold colts and geldings at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

title: G.P.U. Struggle for Financing
description: The accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear generating plant in Pennsylvania has put the General Public Utilities Corporation, the plant's owner, in a financial squeeze between skeptical regulators and nervous bankers.

title: Repair Work to Start On Queens Roadway
description: An 18month repair project on the BrooklynQueens Expressway is scheduled to begin at 10 A.M. today with work on a halfmile section of the expressway between Atlantic Avenue and the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel.

title: Vietnam Denounces Plan to Allow Pol Pot Delegates to Attend Parley
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, June 6 Viet. nam angrily rejected today a compro mise announced earlier as a solution to the issue of Cambodian representation at the conference of third world nations here.

title: The Region
description: BUFFALO (AP)  A Federal judge told the Buffalo school board yesterday that it had not gone far enough in desegregating schools and directed the board to use whatever means were necessary to desegregate 15 schools with all minority enrollments.

title: Max Koch, 87, Designer Of Furs for the Famous
description: Max Koch, a fur designer whose customers had included Eleanor Roosevelt and Doris Duke, died of a heart attack Tuesday at the Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Consumer Debt Rises $4.1 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) American consumers signed for $4.1 billion more in installment debt than they repaid in April but stayed below the fast borrowing pace of last year, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)  The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation was ordered by the Government today to divest two plants it acquired five years ago.

title: Plane Bums at Airport
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., June 6 (UPI)  A cargo plane loaded with nearly 10 tons of marijuana crashed and burst into flames today while landing at the Kanawha Airport here. One man was injured in the crash. He and seven other persons were arrested on drug charges.

title: U.S. Still Storing Oil For Emergency Use
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 Oil may be in short supply in the United States and elsewhere in the world, but the Federal Government is still pouring crude into underground salt domes along the Gulf Coast.

title: 4 Feared Dead in Pipeline Blast
description: PILOTTOWN, La., June 6 (AP)  A piledriving barge ruptured a natural gas pipeline near the mouth'of the Mississippi River yesterday, and four men were feared killed in the resulting explosion, the barge's owners said. Three other crewmen escaped serious injury.

title: Ukrainian Ends Moscow SitIn
description: MOSCOW, June 6 (AP)  A 45yearold Ukrainian woman who has been trying to emigrate from the Soviet Union for five years ended a two.day sitin at the United States Embassy today, an embassy spokesman said. Mariya S. Okopnaya was expected to return to Lvov, where she lives with her husband, Mikhail, and two daughters.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: John R. Purcell has been named executive vice president of CBS Inc. On the company's organization chart, Mr. Purcell, 47 years old, is outranked only by William S. Paley, 77, the chairman and largest individual stockholder; and John D. Backe, 47, president and chief executive officer.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 6 A 23yearold soldier was killed today and three soldiers were wounded in an attack on the headquarters of the Ulster Defense Regiment in Belfast.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Advertising
description: CHINA, which recently discovered advertising, may soon be sending small groups of its young people to this country for training in advertising and marketing.

title: New York City Is Lacking a Budget One Day After the Legal Deadline
description: New York City was without a fiscal 1980 budget yesterday, a full, day after the deadline for approval.

title: BRIBETAKING IS LAID TO A FORMER MAYOR
description: BOSTON, June 6 (AP)  A Government informer testified today that he had paid bribes to a Congressman who was a former Massachussetts mayor, a Congressional aide and other officials.

title: CARTER AND SCHMIDT URGE NATO BUILDUP
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  President Carter and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany expressed concern today about the Soviet buildup of conventional and nuclear forces in Eastern Europe and said they required a response fram the Atlantic alliance.

title: G.O.P. Pair Will Retain S.E.C. Posts
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 President Carter has decided to reappoint John R. Evans and Philip A. Loomis Jr. to the two Republican slots on the Securities and Exchange Commission, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Cabaret: Anita O'Day
description: ANITA O'DAY'S encore to her encores at Marty's, Third Avenue.at 73d Street, where she is appearing this week and next, is a vocalized version of Jimmy Giuffre's essay for four saxophones, Four Brothers, Originally written as a unison ensemble, the composition is performed by Miss O'Day in harmony with her pianist, Norman Simmons, changing what was once a direct, driving bit of swing into a delicately woven tapestry that is filled with lights and colors, and yet, as is almost always the case with Miss O'Day, retains a strong inner swinging momentum.

title: Duran Flashes Old Form
description: The rumors had preceded Roberto Duran from Panama. The best fighter, pound for pound, was pound by pound becoming fat. The hunger was gone. Roberto Duran would no longer hurt anything tougher than pork chops.

title: China Loan Set by Bank In Chicago
description: HONG KONG, June 6  A. Robert Abboud, chairman of the First National Bank of Chicago, announced today that his bank had signed an $8 million short`term loan agreement with China and that the Bank of China would accept Visa checks issued by First National starting in November.

title: Mastropieri Acts To Avert a Vote To Remove Him
description: With a vote scheduled today on an Ethics Committee recommendation to expel him from the New York City Council, Councilman Eugene F. Mastropieri offered yesterday to resign as chairman of the Committee on Economic Development if he were permitted to retain his Council seat.

title: Views Differ On Carter's Fuel Stand
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  White House officials and Congressional leaders emerged from a White House breakfast this morning with different interpretations of what had been agreed upon with regard to the nation's energy problems.

title: Ghana Curfew Is Lifted And Airport Reopened
description: ACCRA, Ghana, June 6 (UPI) Ghana's new military rulers lifted a curfew and reopened Accra's airport today, apparently , confirming that they were firmly in control after a coup on Monday.

title: The Ballet: Baryshnikov
description: THE New York City Ballet may be famous for its neoclassical austerities, yet its repertory also contains some extravagant frolics, and Mikhail Baryshnikov has been cast in several of these diversions, much to his own apparent amusement and the amusement of his audiences. Last weekend, the Russianborn dancer portrayed a. Cockney; Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, he became a, tambourinewhacking Italian merrymaker.

title: HARTFORD ASSEMBLY ENDS ITS 79 SESSION
description: HARTFORD, June 6  The 1979 session of the General Assembly drifted to adjournment today, six weeks after the main work of writing a budget and a schoolaid package was completed, ending months of inconclusive wrangling over a variety of issues that attracted little public interest.

title: The Other League
description: In the candlelit elegance of the Hunt Room in the 21 Club, Lamar Hunt and Billy Sullivan kept shuffling in and out behind a lectern as if they were offensive and defensive masters of ceremonies. Suddenly, over near the bar, a telephone rang.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although it calls itself a novel, The Yawning Heights defies categories, and perhaps description. Satire? Philosophical romance? Encyclopedia?

title: Letter: On Deregulating Trucking
description: To the Editor:

title: New Tax Plan On Home Loans
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  A divided House Ways and Means Committee abruptly postponed a final vote today on legislation barring the use of taxfree mortgage bonds in order to take up what the committee chairman said was an entirely different approach to curbing such Government financing of housing.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW POSES FACTORY CURB
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 At least in theory, as of July 1 industry throughout much of the United States will be barred by environmental law from building new plants that pollute the air.

title: Concern for McDonnell Douglas Rises
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6  The Federal Aviation Administration's suspension of its certificate of airworthiness for the McDonnell Douglas DC10 has heightened concern shout the aircraft's sales prospects and the possible financial damage to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: Guidry Defeats Koosrnan
description: Jerry Koosman's return to New York last night resembled so many games he pitched for the Mets, except the Mets wouldn't have tied the game in the ninth inning and given him a chance to win, like Minnesota did.

title: Keeping Love Canals Out of Our Backyards
description: The games we play under the laws of nature  particularly those that per; tain to the disposal of chemical wastes  seem riddled with mistakes, igno; rances, and ultimately, catastrophic excesses.

title: 2 Capital Policemen Die in Crash Of DepartmentOwned Helicopter
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)  Two District of Columbia police officers died today when their helicopter crashed and exploded in flames in Southeast Washington.

title: Jack Haley, Actor, 79, Dead; Was Tin Woodman in Oz
description: Jack Haley, the mellow stage and screen comedian of the 1930's and 40's who played the Tin Woodman in the movie The Wizard of Oz, died yesterday in Los Angeles after having suffered a heart attack last Friday. He was 79 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Air Service in Disarray Worldwide As Foreign Carriers Heed Warning
description: Domestic and international air travel was thrown into chaos yesterday as virtually every DC10 airliner around the world was ordered out of the sky.

title: British Exhibit Opens in Peking
description: PEKING, June 6 (Reuters)  The Duke of Kent, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth, opened a British energy exhibition In Peking today. The 10day show, at which 350 British companies are exhibiting their wares, is expected to be viewed by 200,000 officials, technicians and students. The British concerns are trying to interest the Chinese in energyrelated technology.

title: Woman Admits Guilt in Plot
description: Los ANGELES,june 6(AP) cia Ferguson has pleaded guilty to three conspiracy charges in a multimilliondollar computer plot involving Stanley Mark Rifkin, an admitted bank thief. Federal District Judge Robert Firth scheduled sentencing for July 2., The Government had charged that Miss Furguson and Mr. Rifkin had schemed to defraud the Union Bank in Los Angeles of up to 650 million.

title: Levin Votes Stock Split
description: The Levin Computer Corporation said yesterday that its board had voted a 2for1 stock split, payable July 16 to holders of record June 18. In addition. the board declared a cash dividend of 12 cents a share on the presplit shares, also to be paid July 16 to holders of record June 18. The company previously paid a cash dividend of 10 cents a share.

title: The City
description: Last August, the fire rescue company that John J. Pritchard belonged to was called to a blaze at a Waldbaum's supermarket in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. The roof collapsed and three times Fireman Pritchard crawled into the fiery building to rescue three of his fellow firemen.

title: Home improvement
description: REPLACING an oldstyle electric doorbell with a more attractive and more pleasant sounding set of electric chimes, or adding a second set of chimes to an existing system, are fairly simple and safe improvements for the doityourself homeowner who is reasonably familiar with basic wiring techniques.

title: N.H.L. Players Group Consents to Merger
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, June 6 (AP) While the National Hockey League Players Association was agreeing today to permit the league's merger with the World Hockey Association in exchange for several benefits, the four surviving W.H.A. teams disclosed results of a dispersal draft of players on the three teams not invited to join the N.H.L. next season.

title: Associated Press
description: DETROIT BIDDING FOR CONVENTION: Democratic National Committee members touring Detroit's Joe Louis Arena, still incomplete. The city, already picked for the 1980 G.O.P. convention, invited Democrats to meet there, too.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SAFE ON FIRST The informal, cozy atmosphere of Joe Burns's Restaurant is further enhanced these weekends by live music, good music, and with little or no fanfare. It's that kind of place.

title: Mattel Reports Drop in Income
description: Mattel Inc., a major toy manufacturer and operator of the Ringling BrothersBarnum & Bailey Combined Shows Inc., reported yesterday that it had net income of $1.8 million, or 10 cents a share, in its first fiscal quarter ended May 5. The results were down from $2.9 million, or 16 cents a share, earned in the same three months last year when the company took a $1.1 million tax credit.

title: Deaths
description: McSHANE  Gertrude M. (nee) Friedrich, on June 5 1979, beloved wife of the late Hugh F., loving mother of Ilene P. Curry, Judge Hugh F., Supreme Court of Kings County, Franklin J., and the late Alfred E. Also survived by 12 grandchildren, 1 greatgrandchlid. Funeral from The Thomas M. Quinn and Sons Inc. Funeral Home 3520 Broadway, Long Island City NY, on Sat. 9:45 AM. Mass of the Christian Burial Most Precious Blood R.C. Church, 10:15 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours 25 and 710 PM.

title: Renaissance for a California Train Station
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6 When the $11.5 million Union Station here was completed in 1939, it was nearly as elaborate as New York City's old Pennsylvania Station, which was patterned after the ancient Roman Baths. It was impressive with its 115foot black walnut ticket counter, its Spanish bronzeframed doors and Belgian black mar, ble. It was one of several union stations so named because they .represented the union of more than one railroad and the construction and operation of a common facility.

title: Entrepreneurs Cash in on Airlines HalfFare Coupons
description: CHICAGO, June 6  The voice on the telephone offered to sell packs of coupons, and the travel specialist became suspicious and called her supervisor, who in turn called United Airlines, which also became suspicious and put an investigator to work.WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI)  Sena. tor Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, today introduced a resolution to insure that senators or their employees who received halffare coupons for official travel passed the savings back to the taxpayers.

title: Investigator of Carter Family Blocks Lance Case Plea
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 Paul J. Curran, the special counsel investigating loans to President Carter's family business. said today that he had blocked a plea bargain with a key witness in the Bert Lance banking conspiracy case to keep his investigatory options open.

title: Franklin, Corder() In Fight at Track
description: A smoldering threemonth feud between Ron Franklin and Angel Cordero erupted into a fist fight at Belmont Park yesterday after Cordero's mount in the fourth race bumped the one ridden by Franklin.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: At Party, Brooklyn Is the Toast of the Town
description: Brooklyn was 354 years old on Wednesday and in an age.when department stores throw parties at the drop of a Ralph Lauren Western hat, what better occasion could there be for a blacktie celebration hosted by the 114yearold Abraham & Straus?

title: Grain Talks With Libya
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (Reuters)  American and Libyan officials are negotiating separate sales of unspecified amounts of United States grain to Libya and Libyan crude oil to farmers in the United States, the American Farm Bureau, the nation's largest farm organization, said today.

title: 3 Held as Brink's Plotters
description: A former convict who tutored Peter Falk in the ways of crime for the filming of The Brink's Job was arrested with two other men last night on charges of plotting to rob a Brink's armored car at La Guardia Airport of $2 million.

title: News Summary
description: A refusal to lift sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia was announced by President Carter. He said he believed that the United States would be seriously damaged in its foreign relations if it acted alone to remove sanctions now and that he would do his utmost to win over a majority in Congress to his position. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: House Republicans Irked on OilTax Role
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee warned today that the Democratic majority must include them in shaping President Carter's proposed windfall profits tax on oil companies or face what they termed destructive results.

title: Hoch Gains Quarterfinals Of British Amateur Golf
description: SOUTHPORT, England, June 7 (AP)  Scott Hoch, the American who has a perfect winning record on his British trip, beat Scotland's Alan Ferguson, 4 and 3, today to reach the quarterfinaLs of the British Amateur golf championship.

title: Major Reorganization Of Brooklyn Hospitals Is Urged by the State
description: The closing of four hospitals in Brooklyn and the reorganization of the rest was recommended yesterday by the New York State Office of Health Systems Management.

title: Deaths
description: BAUMJulia Frankenthaler. Beloved wife of Hans. Dear sister of Justin and Rose King. Services today 2PM, Broadway Memorial Chapel, West 174 St and Broadway.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Scattered thunder clouds are evident over most of the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys. Broken rain clouds cover most of the Middle and South Atlantic States and the Gulf States and the lower Mississippi Valley. Broken rain clouds are also shown over the northern Rockies and the Northern Plain States. Clear skies are apparent in the Far West.

title: Judge Rebuffs CoalGas Plan
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  A Federal law judge today rejected the application of five natural gas companies for authority to build the country's first major coal gasification plant in Mercer County, N.D.

title: Context in Accord For Casino Project
description: Context Industries Inc., a publicly owned real estate, buildingsupply and development company based in Miami, said that it had entered into a memorandum of understanding with Terminal Industries Inc. to develop a proposed hotelcasino project in Atlantic City.

title: Economic Scene; What's Next For Guidelines?; Leonard Silk
description: THE Carter Administration is deep in the toils of trying to decide where it goes from here on wageprice policy. It is not ready to concede that its guidelines have been wrecked by the decision last Thursday of United States District Judge Barrington D. Parker that the denial of procurement contracts to companies that violate the guidelines is unconstitutional. In fact, yesterday the Government,

title: Send the Klan a Message
description: Decatur, Ala., will be on edge Saturday. The Ku Klux Klan, which has come to the surface there in recent months, promises to disrupt a protest demonstration by the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. Decatur has already experienced racial violence. When S.C.L.C. demonstrators marched through town last week, whiterobed Klansmen confronted them. Shots were traded and four people were injured, two on each side. It may sound like the Alabama of the 1960's, but It is not. This time local officials are trying their best to maintain order.

title: City Council to Confer With Estimate Board On Budget Next Week
description: Members of the New York City Board of Estimate and the City Council will meet early next week to resolve differences in their budget proposals and move toward approval of a city bud budget.

title: Israel Plans an Office To Help Citizens Get Tourist Visas to Egypt
description: JERUSALEM, June 7  The Foreign Ministry announced today that it would open facilities in the next few days for Israelis to obtain visas to visit Egypt.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Producer Price Index moved up fourtenths of 1 percent in May, the Government reported, providing the first sign that inflation may be abating. The moderate gain largely reflected a substantial decline in food prices. The report appeared to support the Carter Administration's prediction that the rate of inflation would slow later in the year. W. Michael Blumenthal, the Treasury Secretary, noted that the producer index, excluding the energy components, actually declined during the month. [Page Al.]

title: Funny Philadelphia in Serious Plea to Democrats
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 7  This is the last stop for the small band of admittedly bibulous Democrats seeking spot for their party's 1980 national convention and, having sipped and supped the best of Detroit and New York, they have come into a town whose generosity stops just this side of the moon.

title: Union Aide Accused of Million in Bribes
description: The head Of the boilermakers union in New York City was indicted yesterday on Charges that he had extorted $1.2 million in payoffs,from major construction companies in exchange forlabor peace.

title: Lower East Side Wins Custody Case
description: ALBANY, June 7  A Family Court judge in Kingston has rejected a father's contention that Manhattan's Lower East Side is no place to raise a child and awarded custody of a 10yearold girl to her mother.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  A renegotiated plan for rehabilitating Westchester's parkways has been announced by Governor Carey and the Westchester legislative delegation. The plan includes a new 25cent toll on the Hutchinson River parkway near the Connecticut line.

title: 8 in Hong Kong Trial Accused of Smuggling People From Vietnam
description: HONG KONG, June 7  The captain and the crew of a Panamanianregistered freighter that brought 3,318 refugees from Vietnam were put on trial today on a charge of being involved in an emigration racket with Vietnamese officials.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Tuesday reported incorrectly the total salary increase won by the Suffolk County police through arbitration. The base pay will rise to a maximum of $24,681 by the end of 1980 if the New York area costofliving index goes up 3 percent from January to May of this year, and 7.5 percent from November 1978 through November 1979. If the index rises more slowly, the raise will be proportionately smaller.

title: Operetta: Musical Spoof Of a Temperance Play
description: TEN Nights in a Barroom, an earnest temperance drama by William W. Pratt, first appeared more than 120 years ago, and now Light Opera of Manhattan is giving it new life as a musical spoof, using melodies of its time. With such revivals as these, thank heavens  and let's drink to that  that Eugene O'Neill will never see what happens to his temperance themes in centennial revival.

title: Auctions
description: WHEN the fiveday auction of the Benjamin Sonnenberg collection at Sotheby. Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, passed the halfway mark yesterday afternoon, the pmceeds had exceeded the highest expectations for the sale. The figure by then was $2.2million. The collection, the largest offered in the auction house's history, had been valued at $3 to $4 million. Not only were most of the drawings, paintings, porcelains, silver and brasses selling at or well above their best estimates, but also only 7 lots out of the 970 offered had not been sold. Yesterday morning, the top lot in the entire sale  John Singer Sargent's portrait of Millicent, Duchess of Sutherland, set a world record for a work by that artist, $210,000  well above the highest presale estimate, $150,000. It was purchased by Coe Kerr Gallery, 49 East 82d Street.

title: Bird and Celtics
description: BOSTON, June 7 (AP)  The Boston Celtics called a news conference for 10 A.M. tomorrow to announce the signing of Larry Bird to a fiveyear National Basketball Association contract worth more than $3.2 million.

title: Nicaraguan Towns Fall to Rebels
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 7  A guerrilla offensive to topple President Anastasio Somoza Debayle continued to spread today as several more provincial towns and cities fell into the hands of the rebels.

title: Tennis
description: AT PARIS

title: Milt Jackson Marks First 40 Years in Jazz
description: IN 1939, when Milt Jackson was 16 years old, his father gave him $5 for the down payment on a vibraharp. This purchase changed Mr. Jackson from a gospel singer to a jazz musician, an event that will be celebrated tomorrow evening at an 8 o'clock concert in Carnegie Hall honoring his 40th atunversary in jazz.

title: TV Weekend Documentaries Offer Viewers a Change of Pace
description: THERE's the Belmont Stakes, of course, on CBSTV at 5 tomorrow afternoon. In this 111th running of the thoroughbred spectacular, Spectacular Bid will have an opportunity to become the third Triple Crown champion in three years. The Belmont nurse is $200.000plus. And then there's the revival of Masterpiece Theater's I, Claudius, a deliciously witty evocation of Robert Graves's version of ancient Rome. That begins again on Channel 13 this Sunday at 9 P.M.

title: After Week as Premier, Muzorewa Is Making His Authority Felt in Zimbabwe Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, June 7  The photograph of a World War II Spitfire fighter and the framed copy of the 1965 declaration of independence from Britain are gone now, replaced by a Bible on the telephone desk and a plaque bearing the spearandhoe symbol of a black political party, the United African National Council.

title: Commencements Held by 3 Institutions
description: Three schools in New York City  New York University, the City University Graduate Center and Yeshiva University  held commencements yesterday in balmy weather under sunny blue skies.

title: Medical Catastrophe Plans Seen Diverting Resources to the Dying
description: BOSTON, June 7 (UPI)  National catastrophic health insurance plans, designed to pay hospital costs for sudden, severe illnesses, may divert medical resources to people who woula die soon after receiving highcost treatment, according to a study published today.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  There are not many miraculous new ideas around here for solving the energy crisis, but there is one old idea that is beginning to get thoughtful consideration among some influential members of the Executive, the Congress and the private sector.

title: Bridge:
description: Experts sometimes have to employ magical skill to bring home contracts that lesser mortals would make with no difficulty at all.

title: Screen: Mae West, 87, Does an Encore:Trying for 6th Marriage
description: "SEXTETTE" is a disorienting freak show in which Mae West, now 87 years old, does a frail imitation of the personality that wasn't all that interesting 45 years ago. The movie, which opens today at the Victoria and other theaters, is a poetic, terrifying reminder of how a virtually disembodied ego can survive total physical decay and loss of common sense.The character we see in this peculiar film looks less like the Mae West one remembers from even "Myra Breckinridge" than like a plump sheep that's been stood on its hind legs, dressed in a drag-queen's idea of chic, bewigged and then smeared with pink plaster. The creature inside this getup seems game but arthritic and perplexed. She walks with apparent difficulty. One eye sometimes sags and the voice, despite Hollywood's electronic skills, cracks like the voice of the old lady she really is. Under these circumstances, the sexual innuendos are embarrassing. Granny should have her mouth washed out with soap, along with her teeth.The story, based on a play written some years ago by Miss West, is about a world-famous movie star and her attempts to consummate her sixth marriage to Sir Michael Barrington (Timothy Dalton) despite repeated interruptions by former husbands, lovers, dress designers, secret agents, publicity people and delegates attending an international peace conference just upstairs. It's a plot that Miss West has often favored, and it freely reprises a lot of lines from earlier pictures.The movie was directed by Ken Hughes ("The Small World of Sammy Lee," "Cromwell" and so on), a fellow you might think had better things to do than to prop up the Tower of Pisa. In addition to Mr. Dalton, "Sextette" features a number of other people who, in happier circumstances, are decent actors. These include Tony Curtis, George Hamilton, Ringo Starr and the incomparable Dom DeLuise. There are some original songs and some old ones, a couple of which sound as if they'd been lip-synched by Miss West to old recordings.The real problem with "Sextette" is neither the passage of time nor the erosion of talent. There was never a great deal of talent there to begin with. Miss West's function in the early 30's was to send up and get around the hypocritical moral prohibitions of the day. It made her famous but then the times passed her by. "My Little Chickadee" is the only film she ever made that's still worth seeing today, but its star is W.C. Fields, not Miss West who, in the presense of a comedian of Fields's great character, comes across as monotonous and mean-spirited, even less sexy than the goat that, at one point, Fields cuddles under the deliriously mistaken notion that he has finally bedded Mae."Sextette," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a lot of crudely suggestive dialogue.

title: About Real Estate
description: NORTH HILLS, L.I.  It isn't quite California, and it isn't quite Long Island. It's some of both, says Jeffrey Glick, the builder of a major condominium project called The Estates. It is taking shape here on a site well back from treelined Searington Road, half a mile from Manhasset and the Miracle Mile commercial district.

title: The Pop Life
description: WHAT with the popularity of disco, we are in one of the periodic upsurges in popularity of black music and black artists. The whole, complex relationship between blacks and American popular music is controversial  one overheated propagandist recently tried to stake the claim that all American popular music of any merit was black or Latin. Be that as it may, there can be no question of the crucial importance of blacks in shaping today's popular music and also no question that black musicians have not always been able to share in the glory and profits of that music proportionately to their creative contributions.

title: Bargain Hunting Aids Harvester
description: CHICAGO, June 7  Executives at the International Harvester Company who want to avoid an Archie letter a firm if amiably phrased warning from the company president  are careful to make sure that neither they nor their aides preempt the company's buyers.

title: Schlesinger Optimistic On Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that gasoline supplies should improve slightly in coming weeks but that the availability of oil products would remain tight for the rest of the year.

title: An Old Rivalry at the Thames Regatta
description: The crack of a starter's gun will sound over the Thames River in New London, Conn., at 6:95 tomorrow evening, and the arms of 16 college crewmen will snap taut as they strain against the oars of sleek racing shells.

title: Ballet: Debut in Quixote
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV's Don Quixote received a technically brilliant performance Wednesday during the American Ballet Theater's last week at the Metropolitan Opera House, with stylish and stylized dancing from Fernando Bujones as the barber Basil and Yoko Ichino as Kitri. The production is a friendly ballet, full of lighthearted bombast, and  that rarest of complaints  this Kitri was almost too perfect.

title: Film: 'Down and Dirty' Evokes Roman Squalor:On the Bottom
description: AN extended family of about 28 live in a one-room shanty beside a highway in Rome, and their plight is made to seem both revolting and peculiarly romantic in Ettore Scola's "Down and Dirty." On the one hand, these characters perform most of their bodily functions in public and look upon rats virtually as household pets; Mr. Scola's emphasis is upon earthiness in the extreme. On the other hand, they seem to have no trouble eating or staying healthy in their tiny, insular world, which for all its squalor looks perpetually sunny and warm. Mr. Scola has described the film as "a satirical tragedy," but the principal mood it strikes is one of deep confusion.The production notes for the film include a statement by Mr. Scola and his screenwriter, Ruggero Maccari, in which they deplore the isolation of the poor from the rest of society. Mr. Scola, in a separate interview, has explained that his film is about subproletarians, who, he says, differ from proletarians in that they have absolutely no class consciousness. However compassionate and understanding they may be, though, Mr. Scola and Mr. Maccari also state that "the poor are ugly, dirty, nasty, quarrelsome, violent, brutal and dishonest." These latter qualities are the only ones the film really illustrates, ad nauseam.For its first half-hour or so, "Down and Dirty" concentrates on a wide range of family antics, which are diverse enough to seem colorful and occasionally funny. Later, it zeroes in on what is more or less a plot: the patriarch, played by Nino Manfredi, has a million lire, his insurance compensation for the loss of his left eye, perhaps poked out in a typical family brawl. He guards his money jealously, which makes the others angry, since their only income is generated by stealing, selling their bodies and performing the most mindless and menial jobs.And the patriarch does something even more infuriating: he takes up with a whore, who is hideously fat but beautiful to him, either because his eyesight is poor or because she's the only woman in the movie who doesn't have whiskers. This is the last straw. The family decides to kill the patriarch, and so they feed him a dinner heavily seasoned with rat poison. He wolfs down the meal, suddenly realizes what has happened, staggers away from the table and  in a moment of bizarre victory  he vomits triumphantly. Mr. Manfredi, whose performance is hard to isolate from all the caterwauling around him, has come a long way from "Bread and Chocolate," that's for sure."Down and Dirty," which opens today at the Paris theater, seems promising until the limitations of Mr. Scola's intention become unmistakable. His method is one of endless repetition, and the heavy-handedness of his approach mixes poorly with the film's overall coarseness. His characters, so stylized and belligerent they become exhausting, are disproportionate with his more general concerns, which are much plainer in their way. And for all Mr. Scola's wallowing in the sordidness of his characters' lives, there's something fatally tentative in his approach. It's as if the film's emphatic freakishness  a one-legged actor, a man with a cauliflower nose, a three-legged dog  were meant to compensate for an essential disgust with the entire subject.

title: Assembly Cuts Penalties For Some Drug Offenses
description: ALBANY, June 7 Acknowledging the failure of some aspects of the sixyearold Rockefeller drug laws, the Assembly voted today to reduce penalties for firsttime narcotics offenders, including ending the requirement for prison sentences and possible life imprisonment in all cases.

title: Propane in Ample Supply
description: At a time when motorists have been lining up for gasoline, and diesel and jet fuel shortages have occurred in some areas, propane stocks have been piling up apparently unnoticed by energy consumers

title: F.W. TOMKINS DEAD; ECUMENICAL LEADER
description: The Rev. Floyd W. Tomkins Sr., member of a distinguished family of clergymen and a founder of the ecumenical movement, died Monday in Orleans, Mass., after a long illness. He was 91 years old.

title: JapanBrazil Fuel Plan
description: TOKYO, June 7 (Reuters)  Japan and Brazil have signed an agreement to develop ways of producing fuel alcohol from potato starch to blend with gasoline, the International Trade and Industry Ministry said today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Kenneth Harvey Dead; An Actor and Director
description: Kenneth Harvey, an actor, writer and director in the theater and television, died Wednesday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital, after treatment at the University of Texas Cancer Center in Houston. He was 60 years old and lived in Wilton. Conn.

title: Carey Seeks $15,000 For Expense Account From the Legislature
description: ALBANY, June 7  Governor Carey included a $15,000 expense allowance for himself in a draft bill he submitted to the Legislature today. The bill implements the labor agreements that the state reached with its employees earlier this year.

title: Opera: Three Pintos By MahlerWeber
description: ST. LOUIS, June 7  Of all the shelved items in opera's curiosity shop, none is more curious than Die Drei Pintos. This halflegendary work, which Carl Maria von Weber left in fragmented form at his death in 1826. was comeleted  more accurately, recomposed  by Gustav Mahler 66 years later, literally as an act of love. Mahler, 26 years old at the time, met the grandson of Weber, who persuaded him to decipher and reconstruct the sketchy score. Mahlerfell in love with the idea at once, and soon fell in love with the grandson's wife, which made for many juicy complications, musically and extramusically.

title: Indians Protest at U.S. Embassy
description: NEW DELHI, June 6 (AP)  About 50 demonstrators sprawled on the ground outside the United States Embassy today demanding protection when chunks of the orbiting Skylab spacecraft fall to earth. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has said Skylab will fall from orbit in early July, scattering about 500 pieces of debris.
