title: PANEL FINDS CAUSES OF 2 PLANE CRASHES
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  The National Transportation Safety Board announced today the probable causes of two plane crashes last year in which 20 persons died.

title: German Nuclear Concern to Leave Iran
description: BONN, June 7  West Germany's largest nuclear contractor signaled today that it had virtually given up hope of completing work on two nuclearpower plants in Iran worth a total of $4 billion to $5 billion.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DALLAS, June 7 (Reuters)  The Sunshine Mining Company has purchased the 1.6 million shares of its common stock held by the Hunt International Resources Corporation, ending a long and bitter conflict between the two companies, it was announced today.

title: 3 ASIAN LANDS BACK POL POT DELEGATES
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, June 7  Three antiCommunist states of Southeast Asia were reported today to be solidly in favor of seating the Pot Pot delegates as the representatives of Cambodia at the current conference of thirdworld nations though the same governments strongly condemn the violent repression under the Pol Pot rule.

title: Miss Britz's 64 Leads Championship by 4
description: KINGS ISLAND, Ohio, June 7 Jerilyn Britz, who never has finished better than third in 5 years on the tour, tied a Ladies Professional Golf Association record with nine birdies in one round today and took the openinground lead in the 25th annual L.P.G.A. championship.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Gains Final In France
description: PARIS, June 7 Chris Evert Lloyd and Wendy Turnbull cruised to surprisingly easy semifinal victories in the French open today and will battle each other for the winner's purse of $30,000 in the singles final on Saturday.

title: Schmidt Talk at Harvard Supports New Arms Pact
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 7  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany strongly endorsed the proposed strategic arms treaty here today, calling it vital to his nation's continued trust in the ability of the West to preserve an equilibrium in Europe.

title: E.P.A. Extends Use of Pesticide
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would allow pear growers to use the pesticide amitrtaz for another four years, with safeguards to protect agricultural workers and consumers from possible harm. Workers exposed to the pesticide, sold under the brand name Baam, must wear protective clothing and stay out of treated areas until the poison dries, the agency said. Amitrtaz is suspected of having residues that may cause cancer.

title: Consumer Outlook Found Pessimistic
description: Consumers confidence in the economy and their plans to make. major purchases declined again in May, according to a survey released yesterday by the Conference Board. It was the third consecutive month that its poll showed such a decline, the nonprofit business research organization said.

title: Jack Mulhall,Actor In Earlier Films
description: Jack Mulhall, whose genial personality was his trademark in silent films and the early days of the talkies, died last Friday in the Motion Picture and Television Country House and Hospital in Hollywood, where he had Hired for the last two years. He was 91 years old.

title: Energy Issues Lead Market Upward; Dow Advances 1.47 in Heavy Trading
description: The energy issues continued to steal the spotlight on Wall Street yesterday as the overall market finished with a broad gain in the year's heaviest trading.

title: At the Movies
description: IT was midnight on Park Avenue South and 29th Street one night recently, and the neighborhood was altered by the presence of the police officers who were assigned to order during location shooting of Captain Avenger.

title: Japanese Seek Arctic Oil
description: TOKYO, June 7 (Reuters) The Japan National Oil Corporation said today that it was negotiating with Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Canada for joint development of large oil reserves in the Arctic's Beaufort Sea.

title: 3 Guilty of Trying to Kill Teacher
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 7 (AP) Three girls and a boy, 12 and 13 years old, have been convicted of trying to murder a teacher by poisoning his coffee. The teacher had given them failing grades.

title: Laker Links Jet Crash To Maintenance Work
description: LONDON, June 7 Laker Airways, with all six of its white DC10's sitting idle at Gatwick Airport, charged today that shoddy maintenance practices in the United States may have caused the crash of an American Airlines DC10 that took 275 lives on May 25.

title: Jazz: Unorthodox Amram
description: DAVID AMRAM is a musician whose performances are apt to put almost as much emphasis on proselytizing for whatever type of music he is offering whether he is at a folk festival, conducting a classical concert or heading a musical invasion of Cuba  as they do on playing the music. This week through tomorrow, he is wearing his jazz hat at Fat Tuesday's at Third Avenue at 17th Street, where, between selections, he points out the merits of jazz to his listeners.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Robert C. Hall, executive vice president and the secondhighest employee of the New York Stock Exchange, resigned yesterday to become president and chief executive officer of Satellite Business Systems, effective July 16.

title: 78 Convictions Of Provenzano And Aide Upset
description: ALBANY, June 7  The convictions of Anthony (Tony Pro) Provenzano and Harold Konigsberg in the murder of a Teamsters Union rival of Mr. Provenzano were overturned today by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: Kayo Franklin, OnePunch Cordero
description: It is advertised as a horse race but it's beginning to look like the hottest flyweight bout since Jimmy Wilde boxed Pancho Villa. In spite of the aura of invincibility that has surrounded Spectacular Bid through 12 successive stakes. in spite of predictions that he will go to the post tomorrow at odds of 1 to 10, eight cockeyed optimists paid $1,000 each yesterday and a ninth forked over $5,000 to buy their colts a shot at the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner in the 111th Belmont Stakes. That's probably a track record for rosy san

title: Clearing the Air
description: The Federal Aviation Administration's decision to ground the DC10 is causing endless trouble. Thousands of passengers have had plans disrupted, airlines are losing millions and the manufacturer is threatened with staggering losses. And coming after Three Mile Island, doubts are raised about technology in general and American technology in particular.

title: Daughter of Mobil Official Wed; Nearby Station Stays Open Late
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 7 Last Saturday, the Mobil gasoline station at the corner of Cherry Street and South Avenue in this suburb was open from 6:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. It was unusual because, for the last several weeks, the station had closed its pumps at 11 A.M.

title: Lockwood Cleared for Duty
description: Skip Lockwood, premier relief pitcher for the New York Mets, was reported by the team's surgeon yesterday to be not seriously injured and was expected to resume his role in the bull pen tomorrow.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CarterWallace Inc., a manufacturer of drug and toiletry products, has elected Paul A. Veteri vice president and controller.

title: 520 Sites in New York Are Listed as Polluted By Poisonous Material
description: ALBANY, June 7 There are 520 areas In New York State that are contaminated by toxic materials, but none approaches in severity the hazardous conditions at Love Canal in Niagara Falls, according to a state report released today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: PRESIDENT REFUSES TO LIFT TRADE BAN AGAINST RHODESIANS
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  President Carter refused today to lift sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia and vowed to do everything I can, within my power to prevent Congress from taking the matter out of his hands and mandating an end to the economic embargo.

title: Financial General Gets Higher Bid
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (Reuters) A group of Middle Eastern investors, rebuffed once already in a bid to acquire Financial General Bankshares Inc has raised its offer for the bank holding company to $135 million, Financial General said

title: Zahringer Triumphs In Westchester Final
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 7 George Zahringer, a 26yearold stockbroker from Stanwich Country Club, ran into stubborn opposition today before winning the 60th Westchester amateur championship.

title: 3 Twins Pitchers Stymie Yanks 41
description: Mike Bacsik and Mike Marshall had better luck against Cliff Johnson yesterday than Rich Gossage and Lou DiMuro have had this season. The Minnesota relief pitchers kept the oneman wrecking crew from devastating the Twins and thus preserved a 41 victory over the Yankees.

title: WQXR Uses New Method In Transmitting Recordings
description: WQXR Radio was said to have made broadcasting history yesterday by transmitting recordings made by the new digital process, using digital equipment.

title: Broadway
description: GEORGE ROSE, Millicent Martin and Katharine Houghton will star in Little Lies, which Joseph George Caruso has adapted from Arthur Wing Pinero's The Magistrate, and which will open on Broadway next April 27. This is a long way off; so is the $300,000 or so it will cost to do Little Lies. No matter. the producers say; when the cast commits itself a year in advance, and when Crandall Diehl, the director, commits himself, too, then it must be a sure thing. Little Lies was done last summer at the Greenwich Mews, where it was seen by William DeSilva. Mr. DeSilva, who was once an actor, persuaded Loomis Caryl Irish, who was once a televison executive, to see it, too. Immediately, they decided to produce it on Broadway together. Almost as immediately, Mr. Rose, Miss Martin and Miss Houghton said they would appear in it. The April 27 date, the producers say, will make everyone eligible for next season's Tony awards. Seldom has so much hope sprung so early.

title: Cosmos Effort Pleases Coaches
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 7  The soccer game had been over for almost two hours last night, and the locker room that had been boisterous and crowded was quiet and nearly empty.

title: Urban Development Grant: Spur to Private Investment
description: It's the best thing since flush toilets, Alfred L. Faiella, executive director of the Newark Economic Development Corporation, said when asked to assess the Federal Urban Development Action Grant program. Since his office has been

title: Federal Election Panel Approves Study of Its Auditing Procedures
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  The Federal Election Commission, which has been criticized by Congress for its delay in completing audits of the 1976 Presidential campaigns and by some of its own staff for the narrow focus of those audits, voted today to ask Arthur Andersen & Company, a major accounting concern, and Accountants for the Public Interest, a national nonprofit association, to study its auditing procedures.

title: Mrs. Immerman Is Victor In New Jersey Golf Event
description: NORTHFIELD, N. J., June 7 Mrs. John Immerman of Montclair won the 30th annual Uebelacker Memorial Tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association today with a 36hole net total of 144 at the Atlantic City Country Club.

title: Thorpe Won't Testify at His Trial
description: LONDON, June 7  Jeremy Thorpe said through his lawyer today that he would not take the witness stand to defend himself against charges that he conspired to murder a man who says he was his lover.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE gods visit the sins of the fathers upon the children, Euripides prophesied; but what about the more impersonal sins of history? Are they, too, passed on from one generation to the next? Helen Enstein, a New YorK Journalist whose parents survived the holocaust, was haunted throughout her childhood by her family's difference from others: They were more somber, more susceptible to sudden flurries of rage, more conscious of life's treachery. There was an iron box within her, she recalls in Children of the Holocaust, that concealed some terrible, unspoken secret; and it was only when she came to interview the children of other survivors that she discovered what it was: the inexpressible trauma imprinted on her parents lives, as indelible as the number on her mother's arm. And her awareness of this trauma, Miss Epstein says, determined her own character.

title: SolarHeated Building in China
description: PEKING, June 7 (Reuters)  China's first building to be heated by solar energy is almost completed at Xining, capital of Qinghai Province, the New China News Agency said today. The agency said onefifth of the fivestory building would be heated by solar energy collected by panels installed on the roof.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Concerto for Violin, Strings, and Continuo in G minor, Albinoni; Roumanian Folk Dances, Bartok; Sonata for Flute, Oboe, and Continuo in B flat, Vivaldi; Vocalise, Rachmaninoff.

title: The Dirty Secret in the HBomb Case
description: The Carter Administration's once grimsounding case against The Progressive magazine has degenerated into costly farce. Hbomb secrets as grave  or inconsequentialas those the magazine wants to print are now known to have lain around for four years in the public files of a science library in Los Alamos, and other places. When a researcher for the magazine's lawyers found a strikingly good example of how the Government had declassified what it claims in court to be among the nation's highest secrets, the Administration tried to remove the document from his grasp and closed the library. Yet when it learned that the researcher had mailed a halfdozen copies of the document to various people for comment, no one bothered even to ask to whom they were sent so that they might be retrieved.

title: Market Place
description: THE Petrie Stores Corporation, a lucrative apparel chain whose profits generally end up as dividends or cash in the bank, hopes to acquire Toys R Us Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy a year ago. The management of Toys announced Wednesday at its annual meeting that Petrie had in creased its holding. in Toys to 1.18 million shares about 13 percent of the stock.

title: For an Energy Corporation of the Northeast
description: One energy crisis has been the subject of lofty rhetoric and vibrant calls to action beginning with President Nixon's Project Independence speech in 1973 and continuing down to President Carter's Moral Equivalent of War speech in 1978. During this period, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries quintupled the price of crude oil, our payments for oil imports went from $6 billion per annum to a current level of over $50 billion, our dependence on foreign crude increased, and the dollar collapsed. So much for the effectiveness of the rhetoric.

title: Stage: Irene Worth In Happy Days
description: THE difficulty in giving a solo performance on the stage is inherent in the nature of acting. To act is to react; it is less a matter of transporting than of being transported. If an actor strangles Desdemona or merely crosses from stage left to stage center, it should not be because he decides to, but because something pushes him.

title: Discovering the Pleasures of Columbus Avenue
description: CALL it what you wish  neighborhood rebirth, urban renaisanee, the latest emergence of city chic  but whatever you call it be sure to label it Columbus Avenue, the new Columbus Avenue.

title: EARNINGS
description: The British Petroleum Company reported yesterday that its firstquarter net income soared 229.4 percent to $583 million, or $1.51 a share, from $177 million, or 46 cents a share, in the 1978 quarter. Operating revenues were up 25 percent to $10.5billion from $8.4 billion. B.P., one of the world's largest integrated oil companies, attributed the gain to three factors.

title: Stage: New Group Gives The Days Between
description: ROBERT ANDERSON'S The Days Between is having its New York premiere at the Park Royal Theater, where it Is being done as the first production of the new Playhouse Repertory Company. The company, a child of the famous Neighborhood Playhouse School, wants to do American plays, with actors trained in the school technique. In The Days Between, it has made an altogether interesting start.

title: Screen: 'Players' Takes World Tennis Tour:On the Courts
description: CHRIS (Dean-Paul Martin), in his 20's, is an attractive but directionless tennis hustler. In her own way Nicole (Ali MacGraw) is as much without purpose as Chris. She's what fiction of this sort presents as "an older woman," meaning that she's approaching 40 and looks more smashing than most 30-year-olds.Nicole is both beautiful and beautifully kept by an international business tycoon named Marco (Maximilian Schell), who periodically summons Nicole from her Cuernavaca villa to his Mediterranean yacht. In one of her free periods, Nicole and Chris meet on a Mexican highway after her car runs into a tree. All sorts of sparks are immediately struck. One result is that her car, as if having a temper tantrum, blows up. Another is that she and Chris fall in love. Madly.Can Nicole summon up the courage to turn her back on the money, the clothes, the travel, the servants and the fresh flowers, which life with Marco represents, to follow Chris into the unknown world of professional tennis? Will Marco use his power to destroy all that is good and fine and decent between Nicole and Chris? Will Chris win the longest Wimbledon tennis match ever recorded in a fiction film? Do you care?These are some of the questions raised by "Players," a romantic drama told in a series of unreasonably coherent, chronological flashbacks as Chris thinks about his affair with Nicole during his Wimbledon match against Guillermo Vilas. No wonder he doesn't play too well at the start. It's not because Nicole is not sitting in seat No. 30 but because he has Arnold Schulman's dopey screenplay on his mind.It's ironic that although "Players" is very much what its producer, Robert Evans, likes to call "a man-woman-people film," the most interesting things in the movie are not the men or the women or the people. Instead they are the exotic settings in Cuernavaca, Monte Carlo, Las Vegas and London, as well as the tennis exhibitions that feature a lot of real-life pros, including Pancho Gonzalez, who appears as Chris's trainer."Players" is the sort of movie in which the actors serve the function of scenery. They are nice to look at but it's not really possible to identify with a tree or even a lilac bush. Mr. Schulman's dialogue doesn't help, nor does the direction by Anthony Harvey ("A Lion in Winter"), who never discovers a source of narrative energy to compensate for the emptiness of the characters.The movie unravels in bits and pieces as it cross-cuts between the Wimbledon match and the flashbacks. The sillier the flashbacks become, the more annoying are the interruptions to the game. Miss MacGraw and Mr. Martin, who is a tennis pro in real life and the son of Dean Martin, seem to be nice people but they appear to be very ill at ease in the film's dramatic sequences that, because of the shape of the movie, look like television commercials for products never named."Players," which opens today at Loew's State 1 and the Coronet Theaters, isn't exactly boring. It's pretty and painless and immediately forgettable."Players," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), includes some midly suggestive sexual encounters and vulgar language.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, June 9

title: Tenants Who Withheld Rent in 1976 Win Appeal
description: The New York State Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed yesterday a lowercourt decision giving tenants in a Manhattan housing complex the right to withhold part of their rent because of a strike by building employees three years ago that led to sanitary problems.

title: HOUSE PANEL MOVES ON FLOOD AND DIGGS
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  The House ethics committee, in cases involving two longtime Democratic Congressmen, today accused Representative Daniel J. Flood of Pennsylvania of 25 counts of violating House rules and voted to hold public hearings on allegations against Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr. of Michigan.

title: Worldwide Air Service Still Hampered by DC10 Curb
description: Hampered by the grounding of as many as 275 DC10's around the world, airplane travel continued at less than full efficiency yesterday with airlines switching planes, flights and passengers in an effort to compensate for the absence of the widebody jumbo Jets:

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday COMPOSERS AT THE KITCHEN

title: SUZANNAH RYAN WILLKIE>
description: Suzannah Ryan Willkie, greatgranddaughter of the financier Thomas Fortune Ryan, died of cancer yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 44 years old and lived at 40 East 62d Street in Manhattan.

title: Mime: Jane Adler
description: SOME mimes dispense with music, making their art an art of silence in every respect. Others  among them Jane Adler  find it congenial to work with music. Miss Adler, in fact, regularly collaborates with Andrew Bolotowsky,

title: Belmont Battlers Fined
description: Angel Cordero and Ron Franklin were fined $250 apiece yesterday for fighting the day before, but escaped further punitive action. That cleared the way for both jockeys to ride in tomorrow's 111th Belmont Stakes.

title: Around the Nation
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 7 (UPI)  A California civil engineer was hired yesterday by city officials to find out what caused the roof of the Kemper Arena to collapse.

title: Weekend Outlook on Gasoline
description: Gasoline stations are prohibited from giving special treatment to preferred customers or requiring other purchases to get gasoline, the Federal Department of Energy warned yesterday. It urged any motorist who thought the regulation was being violated to telephone, tollfree, (800) 4249246.

title: Art: The Sculptures Of a Perfectionist
description: DAME BARBARA HEPWORTH died four years ago, the victim of a fire at her Studio in St. Ives, Cornwall. A poignant enough end for an artist who would brook no accidents in her work, it was, made more so by a remark she had uttered not long before. She was beina interviewed by the critic Cindy Nemser and had confirmed once again her lack of interest in automatism, saying that, in sculpture, as in anything else, You use your intuition or sharp response to a set of conditions. Then she added, I would just hate it if I did things heedlessly. I would hate them so, I would set fire to the whole studio.

title: Council Decides To Vote Censure For Mastropieri
description: By a vote of 40 to 0, the City Council censured Councilman Eugene F. Mastro. pied last night, stripping him of his committee chairmanship and his eight years of seniority and fining him three months pay of $5,000.

title: Hurricane Season Spawns Concern in Vulnerable Florida
description: MIAMI, June 7  The official start this month of the hurricane season has spawned fresh waves of anxiety over the potential damage that a great tropical [storm could inflict on Florida and other Atlantic and Gulf Coast states.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Prices Continue to Climb
description: Propelled by a smallerthanexpected increase in the Producer Price Index, the credit market's strong advance continued yesterday. New bond issues sold swiftly. Fixedincome prices closed with moderately large gains and yields declined.

title: Congress Fight on Rhodesia Seen
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  President Carter's decision not to lift economic sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia was certain to face an early challenge in Congress, but a key House supporter said the President's policy could be sustained with active Administration lobbying.

title: Senators Vote Military Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  The Senate Armed Services Committee approved a $3.7 billion military construction bill yesterday, including additional funds for nuclear weapons testing. Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi and committee chairman, said the panel added $28.3 million to the bill for nuclear weapons testing and pollution abatement equipment at the Federal facility at Oak Ridge, Tenn., but gave no other details.

title: MAY BRANDT
description: May Brandt, proprietor of a women's apparel shop on the Upper East Side of Manhattan for more than 40 years, died at her home last Saturday after a brief illness. She lived at 311 East 72d Street.

title: Wrong Turn in Albuquerque
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 7 (UPI)  University of New Mexico officials fear the National Collegiate Athletic Association could order an investigation into how Ken Page, a basketball player, obtained the luxury car he drove to Ohio last weekend.

title: Similar Subway Incidents in 1979
description: The young woman whose hand waisevered by a subway train yesterday was the latest victim in a series of shoving or similar incidents this year in the subways, Transit Authority officials said.

title: Theater: Country Plays Make the Big City Laugh
description: WITH his two oneact comedies, Lone Star and Pvt. Wars, James McLure was the comic discovery of this year's new play festival at the Actors Theater of Louisville. Like a pair of firecrackers, the plays opened at the Century Theater last night.

title: Schlumberger Data Sought
description: Schlumberger Ltd. said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission had requested additional information concerning its offer to acquire the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, a major manufacturer of semiconductor products, for $66 a share, or a total of $400 million. Schlumberger. which provides well logging services for the petroleum industry, said it intended to respond promptly to the F.T.C. request but that its purchase of shares could be delayed up to 10 days after the requested additional information is furnished. The company also said that it had been informed that the F.T.C. was requesting additional information from Fairchild.

title: Critic's Notebook: What's Happened To Movies That You See for Fun?
description: THE thing that most made me want to see Alien was that irresistible line they've been using in the ads: In space no one can hear you scream. In addition. I was interested in the director, Ridley Scott, who also made The Duellists, and in what seemed to be an especially wellmatched cast of cool, compelling players. Besides, Alien appeared destined to become the season's most babbledabout conversation piece. Besides, it sounded like fun.

title: The Greening of New York
description: The Lower East Side of Manhattan gained a small new park yesterday on the site of what was once a rubblestrewn vacant lot.

title: Advertising
description: ONCE the agency for Britain's RollsRoyce and later  briefly  the agency for France's Renault, McCaffrey & McCall has just become agency for Germany's MercedesBenz. The account bills $10 million, and David B. McCall, chairman of the agency, is ecstatic.

title: Business and the Law
description: THE other day, Arthur R. Miller, a Harvard law professor who is gifted with a comedian's sense of timing, was instructing and entertaining a group of Federal judges and lawyers. An expert on privacy, the professor spoke of apprehensions of the Orwellian fantasy of a wombtotomb dossier. He spoke also of how more and more business decisions were being made by merely looking at files and how people had become the alter ego of Manila folders. Then, he paused and pondered: God help us if they got the wrong Arthur Miller  the deadbeat playwright. The audience cracked up.

title: Sheila A. Hayman Is Married To Harvey Stone in Jersey
description: Sheila A. Hayman of London and Harvey Stone of Millburn, N.J., were married yesterday at the Millburn Town Hall by Mayor Maureen Ogden.

title: John Poggi, Singer Co. Executive
description: John J. Poggi, president of the United States Sewing Products division of the Singer Company and vice president of the parent company, died Wednesday after a brief illness at his home in Hillsdale, N.J. He was 57 years old.

title: 7% Pay Raise Proposal Approved by House Unit
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  A littlenoticed amendment to an appropriations bill could allow Congress and topranking Government officials to receive a 7 percent pay increase later this year.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, June 7 (UPI)  China and Vietnam will reconvene their peace talks June 25 in Peking, the New China News Agency announced today.

title: For Larry Holmes, the Show Must Go On
description: Larry Holmes made his Broadway debut yesterday in a boxing ring, stage left, at the Helen Hayes Theatre. To Don King, the world heavyweight champion is no less an angel than the backers of the play, Knockout, currently at the theater.

title: South African Assets Up
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 7 (AP)  South Africa's total gold and foreign currency assets increased by $269.8 million last month and stood at $3.1 billion on May 31, according to the monthly statement released by the reserve bank today. The gold holding alone increased by $232.5 million to $2.4 billion, based on a valuation of $245.30 a fine ounce compared with $220.25 an ounce in April.

title: 3Day Laban Salute At Teachers College
description: The 100th birthday of Rudolf Laban, the influential German teacher and movement theorist, will be celebrated today through Sunday at a Laban Centennial Celebration to be held at Teachers College of Columbia University.

title: Publishing: Finishing Alexander Hamilton
description: NEXT Tuesday will see the end of a project by the Columbia University Press that has been 41 years in the making. On that date the press will issue the final volume  Volume 26 of The Pavers of Alexander Hamilton. It is the first of such projects involving the Founding Fathers to reach completion.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP ONLY 0.4% FOR MAY, LOWEST IN 9 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 A sign that inflation may be abating came today in a Government report that producer prices in May showed the smallest increase in nine months. Producer prices normally foreshadow what consumers will pay in coming months.

title: Airlines Advice for DC10 TicketHolders
description: With the nation's fleet of DC10's grounded, the major domestic and international airlines affected by the move had a variety of tips for ticketed and prospective passengers yesterday.

title: Where to See New Artists
description: INVITATIONAL is not the prettiest word in the language, but it has overtones of hospitality and expansiveness that somehow fit the second weekend in June. A new place, a new face and a new idea all find their warmest welcome as the longest day of the year approaches. And in galleries that normally field only the home team we may find that younger and less familiar artists have the place of honor.

title: Barnes Is Kunstler's New Cause
description: William Kunstler paced the nearly empty room, showing his 2yearold daughter the view of Battery Park with the Statue of Liberty in the distance and checking the elevator bank at fiveminute intervals. His newest client had been scheduled to meet the press at 11 A.M. yesterday and it was close to noon.

title: Israelis Report Air Force Attacks Palestinians in South of Lebanon
description: TELAVIV, Friday, June 8 (AP)  The Israeli Air Force attacked Palestinian positions in southeast Lebanon nine miles north of the IsraeliLebanese border at dawn today, the Israeli military, command announced.

title: Race Barriers in Housing Still High 11 Years After the Civil Rights Act
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  Nearly a dozen years after Congress outlawed racial discrimination in housing, large portions of the nation's home market remain effectively closed to blacks and members of other minorities.

title: A Vision of Utopia Fading at Rochdale
description: Kneehigh grass littered with broken glass and yellowed newspapers alerts visitors to a strike that has left Rochdale Village without maintenance crews these last seven months. For the 25,000 residents who must wade through the debris each day, it seems a perversion of the haven this cooperative community in Queens was once envisaged to be.

title: City and Jersey Ask Change In U. S. Gas Markup Rules
description: New York City and New Jersey officials proposed changes yesterday in Federal markup regulations designed to bring down retail gasoline prices.

title: Art People
description: THE questions that they were asking were not much different from the questions they had asked before, and  as usual they had no hard answers Who really visits museums and why? Should those who do be helped to see by various devices or simply left to their own? Are museums attempting to speak to too many publics? And how can they measure their success in reaching visitors?

title: Shawcross to Discuss Cambodia Book on Today
description: William Shawcross, author of Sideshow: Kissinger, Nixon and the Destruction of Cambodia, will appear on NBCTV's Today show Tuesday morning.

title: Gas Prices Up In South Africa
description: CAPE TOWN, June 7 (AP)  South Africa, hard hit by the cutoff of oil shipments from Iran, today raised gasoline prices by almost 90 percent, ordered service stations closed on Saturdays and sharply lowered speed limits. The action raised the price of a gallon of gasoline to about $2.77.

title: Notes on People
description: After 15 years at the Ford Foundation, where he was vice president for resources and the environment, Marshall A. Robinson is moving a few blocks west and north to head the Russell Sage Foundation, at 230 Park Avenue.

title: Business Loans Up at Big Banks
description: Business loans at the 10 largest New York banks rose $131 million in the week ended June 6, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Senate Unit Votes to Reinstitute Registration for a Military Draft
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI)  A Senate Armed Services subcommittee has voted in a closed meeting to reinstitute registration for the military draft, Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said today.

title: Photographs by Catherine UrsIllo (Opera), Allen Green (Festival), Martha Swope (Stage), Charles Stewart (Jazz)
DC10 INQUIRY TURNS TO HYDRAULIC SETUP
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  The inquiry into the crash of a DC10 jumbo jet in Chicago focused increasingly today on the aircraft's hydraulics systems, which operate numerous vital devices, including the front wing flaps. It is widely believed that those flaps became unevenly deployed on the American Airlines jet after the loss of an engine on takeoff, making the plane uncontrollable.

title: There's Oil for the Asking in Them Thar Hills
description: I began thinking about the energy situation in 1973, the year of the oil embargo. It seemed to me that my company had two choices. We could live in fearevery time a sheik or an OPEC member became angry with the United States, or we could find a way to make ourselves independent.

title: Topics
description: Nearer

title: Restaurants
description: THE 99yearold Gage & Toliner on Fulton Street in downtown Brooklyn is exactly the sort of restaurant we'd love to love. Too many of New York's genuinely antique establishments have met their demise, and this is one of the few remaining that offers a glimpse of what life must have been like during the city's belle poque. This is an enormous restaurant, with arched mirrors parading down both sides, carved plaster walls that are dullburnished gold in color and a row

title: ISRAEL STARTS WORK ON NEW SETTLEMENT
description: JERUSALEM, June 7  A militant Israeli group began work today on a controversial new settlement near Nablus, the largest Arab city in the West Bank, in the presence of Government officials, an army detachment and representatives of the World Zionist Organization.

title: The New York Times
description: INSEPARABLE TWINS: Rob Wilfong (7) and Ken Landreaux of Minnesota colliding while chasing fly ball in fourth inning yesterday at Yankee Stadium. Landreaux held on for the out. The Twins defeated the Yankees, 41.

title: Letters
description: When Vietnam Doves Vindicate the Hawks

title: Carter Approves Mobile Missile, Officials Report
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  President Carter has approved the fullscale development of a new mobile intercontinental missile, known as the MX, but is deferring a decision on the details of how the huge landbased rocket is to be deployed, Administration officials said today.

title: Abortion Foe Will Seek Presidential Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  Sean Morton Downey, an antiabortion activist, declared his candidacy today for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination. He said that the leadership had turned the Democrats into the party of death.

title: Ruth Jenny Koffrler Wed To Malcolm Lee Sheldon
description: The Jewish Center in Manhattan was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Ruth Jenny Koffler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Cohen of Lawrence L.I., to Malcolm Lee Sheldon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin I. Sheldon, also of Lawrence. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Leo Jung, who was assisted by Rabbi Irving Wietschner.

title: Film: 'Dreamer' Bowls for Rainbows:Alley Style
description: I'M not sure I've ever seen a movie that was supposed to tell a story and managed to be as uneventful as "Dreamer," which opens today at neighborhood theaters. Here is this title character  a cockeyed optimist, as you can see  and here is his grand passion: bowling. This is what happens to him during the course of a very long 93 minutes: he wins a couple of trophies. He has car trouble. He bloodies his thumb by overbowling, and one of the friendly barmaids at the bowling alley where he works advises him to rub raw potato on the wound. These waitresses adore Dreamer, but nothing comes of any of it. They all seem to be named Angie.Wait, there's more. Dreamer (Tim Matheson) has a girlfriend (Susan Blakely), who loves him even though he treats her terribly and, as part of the film's dramatic climax, makes him a special shirt with his name embroidered on the sleeve. He also has a coach (Jack Warden), whose motto is "You don't beat a person, you beat the pins." This coach eventually bowls himself to death, but his legacy to Dreamer is a special ball, also with his name on it. The movie ends with one last big tournament, at which a sharp-eyed sports-caster observes that Dreamer is "trying to bring a new dimension to the sport." "They'll remember his style, and they'll remember that white satin shirt."By this juncture, it has become impossible to wonder who'll win or to root for Dreamer at all; as played by Mr. Matheson, he is an arrogant blowhard who spends more than enough time rooting for himself. The only things more grating than the character are a theme song, played at least three different times, about how Dreamer is going to find his end of the rainbow, and incessant plugs for brand-name merchandise, bowling-related and otherwise. And as for bowling-alley ambience, all "Dreamer" offers in that department are occasional glimpses of two Hispanic characters whose job is to set up pins. They are represented as being stupid, shiftless and lazy."Dreamer" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It is never violent, and contains only mild and infrequent sexual innuendoes.

title: Welk Champagne Music Comes to the Garden
description: With all the trouble that NBC has been having finding programs people want to watch, Lawrence Welk was saying the other day, a friend of mine told me I ought to offer them our show. I mentioned it to my producer, Don Feddersen. He talked with our business people. He came back to me and said I couldn't afford to do it

title: House Votes Cutback In Subsidized Housing
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  The House today passed and sent to the Senate a housing bill that its sponsor said would reduce by 25 percent the number of lowincome, federally subsidized housing units that Congress had previously approved. The vote was 355 to 36.

title: Area Store Sales Indicate Gasoline Is Taking Toll
description: Although retail business in New York City continued strong last month, the first signs that suburban shopping had been hurt by the shortage of gasoline and its rising price were reported yesterday as the area's biggest retailers released their May sales results.

title: Safe Reading
description: A few days before Mayor Koch's recent welcome restoration of city funds to the New York Public Library, I returned to the building from lunch to find a trail of freshly splashed blood, leading from the 42d Street entrance to the inquiry desk in the main hall. A Mental patient, out on a pass, had repeatedly stabbed a reading room user in the head and neck; the puddles of blood I saw had spurted from the victim as he was rushed to medical facilities on the ground floor.

title: For Children
description: NATURE SAFARISTALKING THE WILDS OF CONNECTICUT, twelve different nature programs and walks for children and their parents, Sunday, 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M., at the Stamford Museum & Nature Center, 39 Scofieldtown Road, Stamford, Conn. Fee for each program: 50 cents for children; S1 for adults. Call (203) 3221646.

title: Francis Bradshaw, 85, Founder Of Industrial Consultant Concern
description: Francis F. Bradshaw, founder and president of Richardson, Bellows, Henry & Company, consultant psychologists to industry, died Saturday in San Jose, Calif. He was 85 years old.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Amtrak, threatened only a few weeks ago with emasculation, may be at least partially rescued by a combination of ridership gains forced by the energy crunch and vigorous railbuff lobbying. Not that the needed commitment has as yet been made to develop firstclass rail passenger service; but at least the Administration's meat ax appears to have been stayed for a while.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 8, 1979

title: Scientists Say Liquid Water May Exist in Mars Areas
description: Scientists have identified at least two mions of Mars where liquid water may exist just below the surface and thus where conditions might support some forms of life.

title: Talmadge's Attorneys Rebuked by Stevenson Over Defense's Tactics
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  Saying that what we've been going through is intolerable, the chairman of the Senate ethics committee has publicly rebuked attorneys for Senator Herman E. Talmadge for their tactics in defending the Georgia Democrat.

title: 4.5% Rise Is Planned In NewPlant Outlay,
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  American businesses plan to increase their outlays for new plant and equipment this year by about 4.5 percent, adjusted for inflation, the Commerce Department reported today. This compares with a 5 percent increase in 1978. In unadjusted dollar figures, this year's projected capital spending will be up nearly 13 percent, the department said.

title: Skylab Space Station Reentry Now Expected July 4 to July 28
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI)  Revised calculations indicate that the Skylab space station will fall to earth sometime from July 4 to July 28, with July 16 the most likely date, the space agency reported today.

title: Seoul to Import U.S. Grain
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 7 (UPI)  South Korea signed an agreement today to import $40 million worth of United States surplus grain this year. Under the agreement, South Korea will import 140,000 tons of wheat, 80,000 tons of corn and 35,000 bales of raw cotton on concessional terms.

title: One PCBOil Dumping Defendant Cleared by North Carolina Court
description: HALIFAX, N.C., June 7 (AP) Charges against an officer of a transformer repair concern, accused of conspiring to dump oil containing toxic PCBs on a highway near here, were dropped today in a state court.

title: The City
description: FrameUp Charged In Designer's Death

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: The Fairs Take To the Streets
description: THISwill be a bountiful weekend for compulsive nibblers. More than half a dozen street fairs are scheduled, and with strategy you could eat your way through all of them. Ethnic foods, of course, are only one of the attractions at these trafficfree events.

title: Turnout Reported Light as Voting Begins for European Parliament
description: LONDON, June 7  For the first time, citizens of four countries voted today for members of a European Parliament.

title: Evsents and Openings
description: HAPPY DAYS by Samuel Beckett. Directed by Andre Serban. Starring Irene Worth and George Voskovec. Presented by the New York Shakespeare Festival, Joseph Papp, producer. At the Public/Newman Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, 8.

title: U.S. Warns United Air On Pay, Getty on Prices
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) President Carter's Council on Wage and Price Stability said today that the new labor contract between United Airlines and the International Association of Machinists, which ended an eightweek strike, apparently exceeded voluntary wage limits.

title: Oil Subsidy Review To Begin
description: PARIS, June 7  The United States and other Western industrial countries asked the International Energy Agency today to study spot markets for oil around the world to see if President Carter's controversial $5abanel subsidy on imports of homeheating oil was forcing other nations to pay more for their oil.

title: Now, RollerSkating In From the Old West . . .
description: It was inevitable. The rollerskating craze has met the Western fad and produced cowboyboot roller skates. A California company named Alva Action is marketing them, as well as a line of clothes for skaters, and all of it should be in stores by late summer.

title: John W. Hight, 65, Trade Expert And Former U.S. Aide in Europe
description: John W. Hight, former executive director of the Committee for a National Trade Policy and a former director in the United States Economic Cooperation Administration, died Tuesday at the Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 65 years old.

title: Film: Toy Commandos:A War Movie
description: "ESCAPE to Athena," which opens today at the National, is a war movie that wants to be lighthearted but is only ridiculous, as well as slipshod and dreary. It's a melodrama set in Greece in 1944 about an unlikely pick-up team of commandos who make possible the Allied invasion of the German-occupied country.The list of the members of the team reads like the cast of a Lew Grade co-production, which this is. They are a Greek patriot (Telly Savalas), an English archeologist (David Niven), an Italian Cook (Sonny Buono), a pair of U.S.O. performers (Elliott Gould and Stefanie Powers), an American serviceman (Richard Roundtree) and a Greek madam (Claudia Cardinale). They are eventually joined in their mission by the Nazi commandant (Roger Moore) of the local prisoner-of-war camp, a plot twist that's explained by the fact that the commandant is Austrian.The film was directed by George P. Cosmatos ("The Cassandra Crossing"), a man who has no sense of humor and such a great fondness for shooting scenes from helicopters that you suspect it's he who wants to escape. The action footage is ludicrous.Mr. Niven remains debonair under taxing circumstances and Miss Powers is attractively brassy with nonexistent material. Mr. Gould and Mr. Buono do everything but wear lampshades to liven things up. The other performers are terrible. Mr. Moore is facetious. Mr. Savalas has the smug, self-absorbed manner of someone modeling his own line of men's leisure wear and jewelry. Even the sunny scenery of the island of Rhodes becomes tiresome. One comes out of the dark theater wishing for a little real shade."Escape to Athena," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains some vulgar language.

title: For Bonn's First Lady, a Time of Transition
description: She is met by an entourage when she arrives at the airport, greeted with a barrage of flashbulbs and bouquets as she strides into the hotel, and confronted with a packed schedule of events that commence immediately (despite the fact that on German time, it's the middle of the night).

title: Women Write New Chapter in the Theater
description: Hrotsvitha of Gandersheim, the 10thcentury Benedictine abbess who may have been the first woman playwright since Sappho, apparently wrote largely for her sequestered sisters  verse plays in defense of chastity. For cen. turies, her successors continued to write covertly and with some selfconsciousness. In the last few years, however, women playwrights have become as open, active and outspoken as their male counterparts. They are bringing new life and breadth to the American theater. Examples of this movement can be seen by playgoers this weekend.

title: Sports Briefs
description: NORFOLK, Va., June 7 (AP)  Lee Mazzilli drove in four runs and Bruce Boisclair drove in three tonight as the Mets defeated their International League farm team, the Tidewater Tides, 86, in an exhibition game.

title: Folk Dancers Throw Party in Astoria
description: The Balkan Arts Center is throwing a party with a difference on Saturday, from noon to midnight, at Bohemian Hall and Park in Astoria. There will be ethnic music from Balkan, Scandinavian and Italian communities in the greater New York area at the center's Outdoor Queens Immigrant Ethnic Music and Dance Festival. The Romanian and Serbian Orchestra Bantul will be on hand, as well as the Pontic and PanHellenic Lazaros Papadopoulos Orchestra, Elias Kementzides and the Epirot and PanHellenic Halkias Family Orchestra.

title: Girl Pushed in Front of IND Train
description: A I7yearold flutist and soprano suffered a severed right hand yesterday when, witnesses said, a youth pushed her in front of an oncoming IND subway train at the West 50th Street station.

title: Pope Prays at Auschwitz: Only Peace!
description: OSWIECIM, Poland, June 7  Pope John Paul II, making what he called a pilgrimage to the heart of cruelty and hatred, prayed for peace today from an altar erected over the train tracks that bore millions to their deaths in the Auschwitz concentration camp.

title: Music: Western Wind
description: THE WESTERN WIND, an a cappella vocal sextet formed 10 years ago to sing early music, performs contemporary works, as well. The new pieces were the subject of a retrospective program Wednesday night at the Abraham Goodman House.

title: Carter Criticizes Special Interests
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 In a plea for national unity, President Carter told 2,000 union delegates today that he and the American people were tired of seeing the nation pulled apart by selfishness.

description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Pope Is Embraced by Hometown
description: WADOWICE, Poland, June 7  Zbigniew Silkoski, who sat in the last row in school with him a half century ago, met him on the soccer field this afternoon when his helicopter landed.

description: ART (GR 37014)

title: Takeover By Gannett Complete
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  The Federal Communications Commission gave conditional approval today to the acquisition of the Combined Communications Corporation by the Gannett Company in a $370 million merger, the largest in broadcast history.

title: Increase of Carbon Dioxide in Air Alarms Scientists
description: WASHINGTON, June 8  It is invisible, odorless and poses no immediate threat to human health. Government policies to combat air pollution ignore it completely: But the rapid increase of carbon dioxide in the earth's atmosphere is arousing growing alarm among scientists and environmentalists and could impede this country's efforts to solve its energy problems.

title: Market Slips a Bit In Cautious Trading
description: Stock market traders turned cautious yesterday, with many of the recent big gainers among the oil and gambling issues suffering mild price reversals, as trading slackened after a heavy pace of buying and selling earlier in the week.

title: Strikes in France Drop
description: PARIS, June 8 (AP)  The number of working days lost through strike action in France fell by 14.6 percent last year to 2.1 million from 2.4 million in 1977, according to the Ministry of Labor.

title: Miss Britz Keeps L.P.G.A. Lead by 3 Shots
description: KINGS ISLAND, Ohio, June 8 Jerilyn Britz, a 36yearold former Minneapolis schoolteacher, did not collapse today in the manner some surprise firstround leaders do in major golf tournaments.

title: Cancer Victims, Seeking U.S. Aid, Say ABomb Roles Caused Disease
description: WASHINGTON, June 8  It was late September 1945 when James J. McDaniel, then 24 years old, arrived in Nagasaki, Japan, one of 200 marines quartered in a bombedout waterfront hotel. Mr. McDaniel drove a dump truck as the marines cleaned up the rubble from the moonscape that had once been a city.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Coal Output
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)  Production of bituminous coal in the United States for the week ending June 2 was 13.5 million tons, the National Coal Association estimated today. Production for the corresponding week in 1978 was put at 14.03 million tons.

title: Prohibition Continued On Special Gas Pricing
description: ALBANY, June 8 (AP)  Justice Daniel Prior of the New York State Supreme Court extended a prohibition against last month's emergency state regulation designed to allow gasoline stations to charge by the halfgallon. The regulation has allowed filling stations to post prices of more than $1 a gallon.

title: Confrontation Over Mideast Policies Apparently Taking Shape in Idaho 80 Race for Senate
description: BOISE, Idaho, June 6  Idaho, the state of Famous Potatoes, as it says on the license plates, is an unlikely spot for a confrontation over Middle Eastern politics, but that appears to be just what is shaping up here in next year's race for the United States Senate.

title: A Handshake For Stewards
description: In the gray morning haze, Bud Delp was standing under the maple trees near Barn 13 yesterday while Spectacular Bid was having a sponge bath. When the water trickled down his forehead and into his eyes, the horse squinted and tossed his head in annoyance like any 3yearold having his face washed.

title: Begin, in Firm Control of Party, Gives No Sign of Stepping Down
description: JERUSALEM, June 8  A raucous and emotional convention of the Herut Party, the backbone of the rightwing coalition that has been governing Israel for the last two years, proved this week that Prime Minister Menachem Begin was as firmly in control of his political base as ever.

title: British Post
description: LONDON, June 8 Britain's trading account with the rest of the world plunged to an average deficit of $690 million a month in February, March and April, the Government announced today.

title: OBSER VER Incompleat Consumer
description: Sunday: Got up late and consumed three newspapers, four cups of coffee, two cups of tea, one egg, two strips of bacon, small quantity of cheese and Black Forest ham with mustard, two pieces of veal, eight pieces of asparagus, some lettuce, vinegar, salad oil, one glass of ginger ale, two aspirin tablets, three innings of a televised baseball game, an indeterminate quantity of natural gas and electric power, several gallons of water, onethirtieth of a month's rental space. And so to bed.

title: ISRAELI JETS ATTACK TARGETS IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 8  Israeli Jets attacked Palestinian positions in southern Lebanon today In the first such air action in 16 days.

title: Financial Control Unit Approves Teacher Contract
description: The Financial Control Board unanimously approved New York City's 197880 contract with its 59,000 publicschool teachers yesterday, despite a finding that the agreement could cost $300,000 more than had been originally thought.

title: The Region
description: Extra Aid Approved For Olympic Games

title: JACK P. RUSSELL
description: CLEVELAND, June 8 (UPI) Jack P. Russell, one of the last of the ward leader politicians in the United States, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital of head injuries he suffered in his home Sunday. He was 65 years old.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Mugabe Warns West on Ties
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, June 8 Robert Mugabe, coleader of the guerrilla forces fighting the Zimbabwe Rhodesian Government, said yesterday that any lifting of economic sanctions against the country by the United States and Britain could prolong the war, damage Western standing throughout black Africa and prevent harmonious relations with Washington and London if a fully blackcontrolled government came to power in Salisbury.

title: Sir Norman Hartnell Dead at 78; Dressmaker for Queen Elizabeth
description: Sir Norman Hartnell, , official dressmaker to Queen Elizabeth, died .yesterday in King Edward Hospital at Windsor, England, where he had been taken after a heart attack Wednesday. He was 78. years, old.

title: Arnold Koch, 79, Retired Partner With Law Firm of Wormser, Koch
description: Arnold T. Koch, a retired partner in the New York law firm of Wormser, Koch, Kiely & Alessandroni, died Thursday at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. Mr. Koch, who lived in Delray Beach, Fla., was 79 years old.

title: Swiss Prices Up 0.4%
description: BERN, June 8 (AP)  Consumer prices in Switzerland rose by fourtenths of 1 percent in May and were 2.8 percent higher than in May 1978, the Government said today.

title: RadioDecontrol Static
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The Federal Communications Commission will vote soon on ending 50 years of Governmental control of radio. In a move one former F.C.C. commissioner claims will make the Teapot Dome look like petty larceny, the agency is expected to remove all programming regulations from commercial radio.

title: A Developer of Medical Facilities
description: American Medical Buildings Inc. appears to have found a niche in the health care field by specializing in designing and developing facilities that allow doctors and patients to avoid some of the high costs of hospital treatment.

title: 20% Drop Forecast In Soviet Harvest
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) The Soviet Union's 1979 grain harvest may be around 190 million metric tons, 20 percent less than last year's record output of 237.2 million metric tons, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Guerrillas in Ulster Seize Guards And Destroy Auctioneer's Office
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June (UPI)  Suspected Irish Republican Army guerrillas held security guards at gunpoint while they planted firebombs in an auctioneer's office today. The resulting fires destroyed the building..but caused no iniuries.

title: Inman's 64 Captures Lead in Atlanta Golf
description: ATLANTA, June 8 (AP)  Joe Inman vaulted over 34 players with what he called the ugliest 64 ever shot and took a onestroke lead today after two rounds of the $300,000 Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: Health Spa At Montauk Celebrates Great Indoors
description: MONTAUK, L.I.  Montauk isn't Paris in the rain, London in the fog, or even Manhattan blanketed in the clouds. When the sun takes the day off, and the thermometer is too lazy to climb, it is like a beautiful woman with no place to go  not terribly happy. And not terribly happy is a state of mind that sends shivers up and down the spine of one Nick Monte.

title: Iraq Raises
description: Iraq informed some of its oil customers yesterday that it was raising prices to about $20 a barrel as part of a fundamental change in the way it priced its oil, according to oil company sources in New York. The move could accelerate the already rapid pace at which oil prices have been climbing in recent months, these sources suggested.

title: U.S. Aide Joins Passenger Group
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)  Philip A. Hogue, until yesterday a member of the National Transportation Safety Board, has been hired by the Airline Passengers Association to be its Washington representative.

title: U.S. TO ALLOW CITIES TO DELAY DISMISSALS OF CETA EMPLOYEES
description: WASHINGTON, June 8After months of negotiations, the Labor Department issued regulations today that would let local governments avoid dismissing hundreds of thousands of workers from their federally financed publicservice jobs next Oct. 1 and instead phase them out over a year's time.

title: Deaths
description: HANLONMary E. (Ryan). On Thursday June 7,1979. Of HoHoKus, N.J. Beloved wife of the late Laurence F. Devoted mother of John R., and grandmother of Timothy Hanlon. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30 AM at St. Luke's RC Church, HotioKus. Interment George Washington Memorial Park. Paramus, N.J. Memorial gifts to St. Luke's Church would be apprecfated.

title: Drugs and Weapons Linked to Brink's Plot Suspect
description: Drugs, weapons, burglary., tools and false identification papers were found by Federal agents yesterday in the Manhattan apartment of one of three men charged with plotting a $2 million holdup of a Brink's armored car at La Guardia Airport.

title: Funeral Is Held on Staten Island For Model Killed by Cinder Block
description: A funeral mass was said yesterday for Bridget Manderson, the 25yearold model killed in Queens on Monday by cinder block that the police believe was hurled from the roof of a ninestory apartment house.

title: 15 Held on DrugSelling Charges
description: Thirteen men and two women were arrested in a twoday roundup of alleged ii. licit dealers of the depressant drug methaqualone this week, Federal authorities said yesterday in New York. A

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSBarbara, Devoted wife of Richard. Adored mother of Lynne Paris and Donald. Cherished daughter of Jack G. Kahn. Dear sister of Marilyn Orgel. Services Sunday, 1:15 P.M. at Gufferman's Nassau Memorial Chapel Leo Beach Rd. at Greysterie, Rockville Centre, L.I. Donations to Cancer Care would be appreciated.

title: BUSINESS
description: The Iranian Government took control of the nation's banks, citing what Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan called undesirable and unprofitable conditions in the banking industry. He said management of the banks would be taken over by his Government and no management would be considered acceptable unless approved by the Government. Some 27 banks were involved, more than half with heavy foreign investment. But Chase Manhattan, Citibank and other major American institutions minimized the financial impact of the move on them. [Page 1.]

title: lmamu Baraka Held on Charges Of Assaulting Wife in Village
description: Imamu Baraka, the playwright and political activist, was arrested in Manhattan last night on charges of assaulting his wife and two police officers and of resisting arrest, the police said.

title: Lighthouse School to Give Rock Opera for the Blind
description: The Lighthouse Music School cast will present a new rock opera by Samuel Barab, Little Stories From Tomorrow's Paper, which was written especially for the blind and the visually impaired and will be performed by the school's opera workshop. The Lighthouse Singers, a 35member chorus, will sing excerpts from Tanhaser and The Sound of Music and from works by Randall Thompson.

title: Notes on People
description: When people are confronted with a name like Bettmann Archive, I suppose they automatically think of something that's been around for a century or so, and that's why, often when I meet people, they say I thought you died long ago, said Otto L. Bettmann. I guess the word archive makes me a contemporary of King Tut.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports In The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 26..

title: Two Louisiana Officials Indicted With 11 in 78 VoteBuying Case
description: ALEXANDRIA, La., June 8 (AP) Thirteen more persons, including the  Mayor and City Marshal of Leesville, have been indicted for alleged votebuying.

title: Doctors Restore
description: Renee Katz, the 17yearold flutist and soprano whose right hand was severed Thursday when she was deliberately shoved into the path of a subway train, was reported in good condition at Bellevue Hospital yesterday after an intricate 16hour operation successfully reattached her hand.

title: Books of The Times
description: Oh, what psychology has done to love!

title: Black Mover's
description: WASHINGTON,. June 8  Timothy Person, a St. Louis household goods mover who had applied to become the first black man to hold a national operating license, suffered a setback today when an official of the Interstate Commerce Commission ruled that he should have only an I8state operating authority.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 8, 1979

title: BENJAMIN J. M'KINNEY
description: Benjamin J. McKinney, vice president and director of store and facilities planning and construction services for the J. C. Penney Company Inc., died Thursday in Denver. He was 59 years old and a resident of Mountainside, N.J.

title: N.Y.R.A.
description: AIRMAN'S FLAG, with Cash Asmussen up, winning the eighth race at Belmont yesterday. Evening Boo Boo finished second.

title: Pope Calls on Poles to Set Christian Example, Even at the Risk of Danger
description: NOWY TARG, Poland, June 8  Pope John Paul II, celebrating mass for a vast crowd of southwestern Polish highlanders, urged them today to set a Christian example even if doing so meant risking dancer.

title: About Hicksville
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I., June 5  This is a grim place to think about the harmonica. There are no barefoot boys and dirt back roads left above the hot gray seraglio of suburban expressway, and Oh! Susanna has not yet been set to fastfood lyric, so who's to get excited about the harmonica?

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: How to Prefer Veterans
description: Mrs. Helen Feeney is a Massachusetts woman who tried several times to get a government job and earned top test scores  only to be knocked out by lowerscoring men who were veterans. She finally went to court, charging that laws giving preference in public employment to veterans, cheat women. The case went to the Supreme Court. But to prevail in her lawsuit, Mrs. Fee ney would have had to catch the lawmakers openly confessing that their motive was to hurt women rather than help veterans.

title: Bankers
description: ZURICH  In the face of an almost nightmarish scenario of skyrocketing oil prices, oil supply shortages and climbing inflation, the bankers of Zurich seem surprisingly optimistic.

title: Music: Forms With Sound, Light Modes
description: Connie Beckley, who has a soundandlight installation at the U.S. Custom House at Bowling Green through today, had some bad luck with her performance piece that is associated with it and that was scheduled to be seen last Sunday afternoon. A mechanical malfunction forced a postponement of the performance to late Thursday afternoon, which meant that a considerably smaller audience saw it. Fortunately it will be repeated tomorrow at P.M.

title: Croatian Community Is Upset by Blasts
description: LOS ANGELES, June 8 (UPI)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed yesterday that a joint task force of Federal agents and local policemen had been investigating a series of murders, bombings, incidents of extortion and death threats within the Croatian community in the United States.

title: Value to U.S. Doubted
description: Brazil's decision to convert huge amounts of sugar cane to alcohol for use as auto fuel demonstrates the advantages of a large crop surplus, energy experts said yesterday. But, they added, the idea would be of little value in relieving gasoline shortages here.

title: British Ship With Nuclear Cargo Makes Fuel Stop at Pearl Harbor
description: HONOLULU, June 8 (AP)A Britishowned ship carrying 70 tons of nuclear wastes docked at Pearl Harbor today as attorneys for environmental groups sought a court order to keep her out of Hawaiian waters.

title: Why Render Unto Caesars World?
description: Before New Yorkers decide whether to legalize casino gambling, they should look at the recent behavior of New Jersey's Casino Control Commission, the body that is supposed to regulate gambling in Atlantic City. By granting a temporary license to Caesars World, an international gambling conglomerate, the commission has shown how loose the promises of tight regulation can become.

title: Erik Schoemaker Weds Kathleen F. Kozlowsky
description: The marriage of Kathleen Frances Kozlowsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex S. Koziowsky of East Meadow and Peconic, LA to Erik Christiaan Schoemaker took place at the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. The Rev. Charles J. Mahoney performed the ceremony. The bridegroom, who is president of International Investment Services Inc. in Princeton, N.J., is the son of Otto Schoemaker of Zeist, the Netherlands, and the late Anne Schoemaker:

title: U.S. to Increase
description: The Interior Department, at President Carter's request, will step up the sale of offshore oil leases on the outer continental shelf for the period of March 1980 through February 1985.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Cloudiness Is apparent over most of the Atlantic Coast, through the Ohio , Tennessee and Mississippi Valleys. Heavy cloudiness is visible across the central Rockies and Central Plains States. Clear skies are evident over most of the Pacific Coast, the Pacific Northwest, the western Cascades and most of the Southwest.

title: Bridge:
description: GOSIER, Guadeloupe, June 8 The semifinal stage of the Central American and Caribbean championship. began here this afternoon with Panama battling Jamaica and Venezuela clashing with Mexico. These four teams had survived four days of qualifying play in which 14 countries competed. The winners are expected to represent the zone in the World Team Championship scheduled for Rio de Janeiro in October.

title: U.S. Abandons Hopes of Signing More Accords at Vienna Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 After several weeks of advance talks with Soviet officials, the Carter Administration has virtually ruled out the possibility of signing any agreements except the strategic arms limitation treaty during the Vienna summit meeting.

title: 3 Killed and 7 Hurt in Car Crash
description: Three persons were reported dead and at least seven injured in a multiplecar accident on the Grand Central Parkway at 188th Street in Queens last night shortly after 11 P.M., according to the police. Five of the injured were taken to Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center, and two were taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica.

title: Patents
description: Washing Impurities From Coal

title: Assembly Votes Heart Bill On PoliceFiremen Pensions
description: ALBANY, June 8  The Assembly today passed a twoyear extension of the heart bill, which lets New York City policemen and firemen retire at threequarters pay. If they develop any heart ailment during their employment, on or off the Job.

title: For Herring Fans, a Rare Treat
description: The ship came in this week for fresh herring lovers, but connoisseurs of the fleshy, silken delicacy had best not dawdle on their way to the Grand Central Oyster Bar. Though the season is early, it is likely to be short. For the world's herring supply is ouickly dwindling.

title: U.S. SAYS BOMB DATA WERE IN PUBLIC VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, June 8  The Government acknowledged for the first time today that the concepts it has called basic to the secret of the hydrogen bomb were available to the public for three years at a library in Los Alamos, N.M.

title: HOME OIL COSTS UP IN NEW YORK AREAS
description: MINEOLA, I.I., June 8  Homeowners in the metropolitan area who depend on oil for heating have begun to get increases of almost 60 percent in their monthly budgetplan bills for the fuel they use.

title: Polish Church and State: A Careful Balance
description: CRACOW, Poland, June 8  Poland's Roman Catholic Church and its Communist Government have developed a curious dependence on each other.

title: Raymond Wilkes, 65, A State Court Justice And Excounty Judge
description: Justice Raymond L. Wilkes of State Supreme Court died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 65 years old and lived in Oceanside. L.I.. for 27 years.

title: Spectacular Bid Shoots for a Sweep
description: Angel Cordero and Ron Franklin exchanged apologies yesterday as the countdown for today's 111th Belmont Stakes continued with 10 horses still entered.

title: Group of Theater People Seeking Study of TKTS
description: Rumors that the discount TKTS ticket booth in Duffy Square might be discontinued were denied yesterday.

title: Laws, Not Intentions
description: WASHINGTON  The process of legislation  that is, the technical business of writing laws  is degenerating. In recent years, Congress and the courts have come to assume that the actual words enacted into law, are at most only a starting point for determining what the law means.

title: The Dull 20th Century
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Some people were born in the wrong century. I'm one. I've got the wrong moral fiber, the wrong genes, the wrong philosophy of life, the wrong tastes, the wrong temperament, and the wrong soul,

title: Text of President's Statement on Trade Sanctions Against Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)  Following is the text provided by the White House of President Carter's announcement yesterday that he will retain economic sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia:

title: Civil Liberties Union Stand Cited In Vote Not to Expel Mastropieri
description: The intervention by the New York Civil Liberties Union was credited yesterday as the main reason the City Council did not expel City Councilman Eugene F. Mastropieri, the Queens Democrat who had been found guilty of misrepresentation and conflict of interest.

title: TRUCKS DRAW SHOTS IN 2D DAY OF STRIKE
description: Shots were fired yesterday at trucks that ignored an independent truckers wildcat strike intended to halt commerce on the nation's highways.

title: Higher Coffee Prices Foreseen
description: Do your coffee buying early, a leading commodity analyst said yesterday. And he was not iesting.

title: Yanks in 10, Top Royals, 1110
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 8 Ed Figueroa had the right idea. When he was asked about pitching in this game last Tuesday, he decided he was not going to. He had not pitched since May 19, and he had not been told when he would pitch again. He prefers three days of rest and now he had 19.

title: Pecci and Borg Gain Final, Beating Connors, Gerulaitis
description: PARIS, June 8 Victor Pecci, a tall Paraguayan with an effective serveandvolley game, dashed Jimmy Connors's hope for a French Open title by ousting the secondseeded player, 75, 64. 57. 63. today.

title: Danish Ballet Will Salute Bournonville
description: The Royal Danish Ballet will observe the centennial of the death of the Danish choreographer August Bournonville with an unusual series of allBoumonville programs to be held from Nov. 24 30 at Copenhagen's Royal Theater. Details of the festival were announced yesterday by Henning Kronstam, bal

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, June 8 (AP)  Vietnam has signed an accord with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to allow the orderly departure of emigrants.

title: Well Blows Out Off the Yucatan
description: HOUSTON, June 8 An exploratory oil well off the Yucatan Peninsula blew out last Sunday and has been pouring 30,000 to 45,000 barrels of crude oil a day into the Gulf of Mexico.

title: White House Preparing to Defend Its Rhodesia and Panama Policies
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 The Carter Administration prepared today for a critical struggle with Congress next week to block moves to force the lifting of sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia and to preserve the legislation to carry out the Panama Canal treatv.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 9, 1979

title: Prospering Harvard Class of 69 Still Feels Effect of Radical Years
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8  They were all demonstrably and unarguably still young, even if a few prematurely graying heads here and there in the crowd did raise a vision of impending middle age.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: EUCLID, Ohio, June 8 (Reuters) In another bid by a foreign company to acquire assests in the United States, the Swiss industrial concern, OerlikonBuhrleHolding A.G., has agreed to offer about $52 million to acquire the Motch & Merryweather Machinery Company, Motch announced today.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Carter and MX Missiles: How the Decision Was Made
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 With Secre. tary of Defense Harold Brown sitting on one side and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance on the other, President Carter leaned back in his chair Tuesday night in the White House Cabinet Room and said: I feel confident with this decision.

title: 2,140 Receive Degrees From Baruch College; Shultz Receives Honor
description: George P. Shultz, former Secretary of the Treasury and now president of the Bechtel Corporation, was awarded an honorary Doctor of Science degree yesterday at Bernard M. Baruch College's 11th annual commencement exercises at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum. Degrees were given to 2.140 students.

title: Oil Tankers Collide Without Spill
description: CAPE MAY, N.J., June 8 (AP)  Two tankers carrying more than 1.4 million barrels of oil collided in Delaware Bay yesterday, but there were no injuries and no oil was spilled, the Coast Guard said. The 890foot Liberian tanker Eirama, with 845,000 barrels of Algerian crude, collided with the 892font United States tanker Golden Monarch, carrying 570,000 barrels of fuel oil. The collision carved 50foot gash in the Eirama's hull about 50 feet above the water line, the Coast Guard said, and the Golden Monarch lost about 35 feet of railing.

title: Letter: On Closing City Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Caryl Lee Graham Is Married To Samuel F. Citron, Student
description: Caryl Lee Graham, director of the library at the Charles Stark Draper Laboratory in Cambridge, Mass., was married at the Cambridge Town Hall yesterday to Samuel F. Citron, a senior at Harvard. Justice of the Peace Phyllis McGloughlin performed the ceremony.

title: Jazz Move to Utah Endorsed
description: The National Basketball Association was active from coast to coast yesterday.

title: Kaiser Lifts
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising the price on aluminum ingot, the industry's basic product, by 3 cents, to 63 cents a bound.

title: Northwest Airlines Files Suit
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 8 (AP)  Northwest Airlines has gone to Federal court in an effort to get its fleet of grounded DC10's back into the air. The airline said in papers filed in Washington late yesterday that it was losing $900,000 each day that its fleet of 22 DC10's was idle.

title: GOING OUT Gu1de
description: NEW SHELL With the summer theater season approaching, it os reassuring to find two hits from the past in Off Off Broadway.
