title: Donor and Doctors Disagree Over Alcoholism Unit
description: In 1971, Robert Brinkley Smithers announced a gift of 30,000 shares of International Business Machines stock  worth about $10 millionto Roosevelt Hospital to establish an alcoholism program. At the time, it was the largest single grant to fight alcoholism ever made by any individual or agency, including the Federal Government.

title: Outlook on the Availability of Gas for Weekend
description: Gasoline stations are prohibited from giving special treatment to preferred customers or requiring other purchases to get gasoline, the Federal Department of Energy has warned. It urged any motorist who thought the regulation was being violated to telephone, tollfree, (800) 4249246.

title: Tokyo, Jakarta
description: TOKYO, June 8 (UPI)  Japan and Indonesia agreed today to develop crude oil jointly in areas near Indonesian islands, officials here and in Jakarta said.

title: Bishop Charges Appeasement
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, June 8  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa said today that President Carter's decision to maintain economic sanctions against this country's blackled Government was an appeasement of militant African states and of black voters in the United States.

title: Profit Lid
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)  Federal regulators approved a 17.5 percent profit ceiling today for builders of the Alaska natural gas pipeline project.

title: U.S. May Drop Acres In West From Review As Wilderness Areas
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)  Nearly 113 million acres of land in the West have been proposed for elimination from further consideration as possible wilderness areas, Cecil D. Andrus, the Secretary of the Interior, said today.

title: Anderson of Illinois Joins G.O.P. Presidential Lists
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois officially joined today the national Republican competition for the right to run against President Carter, or some other Democrat, in the 1980 election.

title: Ballet Theater to Close With Tiller in Fields
description: Almost everyone who has seen it has agreed that Antony Tudor's The Tiller in the Fields, which was given its New York premiere by the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 5, is one of the oddest new ballets to have been presented in New York in a long time. Asked about it recently, Mr. Tudor. a choreographer fond of provoking or bedeviling audiences, cheerfully conceded that the ballet's oddities were intentional.

title: Yen Rise Is Aim Of Japan Aide
description: WASHINGTON, June 8  The director of Japan's economic planning agency, Tokusaburo Kosaka, said today that he would be happy to see the yen rise in value by 10 percent and that such an appreciation would help with his country's fight against inflation.

title: Sidewalk Minstrels Move Into the Electronic Age
description: In 4/4 time, Dixieland or tempos best described as improvised, this steetcorner duo performed in the city's financial district yesterday with electronically amplified renditions of old favorites. Notes and chords reverberated from electric guitars in a marriage of modern technology and the minstrel's ancient art. One thing, however, stays the same: the passed hat or open instrument case to receive the tokens of the listeners appreciation.

title: Blasts Rip Sewer Lines
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., June 8 (AP)  A series of explosions triggered by gasoline vapor backed up in sewer lines ripped through several homes in east Independence today, forcing several hundred residents to evacuate temporarily, the police said.

title: Calif. StateFullerton Nine Gains Final With Arkansas
description: OMAHA, June 8 (UPI)  Mickey Palmer collected five singles and Matt Vejar knocked in three runs last night as California StateFullerton defeated Pepperdine, 85, and advanced to the final of the college world series against Arkansas.

title: Mormon Head Reports Naming Thousands of Blacks as Officers
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 8 (AP) Thousands of blacks have become officers in the Mormon Church and have performed previously denied temple rites since becoming eligible for the Mormon priesthood one year ago, according to the church's president, Spencer W. Kimball.

title: 7 Ship Lines,
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 A Federal District Court today ordered seven major international shipping lines and 13 executives charged with price fixing to pay $6.1 million in penalties, the largest criminal fine ever imposed under the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Associatecl Press
description: BRAZIL PLANS TO REPLACE GASOLINE WITH ALCOHOL AS FUEL: Brazilianmade Volkswagens, owned by electric power company in Rio de Janeiro, already run on alcohol derived from sugar cane. Article, page 31.

title: OnePassenger Cabs Leave Long Line
description: Does anyone want to share a ride into Manhattan? Sally Banes called down the line outside the Eastern Air Lines shuttle terminal at La Guardia Airport the other day, where arriving passengers were waiting their turn to climb  generally alone  into taxicabs.

title: 500 Flee Kansas Flood; Many Houses Damaged
description: DORADO, Kan., June 8 (AP)  The Walnut River flooded a twomile section of El Dorado today, forcing the evacuation of 500 residents and causing an estimated $2 million to $3 million in damages.

title: Your Money
description: THE gold market has started breaking records again, raising questions for investors as prices ratchet up. It was in late July 1978 that the price of gold on world bullion markets broke the $200anounce barrier for the first time, bolstered primarily by the bad fortunes of the dollar. Economic experts from Zurich to Brooklyn became fond of noting the apparent difficulty of controlling inflation in the United States. Gold, they proclaimed, offered an inviting escape hatch.

title: Orioles Shut Out Rangers
description: BALTIMORE, June 8 (AP)  Mike Flanagan pitched a fourhitter for his seventh victory and Rich Dauer keyed a threerun fifth inning with a runscoring single tonight as the Baltimore Orioles posted a 30 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: Associated Press
description: PULLED FROM RIVER: Ray Ransey collapsed on the chest of the fireman who rescued him from the swift waters of Iowa River in Marshalltown. Mr. Ransey fell into the water as he tried to retrieve a shoe and was caught in the current.

title: IRAN TAKES CONTROL OF PRIVATE BANKS; EXTENT IS UNCLEAR
description: The Iranian Government has taken control of the nation's private banks, citing what Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan called undesirable and unprofitable conditions in the bankine industry.

title: Disease Center Reports 10 Amish Polio Cases
description: ATLANTA, June 8 (AP)  The Center for Disease Control announced today that 12 cases of poliomyelitis had been reported in the United States as of June 5.

title: Mexican Groups Fight GATT Membership
description: MEXICO CITY, June 6  Leftist economists and conservative businessmen have formed an unusual alliance to oppose the decision by the administration of President Jose Lopez Portillo to negotiate Mexico's entry into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: Stevens Resigns as Director Of American Film Institute
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 8 George Stevens Jr., who has been director of the American Film Institute since the organization was founded in 1967, resigned from his $75,000ayear position yesterday at the institute's board of trustees meeting here. At his suggestion, Mr. Stevens become unsalaried cochairman of the board, an arrangement that had already been agreed to by the chairman, Charlton Heston.

title: Putting an End to ArsonSquad Rivalry
description: New York Citys arson investigation squads have burned up a good deal of energy in recent years because of a childish rivalry between the Fire and Police Departments. District Attorney Gold, for example, recently disclosed that fire marshals had held up a major investigation by refusing to cooperate with the police. Mayor Koch has addressed the problem, but his solution sounds more like a bureaucratic compromise than the nononsense system the city needs.

title: Saudis Held Unlikely
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, June 5 Saudi Arabia's chances of checking a general movement toward a sharp increase in world oil prices are remote, United States and Saudi officials have reiterated here.

title: Ralph Lewis, Publisher of Review
description: Ralph Ferguson Lewis, editor and publisher of The Harvard Business Review, died Thursday in Paris. He was 61 years old and a resident of Cambridge, Mass.

title: Disputes Mar ThirdWorld Talks
description: Special to The New York TimesCOLOMBO, Sri Lanka, June 8 Heated disputes over Egypt and Cambodia broke into the open today at the conference of thirdworld nations here as speakers ignored pleas by the organizers for unity at least in public.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Around the Nation
description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 8 (AP)  A United States District Court judge ruled today that the Department of Health, Education and Welfare could not cut off funds to the University of North Carolina without a hearing on the department's charges of discrimination.

title: Carey Gets Vow Of Federal Help On West Valley
description: ALBANY, June 8  The Federal Energy Secretary, James R. Schlesinger, today formally committed the Department of Energy to bear an unspecified portion of the costs  estimated in the hundreds of millions of dollars  and accept overall management responsibility for cleaning up tons of highly radioactive waste stored at West Valley, N.Y., 30 miles southeast of Buffalo.

title: Niekro Conquers Mets, 50
description: Joe Niekro, the Houston righthander who has been playing a prominent role in keeping the Astros on top of the National League's Western Division, turned in another outstanding performance at Shea Stadium last night.

title: Nicaraguans Bracing for a Prolonged Guerrilla War
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 8 With neither the rebels nor the Government appearing to have a clear military superiority, many Nicaraguans are now bracing themselves for a prolongation of the guerrilla war to oust President Anastasio Somoza Debavle.

title: Idaho Indians Agree to Salmon Fishing Ban
description: BOISE, Idaho, June 8 (AP)  A few Nez Perc Indians dipped their fishing lines into the Rapid River in a symbolic gesture today, but state officials reported no problems enforcing a ban on widespread Indian harvesting of the spring chinook salmon run.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Circus Leopard Kills a Boy of 5 In Jersey Town
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., June 8  A circus leopard chained to stake killed a 5yearold boy last night when he walked within about five feet of the animal.

title: United Press International
description: HOME IS WHERE THE BARGE IS: A trucker who got a lift from a barge yesterday on the Kanawha River near Charleston, W. Va., had the opportunity to watch the countryside slip past as house was being moved to a new location.

title: Nationalized Banks Not Uncommon
description: Government ownership of banks, especially large banks, is not uncommon. In France and Italy, the major banks were nationalized decades ago, although nationalization of banks is more common among the lessdeveloped nations.

title: Unmanned Soviet Craft Links Up With Space Station Manned by 2
description: LONDON, Saturday, June 9 (Reuters)  The unmanned Soviet spacecraft Soyuz 34 has docked with the Salyut 6 orbiting space station manned by two Soviet astronauts, Moscow radio said today.

title: Schmidt Addresses Jewish Group
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, at a meeting with American Jewish Committee leaders, warned yesterday that American failure to ratify the strategicarms treaty could mean a return to the cold war, with harsh effects on the Soviet Union's recently liberalized Jewish emigration policy.

title: Ginnie Mae Trading Curb
description: The Amex Commodities Exchange announced yesterday that it would eliminate the spot month trading in Government National Mortgage Association (Ginnie Mae) futures because there had been only two trades in the contracts since the spot month was added to the board earlier this year.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 23.

title: The City
description: A law creating a Department of Juvenile Justice to oversee the treatment of minors accused of crimes was signed by Mayor Koch.

title: Presumption of Innocence: New High Court Questions
description: Of the millions of arrests made each year across the country, only a tiny fraction result in convictions at trial. Many arrests are dismissed for lack of sufficient evidence or because the transgressions were trivial. Other defendants plead guilty before trial most often to charges less serious than the original ones. Before trial, those defendants who are considered bad risks and are too poor to make bail are placed in jail  even though under law they are presumed to be innocent.

title: Nuclear Industry Begins Study
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 8  The nuclear power industry has begun a $4.8 million effort to study the accident at the power plant at Three Mile Island and to persuade the public that atomic power is safe and necessary. The money includes $3.5 million for the study and $1.3 million for a national public relations campaign.

title: Ronnie Perry Turns Down Initial Offer From Red Sox
description: BOSTON, June 8 (AP)  Ronnie Perry, a baseball and basketball standout with one year remaining at Holy Cross University, turned down the initial contract offer of the Boston Red Sox, who picked him in the 12th round of the baseball draft this week.

title: Tanner, Fleming Gain Beckenham Singles Final
description: BECKENHAM, England, June 8 (AP)  Two Americans, Roscoe Tanner and Peter Fleming, advanced to the Beckenham grass court tennis tournament sineles final today.

title: Nepal Is Nepal, New York Is Tat City
description: People wrote to me before I recently returned home to New York, after two years in Peace Corps, about all the changes I'd find: disco, roller skating, a new mayor, a decent Rangers team.

title: Vietnam's Forces Retrench In Cambodia as Rains Begin
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 8 Vietnamese forces in Cambodia are slowing their operations in the countryside now that the heavy monsoon rains have begun and are concentrating their strength along the main roads and in principal towns, Western analysts reported today.

title: Paul Stewart Slade, WideRanging Photojournalist
description: Paul Stewart Slade, a globetrotting photojournalist whose pictures of world leaders and fastbreaking news events appeared for more than 25 years in American and European magazines, died of a heart attack Thursday in his home at 625 Main Street on Roosevelt Island. He was 47 years old.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Editor Carries on With Second Book Beyond Islandia
description: One of the curiosities of the 1992 publishing season was the publication of posthumous novel by a man who had been a lawyer and a law professor, and who had, as far as was known, never written a line. The novel was Islandia, and the author Austin Tappan Wright. Wright left not only a narrative about his realistically rendered Utopia, but also a history of his fabulous country complete with a geography, a language, a detailed peerage and a bibliography of the literature dealing with it. Over the years, Islandia, which is in a genre related to the imaginative excursions of J.B. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis, has won a loyal if not overly large following.

title: Deaths
description: SLADEPaul. Beloved father of Roger and Larry. Devoted son of Beniamin and Rose. Loving brother of Melvin and Ira. Cherished fiancee of Sheila Kraft. Services Sunday June 10 1:30pm at The Riverside 76 Street &Amsterdam Ave.

title: Peter Donald, Actor; Storyteller Conducted Can You Top This?
description: Peter Donald, the actor, dialectician and toastmaster who was perhaps best known as the storyteller on the radio and television program Can You Top This? died of .cancer of the throat and stomach on April 30 at Broward Memorial Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after an illness of more than a year. He was 60 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: AIRLINE IS CLEARED TO MOVE TWO DC10'S
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)  Under an order grunted to American Airlines today by the Federal Aviation Administration, the two planes whose cracked engine mounts brought on the grounding of all DC10's are to be flown to Tulsa, where they are to undergo further inspection. The planes are now in San Francisco.

title: Program to Test Taxicab Sharing Runs Into Delay
description: New York City's plan to test group cab riding on runs to and from the airports has been stalled by a broad range of unexpected problems.

title: An Invasion of RollerSkaters Fuels Battle of Venice, Onetime Bohemia of the Coast
description: VENICE, CALIF., June 8  Linked hand in hand, 12 swimsuited rollerskaters, a moving phalanx with the seeming inertia of an irresistible force, glided effortlessly along the concrete Venice Strand, forcing pedestrians, a bicyclist and two dogs out of their way.

title: Robert S. Niedeiman; Advertising Executive Was Firm's President
description: Robert S. Niedelman, the president of Waterman, Getz, Niedelman Advertising, died of cancer Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Niedelman, who lived In Manhattan, was 48 years old.

title: Sam Houston Golf Victor
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., June 8 (UPI)  Sam Houston State, paced by the one,two finish of Robert Thompson and Bill McEntire, won the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics golf championship today by 28 strokes over GardnerWebb.

title: Joan Didion: Staking Out California
description: In her new book, "The White Album," Joan Didion writes: "Kilimanjaro belongs to Ernest Hemingway. Oxford, Mississippi, belongs to William Faulkner... a great deal of Honolulu has always belonged for me to James Jones... A place belongs forever to whoever claims it hardest, remembers it most obsessively, wrenches it from itself, shapes it, renders it, loves it so radically that he remakes it in his image."

title: A Showcase for Art
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Army Work Sure Keeps A Man Busy
description: The former Army induction center on Whitehall Street in lower Manhattan  where thousands of raw recruits were injected, inspected, detected and selected  is about to become a racquet club. The Brooklyn Army Terminal  where Fulton's steamboat was built and the keels of America's greatest warships were laid  may soon be sold. Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island  which the Army announced last week that it would close next year. is expected to become part of the Gateway National Park.

title: MUSIC
description: IT looks like I'm back in the music festival business again, said Kenneth Wentworth. The pianist has not been gettink too much time to practice lately because he serves as director of the Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence, and also plans the various study workshops that annually make the Bronxville campus a thriving training center and arts festival.

title: Being a Mother Isn't a Lifetime Job
description: ABIGAIL McCARTHY recently described herself as a displaced homemaker. Admitting her own neglect  . . . I had other things to do, children to bring up, she counseled every woman to get as much education as she can, and become professional in skills along the way, no matter how long she is a homemaker.

title: McGuire Sees Success In Campaign by Police To Recruit Minorities
description: Applauding the success of a $250,000 recruiting drive aimed at minorities and women, Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire announced yesterday that more than 46,500 young people had applied to take the department's June 30 examination for police officer, the first such test in six years.

title: Dawn Bedrick Wed To L.A. Bemheim
description: Dawn Bedrick, daughter of Mrs. Maxine Bedrick of Short Hills, N.J., and Bernard Bedrick of New York, was married yesterday at the Pierre Hotel to L. Andrew Bernheim of Far Hills, N.J. Rabbi Joachim Prinz performed the ceremony.

title: Longwood Gardens: Focus for a Weekend
description: I have recently experieneed what I would formerly have diagnosed as an attack of insanity: that is, I have purchased a farm, wrote Pierre Samuel du Pont in August 1906. Perhaps to prove his sanity, Mr. du Pont transformed his weekend retreat into Longwood Gardens.

title: Baraka's Wife Terms Account Of Her Husband's Arrest a Lie
description: The wife of the poetplaywright Imamu Baraka called the police version of the arrest of her and her husband Friday night in Greenwich Village an absolute lie.

title: Boating Limits Asked
description: FOR sailors, a safe passage ends in a safe harbor. On the North Shore, Lloyd Harbor traditionally has been one of the most popular anchorages. But the Village of Lloyd Harbor now contends that its waters are becoming overcrowded and no longer are safe for overnight rafting, a common practice in which boats are tied together.

title: 1,000 Brave the Rain to Oppose A Nuclear Power Plant in Kansas
description: NEW STRAWN, Kan., June 9 (UPI) Against a backdrop of the reservoir of water intended to cool the Wolf Creek nuclear power plant, 1,000 antinuclear protesters sang, cheered and danced their objections to nuclear fission today.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: AEROSOLtype cans of spray paint are ideal for many small finishing jobs around the house. They are widely used for such chores as painting small pieces of furniture, cabinets, railings, toys, appliances and other oddshaped or hardtopaint small objects because they save time and eliminate brushcleaning problems.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: AEROSOLtype cans of spray paint are ideal for many small finishing jobs around the house. They are widely used for such chores as painting small pieces of furniture, cabinets, railings, toys, appliances and other oddshaped or hardtopaint small objects because they save time and eliminate brushcleaning problems.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IT was a time notable in the General Assembly for life and death. The legislators met for interminable sessions, covering the same ground repeatedly. But the righttodie bill, which would let individuals specify that they did not want to be kept alive by extraordinary measures if terminally ill, broke the calm when it reached the Senate.

title: Why Mt. Kisco Said No to Housing Aid
description: MOUNT KISCO

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: I wasn't at all eager to do this interview. The whole idea of an author pushing his book lacks dignity.

title: Brahms on Disks, From the Requiem To the Ballads
description: There was a time when one had to be either a Wagnerian or a Brahmsian; in the musical polemics of the late 19th century, it was exceedingly difficult to be both. That's long since passed, even ii a veiled swipe at one composer by the partisans of the other can still be occasionally encountered. Certainly as far as the record business is concerned, both men are major figures, to judge from the flow of new disks of works by each that comes forth continually.

title: NONCATHOLICS GAIN ROLE IN PUERTO RICO
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., June 9  Eighty years after Protestantism began proselytizing in Puerto Rico the island remains Roman Catholic in name and probably in spirit, but leaders of the Puerto Rico Evangelical Council have pretty much shed their minority mentality.

title: Cuban Adventures
description: CUBA is an enduring theme in American history. For over a century the United States has been involved for better or worse, usually for worse, in the affairs of the country once known as the everfaithful isle. American Presidents from Grover Cleveland to Jimmy Carter have wrestled with the problem, and one of the brightest, John F. Kennedy, won one fall out of two.

title: Oceanographer Is Making a Voyage of Discovery
description: WHEN Sharon L. Smith's 34th birthday rolls around on Thursday, don't look for her in Yaphank, where she lives, or at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, where she is an assistant oceanographer in the oceanographic sciences division of the department of energy and environment.

title: An Expos of Heaven and Hell
description: DEATH is an education, thinks Jake Greenspahn in the title story of Stanley Elkin's 1973 collection, Criers and Kibitzers, Kibitzers and CriersGreenspahn is a merchant who's lost a son. In another Elkin story, I Look Out For Ed Wolfe, a collection agent is fired from his job for doing his job too well. A lot of people can't do It, his boss says. You take a guy who's already down and bury him deeper. It's heartwringing work. But you, you were amazing. An artist. You had a real thing for the deadbeat soul. Stanley Elkin has always been amazing at taking the guy who's already down and burying him deeper; he has a real thing for the deadbeat soul, indeed; and you better believe that it's heartwringing work.

title: How Ballet Helps Pay for the Opera
description: Last year, the Metropolitan Opera Association, after all fees and outofpocket expenses were paid, netted $1,048,000 from its 17week springsummer dance season. That's right, the Met  whose expenditures for its opera activities and theater upkeep resulted in losses of over $11million during its last fiscal year  actually turned a profit on ballet. That income of course, was applied to the Met's overall deficit, and since, as a result of contributions and grants, the Met ended its fiscal year with a surplus of $575,000, it is obvious that the income from its ballet operations helped keep the institution out of the red ink.

title: Harvard Stuns Yale In Rowing
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., June 9 Harvard's varsity crew, which was supposed to lose to Yale at last, beat the Elis in their annual fourmile race on the Thames River today by a halflength.

title: Debra Grady Wed To Thomas White
description: Debra Jeanne Grady, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Grady Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday morning to Thomas Gregory White, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. White of Springfield, Mass. The Rev. William Donovan performed the ceremony in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ALBERTSON  Paintings by Edna May Young; through June 29; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtovm Rd. For hours, CH 87363.

title: Soviet Assails U.S. on MX Missile
description: MOSCOW, June 9 (AP) The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today that American plans to develop the new mobile MX missile run at variance with the spirit of SALT II.

title: Miracle Plays Are Staged In Glastonbury Abbey Ruins
description: The setting sun silhouettes the ruin of the ancient abbey. In the hush of that moment between day and evening, Everyman, accompanied by Good Deeds, makes his eternal way across the sunlit grass, led to Heaven by Death. In the silence, there is a sudden rush of wings, and two white birds follow the sun's rays, circling over the heads of the players, and are gone . . . So ends the Somerset Miracle Play of Everyman, with the universal theme of death and redemption.

title: ANTIQUES
description: James C. Sorber began 90 years ago to collect wroughtiron hardware and tools produced by 18th and 19thcentury American blacksmiths. And  the carpenter and retired builder now owns one of the largest and more impressive collections of this material, 150 examples of which are on view through Sept. 3 in Art in Wrought Iron at the Brandywine River Museum in Chadds Ford, Pa.

title: Hospital at Annapolis Is Closed
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9 (AP)  The 77yearold hospital at the United States Naval Academy here has closed its doors in an attempt to save $1.7 million a year.

title: Health
description: One sparkling May morning a few years ago, a party boat called the Comet left Point Judith, R.I., carrying a crew of three and 24 passengers who

title: Paddle Tennis Moves Into Spotlight
description: What in the world were Gene Scott and Herb FitzGibbon, former worldclass tennis players, doing in a paddle tennis tournament yesterday?

title: Klan and Blacks March Through Tense Decatur
description: DECATUR, Ala., June 9  Five hundred state and local policemen, armed to cope with a riot, blockaded the streets of this strifetorn town today as some 1,200 black demonstrators paraded past 150 jeering Ku Klux Klansmen brandishing clubs, baseball bats and lead pipes.

title: Funds for Rights Panel Backed
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)  The House passed a bill today that authorizes up to $14 million in appropriations for the Civil Rights Commission in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The vote was 279 to 0. The measure will now go to a conference committee, where differences between Senate and House versions will be worked out.

title: NEWS ANALYSIS
description: TRENTON

title: 2 Pulitzer Prize Winners Among Nieman Fellows
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9 (AP) Two Pulitzer Prize winners are among 12 American journalists awarded the Nieman Fellowships for independent study at Harvard University, the Nieman Foundation has announced.

title: REGULATING THE REGULATORS
description: Charlie Schultze has impeccable liberal credentials. Over the years, the 59yearold, gravellyvoiced economist has advised an array of solidly Democratic candidates, such as Senator Edmund S. Muskie.

title: Rebels Seize Some Managua Slums And Report Gains in Other Battles
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 9 The guerrillabacked uprising to topple Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle spread today to the capital of Managua, with rebels seizing several outlying slums and reportedly Inflicting heavy casualties on the National Guard.

title: Jeanne Mauney Offers Evening of Piano Works
description: Jeanne Mauney, a pianist who recently received a master's degree from Juilliard, was heard Thursday night at the Abraham Goodman House. The program was of the hitparade variety  Bach's Partita in D, Beethoven's Pathetique Sonata, Schumann's Fantasia in C and Debussy's L'Isle Joyeuse.

title: Bean Leads by Five On 11UnderPar 61
description: ATLANTA, June 9 (AP)  Andy Bean, exhibiting the power and finesse that has established him as one of professional golf's young stars, shot an 11underpar 61 and took a fivestroke lead today after three rounds of the $300,000 Atl tante Classic.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Dr. Richard A. Frank's Speaking Personally  A Child Dies [May 13] outrages me. Is this a part of your All the News That's Fit to Print"?

title: Off Season on Vermont's Ski Slopes
description: Contrary to what many skiers think, Vermont does not close in the summer. ??? slopes, most all but tank of gasoline from Northeast population centers, offer sundry amusements, resort facilities and hiking. In the following rundown, package rates are for Friday and Saturday nights or for five days in midweek, and prices are for one person in double occupancy with meals unless otherwise noted.

title: Deaths
description: RUBENS

title: GARDENING
description: SOME New Jersey gardeners have just set out their first rose plants, and there is still time for those who didn't get around to it. Roses in containers can still be set out this week, since midJune is the traditional cutoff point.

title: The Presses Pick Titles
description: AMERICA'S ASCENT: The United States Becomes a Great Power, 18801914, by John M. Dobson. (Northern Illinois University Press. Cloth, $15. Paper, $5.)

title: Catholic Comfort
description: Above all else, the Pope has evoked a sense of unity and solidarity in a church that has been strong in spite of Government restrictions that have made it impossible for its people to feel their corporate power. The Pope's presence produced huge rallies where they could share their faith liturgies, prayers, parades and Polishstyle revival meetings. In his messages, John Paul II cheered them and proudly reminded Catholics of the inextricable tie in Poland between national history and the church. He exhorted them to continue to fight the good fight against Communism. He spoke to those whose plight he so well knows, who stand always at the brink of losing heart in their struggle to eke out an existence and keep a spirit of freedom under repression. By showing how Polish he is, bringing the emotional and theological dimensions to religion, sharing the papacy with them, exuding the openness of the Polish people, the Pope gave the church here the precious, indispensible gift of hope. Rubbing shoulders and pledging allegiance to Catholicism in this extraordinary public way has also demonstrated that the faith is being passed to the younger generation. When we are here, we are so moved, said an elderly woman at the Pope's first mass in Warsaw, because we see the youth singing the songs and what

title: Derek Jacobi Claudius Contemplates Hamlet
description: LONDON

title: EXTENSION EXPECTED ON UNIONDUES RULE
description: ALBANY, June 9  The Legislature is expected to extend a law next week allowing some unions of public employees to collect dues from everyone they represent, whether the workers join the union or not.

title: Colleen Kelly Bride Of Robert J. Lack
description: Colleen Phyllis Kelly and Robert Joel Lack, students at the Harvard Law School and magna cum laude graduates of Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, class of 77, were married yesterday in Snyder, N.Y. The Rev. James J. Browne performed the ceremony in Christ the King Roman Catholic Church.

title: Iris Leslie Wolf Bride on L.I.
description: Iris Leslie Won, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Wolf of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Howard Broomfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Edward Broomfield of Cranston, R.I. Rabbi Julius Goldberg and Cantor Morris Wolk officiated in the Plainview Jewish Center.

title: Stephen F. Price Marries Peggy Upton in Vermont
description: Peggy Elise Upton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Upton of Darien, Conn., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., was married there yesterday to Stephen F. Price. The Rev. Richard Anderson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Chapel of the Snows.

title: Ann Hudson Wed To Edward Niehoff
description: Ann Hudson, a doctoral candidate at the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University, was married yesterday to Edward Ernest Niehoff, a New York lawyer. The ceremony was performed at the First Methodist Church in West Lafayette, Ind., by the Rev. Gerald Jones.

title: Avis Navarro Wed to C.B. Ault
description: In St. James Episcopal Church yesterday, Avis Elizabeth Navarro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Luis Navarro of New York, was married to Courtlandt Bromwell Ault, son of Bromwell Ault Jr. of New York and Mrs. George Gilmer Meredith of Palm Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Hays H. Rockwell, assisted by the Rev. J.M. DonaDuque, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: CHESS
description: One of Paul Morphy's main contributions to theory was his recognition of the principle that to exploit the advantage in closed or semiclosed positions, lines must be opened. He wrote nothing about this strategy, but there are many illustrations of it in his games.

title: Minisink: Dream Or Nightmare?
description: Arthur M. Panzer.

title: NEW TRENDS EXPAND CULTURE OF CANADA
description: CALGARY, Alberta  For decades the Canadian artistic and literary Worlds have been known for their domination by British and American influences. The novelist Hugh MacLennan, a Canadian, once condensed the situation into a bit of sarcasm: Boy meets girl in Winnipeg, and who cares?

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: James Sinclair is one of those serious, singleminded people who has a definite view of where he and the human race are headed. The Western world, he says, is clearly in a transition from private enterprise to some form of socialism. As for Mr. Sinclair personally, his goal is represented in a framed artist's rendering in his Broad Street offices of an imaginary New York skyscraper. Across the top of the building are the words, The James Sinclair Building. On a wall around the pleasantlooking sidewalk area below, where dozens of pedestrians are depicted strolling, are the words James Sinclair Plaza.

title: BREZHNEV SUMMIT FOR AN AILING LEADER
description: It took three years for Jimmy Carter and Leonid I. Breztuiev to agree to meet in Vienna, and three years may have been too long. Brezhnev is now 72 years old. His leadership and power are still unquestioned, but for the Americans at the meet ing, uncertainty about his health, about how long he has to live and about the identity of the man who would succeed him should he suddenly disappear from the scene raise troubling questions about the future of the SovietAmerican relationship.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Bill to grant authority to the President to create an emergency energyconservation program, passed, 77 to 13, June 5.

title: Authors Queries
description: For a guide to songs and a discography of the American musical theater, 1866 to date, I would appreciate hearing from collectors of pertinent theatrical ephemera, sheet music, recordings, catalogues, etc.

title: Toni Allen Kramer And Daniele Bodini Are Married on L.I.
description: Toni Allen Kramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Hamilton Kramer of New York and Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Daniele Damaso Bodini of New York. The ceremony was performed at the Kramer home in Sands Point by Archbishopp Giovanni Cheli, Representative of the Vatican to the United Nations. Mr. Bodini is a son of Mrs. Franco Bodini of Rome and the late Mr. Bodini.

title: Ann C.H. Watson Is Married To Richard Agnew Bresnahan
description: The marriage of Ann Carroll Hemingway Watson to Richard Agnew Bresnahan of Warren, Me., took place yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, Conn. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Stuart Symington of New Canaan, Washington and Camden, Me., and the late Arthur K. Watson, formerly chairman of the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation and Ambassador to France. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bresnahan of North Scituate, Mass. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Capital's New Hot Line on Fraud Has Received 5,000 Calls in 1979
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI)  The General Accounting Office's new hot line for reporting fraud against the Government by its employees has received more than 5,000 calls this year, according to Elmer B. Staats, the Comptroller General.

title: Elizabeth Snyder to Be a Bride
description: Janet L. Snyder of Norwalk, Conn., and Philip N. Snyder of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ellen Snyder, to John Francis Gaynor 3d, son of Mrs. Gaynor Jr. of Hilton Head Island, S.C., and the late Mr. Gaynor.

title: Donna Dufek Bride Of Dean C. Durling
description: Donna Jean Dufek, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Dufek Jr. of Milford, N.J., was married yesterday to Dean Chapman Durling, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton C. Durling of Whitehouse and Mantoloking, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the First Presbyterian Church of Mount Pleasant, N.J., by the Rev. Gerald Scott of the Assembly of God Church in Washington. N.J.

title: Tiny Alpine Gardens Can Be Created In Stone Troughs
description: Alpine plants are so tiny you can have a rock garden in inches of growing space. Imagine such a minigarden on a tiny apartment terrace? Or a raised rock garden that can be tended easily from a wheelchair?

title: The Tragic Hero of Radio Music
description: He made it possible to broadcast music over the airwaves and extended man's reach to outer space. Now he seems destined for oblivion even as the sky fills with his inventions.

title: Ballet: Debut by Renvall In Tudor's Undertow
description: On the eve of its season's closing this weekend, American Ballet Theater presented the young Swedish dancer Johan Renvall in his debut as the hero in Antony Tudor's Undertow and Natalia Makarova in her own debut as the ballerina in Harald Lander's Etudes.

title: Welcome to Monmouth Beach, Where the River Meets the Sea
description: THE first thing you notice is the roar of the ocean  rhythmic, almost hypnotic, irresistible. You step closer until the only thing between you and the primitive power of the sea is a 15foothigh wall of black boulders held together by gray patches of crumbling concrete. Twentyfive years of saltwater soakings have turned it glossy and gritty.

title: Telephone Interviews For Times/CBS Poll Got l, 422 Responses
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from June 3 to June 6 with 1,422 adult men and women around the nation. Of them, 445 said they were Democrats, 482 Republicans and 495 independents.

title: Kimberly Maitland Married To John Petitto in the South
description: Kimberly Irene Maitland, daughter of Joanna C, Maitland of Stamford, Conn., and the late Garry A. Maitland of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday in High Point, N.C., at the home of her uncle and aunt, the Rev. and Mrs. Douglas F. Carty. to John Michael Petitto, son of Mi. and Mrs. Michael Petitto of Rochester. Mr. Carty performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: YOU get from Flin Flon to Port Washington by crossing the Canadian border, and you wind up by paying a toll at the Queens Midtown Tunnel.

title: Shows and Events
description: Today  Waterloo Village Antiques Show, Stanhope (off Route 206, north of Interstate 80). Hours: 10 A.M.6 P.M. Admission: $3.50 (includes admission to the village's grounds and buiildings). For information, call (201) 2623063.

title: Helping Women With Finances
description: WESTPORT

title: News Summary
description: International

title: UNUSUAL PROSPECTS SEEKING PRESIDENCY
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  Duke Stockton says proudly that he is a good public speaker with lots of good ideas. A former schoolteacher in Olympia, Wash., he likes town meetings and he likes people. Such a combination of interest and ability makes him a natural leader, he says and a natural candidate for the Presidency in 1980.

title: A Very Public Papal Challenge To Poland's Rulers
description: What are we going to do with this Polish Pope, this Slavic Pope? asked John Paul II, touching the deep chords of nationalism and religious faith still vibrant in Eastern Europe after decades of Communist rule.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: The twin problems of relatively high inflation and unemployment afflicting the major industrialized countries not only have given further evidence of the fallacy of the tradeoff theory but, more importantly, have provided a clear indication of the inadequacy of singlepronged economic approaches.

title: Now It's Basically Bach for Summer
description: We've been accused of trading on the name of another wellknown New York music festival, quipped conductor Richard Westenburg as he leafed through a brochure for the new Basically Bach festival he and his Musica Sacra chorus will inaugurate tomorrow evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Some people have even gone so far as to call us a Mostly Mozart clone. Yes, I suppose there are certain similarities. Both Basically Bach and Mostly Mozart present summer music  that is, music with a broad appeal, music that is modestly scored. You're not likely to hear Mahler symphonies at either festival.

title: Norfolk Seeks To Lure Center For Cousteau
description: NORFOLK, Va., June 9  Jacques Cousteau Superstar? Not exactly, but heads of state have been welcomed with less fanfare than greeted the ocean explorer here this week.

title: Summer Electric Bills to Rise $2 to $7.50 a Month in New York, Connecticut and Jersey
description: Residential electricity bills, which normally increase in the summer as customem turn on their air conditioners, will be up an extra $2 to $7.50 a month this summer in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut because of the rising price of oil and coal.

title: Charles Morton 3d Weds Dr. Jeanne C. Pfeilsticker
description: Dr. Jeanne Carol Pfeilsticker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Charles Pfeilsticker of Langhorne, Pa., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Charles Alfred Morton 3d, son of Mr. Morton Jr. of Syosset, L.I., and the late Lois Morton. The Rev. Richard A. Bower performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: A Journey to Selfdestruction
description: THEY come in droves to the coastal resort towns of Mexico: young, female, hippy hitchhikers filled with innocent romanticism about the primitive life, looking for experience and a cheap place to crash, single women in their 30's out for a week's worth of good times, older, divorced and widowed women, seeking some respite from loneliness and their own moral standards. They are met,in equal droves, by handsome young Mexican beach boys, gigolos and drug dealers, hungry for whatever can be had for free, filled with desire and contempt for the gringa women who are considered almost entirely in terms of money and sex. The same American woman who abhors machismo at home abandons herself to it eagerly while on vacation, blind to that povertyinduced envy, hostility and violence that are at the heart of her lover's endearments. For a short time, the cult of sex and the beautiful body reigns supreme, sweetened by the illusion that she calls love and that he knows as simply another way to survive. The nature of the entente becomes clear only after she has returned to the familiar safety of home and he has returned to the familiar, though not so safe, poverty that his home.

title: Personal Involvement
description: CRACOW, Poland  For a great number of Poles, the Pope's visit is being felt most deeply on a personal and family level that seems to transcend, in immediate terms, whatever other results it may have.

title: A Tale of Family Camping
description: At some point in his life  generally between the ages of 40 and 50  every man comes to the realization that he will never climb Mount Everest or cross the blue Pacific on a raft. This bit of intelligence, swallowed whole, is sufficient to set off a chain of reactions ranging from an office romance to barbells in the bedroom.

title: YearOld Recall of Ford's Pinto Continues to Stir Deep Controversy
description: DETROIT, June 9  A year after the Federal Government and the Ford Motor Company ended a bitter auto safety dispute with the recall 01 1.5 million Pinto and Bobcat subcompacts, the recall and events surrounding it continue to stir concern and controversy for the company and for government.

title: Cornelia Ann Gildea Is Married
description: The marriage of Cornelia Ann Gildea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Gildea of Brooklyn, to John T. McGuire 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McGuire Jr., also of Brooklyn, took place there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Kenneth Calder, assisted by the Rev. Gerald Lanelier.

title: Abortion Measure Going to the Assembly
description: TRENTON

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Small Is Still Beautiful

title: Youthful Speculators Buying Up Airline Coupons
description: LOS ANGELES, June 9  California newscasters are calling it coupon mania: The action is taking place at Los Angeles International Airport, which has seen two of its terminals transformed recently into something resembling a commodities exchange.

title: State Court, Philosophy, Going on Trial In California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An investigation of the California Supreme Court, with all seven justices under the spotlight, is to begin here tomorrow. As might be expected from the state that brought the nation Earl Warren, Ronald Reagan, Garner Ted Armstrong, Charles Manson, the hula hoop and navel oranges, it is no ordinary investigation.

title: Summer Businesses Are Coping With the Gas Crisis
description: Last week, New York and New Jersey launched a campaign for new Federal gasoline price regulations, to make the rules understandable and, ultimately, to bring prices down. Soaring prices, along with tight gas supplies, could have great effects on the economy during the vacation months. Here is look at the possible impact of the gas squeeze in the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut region this summer.

title: Outside Investment and Inside BeltTightening Help a City Recover
description: YONKERS  Four years ago this Westchester city, the state's fourth largest, was beset with fiscal and economic woes so numerous and serious that it was on the verge of default. Last week, Yonkers added two more to the list of successes it has chalked up in its effort to recover fiscal respectability and economic equilibrium.

title: On Language
description: Potato. Potahto,

title: The Prime of Life
description: Cotton fluff is blowing from the poplar trees on the mountainside. Chokecherries and wild strawberries are in blossom, and a flock of goldfinches has gathered to pick apart the dandelions. The porcupines are on the move, from the ledgy spruce forest where they wintered to juicy fields and toothsome orchards. At night an owl barks at the dog and at dawn the warblers make the woods ring. A grouse is drumming, sounding like someone unsuccessfully cranking an outboard motor.

title: Coastal Wins Belmont
description: Anything can happen in horse racing, they say, and it happened to Spectacular Bid yesterday in the 111th Belmont Stakes. He lost.

title: ...And All Ye Need to Know
description: FINALS are over, grades are posted, and the few students who are mad at me because they didn't do their work have finished their tantrums. It's graduation time, a nice, restful moment, and as I brush the dust from my mortarboard in preparation for commencement, I no longer wonder, as I did in November or March, why I keep on teaching college English; for with the strains of Pomp and Circumstance come the remembrance of things past  and students passed.

title: Le Mans Marshal Injured When Struck by Race Car
description: LE MANS, France, June 9 (AP)  A French track marshal was seriously injured at the Le Mans 24Hour road race tonight when he was hit by a Chevron. Roe driven by Marc Sourd of France, according to race organizers.

title: Last Week, the Rebels Appeared Ready to Make Managua the Next Target
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  In the early 1960's, Nicaragua's Sandinist National Liberation Front was just one of a dozen small guerrilla groups in Latin America modelled after Fidel Castro's successful July 26 Movement. Today, the Sandinist rebets number in the thousands and last week they stepped up a new military offensive against the regime of Anastasio Somoza Debayle that was assuming the proportions of a conventional war.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: If you're a barbershop quartet fan, you can indulge yourself this afternoon while contributing to a good cause. At 2 P.M. at the Brookside School in Allendale, the Ramapo Valley chapter of the Sweet Adelines will present New York, New York, a benefit for a 9yearold Allendale girl with a rare kind of brain tumor.

title: Harry Novik, 69, Headed WLIB,
description: Harry Novik, former president and general manager of the New York City radio station WLIBAM and WLIBFM, died yesterday at his home in Heritage Village, Somers, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Donna Christine Atanasio Wed to Frank A.D. Andrea 3d
description: Donna Christine Atanasio, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Atanasio of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Frank A.D. Andrea 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrea Jr. of Old Brookville, L.I. The ceremony was performed in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I., by Msgr. J. Clement Bennington of Philadelphia.

title: L.C. Hufnagel Jr. Weds Miss Nahas
description: Michele McNally Nahas, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gabriel G. Nahas of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Leon Clement Hufnagel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hufnagel of Clarion Pa. The ceremony was performed in the garden at the Nahas borne by the Rev. Dr. Herbert Leo SteinSchneider, minister to the French Protestant congregation at St. John's Episcopal Church in Lafayette Square in Washington.

title: Labor Dept. Dismisses A Key Black Woman In Personality Dispute
description: Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall has dimissed Harriet R. Michel, the second highest ranking black woman in the Labor Department.

title: Puerto Rico's Fantastic Bay of Fire
description: On a dark velvet night, with the Southern Cross like a tilted kite strung lOw on the horizon, our small boat slapped through a light chop at the,entrance to Phosphorescent Bay, a natural wonder denied to Americans who visit Puerto Rico in the wintertime.

title: Trident Launched Successfully
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 9 (UPI)  A Trident missile was fired from the submerged U.S.S. Francis Scott Key yesterday and raced down range to an impact area in the Atlantic Ocean yesterday in the first successful launching of the Trident from a submarine. Three observation ships  two Navy vessels and a Soviet fishing trawler, witnessed the test. The Trident is America's most advanced undersea nuclear missile.

title: Papal Journey Renews Pride Of U.S. Poles
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 9 The visit of Pope John Paul II to his native Poland has stirred new pride in many of the nation's 10 million PolishAmericans, who are finding their own political, cultural and emotional messages in the televised and written accounts of the trip.

title: Democracy vs. the Town Committee
description: NORWALK

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Shelby Coleman Bride of Edward Rogerson
description: Shelby Tucker Coleman, daughter of Mrs. Tucker Coleman of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and Townsend P. Coleman Jr. of Lake Worth, Fla., was married yesterday to Edward Greenleaf Rogerson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Rogerson 2d of Duxburv. Mass.

title: The Struggle to Stay Human
description: THE social history of blacks in slavery has taken breathtaking leaps during the last decade, and good new books by scholars, black and white, continue to appear. The longdominant view presented slaves as objects of oppression, either docile and broken in spirit or in rebellion against a hopeless existence. The new work, which has arrived at an overwhelming consensus on essentials despite sharp debates over particulars, has, in contrast, presented slave life as a largely successful struggle for spiritual as well as physical survival and has, in particular, established the contours of a politically significant cultural achievement.

title: Mao Zedong, the FickleHearted Helmsman
description: A man in China is usually subjected to the domination of three systems of authority, [political, clan and religious], wrote Mao Zedong in his little Red Book. As for women.. ..they are also dominated by men.

title: Motorist, 29, Is Killed In Brooklyn Stabbing At a Gasoline Station
description: A Manhattan man was stabbed to death last night in a dispute at a Brooklyn gasoline station over one car being too close to the other, a police spokesman said. It was the second such incident in New York in 10 days.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: FOR William and Marion Zollo, the work done by a homeimprovement contractor on their newly purchased 70yearold house in Bloomfield turned into a nightmarish example of Murohv's Law.

title: Italian Parties See European Vote Today as a Test
description: ROME, June 9  Italy's leading political parties, all of which were unhappy with the results of the elections to Parliament last weekend, are looking to the European election tomorrow as a major test and an opportunity to improve their tarnished images at home.

title: Polly Morgan, J.M. Timken Jr. Have Nuptials
description: Polly Morgan, daughter of Mrs. Albert Pratt of Osterville, Mass., and Rear Adm. Henry S. Morgan Jr., U.S.N., retired, of Houston, was married in Osterville yesterday to John Marter Timken Jr., son of Mrs. George Armstrong Ott of Waterford, Conn., and the late Mr. Timken. The Rev. Vincent W. Warner performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: Carter Decision on Rhodesia Sanctions Was Another Setback
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique  Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa has been in office for 10 days as Prime Minister of that curious hybrid, Zimbabwe Rhodesia. The setback he suffered last week, when President Carter announced he would not lift sanctions against Salisbury, followed a quiet diplomatic offensive that began in April after the Bishop won controversial elections to lead to a carefully circumscribed form of black rule. The diplomatic campaign was aimed at obtaining support from black African countries as a prelude to Western recognition. So far, it has been a singular failure.

title: Police Are Pressing Their Search For Assailant in Subway Incident
description: The New York City Police and the Transit Police said yesterday that they were continuing their search for the person who pushed a 17yearold music stu, dent into the path of a subway train last week.

title: A Misguided Growth Policy
description: DURING the last few years, Lakeland Industrial Park Inc. lobbied successfully for a free trade zone in Mount Olive Township, in western Morris County. Such a zone is an area in which goods may be imported and exported without being subject to Customs.

title: GARDENING
description: WE often discover rather late in the planting season that we need additional flowering plants for a container on the patio, for the summer cottage or even for the garden. Three likely candidates are exotics from subtropical climes.

title: 4 L.I. Convictions Set Aside Because of Nonlawyer
description: The state's highest court has ruled that the convictions of four Queens and Nassau County defendants must be set aside because they were represented by someone who was masquerading as a lawyer  even though he apparently did an able job in defending them.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: June 10, 1979/The New York Times Book Review

title: DINING OUT
description: WHEN Felix Protos, a native of Crete, saw a 1714 New Jersey farmhouse in Somerset seven years ago, he decided to convert its many rooms into a restaurant without destroying the original layout.

title: Sen. Schweiker Offers National Health Plan With Rebate Feature
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI)  Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, proposed a national health insurance plan today that calls for large companies to offer employees at least three insurance policies and to give rebates to those who choose less expensive plans.

title: Sea Gets Clean Bill Of Health
description: SANDY HOOK

title: A Tribute to Anders
description: ENGLE WOOD

title: Death Laid to Russian Roulette
description: MILWAUKEE, June 9 (AP)  A 27yearold former Marine was fatally wounded while demonstrating a Russian roulette scene from the movie The Deer Hunter, Douglas Wilke, a companion, told the police. The authorities said they were told that Bruce K. Genke was discussing the film last night and pulled a pistol from under a car seat, aimed it at his head and pulled the trigger, apparently assuming that the pistol was not loaded.

title: ANTIQUES
description: PRINCETON

title: Volpe: Man Behind The L.P.G.A. Rise
description: KINGS ISLAND, Ohio, Julie 9  Ray Volpe could not break 100 in a round of golf when he accepted the Job as commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association four years ago. He did not MOW much about the traditions of golf or the rules of the game, but he did know the L.P.G.A. was a few pennies away from being flat broke and was not one of the main attractions in professional sports.

title: Fleming, Goolagong Win Finals
description: BECKENHAM, England, June 9 (AP)  Peter Fleming defeated Roscoe Tanner, 36, 63, 75, in the final of the first grass tennis tuneup for Wimbledon today.

title: Associated Press
description: FIREMEN CONTROL CALIFORNIA BLAZES AS WINDS SUBSIDE: Firemen battled a wall of flame Friday In Canyon Country near Los Angeles. Over a dozen fires throughout state, some which had burned out of control for week, were brought under control as high winds subsided and temperatures cooled.

title: A Gasoline Oasis
description: TEANECK

title: Carleen Lyden Wed To Stewart Kluss
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday, Carleen Hunter Lyden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Lyden of Grosse Ile, Mich, was married to Stewart Radford Kluss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred M. Kluss of Mamaroneck, N.Y. The Rev. George Zabriskie 2d performed the ceremony.

title: Horace Mann's Noble Experiment Has Knokm Much Trouble in 126 Years
description: Antioch University, where financial tension has been a handmaiden of educational daring since Horace Mann started things going in 1853, seems to have inched back from the brink of disaster again.

title: Robinson Beats Paige On Coast
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 9  James Robinson handed Don Paige his first defeat of the outdoor season today by winning the 800meter run at the Brooks Meet of Champions.

title: GARDENING
description: THE rain has increased one of the region's chief garden problems: excess foliage. Obvious overgrowth of shrubs and trees caused by abundant moisture has created a proliferation of leaves. Everything is dense with greenery. The result: shade and more shade and dampness.

title: Sotheby's Sonnenberg Auction
description: The Benjamin Sonnenberg collection, the largest assemblage of art and antiques from a single owner eVer auctioned by Sotheby Parke Bernet of New York, ended yesterday, totaling $4.7 million, the third highest total for any single collection ever auctioned at that establishment.

title: Blanche Porto, MezzoSoprano
description: Blanche Porto's debut recital last Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall may have looked unpromising. Mrs. Porto is a speech therapist from New Haven with no notable professional musical accomplishments. In addition, she was accompanied by a pianist, David Kraehenbuehl, who played conscientiously but without much flair.

title: Jeff lirael, a Guitarist, Plays Varied Program
description: Jeff Israel, a guitarist who teaches at the 92d Street Y and the Bloomingdale House of Music, made his debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. He was a 1974 graduate of the Mannes College of Music, where he was a student of Leonid Bolotine. He has also studied with Albert Valdes Blain.

title: STAMPS
description: The traditional role of the dog as friend to man is probably most dramatically demonstrated when it serves as the eyes of the blind. The United States is making special acknowledgment to these services of guide dogs with a new commemorative, coming out this Friday at Morristown, N.J.

title: Energy Studies Are Available
description: The major, utility companies in the New York metropolitan area offer a variety of energyauditing services to their customers in an effort to teach them about energy conservation in the home. The pro

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Tom Paine's cottage in New Rochelle has been damaged by water runoff for several years and was inundated with almost a foot of water last January. To be able to raise the tiny wooden landmark at least three feet, the HuguenotThomas Paine Historical Association is throwing a cocktail party fundraiser from 3 to 5 P.M. today at the cottage, 20 Sicard Avenue, off North Avenue.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: While New Jersey politicians beat their collective breasts over the impending closing of Fort Dix, with a little forethought and imagination it does not have to be a total loss. For example, why not convert it into a prototype training center for the New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey areas?

title: Ellen Winer Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Harris Winer of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Ruth Winer, to Steven Louis Galetta, son of Winifred Hanson Galetta and Louis Galetta, both of Brooklyn.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Long Wharf, situated at the Long Wharf complex in Sag Harbor, is stunning in its simplicity. The interior setting  woodpaneled walls, butcherblock tables, sandcolored tile floors and several handsome plants  in no way detracts from the lovely view of the harbor beyond the restaurant's tremendous expanse of plate glass. The waterfront vista is even more striking if your table is on the outside deck, overlooking the yachtfilled marina.

title: Returned Marine Gets Some Notes of Support
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., June 9 (AP)  While Pfc. Robert Garwood waits to find out whether he will face a courtmartial on charges that he deserted and collaborated with the enemy in Vietnam, people who have never met the 33yearold marine are writing sympathetic letters to him.

title: CALENDAR
description: TODAY. Stamford Antiques Fair. Yacht Haven West, Washington Boulevard. 1 to 6 P.M. Take Exit 7 from Connecticut Turnpike. 100 exhibitors.

title: PeanutButter Blues
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J.  I ate peanut butter and jelly sandwishes two meals a day, supplemented by an occasional Milky Way. My immersion coil was broken, so I washed down the sandwiches with tea made from hot tap water. Fortunately, the college where I teach had managed to pay my fare to the convention, where I was to lead a symposium, deliver a paper, and share information  hard to come by otherwise  with my fellow social scientists. Attending these annual meetings is about the only way I can keep up with my field.

title: Patricia C. Florez Is Married
description: Patricia C. Florez, daughter of Carolina E. Florez and the late Dr. Climaco Florez, was married yesterday in St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church in Jackson Heights, Queens, to Francisco E. Jaramillo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Efrain Jaramillo.

title: Rethinking Federal Pay
description: Early in the last decade, Federal workers pushed Congress to pass a law that would bring Federal wages up to the level of private industry. In 1962 Congress obliged. Now the law has come back to haunt the workers, for Government salaries have generally risen above private industry and the principle of comparability has been established.

title: Modern Museum Will Get $17 Million for Air Rights
description: The Museum of Modern Art has arranged to sell its air rights for $17 million to a developer who will construct a 44story apartment tower above the museum building. The sale of the air rights, the culmination of a threeyear effort, will help finance a complex expansion plan by the museum.

title: Women's Rights v. Court: Scorecard Less Than Even
description: WASHINGTON  Advocates of women's rights could hardly be blamed if they were confused last week by two important Supreme Court decisions. Both involved claims of unconstitutional discrimination on the basis of sex, both announced broad constitutional principles, and each appeared, at least on the surface, to contradict the other.

title: Johncock Captures Pole With Trenton Track Mark
description: TRENTON, June 9 (UPI)  Gordon Jotmcock drove a PenskeCosworth to a track record of 172.298 miles an hour at Trenton International Speedway today. He earned the pole position for the opening race in twin 100milers for Indianapolistype cars tomorrow.

title: Urban Trend Brings an Increase in Rats
description: ON a bright spring afternoon Allan Mumford was walking his bike through the sundappled paths of the Bronx River near Scarsdale when he encountered a footlong rat.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Wins French Open
description: PARIS, June 9  Chris Evert Lloyd won her third French open singles title today, breezing to victory over Australia's Wendy Turnbull, 6.2,60.

title: GARDENING
description: THE rain has increased one of the region's chief garden problems: excess foliage. Obvious overgrowth of shrubs and trees caused by abundant moisture has created a proliferation of leaves. Everything is dense with greenery. The result: shade and more shade and dampness.

title: Inverness Will Test 153 Golfers in Open
description: At a United States Open some years ago, two professionals thought a United States Golf Association official looked haggard. You'd be tired, too, one of the players commented, if you'd been up all night waxing greens.

title: Music. Kitchen Offering Experimental Festival
description: The Kitchen's New Music, New York festival of experimental music got under way Friday night with two identical benefit concerts. The program was an interesting one, full of good or at least stimulating music. But only some of it was new, and the composers selected, being wellknown ones, didn't really constitute a preview of the evenings to come (the festival runs nightly through Saturday).

title: Mexico Continues Effort to Save Oil From Well Blowout in the Gulf
description: MEXICO CITY, June 9 (AP)  Mexican workers continued scooping thousands of barrels of oil from the Gulf of Mexico today after a blowout at an offshore test well.

title: 400 Join Rally to Urge Columbia To Dismantle Dormant Reactor
description: About 400 antinuclear protesters launched a community drive yesterday to persuade Columbia University to dismantle its dormant reactor at the Morningside Heights campus.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: AEROSOLtype cans of spray paint are ideal for many small finishing jobs around the house. They are widely used for such chores as painting small pieces of furniture, cabinets, railings, toys, appliances and other oddshaped or hardtopaint small objects because they save time and eliminate brushcleaning problems.

title: A Keeper of the Past
description: INTERSTED in George Washington's correspondence? Curious about what Colonial schoolchildren read in their primers? Would you like to see how local merchants of previous centuries kept their ledgers in simpler times? If you're the kind of buff whose is stirred at the prospect of dipping into history, or simply a curious browser among the artifacts of bygone days, a good place to enjoy such pastimes is at the The Westchester County Historical Society, a treasurehouse of memoirs and memorabilia of the county's past.

title: INVESTING
description: Managing a portfolio for retired people whose total income is directly tied to its success in the marketplace, is perhaps one of she most difficult of all investment challenges. But it is not a venture limited to the elderly; many younger people take on the task of managing their parents's money.

title: Mailbox: On Mets McDonald
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Author's Query
description: For a history of musical instrument makers who lived and worked in New York City before 1900, I would appreciate any pertinent information. I am especially interested in contacting descendants of makers and persons knowledgeable about the 19thcentury musical industry.

title: A Block Party Marks Rebuilding
description: The residents of Brooklyn's Pine Street, who only 15 months ago were left stunned and homeless after a devastating fire, opened the doors of their brandnew houses yesterday for a joyous celebration of the rebirth of their block.

title: Miss Pennoyer Becomes Bride Of Peter Lowe
description: The marriage of Tracy Pennoyer, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at New York University, to Peter Sims Lowe, an associate with Cresap, McCormick & Paget Inc., general management consultants, took place yesterday in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Dan Miner, rector of St. Matthew's, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Very Rev. James Norton, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: A Cheap Shot Turns to Gold
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Plays by Neighbors North and South
description: After playing a week at the Kennedy Center in Washington, seven theater companies (five from Latin America and two from Canada) will arrive in New York on Tuesday to join local Hispanic theaters in a citywide Festival of Theater in the Americas through June 23.

title: Lori Helene Jacobs Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Lori Helene Jacobs to Paul Marshall Buckter has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Jacobs of Flushing, Queens, parents of the bridetobe. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kermit Buckter of Bayside, Queens.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: During the 1850's, bank notes were particularly decorative. There was a running competition on artwork and bank officials sought the most impressive designs. These printings were also difficult for countefeiters to duplicate. The souvenir card to be sold at the meeting of the Society of Paper Money Collectors in Memphis on June 1517 will feature a reproduction of an 1859 pictorial bank note.

title: Mellasenah Morris Plays Brahms Sonata in F Minor
description: Mellasenah Morris, whose New York debut took place last Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a young pianist who has earned bachelor's and master's degrees from the Peabody Conservatory, and is now a doctoral candidate there. She impressed as a wellschooled player, with considerable temperament and style.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: NOBODY has contacted him directly, but Suffolk County Legislator William C. Richards has heard the word through the grapevine: Richards better not get a ticket.

title: Male and Female Created He Them
description: IN the old days, when I was a medical student, if a man wanted to have his penis amputated, my psychology professors said that he suffered from schizophrenia, locked him up in an asylum and threw away the key. Now that I am a professor. my colleagues in psychiatry say that he is a transsexual, my colleagues in urology refashion his penis into a perineal cavity they call a vagina, and Time magazine puts him on its cover and calls him her. Anyone who doubts that this is progress is considered to be ignorant of the discoveries of modern psychiatric sexology, and a political reactionary, a sexual bigot, or something equally unflattering.

title: Executive Memories: My Summer Job
description: The summer job is a rite of passage, a step between the indigency of teenhood and the economic independence of adulthood. For many of the men and women who run major companies today, it was a useful introduction to the world of profits and losses.

title: Commuter Parking Tightens
description: WITH Long Island commuters relying more heavily on the railroad since the gasoline shortage, the frustrations of finding parking spaces for automobiles at stations are becoming more acute, and there appears to be no solution in the near future.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Observer
description: Noting my recent adventure in the musical theater, a Poughkeepsie woman writes to ask, Why didn't Shakespeare ever write a musical, since that's where the big theater bucks seem to lie? Wouldn't Hamlet have run almost as long as Grease if it had been done as a musical?

title: Architecture
description: For close to 100 years, certain architects working in the San Francisco area have been building houses that are modest, straightforward  markedly different from what one expects of the usual architectdesigned home. Rather than celebrating the architect's creative inspirations or the owner's social aspirations, the houses of the socalled Bay Area Style address themselves to simpler needs  the need for a sense of shelter, a place to relax, a retreat from striving as opposed to an architectural paean to it. The results, at first glance, look haphazard, undesigned when compared with more formidable homes. But this apparent simplicity is deceiving; these houses are often stunningly complex. The complications, however, reveal themselves gradually, a layer at a time, and are based not on architectural abstraction but on the pleasure principal

title: Late TV Listings

title: Setting a Price on a House Is a Dilemma for Sellers

I'm an interior decorator and I know real estate around here, Mrs. Lieberman explained. It behooves the seller to set a fair price. I didn't want to waste anybody's time, mine or the buyer's. But it went so fast It probably could have sold for more.

title: Wilkens: His Example Should Rule Coaching

During this time I have had the opportunity of observing the tremendous influence professional basketball has had on the lower strata of the basketball world. There are college, high school and grammar school basketball coaches who at least subconsciously emulate the behavior of some pro coaches.

description: Displaying no respect and absolutely no awe for the team that is atop the National League West, the East's cellardwelling Mets struck early at Shea Stadium yesterday and shut out the Houston Astros, 40.

title: TV VIEW
description: There probably isn't an executive in all of television who would denigrate  at least in public  the value of electronic journalism. The TV news departments may be costly and, with the dramatic exception of CBS's 60 Minutes, the product cannot compete in the rating spheres dominated by a Mork and Mindy or an All in the Family. But the delivery news, in the form of regular daily reports, instant speclais on major breaking stories and occasional documentaries, has become an integral part of the broadcaster's obligation, the quid pro quo for the enormous profits gained from the entertainment schedule. More significantly, purely in terms of corporate interest, news is a key factor in the overall image of a network or station. There was good reason for ABC, when it leapt to the top of the ratings heap, to devote considerable energy and staggering sums of money to the improvement of its news division. As a result, the ABC News operation today is both vastly improved and far more competitive, coming from a poor third in the ratings to a virtual tie with NBC for second place. The image of ABCTV as a whole has been enhanced immeasurably.

title: What Gifts to Give The Bridal Party?
description: A great deal of time and thought goes into the selection of the gifts traditionally presented by the bridal couple to their attendants. While there are no hard and fast rules, the general idea is that it be a lasting memento of the occasion.

Hughes prohibited the jurors from watching last night's ABC program The Shooting of Big Man: Anatomy of a Criminal Case. Judge Hughes acted on a request by Alfredo Parrish, a defense attorney, who contended that seeingthe television program might affect the jurors judgment.

title: The Astros
description: One by one, the Houston Astros emerged from their clubhouse runway and strolled across the dugout's wooden floor toward the bat rack. They wore uniforms that resembled a Texas sunset  horizontal orangered and yellow stripes and a big blue star. Across the backs of their shirts were many unfamiliar names  Puhl, Reynolds, Leonard, Howe, Ashby, Niemann, Sambito. Occasionally a fairly familiar name appeared  Cedeno, Cruz, Cabell, Niekro, Richard, Andujar  but mostly, this is the best baseball team that nobody knows. When most fans think of the National League West, they think of the Cincinnati Reds, the Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Francisco Giants but the Astros are leading the National League West and they deserve to be discovered.
