But it has remained a kind of multinational family. And its favorite son of the moment may be William Forsythe, a 29year.old American dancer turned choreographer, whose Handel Concerti and Orpheus will receive their respective New York premieres June 21 and 25.

title: Success Story
description: THE American relationship with Japan continues to progress on two levels of experience. The first is the confrontation on the trade issue. This has become a running story in the press, and is covered with the same blowbyblow attention normally given in this country to prizefights, Supreme Court decisions and corporate proxy struggles. Successive accusations of pricefixing or protectionism against the Japanese are heavily debated and get a wide hearing, though the Japanese (and their American lawyers) rebut the charges as fast as they are made. Even when Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira visited the United States for his first big policy talk with President Carter, he was not able to get past the business pages of most newspapers, apart from occasional mentions when he gave a million dollars each to the Asia Society and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Although Japan traditionally has been protectionist, most of the speculation in this country about why its economy has flourished misses the mark. The reason for Japan's trade success is still widely given as cheap labor, pricecutting and, more important still, some sort of interlocking conspiracy between government, big business and finance that is called Japan Incorporated. This slogan is quickly becoming our economic equivalent of Stalin's master plan, so beloved of editorialists a

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Saturday  Greater Rockaway Auto Sports Society 55mile T.S.D. rally; start at The Livingston Mall parking lot, junction of Eisenhower Parkway and South Orange Avenue, Livingston, N.J. Free novice school at 6:30 P.M.: registration 7; first car off 7:31. Gasoline available. Information: Patricia or Atwell Haines (201) 584 1643.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Two projects that were specially commissioned for the Museum of Modern Art's recent exhibition on Transformations in Modern Architecture, but were not shown with it, are now on display in the Goodwin Galleries of the museum (11 West 53d Street), and will remain there through July 15. Both designs, one by Roger Ferri and the other by Allan Greenberg, deal with public space. They also demonstrate what the museum calls alternate approaches to architecture, a polite way indicating that the two schemes are so unlike that they might have come from different ages or planets.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: It has been the Anthony Dowell season in ballet this spring. No one is saying there were no great performances from other dancers. But the lasting impact has come from the very special moments this British ballet star has consistently offered in his first extended New York season with American Ballet Theater. With the end of Ballet Theater's engagement at the Metropolitan Opera this weekend, Mr. Dowell will tour the United States and Canada this month with the Royal Ballet, the company that raised and formed him.

title: Yale University Press Prepares for the 80's
description: ITS floorboards creak majestically. Its boardroom is hung with its own purple, gold and white flag. Its great fantopped windows stare out imperturbably at Temple Street, as they have for seven decades. In some ways, Yale University Press's venerable building seems as splendid, serene and immutable as those other New Haven academic landmarks the towering Sterling Memorial Library and the stately headquarters of Skull and Bones.

title: Outer Space and Inner Space
description: CARL SAGAN Is the most effective and popular advocate of the wonders of science in the United States. Unlike Barry Commoner and other prophets of doom, Professor Sagan has an optimistic message to communicate: he offers interestine facts about the nature of man and the hope of an exciting future. His enthusiasm for the pleasure of discovery is contagious. The philosophy that appears guide him in his work is stated in the second chapter Broca's Brain": We are an intelligent species and the use of our intelligence quite properly gives us pleasure. In this respect the brain is like a muscle. When it is in use we feel very good. Understanding is joyous. These remarks express a set of values in which reason and intelligent curiosity stand very high.

title: Bonvvit's Redux
description: There is in midtown Manhattan a Golden Core of the most expensive, most soughtafter retail and office space in the world. It is under the constant scrutiny of owners, brokers, lawyers and promoters who are as sensitive to change as a flock of sparrows lined up on a branch. The branch was shaken recently by the closing of Bon. wit Teller's flagship store after 49 years on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street; there was also a tremor over lagging rentals four blocks to the south in the new Pahlavi Foundation skyscraper built by officials of the deposed government of the Shah of Iran.

title: Mr. Begin's Fear, Mr. Eban's Hope
description: There can be only one reasonable explanation for the daily Israeli provocations of the West Bank Palestinians. It must be dawning on Prime Minister Begin that his peace with Egypt gave the Palestinians far more than he intended. Only the fear of a ghastly mistake could cause an Israeli leader to want to validate the worst Arab charges against him.

title: N.F.L and Pass Protection
description: In a game against Denver last season Dan Fouts, quarterback of the San Diego Chargers, had just sent a forward pass on its way when Barney Chavous, the Bronco defensive end. hit Fouts hard in the back after charging from the blind side. Chavous stnick Fouts With his helmet, a blow defined in pro football as spearing. Fouts, more durable than most quarterbacks, went down hard, but he soon arose and managed to finish the contest, although in considerable pain. Chavous's hit went unpenalized.

title: Leigh Carol Nelson Married To 2d Lieut. Keith K. Wilson
description: Leigh Carol Nelson and Second Lieut. Keith Kenneth Wilson, U.S.A., were married yesterday in Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Christopher L. Webber performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Difficult Friends
description: SCHOLARLY quarrels tend to farce. Vanities and passions that have been simmering in the library burst out and the adversaries emerge to pelt each other with dictionaries; but the comedy becomes sad Wnen, as in the quarrel between Edmund Wilson and Vladimir Nabokov, it leads to the cooling of years of close friendship between parties who know they cannot do without each other. Both men put Literature before any other Cause, both were linguists, both admired each other's work, both had reason for gratitude to each other and, before the quarrel, enjoyed each other's pugnacity. It is ironical that their common passion for the genius of Pushkin became the eventual cause of the flareup of their tempers when Wilson's searing review of Nabokov's fourvolume annotated translation of Eiigene Onegin appeared in The New York Review of Books in 1965. Six years after the public quarrel, when Nabokov reread the whole batth of their correspondence, he wrote to Wilson of the thrills of their friendship and said, Please believe that I have long ceased to bear you a grudge for your incomprehensible uncomprehension of Pushkin's and Nabokov's Onegin. And in Wilson's reminiscences, Upstate, published in 1972, Wilson speaks.of Nabokov's fortitude of character and talent.

title: Debate Over Volunteer Military Fueled by Registration Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  Six years after the end of the draft, a major new debate is beginning in Congress and within the defense establishment about the future of the allvolunteer Army.

description: WASHINGTON, June 9 The suspense about United States policy on Zimbabwe Rhodesia ended for President Carter's top advisers Wednesday morning at 7:30 when he walked into the Cabinet Room and revealed his decision not to lift the economic sanctions. It is the right thing to do, he said.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 9 (AP) Thai soldiers have sent more tham 16,000 refugees back into Cambodia during the last two days, according to refugee sources here.

This flatfish, regarded as a prime table fish, is reported in good numbers in the bays and rivers, as well as within a halfmile of the beaches.

title: Five Novels
description: The publisher calls this fictional version of the interlocking lives of Robert F. Kennedy and James R. Hoffa a documentary novel. However, there was no documentation offered as authority in my copy. Had the authors consulted the Guinness Book of World Records, they would have known that J. Pierpont Morgan could not have sat with Tom Thumb perched on his lap in the Senate Caucus Room in 1933, because Tom Thumb died in 1883. (It was another little person, and a lady at that.) Nor was the late Joseph P. Kennedy popularly known as the Wolf of Wall Street. That title belongs to Jesse Livermore, another improper Bostonian. Small errors make one suspicious of the larger statements in a novel that purports to deal with real and historic events.

description: COLD SPRING HARBOR

title: TOXIC WASTE FUND SOUGHT IN CONGRESS
description: With thousands of abandoned chemical dumps threatening homes and water supplies across the country, and occasional oil and chemical spills that must be cleaned up quickly and paid for, the Environmental Protection Agency and two New York Congressmen have drawn up bills that include a new concept, for dealing with environmental problems that they call the superfuod.

title: SOUTHERN BAPTISTS DIVIDED OVER BIBLE
description: The largest Protestant denomination in the United States, the 13 millionmember Southern Baptist Convention, is bracing for a public struggle over biblical accuracy at its annual convention in Houston June 1214.

title: Timing Is Essentially Political in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 9  Timing seems to be the underlying theme in recent political developments in California.

title: Miss Burns Has a Bridal
description: Chandler Knight Burns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Shelly Burns of Saunderstown, R.I., was married yesterday to Philip Lanier Ross, son of Mrs. Karl Beckwith Smith of Jamestown, R.I., and W. Ogden Ross of New Haven and Newport, R.I. The Rev. John B. Lewis performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. John the Divine in Saunderstown.

title: Hawks Appoint Johnston Coach
description: CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) Eddie Johnston has been signed for one year to coach the Chicago Black Hawl& next season and there is a chance that Bobby Hull will be playing for him, the National Hockey League club says.

title: An Ounce of Prevention For State's Human Services
description: THE citizens of Connecticut have, for too long, been excluded from debates on issues that have profound impact on their social wellbeing. One such debate concerns whether our human services should continue to be organized in a predominantly reactive, crisisonented manner, or whether there should be an increased emphasis on services that actively promote the sound development of the children, families and adults of the state. I believe that the time has come to think preventively about psychological and emotional difficulties and to seek to eliminate clearly avoidable human distress.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: For all those who want to know when the lights will go out, and why...

title: Marybeth N. Boyle, Geoffrey S. Stewart To Wed on July 28
description: Dr. and Mrs. Clifford H. Boyle of Westwood, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marybeth Norton Boyle, to Geoffrey S. Stewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon D. Stewart of Louisville, Ky,

title: Fashion
description: Out in Venice, they do it on roller skates. In Los Angeles, in spite of the gas situation, they hop in their cars and drive to their favorite shops, wherever they may be sprawled in the sprawling city. And in between, besides taking care of the daily chores, everyone must exercise, jog, sun, swim, diet, take vitamins and count calories. For this is the land of the beautiful bodies, where every man, woman and child seems to have a good taut physique and sunkissed skin.

title: Carter Game Plan Gets Mixed Signal
description: One month's number does not a trend make, but Administration economists, after a winter of discontenting inflation reports, seized upon May's producer price index as the first breath of spring.

title: New Fires Erupt on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 9 (UPI)  New brush fires erupted today in the southern part of California. In the Hollywood Hills, an expensive home and an apartment building were damaged in the path of brush fire that was held to half an acre. In san Diego County, a 250acre tire burned several farm shacks and threatened some homes along Pepper Drive, and in the Valley Center area, a blaze charred charred 200 acres of brushland, damaging an avocado grove.

title: Summer for City Children on Fresh Air Fund Farm
description: All winter long, Sugar and Babe have been the only residents of the model farm at the Fresh Air Fund's Sharpe Reservation in Fishkill, N.Y. But soon the two oxen will be joined by pigs, cows, rabbits, sheep and chickens borrowed from neighboring farmers and by 2,500 city children who will spend time this summer at one of the fund's camps on the reservation.

title: Of Special Interest
description: On Tuesday evening the Metropolitan Opera moves. out under the stars again. The company's 13th season of free opera concert performances in the city parks gets underway in Central Park's Sheep Meadow with Verdi's Aida, with the Yugoslavian soprano Ljiljana MolnarTalajic in the title role, and Mignon Dunn, Guy Chauvet, Cornell MacNeil and Jerome Hines featured. Michelangelo Vetri will be making his parks debut as conductor. Thereafter, the company will bring Aida and La Traviata to the other boroughs for seven performances during June. (See Music)

title: At Home: The Store That Is No More
description: ASTORE in our town failed, and my wife and I were shocked and saddened. The signs in the store's windows announcing a bank sale affected us like handwriting on the wall.

title: Shortage of Commuter Parking Worries Officials on Long Island
description: With Long Island commuters relying more heavily on the railroad since the gasoline shortage, the frustrations of finding parking spaces for automobiles at stations are becoming more acute, and there appears to be no solution in the near future.

title: Editors Choice
description: A BEND IN THE RIVER, by V. S. Naipaul. (Knopf, $8.95.) The ordeals and absurdities of living in a new third world country, precisely observed by a toughspirited novelist.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 Porsches Trail Mirage at Le Mans
description: LE MANS, France, June 9 (AP) An Americanentered Mirage Ford, driven by Derek Bell and David Hobbs of Britain, took the lead in the Le Mans 24hour road race tonight as the favored Porsches encountered trouble.

title: Karen Quinn Is Married To Michael J. Regan Jr.
description: Karen Anne Quinn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Leigh Quinn of Winchester, Mass., was married thergyesterday to Michael J. Regan Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Regari of Scotch Plains, N. J. The Rev. Frank Sullivan, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Turkey Seeks LongTerm U.S. Aid
description: ANKARA, Turkey, June 9  Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit says that Turkey wants longterm aid from the United States, in an amount that American officials put at $1 billion a year, to revive the country's ailing economy and enable it to play its role in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: SEVERAL years ago, my wife, a nurse, cared for a young paraplegic, whom I'll call Leona, through her recovery after an operation. The operation was a success  that is, it alleviated Leona's pain, although it did nothing to fundamentally alter her condition  and she has since resumed her earlier life.

title: The Dawn of the Disco Disk
description: The popularity of disco music has spawned the first major change in record formats since the introduction of the 7inch diameter (45 rpm) single disk over 30 years ago. Record stores are now featuring 12inch disco disks, the size of longplaying albums, that carry just one song per side.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless .otherwise indicated.

title: OPEN SEASON ON OPEN GOVERNMENT
description: Last August, a convicted loan shark and confessed killer involved in organized crime was testifying before the United States Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations. Question ing turned to the Freedom of Information Act, and the witness boasted that files he had obtained through the F.O.I.A. while he was in prison had enabled him to identify the informant who had been responsible for jailing friend.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: The novelist John Nichols, who wrote The Sterile Cuckoo, settled in Taos, N.M., eight years ago. A few years later he met the photographer William Davis, and together they have assembled a handsome book that records in words and 65 fine color photographs their great love of the landscape, the mountains, river, mesa, forest and desert that make up the Taos Valley of Northern New Mexico.

title: Music Notes; Honoring Respighi
description: This is the week when the 34th annual Caramoor Festival opens in Katonah and the fifth annual Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence open in Bronxville. The two events are quite different in purpose and nature, perhaps as far apart as they are geographically, with Katonah in northern Westchester and Brommille in the southern part of the county. But they are both individual and attempt to be creative. As Kenneth Wentworth, who masterminds the college series, says: In trying to develop a major arts festival for people in the North Bronx, Yonkers and White Mins, we are doing our own things on the campus. We do not want to be another stop on the theater and concert circuit for packaged culture. We want to offer quality at moderate prices.

title: Andrea Lynne Ruffi Wed To William H. Sanders
description: Andrea Lyrme Ruffi and William Henry Sanders, who own and operate tobacco and livestock farm in Cynthiana, Ky., were married yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church in Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Hal S. Daniell Jr. and the Rev. Gordon Bechtel performed the ceremony.

title: Living Fossil Is Coming Ashore
description: TONIGHT, as the fulr moon rises, instinct will stir hundreds upon hundreds of horseshoe crabs to come ashore on Long Island beaches and lay their eggs. These living fossils mate once a year during the moon tides, or highest tides, in June.

title: Notes: FarRanging Tours for Summer
description: By JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT

title: Author's Query
description: For a study of Hans Kindler, cellist, founder and conductor of the National Symphony, I would be grateful for letters, memorabilia or recollections of encounters with the maestro.

title: Problems of Suffolk Sewer District Threaten to Mar Republican Unity
description: What should be a routine renomination and reaffirmation of support of the highestranking Republican public official in Suffolk County tomorrow evening instead looms as a politically embarrassing affair in which Republican disunity and disarray will be out in public.

title: Clans to Gather in Nova Scotia
description: For the first time the International Gathering of the Clans is being held outside Scotland. The series of festivals, Scottish games, Highland dancing, sheep dog trials, bagpipe competitions and celebrations of Scottish culture begins on June 28 in Halifax, Nova Scotia, and continues throughout the Canadian province until Aug. 12.

title: Quiet Islands of Birds, Fish and Shells
description: We will be landing at Mahe in a few minutes. Enjoy your stay in the Seychelles, announced the British Airways flight attendant. I had been planning a trip to Kenya when I consulted a map and realized that the Seychelles were only three hours by air from Nairobi; I had heard that the islands were among the world's most beautiful and least spoiled, and that the snorkelingand shells there were unsurpassed.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Heavy institutional buying last week enabled the stock market to register a strong advance despite Wall Street's concern over gasoline shortages and inflation.

title: Virginia L. McCray Wed To John McLeod Powers
description: Virginia Lee McCray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Winn McCray Jr. of Virginia Beach, Va. was married last evening to John McLeod, Powers, who is with the architectural firm of Stockton, Whatley, Davin & Company in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Civiletti May Suggest That Mild Marijuana Be Made Legal in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) Deputy Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti has suggested that it might be best to legalize mild forms of marijuana, because with so many Americans smoking it they are in effect supporting an enormous hoodlum drug society.

title: What's Doing in SULLIVAN COUNTY
description: BACK TO NATURE  In this summer of gasoline shortages, the Sullivan County Catskills, traditionally known to New Yorkers as the mountains, may well become the place you can get to. Because of their ready accessibility  a tankful of gas from most cities in the Northeast and two hours by car from Manhattan  the southern Catskills are expecting a minor tourist boom, and hoteliers are acting as catalysts by offering to guarantee gasoline for guests who need fuel for the trip home.

title: JOAN DIDION: STAKING OUT CALIFORNIA
description: In her new book, The White Album, Joan Didion writes: Kilimanjaro belongs to Ernest Hemingway. Oxford, Mississippi, belongs to William Faulkner ... a great deal of Honolulu has always belonged for me to James Jones. . . . A place belongs for ever to whoever claims it hardest, remembers it most obsessively, wrenches it from itself, shapes it, renders it, loves it so radically that he remakes it in his image.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Last May 22, David L. Turosak of Richmond, Va., dreamed that a piece of Skylab about the size of a Volkswagen would fall on the vacant lot next to his house at 1107 Grove Avenue. His impression is that there will be a bright reddishorange glow when it lands and he is so certain that no one will be hurt that he is thinking of selling $5 tickets for dropzone seats and all the beer you can drink.

title: Parking Data in Error; City Pledges Leniency On Fines for Motorists
description: Based on inforniation supplied by the city's Sanitation Department, The New York Times reported incorrectly on Friday that alternatesideof thestreet parking regulations would be suspended in all boroughs yesterday because of trashremoval problems during the tugboat strike.

title: The Musicals That Flopped A Postmortem
description: It seems as though the bottom fell out of the Broadway musical this past season. To be sure, They're Playing Our Song, Eubie, Whoopie and Sweeney Todd are doing good business nowadays, but none of them  not even Sweeney Todd with its freshly won satchel of Tonys  can be classified as a super smash. The last one of those was Annie, which opened on April 21, 1977. The big hit before that was A Chorus Line. Not in recent memory have there been so many musical flops and such staggering financial losses as this season, which more or less of fi cially wound up on May 31 when I Remember Mama (with Liv Ullmarin making her musical debut) drew sighs and snorts from the majority of the firstnighters. Altogether there have been no fewer than 11 turkeys, representing a loss of almost $13 million. These flops include Alice (estimated loss: $1.05 million), King of Hearts (estimated loss: $1.5 million), Platinum (estimated loss: $1.25 million), A Broadway Musical (estimated loss: $1.1 million) Oh, Kay! (estimated loss: $1.2 million), Back Country (estimated loss: $500,000), The Grand Tour (estimated loss: $1.3 million), Carmelina (estimated loss: $1.1 million), Home Again, Home Again (estimated loss: $1.25 million), The Utter Glory of Morrissey Hall (estimated loss: $600,000), and Ballroom (estimated loss: $2

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Best known of all fairy tales, the Cinderella story originated in the Orient  which is not surprising in light of the ancient penchant there for women with small feet.

title: Carter Stands on Rhodesia Sanctions
description: To a Senate deeply skeptical about the new strategic weapons agreement with the Russians, President Carter offered a nuclear sweetener last week  the official goahead for the $30 bilnon MX intercontinental missile. But to a Senate even more hostile to another Administration foreign policy keeping economic sanctions on Rhodesia he promised nothing but a fight.

title: Lively Cast Not in Awe of Shaw
description: PORT JEFFERSON

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: ART

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Clouds extend In a band from New England across the central and lower lake region. Heavy cloudiness covers the intermountain region, the Northern and Central Plains States and the Colorado Plateau. Mostly clear skies are apparent In the South Atlantic States, the Texas Gulf Coast, and the western half of the country.

title: ART VIEW
description: LONDON

title: Chain Stores: Musical Chairs in the Executive Suite
description: A job at the top in retailing these days is starting to look as transitory as coaching professional baseball. To wit:

title: U.S. Olympic Prospects To Be Aided by Computer
description: Computer technology will come to the aid of America's future Olympic athletes. Colonel F. Donald Miller, the executive director of the U.S. Olympic Committee, announced the donation from Data General Corporation of the first computer designed to help athletes in training for all future international competition.

title: PAPERBACK TALE
description: Long Weekend in Tinseltown. It's an experience eagerly awaited by people from all corners of the book world. Late each spring, publishers, editors, agents and writers join booksellers at the convention of the American Booksellers Association to see old acquaintances, to exchange gossip and ideas, to sell each other services and wares.

title: 2 Men Die in Crash of Jet Fighter On Takeoff at Niagara Falls Base
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 9 (AP)  An F101 Air National Guard fighter plane crashed in flames today while taking off from the Niagara Falls air base, killing both men aboard.

title: POLISH AUTHORITIES
description: MOGILA, Poland, June 9  Pope John Paul II, barred by the authorities from the town of Nowa Huta where he achieved his greatest triumph as a Cardinal, visited this neighboring suburb today and Implicitly condemned Poland's leaders for treating humans merely as a means of production.

title: Deaths
description: BRODY

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THERE has been a persistent rumor in aviation circles in the county that the New York Air National Guard unit at Westchester County Airport is going to pull out and move somewhere else. Lieut. Col. Marvin Shiro, director of public affairs of the New York State Division of Military and Naval Affairs in Albany, Guard spokesman, neither denies nor confirms the report. Being a military organization, he says, noncommittally, we're always planning.

title: The State and the Arts
description: ALTHOUGH Cuba since the revolution has retained an importance for Latin American intellectuals out of all proportion to its size, it has been isolated culturally as well as economically for much of the past two decades, and the international flow of writers and their works has been limited. Hemispnerle blockade, foreignexchange constraints and ideological concerns have meant that few Cuban writers travel abroad and few foreign books can be bought in Havana, although the work of some foreign authors is available, generally in unauthorized Cuban editions.

title: Subways to Heaven
description: The Rev. William B. Gray, director of communications for Trinity Church, is interested in energy, he says, and so the existential leap between death and the gasoline shortage was easy enough to make.

title: Military Rebels in Ghana Delay Return to Civil Rule
description: KOTOKA, Ghana, june 8  The junior officers who seized power in Ghana on Monday have decided to delay by three months the return to civilian rule scheduled for July 1, according to the Ghana radio. But the announcement said the elections to choose the government would go ahead as planned June 18.

title: Side Trips to Museums and a Colonial Town
description: Longwood Gardens, though spectacular, are merely one of the extraordinary places to visit during a trip to chateau country in the Brandywine Valley. Here are just a few of the important places that are tucked into the rolling countryside near Wilmington.

title: LivePerformance Opera Legal and Otherwise
description: Live opera recordings, performances taped in the house and circulated on disks, are flourishing these days, and what used to be underthecounter items are now seen out in the open everywhere  many of them are even officially listed in the Schwann Record Catalogue and reviews are being solicited in consumer publications. A few of these albums, like those from the Metropolitan Opera, have been legally cleared for release and serve a beneficial purpose for both the company and record collectors. Others, like a recent Vox release of a Carmen from La Scala, have a distinctly suspicious look about them, as we shall soon see. But first the good news.

title: U.N. Development Program Unit, Once in Deficit, Now Flourishing
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9 The United Nations Development Program, which three years ago was near bankruptcy, now is aiming to carry out a $6.7 billion fiveyear aid program beginning in 1982.

title: I'm Always Ready to Lose
description: Hung on the rail around the Belmont Park walking ring was a handlettered salute to Spectacular Bid's jockey. Ron Franklin, the sign read, is spectacular. Horse players were jammed eight or 10 rows deep around the paddock as the field for the Belmont Stakes paraded, but there must have been at least one fight fan among them. Franklin will whip your tail, he cried as  Angel Cordero, the jockey who moonlights as Franklin's sparring partner, was hoisted aboarc. General Assembly.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: WASHINGTON

title: Troubled Water
description: It's as if the government had investigated apple pie and found it short of apples. The Poland Spring Corporation of Las Vegas, Nev., bottlers of Poland Spring natural spring water, is fending off allegations that its water is little better than the stuff that comes out of the tap. That is a troubling charge for a small company whose annual sales have jumped from a quartermillion dollars a few years ago to over $2 million last year and perhaps over $6 million this year.

title: Weddings: Inventive Invitations
description: Some couples are content to settle for a Loveland, Colo., or Bridal Veil, Ore., postmark.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Does it matter that Mozart wrote vulgar letters his wife, that Beethoven drove his nephew to attempt suicide, or that Wagner was a deadbeat? Obviously most of us think so, or biographies composers would not be so popular with the public or treated so seriously by scholars. Somehow, we are convinced that how an artist lives, and when and where, has something to do with the artist's works, even though the relationship may be shadowy or totally baffling. But exactly to what extent are the facts of Beethoven's tortured personal history reflected in, say, the Hammerklavier Sonata? Lately I have been worrying this old question as it applies to the music of Anton Webern, whose life and work are the subjects of a massive biography written by Hans and Rosalean Moldenhauer and recently published by Knopf.

title: Authors Queries
description: For a biographical study of Elizabeth Palmer Peabody (180494), I would appreciate hearing from anyone who has or knows of letters or other manuscripts concerning her life and work.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Clinic to Help Children Plagued by Fears
description: Poisonous or not, wild mushrooms are simply a part of the passing natural scene to most people. But to 6yearold Bobby, the growths in his backyard were so threatening that he could not play on or even touch the grass. Nor could he talk about the problem.

title: Soviet Reports Docking Of Soyz With Salyut 6
description: MOSCOW, June 9 (UPI)  An unmanned Soyuz capsule docked flawlessly with the orbiting Salyut 6 space station, apparently easing Soviet fears that a faulty approach control engine would hamper the manned space program, the press agency Tass reported today.

title: Levenson of South Africa Leads Belgian Open by 3
description: WATERLOO, Belgium, June 9 (UPI)  Gavin Levenson, a 25yearold South African, shot a fiveunderpar 68 for 207 and a threestroke lead in the $60,000 Belgian open golf tournament.

title: Tower Over Museum to Rise in Expensive Luxury
description: The 44story apartment tower that is to rise above the Museum of Modern Art is designed for luxurypriced condominiums that will feature ninefoothigh ceilings and floortoceiling window walls in living rooms.

title: Lucile Reid Fiance Of J. P. McMahon
description: Mary Lucile Reid, a financial analyst with CTICryogenics in Waltham, Mass., and Joseph P. McMahon, an electrical contractor in Cambridge, Mass., plan to be married in August in Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: They March To the Academies
description: KINGS PARK

title: Ellen Pleasants Gives An AllLiszt Bill
description: Ellen Pleasants, a pianist who has studied at Juilliard, Maimes, and Marymount Manhattan College, gave a courageous New York debut recital last Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. She played nothing but Liszt, and, even for Liszt, the pieces were difficult: the B minor Sonata, the Mephisto Waltz, Rhapsodie espagnole and three Transcendental Etudes  Mazeppa,  Paysage and Wilde Jagd.

title: Webster: Pain and Inspiration
description: THERE was a loud moan, then a grimace on his unshaven face as Marvin Webster lifted one of his long legs. The leg was strapped to an iron bar of a $14,000 Cybex machine, and beads of sweat formed on his forehead as Webster fought to raise the leg. The machine's pressure is supposed to strengthen the muscles around his aching knees. The harder Webster worked, the more resistance the machine offered; all the while, the machine provided printouts of his moves.

title: Samuel Viviano, Pianist, Plays Schumann Fantasy
description: Samuel Viviano, a JuilHard graduate and member of the music faculty of Mount Holyoke College, made his formal New York debut as a pianist Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. For his major statement of the evening, Mr. Viviano chose Schumann's Fantasy in C, a piece as popular with debutants as it is difficult to olav.

title: BOURGUIBA, ILL AT 75, HOLDS TIGHT TO RULE
description: Later, the television news shows the Supreme Combatant, as President Habib Bourguiba is called, signing important documents in the Tunisian Embassy, or conversing by telephone with his Prime Minister here.

title: The Nation
description: An informal network of antinucleai groups last week organized demon. strations across the United States and in several foreign countries, turninE out thousands of protesters to demand a halt to atomic power development.

title: Loves of a Yankee Lover
description: IF my family photo album is any indication, I guess my love affair with baseball began when I was no taller than a size36 Louisville Slugger, Yogi Berra model. One photograph shows me falling out of my older brother's Pony League uniform. Another has me in a Yankee Tshirt. Still another has me swinging one of those small souvenir bats you buy at the ballpark. There we were, baseball and I.

title: Sinus? Backache? Try Foot Massage
description: AS she massages your toes, Jane Gold could be clearing up your sinus condition. When she kneads the inside edge of your foot, you might find your perpetual backache is slipping away.

title: Sara Ann Truslow, Actress, Is Married to Edward Hardin
description: Sara Ann Truslow, a model and actress, was married yesterday in Norwalk, Conn., to Edward Hull Hardin, a fashion photographer. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's on the Green Episcopal Church by the Rev. Timothy E. CampbellSmith.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Haste Is From The Devil
description: WASHINGTON From the difficult to the more difficult. This is the process unfolding in the Middle East.

title: The Opera: 3 Under Brooklyn Bridge
description: The After Dinner Opera Company found an unusual setting for its performances of three oneact comic operas this weekend  Bargemusic, Ltd., an indoor concert barge docked at Fulton Ferry Landing in the East River right under the Brooklyn Bridge. The operas were unusual too, PonEhielli's The Talkative Suitor, Chabrier's An Incomplete Education and Apollo and Persephone by the late English composer Gerald Cockshott.

title: Questions/Answers
description: Several years ago, I planted a lilac. I had beautiful foliage, but no blown until last year, when it bloomed profusely. Last fall I pruned it and put lime around the soil. This spring, no flowers. Why? Mrs. B.T., Astoria, N.Y.

title: POLITICS
description: DEMOCRATIC candidates for county offices will go into the November general election solidly supporting a yes vote in the referendum on whether to establishment a county utility agency to study a takeover of the Consolidated Edison distribution network. Republicans are likely to have trouble forging any kind of unified stand on the issue, even though it was the party's majority on the County Board of Legislators that has been identified with opposition to such a takeover.

title: Girl, 13, Gets 114 Years In Fatal Beating of Man
description: MIAMI, June 9 (UPI)  A 13yearold girl was sentenced to 114 years in prison yesterday for robbing an 85yearold man of $660 and beating him to death when he refused to give her and four companions more money.

title: Massaging Data for Fun and Profit
description: When Data Resources Inc. of Lexington, Mass., was founded a decade ago, its clients included American Telephone and Telegraph, General Motors, the Morgan Guaranty Bank, Prudential Insurance and six other major corporations. By the time it went public in 1976, it had lined up 52 of the nation's 100 largest industrial corporations, 32 of the 50 largest commercial banks, 9 of the 25 largest insurance companies and 19 of the 50 largest securities firms.

title: Another Look at a Tax Cut
description: Last November maximum Federal tax rates on longterm capital gains were rolled back from 49 percent to 28 percent. Advocates of the rollback urged that it would encourage investment in our deteriorating capital plant and productive equipment. Opponents said it was just a device to enrich the wealthy.

title: 7YearOld Proposal to Rehabilitate Cold Spring Harbor Waterfront Appears to Be Headed for Approval
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I.  For the last seven years, Huntington Town has had plans to rehabilitate and beautify a section of the waterfront area here. It now looks as though those plans will finally be realized at the end of this season, pending official permission from the State Department of Environmental Conservation, which is expected soon.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The young man, a student, was making a botch of the interview. I wasn't especially interested in quettions about the number of movies I see a year (between 150 and 200), my social relations with filmmakers (few and random), how I choose the movies I'll write about (sometimes arbitrarily) and my reactions to review quotes taken out of context (occasional Irritation); I suggested it might be easier if I asked the questions as well as answered them. The student, having no choice, agreed.

title: THEATER
description: ELMSFORD, N.Y.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: WHEN it comes to campers, boats and other towable toys, the gas shortage has done a lot for the printers of For Sale signs. And that means there are bargains to be found in yards and driveways all over Connecticut. It means, too, that when you find one of those special deals, you will need to be up on the basics of trailering.

title: David Bowie Is Rock's Cunning Chameleon
description: David Bowie sloughs off musical styles and theatrical personas like a snake sheds its skin. The fascination his zigzagging music has exerted for a decade now has always been somewhat reptilian: It glitters with a cold cunning that's spellbinding but also a little bit repugnant.

title: Old Caldwell Branch at End of the Line
description: CALDWELL

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The impact was felt almost everywhere in the world. The grounding of the problematic DC10 aircraft last week by the Federal Aviation Administration left air travelers frantic, the airlines in disarray, the maker of the plane facing big losses in future sales, and the Federal Government under intense pressure from all directions to find a way out of the mayhem  fast.

title: Nancy Kuhlman Is Married
description: Nancy J. Kuhlman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Kuhlman of Garden City, L.1., was married there yesterday to Dale J. Oleff, a special agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and son of Mr. and Mrs. John Oleff of North Royalton, Ohio. The Rev. Thomas J. McCarthy performed the ceremony in St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church. The bride's father is director of protection at B. Altman & Company.

title: Donoghue Wins in 4:01.1
description: YONKERS, June 9  Ross Donoghue of St. John's outlasted Jim DeRienzo of Georgetown and won the third Yonkers Raceway invitation mile tonight. The winner's time was 4:01.1.

title: Claims of Flu Shot Victims Unpaid Despite U.S. Pledge
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  Three years ago Mark Waldvogel trusted the United States Government. Following the widely disseminated advice of President Ford and Federal health officials, Mr. WaldVogel, at the time.a healthy, athletic high school senior in Kailua, Hawaii, took a swine flu vaccination.

title: Debt and the Third World
description: WASHINGTON  In the wake of the 197374 explosion of oil prices, the hardpressed developing countries ran up a mountain of debt that threatened to overwhelm an industrialized world banking system that was staggering through a global recession. As one developing country after another approached default on its loans, international conferences were called and Congress held hearings into the big American banks lending practices. The world economies came through that period much less scarred than feared but the debt continues to mount.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Wine
description: Suppose you are driving through the Napa Valley one day soon and want to buy a nice bottle of wine. You might consider stopping off at the Heitz Wine Cellar retail shop to pick up a bottle of cabernet sauvignon. If you are in luck, there will still be a few bottles of the 1970 Heitz Martha's Vineyard cabernet sauvignon. The price: $40.

title: Around the Nation
description: CALUMET, La., June 9 (AP)  An explosion sent shock waves ripping through vast corridors of a salt mine near here today, killing four miners and leaving one other missing and possibly trapped 1,200 feet underground, the authorities said.

title: Jennifer Lovejoy, Designer, Is Bride
description: Jennifer Lovejoy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen F. Lovejoy of Riverside, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. Paul's Episcopal Church to Edward S. Craddock of Newton, Mass. The Rev. Donald G. Stauffer performed the ceremony.

title: Lewis, Jersey Schoolboy, Sets 266 LongJump Mark
description: NAPERVILLE, III., June 9 (AP)  A handful of meet records fell today at the International Prep track and field invitation meet, highlighted by a sensational 26foot6inch mark in the long jump by Carl Lewis of Willingboro (N.J.) High School. Lewis is the New Jersey state champion and the best scholastic long jumper in the nation. Lewis's jump erased the record of 262, which had stood for seven years.

title: Fiscal Plan Is Approved By Cleveland Factions
description: CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP)  City Council leaders and members of Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich's administration, ending a long feud over how to resolve the city's fiscal crisis, have agreed on a sixstep plan to present to the banks holding the city's overdue loans.

title: Letters
description: The World of Woody Allen

title: Wealthy Young People Finance a New Foundation
description: Some grassroots  groups formed to work on basic human problems in New York City are slightly better off because the North Star Fund, a new community foundation, has made its first round of grants.

title: Headliners
description: In 1975, Joan Little, a black woman, stood accused of killing a white North Carolina jailer with an ice pick. She claimed selfdefense, that he had tried to sexually assault her. After a trial that attracted international attention, she was acquitted. Late last year, Miss Little, who was serving a sentence for breaking and entering, escaped from a prison for women in Raleigh and fled north. Before she was apprehended and extradited to North Carolina, she worked for a time in New York City for the National Council of Black Lawyers. Last week, Miss Little was paroled; she returned to New York to take a job as a file clerk in a law firm.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: WHEN it comes to campers, boats and other towable diversions, the gasoline shortage has done a lot for the business of printing For Sale signs. That means there are bargains to be found in yards and driveways all over Westchester County. It means, too, that when someone finds one of those deals, he will need to be up on the basics of trailering.

title: Youth Shelter Faces Shutdown
description: MOUNT VERNON

title: Events Today
description: United Irish Counties Fete: Irish cultural festival, with music, dancing, arts and crafts; 10 A.M.; St. Joseph's Seminary, Seminary Road, Dunwoodie, Yonkers. Jewish Lower East Side Spring Festival: Folk dances, music, walking tours; 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; East Broad. way between Rutgers and Montoomery Streets. Flushing Outdoor Art Show and Sale: 10 A.M.; sidewalk around the Flushing Municipal Parking Field, 138th Street and 37th Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

title: Gwendolyn Bradley Sings Glitter and Be Gay
description: The Concert Artists Guild came up with a real winner at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night when it presented tho debut of Gwendolyn Bradley, a lyric soprano with a lovely voice and the ability to use it efficently and effectively. A graduate of the North Carolina School of the Arts who has also studid at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia, Miss Bradley has already sung wIth a number of opera companies and symphony orchestras.

title: BUDGET IN BALANCE IN 1981 Is FORECAST
description: PRINCETON, N.J., June 9 Favorable economic indicators, coupled with the Government's current tight fiscal policy, Will make it possible for President Carter to present a balanced budget for the 1981 fiscal year, Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal said today at Princeton University.

title: Valerie McKesson Bride of Clayton Arthur Callihan 2d
description: Valerie Gage McKesson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Arthur McKesson of Spring, Tex., was married yesterday in Kent, Conn., to Clayton Arthur Callihan 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Clayton Callihan of Briarcliff Manor and Minerva, N.Y. The Rev. Charles Rowins performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Kent School Chapel.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: The Effects,
description: CRACOW, Poland  At the start of his nineday visit to Poland, Pope John Paul II, leader of the world's 720 million Roman Catholics, paid a call on the Communist leadership. The First Secretary of the Communist Party, Edward Gierek, was there. So was Henrvk Jablonski. the fieurehead President of Poland. Conspicuously absent was Protr Jaroszewicz, the Prime Minister, who built his career on conflict with the church which functions as the nearest thing to political opposition in a Communist system where 90 percent of the 35 minion population has remained Catholic. There were reports that Mr. Jaroszewicz was seriously ill, even rumors (since vigorously denied) that he had died. Yet not once was his name even mentioned by his associates or by the tightly controlled media, in what was viewed as an extraordinary mark of deference to Pope John Paul.

title: What your home could have in common with the Met, the Tate, and the Louvre.
description: Beautiful, original works by artists who are represented in the world's great museums and galleries can be yours for very reasonable prices. We offer original etchings, lithographs and serigraphs signed by Calder, Chagall, Renoir and other important artists.

title: MUSIC
description: To the array of Connecticut summer festivals discussed in our last column, we should add the celebrated Caramoor concerts, even though they are across the Westchester border, in Katonah.

title: SPORTS
description: THE Chinese are coming! The Chinese are coming! This time it's women softball, and considering the dedication, perseverance, athletic skills and plain huge numbers of available women, it's a safe bet that China will be producing Joan Joyces of all dialects and competing with the United States, Japan and Australia for world honors within a very short time.

title: Nuclear Agency Will Issue Rules On Radioactive Waste Shipments
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission plans to issue rules next week on the shipment of nuclear wastes, including a requirement for armed escorts in heavily populated areas to protect shipments against sabotage.

title: Author's Query
description: For an authorized biography of Kay Boyle, I would appreciate any letters, memoirs, personal recollections or other information.

description: ON A recent evening in the tiny but trim Monmouth County borough of Little Silver, a phalanx of Department of Transportation troops, led in person by the commanding general, Commissioner Louis J. Gambaccini, held yet another rail commuter outreach meeting.

title: Author's Query
description: In connection with research on the history of the publication of Joseph Conrad's novels in America, I am eager to locate the heirs of George H. Doran. I would appreciate hearing from anyone who might be able to help me locate his daughter, Mary Doran Rinehart; his grandchildren, G. H. Doran Rinehart and Mary Rinehart Huvel le ; or their heirs.

description: BR1DGEHAMPTON

title: Food
description: Iwould be hard put to argue the merits or demerits of the numerous and variously styled deepfat fryers that are now  to use a word guardedly saturating the market. It remains a heartening fact, however, that Americans are learning that more can come out of a fryer than Southern fried chicken, fish and chips, and tempura (although I suspect it is these foods that have spurred an interest in, and sales of, the appliances).

title: She's Mesmerized by the Blues
description: ROSLYN

title: Francesca B. Bator Engaged to Writer
description: The engagement of Francesca Bradley Bator, a graphic designer with Oceans magazine in San Francisco, to William Philip Johnson, a writer and realestate investor, has been announced by Mrs. John James Macbride of Union, Me., and Peter Anthony Bator of New  York and Nonquitt, Mass., parents of the prospective bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Johnson of Toledo. Ohio.

title: Son of Ian Smith Is Married
description: OSLO, June 9 (Reuters)  Alex Smith, 30yearold son of former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia, was married today to Elisabeth Risum Knudsen, a 29yearold Norwegian. The bridegroom's parents were not at the ceremony.

title: Problem Plague Lilco's Uranium Supplier
description: MARQUEZ, N.M.

title: Amy Boyer Married to Mark W. McElroy
description: Amy Richards Boyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Creighton Boyer of Centreville, Del., was married yesterday to Mark Wayne McElroy in Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, Greenville, Del. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's mother, the Rev. Catherine McElroy, who is a pastoral assistant at the Church of the Intercession in New York and a staff member of the Division.of Overseas Ministries of the National Council of Churches.

title: Foreign Buyers in Deal for Landauer
description: In the first move toward the creation ofa new international real estate consuiting firm, Landauer Associates Inc., the New Yorkbased real estate consultant, is being acquired by a group that will include American and foreign investors.

title: President Carter's Campaign Audit, a Case in Point, Was Released Last Week
description: WASHINGTON  When the Federal Election Commission was set up four years ago, one of its first members, former Democratic National Committeeman Neil Staebler, looked back at Watergate, and election scandals before it.

title: Hitler Paintings Fetch $14,000
description: MUNICH, West Germany, June 9 (Reuters)  Two watercolors by Adolf Hitler were sold for about $7,000 each at an auction here today, an auction spokesman said.

title: John McNamara Leading the Big Red Band
description: When the Cincinnati Reds let Pete Rose escape into the freeagent market last November that was one thing. when they dismissed Sparky Anderson as manager a few weeks later, that was another. But when they hired a man named John Francis McNamara to run the show a few days later, eyebrows and hackles were raised all across midAmerica.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration Unit Gets Computer To Aid Search for Illegal Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has announced the first phase of a new cornputer system that he said would bring the Immigration and Naturalization Service into the 20th century and make it easier for the service to catch illegal aliens.

title: A Veterinarian Looks at a Changing Area
description: KENT

title: Where to Find the Fish
description: As of this writing, the stripedbass shore angling off the Vineyard has been as good or better than at any time in this decade. Most of the fish are large, ranging from 15 pounds to more than 40 pounds. and they have been taken from practically every beach and bridge. A few large bluefish arrived a few weeks ago, but since then, most of that species caught have been small.

title: U.S. Cutting Back State Transit Funds
description: WASHINGTON

title: MARY VALOUCH
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 9 (AP)  Fred (Cyclone) Taylor, a member of hockey's Hall of Fame, died in his sleep Saturday at a hospital. He was 94

title: Rougher Riding For Commuters
description: MARK FRAWLEY, a lawyer who has been commuting on the railroad from White Plains to Manhattan for 25 years, says has seen the service get worse and then get better in that time. At the moment, he says, it is getting worse again. They were new trains five or six years ago, he said the other day as rode a crowded, fourcar Harlem Line train that was short two cars. Now the cars are getting older, and I have a hunch they don't maintain them quite as well.

title: GEHLEN DIES AT 77;
description: MUNICH, West Germany, June 9 (Reuters)  Reinhard Gehlen, a longtime German intelligence officer and the first postwar chief of West Germany's espionage agency, died last night at his home at Lake Starnberg, relatives of the 71yearold retired general said today.

title: U. OF TEXAS DEBATES POSITION FOR ISRAELI
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 6 The University of Texas, one of the nation's wealthiest strivers toward academic eminence, is embroiled in a rancorous squabble over the proposed appointment of an Israeliborn historian to a position in the university's Center for Middle Eastern Studies. The study center is partly supported by funds from Arab governments.

title: David W. Levinson And Adair M. Rees Will Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Mason Rees of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Adair Mason Rees, to David Warren Levinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Levinson of Valley Stream, L.I. The couple plan to be married in August in Rye,N.Y.

title: Peregrine Falcon Nestles Down on Building Ledge
description: BALTIMORE, June 9 (UPI)  When Sc'arlett moved to Baltimore, the people who raised her hoped that she would find a nice young mate, settle down and raise a family. They weren't ready for what happened when she saw herself in a mirror.

title: BRIDGE
description: In the half century since contract bridge became popular, not to mention the previous two centuries in which related games were written about, one might think that every conceivable type of defensive play had been analysed and described. But this is not so, a tribute to the inexhaustibility of the game.

title: The Region
description: No man's life, liberty or property is safe while the Legislature is in session; an old sage said years ago. Last week, the Connecticut General Assembly ended any threat it might have posed to that state's citizens by adjourning. New Yorkers, meanwhile, have at least another week to wait before their legislators call it quits.

title: CRIME
description: About seven years ago George Higgins wrote a book called The Friends of Eddie Coyle, and for a while there were enormous repercussions in the crime writers fraternity. Mr. Higgins had attempted to present the speech and thought patterns of the criminal subculture as they actually were. It was not merely a matter of fourletter words. Rather, it was murder as business  the welltodo successful hoodlums talking and working out an assassination or whatever, then going home to the wife and children like Seventh Avenue furriers. Mr. Higgins did a marvelous job, and many writers tried to follow his method.

title: Astles Is Extradited to Uganda
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 9 (Reuters) Robert Astles, Britishborn aide of the ousted Ugandan leader, Idi Amin, was extradited from Kenya to Uganda today to stand trial for murder. The 59yearold Mr. Astles, accompanied by three Ugandan policemen, was driven to Nairobi's Wilson Airport and put aboard a plane. He is accused of having killed a fisherman last year in eastern Uganda.

title: 2 Share L.P.G.A. Lead by Shot
description: KINGS ISLAND, Ohio, June 9 Donna Caponi Young shot a twounderpar 70 today and moved into a tie for the lead after three rounds of the 25th annual Ladies Professional Golf Association championship. Mrs. Young caught Jerilyn Britz, who led after each of the first two rounds.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE ruling by the United States Supreme Court last week that It is legal to give war veterans a preference in hiring for government jobs may have been the final nail in the coffin in efforts to adjust a New Jersey law on the same subject.

title: Computerized Energy Control
description: In an exquisite bit of programming, the computerized energymanagement industry is corning of age just as the energy crisis is showing signs of becoming permanent and increasing numbers of owners of residential, commercial and industrial buildings, both large and small, are installing computer systems in old structures or planning them in new ones.

title: House Votes Olmsted Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)  The House today gave approval to legislation establishing the home of Fredrick Law Olmsted, the conservationist, as a national historic site. The bill authorizes $1 million for acquisition and development of the home, in Brookline, Mass.

title: DINING OUT
description: MY ideal restaurant  and it does not exist except in the ideal  is small, warmly lighted, never stuffy, slightly informal, with a welltrained staff that gets know your wishes quickly and responds in a friendly but not effusive manner. It is a p!ace where people something like oneself tend to congregate. Above all, the food is superb and unique, and a few dishes are so good one tends to keep ordering them time after time. It is a place one goes when fanciness and flourish are not desirable.

title: Realty News
description: H. Muehlstein & Company, which markets thermoplastic and rubber materials, has leased 19,000 square feet of office space in the recently completed building at 591 West Putnam Avenue in Greenwich. Conn.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  There's a tendency here to write off the CarterBrezimev meeting in Vienna as another one of those theatrical diplomatic performances and meaningless compromises. But Vienna itself is a reminder that sometimes patient negotiations do have some meaning.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Israeli Demonstrators Travel to West Bank To Protest Settlement
description: JERUSALEM, June 9  Nearly 3,000 Israelis gathered on the outskirts of Nablus in the West Bank todaay to protest the establishment of a new Jewish settlement.

title: PulitzerWinning Paper Resisting Synanon Bid
description: POINT REYES STATION, Calif., June 9 (UPI)  David Mitchell, copublisher of the weekly newspaper that won a Pulitzer Prize for its investigation of the Synanon Foundation, says he will resist a subpoena from the organization for his notes and records.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: F.D.A. Is Seeking to Revise Rules On Processing and Storing Food
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)  The Food and Drug Administration has proposed revisions to its rules governing manufacturing practices and plants and warehouses that handle food.

title: Small Plane Crashes on Freeway, Killing 4 and Injuring 2 on Coast
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., June 9 (AP) small plane crashed on the San Diego Freeway moments after takeoff today, Struck a truck and burst into flames. The police said that all four persons aboard the plane were killed and that two men in the truck were injured.

title: Richard Gambrill Casey Marries Mary E. Disch
description: Mary Elizabeth Disch and Richard Gambrill Casey were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's grandmother, Mrs: Richard Van Nest Gambrill in Peapack, N.J. The Rev. Hilary O'Leary of the Delbarton School in Morristown, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: Ideas &
description: As feminists see it, veterans preference laws unfairly discriminate against women because most veterans are male. The Supreme Court does not think much of such laws, either. Last week the Court agreed that the laws have a devastating impact on women's civil service job opportunities. It called the laws unwise, said they give veterans more than a square deal, and termed them an awkward exception to the widely 'shared view that merit and merit alone should prevail in the employment policies of government.

title: The World
description: There was a special poignancy about the latest change of power in Ghana last week. After corrupt and inefficient administration by military and civilian leaders beginning with Kwame Nkrumah, Ghana's flamboyant first President, the yearold Government of Lieut. Gen. Frederick W. K. Akuffo had acted to bring order to the economy and restore civilian rule.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Normally, when an Incoming musical is plainly need of a thoroughgoing overhaul out of town, the overhaul takes the form of a massive hype: the dances get faster, longer and louder, the principals find themselves belting tunes oftener at much brighter tempos, the gags grow broader and the sharply reduced libretto scurries out of the way at a sometimes dizzying pace. The results can be incoherent or, if coherent, vulgar. But that isn't what's happened to I Remember Mama.

title: At Home: Job Snob Turns to Reality
description: AMAN came to pump out my septic tank and I was surprised to see that he was young, handsome, even elegant. Tall, slender, with a casual grace of movement, he might easily have passed for a count or an actor. His voice was melodious, his speech precise, though slightly tinged with an accent.

title: P.E. Salas Weds Caroline Trevor
description: Caroline Wilmerding Trevor and Peter Eckert Salas, who are with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, were married yesterday in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I. The rector, the Rev. Charles G. Newbery, performed the ceremony.

title: DINING OUT
description: GREENWICH

title: The Night Life of Paris Retains Its Spicy Savor
description: The rave review of the show at the Paradis Latin, blown up and posted at the entrance, says it is not the shoddy sort of entertainment devised for libidinous, fat and sweaty tourists and chastely called Paris by Night. But the fact is that Paris by Night is not what it used to be. It no longer needs to be. There is really nothing more, or naughtier, that Paris can offer visitors this summer than is offered in New York, San Francisco, Copenhagen, Dusseldorf, Tokyo and points between. Gay in Paree no longer means just a festive evening's play, but the same as it means everywhere else. So night life has changed.

title: Vorster
description: JOHANNESBURG  In South Africa, even whites who oppose apartheid criticize the double standard of Western governments that condemn.Pretoria's abuse of democratic rights while embracing African states that have no semblance of democracy. It is common cause among South African whites that their country, for all the constraints placed on black freedoms, still has elements of democracy for whites a relatively free press, an independent judiciary, a fairly elected Parliament with a functioning opposition that have been suppressed in most black African states, including those most vociferous in their demands for South Africa's isolation.

title: Federal Officials Predict Measles Will Be Eliminated Soon in U.S.
description: ATLANTA, June 9 (UPI)  Federal health officials believe the United States is approaching what they term a significent milestone in medical history, the elimination of measles in this country.

title: Burma Saves Some Treasured Pagodas but Many Decay
description: PAGAN, Burma  From the 11th through the 13th centuries, so many trees were cut to fuel kilns to dry bricks for temples and pagodas in this region that the climate changed, according to Burmese scientists.

title: Gail Sander Is Wed To David A strove
description: Gail Eleanor Sander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. James Sander of New. Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday to David Michael Astrove, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Astrove, also of New Rochelle. Rabbi Amiel Wohl and Rabbi Jacob K. Shankman officiated at Temple Israel.

title: SelfPolicing and SelfInterest Are Supposed to Ensure Safety
description: LOS ANGELES  A passenger buys a ticket, picks up a newspaper to read on the trip, and settles into his seat, confident that the airliner he has just boarded is safe. How could it be otherwise? The Government has allowed it to fly and carry passengers.

title: Giacometti Sho wn In a New Dimension
description: NEWARK

title: Playing King of City Hall's Hill
description: In the age of permissiveness, a deadline becomes merely a felt need. In the realpolitik that invests New York City, a deadline becomes a joke. Last week, the city's budget deadline was missed (with the Mayor arriving emptyhanded at a White House dinner) and the head of the City Council's Finance Committee shrugged: All they can do is give you 20 lashes.

title: France Expands Nuclear Power And Runs Into Little Opposition
description: CATTENOM, France, June 7 While the radioactive gas clouds were still billowing up inside the reactor on Three Mile Island early in April, President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France did what no other Western leader would have dared attempt at so difficult a moment for supporters of nuclear energy.

title: INTERVIEW
description: LOWELL J. TOOLEY majored in municipal affairs at the University of Wisconsin and then quickly discovered, in his first job at Shorewood Hills, what it meant to be a village manager, at least in 1949: He drove the garbage truck, the fire truck and the ambulance as well as performing most of the Wisconsin village's other nonpolitical functions.

title: Betty Satterwhite Bride of Laurence Sutter
description: Betty Archer Satterwhite, chief researcher for the nation section of Time Magazine, and Laurence B. Sutter, who is with the New York law firm of Shea Gould Climenko & Casey, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club. Khoren Arisian of the New York Society for Ethical Culture performed the ceremony.

title: Big Cars Banned in Philippines
description: MANILA, June 9 (Reuters)  The Phillipines issued a ban on all six and eightcylinder cars on weekends in an effort to save gasoline. The Ministry of Energy said the cars of drivers who ignored the ban would be impounded. Its order exempted diplomatic cars and tourist vehicles such as buses.

title: Davis Firm as Cosmos Regular
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 9  Mark down the name of this boy, Eddie Firmani said in 1976 when he was coach of the Tampa Bay Rowdies and scouting Ricky Davis. He is a pedigree if I ever saw one in the United States.

title: The Summer of 79: Plenty of Jobs
description: This summer should be a good one for students who want to work. The economy may be heading toward a recession, but it is relatively strong for now, and demographic shifts auger well for teenagers. The low birth rates of the 1960's mean there is less competition for jobs.

title: CAMERA
description: The traditional way of learning how to control photography is by trial and error. That is taking a lot of pictures to develop what is commonly called a picture eye.

title: Probe Detects Zone Near Jupiter Much Hotter Than Sun's Surface
description: LAUREL, Md., June 9 Space scientists today announced the discovery of the hottest spot yet measured in the solar system, a sort of interplanetary torrid zone between Jupiter and Mars with temperatures more than 100 times those of the sun's surface.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSBarbara, Devoted wife of Richard. Adored mother of Lynne Paris and Donald. Cherished daughter of Jack G. Kahn. Dear sister of Marilyn Orgel. Services Sunday, 1:15 P.M. at Gutterman's Nassau Memorial Chapel Long Beach Rd. at Greystone, Rockville Centre, L.I. Donations to Cancer Care would be appreciated.

title: Miss Wray, C.C. Fountain Have Nuptials
description: Elizabeth. Wray, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clifford C. Wray of Watertown, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Caldwell Fountain, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Fountain of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. John B. Smiley performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Watertown.

title: Kathleen Collett McNeily Wed to George Davis Jr.
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly, N.J., yesterday, Kathleen Collett McNeily, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter W.G. McNeily of Kennett Square, Pa., was married to George Martin Davis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Davis of Franklin Springs, N.Y. The Rev. Henry Powers performed the ceremony.

description: Catherine Holohan Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Johnston of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Robert Morrisson Mullin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mullin of Belmont, Mass. The Rev. John N. Ryan performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration.

title: Rent Unit Uses Survey Citing 8.2% Cost Rise For Landlords in 78
description: A Federal survey of New York City housing costs that will be used this week as the basis for deciding the maximum allowable rent increases in 300,000 rentstabilized apartments found that owners expenses increased 8.2 percent last year.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  The Fantasticks, In an Actor's CafeTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through June). $3.5045.50; students and the elderly, $2.5044.50; group rates. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Speak Up, Get Fired
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  Recently, an American Telephone and Telegraph Co. supervisor was fired from his job because he participated in a political demonstration. He is suing A. T. & T. for damages. His chances of winning are lightly regarded because, under the law in most states, an employee who does not have an employment contract or is not protected by a union can be dismissed for good cause, for no cause or even for cause morally wrong.

title: Beyond Coping
description: WASHINGTON  In the cold glare of hindsight, the world's adjustment to the 197374 Arab oil embargo and the consequent quadrupling of crude oil prices served principally to buy time, five years of it. Now the piper has returned to be paid again. The question is how, and principally whether, this time longterm policies to provide a smoother adjustment to new energy realities will be put in place. As Theodore Eck, chief economist at the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), puts it: If we balance out because of a recession, the politicians are going to go back to sleep. It would be the right answer for the wrong reason.

title: The 'student Prince At the Paper Mill
description: MILLBURN

title: Mother Asks Inquiry on Conflict In Stories of Son's Fatal Beating
description: The mother of a 14yearold boy who was fatally beaten at a school for the mentally handicapped in Vineland, N.J., on May 26 said last week that she would ask the Cumberland County Prosecutor to investigate conflicting accounts of the incident.

title: STATE SHARE OF AID IS REPORTED LOWER
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  Senator Daniel PattIck Moynihan declared today that the transfer of wealth out of New York State continued in the fiscal year ending last fall.

title: Computer Flaw Disrupts Phones
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 9 (UPI) Most of downtown Salt Lake City was without telephone service yesterday because of a computer failure at the Mountain Bell Telephone Company.

description: BRAVERMANLEVY

title: Mary W. Bone Becomes Bride
description: Mary Washington Bone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Bone of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thomas Dewees Zara of Stamford, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Zara of Santa Ana, Costa Rica.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: WHEN it comes to campers, boats and other towable toys, the gasoline shortage has done a lot for the business of companies printing For Sale signs. But that means there are bargains to be found in yards and driveways all over New Jersey. It means, too, that when you find one of those special deals, you'll need to be up on the basics of trailering.

title: Nevada Trying to Reclaim Land Held by Government Since 1864
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., June 9 (AP) Nevada has made a move to wrench most of its land from Federal control. It could be the first shot in a courtroom civil war.

title: Royals eat Yanks in 13th, 98
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 9  After 7 hours 41 minutes of baseball within 24 hours; after 23 innings, 38 runs, 61 hits and 41 runners left on base, the Yankees have seen that they can beat the Royals and the Royals have seen that they can beat the Yankees.

title: Breaking Our Word in Panama
description: It is an unhappy fact of American politics that reason stops at the edge of the Panama Canal. Members of Congress who are kind to children and profess respect for law turn into scofflaws when the subject of Panama arises. Now they are threatening to undo 14 years of work by four Presidents by billing the Republic of Panama for as much as $4 billion in closing costs for transferring the Big Ditch to its lawful new owner by the year 2000. If they get their way, the United States would be in violation of the letter and spirit of canal treaties ratified only last year.

title: Author's Query
description: For a history of Thomas A. Edison's first village plant, erected in Roselle, N.J., (188190), we would be grateful for any pertinent information, anecdotes or memorabilia.

title: Hercules Is a Myth, I'm Not
description: KIAMESHALAKE,N.Y. WHEN he strolled through the side door with his sparring partners, none of the nearby PingPong players even turned around. And now, as the heavyweight challenger shadowboxed in a corner of King Arthur's Court in the Concord Hotel, two men in tennis clothes wandered over and stared at him.

title: Stage: 2 Comedies on Bill at Stratford
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 10 At last season's Stratford Festival, Canada, the artistic director, Robin Phillips, underwent an endurance test by directing or codirecting seven productions. This season he has cut his contribution down to a more manageable three  a new production of Love's Labour's Lost, codirected by Urjo Kareda; a revival of his production of The Importance of Being Earnest and Peter Ustinov as King Lear, which does not join the repertory until October.

title: Florida Brothers Triumph at Le Mans
description: LE MANS, France, June 10 (AP) Florida's Whittington brothers, Don and Bill, and their teammate, Klaus Ludwig of West Germany, scored a tensionwracked victory today in the 97th Le Mans 29hour road race. They drove a Porsche 935 twinturbo coupe.

title: Lynnie Godfrey, Singer, Bride
description: Lynnie Godfrey, a singer and featured player in the musical Eubie, was married yesterday to Carl Everard Lee, a distribution specialist for Mobil Oil Inc. in New York. The ceremony was performed in the Central Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Eugene Callender, former president of the New York Urban Coalition.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVINO TODAY, June 11

title: U.S. Launches Satellite to Watch Space Activity From the Equator
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 10 (UPI)  An Air Force Titan3C rocket blasted off from Cape Canaveral today, apparently to position a satellite over the Equator to monitor Russian and Chinese space launch activities. The Air Force did not comment on whether the unannounced launch was successful.

title: Letting the Children Discover Golf
description: KRISTEN MILLER is 8 years old and only slightly taller than her father's 3wood. She doesn't like to practice playing her violin, but she does like to play golf.

title: SOVIET CAUTIONS U.S. ON MX DEPLOYMENT
description: MOSCOW, June 10  An authoritative Soviet commentary said today the planned deployment of a new MX missile by the United States was incompatible with the strategic arms limitation treaty President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev are to sign in Vienna June 18.

title: Photoengravers' Union Ratifies 3Year Pact With 2 Newspapers
description: Members of Photoengravers Union IP voted 78 to 6 to ratify a new threeyear agreement with The Daily News and The New York Times.

title: DEATH RATE OF MEN UP IN SOVIET TOWNS
description: Recent census results issued by the Soviet Union have disclosed a sharp increase in some death rates and declines in births that may aggravate a labor shortage in the economy in the 1980's.

title: Gregory Andrews Weds Susan Battles
