description: Susan Battles, a speechwriter for the American Bankers Association in Washington, was married yesterday to Gregory B. Andrews, a Congressional liaison officer with the Department of Transportation. The ceremony was performed in St. Robert's Roman Catholic Church in Andover, Mass., by the Rev. Edward L. King.

title: Cosmos Win, 41
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 10  Playing with three new faces in the starting lineup because of injuries, the Cosmos defeated the Dallas Tornado, 41, at Giants Stadium today.

title: Strategy Pays Off in Oriole Victory
description: There is a baseb'all axiom that says games played early in the season are as important as games played in September. Earl Weaver, the manager of the Baltimore Orioles, is a believer.

title: Courts Under Siege
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  In our zeal to tighten popular control over government, we seem to be forgetting what the constitution's farmers knew equal justice under the law requires a judiciary not dependent on political will. Now a bizarre drama is unfolding in California. If Americans elsewhere follow their example, our independent judiciary will suffer a serious blow.

title: When and Where
description: Below is the schedule of the Metropolitan Golf Association's seven remaining junior clinics this season. There is no charge, and no registration is required.

title: Around the Nation
description: As the lack of trucks began to be felt by grain elevators and packing houses in Western states, snipers and arsonists yesterday attacked some trucks hauling cargo in defiance of the wildcat strike by independent truckers.

title: Sculptured Jewelry That Evokes Primitive Images in 22Karat Gold
description: The name Mahie has come to denote a certain look in jewelry, on both sides of the Atlantic. But not everyone who collects the jewelry is aware that the distinctive 22karat gold body ornaments and minisculptures that bear the signature Jean Mahie were actually made by Jacline Mazard and her fatherinlaw, Jean Marie.

title: Davona Dale Triumphs
description: The New York Racing Association triple crown for 3yearold fillies is still within reach for Davona Dale of Calumet Farm.

title: The Middle Course on Rhodesia
description: President Carter has defined a right and expedient new policy for Rhodesia: It stays in step with Britain's Conservatives. It protects Western interests in black Africa. It preserves a hope for ending the civil war and keeping the Russians out. The only trouble is, it offends the Senate and perhaps the House, too, and the sense of fairness of many Americans. They don't understand why we should be boycotting a new blackwhite regime whose election looked more democratic than any other recently held in black Africa.

title: Bean Hot, Wins by 8 Shots
description: ATLANTA, June 10 (AP)  Pulling happy gallery of thousands with him on his trek over the red clay hills and through the Georgia pines, Andy Bean fired a 5underpar 67 for a recordsetting victory today in the Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: Deputy Prime Minister of Israel Leaves for a 6Day Visit to Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, June 10 (Reuters)  Yigael Yadin, Israel's Deputy Prime Minister, left today for a sixday visit to Egypt at the invitation of President Anwar elSadat. Mr. Yadin, an archeology expert, told reporters he would be mainly visiting archeological sites and would not deal with the issue of Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Law to Help Save HalfFare Rates Cited
description: Representative Elizabeth Holtzman speaking yesterday at a news conference in Rockefeller Center. The conference, sponsored by a coalition of citizen groups, was called to warn the Metropolitan Tranportation Authority that the Holtzman amendment to the Urban Mass Transit Act would prohibit any change in the halfprice fares on subways and buses without a public hearing. The M.T.A. voted recently to extend reduced fares fora sixmonth period.

title: Sports Briefs
description: A record was set for length of time and number of games in the semifinals of the national paddletennis open doubles championship yesterday at Stuyvesant Town. In the marathon match, Doug Russell and Steve Geller of New York beat the California team of Greg Lawrence and Brian Lee in five sets that took 5 hours. The scores were 46, 64, 67, 76, 3836.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIVAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) voltrE PLAINS 9.5300; NASSAU CO. (516) 707.0500; SUFFOLICO. (516) 66911300; CONNECTICUT (203) 3484707.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Preparatory Committee for the New International Development Strategy 10:30 A.M.

title: Outdoors: Rafting in a WhiteWater Wilderness
description: JIM THORPE, PA. BETWEEN the cliffs lined with rhododendrons and blooming laurel and the banks softened by ferns, inflatable nylon rafts bounce off rocks like bumper cars at the boardwalk. Then, caught by the current, they swirl, rise and plunge on with the river that rushes down from the Pocono Mountains.

title: N.H.L. Prepares for Expansion
description: MONTREAL, June 10 (AP)  The wheeling and dealing was over in the National Hockey League as rosters were frozen today for an expansion draft on Wednesday that will provide 17 players for each of four incoming clubs.

title: Erato
description: HOWARDPhilip B., of Cold Spring Harbor suddenly on June 9. 1979 in his 51st year, husband of Lee Howe Howard, father of David Allen, Christopher Bullard, Daniel Chandler and Mark Howe, son of Marion Bullard Howard, brother of Judith Howard Miller and Frank Albert Howard. Memorial service June 12, 11:30AM, St. John Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Huntington Hospital Coronary Care Unit, Park Ave, Huntington, NY 11703.

title: New Thriller by Forsyth Will Come Out in March
description: The word this morning is that fans of Frederick Forsyth (The Day of the Jackal and The Odessa File) will have to wait until next March for Mr. Forsyth's newest caper, The Devil's Alternative. However, it seems a wait worth waiting for.

title: San Francisco Opera To Sing Tosca in Manila
description: The San Francisco Opera will present three performances of Puccini's Tosca in Manila next December. It will mark the first time the company will have performed outside the United States.

title: Public TV to carry Programs on a Network Basis for the First Time in Fall
description: What is standard procedure for most commercial television stations around the country will become an innovation for public television next fall  the simultaneous broadcast of the same programs on the same evening and in the same time sequence.

title: Catastrophic Scope of 1976 China Earthquake Is Revealed
description: Details of the greatest natural disaster of recent centuries  the earthquake that struck Tangshan, China, on July 28, 1976  have become available, and they paint a picture of devastation and suffering without parallel in modern times apart from the atomic bomb attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

title: Aretha Franklin's Father, a Cleric, Is Critically Wounded in Shooting
description: DETROIT, June 10 (AP)  The Rev. Clarence Franklin, father of Aretha Franklin, the rhythymandblues singer, was wounded in a shooting at his home early today, the police said.

title: Borg Captures 4th French Title
description: PARIS, June 10  Bjorn Borg won the French open singles title today, stifling the powerful Victor Pecci of Paraguay, 63, 61, 67, 64.

title: Pop: Welk Gives Show In Garden
description: LAWRENCE WELK is such a well established success and survivor (he was 50 years old by the time he made it big on television and now, at 76, he Is as buoyant as ever) that the early disparagements he suffered  his corny material, his clumsy announcements  have completely evaporated. Why this has happened was evident in the show that he brought to Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

title: Amy Beth Leiwant Married To Richard Jayson in Jersey
description: Amy Beth Leiwant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney E. Leiwant of South Orange, N.J., was married there yesterday in Temple Israel of the Oranges and Maplewood to Richard Mark Jayson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Jayson of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Herbert Weiner nerformed the ceremony.

title: Leak in Alaska Pipeline Shuts Off the Flow of Oil
description: ANCHORAGE, June 10  A leak caused the 800mile TransAlaska pipeline to be shut down today, halting the flow of 1.2 million barrels of crude oil daily to domestic markets.

title: Piano: McFrederick
description: CHOPIN'S G minor Ballade was unquestionably the least representative part of Michael McFrederick's concert Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. It turned up as a sort of celebrity guest, alongside three of Mr. McFrederick's compositions and Mario CastelnuovoTedesco's Piedigrotta,(1924), a littleknown piano suite that proved worth knowing. Yet, in a sense, Mr. McFrederick's performance of the thricefamiliar Chopin work furnished the clearest evidence of why he is such a likable musician, and why the entire evening was such a delight.

title: RUSSELL JONES DIES; PRIZE REPORTER, 61
description: Russell Jones, a former European correspondent for United Press International who won a Pulitzer Prize for his coverage of the Hungarian revolt in 1956, died Saturday in his home in Vienna. He was 61 years old.

title: With New Political Mood, Focus of Urban Aid May Ignore the Poor
description: Not only have the nation's economic condition and its political mood changed the financial parameters of the debate on social issues, they have substantially changed its focus as well, according to seasoned Capital observers.

title: Red Sox Scout Stalks Prey Tenaciously
description: THE dozen middleaged men chewing tobacco and fiddling with their World Series rings are staring hard at a gangly 6foot6inch high school pitcher who they think has potential in his right arm. Baseball scouting is a profession of minute assessments, and on this spring day in the Berkshires, Bill Enos, a Red Sox scout, has the edge.

title: U.S. Aide Says Rumania Fails to Help in Fascist's Trial
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  The Rumanian Government has given virtually no assistance to the United States Government in the prosecution of Valerian D. Trifa, a World War II leader of the Rumanian fascist movement, who faces trial on charges he participated in a massacre of Jews. American officials ARV.

title: Dance: New McIntyre
description: DANNE McINTYRE is one of the few black choreographers who work within both the mainstream modern dance style and the jazz and character style that has come to be thought of as black dance. She may be the ogly choreographer today to attempt to blend the two, often with impressive results. Her new The Last Days of the Down Home Boogies, seen on Saturday at the Harry de Jur Henry Street Settlement Playhouse, is such a dance.

title: Burma Fights Growing Domestic Heroin Addiction
description: RANGOON, Burma  On street corners in Rangoon these days, heroin is almost as easy to buy as black market razor blades and ballpoint pen refills.

title: The Region
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)  New Jersey averted a proposed cutback in Federal financing for a summer program for lowincome youths, and instead stands to get 50 percent more money for the program, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. announced yesterday.

title: Rising Costs at Jails. Press Judges To Find Sentencing Alternatives
description: In Florida, Kathy Rodriguez pleaded no contest last month to charges that she abused her 8yearold daughter. She was not sent to jail.

title: The City
description: A Spring Valley, N.Y., man offered $1,000 yesterday for information leading to the arrest of a man who pushed Renee Katz, a senior at the High School of Music and Art, in front of a moving subway train last week.

title: Sports World Specials
description: If it weren't for bad luck, Comma dore Downs wouldn't have any luck at all.

title: Helping Small Savers and Their Banks
description: Federal regulators announced higher interest rates on savings accounts last week and President Carter went even further, asking Congress to abolish all Regulation Q interest ceilings on savings deposits. These measures represent simple justice for small savers, who are now permitted only 5 percent on their accounts while people withmore money can earn 10 percent. But the break for small savers is only one part of the Administration's proposal. It would also eliminate many of the regulatory barriers that separate savings institutions from commercial banks so as to stabilize housing credit and increase competition in banking.

title: Deaths
description: RAPHAELSIDNEY 0. The Rabb Jacob Joseph School mourns ter passing of our beloved and devote( Chairman of the Board, Sidney 0 Raphael. An esteemed alumnus our Yeshiva and an outstandlnt lawyer for more Than half a centu ry, he served our school with dis tinction and dedication. He was man of grace and dignity to whop we and countless others turned ti for sage counsel and inspiration Our loss is great. May his dear wife Thelma. and all the members of hi: family be comforted with the thought that he served all humanib with love and understanding.

title: Mets Strand 10, Lose to Astros by 53
description: In an exhibition that might well have been named Missed Opportunities had it been staged on Broadway, the lastplace New York Mets lost a 53 decision to the firstplace Houston Astros at Shea Stadium yesterday.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: I'm a born optimist, says Joseph W. James, president of National Car Rental System, and that could explain why he believes that his company will weather, and perhaps even benefit from, the current gasoline crisis.

title: 4,000 Island Goats May Be Moved To Mountains Near Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10  The Santa Monica Mountains may be the site of modernday stampede: 4,000 wild goats from San Clemente Island.

title: 4 Die in German Air Collision
description: SCHWARMSTEDT, West Germany, June 10 (Reuters)  Four persons were killed when two private planes collided at an air rally near this town in northern West Germany today, the police said. The dead were the pilots and the copilots.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Low level clouds extend from New England to the southern Appalacians, while a band heaavy clouds extends over a frontal system from the upper lake region through the Mississippi and Missouri Valleys to the Southern Plains States. Low level clouds cover portions of the Pacific Northwest. Clear skies are apparent elsewhere.

title: Tumultuous Session Winds Up Third World Meeting
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, June 10  An acrimonious weeklong conference of thirdworld nations ended quietly early this morning, a day late, after a tempestuous last negotiating session in which the frustrated Sri Lanka chairman reportedly threatened to resign.

title: Scientists Warn of Peril to Homes On Beachfronts of Barrier Islands
description: CAPE HATTERAS, N.C., June 9  The strands of barrier islands draped along the Atlantic Coast from Maine to Florida are on the move, as they have been for centuries, and nothing people have devised so far has succeeded in stopping them.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  If the CarterYoungMcGovern campaign to destabilize the most freely elected government in Africa were to succeed, this would be the result:

title: Tom Watson Goes After the Open
description: TOM WATSON is the best golfer in the world today, all the game's rail birds agree. The only disagreement is whether he is yet one of the great ones of history, up there with Harry Vardon, Bobby Jones, Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Sam Snead, Byron, Nelson, Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus.

title: Leak Reported At Atom Plant In Connecticut
description: Northeast Utilities, which provides most of Connecticut's electricity, yesterday began shutting down its flagship nuclear generator, the 830megawatt Millstone II plant at Waterford to repair a leak of radioactive water from a valve in the primary cooling system.

title: Music: Bai Konte Plays On Harp of West Africa
description: AN early European explorer described the music of the Halam, a kind of West African banjo, as wind through the trees in heaven. The image is even more appropriate to the kora, a 21string West African harp that produces a delicate, brightly sonorous rustling when played by a master.

title: Gas Station Attendant Held In Gun Threat on Customer
description: A gasstation attendant in Queens was arrested yesterday and charged with illegal possession of a weapon and with menacing a customer after he allegedly refused to serve him because he was not a regular customer and reportedly pointed a pistol at the motorist.

title: Sony Unit In Mexico Pact
description: TOKYO, June 10 (AP)  The Sony Corporation said that its wholly owned subsidiary, Sony Magnetic Products Inc., had established a subsidiary in Mexico to produce cassette audio recording tapes.

title: SHAH AND EMPRESS FLY TO MEXICO CITY
description: MEXICO CITY, June 10 (AP)  Shah Mohammed Rim Pahlevi of Iran and and his wife, Empress Farah, flew to the Mexico City airport today from the Bahamas and left by car for an undisclosed location. airport sources said.

title: 2 Children in Foster Care Named To City Panel to Improve System
description: Two children in foster care have been appointed fullfledged members of a task force set up by Mayor Koch to work on ways to improve that often criticized childcare program.

title: Cone vs. Denim Fluctuations
description: GREENSBORO, N.C. The bales of soft cotton with their herbal odor stand out amid the industrial clatter of spinning machines and looms and the vats of indigo dye here at the huge White Oak manufacturing plant of the Cone Mills Corporation.

title: Chess:
description: One objective that Anatoly Karpov achieved in the Man and His World Challenge Cup International Tournament in Montreal was to discourage two of the younger generation of grandmasters who have been singled out as possible contenders for his world chamoion's crown.

title: Carolyn E. Carter Bride of Jonathan S. Paris
description: Branford Memorial Chapel at Yale University was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Carolyn E. Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford E. Carter of Urbana, Ill., to Jonathan S. Paris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Paris of Beachwood, Ohio. Rabbi Steven Reuben performed the ceremony.

title: Frigitemp In Bankruptcy
description: The Frigitemp Corporation, which filed under Chapter XI of the Federal Baitkruptcy Act in March 1978, was ruled bankrupt on May 29 by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, the company disclosed.

title: Linda Faye Lichtman Is Wed
description: Linda Faye Lichtman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Lichtman of Hillcrest, Queens, was married yesterday in the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., to Dr. Robert Alan Caine, son of Mrs. Paul Caine of Worcester, Mass., and the late Mr. Caine. Rabbi Eugene Markovitz performed the ceremony.

title: Indian Premier in Tashkent
description: MOSCOW, June 10 (AP)  Indian Prime MiniMer Morarji R. Desai arrived in the Central Asian city of Tashkent today at the start of a fourday official visit to the Soviet Union. The 83yearold Prime Minister is scheduled to hold talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, tomorrow.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 27, 35, 17, 12, 1 and 19. The supplementory number was 28.

title: American Honda Chooses Dailey
description: The waiting is over out on the Coast. The American Honda Motor Company, the United States arm of the world's largest motorcycle maker, has just made its decision on an ad agency. It has chosen Dailey & Associates to handle its $10 million motorcycle account.

title: As Antioch College Grows, So Does Its Anxiety Over Finances Tradition and Identity
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, June 9 The academic year seemed to be winding down to a typical ending this week at Antioch College, where barefooted students in cutoff jeans and tank tops sprawled on the lush lawns and the malaise induced by Southern Ohio's humidity began its annual descent on the camnus.

title: Mortgage Is Foreclosed On Billy Carter's Home
description: BUENA VISTA, Ga., June 10 (AP) The holder of the mortgage on Billy Carter's home in Draneville has foreclosed and is advertising the property for sale.

title: In Nicaragua's Embattled Cities, Rebellion Becomes a Way of Life
description: MASAYA, Nicaragua, June 10  In the Indian district of Monimbo, heads are barely turned by the sound of gunfire. At street corners, deep trenches and four. foothigh barricades await any assault by the National Guard on the shantytown.

title: Supreme Court Workers Mostly White and Male
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI)  Most workers at the Supreme Court are white and male, statistics released by the Court show.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Intext Releases Accord Details
description: Intext Inc., publisher of textbooks for schools, has disclosed some details of its previously announced agreement with CohenHatfield Industries under which the latter will not make any open market purchases of Intext common stock for eight months and will not make any private purchases of Intext common for six months unless another party made a tender offer for Intext or was required to file with the Securities Exchange Commission because of purchases of Intext common.

title: Events
description: SCRAMBLED FEET, written and caracoled by John Driver and Jeffrey Haddow. Directed by John Driver, at the Village Gate, 160 Bleecker Street, 6:45.

title: Projections in Voting For Europe Assembly Show Setback for Left
description: PARIS, Monday, June 11  Projections early today indicated that centerright parties in the ninenation European Economic Community were winning a clear majority of seats for the European Assembly, which was being elected for the first time by direct ballot.

title: Talmadge Accusing Attorneys Of Senate Unit of Profit Motive
description: ATLANTA, June 10 (UPI)  Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, said today that the Senate Select Committee on Ethics had presented no evidence against me in five weeks of hearings on his finances, and accused staff attorneys of prolonging his political ordeal for their own profit.

title: Troop Strength A Key Problem At Bases in U.S.
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  The young, helmeted troops climbed slowly down Owl Creek Ridge, fiercely gripping ropes and dangling in the air as sergeants shouted, Hold tight, hold tight, move slow!

title: National DraftKennedy Backers Hail Senator at Minnesota Rally
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 10  The movement to draft Edward M. Kennedy as the Democratic candidate for President in 1980, converging at an organizational rally here today, loudly exhorted the Massachusetts Senator to run, while it harshly criticized Jimmy Carter as an incumbent who had betrayed his party and his principles.

title: Armed Man in Siege Surrenders
description: NORTH OLMSTED, Ohio, June 10 (UPI)  An armed man who locked and barricaded himself in an apartment on an upper floor of an 18story building surrendered at 5 P.M. today to end a 20hour siege. Police Capt. Thomas Marsh said the man had fired several shots early in the siege but no one was hurt. He said the man's name was not being released until charges were filed.

title: Phillips Cuts Fuel Estimate
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla. June 8 (UPI)  The Phillips Norway Group, representing the Phillips Petroleum Company and various foreign oil interests, lowered its estimate today of oil and gas reserves in the greater Ekofisk area in the Norwegian North Sea from 4.4 billion barrels to 3.7 billion barrels of oil and oil equivalent. Peak production rates were not revised, however, remaining at the anticipated 575,000 to 625,000 barrels of oil a day in the early 1980's.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN Judge Pierre N. Leval ruled in favor Edper Equities Ltd. in that company's efforts to keep 30 percent of Brascan Ltd., he appeared to open a broad new road for takeovers.

title: Deaths
description: BATTINELLIR. Louise, on June 9, beloved wife of the late S. Louis, devoted mother to Robert R., Norma and Louis. Also survived by ten grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. Friends may call Monday and Tuesday, 2.5 and 79 PM at Frank E. Campbell. Madison Ave. at 81 St. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Francis DeSales, 135 E. 9 St. Interment at St. John's Cemetery, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Survivors Remember the General Slocum
description: Seventyfive years ago this week on a sunny June morning, an explosion and fire swept through the excursion steamship General Slocum, claiming the lives of 1,021 persons on their way up the East River to a picnic.

title: POPE ENDS HIS TRIP TO POLAND, CALLING FOR RENEWED FAITH
description: CRACOW, Poland, June 10  Pope John Paul II concluded his triumphal nineday visit to Poland today with a mass before a million people, and said that the trip had raised Poland to a new level of historical maturity.

title: Washington Watch
description: THEY said it could never happen, but Saudi Arabia, of all countries, now seems to be running short of cash. At least that is one explanation for a quiet drawing down since the middle of last year of Saudi holdings of United States Treasury securities, in which much of Saudi reserves are kept.

title: William McCullam, 66, ExChief Of Editorialists at Hearst Papers
description: William Frank McCullam, who retired last year as chief national editorial writer for the Hearst Newspapers, died Friday at New York University Hospital after brief illness. Mr. McCullam, who lived in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.. was 66 years old.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Transformation

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Last month the South African Government took steps that seemed to promise a substantial easing of racial discrimination. The Rand Daily Mail, usually critical, saw more hope of change than we have had in the nearly thirtyone years that the Nationalist Government has been in power. There was approving comment from abroad.

title: News Summary
description: The Pope ended his trip to Poland with a plea for a renewal of the strength of the Catholic faith of the Polish people. Before his departure, he celebrated a pontifical mass before one million people on Cracow's Blonie Parade Ground, where he said that his visit had raised Poland to a new level of maturity. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: De Gustibus And Now on the East Coast, a Source for Caviar
description: We wrote some weeks ago of a burgeoning fresh caviar business recently begun on the West Coast. Now comes a note concerning a source for fresh locally produced caviar.

title: Formulation of New York City's Budget Is Explained
description: Politicians are continuing to tinker with changes at the fringes of the $12.8 billion New York City budget, but there is agreement on the basic budget for the next fiscal year.

title: Mrs. Young Takes L.P.G.A. Title by 3 Shots
description: KINGS ISLAND, Ohio, June 10 Donna Caponi Young, who won the first of her two United States Women's Open championships 10 years ago, gained her third major title today by winning the 25th annual Ladies Professional Golf Association championship.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AIRBORNE The outdoor performances last year by the sevenmember Battery Dance Company, which is based in SoHo, were a, splash of welcome color in various city parks. Today the troupe begins its third annual series, presenting two, different programs. The series will end early next month as part of the Harbor Festival.

title: At a Queens High School, The Prom Isn't Outdated
description: This was the senior prom of a high school on Main Street in Flushing, Queens. It could have been any senior prom, any high school, any main street. It was as inconsequential as a pair of patentleather shoes, as momentous as a diploma tied with a silk cord.

title: The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee
description: With booming bands, fluttering flags and swirling skirts, thousands of Puerto Ricans marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday and then swarmed over Central Park for an allday fiesta that went into the night.

title: Letters
description: To my great dismay, The Times is once again espousing a shortsighted, easy answer to our energy problem the export of Alaskan oil (The Oil That's Waiting for Congress, editorial May 30).

title: Yanks Triumph On Big 7th, 104
description: KANSAS CITY, June 10  If you think about it, it made sense that Steve Mingori of the Royals started against the Yankees today, even if he had pitched only 122/3 innings this season and had started only one major league game in 10 seasons.

title: German Central Bank Post at Stake
description: BONN, June 10  The Bundesbank, the physical manifestation of West Germany's economic stability and powerful currency, may be in for a change at the top.

title: Soviet Avows Atheism After Pope's Remarks
description: MOSCOW, June 10 (AP)  As Pope John Paul II ended his historic visit to Poland today, the Soviet press printed a declaration by a Communist Party leader calling for viligance In enforcing the official Soviet policy of atheism.

title: BRUCE CARNER
description: Bruce Carner, a builder of homes in Brooklyn and on Staten Island, died yesterday at his home in West Hempstead, L.I. He was 45 years old.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Joyeuse, Debussy; La Coranto; The Frog Galliard, Anonymous; Summer Night on the River, Delius; Pavane, Dowland; Ogives, Satie.

title: History Catches Up to HoffaKennedy Book
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10  Last February, a manuscript was delivered to Ballantine Books linking James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and two organizedcrime figures, Carlos Marcello and Santos Trafficante, to the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: Dorothy Grant Married At Home to Jesse Slome
description: Dorothy R. Grant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Grant of Fair Haven, N.J., was married yesterday at her home to Jesse R. Slome, son of Hanna Slome of New York and the late Henry W. Slome. Rabbi Jack M. Rosoff performed the ceremony.

title: Engineer and Former F.A.A. Aide Will Head Teams Studying DC10
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  A prominent aeronautical engineer and a retired regional director of the Federal Aviation Administration havebeen chosen to head the investigating teams that will study the illfated DC10 and try to clear it for a resumption of service.

title: Fiedler Has Mild Heart Attack
description: BOSTON, June 10 (Reuters)  Arthur Fiedler, conductor of the Boston Pops Orchestra, was reported in stable condition at New England Medical Center tonight after suffering a mild heart attack, a hospital spokesman said. The 84yearold maestro, who has had four other heart attacks since the age of 50, was stricken last night.

title: An Element Of Chance
description: GRANTLAND RICE was a horseplayer, a racing fan and a realist, in that order. Late in his illustrious life, the realist forced the player to a mournful conclusion: There is a certain element of chance horse racing.

title: 9 Triumphant Days in Poland
description: CRACOW, Poland, June 10  Pope John Paul II, in nine triumphant days in Poland, has made himself a totally novel and incalculable element in future EastWest relations.

title: School Lunch Skirmish Illuminates Battle of the Budget in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  A little drama that was played out on the floor of Congress last week illustrates how difficult it is to translate the rhetoric of budgetcutting into reality.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: HIS devoted wife once told Gladstone, Oh, William, dear, if you weren't such a great man you would be a terrible bore. Certainly a sense of humor was not among his gifts. His enemy Disraeli remarked, He has not.

title: Voice From the Past Offers Encouragement to Women Coal Miners
description: INSTITUTE, W. Va.,'June 10  A half century ago, a slight, fairskinned miner's wife named Florence Reese tipped a page off a calendar that hung in a kitchen and quietly, almost methodically, wrote the lyrics of a song that has since become an anthem for union organizers.

title: Marjorie Brooks Is Bride Of Dr. Stephen Goldstone
description: Marjorie Lynn Brooks, a nurse in cardiothoracic surgery at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, was married yesterday in Lynbrook, L.I., to Dr. Stephen Elliot Goldstone, a 1979 graduate of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine at Yeshiva University. Rabbi Harold Saperstein performed the ceremony at Temple EmanuEl.

title: ARAB CITY PROTESTS ISRAELI SETTLEMENT
description: NABLUS, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, June 10  Arabs in this fiercely nationalistic city of 50,000, the largest in the West Bank, demonstrated today against a new Jewish settlement on a nearby hill, but Israeli soldiers ordered shopkeepers to reopen businesses that had been closed this morning in protest.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Lovers of the oldfashioned highwheeler can obtain newly made fullsize reproductions from Rideable Bicycle Replicas of 2443 Telegraph Avenue, Oakland, Calif. 94612, (415) 4441666. The company's custommade facsimiles come either in a standard black finish or in nickel, chrome, brass or copper plate, depending on the design you choose. In addition to the madetoorder bikes, there are regular models that are usually in ready supply, such as the Penny Farthing (with a large front wheel), the Flying Arrow (with a small front wheel and a large rear wheel), the Family Sociable (a fourwheeler) and the Courting Cycle (with a front seat for a chaperone). The price will run from $500 to $1,500, depending on model and finish. Order directly, adding a $40 freight charge, or through Le Petit Bicycle Rental, 213 West 58th Street, Manhattan, (212) 5814960.

title: Torture's Teachers
description: LOS ANGELES  A few months ago, I received some clippings of interviews with a former Federal intelligence agency official. That operative, Jesse Leaf, had been involved with the agency's activities in Iran, and well into the stories Mr. Leaf made some damning accusations.

title: Eight Dance Companies In Series Starting Oct 13
description: Eight American and international dance companies will perform next season in a series of programs sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College. The Cloudgate Dance Theater of Taiwan will make its North American debut, opening the series Oct. 13 and 14.

title: New Books
description: Adding Room, Saving Energy, by William M. Cowan (Macmillan, $12.95). Illustrated howto.

title: Role of Banks Challenged In Unfriendly Takeovers
description: In preparation for an attempted takeover of the Washington Steel Com, pany a few months ago, Talley Industries, the company that makes Big Ben and Baby Ben clocks, arranged with the Chemical Bank of New York to borrow $70 million.

title: Amy Ernst Is Wed To Eric D. Johnson
description: Amy Louise Ernst, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jimmy Ernst of East Hampton, L.I., and granddaughter of the late Max Ernst, the Surrealist artist, was married yesterday in Rye, N.Y., to Eric Donald Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Johnson of Katonah, N.Y. Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg of the State Court of Appeals performed the ceremony at the Westchester Country Club.

title: Two Killed in Japan Street Fight
description: KAWASAKI, Japan, June 10 (AP) Two persons were killed and one seriously injured in what police believed was a fight between rival radical groups in Kawasaki, 15 miles south of Tokyo, a police spokesman said today. The spokesman said a gang of seven young men armed with steel pipes attacked a group of 10 students on a street last night.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bangor Punta Corporation, Greenwich, Conn., primarily a manufacturing company, has named Joe Gessiness president and chief operating officer and Peter Lemanis vice president and general manager of its finance subsidiary, the Bangor Punta Acceptance C.orporation, Goshen, Ind.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times last Thursday that DC10 airplanes belonging to Air Canada had been grounded. Air Canada has no DC10 jets.

title: Before They Leave Albany
description: Members of the New York State Legislature are straining to leave Albany for home but there is still urgently needed work to do. Some people may have more priorities, than others but we think any mustlist should include the following mixture of action and, just as important inaction.

title: Pamela Long Bride Of Stephen Mattson
description: In St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Warwick, R.I., yesterday afternoon, Pamela Jean Long, daughter of Mrs. William Long of Warwick and the late Mr. Long, was married to Stephen Edward Mattson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Edward Mattson of Stamford, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Kenneth Roderick Franklin.

title: Museum of New York City Salutes Child Stage Stars
description: To honor child performers who have graced the city's stages, the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, is mounting an exhibition of costumes, posters and memorabilia that will go on display tomorrow. The show, titled Child Stars of the New York Stage: Little Evas, Lord Fauntle. roys and Armies, will run Oct. 28.

title: Bridge:
description: GOSIER, Guadeloupe, June 10  The battling foursome from Mexico, which seemed down and out on Friday night, became champions of the Central American and Caribbean Zone here last night and are probably going to compete in the 1979 World Team Championship in Rio de Janeiro next October. Having solved all their problems at the bridge table, they now need to overcome some administrative hurdles.

title: U.S. Urged To Induce Slowdown
description: BASEL, June 10  The Bank for International Settlements urged President Carter today to push the United States economy into a mild recession now in order to avoid the possibil ity that a major world recession would develop later on.

title: New Index Shows a U.S. Lag
description: A new index of leading economic indicators of seven major industrial countries showed that comparable indexes of six foreign nations advanced an average of about 8 percent during a 12month period, while leading United States economic indicators edged up only percent.

title: $1 Billion TaxFree List
description: Yields on taxexempt bonds dropped last week to their lowest levels yet in 1979, and a heavy schedule of new offerings is set for this week.

title: 2 Former Pullman Executives Say New York Transit Aide Took Bribes
description: Two former high executives of Pullman Inc. have charged that at least one Transit Authority official responsible for the testing and installation of 754 problemridden subway cars took bribes from employees of Pullman, the contractor for the new equipment.

title: Casting Off
description: Armstead's Whitewater Rafting Guide of Rivers and Outfitters in the Eastern United States is a booklet that describes 20 whitewater rafting rivers along the East Coast. It tells where to go, equipment needed, best times for rafting, costs involved and what to wear. To get a copy, send $1.50 to the publisher, the Candid Photo Corporation, P.O, Box 631, Herndon, Va. 22070.

title: Jackson Marks 40th Year in Jazz
description: THE celebration of Milt Jackson's 90th year in jazz at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening had a few threads leading to the past and a brief glimpse of the future. But most of the evening was the contemporary Milt Jackson, a concentration made possible by the fact that Mr. Jackson's approach to the vibraharp has remained virtually unchanged over most of his career.

title: Retirees Help to Defeat School Budgets
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., June 8  As some gloomy officials sat in the Town Hall here the other night tabulating the results of the latest referendum on the school budget, a man who had been grumbling in the corridor about the villagers poked his head in the door and announced to no one in particular:

title: Natalie Lichtenstein, Lawyer, Wed to Willard Ken Tom
description: Natalie Lichtenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abba Lichtenstein of Tenafly, N.J., was married at noon yesterday to Willard Ken Tom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hing Yee Tom of Honolulu. Cantor Jerry Heller of New City, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Lichtenstein home.

title: Michiganders Split Over Indian Fishing
description: BAY MILLS, Mich. June 8  The question of Indian fishing rights, already a burning issue in the Northwest, has found its way to upper Michigan, where the conflict between sports fishermen and the Indians has everyone talking violence and a few committing it.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter plans to take a tough line on oil prices and supply when he talks with this country's allies late this month at the sevennation economic summit meeting in Tokyo, Administration officials say. The President, they add, will take a hard line toward OPEC and insist that American allies cooperate in this. [Page A1.]

title: Advertising
description: THE latest round in the Coke vs. Pepsi feud is a victory for Coke. A panel of the National Advertising Review Board, advertising's selfregulation court of last resort, has supported a CocaCola claim that had been challenged by PepsiCola.

title: Philharmonic: Premiere Of Druckman's Aureole
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN'S second special concert with the New York Philharmonic last week took place in Avery Fisher Hall Saturday night, and it featured the world premiere of Jacob Druckman's Aureole, commissioned by the Philharmonic and Mr. Bernstein. This was the second new work by Mr. Druckman that the orchestra has introduced this season, the earlier one being a Viola Concerto performed last November.

title: 2 New Yorkers Dead and 8 Injured In Blast of Dud Rocket at Ft. Dix
description: A bazooka rocket, thought to be a dud, killed two New York men and wounded eight others when it exploded in Fort Dix, N.J., in the midst of a New York National Guard unit early yesterday, officials of the training base reported.

title: Robert Langan Marries Sara Weber, Ph.D. Intern
description: Sara Weber, daughter of Harry Weber and the late Edith Weber, was married yesterday to Robert Langan, son of Mrs. Richard Van Bolt of Brooklyn and the late Robert Langan,of Kodiak, Alaska. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bridegroom's mother and stepfather by Rabbi Roy A. Rosenthal.

title: Degrees in Law Given First Time At Two Schools
description: Three years ago, after some false starts, two new law schools opened in the metropolitan area: Pace University School of Law in White Plains and Yeshiva University's Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in Manhattan. And yesterday they held their first commencements.

title: The Tisch Investment Strategy
description: Sometimes referred to as the liveliest family act in American business, the brothers Tisch pop up in the most unlikely business situations, usually with a heavy investment or takeover bid involving an undervalued company or a financial interest in an industry long out of favor.

title: Nashville Swan Ball: It's No Small Change
description: NASHVILLE, June 10  A party is a party is a party. No, no, no. A quarter of a million dollars net, which is what the Swan Ball ended up making last year, and hopes to make this year, is no small change, even in big board rooms.

title: Rebuilt After Crippling Fire, Church is Rededicated
description: Worshipers held a service of rededication yesterday in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in Hollis, Queens. Occasion marked a complete rebuilding following destruction of church by vandals who built a bonfire inside on July 15, 1974. The vandals were never found, but church members restored the sanctuary, then added a school and library.

title: Bobby Unser Wins Twice
description: TRENTON, June 10 (AP)  Bobby Unser broke a threeyear victory drought today, sweeping both ends of the Trenton TwinIndy at the International Speedway. The event was sanctioned by Championship Auto Racing Teams.

title: Ozawa, Man of 2 Worlds, Turns to Opera
description: PARIS, June 10  Seiji Ozawa, who won his first conducting prize in France and learned to love Paris as a poor student, is back now buying his baguette and fresh milk in the morning, cleaning his own room, learning new music. But this time, it is in triumph, opening the St. Denis music festival tomorrow night with a tremendous performance of Mahler's Eighth Symphony and conducting at the Opera.

title: Song: Barbara Schardt
description: ALTHOUGH Barbara Schardt's singing Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was not the sort that captures the attention of vocal connoisseurs, on its own terms it was confident and exuberant, and a capacity audience of friends and admirers went home well satisfied.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Ever since I first heard the expression It's great to be young and a Yankee, I have naturally assumed that the sentiment was originally voiced by some New York Yankee player. Now a friend of mine tells me that the original expression Vas actually It's great to be young and a Giant, that it was voiced by a member of the old New York Giants. Who is right?

title: Unusual Alliance Defends. Housing Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  When a fractious HousesWays and Means Committee took up a bill last week to outlaw the use of taxfree bonds for housing construction, an unusual ideological alliance was struck among members from New York.

title: Sister Theresa Falls; A College President And Official in Order
description: Sister Theresa Falls, president of the College of New Rochelle from 1963 10 1970, died Saturday in New York City. Sister Theresa, who lived in the Bronx, was 67 years old.

title: CARTER IS EXPECTED TO PUSH U.S. ALLIES FOR TOUGH OIL LINE
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  President Carter's strategy for the sevennation economic summit meeting in Tokyo this month promises a tough attitude toward American allies on the question of oil prices and supplies, Administration officials have disclosed.

title: London Cabbies Threaten Tieup
description: LONDON, June 10 (AP)  London's 2,000 cab drivers, angry at government delays in approving fare increases, threatened today to mount a traffic jam around Buckingham Palace to disrupt the state visit to Britain of President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya on Tuesday. The cab drivers say that gasoline prices have gone up nearly 40 percent in two months and they need higher fares to offset the increases.

title: Parents of Missing SoHo Boy, 6, Spend a 17th Day Without Word
description: The streets of SoHo were bustling with the usual weekend tourists yesterday, but it was a long, slow Sunday in Stanley and Julie Patz's loft apartment on Prince Street.

title: Notes on People
description: Now that she's free on parole and living in New York City again, Joan Little is at work on the speech she hopes to deliver as the commencement speaker at a Queens high school.

title: Trainer Says Bid Ran Hurt
description: Spectacular Bid's puzzling defeat in the 111th Belmont Stakes raised a bizarre new question yesterday when the colt's trainer put the blame for the loss on a pre race leg injury.

title: World News Briefs
description: HONG KONG, June 10 (Reuters)  An additional 2,400 Vietnamese refugees arrived in Hong Kong today in a fleet of 27 small boats.

title: Soviet Papers Report Ski Unit Has Reached North Pole Over Floes
description: The Soviet Union has disclosed that a team of seven skiers has reached the North Pole after covering 900 miles in 77 days across the ice of the Arctic Ocean.

title: Dr. Rene E. Fox Married To Dr. Philip Paul Breitfeld
description: Dr. Rene Ellen Fox and Dr. Philip Paul Breitfeld, who received M.D. degrees last month from the University of Rochester, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in West Brighton, S.I. Rabbi Milton Rosenfeld performed the ceremony.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: Seniors Hear Dr. Marshak's Last City College Address
description: Addressing his last commencement audience as president of City College, Dr. Robert E. Marshak warned yesterday afternoon of the dangers of internal divisiveness to the great social ideal of the college.

title: ROLE OF ISSUES HELD MINOR FOR 80 RACE
description: The American people say tney would be more likely to vote for Presidential candidates who back wage and price controls, a strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union and government health insurance and who oppose more nuclear power plants. But at least for now they are rarely deciding to like specific candidates because of those issues.

title: Donizetti Variations Revived
description: DONIZETTI Variations is one of those light ballets by George Balanchine that are too good to drop from the repertory and yet not deep enough to be considered major works. Yet when Donizetti Variations has the kind of outstanding performance from every member of the cast that the New York City Ballet gave it Saturday night at the State Theater, it becomes a ballet with a bright new allure of its own.

title: P.L.O., Shaken by EgyptIsrael Treaty, Seeks to Force U.S. to Accept Its Status
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  We will force the United States to recognize us. Without the Palestine Liberation Organization there is not going to be any peace in the Middle East.

title: Dr. Delia NaiYueh Sang Bride at Harvard
description: In the Memorial Church on the Harvard campus in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday, Dr. Delia NaiYueh Sang, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. HengKang Sang of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married to Dr. John Braverman Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Levine of Lowell, Mass. The Rev. Carl Scovel, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Squeezed
description: WASHINGTON  There was a time when a fool and his money were soon parted, but now it happens to everybody. ne late Senator Adlai Stevenson's remark is more apropos than ever. The 1.1 percent increase in the consumer price index recorded in April, up onetenth from March, means a 13.2 percent rate of inflation for the first four months of 1979 (as opposed to 9 percent in 1978).

title: John Slate Weds Lisa Hampton
description: In the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Lisa Scott Hampton, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Hately Hampton of Greenwich, was married to John Hampton Slate, son of Mary Ellen Slate of Port Washington, L.I., and the late John Hampton Slate. The Rev. Mark Pawlowski performed the ceremony. Dr. Hampton is a psychiatrist. The bridegroom's mother is an editor of Antiques World magazine. His father was a lawyer.

title: Dr. Ellen Frankel, Intern, Is Married
description: The marriage of Dr. Ellen Frankel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard J. Frankel of Woodbury, L.I., to Frederick Jaccarino Jr. took place yesterday at the Huntington (L.I.) Town House. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. Jaccarino of Stamford, Conn., and Gloria Jaccarino of Riverside, Conn. Rabbis Daniel Fogel and Stephen Stein officiated.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: To a growing segment of the credit markets, seeing is believing. As bonds last week continued to rally for the fourth consecutive week, more traders, analysts and investors shed their doubts and adopted the view that interest rates had finally peaked.

title: General in Guatemala Murdered in Ambush
description: GUATEMALA, June 10 (AP)  The chief of staff of the Guatemalan Army, Gen. Jose David Cansinos, 52 years old, was machinegunned to death tonight as he rode through the southeastern part of the city, a national police spokesman reported.

title: Commodities
description: FOURdollar July! Wheat traders had not heard that cry since the summer of 1975. And when it boomed out of the vast Chicago Board of Trade wheat pit last Friday it echoed through all commodity futures markets, signaling higher food costs and more inflation.

title: Medicare Waste on Care Of Elderly Cited in Study
description: A shortage of beds in nursing homes is unnecessarily prolonging the hospital stays of elderly patients, wasting hundreds of millions of dollars a year in Medicare funds, a Federal report has found.

title: Paris Show Lures Plane Producers
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  The international aviation and aerospace community converged on Paris this weekend in the biennial bid for sales known as the Paris Air Show.

title: Brezhnev Calls Parley With Carter Key Step In Overall Relations
description: MOSCOW, June 11  Leonid I. Brezhnev today described his Vienna meeting later. this week with President Carter as an important stage of further development of SovietAmerican relations that would advance arms control and the prevention of nuclear war.

title: Samuel L. Snyder, 97; Plumbing Concern Head
description: Samuel L. Snyder, believed to be the oldest licensed plumber in New York State, died Sunday at his home in Yonkers. He was 97 years old.

title: Stage: 'scrambled Feet
description: TOWARDS the end of the collection of skits assembled under the title Scrambled Feet, the four perforinerS place a duck named Hermione on top of their piano. All interest centers on whether the duck will or will not fertilite the Piano; meanwhile, Evalyn Baron, one of the perfcirmers, sings a song adviSing against..sharing the stage with an animal.

title: President Seeks to Increase Cutting Of Timber in the National Forests
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  President Carter announced today that he would try again to increase the cutting of timber from the national forests in another attempt to check the rising costs of housing.

title: Winter Wheat Forecast Raised by 3%
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)  This year's winter wheat crop is estimated at 1.93 billion bushels, a 3 percent larger forecast than last month, the Agriculture Department said today. ne latest estimate, based on field conditions as of June 1, also is up 14 percent from the 1978 winter wheat harvest, which was the smallest in five years. A month ago the crop was estimated at 1.39 billion bushels. The 1978 harvest was less than 1.25 billion bushels.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY. JUNE 11. 1979

title: Taxes
description: CONGRESS is considering giving firsttime home buyers an individual tax credit as a substitute for the reducedrate mortgages that some state and local governments have been providing through the sale of taxexempt bonds.

title: Hanoi Regime Reported Resolved To Oust Nearly All Ethnic Chinese
description: HONG KONG, June 11  Vietnam appears determined to expel virtually all the members of its ethnic Chinese minority and is exacting hundreds of millions of dollars from them before their departure, much of it to repay Soviet aid and arms sales, according to refugees and intelligence sources here.

title: More U.S. Aid Is Urged For Jobs for City Youth
description: Representative Elizabeth Holtzman and Councilman Antonio G. Olivieri said yesterday at City Hall that they had sent a telegram to President Carter urging him to increase funds for New York City summer youthjobs from the current $32.3 million for 54,000 jobs.

title: Q&A
description: Q.What did legionnaire's disease finatty turn out to be and what are its general symptoms?

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in SportsMonday yesterday that the Metropolitan Golf Association had begun clinics for junior players. The program is being administered by the Metropolitan P.G.A.

title: EARNINGS G.&W. Net Up 17% in Quarter
description: Gulf and Western Industries Inc. has reported earnings increases of 17 percent for the third fiscal quarter and 36 percent for the nine months ended April 30, setting profit records for the periods.

title: CART in Bid To End Feud With USAC
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 11 (AP) Championship Auto Racing Teams, in what was called a goodfaith move toward the United States Auto Club, said tonight it would not conduct a race at Trenton on June 24 and will present to USAC tomorrow a proposal to end the sixmonth feud between the rival racing factions.

title: Super Valu Reaches Accord With A.&P.
description: Super Valu Stores Inc., the nation's largest grocery wholesaler, said it had completed an agreement with the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company that will allow independent grocery retailers affiliated with Super Valu to sublet 73 supermarkets closed by A.&P. earlier this year.

title: Engine Fire on DC3 Causes Crash in Idaho
description: GRANGEVILLE, Idaho, June 11 (UPI)  A DC3 carrying 12 United States Forest Service employees on a halfhour flight dropped an engine today and plunged into a turbulent northern Idaho river. At least two persons survived, including one who walked 10 miles to a ranger station.

title: Most Iran Bank Units in City Optimistic
description: The white picture hook stands out against the dark wood paneling where the portraits of the Shah of Iran and his Empress used to hang in the New York agency of Bank Sanaye Iran.

title: Prisoner Convicted in 1977 East Side Murder Flees Jail on Rikers Island
description: A 20yearold Manhattan man who was sentenced last month to 15 years to life imprisonment for a burglarymurder in 1977 escaped yesterday from the Rikers Island Adolescent Reception and Detention Shelter.

title: Women Attempt to Get Own TV Station
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Two years ago Laurel Vlock, a Connecticut teteviSian personality, attended the National Women's Conference in Houston and was inspired by the impact of the women's movement. She was so inspired, in fact, that she came home and convinced 10 women to join her in apt:dying for a local television license.

title: Mortgages Sold To Yield 11.142%
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported that it purchased $71.8 million of home mortgages yesterday at an average yield of 11.142 percent, the highest rate since the agency began operations in 1971. Last week, the rate was 11.042 percent.

title: Falconbridge, Amax Raise Nickel Prices
description: Two major producers of nickel, metal used extensively in stainless steel and other alloys, announced price increases yesterday, bringing most of the nickel industry above $3 a pound for the first time.

title: G.I.'s in Europe Called Ready, if Less Skilled
description: FULDA, West Germany  A hard rain pelted Observation Post India, which overlooks a metal grid fence that separates East and West Germany. Sgt. Jerry Smith peered through binoculars at two East German soldiers moving along a steep slope on a motorcycle.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MEN OF THE HOUSE Bloomingdale's is heralding Father's Day next Sunday with something different  the sound of music  each afternoon starting today in the groundfloor men's department of the store, at 59th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues. The music ranges from medieval to now, and the public is invited to stop by and tune in free each noon until around 3 P.M.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Because of trashremoval problems during the tugboat strike, alternateside parking regulations will be in effect today and tomorrow in Manhattan and Brooklyn only.

title: Harper &
description: Harper & Row Publishers reported yesterday that it had a net loss of $1.2 million for the fourth fiscal quarter ended April 30, in contrast to profit of $409,000, or 18 cents a share, in the 1978 Quarter.

title: CORRECTION
description: Representative Ted Weiss's OpEd article on June 6 incorrectly identified the authors of the PriceAnderson Act, who were Representative Melvin Price (D.Ill.) and the late Senator Clinton P. Anderson (D.N.M.).

title: How to Help
description: The advances of microsurgery that have made reattachment of severed parts possible means that witnesses can play crucial roles in aiding accident victims.

title: Jews and Christians Worship Together
description: Standing next to a cross, a prominent rabbi read from the Old Testament, while 50 Jews and Christians responded with amens last Wednesday in St. Peter's Lutheran Church on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan.

title: EDMOND HANRAIIAN, FORMER S.E.C. HEAD
description: Manhattan Lawyer, 73, Defended Commission in Eaton Dispute Edmond Martin Hanrahan, a Manhattan lawyerwho served as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and as a New York State Racing Commissioner, died Sunday at Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived in Spring Lake, N.J., where he had moved from New York City a few years ago. mr. Hanrahan was associated with the law firm of Sullivan, Donovan, Hanrahan & Silliere since his graduation from Fordham Law School in 1929. He became partner in 1933, specializing in bank reorganizations and trial hearings.

title: U.S. Acknowledges Possibility of a Uranium Theft
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission suggested today that 200 pounds of highly enriched uranium might have been stolen from a Pennsylvania nuclear plant in the mid1960's.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, S P.M. RadioWINS, 8 P.M.)

title: Weekend Fight
description: STOCKTON, Calif.  Darrel Penn, Portland, Ore., outpointed Rudy Barro, Sacramento, 10 rounds, welterweights.

title: Breaking Bus Jams
description: One of the most persistent, annoying and misunderstood of all New York City's transit problems is the phenomenon of buses that arrive at their stops in packs of four or five, after long, busless intervals.

title: Carter Unit Recommends Easing of Bribery Law
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  A White House task force on United States exports has drafted recommendations for President Carter that call for immediate weakening and eventual abandonment of key provisions in the law that prohibits payment of bribes overseas by American corporations.

title: Winding Down in Trenton
description: New Jersey lawmakers are moving fast toward recess, but before they leave Trenton they should take up at least four measures. Each will require the legislators to oppose some vested interest.

title: Richard T. Lyons, at 83; Oil Exploration Leader
description: HOUSTON, June 11  Richard T. Lyons, retired president of the Union Texas National Gas Corporation and pioneer in the use of scientific techniques in petroleum exploration, died here yesterday after a short illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In his June 4 column, How to Hurt Sadat, Anthony Lewis sidestepped the most salient point, namely that the Camp David agreement stipulated free movement, including settlement, for both Jews and Arabs on the West Bank. Referring to legitimate settlers as squatters is unworthy of Mr. Lewis.

title: Energy Dept. Gets Oil Data Auditor
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Amid a debate over the accuracy of its oil figures, the Energy Department is hiring an outside auditing firm.

title: DEAF STUDENT LOSES HIGH COURT APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Federal law does not require a college either to accept a student whose handicap prevents him from meeting the requirements of a particular program or to provide extensive modifications

title: Study Peeks At Spiders Courtship
description: IT has long been known that the male spider faces the challenge of mating without being eaten by the female. Only now, however, are the diverse strategies used by the male to cope with this danger coming to light.

title: Manhattan's Hotel Shortage Sending Juries Out of Town
description: Sequestered juries from State Supreme Court in Manhattan are sleeping as far away as Red Bank, N.J., and Riverhead, L.I., because of the shortage of hotel rooms in New York City.

title: Consumer Antitrust Suit Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that consumers who believe that antitrust violators are forcing them to pay higher prices can sue the violators for triple damages under the Clayton Antitrust Act.

title: IN THE NATION Who Needs the MX?
description: After telling the National Security Council the other day that he would approve fullscale development of the MX mobile intercontinental ballistic missile, President Carter is reported to have said, I feel confident with this decision.

title: Earthquake Felt in California
description: CONCORD, Calif., June 11 (AP)  A mild earthquake shuddered through the Diablo Valley early today, the authorities said. The quake hit at 4:52 A.M. and registered 3.0 on the Richter scale, said James Stifler, a seismologist at the University of California Seismograph Station.

title: Conservatives Gain in Europe's Voting
description: PARIS, June 11  Nearly complete results from the European Community's first direct elections showed today a general move toward conservatism.

title: Court to Decide if Black English Is a Language and a Learning Barrier
description: DETROIT, June 11  Is black English,  which many black Americans use regularly  a distinctive language or just a dialect?

title: Turkey Announces 43% Lira Value Cut
description: ANKARA, Turkey, June 11 (Reu: tern)  Turkey, bowing to Western pressure in return for promised massive aid, tonight announced a new multiplerate system for its lira, amounting to a de facto devaluation of between 24 and 43 percent against Western currencies.

title: Tire Blowout Halts DC8 Takeoff
description: HONOLULU, June 11 (UPI)  An Air New Zealand DC8 carrying 134 passengers and 10 crew members bound for Aukland, N.Z., was forced to abort takeoff yesterday at Honolulu International Airport because of a tire blowout.

title: Herbert S. Polesie Dies; 20 Questions Panelist
description: Herbert S. Polesie, a producer and director in the early days of radio and television, most popularly known as a panelist on the radio and television show 20 Questions, died Friday at Mercy Hospital in Marina Del Rey, Calif. He was 79 years old and had lived in Marina Del Rey for the last year.

title: Pope John Paul II Flies To Alban Hills for Rest
description: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy. June 11 (UPI)  Pope John Paul II flew by helicopter today to the papal summer palace in the cool Alban Hills south of Rome for two days of rest from his historic trip to Poland.

title: Business Records
description: ROBERT W. MI EL ISH, 15 Morris Road, Spring Valley, N.Y. Liabilities, not listed; assets,S3,755.

title: New Books
description: In Transition, by Judith M. Bardwick (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $8.95). How feminism, sexual liberation and the search for selffulfillment have altered lives.

title: Jesse Abramson Dies at 75
description: Jesse Abramson, a sportswriter for 56 years who was noted for his coverage of track and boxing, died at the age of 75. An obituary appears on page D19.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Owner of a Bookstore Wins Appeal on Obscenity Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The Supreme Court today unanimously overturned the conviction of a New York bookstore owner charged with violating that state's obscenity law. The Justices ruled that the procedure used by the police had deprived him of his constitutional right against unreasonable search and seizure. The procedure involved an openended search warrant that did not specify the material to be seized and also involved the active participation of a local judge in a sixhour search through the store's inventory

title: For Fare Cuts to Finance Our Transit System
description: To start the Metropolitan Transit Authority on its way back toward providing economical, reliable, safe transportation, drastic steps beyond the conventional are required.

title: Richard Rodgers With Nothing in Mind
description: WHAT might a man want to do next after he has spent 60 years writing music, much of it the best of its times, for musical comedies?

title: Yemen Seeks U.S. Aid on Border Force
description: SANA, Yemen, June 6  Yemeni leaders are urging the United States to train and equip a special mobile force to defend their borders against incursions from neighboring Marxist Southern Yemen.

title: Fraunces Tavern Gallery Begun
description: Construction has begun at 54 Pearl Street on a gallery for the Fraunces Tavern Museum. The Adeline Moses Loeb Gallery, next to the tavern where Washington bade farewell to his officers in 1783, is to be completed in October.

title: PRAYERS IN SCHOOLS APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The House of Representatives voted today to permit voluntary prayers in the public schools and to ban busing of students to achieve racial balance.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD  Workmen began repairing a leaky valve yesterday in the primary cooling system of the Millstone II nuclearpower plant at Waterford, and company officials said they expected the plant to be back in operation by tomorrow.

title: Schlesinger: A Study In Survival Under Fire
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  After 22 months in one of the Administration's toughest jobs as the first Energy Secretary, James R. Schlesinger has acquired an uncoveted reputation as the most criticized member of President Carter's Cabinet.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Decline
description: Treasury bill rates dropped sharply yesterday, falling to their lowest levels since late last fall.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1979

title: Jackson, Johnson Get Good Reports
description: While the Yankees had a day off in Minneapolis yesterday, Reggie Jackson in New York had the splint removed from his left leg and replaced by an elastic bandage.

title: Letters
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES: The instructions on how to construct a cylindrical wing were as simple as pi. [Toying With a Flying Cylinder, June 5.]

title: 187 U.S. Craft Hijacked Since 61
description: According to Government figures, a total of 187 United States airliners have been successfully hijacked since May 1, 1961, when Antulio Rameriez Ortiz, a 30yearold Puerto Rican became the first person to commandeer an American plane and force it to fly out of the country. Mr. Ortiz, who used a steak knife and a gun to take over a National Airlines twinengine Convair on a flight from Miami to Key West, forced the pilot to fly to Cuba, which has been the favorite destination of American hijackers ever since.

title: Skylab Nears Its Dengers Plunge
description: WASHINGTON THE Skylab space station, a onetime symbol of man's ability to habitate space that now seems emblematic of man's inability to plan ahead, slowly dropping back to earth, coming 100 yards closer to destruction with every revolution of the globe.

title: Science Watch
description: A radar technique that measures both the size and number of falling raindrops may give meteorologists more accurate estimates of the rainfall in storms, the National Science Foundation reports. Such accurate information on rainfall would be a significant aid in flood prediction among other things.

title: N.H.L. Draft List
description: Barry Gibbs, d; Gerry Hart, Garth MacGuigan, c; Bert Marshall, d; Alex McKendry, rw; Pat Price, d; Yvon Vautour, rw; Goren 140gosta, g; Terry Richardson. 0.

title: Japan's Exports Up in May
description: TOKYO, June 11 (UPI)  Japan's exports licensed in May were up 3.8 percent from the same month last year, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry reported today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Development Program Governing Council 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. UNICEF Executive Board  3:30 P.M.

title: Nuclear Weapon Is Tested
description: PAHUTE MESA, Nev., June 11 (UPI)  A nuclear weapon buried beneath the volcanic rock of Pahute Mesa was triggered today, sending out earth shock waves that were felt slightly in Las Vegas 110 miles away. The Department of Energy said that the underground nuclear test, code named Pepato, had a yield of 20 to 150 kilotons, or a maximum equivalent of 150,000 tons of TNT.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Retail sales declined in May for the second consecutive month, providing further evidence that an economic slowdown was in progress, according to the Commerce Department. Its report showed that retail sales fell twotenths of 1 percent in May to $71.1 billion. The agency also revised its April sales figure downward by nearly $1 billion, turning what had appeared to be a slight increase into a loss of 1.1 percent. [Page D1.]

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Price Surges Again; Dollar Ends Day Mixed
description: The price of gold continued scaling new heights in Europe and New York yesterday, while the dollar was mixed against the currencies of West Germany, Japan and Switzerland.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY GUGLI ELMO MARCONI (Italian Line Cruises International). Lett Santo Domingo; due at 8 A.M. at West 55th Street.

title: CONNALLY PRESENTS AN ENERGY PROGRANI
description: PITTSBURGH, June 11  John B. Connally, the DemocratturnedRepublican Presidential candidate, brought his campaign today before the nation's mayors, most of whom are Democrats, with the charge that the energy crisis was more than anything else a product of national political impotence.

title: Deaths
description: DALGLIE514Alicedige 85,o/ Main St. North,Woodbury,Conn..retlred Children's Book Editor Charles Scribner's Sons Publishers and former leading author of children's books. 6/11/79. Graveside services Wednesday 11AM New North Cerneterv.Wocdbury.Conn. Omit flowers. Contribute to the Children's Room. Woodbury Public Library. de BEERRobert H. on June 10, 1979 of Ridgewood, NJ. Father of Katharine H. de Beer of New York City and Peter H. of Port Jefferson Station. NY and grandfather of Melissa. Also survived by his sister, Mrs. Martha Mader of Beverly, NJ. Memorial Service 2gm Sunday. June 17, at the C. C. Van EmbiXgh Mortuary, 306 East Ridgewood Avenue. Ridgewood, New Jersey. No visitation. Interment private. Donations in his memory to the National Audubon Society 950 3 Ave. N.Y.C. would be greatly appreciated. deFLOREZMarian King, of Palisades, N.Y. on Monday. June 11, 1979. Beloved wife of the late Luis. Mother of Peter. Graveside services will be held at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA on Thursday at 11am. Eor further information, please contact Quirk Funeral Home of Tenafly. N.J.

title: Koch, a Jogger, Hails Marathon
description: I jog eight minutes a day, Mayor Koch said somewhat apologetically yesterday as he announced the 10th running of the New York City Marathon, to be held on Oct. 21. About 14,000 entrants from all over the world are expected to participate.

title: Iran Selects Managers For Banks
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 11 (Reuters)  Iran's banks opened today as new, Governmentappointed managements were named. Bankers described business as normal, following last Friday's takeover announcement.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Carborundum Company, a subsidiary of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, has appointed Robert E. Flynn and Charles R. Landback senior vice presidents.

title: Around the Nation
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., June 11 (AP)  A judge dismissed charges against Dr. William Waddill today after a jury became deadlocked over charges that the obstetrician had killed a baby the survived an abortion attempt. The majority of the jurors, voting 11 to 1, favored acquittal.

title: Kissinger Interceded For Shah in Mexico, As Did the State Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Both the State Department and former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger asked the Mexican authorities to let the deposed Shah Mohammed Riza Pahievi of Iran enter Mexico from exile in the Bahamas, Administration officials said today.

title: Japan's Big Chance
description: TOKYO  The Japanese Government has before it a golden opportunity to change policies, and to begin, some 10 years late, to fill in the gaps in Japan's domestic economy and ease trade imbalances at the same time.

title: Police Ordered To Keep Watch At Gas Stations
description: The New York City Police Department ordered its field commanders yesterday to give special attention to preventing violence at gasolineservice stations in the city. There have been two recent homicides as a result of disputes among customers waiting on line to get to pumps.

title: COMMODMES Wheat Futures Climb, Spurring Corn, Soybeans
description: Speculators continued actively buying wheat futures yesterday after the Agriculture Department cut its assessment of the 1979 Soviet grain crop, and traders speculated that Russia could seek to buy as much as 10 million more metric tons from the United States in the marketing year beginning this fall than they are expected to buy this year. but American crop commons are generally good, and the weather during the next 60 days in both the United States and the Soviet Union will be critical in determining whether any such demand actually develops.

title: The Lesser Mortgage Evil
description: The House Ways and Means Committee is thrashing around looking for a way to close a new tax loophole known as the taxexempt housing bond. The committee members don't have the political courage to accept the good advice of Chairman AI Ullman and ranking Republican Barber Conable, and simply legislate it out of existence. But now Representative Andrew Jacobs of Indiana has hit on a compromise that would at least limit the waste of Federal dollars.

title: A Little Ink for Goldie
description: He can be kind of nasty, Oesch said yesterday at barn 15 in the Belmont Park stable area, but I love this horse. He's a gutsy little guy, and he still isn't getting the recognition he deserves. No ink at all. That really bugs me.

title: Venezuelan Oil Output Up
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 11 (UPI)  Venezuela's production of crude oil through June 6 averaged 2,343,079 barrels a day, the Ministry of Energy and Mines reported today. The figure represented an increase of 335,698 barrels a day, or 16.72 percent, over the same period last year, the ministry said.

title: Bridge:
description: For the third time in four years a team from Westchester County has upset favored New York City opponents to win the Grand National zonal title. Playing partly in White Plains and partly in Rye, N.Y., over the weekend, Allan Stauber of Poughkeepsie.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A thick band of clouds extending from New England through the Middle and Southern Atlantic States to the Texas Gulf Coast marks a cold front moving out over the Atlantic. A few scattered clouds are visible over the Northwest and the Intermountain Region. Clear skies prevail from the West coast to the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys.

title: Senate Bars Military Outlay
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)  The Senate approved today an amendment to prohibit spending on a military version of the DC10 aircraft until it is certified as airworthy and fit for service.
