The measure, sponsored by Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, was adopted on a voice vote as part of a $40.1 billion defense authorization bill on which debate continues tomorrow.

title: Islanders Form Half of AllStars
description: MONTREAL, June 11  The New York Islanders, the top team in the National Hockey League during the regular season, and the Montreal Canadiens, the fourtime Stanley Cup champions, locked up the six positions on the league's AllStar first team announced today.

title: Advertising
description: WILLIAM P. COOLEY & ASSOCIATES, which according to young Mr. Cooley's business card is in communications marketing (a fancy way of saying national advertising representative), has just added a new title to the client list that already includes Financier, 'shooting Commercials and Executive Female Digest. It is called &. And in order to help out the less literate, it is subtitled Ampersand.

title: Pecci's Poise Is Growing
description: PARIS, June 11  Victor Peed, the tall, looming figure with the rocketlike serve and diamond in his ear, is the only professional tennis player in his native country, Paraguay.

title: Stage: 3 Stratford Festival Plays Explore the Decline of Kings
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 11 To attempt a cycle of Shakespeare, a theater should have a unifying attitude toward the related plays as well as actors who can move from the shadows into the spotlight. When the Royal Shakespeare Company presented Henry IV, Part One, Henry IV, Part Two and Henry V at StratfordonMon, England, it was deep in talent, led by Alan Howard as driving force. We could see Mr. Howard progress from play to play, from callow Prince Hal to powerful Henry V.

title: South African Cargo Ship Docks With a Murder Mystery Aboard
description: The cargo ship South African Constancia pulled into Brooklyn's Pier 6 at sunrise yesterday, her chief cook dead and a 19yearold steward missing. The youth was presumed to have drowned in the sharkinfested waters 150 miles north of Bermuda.

title: Egyptians and Israelis Meet
description: CAIRO, June 11  Egyptian and Israeli negotiators met today to work out a format for discussing Palestinian home rule, and promptly clashed over Jewish settlements.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, June 11 (UPI)  The Soviet press agency Tass charged today. that American instructors were teaching Afghan rebels in special camps how to use weapons against the proSovie Afghanistan Government.

title: Jesse P. Abramson, Sportswriter For Herald Tribune, Dead at 75
description: Jesse P. Abramson, a distinguished figure in sports journalism for 56 years and widely recognized as the nation's leading track and field writer, died of cancer last night at his home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: News Summary
description: Vietnam is expelling its ethnic Chinese, and collecting hundreds of millions of dollars from them before their departure, much of it to repay Soviet aid and arms sales, according to refugees and intelligence sources. Despite official denials, there is evidence that the exodus is being organized by the Hanoi Government. [Page A1, Columns 12.]

title: Is It Really a Chair?
description: It looks like a complicated surfboard. But it's really a chair well, not really a chair, but a perch, and it's for the beach. It's for peekers, explained Mitchell Gold, the furniture buyer who first saw it at a furniture fair in Milan. You stand against it, get the sun and can still take a look at who is passing by.

title: New U.N. Lebanon Mandate Urged
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim recommended today a sixmonth extension of the mandate for the United Nations 5,800member peace force in Lebanon. He criticized Israel for what he said was refusal to cooperate with the United Nations force.

title: Iraq Halts Dealings With Egypt Banks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11 (UPI)  Iraq's central bank today halted all financial dealings with Egyptian banks and companies, the official Iraqi news agency said.

title: North Korea Buildup Confirmed by the U.S. In Intelligence Report
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  A new intelligence report has confirmed that North Korea has more troops and tanks than previously believed but State Department officials said today they did not expect a final decision on the troop withdrawal question until after President Carter's forthcoming trip to South Korea.

title: F.T.C. Aide Accuses Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)  Oil companies apparently helped create current gasoline shortages by stockpiling crude oil instead of refining it into gasoline, a top official of the Federal Trade Commission charged today.

title: M.A.C. Approves 80 City Budget But Urges Koch to Slash It Further
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation approved the city's executive budget for fiscal 1980 yesterday, but urged Mayor Koch to cut it further to prepare for future budget gaps.

title: MX Missile: New Source of Jobs, Revenue
description: LOS ANGELES, June 11  By Air Force estimates, the Carter Administration's decision to proceed with the $30 billion MX missile project could mean the creation of 130,000 new aerospace and supportingservices Jobs nationwide. And, assuming development expenditures of $5 billion to $7 billion, the missile program is expected to generate substantial state revenues.

title: Problems of Defective Subway Cars Stir Conflicts Among City Officials
description: The delivery of 759 defective subway cars from the Pullman Standard Company has stirred division in the city government over how to deal with the safety hazards they present and how to settle a substantial claim against the manufacturer for late delivery of the equipment.

title: Maree Finds a Way to Keep Running
description: Sydney Maree, the world's leading distance runner at the moment, has found a way to continue competition despite an international ban on South Africans.. As a result, he is expected to run the mile in the New Jersey Olympic Track Classic June 23 at Piscataway, N.J., and the Brooks Meet of Champions June 30 in Philadelphia.

title: Albert E. Hitchcock, Plant Expert
description: Albert E. Hitchcock, a prizewinning plant physiologist and pioneer in the development of herbicides, died last Friday at his home in Irvington, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Dance: Jacaranda Bows
description: AFTER the sound of footsteps and a slamming door, a man woke to find that the woman with whom he had been living had left him. And what did he do then? He started reminiscing. What else did he do? He danced.

title: Retail Sales Fell Again In May
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)  Retail sales across the nation declined for a second consecutive month in May, providing further evidence that an economic slowdown was in progress, according to a Government report released today.

title: Price Changes On Car Imports
description: Three foreign car manufacturers said yesterday that they were changing the prices on their cars sold in the United States, with one announcing price reductions and the other two price increases.

title: EDUCATION Enrollment Rising In Private Schools
description: FIVE years ago, New York City's private schools were worried about their future as they confronted a declining birthrate, a steady exodus of middleclass families to the suburbs and a diminishing pool of applicants. It seemed possible that the private schools might not be able to maintain enrollments unless they became less selective.

title: About Education
description: AMERICAN colleges and universities may face a far more serious enrollment crisis than has been predicted by analysts of higher education, according to the Census Bureau's latest enrollment statistics.

title: 3 Angels Suffer Shoulder Injuries
description: CLEVELAND, June 11 (AP)Three California players suffered shoulder injuries during the Angels 94 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

title: About New York
description: One old woman was antic and gray in her wheelchair, as if for her Eugene O'Neill's words were dancing separate little jigs: And baby's cries can't waken her in the baggage coach ahead.

title: PLANE CARRYING 207 IS HIJACKED TO CUBA
description: A Delta Airlines widebodied jetliner carrying 207 passengers and crew members on a flight from New York to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was diverted to Cuba by a hijacker last night, the Federal Aviation Administration reported.

title: Truckers Group Urges Owners to Join Protest
description: The Independent Truckers Association yesterday urged 100,000 owneroperators to park their rigs and join a nationwide work stoppage that already has led to sporadic violence and threatens to disrupt shipments of food to gro. cery stores.

title: L.I. Youth Is Charged As Body of His Father Is Found in Basement
description: HOLBROOK, L.I., June 11 (AP)  A 17yearold Huntington youth was charged today with fatally shooting his father 15 months ago, then burying him deep in the sand of their home's unfinished basement here.

title: Sports Briefs
description: LONDON, June 11 (UPI)  Stan Smith survived three match points in defeating Colin Dibley, 64, 67, 97, today and advancing to the second round of the $125,000 Queen's Club grass tennis tournament.

title: Cosmos Acquire Neeskens
description: Johan Neeskens, a top soccer player in Europe, signed a fiveyear contract with the Cosmos yesterday for a reported $1.6 million.

title: Citicorp Bid Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) The Supreme Court turned down today an appeal from Citicorp, the nation's secondlargest bank holding company, seeking to overturn a Federal Reserve Board decision denying Citicorp's application to retain a subsidiary involved in mortgages.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Paccar Inc. of Bellevue, Wash., a maker of Kenworth and Peterbilt trucks, offered yesterday to pay $20 a share, or about $180 million, for the Harnischfeger Corporation, a Milwaukeebased producer of cranes and earthmoving equipment.

title: New York Planning to Close 4 Municipal Hospitals
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it planned to close four municipal hospitals, including Metropolitan on the upper East Side and Sydenham in West Harlem, in an effort to reduce by $40 million the city's projected budget gap in the fiscal year 1981.

title: begin Rebuffs Criticism of New Settlement
description: JERUSALEM, June 11  Prime Minister Menachem Begin today denounced domestic and foreign critics of his Government's, settlement policies and said we shall nay no attention.

title: Surgical Implants Correct Impotence
description: AN inflatable implant to treat male impotence that cannot be corrected without surgery has been used successfully in 234 carefully selected cases, according to a research team at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston.

title: Embattled Chief Justice
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11  For Rose Elizabeth Bird, the Chief Justice of California, setting precedents is nothing new. She distinguished herself as the first woman deputy public defender in Santa Clara County, the first woman appointee to a cabinetlevel position in the Governor's office, and in 1977 the first woman Supreme Court Justice of California.

title: Closer Rein On Foreign Bank Loans
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 11Major Western central banks opened new drive today to control the explosive growth of international bank lending, which many of them believe is helping fuel another worldwide surge in inflation.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSJererne L. All of us, his partners, associates & staff who have worked with him, mourn his Passing with great sorrow. To the bereaved family we extend our deepest sympathy.

title: U.S. to Open Inquiry Into Bribe Allegations
description: Federal lawenforcement officials said yesterday that they would join the city in investigating allegations that at least one Transit Authority official accepted bribes from Pullman Standard Company, the manufacturer of subway cars. The company's equipment has been found to be defective.

title: Entertainment Events
description: BRUCE FORSYTHE ON BROADWAY, Winter Garden, Broadway at 50th Street. 7.METROPOLITAN OPERA IN THE PARKS, Verdi's Aide, Sheep Meadow, Central Park, 8:30.

title: Asian American Dancers Doing 8 Works in 3 Days
description: Eight works by the Asian American Dance Theater, including two new dances, will be presented June 2124 at the American Theater Laboratory at 219 West 19th Street.

title: TV: San Quentin, Victim Of Its Utter Futility
description: THE penal system, in its various guises, is suddenly public television's most prominent subject. Sunday at 10 P.M., Channel 21 carried Tattooed Tears, made at a Calilfornia center for young menit will be shown on Channel 13 next Sunday at 11 o'clock. Next Monday at 9 o'clock, Bill Moyers Journal will visit a women's detention center in Miami. And tonight at 10 o'clock on Channel 13, the videotape subject is Inside San Quentin. Warnings abound about profanity and brief scenes of nudity.

title: New York's 4 Percent Solution
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation and its reinstated chairman, Felix Rohatyn, have made a forceful critique of New York City's new budget. What the budget has failed to do, they say, is reduce the city's force of 194,000 employees, about 8 percent of whom normally leave every year. Unless the city government disciplines itself and replaces no more than half of those who leave, it will need an incredible run of luck to balance its budget in coming years. The economy would have to thrive beyond all predictions, the work force would have to adopt selfdenial as a negotiating principle and Washington would have to display avuncular generosity. The combination is unlikely.

title: Carey Retracts Hongisto Name For Prison Post
description: ALBANY, June 11  Fearing rejection by the State Senate, Governor Carey today withdrew his nomination of Richard D. Hongisto as Correctional Services Commissioner.

title: Biography Of Poet Due
description: Gwendolyn Brooks, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1950 for her book of poems Annie Allen, the first black woman to do so, will be the subject of a biography by George Kent, professor of English at the University of Chicago. Mr. Kent, who has had access to the writer's notebooks. found that she had been trying her hand at poetry as early as age 7. He found too that she was a very disciplined and determined writer. She wrote one or two poems day, Mr. Kent said.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: ALINE BERNSTEIN was a leading New York scenic and costume designer whose work in the 1920's and 30's had a role in establishing design for the theater as a profession in itself. She helped found the Neighborhood Playhousa and went on after its demise in 1927 to work with the Theatre Guild, Eva Le Gallienne's.

title: Italian Prices Climb
description: ROME, June 11 (UPI)  Italy's consumer prices at the end of May were up 14.5 percent from the yearearlier month, the Government statistics institute said today. The institute said May consumer prices were 1.3 percent above those in April but that the rise was lower than increases in January. February and April.

title: Disco Previews Delayed
description: Previews for Got Tu Go Disco, musical opening June 20 at the Minskoff, have been delayed until Sunday. The previews were supposed to have begun last Friday. According to a spokesman, the previews had to be delayed because the sets were not ready. He added, The June 20 premiere date will remain firm.

title: The Doctor's World How Delicate Surgery Saved a Hand
description: IN an intensive care unit at Bellevue Hospital, a doctor pressed firmly against the finger tips that Renee Katz had used to play the flute. The skin blanched, then quickly turned a healthy pink, bringing smiles to the faces of the doctors who had reattached her hand.

title: OBSERVER This I Don't Believe
description: The radio emitted the latest fact about the gasoline situation. I didn't believe It.

title: 'souvenir Bazooka Rocket Blamed in Fatal Dix Blast
description: One of two New York National Guardsmen killed Sunday in the explosion of an old bazooka rocket at Fort Dix, N.J., had found the ammunition on a firing range and, thinking it was a dud that he could use to make a lamp, had taken it back to his unit's bivouac area, where it went off, several survivors of the blast said yesterday.

title: Florida City to Market Bonds After Year's Delay
description: After a delay of more than a year, Gainesville, Fla., is selling $150 million of utility system revenue bonds this week, largely to refund outstanding securities at lower cost. The financing would have been completed last May prior to the imposition of a Federal Government ban on advance refunding issues, but a court challenge later thrown out  held up the bond sale until it was caught by the Treasury's new regulations.

title: Call for a Better World Includes NonCatholics
description: CRACOW, Poland, June 11  From his many sermons and speeches here, it is apparent that Pope John Paul II is calling for a partnership between Roman Catholics and nonCatholics for the betterment of human conditions and the enhance.

title: Associated Press
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 11  As fighting between Government troops and guerrillas continued in Managua and other Nicaraguan cities today, President Anastasio Somoza Debayle vowed he would not resign and predicted he would crush the latest insurrection against his regime within two weeks.

title: House Panel Calls F.A.A. Chief Lax on DC10 Crash
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  A Congressional panel leveled criticism today at Langhorne M. Bond, chief of the Federal Aviation Administration, charging that he had failed to delve into problems. with the DC10 engine mounts before the Chicago crash on May 25 in which 275 persons were killed.

title: TALMADGE LAWYERS CHALLENGE ACCUSER
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Daniel Minchew, his credibility increasingly in question, finished testifying before the Senate Select Committee on Ethics today by charging anew that Senator Herman E. Talmadge had spent office and campaign funds for personal use.

title: Annexation Proposal By Houston Rejected As Favoring Whites
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)  The Justice Department today blocked a Houston annexation proposal that would have added 140,000 people to the city's population. The department said that the change would dilute the voting strength of blacks and MexicanAmericans.

title: Separated Siamese Twins Gain
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 11 (AP) Lisa and Elisa Hansen, separated Siamese twins, were upgraded to fair condition today, and for the first time doctors expressed some optimism about their future. The 20monthold girls, joined at the tops of their heads at birth, were separated in a 16hour operation May 30. They were listed in critical but stable condition for a week after the separation, then in serious but stable condition.

title: Notes on People
description: There were more than enough ironies for anyone's taste in Montgomery, Ala., yesterday as Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. of the United States District'CoUrt was inducted into the state's AcadeMy of Honor.

title: Coach of Canadiens Becomes Buffalo's General Manager
description: MONTREAL, June 11  The Montreal Canadiens lost their successful coach today, and the Buffalo Sabres acquired a new general manager.

title: The Battle of Nicaragua
description: Civil war rages in Nicaragua, again. Last September's fighting gave way to an attempt to mediate, but mediation failed because President Anastasio Somoza Debayle believed that by playing off his opponents he could retain the power his family has held for nearly half a century. Challenging him with renewed force is a broad movement, ranging from business leaders to leftist revolutionaries, but now dominated increasingly by the guerrilla forces of the Sandinist National Liberation Front. The civilian population is caught in the middle; three thousand died in the fighting last September and thousands more have been killed since.

title: Milwaukee Line Is Short of Fuel
description: MILWAUKEE, June 11 (UPI)  Insufficient diesel fuel may force the financially troubled Milwaukee Road to curtail rail service on its nationwide system next week, it was reported today.

title: Gambling Stocks Lead Market Higher
description: Specialsituation and gambling stocks scored impressive gains yesterday as the overall market finished slightly higher in slower trading.

title: Red Sox Score 4 in 10th To Defeat Royals by 40
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 11 (AP) Dwight Evans's double and a throwing error by the Kansas City reliever, Al Hrabosky, opened the way for four Boston runs in the 10th inning tonight as the Red Sox recorded a 40 victory over the Royals.

title: David Sucherman, 78, Controller For a Stock Specialist Company
description: David Sucherman, controller and general manager of Fowler & Rosenau, stock specialists and members of the New York Stock Exchange, died of a heart attack at the home of a friend Saturday night. He was 78 years old and lived in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Steel Output Down in Week
description: Steel production in the United States fell to 2.8 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 2.7 percent from the previous week's 2.9 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: U.S.Soviet Trade Slows
description: MOSCOW, June 11 (UPI)  Trade between the Soviet Union and the United States in this year's first quarter fell 10 percent from the yearearlier level, but the balance of trade in favor of the United States grew almost 18 percent, the American Embassy reported today.

title: Music: Greek Themes
description: BECAUSE of the multifarious interests that usually demand to be satisfied, concerts by ethnic organizations do not often end up satisfying high classical standards. But the concert conducted by Dino Anagnost at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night was a model of its kind, diverse and entertaining as well as artistically sophisticated. Half the night was given over to music with Greek themes, most of it firstclass; after intermission came nothing less than Mozart's Requiem.

title: State Financing of City U. Periled By Issue of Aid to Private Colleges
description: ALBANY, June 11  An agreement that would provide for state financing of the City University of New York appeared in jeopardy today because of Republican demands for additional state aid to private colleges.

title: Poll Shows Most Americans Prefer Gas Rationing Over Higher Prices
description: The American public, still not believing that there is an oil shortage, solidly prefers gasoline rationing to scrambling to find supplies or to paying still higher prices, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. ( N ) cafes stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the Amer(car Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: The City
description: The Moran Towing and Transportation Company, one of the largest tugboat operators in the Port of New York, withdrew yesterday from the employers association that has been attempting to reach agreement on a new contract with striking tugboat crewmen.

title: Thais Deport 30,000 Cambodians While Others Continue to Arrive
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 11 Thirty thousand Cambodian refugees have been forcibly returned to their homeland by Thai military authorities in the past four days, and 50,000 more will be sent back to Cambodia as soon as possible, according to Government and United Nations refugee sources in Thailand.

title: House Panel Increases Tax in Oil Windfall Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The House Ways and Means Committee made two changes in President Carter's windfall profits bill today that would increase by more than $2.2 billion the taxes that the oil industry would pay on additional income realized from decontrol of domestic oil prices.

title: Mexico Aims to Cap Well in Days
description: MEXICO CITY, June 11  The Mexican Government said today that it hoped within 10 days to be able to cap an offshore oil well that has been pouring an estimated 1.2 million gallons of crude oil into the Gulf of Mexico each day.

title: Inquiry on California's High Court, First in State's History, Is Opening
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11  A public investigation of the California Supreme Court  the first in its history  opened here today with the presentation of a written report on the preliminary findings. Next Monday it will resume with the court's seven Justices among the witnesses to be called.

title: Bond Prices Up on Late Surge
description: The monthlong recovery of the credit markets, after faltering last Friday and again early yesterday, got a new burst of life later in the day when the Government reported weaker retail sales in April and May. Bond prices rose sharply late in the afternoon to finish higher for the day, and sales of new bond issues perked up.

title: New Tools of a Treasure Hunter
description: IN the hunting of sunken treasure, as in many endeavors these days, new technologies are making a difference. Burt D. Webber Jr. has reason to believe it is a multimillion dollar difference.

title: Jersey Assembly Supports Curbs In All Abortions
description: TRENTON, June 11  A bill that would make abortions more difficult to obtain in New Jersey passed the State Assembly today, 51 to 17, and was sent to the Senate.

title: Draft Registration Is Unnecessary, Brown Says, Contradicting Officers
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The Carter Administration does not think registration for a military draft is necessary now, Defense Secretary Harold Brown said in a letter released today.

title: Bank of America To Refund Interest
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (UPI)  The Bank of America said today that it would pay nearly $9 million in refunds to people who were inadvertently overcharged Interest on consumer installment loans.

title: A Hapsburg Gets Elected
description: BONN, June 11  Otto von Hapsburg. the eldest son of the last AustroHungarian emperor, was elected today as one of West Germany's 81 representatives in the Common Market's European Parliament.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Elliot J. Stone, president of Gimbel Brothers Inc. and chairman and chief executive officer of its New York division, has been named president and chief executive of Jordan Marsh in Boston. Yesterday's announcement, continuing the game of musical chairs in the executive suites of the nation's leading retailers, said the changeover would be effective on July 15.Stover said in a telephone interview yesterday. It should be a viable organization for the forseeable future.

title: CARTER TO PRESENT HEALTH PLAN PAYING COSTS ABOVE $2,500
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  President. Carter is expected to ask Congress tomorrow for an $18 billion national health insurance program that would pay an American family's hospital and medical costs above $2,500 a year, according to White House officials.

title: Veteran Defenseman May Retire Rather Than Relocate
description: Gerry Hart, a defenseman for the New York Islanders for all seven years of their existence in the National Hockey League, was not on the club's list of protected players for the expansion draft that will take place tomorrow in Montreal.

title: Mets Defeat Reds, Lose Zachry
description: Winning battles but losing wars, the New York Mets defeated the Cincinnati Reds last night, 32, but returned Pat Zachry to the disabled list and received a negative medical report on Skip Lockwood.

title: U.S. Appeals On Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)  The Carter. Administration urged the United States Court of Appeals today to overturn a lower court ruling and restore the President's power to punish violators of his voluntary antiinflation guidelines.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Spring Floods Threatening Shrimp Catch
description: HOUSTON, June 11  Spring floods and heavy rains have sent a surge of water into the bays and shallow tidal zones of Texas and Louisiana, threatening to devastate this year's shrimp crop.

title: 2 Muzorewa Aides Coming to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Two officials of Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa's newly formed Government in Zimbabwe Rhodesia are planning to visit the United States later this week, presumably to press for a lifting of American sanctions, State Department officials said today.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Sonata No. 2 for Trumpet and Organ. Viviani; Masques, Debussy; Sonata in A for 2 Oboes d'amore and Continuo, Telemann; Andrea Chenier, aria, Giordana; Marche heraque, SaintSatins.

title: SchoolAid Law In State to Face Judicial Review
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether New York State's most recent effort to provide state aid to parochial schools is constitutional:

title: In California Wine Country, a Rare Beer
description: SONOMA, Calif.  With all the fuss raised about wine in these parts, it comes as a surprise to most people to discover that what may be one of the country's best beers is made here. too.

title: Market Place
description: INVESTING overseas is one of the hottest new strategies for Americans. Many American banks and money management companies are actively offering their new international expertise to corporations and pension funds, in competition with money managers from London, Zurich and other foreign financial centers.

title: John Wayne Dead of Cancer on Coast at 72
description: LOS ANGELES, June 11 (AP)  John Wayne, the veteran Hollywood actor, died today at 5:23 P.M., Pacific daylight time, at U.C.L.A. Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said. The cause of death was given as complications from cancer.

title: Veterinarian Backs Choice To Run Spectacular Bid
description: BALTIMORE, June 11 (AP)  Dr. Robert Vallence, attending veterinarian of Spectacular Bid, said that if he had had to make the decision, he would have run the thoroughbred in the Belmont Stakes after the horse stepped on a safety pin Saturday morning before the race.

title: Uncertainties in DC1 0 Inquiry
description: As shown at Monday's start of a series of Capitol Hill inquiries into the crash of a DC10 jumbo jet in Chicago on May 25, large uncertainties persist over what might be the plane's defects, who is to blame and what corrective actions are needed.

title: Anderson To Pilot Tigers
description: Sparky Anderson, out of baseball for the last six months despite having been one of the most successful managers of the last decade, became the manager of the Detroit Tigers yesterday.

title: Accord Reached On City Budget For Fiscal 1980
description: Agreement on revisions to the executive budget for fiscal year 1980 was finally reached last night by the Board of Estimate and City Council leaders, more than a week after the deadline for budget anoroval had nassed.

title: Yanks Win, 41; Guidry Is Injured
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 12 The joking stopped. The Yankee clubhouse was silent, except for a radio that had not been turned off. A 91, ninthinning victory over the Twins tonight was suddenly forgotten. There was Ron Guidry, strapped to a rolling table, motionless, eyes closed, a neck brace holding his head still, on his way to an ambulance.

title: Pan Am Cutting A Fare to Coast
description: Pan American World Airways entered the New YorkCalifornia airline price war yesterday with an announcement that it will offer an $89 oneway standby fare and that it would honor the halffare coupons issued by other airlines.

title: West's Inflation Rate Found Accelerating
description: PARIS, June 12  Inflation is starting to accelerate again throughout the Western industrial world, arousing fears that another economic slowdown with higher unemployment may lie ahead.

title: Advertising
description: 50 Plus Aiming for Million Plus

title: Japan Plans Coal Ship
description: TOKYO, June 12 (UPI)  Nippon Yusen, Kaisha, a leading Japanese shipping company, said today that it would build a vessel designed exclusively to carry coal for electric power plants. The company said the ship would be of the 60,000ton class and had been ordered by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. to transport coal imported from Australia and China.

title: COMMODITIES
description: By The Associated Press

title: Brockway Seeking Standard Container
description: The Brockway Glass Company, manufacturer of glass and plastic containers, tubing and rods, said that it had begun a tender offer for all outstanding shares of the Standard Container Company at $13.70 a share.

title: Japan's Housing Starts Up
description: TOKYO, June 12 (UPI)  Housing starts in Japan in April rose 11.8 percent from the same month last year to 156,200 units, the Construction Ministry announced today. The ministry said there was a gain of 51.4 percent in publicly financed starts but a decline of 6.4 percent in privately financed starts, the 26th straight monthly drop for that category.

title: Administration to Seek Panama Vote In Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  Administration officials said today that they hoped to reschedule a vote in the House of Representatives next week on legislation to carry out the Panama Canal treaties.

title: Royals Top Red Sox In 10th Inning, 7 to 6
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 12 (AP) Al Cowens's sacrifice fly scored George Brett in the 10th inning tonight and lifted the Kansas City Royals to a 76 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Waldheim Sends Aide to Thailand
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim sent diplomat to Bangkok today to try to persuade Thailand to stop its forced repatriation of thousands of Cambodian refugees who have fled across the border in recent days.

title: Jockey Admits to Taking Bribe at Pocono Downs
description: BOSTON, June 12 (AP)  A suspended jockey has admitted taking bribe to hold back three horses in races at Pocono Downs race track in Pennsylvania.

title: Man Powered Flight: Science Gives Wings to an Old Idea
description: For more than 40 centuries, men have tried to flap, pedal or crank their way into the air, unaided by beasts or engines. But without the technological advances of recent years, manpowered flight would have remained an unfulfilled dream.

title: Deaths
description: BRILL  Rae Hessberg on June 10, 1979. Beloved wile of the late Henry S. Brill. devoted mother of. Adele Bleyer Zeitz and Evelyn Stark. Surviving also are 3 grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Funeral privale.

title: So You Want to Be a Referee?
description: Dick Bavetta remembers his weekends officiating in the old Eastern Basketball Association. I'd come into work on Monday morning and people would be talking about the concert they saw at Westbury or the show they saw on Broadway, he said. I'd feel a little embarrassed. The highlight of my weexena was a police escort out of Scranton.

title: WILLIAM V. FAGAN Sr.
description: William V. Fagan Sr., former assistant city editor of the New York desk of The Associated Press, died last Thursday after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 6025 83d Street, Elmhurst, Queens.

title: 2 Killed as a Second DC3 Crashes Within 24 Hours
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June 12 (AP)  A DC3 plunged to the ground between a busy freeway and a roW of houses today just after taking off from Fort Lauderdale Executive Airport. The pilot, one of two persons killed in the crash, and the plane were linked by the police to the marijuana trade.

title: Transit Aides Found Manufacturer Misrepresented SubwayCar Tests
description: The manufacturer of the trucks, or undercarriages, for the city's fleet of R46 subway cars misrepresented the results of the Xray tests of the equipment that were required under its contract, according to a report by the Transit Authority's engineering staff.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Transformation 6:00(5)New Zoo Revue

title: COURT ORDERS HALT IN PENSION BOYCOTT
description: The union trustees of the New York City Police Pension Fund were ordered yesterday to end their threemonthold boycott of the fund's deliberations on accidentdisability retirement cases. Justice Thomas J. Hughes of State Supreme Court in Manhattan issued the order in response to a petition filed by the city.

title: Burning of Newspaper Is Setback for Somoza Enemies
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 12Refugees fleeing from nearby battle zones paused briefly today to contemplate the burnedout wreck of the opposition newspaper, La Prensa, which had been destroyed by the Nicaraguan National Guard a few hours earlier.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Low level clouds cover most of northern New England and areas in the South Atlantic States. Widely scattered showers and thunderstorms are expected across the Northern Plains States, the southern Intermountain region and the upper Mississippi and Missouri Valleys. Clear skies will prevail throughout the rest of the country.

title: CARTER AND KENNEDY PRESS RIVAL EFFORTS ON HEALTH PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy marshaled supporters of their opposing national health plans today and pitted them against each other at news conferences in the White House and on Capitol Hill.

title: Careers
description: Retailers Offering Openings

title: U.S. to End Import Curbs Placed on Specialty Steel
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 President Carter has decided to phase out import quotas on specialty steel over the next eight months, the White House announced today.

title: In London, You Are Where You Eat
description: LONDON CLUBS are out, restaurants are in. The slow demise of English country life is currently paralleled by a revival of cafe society with pretty, and sometimes famous people competing fiercely for the best tables in trendy restaurants. These establishments have largely replaced the club in London's social order. You are where you eat.

title: Sidney O. Raphael, Lawyer, at 73
description: Sidney O. Raphael, a lawyer and philanthropist, who served as chairman of the board of the Kingsbrook Medical Center in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 575 Park Avenue.

title: Dressing for Life In a Discomfort Zone
description: TIME: the nottoodistant future. Place: a large Manhattan office building where, in accordance with Federal energy conservation regulations for summer, thermostats are set at 82 degrees and business is conducted in bathing suits. The boss wears custommade swim trunks. The typing pool is awash in bikinis.

title: Judge Rules Gotbaum Must Remove 8 Aides From Hospital Union
description: Victor Gotbaum, executive director of District Council 37, must remove eight of his aides from the staff of the affiliated union of municipal hospital workers because of objections by the local's president, a New York State judge has ruled.

title: Play Brings Learning and Laughter to Imaginative Harlem Students
description: Dragon With the Sun in His Mouth, a collection of poems, like the one above, set to music, opened and closed yesterday morning to thunderous acclaim in East Harlem.

title: Tories Disclose Radical Changes In British Budget
description: LONDON, June 12  Britain's new Conservative Government laid out its plans today for the most radical change in the country's economic direction since the Labor Party's quiet revolution of the early postwar years.

title: Benefit Party: One for the Books
description: SOMETIMES people give parties just because they want to get together with their friends and socialize. Everyone likes to be invited to that kind of party. Other times people give parties because they want something from their guests. Not everyone treasures an invitation to one of fling'.

title: Judge Ends a Stay of Execution; Upholds Alabama Death Penalty
description: MOBILE, Ala., June 12 (UPI) A Federal district judge today dissolved a stay of execution of John Louis Evans 3d, upholding the constitutionality of Alabama's death penalty law.

title: Personal Health
description: IT'S often the butt of jokes, but to many of the people who've been involved in this legally and morally forbidden form of sexuality, incest is anything but funny.

title: Energy Official Blames OPEC, Not Oil Refiners
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)  The responsibility for gasoline shortages rests with foreigners and not with United States oil companies, the Energy Department's secondranking official asserted today.

title: Mostly Mozart Tunes Up
description: Tickets will go on sale at noon Sunday for the 13th annual Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall, which will open July 16 and continue through Aug. 25.

title: 91Day Note Rate Slips
description: Citicorp reported yesterday that the average rate at its weekly auction of 91day notes declined to 9.845 percent lowest since April 24  from 10,112 percent last week. The bank holding company received more than $1.02 billion of bids, the largest volume since it began selling these notes on Sept. 19, 1978, for the $100 million for sale. Bids accepted ranged from 9.800 to 9.849 percent.

title: Koch Is Assailed on Hospital Plan
description: Opponents of Mayor Koch's plan to close four municipal hospitals charged Mr. Koch yesterday with racial insensitivity and with planning to give one of them  Metropolitan Hospital Center as a political payoff to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: Draths
description: ABRAMSJerome L. Ace 61 of 376 West End Ave., Long Branch, NJ, on June 11, 1979. Husband of Charlotte Abrams, father of Mrs. Beth Kloor and stepfather of Robert ElIts, and Mrs. Cheryl Kitson. Brother of Meyer H. Abrams. Funeral Service Wed., June 13, 12 noon, from the Woolley Funeral Home, 10 Mot, roll St., Long Branch. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, June 12,1979

title: Cargo Traffic Periled by DC10Halt
description: The chaos that erupted at airport passenger terminals after the grounding of the McDonnell Douglas DC10's is spreading to the airlines cargo operations, normally a $2 billion business.

title: Cash Prices
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 12, 1979

title: News Summary
description: President Carter lost the first round of a show down that he deliberately sought with Congress over the economic santions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia, when the Senate in effect voted 52 to 41 to force the lifting of the embargo. [Page Al, Column 6]

title: Woman in Rockland Wins a 9Year Fight To Regain Daughter
description: Nearly 15 years ago, a young woman who had immigrated from India met an Indian student and they planned to marry. But she became pregnant, and he deserted her. She dropped out of school and in May 1966 her daughter, Sanjivini, was born, in Rockland County.

title: U.S. Believes Hijacker, in Custody In Havana, Ii Pilot Who Fled Cuba
description: MIAMI, June 12  A man tentatively identified as a defector from the Cuban Air Force was in the custody of the Cuban authorities today after hijacking a Delta Air Lines jumbo Jet to Havana last night.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: TASTE is one of the most subjective things on earth. I have no quarrel with the man who despises caviar; at today's prices, I might even envy him. I have one very close friend, a professional in the field of food, who can't abide the smell or taste of cheese, even cream cheese.

title: N.B.A. Leaning to 3Point Goal
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  Thousands of American Basketball Association red, white and blue balls are still bounced around playgrounds and parks three years after the league's demise. Now it appears the 3point basket, the A.B.A.'s innovation for field goals of about 24 feet and over, has a good chance of being adopted by the National Basketball Association next season.

title: Educators Turning Away From OutofClass Help
description: Programs that take youngsters out of class to give them special help may be doing more harm than good, according to New York State and City education officials.

title: News of the Theater Maggie Smith Returning to Broadway
description: MAGGIE SMITH is coming back to Broadway next season. The actress, who won her second Academy Award this spring for her performance in the movie of California Suite, will star in Tom Stoppard's current London tit, Night and Day. She last appeered on the New York stage in Noel Coward's Private Lives in 1975. Night and Day will start an outof town run at the Kennedy Center in Washington on Oct. 15 and open in New York at the LuntFontanne on Nov. 26.

title: Simon Endorses Kennedy
description: Saying that President Carter is sorely lacking in the leadership that Is so essential for the survival of our borough, our city, and,indeed, all of urban America, Stanley Simon, the Bronx Borough President, yesterday endorsed Senator Edward M. Kennedy for President in 1980.

title: Country Fair in Brooklyn
description: The country fair will be coming to the city. At the first New York City Gardeners Harvest Fair on Sept. 15 urban planters will have a chance to win a blue ribbon for their homegrown produce, and cooks may vie for prizes for their homemade breads, jellies, jams and pickles. The biggest sunflower and the scariest scarecrow will also take honors at the allday event to be held at Gateway National Recreation Area in Brooklyn.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Rats, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 2 P.M. (Radio WMCA, 2 P.M.)

title: Ayatollah Exchanges Sharp Words With Soviet Envoy
description: TEHERAN, June 12  Ayatollah Ruho'lab Khomeini accused the Soviet Union today of suppressing the Islamic movement in neighboring Afghanistan and possibly interfering in Iran, and the Soviet Ambassador, Vladimir M. Vinogradov, countered by complaining to the religious leader that the Soviet Union's image was being distorted in Iran.

title: Stage: British Vaudeville Of Bruce Forsyth
description: IF brashness could be bottled, the label would read Bruce Forsyth. Mr. Forsyth is a British entertainer, who apparently has a large and fervid following on stage and on television in his home country. Among his other accomplishments. he has been a headliner at the Palladium and he has performed for members of the Royal Family. Last night, for the first time, he brought his act to New York, opening a week's run at the Winter Garden Theater in a show entitled Bruce Forsyth on Broadway!

title: U.S. ASSAILS VIETNAM FOR REFUGEE POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  Describing the refugee problem in Southeast Asia as a massive disaster, the United States condemned Vietnam today for virtually forcing all ethnic Chinese to leave the country. It also rebuked Thailand for forcibly returning thousands of Cambodian refugees to their country.

title: Banks and Bonds, Continued
description: A letter today from Michael Mussa, writing on behalf of the investment banking community, takes strong exception to our support for letting commercial banks underwrite municipal revenue bonds. Mr. Mussa makes some valid points. But we still think the case for the commercial banks is a Rood one.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: I VISITED my salesman neighbor one afternoon while he was in the middle of a phone conversation with his boss, writes Bill Hogg. They spoke of a difficult customer and why he was not getting an order from him.

title: Kitchen Equipment FrenchFry Cutters
description: WHEN I was describing the strengths of two new food processors last week  the Cuisinart DLC7 and the new Farberware design  I didn't mention a drawback that is trivial in the grand scheme, but will matter a lot to some people. These machines aren't much good for slicing french fries. Even the Farberware, which has frenchfry blade, fails. The reason is that a good fry, to my mind, ought to have some length to it, perhaps three inches, and it ought to be substantial. Otherwise, you've got julienne potatoes. Food processors are not designed to yield the longer slice.

title: Bridge:
description: When a knockout team match comes down to the final eight deals with the score relatively close, the tension can be extreme, for players and spectators alike. This is especially true when there is much at stake, as there was in the Grand National zonal team final playoff between Westchester and New York City Sunday niaht.

title: Yeshiva U. Honors G.M. Chief
description: Thomas A. Murphy, chairman and chief executive officer of the General Motors Corporation, received an honorary doctorate and a distinguished service award from Yeshiva University last night at an awards banquet at the New York Hilton. Mr. Murphy. who received the award and the honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree from Yeshiva's president, Dr. Norman Lamm, was cited for his outstanding leadership and sustained efforts to advance the intellectual, physical and cultural well being of society. Senator Donald S. Riegle Jr. of Michigan was the main speaker and Irving S. Shapiro, chairman and chief executive officer of the Du Pont Company, was chairman of the banquet.

title: EGYPTISRAEL TALKS MAKE NO PROGRESS
description: CAIRO, June 12  Egypt and Israel wound up their second round of talks on the future of the Palestinians today without reaching agreement even on procedures for negotiating the issue.

title: The Part John Wayne Played
description: With sad precision, the hospital spokesman said that John Wayne, 72, had died at 5:23 in the afternoon. It was too early in the day to ride off into the sunset. But it was just about the time a lot of people were heading home from work, perhaps hoping to see a good, comfortable movie with action more virile and morality more plain than in the real world  in short, a John Wayne movie. That's exactly what millions of Americans did for almost half a century. They loved the man with the powerful walk, red bandanna, oldfashioned good manners and the halfdeep voice. It all suggested not great wit or stirring sensuality but decency, common sense, good humor, and America.

title: Canada's Jobless Rate Dips
description: OTTAWA, June 12 (AP)  Canada's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate dropped to 7.7 percent in May, its lowest level since January 1977, when was 7.6 percent, Statistics Canada said today. The May rate compares with jobless levels of 7.9 percent in April and 8.5 percent in May 1978.

title: Striking Union Drivers Attempt to Block Getty Oil Deliveries
description: Members of the Petroleum Trades Union, some with their families beside them, attempted to keep Getty Oil trucks from leaving its Greenpoint Avenue plant in Queens yesterday, after contract drivers replaced union people. Police were called in to escort trucks. Getty has made good on plan to lay off 55 gasoline truck drivers  who have been on strike more than a month  and replace them with employees of Island Transportation Company.

title: Johnson Golf Victor
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 12 Glenn Johnson of Grosse Isle, Mich., captured his second straight Eastern Seniors Golf Association tournament today with a 36hole score of 196 at the Wykagyl Golf Club. The 56yearold former Michigan amateur titleholder had a 74, 72 in his sevenstroke victory.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: First National Bank of Commerce, New Orleans, has appointed Allen E. Frederic senior vice president of its national accounts and international banking division.

title: Venezuela Gets SteelPlan Loan
description: LONDON June 12 (AP) A $250 million loan to help Venezuela increase its steelmaking capacity and reduce its imports was announced today by major British banking houses.

title: Multimedia Buys Cable TV System
description: Multimedia Inc., a publisher of newspapers and owner of radio and television stations with headquarters in Greenville, S.C., said that it had purchased its first cable television system, The 16city system was purchased from the cable television division of Kansas State Network Inc. of Wichita, Kan. The price for the system, which has 17,000 subscribers, will be $11 million.

title: BABIES CRIES VIEWED AS CLUES TO DISEASES
description: To most people, a baby's crying is just a loud noise that disturbs sleep or the neighbors and evokes irritation or sympathy according to the temperament of the listener.

title: U.S. Says Food Prices Are Stabilizing
description: >WASHINGTON, June 12  Retail food price increases have begun to level off and major increases are not expected during the remainder of this year, the Agriculture Department's chief economist said today.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: MENOWITZ  Sophie. The Board Of Trustees of North Shore University Hospital Is deeply saddened at the passing of Sophie Menowitz. beloved wife of Associate Trustee Harold Menowitz. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the members of her family.

title: Wine Talk
description: BERKELEY,CALIF. MENTION Berkeley to anyone over 20 and you conjure up images of golden youth in laidback academia, of, almostforgotten 60's anguish, of hair long since shorn and of causes long since dropped.

title: The Classroom's Ubiquitous Rival: Pop Culture
description: We Americans have constructed, in less than 200 years, the most magnificent democratic edgcational system in history. Today we find that entire system cracking, and some parts of it falling to pieces. We all know the reasons usually given, and all of them contribute to our trouble. Yet one has the uneasy feeling that they have all appeared in our time as a consequence of some deeper shift in our national psyche.

title: Mario Miranda, Pianist And Teacher, 53, Dies
description: Mario Miranda, a Chilean pianist who performed and taught In New York for 20 years, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his apartment at 333 East 14th Street. He was 53 years old.

title: Conviction Is Reversed In a 1975 Murder Case
description: An appeals court yesterday reversed the conviction of a man serving a maximum prison sentence in the 1975 murder of a wealthy Manhattan man. The court ruled that the trial judge, State Supreme Court Justice Clifford Scott, had allowed the jury to hear tainted testimony.

title: Udall Thinks Party Will Support Carter but Delays Own Backing
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 Representative Morris K. Udall, who has been sympathetic to President Carter's bid for reelection without explicitly endorsing him, said today that the peril. point for Mr. Carter's hopes for renomination would come if the President began running sharply behind potential Republican rivals in the opinion polls.

title: Cooking the Uncommon Catch
description: To prepare the sea urchins, use a clean towel or other cloth to protect the hand from needle pricks. Hold the sea urchin in one hand and, with a pair of kitchen scissors, trim away the spikes or needles surrounding the body.

title: Ballet: Romeo by the Stuttgart
description: SINCE it first came to New York exactly 10 years ago, the Stuttgart Ballet has done more than any other company to popularize the fullevening story ballet. Last night, the West German company returned to the Metropolitan Opera House with John Cranko's Romeo and Juliet, not only its own best work in the narrative genre, but also one of the best ballet versions of Shakespeare's play in existence.

title: L.I. Strawberries: Flavor of Early Summer
description: JUNE is strawberry time on Long Island. Berries ripening in the fields perfume the countryside. Their heady aroma will linger until early July, when the last morsels of fruit are carried off by the birds, leaving the fields to the daisies.

title: Dining Sans Souci in Washington's Parks
description: WASHINGTON BLUE skies, flowering bushes, no reservations, no tipping, new entertainment daily, full meals from $3 down, minutes from the White House, the Capitol and major museums  few restaurants can match the appeal of a sunblessed lunch in one of Washington's downtown parks.

title: Broadway Star Is Back For an Indefinite Run
description: Broadway grew richer by 4,200 lights Monday night when the MONY weather star returned by popular demand nearly five months after what was to have been the final curtain.

title: Princeton Confers 1,589 Degrees On Its 232d Commencement Day
description: PRINCETON, June 12  On a perfect day in a picturebook setting in front of Nassau Hall, which was the nation's Capitol in 1783, Princeton University conferred bachelor and advanced degrees today upon 1,589 candidates at its 232d commencment.

title: Private Lives
description: IN HER fine new collection of essays, The White Album, Joan Didion speaks of the freeway experience as the only secular communion Los Angeles has. She goes on: Mere driving on the freeway is in no way the same as participating in it. Anyone can drive on the freeway, and many people with no vocation for it do, hesitating here and resisting there, losing the rhythm of the lane change, thinking about where they came from and where they are going. Actual participants think only about where they are. Actual participation requires a total surrender, a concentration so intense as to seem a kind of narcosis, a raptureofthefreeway. The mind goes clean. The rhythm takes over. A distortion of time occurs, the same distortion that characterizes the instant before an accident.

title: Stu Aberdeen, Coached Basketball at Marshall
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., June 12 (AP)  Stu Aberdeen, basketball coach at Marshall University here, died last night of an apparent heart attack while vacationing in New Smyrna Beach, Fla. He was 43 years old.

title: Bribe Law Is Defended In Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  Some Congressional leaders reacted angrily today to reports that a White House task force favors taking steps to weaken the law prohibiting payment of bribes overseas by American corporations.

title: The New Tort Times / Edward Hausner
description: Promptly at 11 A.M. yesterday morning, traffic aides detoured passenger cars away from 49th and 50th Streets as a midday ban on such vehicles  designed to speed buses and cut down on pollution  went into fect between Third and Seventh Avenues. Transportation officials termed the ban a success, as evidenced, below, in views looking west from Park Avenue on 50th Street before 11 A. M., left, and after. Article, page B3.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS The Monsoon Better Come Soon
description: NEW DELHI  The summer monsoon should have broken over many parts of India and Bangladesh two weeks ago; so far there have only been a few desultory showers here and there. By midJune it should be bursting in full fury along India's west coast and northeastern regions; the northeast continues to swelter in the heat. Over 350 people have died of heat stroke.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHEN Emmett Dalton is imprisoned for seconddegree murder, he writes to Eugenia Moore, a former schoolteacher who was his brother's mistress and a member of the Dalton gang as well. Horse stealing, he writes, was how we occupied ourselves in 1889 and 1890. She replies, It seems rather headlong, doesn't it?

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzl
description: MAYOR TAKES UP THE BATON: In shirtsleeves and wearing a hat given him moments before by Urban Park Rangers, Mayor Koch was invited yesterday to lead AllCity High School Band in The Stars and Stripes Forever. Page B6

title: ALICE DALGLIESH, 85; CHILDREN'S AUTHOR
description: She Wrote More Than 40 Books Was an Editor at Scribner's Alice Dalgliesh, one of the most revered figures in the world of children's books, died Monday at her home in Woodbury. Conn. She was 85 years old.

title: Ugandan Refugees Finding A Haven in Southern Sudan
description: JUBA, the Sudan, June 7  In luxury sedans and battered buses, by truck or canoe and on foot, tens of thousands of Ugandans, the privileged and poor alike, have fled to the sanctuary of southern Sudan.

title: Collective Ethic in Soviet Is Eroded As Interest in Private Life Increases
description: MOSCOW  The Soviet Union has always put great importance on the collectivist ethic, teaching children to submerge their individual desires and defer to the broader interests of the group. Now a suoue crosscurrent nas developed, not an Americanstyle individualism but a tentative withdrawal into private life that some Russians believe has begun to erode the population's social conscience and ideological commitment.

title: Events
description: THE MADWOMAN OF CENTRAL PARK WEST, musical comedy by Phyllis Newman and Arthur Laurents, 22 Steps Theater, 200 West 48th Street, 6:15.

title: Videotapes for Homes
description: Along with cable television, pay television and new networks distributed by satellite, the 80's promise a burgeoning of the home video market. The key components of this new field are to be video taperecording units and phonographlike devices that play video disks.

title: House Clears Rep. Mitchell
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)  The House voted unanimously today to dismiss a challenge to the election of Representative Parren J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maryland, after being told by the House Administration Committee that there was no evidence to support it. Debra HananiaFreeman, a Labor Party candidate, had charged voting machine irregularities, fraud, violence, intimidation and dirty tricks.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., June 12'(AP) For.mer landowners in the Harris Neck coastal community and their descendents asked the Federal Government today either to return their land, which waS taken for an air base in World War II, of offer them a fair market price for the prop. erty.

title: Bellevue Surgeons Working to Save Severed Hand of a Jersey Man, 44
description: Surgeons at Bellevue Hospital who last week reattached the severed right hand of a 17yearold music student worked yesterday to try to save the nearly severed hand of a 44yearold New Jersey man.

title: The Bouillabaisse In American Waters
description: ONE of the most memorable meals of my life was an unplanned feast that came about one midsummer noon about 10 years ago.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Please clarify the difference in uses between crushed, finely minced garlic and coarsely chopped garlic. Could not the same results be obtained with a garlic press? When add a crushed clove of garlic to a stew, it falls apart in the cooking.

title: Deaths
description: DICKERSON  Theresa Mary. At the age of 100. On June 11. 1979. A resident of Garden City for 70 years. Beloved wife of the late William T., survived by four grandchildren, William T. Dickerson Jr of Florida, Herbert Dickerson of Poughkeepsie. Caroline Donnelly of Connecticut and Marcia Horan of Connecticut and many great orandchildren. Friends may call at The Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12 St, Garden City, Wednesday 24 & 79PM. Service at The Cathedral of The Incarnation, Garden City, Thursday 11AM. Interment Greenfield Cemetery. In Ilea of flowers, donations to The Cathedral, would be appreciated.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CENTERPIECES The popular Music for a City Evening concerts start their sixth season today in Rockefeller Center, with Lee Castle leading the Jimmy Dorsey Orchestra in melodies from the late 30's. The 90minute diversions from 4:30 to 6 P.M. are planned for afterwork listening. Today's program is in the Channel Gardens, off Fifth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets.

title: POLL SHOWS BELIEF SOVIET LEADS IN ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  With the signing of a SovietAmerican nuclear arms accord only days away, a solid plurality of Americans believe that the United States has fallen behind the Soviet Union militarily but stands a better chance of maintaining equality under the new treaty, according to the latest New  York Times/ CBS News survey.

title: 34 Challenge Sea in SingleHanded Race
description: There is a yacht race in progress today somewhere between Newport, R.I., and Bermuda, one involving 34 participants and 34 yachts, one per person. It is a singlehanded ocean race sponsored by the Society of Lone Offshore sallors (SOLO). The sport. madefamous by the late Sir Francis Chichester, is a dangerous one that has occasionally taken lives.

title: Market Place
description: SHORTAGES of fuel and higher fuel prices have been painful news for airlines. But for several companies that have developed fuelsaving systems for aircraft, the fuel problems have created a sudden surge of interest in their products.

title: IRVING STEINLAUF
description: Irving Steinlauf, a New York realestate broker who specialized in the sale of hotels and apartment buildings, died of a heart attack Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Local Boards Accuse 8 Agencies Of Violating Charter on Borders
description: Eight New York City agencies were accused yesterday by the Coalition of Community Boards of flagrantly violating the City Charter by failing to make their boundaries match those of the local boards.

title: Deaths
description: FORD  Thomas Evans. Memorial service at St. James Episcopal Church. 865 Madison Ave. at 11AM on Thursday, June 14th. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Michigan Cancer Society.

title: Notes on People
description: It was frontpage news 19 months ago when Margaret Hillis, choral director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, replaced an ailing Sir Georg Solti and led the orchestra through a performance of Mahler's complex Eighth Symphony at Carnegie Hall.

title: Wayne Hailed as Symbol Of American Heroism
description: Tributes to John Wayne, who died Monday of cancer, were paid yesterday by public figures in and out of the motionpicture industry. President Carter called him a symbol of many of the most basic qualities that made America great.

title: Cox Cable to Sell Atlanta Service
description: The Cox Broadcasting Corporation said that its subsidiary, Cox Cable Communications Inc., had agreed to sell its Atlanta area cable television and paytelevision services to Cable America Inc. for about $5.5 million.

title: Companies List Their Earnings Reports for Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: SALISBURY GENERAL EXPECTS REBEL PUSH
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, June 12  The military commander of Zimbabwe Rhodesia, who was hopeful only a month ago that guerrillas fighting the Government would desert en masse to the new blackled administration, has warned that the country now faces the sharpest insurgent onslaught of the war.

title: ExSuffolk Aide Is Named in Fraud
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 12  Michael Gotthainer, former deputy Suffolk County executive, was arraigned today on criminal charges that he tried to persuade the County Legislature to approve a resolution authorizing the payment of $55,000 for laboratory equipment he knew had already been paid for as part of a lease.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Pound Climbs Sharply
description: CURRENCY MARKETS

title: LowYield State Bonds Go Begging
description: Topgrade state bonds were offered to investors yesterday at the lowest yields since last autumn as underwriters calculated that the rally in the credit markets would continue. Investors hung back and did not rush to buy. In the benchmark sale of the day, North Carolina, which shares with Utah the reputation as the most creditworthy state, auctioned $60 million of tripleA highway bonds that were subsequently priced to yield from 4.60 percent in 1980 to 5.30 percent in 1995. The First Boston Coporation headed the winning syndicate.

title: Talk of Unions Unsettles a City of Retirees
description: SUN CITY, Ariz.  In a digpute with echoes from the industrial Northeast of 40 years ago, this community of 48,000 people has been divided by a bitter feud between prounion organizers and antiunion forces. It is a scrap that recalls 1 some of the emotional labor struggles of the 1930's, except for one thing  none of the antagonists has a iob. They are all retired.

title: Judge Reserves Decision on Ban of HBomb Article
description: MILWAUKEE, June 12  A Federal district judge reserved decision here today on a motion by attorneys for The Progressive and its editors to revoke the preliminary injunction that has kept the magazine from publishing an article about the hydrogen bomb.

title: Associated Press
description: ASTRO IS OUT AT THE PLATE: Jose Cruz of Houston after being tagged out by Philadelphia's catcher, Bob Boone, when he tried to score from third on a fly ball in the second inning Monday. Phiilies won, 42, in Philadelphia.

title: Rocky Fights It Over
description: Rocky Balboa still had a lot of fighting to do when Sylvester Stallone suffered a torn pectoralis major, the muscle anchored to the ribs that holds the arm in place. Trouble was, Sylvester Stallone was playing Rocky Balboa, and with the injury he couldn't throw a decent punch with his right.

title: Northwest Timbermien Go South
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The American timber industry has traditionally followed sources of supply, cutting its way from North to South and then westward across the Rockies to the Pacific Northwest. Now it is on the move again.

title: Morgan Cuts Prime To 11%
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company redirced its prime rate by onequarter percentage point to 11 percent yesterday. Market analysts were divided over whether the decline signaled a temporary drop in interest costs or whether it represented a more fundamental downturn. Morgan, in its usual terse announcement, merely said the action, lowering the rate it charges its most creditworthy corporate customers, reflected market conditions.

title: House Backs Education Agency But Takes Stand Against Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)  The House of Representatives, resuming debate today on whether to establish a separate department of education, went on record as opposing quotas in education.

title: Radio
description: 8:139 A.M., WQXR. Symphony in B flat, Haydn; Morceau de Concert, SaintSaens.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  A source close to the investigation of two double murders last month in Bedford Hills said that the first three or four witnesses would begin to appear today before a Westchester County grand jury. Members of the victims families were in White Plains yesterday identifying property stolen during the slayings.

title: Letter: On Federal Budget Cuts
description: To the Editor: Now, I admit I've only been in the Senate since 1976 and have a lot to learn. But even so I was astonished to learn from your June 2 editorial (Congress Puts a Lid on Itself) that you know of a second Senate Budget Committee, totally unlike the one on which I sit and of which Ed Muskie is chairman.

title: Best Buys
description: CONSUMERS looking for new ways to cope with soaring food prices had best not turn to Carter Administration officials for innovative tips. They admit that they, too, have run out of ideas.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Development Program Governing Council 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Mitsubishi Pays Dumping Fine
description: TOKYO, June 12 (AP)  The Mitsubishi International Corporation, a United States subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Corporation, a major Japanese trading house, has paid antidumping penalties to the United States for importing Japanese color television sets at unfairly low prices, a Mitsubishi spokesman said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONTREAL, June 12  Just as they dominated play during the regular season, the Islanders and the Montreal Canadiens dominated the National Hockey League's annual awards luncheon today.

title: Economic Scene
description: I DON'T know anything about art, but I know what I like, said the Philistine. And most Americans say they don't know much about economics, but they know what they don't like such as the present state of the Ainerican economy The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows that President Carter's approval rating has tumbled from 42 percent in March to a new low of 30 percent this month, with public concern over the economy and inflation the main cause of his fall. Only 20 percent of the 1,422 adult men and women interviewed around the country said they approved of President Carter's handling of the economy.

title: Architecture: Aalto's Works at CooperHewitt
description: THIS is clearly the time for a show on the work of Alvar Aalto, the Finnish architect who died in 1976 and whose work, along with that of Louis Kahn, helped to lead architecture out of the straitjacket of the International Style.

title: Memories of Anne Frank on 50th Birthday
description: AMSTERDAM, June 12  If she had lived, Anne Frank would have been 50 years old today.

title: Margaret McCullough Simpson; Was Active in Equestrian Circles
description: Margaret McCullough Simpson, an active horsewoman, died Monday while en route to visit relatives in the Connecticut area. Mrs. Simpson, who lived in Winthrop, Me., and Fort Meyers, Fla., was 56 years old.

title: Cuban Defector Complained of Hard Times in City
description: Eduardo Guerra Jimenez, the former Cuban Air Force pilot who was tentatively identified as the man who hijacked a Delta Air Lines jet to Havana Monday, fell on hard times after he defected to this country a decade ago by piloting his Sovietmade jet to Florida.

title: Lefkowitz, at Queens College, Sees Cooperation as Key to City Issues
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, former New York State Attorney General, told graduating Queens College students yesterday that the problems faced by New York City could still be corrected through mutual cooperation.

title: Chess:
description: Superior control of space in the center is most effective in the middle game with many pieces on the board, but it can also be a significant factor in various end games.

title: Lieut. Gen. Edward M. Almond; Led 1950 Inchon Landing Force
description: Lieut. Gen. Edward Mallory Almond, the United States Army officer who commanded the United Nations ground troops in the invasion of Inchon in the Korean War, died Monday at the Brooke Army Medical Center at Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio.

title: Caution Voiced on Dollar
description: BONN, June 12  The president of the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, warned today that much of the American dollar's recent strength on currency markets resulted from shortterm factors and hinted that renewed pressure on the dollar could be in the offing.

title: LID ON INCOME TAX LOWERED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, June 12  The Assembly tonight gave final passage to a $190 million reduction in the state's maximum income tax and also approved a $48 million salestax cut for manufacturers  a move that seemed unlikely only a few weeks ago.

title: BUSINESS. Digest
description: Kuwait says petroleum prices must rise fairly sharply to bring about conservation measures and the development of alternative energy sources in the industrialized nations. The managers OPEC's fourthbiggest oil producer are convinced that the world faces a longterm energy shortage, says Sheik Ali Khalifa alSabah, Oil Minister of Kuwait. [Page A1.]

title: Dalai Lama Flies to Soviet Union
description: NEW DELHI, June 12 (AP)  The Dalai Lama left today for the Soviet Union and Mongolia on his first visit to Communist countries since he fled Tibet after the 1959 revolt against China.

title: April Inventories Up 1.4%, Heaviest Rise in a Year
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)Business inventories climbed a steep 1.4 percent in April, the largest increase in a year, the Commerce Department reported today. manufacturing, retail and merchants wholesale inventories moved up $5.4 billion to $397.1 billion, the report indicated. The dollar increase was bigger than any we've had since October of 1974 as the economy headed into a recession, said a Commerce Department analyst who asked that his name not be used.

title: Billy Carter Is in Debt; Home May Be Forfeited
description: BUENA VISTA, Ga., June 12 (AP) Billy Carter, the President's brother, is heavily in debt and owes thousands of dollars to lenders in several Georgia counties, court records indicate.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: The Saturday cowboys who saunter through Bloomingdale's in handtooled boots and other Western trappings have something new to flip over: extraordinary silver buckles, some as large as saucers and set with a ruby or two. The buckles are made by Tom Taylor, a rodeo rider who quit to take up silversmithing in Albuquerque, N.M. Mr. Taylor and his wife, Jean, make the circuit of the quarter horse races (he makes the award buckle for the American Quarter Horse Congress in Columbus, Ohio) showing his work. Although Mr. Taylor has had no formal art training, his work in leather and silver is exceptional  the silver etching is as delicate as lace. All the buckles, loops and tips and the belts themselves are custommade (allow four weeks for delivery); prices range from $135 for a small buckle to $1,800 for a large gold and silver one. They're in the CuldeSac section on the main floor.

title: Rent Board Votes 61 to Bar Pass Along Charge for Fuel
description: In a raucous meeting that was interrupted repeatedly by shouts and catcalls from the audience, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board yesterday voted not to pass along fuel costs to tenants in about 150,000 rentstabilized apartments.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CLEVELAND, June 12  Directors of the Reliance Electric Company decided today not to make a recommendation to shareholders on the proposal by the Exxon Corporation to purchase all Reliance common stock for $72 share.

title: The City
description: Striking tugboat crewmen and towing employers settled a critical issue yesterday relating to the geographical area of operations, an employer spokesman said. The two sides were scheduled to address economic issues in talks today in an intensified effort to end the 73dayold walkout.

title: Real Estate
description: How Banks Are Using Space Now

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Prices Jump On Prime Rate Drop
description: Spurred by news that the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company had lowered its prime rate, the credit markets again moved powerfully toward higher prices and lower interest rates yesterday.

title: David M. Sibeko, 40, South African Exile, Murdered in Tanzania
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 12 (AP)  David M. Sibeko, a member of the presidential council of the Pan Africanist Congress, a political party of South African blacks, died today after being shot in an apparent party feud, the Tanzanian police said. He was 40 years old.

title: Mets Get Record 10 in 6th, Rout Reds, 126
description: Surrounded by troubles and racked with injuries, the lastplace Mets rose like the furies last night in Shea Stadium and stormed across the plate with 10 runs in the sixth against the Cincinnati Reds for the biggest inning in their 18year history.

title: 3,500 Get Degrees at Brooklyn College Ceremonies
description: The City University has been cut over $1 million since 1975, while the highly effective lobbyists for New York State's private colleges and universities have persuaded all too many elected officials that private is better than public, Dr. John W.
