Kneller said yesterday, addressing his last commencement audience as Brooklyn College's president.

title: Jersey Woman No. 1 Pick
description: When Frank LaPorte, the coach and general manager of the San Francisco Pioneers, called out the name of Montclair State's Pat Colasurdo as the Women's Professional Basketball League's No. 1 draft pick yesterday, it showed how different the W.B.L. draft this season was from last season's. rust, there were no free agents among the 143 players drafted by the 14 teams at the Hotel Roosevelt, since only college seniors were allowed to enter. Second, there were no names to match the luster last season of Carol Blazejowski, Montclair State's scoring machine, Ann Meyers of U.C.L.A., or Lusia Harris and Debbie Brock of Delta State.

title: Big Missile, Little Security
description: President Carter's decision to build the MX missile starts another round in the nuclear weapons race even before the current round is ended. The 95ton MX is the biggest mobile land missile allowable under the pending arms treaty with the Soviet Union. The President's decision clearly pleases the Joint Chiefs of Staff and will help win votes for the SALT II treaty. The more important question, however, is whether this $30billion weapon will make America more secure. That is far from certain.

title: MAYORS FACE FUTURE OF LESS FEDERAL AID
description: PITTSBURGH, June 12  Richard E. Carver, the 41yearold Republican Mayor of Peoria, Ill., favors the MX missile and expanded spending for the cruise missile and believes that the salvation of America's cities lies more in private business development than in new aid from the Federal Government.

title: Private Garwood Gets Leave
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., June 12 (AP)  Pfc. Robert Garwood, stationed at Camp Lejeune while the Marine Corps decides whether to try him on charges that he deserted while in Vietnam, has been granted a 10day leave after suffering a broken collarbone. A Marine spokesman, Maj. John Woggon, said today that Private Garwood fractured his left collarbone Sunday while riding motorcycle on the base.

title: SENATE VOTES DOWN A MOVE TO PRESERVE RHODESIA SANCTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  The Senate voted tonight to overturn President Carter's decision to maintain economic sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, June 12  President Ferdinand E. Marcos installed in office today tne newly elected Moslem officials of southern Mindanao and appealed to all rebels in the area to join in the effort toward national unity.

title: Lawyers: Paid for Doing Nothing?
description: Professional selfregulation enables the members of a profession to write the rules governing their behavior. Lawyers, including New York lawyers, have enjoyed more selfregulation than most other professionals. This experience confirms the proverbial danger in allowing foxes to design security for the chicken coop. It is time to stop it.

title: American Pilot Pedals a Plane Across Channel
description: CAPE GRISNEZ, France, June 12  A flying machine pedaled by an American sitting on a bicycle seat flew over the English Channel today in the first crossing of the channel by a manpowered plane.

title: Mrs. Talmadge Tells of a Coat Stuffed With $100 Bills
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  Insisting that she was a reluctant witness, Betty Talmadge told the Senate Select Committee on Ethics today that in her marriage to Senator Herman E. Talmadge she routinely got spending money by dipping into one of his old overcoats that was stuffed with up to $45,000 in $100 bills.

title: Jackson Calls Approval Of Pact Appeasement
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that Senate approval of the new armslimitation treaty with the Soviet Union would constitute appeasement in its purest form.

title: TV: Lieder by Brahms Sung by Christa Ludwig
description: TELEVISION may be awash in sitcorns and action escapism, but, not infrequently, there are moments of indisputable quality. The elitist, too, must be served  at learit occasionally. That is preCISelyMI IS being Cone for an hour this evening with A Brahms Lieder Recital,lbe Great Performances presentation that can be seen on WNETTV at 9 o'clock.

title: WASHINGTON The Pope's Divisions
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  It has taken over two years to arrange this week's summit meeting between Presidents Carter and Brezhnev in Vienna, but maybe the time wasn't wasted. For both sides now have a more modest appraisal of their modest achievements, and a more realistic appreciation of their common interests and fundamental differences.

title: Dividends
description: xapprox 82.871 per depositary share.

title: White House Criticized By Western Governors
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, June 12 (AP) The predominately Democratic Western governors took aim at the White House again today, sniping at the Carter Administration's policies on wilderness, water and rangeland.

title: Myth as a Man Realized Our Dreams
description: John Wayne was not an empire builder or a frontiersman or even much of a fighting man. Though he was often seen in films as a rugged Army, Navy or Marine Corps officer, he never actually served in any of the armed forces.

title: Klein Nominated in Rowdy Convention
description: BLUE POINT, L.I., June 12  Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein narrowly won the Republican nomination for reelection early this morning at a raucous allnight convention at party headquarters here that left the county's party organization in disarray.

title: Trans World Bid For Spartan Set
description: Directors of the Trans World Corporation and Spartan Food Systems Inc. have approved a merger of Spartan into Trans World, the holding company that operates Trans World Airlines.

title: Market Up As Trading Swells
description: The stock market advanced along a broad front yesterday in the heaviest trading in more than seven months, with the blue chips and specialsituation issues making the best gains.

title: EARNINGS Seagram Net Falls 45.3%; Loss in Exchange Cited
description: The Seagram Company, a major producer and marketer of distilled spirits, reported yesterday that it had a 45.3 percent drop in thirdquarter earnings and a 4.3 percent decline in its net for the nine months ended April 30. The company is based in Canada, but the bulk of its sales are in the United States.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows the past week (Monday. June 4. to Sunday. June 10). listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Kuwait Urges Sharp OilPrice Rise To Firm Level With No Surcharges
description: KUWAIT, June 11  The managers of Kuwait's oilbased economy, convinced that the world faces a longterm energy shortage, say petroleum prices must rise fairly sharply to encourage the industrialized nations to adopt conservation measures and to develop alternative energy sources.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Contrary to the allegations of Sheridan G. Snyder, chairman of Bustop Shelters, Inc. (letter May 31) the bidding process for the bus shelter franchise was formulated and ultimately authorized in full public view by the entire Board of Estimate. Alexander J. Mautner, former Commissioner of Transportation, was not responsible for the bonding requirements or for eliminating the the socalled right of first refusal in favor of Bustop.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWARTZ  Belle. Beloved wife of Joseph. Dear sister of Irving Hurwitz and Lt.Col. Ben Hollis. Services at Parkside Chapel, 9860 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park, today at 11AM.

title: Foe of U.S. in 20's Inspires Nicaraguan Rebels
description: The Sandinist guerrillas who are fighting to topple the Nicaraguan Government of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle take their name from a Nicaraguan revolutionary of the 1920's and 1930's.

title: $3.7 Billion in Boeing Sales
description: SEATTLE, June 12 (UPI)  The Boeing Company said yesterday that, counting its most recently received orders for new aircraft, its sales for the year to date total $3.7 billion for 148 planes.

title: Chuck Berry Pleads Guilty To Tax Evasion for 1973
description: LOS ANGELES, June 12 (UPI)Chuck Berry, the rock singer, pleaded guilty today to charges that he evaded paying nearly $110,000 in income taxes in 1973.

title: Debra Arna Rosenman Is Wed to Rabbi Lyle A. Fishman
description: At the Lincoln Square Synagogue yesterday, Debra Arna Rosenman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yehuda Rosenman of New York, was married to Rabbi Lyle Armin Fishman, rabbi of the Greenburgh Hebrew Center in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.. and son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Fishman of Springfield, N.J. Rabbis Theodore Friedman, Max Routtenberg, Ephraim Shimoff and Ephraim Zomand officiated.

title: His More Than 200 Films in 50 Years Made Wayne a Folk and Father Figure
description: In more than 200 films made during 50 years, John Wayne saddled up to become the greatest figure of one of America's greatest native art forms, the western.

title: Met Opens 13th Season In the Park
description: At about 8:15 last night, a Metropolitan Opera trumpeter came out on the stage erected at the south end of the Sheep Meadow in Central Park and played a jubilant strain from the Triumphal Scene of Verdi's Ada. It served, as a fanfare announcing not only the performance that was to begin 15 minutes later, but also the opening of the Met's summer season of free opera concerts in New York parks.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Indonesia Oil Price Rising
description: TOKYO, June 12 (UPI)  Indonesia has told Japanese oil companies that it will raise oil prices by $2.10 to $3 a barrel effective this Friday, the oil companies said today. They said the new price of Indonesia's Minastype crude oil would be $18.25 a barrel and that of Atakatype crude $21 a barrel.

title: Europeans Seeking to Fly DC10
description: STRASBOURG, France, June 12 (AP)  The civil aviation authorities of 21 European countries today adopted a program aimed at putting Europeanowned DC10 airliners back into service by next Tuesday.

title: Music: Basically Bach Festival Opens
description: INDUBITABLY imitative and definitely derivative though it is in name, the Basically Bach Festival that opened its inaugural season at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night could well turn out to be as welcome a summertime guest as the venerable Mostly Mozart, soon to begin its 13th year.

title: Price Rein Eased for 12 Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 In a decision that reflects the general difficulties the Administration is having with its voluntary pricerestraint campaign, the Government excused the United States Steel Corporation and II oil and chemical companies today from complying with the basic test for price deceleration.

title: Arthur McC. Wilson; Dartmouth Professor Wrote Life of Diderot
description: Arthur McCandless Wilson, professor emeritus of biography at Dartmouth College and government and biographer of the French philosopher Denis Diderot, died yesterday at a hospital in Hanover, N. H. He was 76 years old and lived in Norwich, Vt.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: In the oil business, the man at the pump has never been high on the totem pole. But these days things are looking up in Gasoline Alley. In fact, the corner service station is doing well enough to attract recruits from whitecollar ranks at Exxon, the world's largest oil company. Apparently, pumping gas and wiping windshields is the latest version of rags to riches.

title: Waldheim Says U.N. Might Remove Troops From South Lebanon
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim warned today that it might be necessary to consider removing the United Nations peace force from Lebanon if it was unable to fulfill its mandate.

title: FERENC NACY DEAD; LED HUNGARY IN 47
description: He Was on Vacation in Switzerland. When Communists Took Over, Then Moved to the U.S.

title: Associated Press
description: BAPTISTS ELECT HEAD: The Rev. Adrian P. Rogers, a conservative, was chosen president of Southern Baptist Convention. Page A12.

title: Stunt Man Abandons, An Undeiground Tomb
description: PHENIX CITY, Ala., June 12 (AP) Digger O'Dell, the 63yearold publicity stunt man who had himself buried alive and vowed not to come up until gasoline prices went down, has been forced to surface.

title: I.M.F. Philippine Loans
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (Reuters) The International Monetary Fund announced today that it would grant a loan to the Philippines amounting to $133 million to sunnort its economic development program. In addition, a $56 million credit will be made available to the Philippines because of shortfall  in exports last year, the I.M.F. said.

title: Music: Lee Ritenbur and His Band
description: MUSICIANS who make their living in the recording studios of Los Angeles are supposed to be fast and facile. Conventional wisdom has it that they don't make good performing musiclans because the fact that they derive a comfortable living from their work robs them of a burning desire to play. Besides, they have to be too chameleonlike to develop strong musical personalities of their own.

title: N.H.L. Draft
description: Cam Conn, Montreal, lw; Lee Fogol in, Buffalo, d; Pator Price, Islanders, d; Colin Campbell, Pittsburgh, d; Larry Brown, Los Angeles, d; Pete LoPresti, Minnesota, B; Ron Areshenkoff, Buffalo, c; Moe Hammerstrom, St. Louis, lw; John Gould, Atlanta, rw; Doug Hicks, Chicago, d; Tom Edur, Pittsburgh, d; Wayne Blanchin, Pittsburgh, lw; Mike Forbes, Boston, d; Doug FoYell, Colorado, g; Doug Patey, Washington, c; Bob J. Kelly, Chicago, lw.

title: Sharp Cut Seen In Brazil Coffee
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 13 (AP)  Recent frosts in southern Brazil will result in a loss of more than nine million 132pound bags of coffee over two years and will keep world coffee prices high, the Government said today.

title: Wreckage of NATO Plane Found
description: LONDON, June 13 (Reuters)  A British Navy helicopter crew today found the wreckage of a NATO plane that had been reported missing during a test flig.ht off northwest England yesterday. There was no sign of the two crewmen of the swingwing Tornado, which is intended to play a major part in the North Atlantic alliance's defenses. The plane was spotted in the Irish Sea about 45 miles from land.

title: Tug Catches Fire in Collision
description: GALVESTON, Tex., June 13 (AP)  A tug towing barges filled with flammable cargo burst into flames after colliding with another tug early today in the mouth of the Houston Ship Channel. There were no injuries. It took 4 hours to put out the blaze, the Coast Guard said.

title: GEN. ALMOND DEAD; LED INCHON LANDING
description: Lieut. Gen. Edward Mallory Almond, the United States Army officer who commanded the United Nations ground troops in the invasion of Inchon in the Korean War, died Monday at the Brooke Army Medical Center at Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio. fie was 86 years old and had moved to Texas in Februrary from Anniston, Ala., where he had been a public relations official since his retirement from the Army in 1953.

title: Haines, Carding 75 for 147, Leads Jersey Amateur Golf
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 13 George Haines Jr., a 35yearold mathematics teacher at the Haverford (Pa.) School, led the field of survivors by two strokes today in the 78th New Jersey State amateur golf tournament with a 75 for a 147 total.

title: Rockefeller Warns on Petrodollars
description: LONDON, June 13  The surge in oil prices this year may put so much money in the hands of the producing nations that the world's banks may no longer be able to play the key role in reinvesting the funds, a leading American banker said here today. David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said the problem of financial surpluses within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had become more complex than it was after the sharp price increases that strained the world's financial system five years ago. He said it was imperative that new international measures be adopted to cope with the current flows of oil money, usually called petrodollars.

title: Blake Book Fetches A Record $140.000
description: LONDON, June 13 (AP)  The New York book dealers John F. Fleming Inc. paid 3140,000 today for an 18thcentury book of poems and etchings by William Blake. It was the highest price ever paid for a single work of English literature, the London auctioneers Christie's resorted.

title: Albany Conferees Reach Accord on City U. Financing
description: ALBANY, June 13  Legislative negotiators reached a tentative agreement tonight on state financing over four years of the City University of New York. The wideranging proposal would also provide a $22 million increase in state aid for private colleges.

title: Bomb Scare on a La Guardia Jet
description: A Chicagobound Trans World Airlines 727 jet was forced to return to La Guardia Airport at 10:22 A.M. yesterday after the airline was told there was a bomb on Doard. The police reported that a telephone caller had said there was a bomb aboardthe plane, Flight 315, which left at 9:26 with 98 passengers and seven crew members aboard. No bomb was found.

title: Moscow State Symphony To Play at Queens College
description: A concert by the Moscow State Symphony on Nov. 3 will open the 197980 concert season at Queens College's Colder Center for the Performing Arts. Artists and ensembles scheduled to appear are Andre Watts and Emanuel Ax, pianists; YoYo Ma, cellist; the Prague Chamber Orchestra; the Vienna Mastersingers and Players; the Guarnieri Quartet; the Preservation Hall Jazz Band and the Ohio Ballet.

title: Israelis Forbid Protest At Bir Zeit University
description: JERUSALEM, June 13  The Israeli military government today banned a rally to protest the closing of Bir Zeit University.

title: Letters
description: The Administration's attempt to place the burden of our recent gasoline shortages on Congressional inaction or consumer insensitivity is a thinly disguised effort to mask a series of blunders by the Department of Energy.

title: Hers
description: GOOD taste has been decreed. This year in Metropolis it's Michelangelo, garish running shoes, Le Fromage Triste for lunch. Why does it seem that in matters of taste we are so often bullied? Yes, ordered about. See this. Hear that. Tap dance. Buy Victorian. Unload Utrillo. For God's sake, lower your hem. Blow dry. Filter. Snort. The great weight of fashionable opinion.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Judge Scolds Agency for Eviction
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn scolded the New York City Housing Authority yesterday for trying to evict a working family because it was late in paying rent and said the family would receive better treatment if it were on welfare.

title: Deaths
description: RAPHAELSidney O. The Board of Directors and staff of the United Hospital Fund note with deep sorrow the loss of a beloved friend and colleague, Sidney 0. Raphael. Untiring in his service to hospitals, Mr. Raphael served as VicePresident of The Brookdale Hospital Medical Center and Chairman of the Board of The Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his family.

title: Around the Nation
description: ANCHORAGE, June 13 (AP)  The transAlaska pipeline, with a fiveinch crack temporarily patched, was reported back in operation early today when oil began flowing into the line's southern terminal at Valdez.

title: Special Pleading for Hospitals
description: If the attempt to close excess hospitals in New York City is to succeed, the process must be fairand be perceived to be fair. Otherwise, special interests may succeed in blocking any closings. Such opposition surfaced even before decisions about which hospitals to close. And now the city and state have each announced closing plans that are bound to invite charges of favoritism and make a difficult job even harder.

title: Proposed Repair Of Subway Cars Called a Hazard
description: The executive officer of the New York City Transit Authority's rapidtransit division charged yesterday that the terms of a proposed agreement to repair defective undercarriages of subway cars could actually worsen safety hazards already present in the equipment.

title: Home Beat
description: TEN years ago, Joao Isabel, then a 25yearold law student in Lisbon, was restless. He decided to go to New York and start his life over. His first job in the city was teaching Portuguese at the New School for Social Research. Then he worked for a furniture company, applying gold leaf and antiquing pieces. One day, a customer asked for queensize brass bed. By the time the fourth person asked me the same thing, I had decided that it was time to bring back to life something that people had forgotten about, said Mr. Isabel. Now he has a company that specializes in brass bed frames. But, he said, instead of stamping sheets of solid brass, we work with brass castings, or solid rod fittings, that are handcarved on a lathe. The headboards and bed frames don't have a beer can feeling, he said, but are heavy and sturdy. In time, Mr. Isabel added, the brass will look like that of an old bed that turns green, and you have to spend hours cleaning it. Mr. Isabel likes that. The patina looks better a few years after you buy the bed. He believes that a brass bed is an investment, because the price of the base is going up all the time. He will make any size frame or headboard, in any style. Delivery, depending on the nature of the design, takes six to 10 weeks. The price for a queensize headboard starts at about $350; a head, foot and frame set starts at $595. Isabel Brass Furniture is at 120 East 32d Street. The telephone number is 6893307.

title: No Price Cut, Toyota Says
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. said this week that it was unaware of any planned reduction in the price of Toyota automobiles sold in the United States. Later, Toyota officials in Japan confirmed that prices would not be cut.

title: Astros Niekro Checks Phils, 43, for No. 10
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) Joe Niekro pitched his ninth straight victory, a club record, and his 10th of the season, tops in the National League, as the Houston Astros beat the Philadelphia Phi hies tonight, 43.

title: LaCoss And Reds Top Mets
description: Joe Torre didn't think it was a dayafter syndrome or a psychological letdown, or anything like that.

title: Alleged Nazi's Guest Knifed on L.
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 13  A 70yearold Bronx man was stabbed and critically wounded here yesterday and his wife was injured by an assailant who apparently thought he was attacking Boleslays Maikovskis, who is suspected of being a Nazi war criminal. The attack took place in Mr. Maikovskis's yard, and the victims were house guests.

title: Norwegian Premier, On Visit, Bids Senate Approve Arms Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Norway's Prime Minister has appealed for Senate approval of the projected AmericanSoviet treaty to limit strategic arms, saying rejection could be a major setback to EastWest relations.

title: Stage: Shevelove's Happy New Year
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 10 Cole Porter and Philip Barry stand as twin pinnacles of urbane Sophistication in the 20's and 30's. When they were alive, they operated in separate spheres, but after Barry's death, Porter wrote the score for the film High Society, the musical version of Barry's The Philadelphia Story. Memories of that felicitous score echo as we await Happy New Year, a new musical based on Barry's play Holiday, with songs by Porter. In the absence of author and composer, the talented Burt Shevelove is acting as adapter and director. His musical Happy New Year had its world premiere during the weekend at the Stratford (Ontario) Festival.

title: $5 Minimum on Sales OF Gasoline Proposed By Koch and Solomon
description: Gasoline customers in New York City would be required to purchase a minimum of $5 worth of fuel under a proposal by Deputy Mayor Peter J. Solomon.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: Source: American Petroleum Institute

title: Redoing Brooklyn Brownstones
description: FROM the outside, most Brooklyn brownstones look alike. Same period, same facade, same stoop and predictable color  and on the inside, probably the same weekender in faded jeans, scraping the paint off his Victorian staircase.

title: 2YearOld Center Spurs Detroit Revival
description: DETROIT, June 13  When the Renaissance Center opened its doors on the banks of the Detroit River here, in virtual isolation from the rest of the central business district, city leaders praised it as a catalyst for the rebirth of a city that had experienced more than its share of hard times. Yet, a debate raged on two major points.

title: Margaret McCullough Simpson; Was Active in Equestrian Circles
description: Margaret McCullough Simpson, an active horsewoman, died Monday while en route to visit relatives in the Connecticut area. Mrs. Simpson, who lived in Winthrop, Me., and Fort Meyers, Fla., was 56 years old.

title: Monetary Fund Pact For. Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (Reuters) Turkey and the International Monetary Fund have reached agreement in principle on a financial arrangement that would allow Turkey to borrow money from the fund, a spokesman for the fund said today.

title: Motorman Gets Medal for Help To Renee Katz
description: Justo Barreiro, the subway motorman who leaped from the cab of his IND train a week ago to help rescue Renee Katz, the 17yearold high school student who was pushed into the path of his train, received the Mayor's Medal yesterday at a City Hall ceremony.

title: Furnishing a Child's Space: Enter HighTech
description: THEY worried, at least in the beginning, that their book's hardedge esthetic would not sit well with those of more sedate tastes, those who gravitate to matching furniture suites, Little Bo Peep wallpapers and ruffled curtains.

title: Woodside Rages Over Influx of Illegal Aliens
description: Send them back where they came from, said Ed Fawley, his voice rising emotionally, as he sipped a Coke in the Woodside, Queens, bar called Shelley's that he has owned for 18 years.

title: Tenneco Plugs Well Off Jersey
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 13 (AP) Tenneco has plugged the Baltimore Canyon well where it recently discovered oil and gas and has begun drilling far to the south on the first of 39 new tracts leased by the Government in February, the company said yesterday.

title: John N. May Jr., Long a Director Of Summit, NJ., Trust Company
description: John N. May Jr., a former director of the Summit Trust Company in New Jersey, died Sunday at Overbrook Hospital, after a brief illness. He was 82 years old, and lived in Summit.

title: Loren Murchison, 80, Track Star
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J. June 13 Loren Murchison, a goldmedal winner for the United States in the 400meter relay at the 1920 and 1924 Olympics, died Monday in Point Pleasant Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Home Improvement
description: IF your walls are covered with wood paneling, you can drive nail in almost everywhere and it will hold when you want to hang picture, a mirror or a set of shelves. However, the walls in most homes and apartments are actually hollow  theyare covered with plaster or drywall (gypsum board that may vary from %to 1inches thick) over a framework of lengths of twobyfour lumber, known as studs.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Sales of the Big Three auto companies fell 29.8 percent from the yearearlier level in the first third of June, the companies reported. They attributed the decline, the seventh straight for a 10day selling period, to uncertainties over fuel supplies. Sales also tumbled from the levels reported in May. Truck sales also fell sharply. [Page D1.]

title: House, Reversing Itself, Rejects a 5.5% Pay Rise
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)  The House reversed itself today on the issue of raising its members salaries by rejecting a bill that would have given them a 5.5 percent costofliving increase in October.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmosone Ic Administration/UP1 Scattered cloudiness covers most of northern New England, southern and central Florida, the Tennessee, Ohio and Missouri Valleys and the central Plains States. Clear skies are apparent over the North and Middle Atlantic States, the Midwest, the Southwest and the Central and Southern Pacific States.

title: Cosmos Win, 32, on Late Goal
description: TULSA, Okla., June 13  Tony Carbognani's first North American Soccer League goal came at the right time for the Cosmos tonight.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: A $500,000 race pitting Spectacular Bid against one or both of the colts who beat him in the Belmont Stakes Coastal and Golden Act  is being. seriously considered for the Meadowlands track in New Jersey.

title: 8 From China to Observe Dance Events in U.S.
description: Eight teachers and performers from the Peking Dance Conservatory and the National Dance Company of China will tour the United States from Sunday through July 16 to observe American dance.

title: Senate Delays Debate On Draft Registration And Passes Arms Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  A proposal in the Senate requiring young men of draft age to register with the Government was pulled back from debate today after an agreement to raise the issue in the next few weeks was reached.

title: The Prospect Is Sneezy For HayFever Victims
description: BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 14 (AP) The coming summer could turn into sneezing nightmare for hayfever sufferers.

title: TV Tribute to Wayne Sunday
description: As a tribute to John Wayne, WNEWTV, Channel 5, will preempt its regular programming this Sunday afternoon and evening to televise four films starring tne actor, who died Monday. The station has scheduled Rio Grande (1950) at 1 P.M., Dakota (1945) at 3:15 P.M., Sands of Iwo Jima (1949) at 5 P.M. and The Searchers (1956) at 7:25 P.M.

title: The U.N. Today
description: United Nations Development Program  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Advertising
description: BACK in 1977 when beleaguered Amtrak was experiencing a worse fiscal crisis than usual, all the frills were cut, including the one called advertising. Faced with that untenable situation, the marketing chief approached Paul H. Reistrup, then president, with a tear in nis eye to ask how he could do his job without the magic of advertising. Pull a rabbit out of a hat, suggested the president.

title: Tighter Rule Is Proposed On Estimates by Movers
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) Movers of household goods would not be able to charge customers more than the premove estimated price under a rule proposed today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Julie M. Sogg Bride Of Samuel Seymour
description: The marriage of Julie Meg Sogg, daughter of Mrs. Edward Munves and Jonathan Sogg, both of New York, to Samuel Whitney Seymour took place yesterday at the Lotos Club. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thaddeus Seymour of Winter Park, Fla., where his father is president of Rollins College. Justice Arthur Markewich of the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division performed the ceremony.

title: Why Carter Wants Schlesinger to Stay
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 President Carter's determination to stick with James R. Schlesinger, despite Congressional pressures for his resignation and despite advice from senior White House aides that the bluntspoken.

title: Halston Focuses on Legs
description: LEGS are spotlighted in Halston's madetoorder collection for fall. Not in any strident, blatant way, of course. No thighhigh hemlines or shocking slits: That's the easy way to get attention.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: CASTERS provide an easy way to move large or heavy pieces of furniture and there are more than 300 kinds manufactured, including ones for carts, beds and chairs; indoor casters, casters to be used on rugs and corner casters. The more common ones are ease to find in hardware stores, but there are also some unusual casters available.

description: Music

title: Assoclated Press
description: MAGIC MOMENT: Larry Bowa of Phils flipping ball Bud Harrelson for force play during game Tuesday night against Astros in Philadelphia. Nino Espinosa, former Met, pitched sixhitter as Phils topped Astros, 40.

title: Looting Is Widespread In Managua as Troops Try to Dislodge Rebels
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 13 Looting broke out throughout Managua today as National Guardsmen tried to dislodge young rebels who have seized most of the capital's outlying slum districts in an offensive aimed at overthrowing President Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Rhodesia Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON. June 13 (AP)  Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate killed an amendment extending trade sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia yesterday:

title: Business Records
description: DAVID DESSNER, 31 Shore View Drive, Yonkers. Liabilities, $12,800; assets, $4,030.

title: Stage: Phyllis Newman Portrays Madwoman
description: IN a onewoman show such as Phyllis Newman has provided in The Madwoman of Central Park West, there is an inevitable blurring of lines between performer and personage.

title: Baptist Leader Keyed to Bible
description: HOUSTON, June 13  A normal Sunday for the Rev. Dr. Adrian Pierce Rogers consists of preaching two sermons in the morning, holding a few meetings in the afternoon and conducting another service in the evening.

title: TV Union Fears 'superstations
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI)The economic rights of television performers are being trampled by operators of superstations that send local television signals to distant cable televisor systems, a union spokesman told Congress today.

title: Gen. Rowny Retiring; Worked on Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)  Lieut. Gen. Edward L. Rowny, a member of the negotiating team in the SovietAmerican talks on nuclear arms limitation who reportedly opposes some provisions of the new accord, has filed for retirement, military sources said today.

title: Horse Show
description: FirstYear Green Working Hunter Championship  Champion, Sherry Robertson's Strath Tay, 15 points; Reserve, Hilltop Stable's J. B. Jopair, 9.

title: Rhodesia Lauds U.S. Senate's Vote
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, June 13 (AP)  Government officials were jubilant today about the United States Senate's refusal to extend economic sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia. They said they were eagerly awaiting the outcome of the House vote scheduled for next week.

title: SingleFamily Housing Issues
description: Two bond issues to raise $280 million for singlefamily mortgages were tentatively priced yesterday. unaerwnting group led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company set terms on $175 million of New Mexico Mortgage Finance Agency single. family housing revenue bonds to yield as much as 7.20 percent. The sale is contingent on the issue's getting a clean legal opinion stating that the bonds are unquestionably taxexempt.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ASCONA (Nordana Line Barber Steamship Lines). Fos June 24, Tripoli July 1, Benghazi 4, Piraeus 14 and Alexandria 16; sails from Port Newark, N.J.

title: 13 Are Killed in Borneo Flood
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 13 (AP)  At least 13 persons were reported dead today in floods that hit the town of Balikpapan on the east coast of Borneo after heavy rains. Six thousand people were reported evacuated. The Balikapan air base was closed and all land communica, tion with the town was cut off, a report said today.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Bloomington. (Radio WINS, 8:30 P.M.)

title: The Region
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.  The defense in the murder trial of Robert Reldan, an exconvict and former house painter accused of killing two Bergen County women in October 1975, rested yesterday without calling any witnesses.

title: Fall of the Shah Prompts Saudis To Build Forces
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Saudi Arabia is in the predicament of an immensely wealthy man who has counted on the police station next door to guard his riches. Suddenly, the reliable policemen are gone, replaced by unpre dictable neighbors. In this situation, Saudi Arabia has had no alternative but to engage in a frantic search for security in the form of modemarmed forces.

title: Art Dealer Marries Leslie di Carpegna
description: Leslie Boocock di Carpegna of Millbrook, N.Y., was married in the charttry of St. Thomas's Episcopal Church yesterday to Rutgers Barclay of New York. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony.

title: Wanted, for the F.B.I.
description: It has been seven years since the death of the legendary first Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation but not until now has the era of J. Edgar Hoover seemed truly over. In his 48 years in office, F.B.I. power developed to the point where, at times, the agency seemed to decide for itself which laws it would enforce and which it would obey. After the Senate Intelligence Committee uncovered abuse after abuse, starting long before Watergate, a process of correction began. In the Ford Administration, Attorney General Levi laid down strict regulations for the F.B.I. But even that effort was grounded only in executive authority, subject to change by some less scrupulous future administration.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury disclosed plans yesterday to sell $5.5 billion of twoyear and fouryear notes next week, and the announcement caused the credit markets  already a little shaky after the recent strong rally  to decline in price.

title: Deaths
description: BURSTEINLillian, dearly beloved wife of Harry, mother of Florence, Susan. Mother in law of Irwin Kaminsky, Grandmother of Gary.Died June 12. Services at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Flatbush Ave Brooklyn NY June 13, 1978.

title: Two Convicted of Fraud In $35 Million Bank Loans
description: Two businessmen, Nicolas Reisini and James L. Fallon, were convicted yesterday of fraudulently obtaining $35 million in bank loans with the help of former high official of the Anaconda Company.

title: A Memoir of Gandhi By Shirer Due in 1980
description: So closely has William L. Shirer been identified with the European scene, especially with the history of German fascism, that most readers are not likely to remember that as a young reporter for The Chicago Tribune he spent from 1934 to 1936 in India, where he enjoyed the friendship of Mohandas K. Gandhi. They would walk and talk together, the reporter would watch Gandhi work on his spinning wheel and the like. It was a connection that added enormously to the authority of Mr. Shirer's coverage of India, then in the middle of its civil disobedience movement, which Gandhi originated and led.

title: Woman Berates Carey As He Receives Award
description: A dinner at the New York Hilton Hotel honoring Governor Carey was briefly disrupted last night by a woman protesting his welfare policies.

title: Nevil Ford, a Retired Banker, 88
description: Nevil Ford, a retired investment banker associated with the First Boston Corporation, and the chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York during World War II, died Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 88 years old and was a resident of Manhattan.

title: Technology
description: THE Exxon Corporation's claims for its variable speed electric motor control device are coming under sharp attack in the electric motor industry, where critics charge that the concept is old and that pricing problems have not been solved.

title: German Court Jails Four On Trial for War Crimes
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, June 13 (AP)  Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, a former Queens resident, and three other defendants in a Nazi warcrimes trial were jailed today as a precaution against their leaving the country.

title: Russians Covet Western Affluence But Find Democratic Ideals Alien
description: MOSCOW  Soviet society has been exposed to more American influence during this decade of dtente than in any other period since the Bolshevik Revolution, deepening the ambivalence that Russians have historically felt toward the West.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: ON THE MOVE With a repertory of more than 30 works, the Claude Kipnis Mime Theater has drawn acclaim here and abroad for its short pieces and fulllength interpretations of Mussorgsky's Pictures at an Exhibition, Bartok's Miraculous Mandarin and Stravinsky's Histoire du Soldat. After a recent tour of Mexico, the company is giving five performances at Pace University, its only New York appearance this season.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Grain and soybean futures climbed yesterday amid continued speculation that the Soviet Union and Eastern European nations will need to buy more United States grain this year and next.

title: Board of Estimate and Council Try For Agreement on Budget Savings

Friend of Minnie Smith. Reposing Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 St. Visiting Thursday 79pm, Service Friday fpm.

title: Market Place

National carries more of its passenger load in DC10's than any other airline. But if National's shareholders were scared, its merger suitors were not. This week both Pan American World Airways and Eastern Air Lines declared their continuing ardor for National and discounted the costs that will be necessary to fix the DC10 problems.

title: U.S. Warns On Inflation CatchUp
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  The Carter Administration's inflationfighting agency said today that the United States was 'at a critical crossroads in its effort to reduce inflation without incurring the costs of recession and rising unemployment.

title: U.S. Confirms Report That Amin Is Living in Libya
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Idi Amin, the deposed President of Uganda, is living in exile in Libya, United States officials said today.

title: Upstate New York Counties Thwart a Woodstock Encore
description: Hastily enacting laws to restrict rock festivals, a number of upstate New York counties have blocked an attempt by John H. Morris Jr., a music promoter, to stage a threeday concert on the 10th anniversary of Woodstock, the festival that drew more than 300,000 fans to Bethel, N.Y.

title: Brazil ls High on Alcohol Fuel
description: SAO JOSE DOS CAMPOS, Brazil, June 11 Even in Brazil, home of some of the world's most exotic ways of worship, one had to wonder why a grown man was crouching behind the tailpipe of an idling car, inhaling deeply and smiling the smile of the rapturously committed. Sweet, isn't it? he asked, ladling a handful of warm air toward a visitor.

title: Carter Plan Gets Boost
description: WASHINGTON. June 13 (UPI)  The Senate Human Resources Committee gave a boost to Mr. Carter's proposed hospital cost containment legislation today by recommending it to the full Senate by an 11to4 vote. However, the Senate Finance Committee also must approve the measure before the bill is considered by the Senate.

title: Philippines Foreign Debt
description: MANILA, June 13 (UPI)  The Philippines outstanding foreign debt stood of $8 billion at the end of 1978, up 22 percent from the previous year's $6.56 billion, official fieures showed today. A report by the Philippine central bank said that the public sector had accounted for 97 percent of the $1.44 billion debt increase. It noted that of the total foreign debt, the Government had borrowed 54 percent, or $4.35 billion.

title: Kennedy Says He Informed Carter Of Likely Support for Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that he told President Carter more than two months ago that he expected to support him for the Democratic nomination next year instead of running against him.

title: Notes on People
description: Tired of being a fugitive, Louis Poveremo, one of 10 convicts who escaped from Dutchess County Hospital, Beacon, N.Y., in May 1977, decided to return. And, since this is the Age of the Celebrity, he arranged for a spokesman to send out news releases saying that he would arrive yesterday on American Airlines Flight 18 at Kennedy International Airport at 5:30 A.M. The information was not furnished to the police, however, and they spent the better part of the morning trying to track him down.

title: Spoleto Festival Opens June 27 With a Bellini
description: The Festiiral of TWO Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, founded 21 seasons ago by Gian Carlo Menotti, Will open on June 27 with a new prodtiction of Bellini's La Sonnanibula. ft Will be conducted by the festival's newly appointed music director, Christian Badea. The designs are by Pier Luigi Sani4ritani.

title: A New Penn Central Emerges From Reorganization
description: For years the stockholders of the defunct Penn Central Transportation Company stood helplessly on the sidelines as the Government carved Conrail and parts of Amtrak out of their bankrupt business.

title: Chain Sales Up for April
description: April sales for 30 of the nation's largest retail chains were up an average of 9.5 percent from sales in April 1978, according to Chain Store Age, a trade publication.

title: Film: 'Kirlian Witness,' Parapsychology in SoHo:Only the Plants Know
description: THOUGH occultism seems a lazy way of dealing with life, stories of the occult can be fun when, like "The Turn of the Screw" or even "Dracula," they operate according to the laws of their own consistent, if completely mysterious, universes. Too often, however, they are inconsistent as well as lazy, which more or less describes "The Kirlian Witness," a first feature by Jonathan Sarno."The Kirlian Witness" is a movie that sort of dabbles in parapsychology, being about a plant that fingers (leafs?) a murder suspect. The low-budget, independent movie, which opens tonight at the Film Forum, is quite nicely acted by its New York cast and makes good use of its lower Manhattan locales, but there's no way to sit through the inanities of its plot and the deadpan understatements of its dialogue without wanting to hoot a lot.This is the story of Rilla, a photographer who lives in a SoHo loft with her husband, Robert, an architect, and just one floor above her sister Laurie, a taciturn kook who invites strange men into her plant-laden apartment to meditate and screams hysterically if they make passes at her.The film opens with Rilla, who is the narrator as well as the heroine, glumly recalling events she describes as "this mess.""If anyone was left holding the bag," says Rilla, "it was me," which, considering that "this mess" involves three murders, including those of her sister and someone else close to her, must be the least adequate introduction to a movie in the history of the cinema.Mr. Sarno and Lamar Sanders, who take credit for the screenplay, seem to be writers who can't cope with their own narrative inventions. Instead of being logical, they wring their hands. When Rilla finds Laurie very dead  murdered  on the roof of their loft building, does she scream or yell or fly into some other kind of panic? No. She just becomes very quickly sad and goes downstairs  one suspects  to think about it.The pursuit of the killer  and this is where the parapsychology comes in  leads Rilla to conduct her own experiments in communication with plants, including Laurie's favorite, a rhododendron so sickly looking that I hoped it would turn out to be a romantic poet.The cast is headed by Nancy Snyder (Rilla), the pretty blond actress who was so good as Joan of Arc in the Off Off Broadway production of Jules Feiffer's "Knock, Knock" but who was replaced by Lynn Redgrave when the producers fancified the show for its Broadway failure. Joel Colodner plays Rilla's husband, and Ted Leplat appears as an unreliable handyman, the sort who comes in to fix the tub and then, uninvited, takes a bath in it."The Kirlian Witness" will be shown at the Film Forum tonight through Sunday at 7:45 o'clock and repeated next Thursday through Sunday at the same time.

title: About Cannondale
description: CANNONDALE, Conn., June 11  As the latest fourthdegree inductee into the old farmers Grange here, June Havoc finds herself a redeemed actress, finally accepted by Yankees after 20 years residency in Connecticut.

title: Court Awards $100 Million to Indians in Land Claim
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)  The United States Court of Claims, in the largest court settlement ever awarded American Indians, said today that the Sioux Nation was entitled to more than $100 million as compensation for land confiscated by the Federal Government a century ago.

title: Palestinian Campus in West Bank, Known as an Arab Berkeley, Is in State of Turmoil
description: BIR ZEIT, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, June 11  Bir Zeit University, a cluster of old school buildings and private houses in this Arab hilltop town 15 miles north of Jerusalem, is sometimes called the Berkeley of the West Bank. Like the Berkeley campus in the 1960's, Bir Zeit is in a state of agitation and turmoil.

title: PARADE TODAY
description: A parade celebrating Flag Day will begin today at noon at Fulton and Water Streets. The parade will march south on Water Street to Wall Street, west to Broadway and then south on Broadway to Fraunces Tavern at 54 Pearl Street.

title: Deaths
description: LEGATMeta Ehrlich. On June 12, 1979. Adored wife of the late Mucki. Beloved sister,devoted aunt and dearest cousin.Services Thursday, 10:30am, The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions to N YU School of Medicine,Leukemia Research Foundation. Attention: Dr. Robert Silber

title: State to Tap Reserves of Gas for Weekends
description: ALBANY, June 13  To shorten long lines and avert violence at service stations, New York State announced today that it would tap its own emergency reserve of 25 million gallons of gasoline to supply dealers who are willing to stay (men on weekends.

title: Dividends
description: Pe. Stk. payriod Rate recordable

title: Miss Bernstein to Be Adviser to Regan
description: Blanche Bernstein, former New York City welfare chief, was named yesterday to be a consultant to the New York State Comptroller for the next six months on a new program that seeks to improve welfare, Medicaid and socialservice programs.

title: All 5 Democrats Abstain on Vote As Senate Unit Rejects Hongisto
description: ALBANY, June 13 With all its Democratic members abstaining in protest, the Crime and Corrections Committee of the Republicanled Senate today rejected the nomination of Richard D. Hongisto as Commissioner of Correctional Services.

title: Companies Warned On Auditors
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  The Securities and Exchange Commission warned companies today against using their outside accountants to provide certain kinds of consulting services.

title: Burma, Long Isolationist, Is Looking Abroad for Aid
description: RANGOON, Burma  Burma, like a turtle, poked a little farther out of its isolationist shell in recent weeks, taking a few more halting steps along the development path that neighboring Southeast Asian nations sprinted down years ago.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Ocean shipping around the world is in a state of utter chaos. Rates are low to the point of unprofitability and competition is intense. In the United States, several ocean carriers have recently gone bankrupt. IU International, a diversified company, is deciding whether to get rid of its shipping subsidiary by spinning it off to stockholders.

title: Jazz: Annie Ross as Solo Singer
description: ANNIE ROSS is best known in this country as the female voice in the trio of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, which, from 1958 to 1962, added a new dimension to vocalized jazz with its frequently rapidfire, tonguetwisting delivery of lyrics written to celebrated jazz solos and arrangements. In her native England, however, Miss Ross is at least as well known as an actress and as, as she says, an entertainer.

title: Carter Wins House Test on Education Department
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  The Carter Administration won a crucial test tonight as the House, after 13 hours of debate, rejected a move to kill a bill creating a Cabinetlevel department of education.

title: Torsney Ouster From the Force Expected Today
description: Robert Torsney, the white police officer found not guilty by reason of insanity in the 1976 shooting death of a black teenager in Brooklyn, will be dismissed from the Police Department by Commissioner Robert J. McGuire, according to high police officials. The dismissal is expected to be announced today.

title: House Panel Asks 70% Windfall Tax
description: WASHINTON, June 13  The House Ways and Means Committee voted tonight to toughen President Carter's proposed windfall profits tax on the oil industry by raising the levy to 70 percent from the 50 percent Mr. Carter had suggested. The vote on the amendment by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, was 22 to 14 and came after, the committee rejected earlier proposals to set the tax as high as 85 percent and as low as 60 percent.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The price of gold in Europe and New York retreated yesterday from records reached earlier this week, while the dollar was mixed against major currencies.

title: Bridge:
description: Look for Some Overtricks When Contract Is Assured Once a contract is assured, a good player starts thinking about overtricks, which are of particular importance in pair play and should not be neglected in other forms of the game. The aim is not necessarily to make as many tricks as possible, at any cost, but to maximize the prospects.

title: Finlandization: Not the Worst Fate
description: HELSINKI  I came here armed to the teeth with pamphlets. Finlandization was the agitated theme that was about to descend upon me, and I had all the literature at hand, a suitcase full of articles, brochures and books, an devoted to the subject the Finns constantly insist is malevolently misunderstood in the West and which Westerners contend must be more honestly and critically addressed if certain other free European peoples are not to fall prey to the danger of being Finlandized.

title: Soviet Reports Deaths of a Pilot And a Leading Aircraft Engineer
description: MOSCOW, June 13 (UPI) The Soviet press today reported the death of a top military pilot, Col. Yevgeni Bryakov, and a leading aircraft design engineer, Vladimir A. Orlov.

title: Riot Free Victor in Ox Ridge Horse Show
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 13  There are some days when Rodney Jenkins is frustrated in the horse show world, but today was pot one of them. The 35yearold Jenkins from Orange, Va., riding Eche Spruance's Riot Free in the regular working hunter division, won the championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club Show in effortless fashion.

title: End to U.S. Doctor Shortage by Late 1980's Forecast
description: The nation's shortage of doctors is expected to end by the late 1980's, a decade earlier than forecast, according to a report based on two studies, one of which is believed to be the largest study of the way physicians practice.

title: Architectural Drawings On View at the Modern
description: Drawings of architectural projects by Roger Ferri and Allen Greenberg, architects who would like to revitalize public space, will be on view at the Museum of Modern Art through July 15 in secondfloor galleries.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Aristar Inc., engaged in consumer financing, auto leasing and insurance, has announced the appointment of Leigh R. Meininger as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the John Alden Life Insurance Company, a wholly owned subsidiary.

title: Rangers and Islanders Lose Defensemen in the Expansion Draft
description: MONTREAL, June 13  Five defensemen from the two New York teams were selected within the first four rounds of the National Hockey League's expansion draft today. Overall, 65 players were taken by Winnipeg, Quebec, Hartford and Edmonton, the four World Hockey Association teams that will join the N.H.L. officially iri 10 days.

description: Morning

He was the beloved husband of Mrs. Eleanor (Vooth) Albrecht, father of Kenneth and Michael Albrecht, Mrs. Margaret Valashinas, Ms. Sheila Walsh and Mrs. Rosemary Ausbrook, brother of Samuel Albrecht, Mrs. Esther Ershowsky, Mrs. Minnie Paley, Mrs. Anna Swartz, Mrs. Bess Barron and leaves thirteen grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. It's an unusual design combination, but it looks warm and inviting in a model room at the Seventh Annual International Craft Show, which opens today at the New York Coliseum and continues through Sunday.

description: WASHINGTON, June 13  President Carter, saying that oil spills and human exposure to chemical wastes were two of the worst environmental problems facing the nation, asked Congress today for legislation that would establish a $1.6 billion fund to speed the Government's response to the hazards.

description: RICHARD III, by Shakespeare, the Coe Theater, 138 West 48th Street, 8.

description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Troops who participated in Shot Smoky, a nuclear weapons test in the atmosphere in Nevada in 1957, and later began showing what appears to be a high incidence of leukemia actually received small doses or radiation, a study just completed for the Defense Nuclear Agency shows.

description: On Tuesday evening, John Barnett, the assistant curator of the United States Navy Art Collection; parked a white Navy van containing 81 paintings valued at $25,000 on 52d Street between Second and Third Avenues. When he went out the next morning to drive to Washington, the van was gone, along with the paintings, which depicted scenes from the 1976 Operation Sail.

title: Dispute At Elliman Meeting
description: Douglas Elliman & Company, one of the city's leading managers of residential properties, held its first share, holder meeting in two years yesterday in the wake of an investigation of the firm by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Gasoline Stores Resume Slide, but Oil Level Rises
description: After an unexpectedly sharp jump in the week that ended June 1, inventories of gasoline resumed their downward slide last week, according to statistics released yesterday afternoon by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Shah Leaves Fate to Providence
description: CUERNAVACA, Mexico, June 13 (AP)  The exiled Shah of Iran said here today that he was leaving it to Providence whether he escaped assassination or ever returned to his country.

title: Financial General Studies Arab Offer
description: Financial General Bankshares Inc., operator of more than 12 banks, mainly in Washington, D.C., Virginia and Maryland, said it had delayed a decision on a takeover offer from a group of Arab investors.

title: Topics
description: Choosing carefully from the West's arsenal of incendiary rhetoric, Senator Henry Jackson calls Presidents Nixon, Ford and Carter the sponsors of anneasement of the Soviet Union and compares Mr. Carter's journey to the Vienna summit this weekend to Neville Chamberlain's sellout to Hitler at Munich in 1938.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Because of trashremoval problems during the tugboat strike, alternateside parking regulations will be in effect today and tomorrow in Manhattan and Brooklyn only.

title: Health Experts Reveal New Strategy on Disease
description: ATLANTA, June 13 (UPI)  A 10year battle plan to substantially reduce the incidence of many diseases in this country, with major emphasis on prevention, was outlined today at a meeting of top health experts from across the nation. nuenaing tne first of a twoday session sponsored by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare were more than 300 public health officials who were asked to help formulate specific disease prevention and health promotion objectives to be achieved by 1990.

title: STRIKE BY TRUCKERS OVER FUEL EXPANDS
description: A truck driver's wife was in critical condition yesterday in Tuscaloosa, Ala., after she was hit by sniper fire, as independent truckers escalated a nationwide protest aimed at getting more diesel fuel at lower prices.

title: Israelis Heckle and Jeer in Debate Over Settlement
description: JERUSALEM, June 13  Cries of Fascist! Racist! Infantile! and Idiot! rang through Parliament today as a controversy over the latest Jewish settlement on the occupied West Bank reached the floor.

description: PARIS  While the Carter Administration is thinking only of the signing of SALT II at the summit this weekend, Leonid Brezhnev is already figuring out the followup to his strategic triumph: a different treaty, called M.B.F.R., to assure the Soviet domination of Europe with more conventional arms and armies.

description: Keep Eye on Whole Board In Playing Leftover 1 Point

title: Big Chicago Bank Sets 11% Prime
description: Chicago's Continental Illinois Bank yesterday became the second of the nation's largest banks to announce a reduction in its prime lending rate to 11 percent from 11 percent.

title: EarlyJune Auto Sales Off at Big 3
description: DETROIT, June 13 (UPI)  Sales by the nations Big Three auto makers tumbled 29.8 percent in early June, the companies reported yesterday. They attributed the yeartoyear drop for the 10day selling period, the seventh in row, to continuing uncertainties over summer fuel supplies.

title: Stage: In a Cafe on the West Side
description: CAFE, by Joel Vance, is comedy in three acts and any number of plots. They are all lively, although some of them are utterly incomprehensible. and a few are simply unhinged. Cafe is intent on sophisticated whimsy and the bittersweet rue of love, and every so often it almost finds one or the other.. Mostly, however, it finds only hysteria. Tbeplay is at A Little Theater.

title: N.B.A. Studies Farm System
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Creation of a farm system for the National Basketball Association, long a subject of controversy, took a step toward acceptance today.

title: Lawyer Calls Witnesses Tainted As Trial of Thorpe Nears Its End
description: LONDON, June 13 (Reuters)  The trial of Jeremy Thorpe moved into its final stages today with a defense lawyer assailing what he said were the tainted witnesses called by the prosecution. The lawyer, John Mathew, said that some of the evidence in the case defied belief.

title: Hearing Opens on Appeal Of GuideSanction Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) The Administration argued today that the voluntary nature of President Carter's antiinflation wage guidelines supported its appeal of a ruling that economic sanctions in the program were unconstitutional.

title: Ordination of Women Approved
description: HOLLAND, Mich., June 13 (UPI) Delegates to the Reformed Church of America's 173d Synod voted today to amend the Book of Church Order to allow women to be ordained as ministers and to uphold the ordinations of Valerie DeMarinus Miller of Brooklyn, Joyce Borgman DeVelder of Albany and Louise Ann HillAlto of Bergen, N.J. Members of the General Synod, the highest judicatory branch of the church, voted 150 to 115 to uphold the three ordinations.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I just read Jane Geniesse's piece on Martin J. Davidson's home (When Nothing But the Best Will Do, June 7). I don't know the gentleman, but feel I do now, having read the article on his new loft. It made me laugh so much that I just had to write and thank you for starting a day off so well for me.

title: State to Lease Rikers for 99 Years
description: New York City will lease Rikers Island to the state for 99 years for $200 million, Mayor Koch and Governor Carey announced yesterday.

title: MARTEN FAIR GAME IF YOU'VE AIR FARE
description: It may be open season on the pine marten in New York State  that is, if officials can get straight which brown, furbearing animal the Legislature is talking about in a newly passed bill. ine Larousse tncyciopecna of Animal Life says the pine marten exists only in Europe. Only Martes martes, the European version, is a pine marten, the book says.

title: Red Sox Trade Scott to Royals
description: BOSTON, June 13 (AP)  The Boston Red Sox traded George Scott to the Kansas City Royals for Tom Poquette, an outfielder, today and also acquired Bob Watson from the Houston Astros for a minor league pitcher, a player to be named and cash.

title: Design Notebook
description: RARE are the objects that manage to be taut, yet warm; crisp, yet soft. But such is the furniture of Alvar Aalto, the great Finnish architect whose essays in furniture design alone would have marked him as one of the 20th century's great designers, even had he not completed a single building.

title: Simon Places Himself Formally in the Race To Fill Abrams's Term
description: Stanley Simon, the interim Borough President of the Bronx, formally announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the remaining two years of the fouryear term left vacant when Robert Abrams became State Attorney General last January. The term expires in 1981.

title: Deaths
description: EYRETherese Quanz, age 84, formerly of Rye, N.Y. and Greenwich, Conn. Died Sunday June 10, 1979. Widow of Henry N. Eyre. Survived by three daughters, Mrs. Elizabeth E. Taylor of Southfield, Mass., Mrs. Shirley E. Knapp of Greenwich, Conn.,.Mrs. Cameron H. Repp of Darien, Conn. and her son, Henry N. Eyre, Jr., of Farmington, Conn. Funeral services will be private. Memorial contributions to the Albert Schweitzer Foundation, Great Barrington, Mass. 01230, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have recently acquired a used maltagony baby grand piano. It has no nicks, severe scratches or stains, but layers of white furniture polish combined with tons of dirt seem to have dulled and dirtied the piano's finish. How can I remove the old wax and dirt and restore an attractive shine?D.L., Woodmere, L.I.

title: Sound
description: THE minor ravages of age that keep your sound system from doing as well as it once did may not be obvious. Phonographs, like people, sometimes age so gently that unwelcome changes creep, up gradually and unnoticed. In the case of people, it may take an intense encounter with a mirror or a bathroom scale to suggest the need for remedial measures. In the case of phonographs, a test record serves to provide that kind of early warning. Such a disk can reveal  for better or worse  merits and shortcomings. Admittedly, the test tones presented on such a record do not encompass all the complex and subtle factors that enter into the reproduction of musical sound. Yet, unlike musical recordings, such disks provide clearcut indications of otherwise elusive faults.

title: VANCE HOPES TALKS IN VIENNA WILL SPUR STABLE SOVIET TIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States hoped that the meeting with the Soviet leadership this weekend would produce a more stable relationship and end the fluctuations of the past.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE time has long since passed when novelists ventured in search of a subject. Flaubert's friend Louis Bouilhet spoke of an obscure provincial suicide that had occurred in their neighborhood and declared: there is your novel. The fashion now is to write one's autobiography and call it fiction.

title: WEST URGED BY U. S. TO HELP DRUG FIGHT
description: PARIS, June 13  In a new move in America's long war against drug abuse, the Carter. Administration proposed today that Western industrial countries devote some of the economic aid that they give developing nations to discouraging farmers from growing crops used in the illicit manufacture of hard drugs, like heroin and cocaine.

title: May Oil Output Off 5% in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 13 (Reuters)  Oil production in Iran dropped by 5 percent in May from April, to 3.9 million barrels a day, according to figures from the National Iranian Oil Company reported today by Pars, the country's official news aeencv.

title: At Thai Camp, An Exile's Joy Turns to Grief
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 13  The first good news that Kim Kok Hoai had received in more than four years readied him at his home in Paris last month. A Cambodian of Chinese origin, like himself, had discovered Mr. Kim's 18yearold sister in a Thai border camp, where she had found refuge. on hearing the news, Mr. Kim flew to Bangkok on the first plane and reached the Nongchan camp, an open field three hours drive from here, the following morning. It was not easy to find his sister among the 30,000 refugees huddled under low tents, but he did.

title: Guidry's Diagn osis: BackMuscle Strain
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 13 The morning after Ron Guidry was sedated, strapped to a stretcher and wheeled through the Yankee clubhouse there was less pain and more hope. He is expected to return home tomorrow, after his release from FairviewSouthdale Hospital.

title: HERBERT J. HARTUNG
description: Herbert J. Hartung, who spent 35 years with the F. & M. Schaefer Brewing Company as a salesman and then as an executive, died Tuesday on his 69th birthday. He lived in Malverne, L.I.

title: ExSS Doctor Is Fined $255,000 in Germany For the Killing of Jews
description: WEST BERLIN, June 13  A former SS doctor was convicted here in absentia today of having murdered scores of concentration camp inmates in 1941 and 1942, sometimes out of pure boredom. As a result, he lost title to a West Berlin apartanent house that had given him an annual income of about $35,000 for the last 20 years.

title: Cargo Loss for Port Put at $1.5 Billion in Tug Strike
description: The strike by 2,800 commercial tugboat workers that has disrupted commerce in New York Harbor since April 1 has caused the diversion of more than $1.5 billion in cargo to other ports, and officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey fear that some of the loss may become permanent.

title: FINANCIAL CONCERN CALLED CRIME FRONT
description: SAN DIEGO  The offices of MB Financial Inc. on Morena Boulevard here had an aura of success and money. The furnishings were expensive, the staff effident, and there was a steady stream of investors, winning 27 San Diego police officers, eager to write out checks with expectations of receiving interest of as much as 10 percent monthly.

title: Sarah Webb Barrell, U.S. Photojournalist, Covered Wars Abroad

title: Film: Arkin and Falk In Comic 'In-Laws':Comedy of Insanity
description: I WAS laughing so hard at "The In-Laws," a wonderful new comedy of errors opening today at the Beekman and other theaters, that after a while I was crying. Then I was wiping my eyes. Then I forgot to take any more notes. And now I can't remember exactly what was so funny. When anything is thatfunny, though, maybe the fine points don't matter."The In-Laws" is certainly not a movie for anyone interested in fine points. As directed by Arthur Hiller, it is, at best, a happy shambles, and it gets off to a muddy start. A Federal security truck is robbed, with the theft masterminded by Peter Falk; not so interesting, since Mr. Falk has lately been seen plotting a similar heist in "The Brink's Job." But wait. The truck is full of money, and the thieves don't even want it; they're after something else. This is the first of a number of new wrinkles.It is dinnertime, and Mr. Falk and Alan Arkin are meeting for the first time. Mr. Arkin is playing one of the world's foremost dentists, and surely Mr. Falk is playing one of the world's great straight men. The dentist's daughter is scheduled to be married only a day or two later to the robber's son, but a lot will be happening between now and then.Mr. Falk, asked about his work, is a little vague. But he says it took him to Guatemala, and tells some stories about tse-tse flies as big as eagles. The next day, at lunch with Mr. Arkin, he is more candid: he claims he is with the Central Intelligence Agencey. That, he says, is why he has never heard of "The Price Is Right." And presumably it also explains the autographed picture of former President John F. Kennedy on his office wall, a picture that has something to do with something he did in Cuba. "To Vince," it says. "At least we tried."In no time, Mr. Falk has implicated Mr. Arkin in a Federal crime and whisked him aboard a tiny plane with a two-man Chinese crew. ("You know, if Chiang had ever made it back to mainland China, Billy and Bing would be anchoring the evening news," Mr. Falk calmly explains.) Soon they are in a Carribean hotel, with a lobby full of live chickens. Then they are visiting a friend of Mr. Falk's, a crazy General (Richard Libertini), whose art collection Mr. Arkin is quietly advised to admire. The art collection, which is best left undescribed, is the funniest thing in this altogether sidesplitting movie.Andrew Bergman has written one of those rare comedy scripts that escalates steadily and hilariously, without faltering or even having to strain for an ending. As for Mr. Arkin and Mr. Falk, it is theirs, and not their children's, match that has been made in heaven. The teaming of their characters  milquetoast meets entrepreneur  is reminiscent of "The Producers." But instead of exaggerating either extreme, both actors play it almost deadpan.However wild things get, Mr. Falk is always willing to offer an extremely patient explanation. And Mr. Arkin is always willing to try, however unsuccessfully, not to scream. If either of them has ever been more delightful, I can't remember when."The In-Laws" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains a few mild obscenities.

title: Film: 'Walk Proud' Is Upbeat Gang Movie:West Coast Story
description: "WALK PROUD," which opens today at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters, is a gang movie that is reassuringly upbeat in an old-fashioned sort of way. Based on an original screenplay by Evan Hunter, who wrote "The Blackboard Jungle," the granddaddy of all gang movies, it stars Robby Benson, in dark face, as a member of an East Los Angeles Chicano gang who decides, after much violence and with the help of a good young woman, to seek a better life.The movie has the kind of positive narrative that one associates with movies made under the old Production Code, when wrongdoing was supposed to be promptly punished and sex was mainly a meeting of small minds. "Walk Proud" isn't quite that old-fashioned  it talks dirty enough and some of the gang's encounters are fairly brutal; yet it's a movie that still seems to believe there are tangible rewards for the clean of heart. The movie's sentimental, realistic style has nothing whatsoever to do with the dreamlike, glossy cool affected by Walter Hill's notorious "The Warriors."Yet "Walk Proud" may well be a far more revolutionary picture than the randomly pretty Hill film. In the way it documents the power plays of the Aztecas, the Chicano gang, as its members negotiate and then break treaties covering such things as safe passage through Santa Monica, it manages to suggest the self-generating absurdities built into all international relations conducted through power blocs. When at the end of "Walk Proud," Emilio (Mr. Benson) turns his back on the Aztecas and says, "I want something else," he could be turning his back on the East, the West and the third world.This may be to freight the scheme of the film with more meanings than it can carry. Robert Collins, whose first theatrical film this is, has directed it with the kind of modest efficiency typical of the better television series. The movie doesn't waste time on nonessential details, though it makes free use of street language and likes to toss a love song onto the soundtrack to be sure we get an essential point of emotion.Starting with Mr. Benson, the members of the cast are fine. These include Sarah Holcomb, who plays the WASPy girl with whom Emilio falls in love; Pepe Serna, Domingo Ambriz and Trinidad Silva, as three of Emilio's pals, and Ji-Tu Cumbuka as a black police sergeant who attempts, without much success, to monitor the activities of the Aztecas."Walk Proud," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains the expected rough language and some scenes of gang violence.

title: Oil Well Drama At Sea Disrupts Mexican Town

It boils like witch's caldron, spreading crude oil the color of Mississippi mud over the Gulf of Mexico. It burns, too, the flames dancing over the erupting oil at the wellhead, forming a 50foot orange corona visible for miles.
