title: Screen: Frankenheimer's 'Prophecy':Mercury, Lukewarm
description: "PROPHECY" is a very small horror movie that pretends to be as big as all outdoors. It's about the dreadful effects of a mercury compound that has been used for 20 years at a lumber mill on the ecology of rural Maine. Raccoons lose their minds and attack tourists with the frenzy of rug peddlers. Tadpoles attain the size of salmon, and salmon the size of dolphin.Worst of all are the human mutants, rubberized monsters that, as babies, look like failed Barbie dolls and, as adults, specially in the long shots, like stunt men wearing grizzly bear suits. Even Maine looks very different. It has suddenly become as dramatically scenic and snow-capped as British Columbia, not because the landscape, as if to repel the mercury, has thrown up strange new mountain ranges, but because British Columbia is where this epically trivial movie was made."Prophecy" is the work of the gifted John Frankenheimer, the director of "The Manchurian Candidate," "The Gypsy Moths" and "Black Sunday." and it was written by the not-so-gifted but staggeringly successful David Seltzer, who wrote "The Omen." This time, Mr. Seltzer makes a feeble attempt to recycle the sort of formula movie one expects from American International Pictures. "Prophecy" is pretty much the same plot we got several years ago in American International's unintentionally hilarious "Food of the Gods."The principal characters of the piece are a crusading young doctor and his wife (Robert Foxworth and Talia Shire), an angry young Indian and his wife (Armand Assante and Victoria Racimo), a shortsighted executive of the lumber mill (Richard Dysart) and an elderly Indian (George Clutesi), who thinks he has special spiritual powers when, in reality, his mind has turned to mush.Mr. Frankenheimer treats this material with the kind of majesty usually reserved for movies about Cleopatra, Napoleon and General Patton. "Prophecy," which opens today at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters, is full of lingering lap-dissolves and elegant camera movements that suggest history is being made. Leonard Rosenman's soundtrack music is so grand it could be played at a coronation, and it's so loud that it pierces the ears and threatens the head.None of this fits the movie, which includes a fight between a man with an ax and a man with a portable power saw, and a number of attacks by the mutant monsters on random campers and forest rangers as well as on the film's principal players. For extra gore, there's the obligatory decapitation and the strong suggestion that one fellow is bitten in half at the waist.As monsters go, the ones in "Prophecy" are less fun and far less mysterious than Godzilla."Prophecy," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains the violence described above.

title: Film: 'Wild Flowers' Is Wry Yugoslav Idyll:For the Simple Life
description: "THE Fragrance of Wild Flowers," a new Yugoslav film at the Quad today, gets off to a promising start, and remains rewarding for a good long while. We meet a dour-looking man, an actor, and we surmise immediately that he must be a person of great talent, because no one would otherwise put up with him. Indeed, he turns out to to be an international movie star who's sick and tired of his career. He wants to lead a simple life, and smell the flowers  hence the title. And so, without a thought for his co-workers, he walks out on a play he has been scheduled to star in on the day of the premiere. This is Step One in his plan to leave behind his old life and embark on a new one.This, it turns out, is not easily done. When the actor moves onto a barge  run by his old friend, a simple fisherman, and the fisherman's very down-to-earth mistress  he is followed by a film crew. The theater group also tags along, hoping to coax him back to work. They all sit at a tavern on the Danube, right beside the spot where the barge is moored. While waiting for something to happen, they admire the tripe and a singing waitress.All of this finds its way into the headlines, and tourists arrive. Soon, the waitress has show business aspirations, and the tripe is being touted as a delicacy. As for the actor and his simple life, well, he seems to have miscalculated somewhere along the line.Until it gets out of hand  as does the ever-expanding circus that surrounds the actor  this film by Srdjan Karanovic is wry, richly textured and very impressive. The characters seem to have been choreographed rather than directed, as they swarm around the actor, make bargains or strike up expedient friendships. Several marriages and one death result from this almost dreamlike idyll, which takes place on a broad and imaginative scale. But Mr. Karanovic's mounting cynicism, which leads the film to a disappointingly pat finale, proves more and more limiting as the story progresses.As the actor, Ljuba Tadic effortlessly gives the film weight, though he seldom speaks and never smiles. He hovers compellingly between self-importance and true gravity, making the other characters look all the more frivolous by comparison, save for the fisherman's mistress, the only one whose instinct is to cut the actor down to size. The barge she lives on is other worldly in a way that suggests Jean Vigo's mysterious boat in "L'Atalante."The music, by Zoran Simujanovic, is lovely, and it enhances this mood of eerie detachment. "The Fragrance of Wild Flowers" was the winner of the International Critics Award at Cannes, France, last year.

title: Screen: 'Rocky II' Fights a Rematch:Second Stanza....
description: WHAT happens to Rocky in "Rocky II," which opens today at the Cinerama and at neighborhood theaters, is a lot like what happened to Sylvester Stallone. Last seen "going the distance" in his one-in-a-million fight with the World Champion, Rocky is still at it when Part II begins; the new film actually replays the ending of the old one. But after the first flush of success is behind him, Rocky flounders. And after an extended period of floundering, he realizes that the only way he can match that early triumph is to duplicate it as closely as possible. In Rocky's case, this means agreeing to a rematch with the Champ. In Mr. Stallone's, it means trying to make the same movie all over again.The extent to which Mr. Stallone, who wrote and directed "Rocky II," has been able to use his "Rocky" script as a blueprint is remarkable. After all, "Rocky" was the story of an ostensible nobody who made good, and at the start of Mr. Stallone's new story Rocky is a big hero. No matter; once the swelling goes down he turns into a nobody all over again.He spends the prize money on presents for himself, his old dog and his new wife. (He and Talia Shire get married as the new story begins.) He buys a house. After that, he can't get a job. Two of his former lines of work, boxing and breaking thumbs, don't interest him any more on account of the wear and tear. All he can find is a part-time job in a meat-packing plant, and even that comes to nothing. He gets laid off.Only one person really remembers him  Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers), the Champ. The Champ has been getting hate mail saying he didn't really beat Rocky fair and square and, according to Mr. Stallone's script, the accusations are driving him crazy. So he takes out newspaper ads trying to goad Rocky into a rematch. The ads call Rocky "The Italian Chicken" instead of "The Italian Stallion."This is the point at which Mr. Stallone, who has done a creditable job on the whole, begins to turn superstitious. After having wandered far afield of his original formula in "F*I*S*T" and "Paradise Alley," he has returned to it with rather an uneasy vengeance. This is evidenced by the many scenes showing Rocky praying in the new film and by the abundance of good-luck totems.The same cast is back. So are the same turtles. Likewise the gang of street singers on Rocky's corner, led by Mr. Stallone's brother. The music, again by Bill Conti, is almost identical, and indeed the old "Rocky" theme is reprised for the sequence  yes  in which Rocky again jogs through Philadelphia in his same old gray sweatsuit, training for the fight. This time he is followed by about 800 admiring schoolchildren, presumably kids of strong stamina.The thing Mr. Stallone is most afraid to touch, and the thing that most needs tampering with, is Rocky's navet. The evanescence of his triumph is sad, but Rocky is not allowed to feel sorry about that; he barely even notices. And, more problematically, he is not allowed any feelings of ambition or rivalry that might correspond to the Champ's, and hence liven up the fight. Mr. Stallone works very hard to establish that Rocky wouldn't fight if he didn't have to. But this makes the buildup to the match seem aimless, and that's about half the movie. And it makes the final scenes all the more brutal, since Rocky  who is this time only making a career move, more or less  winds up looking like steak tartare.Mr. Stallone, whose direction borrows a lot from John Avildsen's direction of the first film (except for some bizarre lapses into slow motion, a touch that is purely Mr. Stallone's own), gives the same kind of unexpectedly affable performance he gave the first time. All the uneasiness of his intervening films has disappeared. Nevertheless, "Rocky II" has a waxy feeling, and it never comes to life the way its predecessor did. As the characters go through their stock routines  Talia Shire shyly whispering "I love you," Mr. Stallone making self-deprecating jokes, Burgess Meredith telling the kid he's either a bum or a hero  you get the feeling that you've been here before. Well, you have."Rocky II" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). The fight with which it concludes is indeed a bloody one.

title: Marcia Hayde Back in Onegin

The opening ballet of the company's first season, in 1969, it established Miss Haydee as a persuasive dramatic dancer in the minds of many New York balletomanes. In the ballet, which Miss Haydee will dance tonight and tomorrow afternoon during this first weekend of the Stuttgart's 1979 spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, Tatiana is first an impetuous, innocent, young girl in love with the mysterious Onegin, but by the end she has become the older, more worldly woman who rejects him.

title: Masters of Fantasy At CooperHewitt
description: THE immense appeal exerted upon our imagination by the art of illustration is fundamentally different from that of painting and sculpture. Illustration,. no matter how inspired its visual magic may be, remains firmly tethered to a literary occasion, whereas the- interest of painting and sculpture- and the drawing directly related to them  is essentially independent of whatever literary subject may be encompassed. This attachment to literature  to a text or a myth or whatever  lies at the very heart of the illustrator's vocation, and we are better able to appreciate the esthetic delights of illustration when we understand this fundamental condition of its existence.

Written and directed by Jeff Stein, the film contains some fascinating footage and some even more fascinating lapses. Mr. Stein has managed to tackle his very interesting subject with diligence, myopic intensity and no discernible point of view.

title: Drama: Al Pacino Plays Richard III

Al Pacino's portrayal of Richard III contains some intelligent and exciting ideas for playing Shakespeare's exuberant villain; and he plays them with a fierce and absorbing energy. But although he often goes right, he often goes very wrong. What at one moment is riveting, at the next moment sometimes from excess, sometimes from inappropriateness  becomes ludicrous.

title: Screen: A Witty 'Goldengirl':Nurtured to Win
description: "GOLDENGIRL," which opens today at Loews State 2 and other theaters, is something of an oddity  a cross between a science-fiction film and a horror film in which there are no spaceships and few futuristic gadgets. It has a monster, but the monster possesses the astonishingly lifelike shape of Susan Anton, the tall, blond, California-born actress, model and singer, best known nationally as the television spokeswoman for Muriel cigars.The melodrama, directed by Joseph Sargent and adapted by John Kohn from a novel by Peter Lear, is set in 1980 and is about the attempts of a mad but mannerly neo-Nazi doctor, played by Curt Jurgens, to produce a superwoman. The guinea pig is his adopted daughter, Goldine (Miss Anton), who has been specially fed, exercised and physically and emotionally conditioned since childhood to become a track star, more specifically, to win three gold medals for running at the 1980 Moscow Olympics.To finance his project, the old scientist has sold shares in his daughter's future earnings to a group of businessmen, who, in turn, have brought in a merchandising wizard, played by James Coburn, to insure that they get their money's worth."Goldengirl" is a wittily conceived and executed movie that, with the straightest of faces, manages to satirize the kind of big business that surrounds so-called amateur sports today. It also sends up science and science-fiction while getting in a few jabs at a civilization that systematically pollutes its environment for short-term gains.The environment here is the amazing Goldine, also called Goldengirl, and she's splendid. She's an Alp that walks, talks, runs, smiles and in all other ways is extremely human, but who may now and then say something like, "I'm just a simple American girl born to win three Olympic gold medals."Though Goldine thinks she was born in this shape, we in the audience know better (or worse). Goldine didn't come naturally by her extraordinary size and talent. Since she was a little girl, her father has been stabbing her with long needles that didn't contain the vitamins he said, but all sorts of strange hormones, which eventually do her no good. Inside that magnificent body, a terrible wasteland is being created."Goldengirl" is a very intelligent movie of its kind, written and directed in the same brisk style that marked Mr. Sargent's earlier "Colossus  The Forbin Project." If the producers aren't entirely successful in persuading us that the scenes shot at the 1980 Moscow Olympics were really shot there, that's not as important as the effectiveness of the performers. They're all good, particularly Mr. Jurgens, who not many years ago was playing Werner von Braun as a hero; Mr. Coburn, and Leslie Caron, who appears as Goldine's in-house behavioral psychologist.The star, though, is Miss Anton. Farrah Fawcett-Majors clone or not, she's a sight for sore eyes, and I suspect she may also be a very acceptable actress. This is not intended to put down what she does here, which is quite a lot. It's only to admit that it's difficult to understand a phenomenon as spectacular as this after a single viewing. She's one sunrise I'd like to see again."Goldengirl," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some vulgar language and one slightly suggestive situation.

title: Canadian Dockers Vote to End Strike
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 14 (UPI)  British Columbia's 4,000 longshoremen voted today to end their 10day strike, which has paralyzed West Coast shipping and cost Canada millions of dollars.

title: Tight Fittings in the Engine Mount Cited by Inquiry Into DC10 Crash
description: Ciovernment officials are becoming increasingly convinced that the crash of the DC10 jumbo jet in Chicago last month was a result of maintenance mishaps that were caused at least partly by the tightness of fittings in the original enginemount design.

title: Publishing: A Fair Of Books on 5th Ave.
description: THE stretch of Fifth Avenue from 47th street to 57th street, an area that some believe has the largest concentration of major bookstores in the country, will be the site this Sept. 16 of New York Is Book Country, a 10-block-long book fair. All the bookstores will be oven: kiosks will be set up on the sidewalks; authors will mix with mere mortals; children's book characters will materialize; craft demonstrations will take place; an exhibition, complete with printing press, will show how a book is put together, and Maurice Sendak and Edward Gorey have promised to do posters.

title: Motet Choir Savors Success On Eve of Tully Hall Concert
description: The New York Motet Choir, led by Stephen Sturlc, is to give a concert at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center at o'clock tomorrow night and rightly so, it would seem. The reason we're in

title: STRIKE IN CALIFORNIA PERILING CROP LANDS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 14  About 1,500 of this state's 210,000 employees walked off the job yesterday and today in a labor dispute that threatens irrigated crops in the Central Valley and could limit water deliveries through the 444 milelong aqueduct from the rivers of northern California to southern California's deserts.

title: Grace McGrath Leads by
description: LiKEAT NECK, L.I. June 14  Grace McGrath of Piping Rock continued to lead the'29th Women's Cross County Golf Association tournament today at Fresh Meadow Country Club by carding a 79 for a 157 total. Phebe Dempsey of St. George's trailed by two shots. The event ends tomorrow with 18 holes at Harbor Hills Country Club in Port

title: The New York Times/ Edward Hausner
description: In Hospital, Renee Katz Receives Her Academic Awards

title: 68 Steps to Fame Retraced By Stallone in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 14  One dawn in December 1975, an obscure actor loped up Ninth Street in South Philadelphia as a camera crew recorded his motion. As he entered the&

title: NICARAGUAN PLANES HIT REBELHE6D CITY
description: LEON, Nicaragua, June 14  With sporadic fighting continuing in the capital of Managua, Government planes today concentrated their rocket and machinegun attacks on Leon, 'he country's 'secondlargest city, which for the last 11 days has been in the hands of guerrillas fighting to overthrow President Anastasio Somoza Debavle.

title: United Press International
description: THE COST OF DOING BUSINESS: Dan Swal of Dallas, who boasted he could make $5,000 selling United Airlines halffare coupons, buying a coupon, at left, then waiting for the police to let him go. The police seized Mr. Swal on Tuesday at Denver's Stapleton Airport for soliciting, but were unable to keep him under arrest.

title: State High Court Throws Out Suit By L.I. Illiterate
description: The New York State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that, as a matter of public policy, courts should avoid making judgments in lawsuits for educational malpractice.

title: Court Upholds Westchester's SheriffPolice Merger
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 14  The Court of Appeals, New'York State's highest court, ruled today that Westchester County's proposed merger of the sheriff' /b-s office and the parkway police was valid ana constitutional. It said that the merger, which was expected to consolidate many parallel and overlapping police functions, could take effect as planned on July 1.

title: Eastern Air Is Rebuffed On National
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  An ad. miniitrative law judge for the Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that an acquisition of National Airlines by Eastern Air Lines would be unlawful and should not be approved. Eastern plans to press its bid on appeal.

title: John Nerud Da at Belmont
description: First they ran a flag up the staff at Belmont Park. Red letters on a green background, representing the racing colors of Tartan Farm, read: John Nerud Day. Then a chestnut colt named Sofiysk, a son of Dr. Fager bred by John Nerud for Tartan Farm and trained by John's son Jan, won the second race and paid $11.80 for $2. It was a $15,000 purse, with $9,000 for the winner. Can you imagine getting $9,000 for a horse to break his maiden? John asked Ted Atkinson. who used to ride for

title: World News Briefs
description: CAPE TOWN, June 14 (AP)  Prime Minister Pieter W. Botha announced his first major Cabinet changes today, excluding James T. Kruger, the hardline Minister of Police, Prisons and Justice.

title: The Region
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J.  A 50pound Siberian husky named Angel killed 4yeatold boy yesterday, its second attack on a child in a little over six weeks, the police said. The dog, which was not tied up, was removed to a Humane Society animal shelter in nearby Forked River pending a decision on whether to file criminal charges against the dog's owner, Denise Simpson.

title: Tennis
description: AT LONDON $125,000 STELL LONDON ARTOIS GRASS

title: Nicholas Molnar Dead; Chemical Engineer, 75
description: Nicholas Molnar, a chemical engineer and the founder and chairman of the Cooper Union Research Foundation of New York, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 75. He lived in Manhattan.

title: Where Grime Never Pays
description: Tens of thousands of prospective jurors have passed through the New York State Supreme Court Building at 60 Centre Street in the last 40 years, each of them seeing less and less of the 20 murals that were erected on the walls of the central jury room during the Depression.

title: Torsney Is Discharged From the Police Dept.; Unable to Get Pension
description: Asserting that he had a responsibility to protect the community from any police officer who is incapable of carrying gun, Commissioner Robert J. McGuire yesterday dismissed Robert Torsney from the New York City Police Department.

title: Haines Jersey Victor
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 14 George Haines Jr. of Somerset Hills won his second New Jersey amateur championship today at the Baltusrol Golf Club. Haines fired a 2underpar 70 in his morning round and coasted home with an 80 for a 297 total that gave him the victory by two strokes over Howie Pierson of River Vale and Ken Hardwick of Green Knoll.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Because of trashremoval problems during the tugboat strike, alternateside parking regulations will be in effect today in Manhattan and Brooklyn only. No decision had been made yesterda v on tomorrow's regulations.

title: Despite Coup, Ghana Goes Ahead With Plans for Election
description: ACCRA, Ghana  It now looks as Ghana's first civilian elections in a decade will take place here on schedule on Monday, despite the fact that junior officers who seized power on June 4 have postponed the return to civilian government from July 1 to Oct. 1.

title: Hunts Point Feels Impact Of Truckers
description: High prices for diesel fuel and nationwide protests from independent truckers could significantly affect the availability, price and quality of fresh fruits and vegetables in this area in coming weeks. Merchants at Hunts Point Terminal Market said yesterday that many truckers were refusing jobs, and even haulers already commissioned were arriving one to two days late, or not at all.

title: Steel Price Rise Slow to Spread
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  The Council on Wage and Price Stability expressed some doubt today that the percent price increase announced Tuesday by the United States Steel Corporation will hold in the market.

title: CITY TAKES 109 CARS OFF SUBWAY SERVICE AS UNSATISFACTORY
description: Mayor Says That Undercarriages Must Be Replaced Because of Cracks in the Equipment

title: Simms Is Notable Absentee in Giant Camp
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 14  The Giants had 98 players present today for the opening of a threeday minicamp, but the one who might be the most important, Phil Simms, was absent.

title: General Cinema Sues ExAide
description: The General Cinema Corporation has I filed a suit against Herbert G. Paige, former officer and director and president of its beverage division.

title: Leukemia Victim, 50, Ends CrossCountry Bicycle Trip
description: Robert Fisher, who has leukemia, completed a childhood fantasy yesterday when he pedaled into Manhattan after a\ 3,700mile bicycle trip across the country..:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 Slain in Subways So Far in 79
description: Eleven persons have been slain in the subway system so far this year, two more than the total for all of last year, Transit Authority officials report. Two others were killed by transit policemen, one of them accidentally.

title: The Flu War Isn't Over Yet
description: More than two years have passed since the swine flu immunization campaign was aborted because the vaccine appeared to cause a rare paralytic disease, GuillainBarre Syndrome, in a small percentage those inoculated. But few of the victims of this public- health misfire have yet been compensated for their injuries. As a recent report to The Times by Philip Taubman noted, only 14 of 732 GuillainBarre claims, and only 4 of 321 GuillainBarre lawsuits, have been settled. One young man who became paralyzed two weeks after vaccination and who will be confined to a wheelchair for life says he can't understand why it's taken so long.

title: Serious Subway Crowding Likely as Result of Decision
description: The subway platforms under Queens Boulevard  crowded during the morning rush hour on the best of days  are likely to be jammed with commuters this morning because of yesterday's decision to pull 109 subway cars out of service. It'll be crowded there, said Steven K. Kauffman, executive officer of the Transit Authority's rapidtransit division in estimating the impact of the decision on those among the city's 3.5 million daily subway riders who use the affected lines. We'll have to have extra transit police there, particularly on the extrabusy platforms like Queens Plaza and Roosevelt Avenue.

title: Plane Ditched in Lake; Carried Toxic Insecticide
description: PRESQUE ISLE, Me., June 14 (UPI) - A cockpit fire today forced a four-engine C54 aircraft carrying 800 gallons of toxic Insecticide to ditch in Eagle Lake in northern Maine's scenic Allagash Wilderness Waterway.

title: Opening Today: 8 New Movies
description: Susan Anton competing for the United States at the Olympics in Goideneri, which opens today at Loews State 2 and other theaters. A review appears on page C10.

title: Big Board Suspends Kleinman Partner for a Year
description: The New York Stock Exchange meted out one of its severest penalties ever yesterday by suspending Jonathan B. Kurtin, a partner of the brokerage firm of James J. Kleinman & Company, from any dealings on the exchange for one year for what the exchange called conduct inconsistent with just and equitable principles of trade.

title: Stage: A Marathon Of OneAct Plays
description: CURT DEMPSTER'S Ensemble Studio Theater is overflowing with energy and activity as the company begins Marathon 79, its annual festival of oneact olays. In one evening, the company Presented three short plays by three promising writers, Shirley Mezvinsky Lauro, Peter Maloney and Neil Cuthbert.

title: Notes on People
description: Something New at Wedding of Niarchos's Daughter

title: TV Weekend Special on Arms Accord
description: IN sports, the United States Open golf tournament will be covered by ABC Sports on Saturday and Sunday, beginning at 2:30 P.M. each day. The winner's share ,of the $325,000 purse will be $50,000. Defending champion in this event, which dates back to 1920, is Andy North.

title: Toyota Output At Peak in May
description: TOKYO, June 14 (AP) The Toyota Motor Sales Company, the sales arm of the Toyota Motor Company, Japan's biggest auto maker, said today that production of its cars set a record in May but that its exports to the United States and other countries declined.

title: California Court Reverses Ruling That Led to Inquiry
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 19  The California Supreme Court reversed itself today and upheld a mandatory sentencing law in a case that has prompted an investigation of the justices handling of several dPeicinnc

title: ISRAELI CHARGES U.S. IMPERILS PEACE PACT
description: JERUSALEM, June 15  Agriculture Minister Ariel Sharon, the foremost hardline member of Israel's Government, charged today that the United States was gravely imperiling the peace achievements in the Middle East by what he said was its desire to establish a Palestinian state in the West Bank and the Gaza Strio.

title: Britain Seeks Oil Search
description: LONDON, June 15 (AP)  In an effort to encourage oil exploration by more companies in the North Sea, Britain's new Conservative Government has announced that the stateowned British National Oil Corporation and the British Gas Corporation will no longer have first option on exploration rights.

title: Emery Proving to Be Adept Tactician in Assembly Role
description: ALBANY, June 15  The Democrats were panicking.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 16, 1979

title: Sharp Fall In Credit Markets
description: Prices of fixedincome securities dropped sharply yesterday, pushing interest rates higher in the wake of a strong rebound in industrial production in May and record growth of the money supply. The decline was the credit market's most pronounced since its recent recovery began early last month.

title: Dr. David Morton, a Psychiatrist At New York City V.A. Hospitals
description: Dr. David P. Milliken Morton, a psychiatrist and neurosurgeon who was instrumental in the establishment of psychiatric services at Veterans Administration hospitals in New York City, died June 2 in San Bernardino, Calif. He was 72 Years old.

title: Senaton Plan Hearings In July on Arms Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will begin hearings July 9 on the strategic arms limitation treaty and the full Senate will likely start the ratification debate in September, accordin2 to a schedule made !Dublin today

title: Growing Up White in BedStuy
description: One by one, the white passengers got off the Eighth Avenue subway. By the time we reached Boro Hall all the faces were black except for my fairhaired son's and my own.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, June 15, 1979

title: Arabian Anxieties: What Soviet Might Do and What U.S Might Not
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Anxiety about the Soviet Union's next military and political moves in or around the Arabian Peninsula and doubts about the strength and speed of the United States

title: Property Value in City Put at $38.05 Billion By Local Tax Agency
description: The total value of land and buildings in New York City was fixed yesterday at $38.05 billion by the city's Tax Commission, reversing a threeyear shrinkage in the city's propertytax base.

title: Beaths
description: ROBINSONAbraham S. The Sixth Masonic District Association ol Manhattan mourns the loss of Righl Worshipful Abraham S. Robinson who passed away on Thursday, June 14. 1979. Past District Deptfh Grand Master of the Sixth Masonic District of Manhattan, a member and leader of various committees of the Grand Lodge of the State of Nev York and the Sixth Masonic District of Manhattan. Masonic services wit be held on Sunday, June 17th at noon at The Riverside Funeral CM pel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: 8th Body Found in DC3 Crash
description: GRANGEVILLE, Idaho, June 15 (UPI)  Searchers recovered two more bodies from the Solway River today, several miles downstream from where a Forest Service DC3 crashed Monday. Eight bodies have been recovered, and two persons are still missing. A man, a boy and two dogs survived the crash.

title: Bedford Hills Case Focusing on 2
description: Junious Gray and James L. Allen, who were indicted with two others for a robbery in Brooklyn three weeks ago, emerged yesterday as the principal suspects in the earlier Bedford Hills, N.Y., murders.

title: Rock: Yes, British. Group, Plays Garden
description: Yes, the English rock band that used to specialize in fanciful lyrics, extended suites, surreal instrumental sounds and elaborate stage sets, came back to earth for an appearance at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night. For several years now, the group has been curtailing its tendency to selfindulgent flight of fancy and becoming more songoriented. Its presentation at the Garden reflected this change in direction. The group played from a revolving stage in the center of the arena, with the front row of the audience just few feet away, and for the most part the players avoided their former penchant for cosmic meandering.

title: U.S. Warns Refiners It Can Shift Crude Oil
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  The Carter Administration warned the oil industry today that it was considering measures to take crude oil from companies that are not refining as much gasoline as they can and to give it to companies prepared to use it.

title: Miss Blalock, on 70139, Leads by Shot in Rochester
description: ROCHESTER, June 15 (AP)  Pat Bradley shot a 67 today with two eagles, but fell one stroke short of Jane Blalock after two rounds of the $100,000 Sarah Coventry golf tournament at Locust Hills Country Cluh

title: Albany Will Cut HomeInsurance Rate
description: ALBANY, Saturday, June 16  With the State Legislature working furiously in an effort to recess by tonight, negotiators yesterday reached agreement on a plan to lower the insurance rates charged customers who are unable to buy normal coverage because their neighborhoods are considered bad risks.

title: TV Reporter Is Seized Filming Coupon Story
description: Steve Wilson, a reporter for WCBSTV, was taken into police custody yesterday on a complaint by American Airlines while taping a report about halffare coupons at La Guardia Airport, the police said. He was charged with loitering to solicit and told to appear in Manhattan Criminal Court July 23.

title: Quandary for the Colleges
description: when congress enacted what has come to be known as the Handicapped Bill of Rights, the legislation Contained only 46 words. That brief expression of equality was the subject of a United States Supreme Court decision this week that ran

title: Letter: On Doubling Sunday Fares
description: To the Editor:

title: Rubber Union and Goodrich Reach Tentative 3Year Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  Tentative accord was reached here today on a threeyear contract between the United Rubber Workers Union and the B.F. Goodrich Company, the nation's fourth largest tire maker.

title: OIL INDUSTRY INSISTS REFINERIES
description: House Demands Proof Gasoline Shortage Is Real  Analysts See Risk On Heating Fuel

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 22.

title: Crisis In Food
description: WASHINGTON  It is never a good time to put the world's food system into working order. When serious food shortages cause wider malnutrition and higher death rates governments seem paralyzed. Such a time. they say, is the wrong time to act. Food is either too scarce, to build reserves or too expensive to provide more aid.

title: Irving Galt, 68, Served New York State Units As a Litigation Expert
description: Irving Galt, former assistant solicitor general for New York State, died of heart attack Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and had retired in March 1978.

title: The New Wave
description: A client walking; into the Gerard Bollei salon the other day stopped and did a double take. There sat Kathy Finnegan with what looked like scaffolding rising out of her head.

title: Loose Playground Surface Rated Best
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)  Playgrounds are fun,, but they can also be hazardous and the National Bureau of Standards says the surface under play equipment can make a big difference.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Because of trashremoval problems during the tugboat strike, alternateside parking regulations will be in effect today in Manhattan and Brooklyn only. On Monday the regulations will be in effect in Manhattan and the Bronx only.

title: Got Th Go Disco
description: The opening of Got Tu Go Disco at the Minskoff Theater has been postponed. The new date is June 25. This new musical had been scheduled to open Wednesday.

title: Kimberley Ann Behre Wed to Frank Kenna 3d
description: Kimberley Ann Behre, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry August Behre Jr. of Madison, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church to Frank Kenna 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenna Jr. of Madison and Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. Gerard Schmitz performed the ceremony.

title: Ballet: Klosand Miss Hanke In the Stuttgart's Onegin
description: Is it a poignant dancedrama or just a soap opera? Balletgoers tend to label John Cranko's Eugene Onegin as either one or the other. And when they do, they usually express their feelings in no uncertain terms.

title: Track and Field
description: AT WALNUT, CALIF.

title: Army Chief Sees Soviet Surpassing U.S. Strategic Capability in 1980's
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  The Army's Chief of Staff, Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, predicted today that the United States would fall behind the Soviet Union in strategic capability in the early 1980's, and said that Russia might then test the resolve of the United States.

title: Lemaire of Canadiens Signs Swiss Club Pact
description: MONTREAL, June 15 (AP) Jacques Lemaire, a center for 12 seasons with the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League, announced today that he had signed a threeyear contract as player, coach and general manager of a club team in Switzerland starting next fall.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, June 15 (AP) The Ford Motor Company said today that it had rejected offers to buy its faltering tractor operations and would not entertain other offers.

title: Soul City Seeks To Get Recruits From the North
description: I want to dig in the dirt again and go fishing when I feel like it, Elaine Alexander said yesterday. I'm tired of the noise, the crowds and the fear of walking the streets or into your own hallway.

title: Favorite Again Plays Poorly
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, June 15 Tom Watson said: I can't describe my round in any one word. It was sloppy, careless and I used poor judgment. It was disappointing.

title: Associated Press
description: CONCORDE'S. TIRES BLOW, 90'ABOARD ARE SAFE: Air France technicians inspecting daMage to the landing gear of a Concorde supersonic Jetliner at Duffel; Airport

title: Macy's Sprinklers Were Not Working
description: The Fire Department said yesterday that the extent and severity of Thursday's fire at the Macy's store at Herald Square was essentially due to the lack of sprinkler protection in the fire area. One fireman died in the blaze, and 10 firemen and four shoppers were injured slightly.

title: Sanction End Held Affecting U.S. Little
description: Only one segment of the American economy would be likely to reap any significant benefits if economic sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia were lifted. Tobacco trading organizations in the South would be able to resume buying and exporting that country's tobacco, one of its most important exports.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: C.A.B. Approves Air Fare Increase
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today a 2.3 percent general increase in airline fares that will go into effect in July. The action opened the door for carriers to file for another raise of 4.3 percent that could become effective in August.

title: Yanks Fall, 95
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., June 15  After losing to the Rangers, 95, tonight for their fourth defeat in the last six games, and after falling farther from first place than they have been at any time this season, the Yankees traded Cliff Johnson and Jay Johnstone.

title: Exxon Puts Its Shortfall In Oil at 14%
description: PARIS, June 15 (AP)  The chairman of the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest petroleum company, said today that his organization appeared to be harder hit than others by the current oilsupply shortfall.

title: Suspect in Restaurateur's Death Freed on Bail From Rikers Island
description: Salvatore Prainito, an illegal alien from Sicily held on charges that he helped Howard Jacobson, a racehorse trainer, murder a Manhattan restaurateur, was freed from a Hikers Island jail late Thursday on $35,000 bail, officials said yesterday.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 15, 1979

title: Bridge:
description: Standard bidding methods offer no satisfactory solution to the problem of bidding very strong threesuited hands. Some sophisticated modern systems provide specialized sequences to cover such situations, but these are not available to 99.9 percent of players.

title: Amex Building Action Urged
description: ALBANY, June 15  Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the American Stock Exchange, came here today to push for immediate passage of financing legislation that will enable the exchange to get started on the building of a new $40 million headquarters in lower Manhattan.

title: Transit Executive Rejected a Call To Refuse Flawed Subway Cars
description: More than a year and a half ago, the City Comptroller's office, citing concern for public safety, urged the Transit Authority's chief executive officer to stop accepting delivery of subway cars whose caststeel undercarriages had been developing cracks and to halt further payments to the manufacturers.

title: Mood Somber at Douglas Plant
description: LOS ANGELES, June 15  Shortly after the DC10 was grounded by the Federal Aviation Administration, the president of the Douglas Aircraft Company, John C. Brizendine, gave many of the 20,000 employees at the Long Beach, Calif., plant a noon pep talk over the public address system. His message was that the company would keep on building the world's best airplanes.

title: A Hotel in Las Vegas And Some Executives Lose Gambling Permit
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 15 (UPI) The Nevada gambling licenses of the Aladdin Hotel and some of its top executives have been revoked on the ground that hidden owners were allowed to control the multimillion dollar resort on the Las Vegas strip.

title: 2 Wounded in GasolineLine Violence in the Bronx
description: Two persons were hospitalized for gunshot wounds yesterday after a free-for-all among drivers of gypsy cabs waiting for gasoline at a service station in the Bronx. In the latest violence to erupt on lines at gasoline stations, the drivers wielded knives, crowbars, two-by-fours and jack handles.

title: Jean Cici Is Declared Victor In Cross Country Golf Even
description: PORT JEFFERSON, LI., June 15 Jean Cici of Classic and Phebe Dempsey of St. George's finished in a tie at 238 in the Women's Cross County Golf Association championship today. Mrs. Cici was declared the victor, however, because Mrs. Dempsey signed an incorrect scorecard and was disqualified.

title: From Cornelius Ryan's Wife, the Story of a Battle Close to Home
description: He was 50 years old: a bestselling author with a happy marriage, two teen-age chirdren, an estate in Connecticut famous friends all over the world, a fascinating life. CM a Caribbean vacation, he developed a touch of prostatitis - nothing, scoffed one friend, that half the guys in the. world haven't had:.

title: OBSERVER
description: The White House was on the phone. It was a woman. Is this the Word Wizard? she asked.

title: Los Angeles Times/Steve Rice via United Press International
description: FUNERAL SERVICE FOR JOHN WAYNE: Pallbearers carrying the casket of the late actor from Our Lady Queen of Angels Catholic Church in Corona del Mar, Calif., yesterday after funeral mass. Mr. Wayne, who died of cancer Monday at the age of 72, was buried at the Pacific View Mortuary on a hill overlooking the ocean.

title: The Region
description: ATLANTIC CITY (UPI)  An Atlantic City police detective who had access to organizedclime files met and helped an associate of a reputed Cana': dian organizedcrime figure buy resort land, according to the Atlantic County Prosecutor's office.

title: Use of a Lottery in Assigning Teachers Is Proposed
description: The New York City Board of Education and the School Chancellor have devised plan to select and assign teachers to schools by lottery.

title: U.S. Sees Farm Exports To China of $700 Million
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) American farm exports to China will reach a record $700 million this year and could go as high as $800 million, the Aericulture Department said today.

title: Rhodesia Awaits Sanction End
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, June 15  After 19 years of clandestine maneuvering to move his company's products into international markets, Eric Knight is looking forward to the day when he can ship pine transmission poles to Britain or coffee to France without the complex stratagems required to evade economic sanctions.

title: Special Situations Lift Dow Modestly
description: The stock market finished slightly higher yesterday, with special-situation issues posting the best gains.

title: Getting Ready for the Lean Years
description: Between 1972 and 1979, two poor world harvests and huge Russian purchases cut so heavily into grain stocks everywhere that hunger spread across the globe. One result was Henry Kissinger's plan. endorsed by the 1974 World Food Conference in Rome, to establish an international grain reserve. That plan remains a dead letter; talks on an international wheat agreement collapsed earlier this year. But lately a stopgap solution has been proposed that deserves support at the sevennation Tokyo summit meeting later this month.

title: NICARAGUANS FIGHT BESIDE U.S. EMBASSY
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 15  An hourlong gun battle erupted outside the United. States Embassy here today when National Guardsmen stationed inside the Embassy compound opened fire on -suspected guerrillas moving through nearby fields.

title: Mrs. Stackhouse Winner
description: ORADELL, N.J., June 15  Mrs. Frank Stackhouse of Canoe Brook won a Women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament today by scoring an 84 at the Hackensack Golf Club. Mrs. Thomas Appleby was second with an 89 on the 6,067yard, par74 course. Mrs. Lillian Littlefield of Montclair took the low net with 95-21-74.

title: Beaths
description: BERMANBeatrice. Beloved wife of Aaron. Devoted mother of Lewis. Dear sister of Florence Grathwohl. Dearest grandmother. Services Sunday 11:30AM The Riverside Brooklyn. Ocean Parkway at Pros Pect Park.

title: Coal Output Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) The National Coal Association estimated today that bituminous coal production for the week ended June 9 was approximately 15,970,000 tons, up from 15,395,000 tons during the same week in 1978. The revised production figure for the week ending June 2 was 13,745,000 tons. The year-todate, or cumulative figure, for Jan. 1 through June 9, 1979, was 317,615,000 tons.

title: U.S. Delays Decision to Tighten Curbs on the PainKiller Darvon
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)  The Government today put off for at least year a decision on whether to tighten restrictions on the painkiller Darvon and other drugs made from the chemical propoxyphene.

title: Francis. Advances In L.I. Golf
description: SANDS POINT, L.I., June 15  Gene Francis, a 41-year-old Huntington stockbroker who has won the Long Island amateur golf championship six times, including the last three. carried on as expected today by dominating his two matches in this year's tournament at the Sands Point Golf Club.

title: 40-a-Pound Rise Forecast for Coffee
description: CHICAGO, June 15 (AP)  Consumers are likely to face a 40cent jump or more in retail coffee prices this summer because of a recent frost in Brazil and the possibility of more bad weather, an Agriculture Department economist said today.

title: CARTER WINS A VOTE IN RHODESIA DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  The House Foreign Affairs Committee unanimously approved a measure today that would allow President Carter to maintain existing economic sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia if he deemed it in the national interest.

title: City Children Run Hot and Cold
description: Vlad Guzman, left, and Jimmy Cauley were the speedy victors in 50yard wheelchair race at a special Olympics for handicapped children on Randalls Island yesterday. In Manhattan's Abbingdon Square, youngsters took it easy and cooled off under a park sprinkler.

title: Suffolk's ExSewer Chief Slain in Lovers
description: SAYVILLE, L.I., June 15  John M. Flynn, the former overseer of Suffolk County's troubled Southwest Sewer District, was found stabbed to death here today in what authorities termed t lovers auarrel several hours before he was to have been arraigned on charges related to alleged doublebilling for county laboratory equipment.

title: I.C.C. to Allow Surcharge of 5.6% In a Move to Stem Truck Stoppages
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  The Interstate Commerce Commission, in a move to head off spreading violence and work stoppages by independent truckers over the price of scarce diesel fuel, ordered trucking companies today to pay a surcharge of 5.6 percent to owneroperators who work for them.

title: Irwin Is Third on 68142
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, June 15  Larry Nelson and Tom Purtzer, two relatively unknown players on the PGA Tour, shared a threestroke lead at 139 today in the second round of the 79th United States Open.
