description: HONG KONG, June 15  Starting from his home in a village in rural Guangdong Province, Wang Yonghe went on a 13day joyride this spring during which he stole two bicycles, two cars and four trucks. That does not

title: A Calder Stabile Makes a Move
description: Alexander Calder, the late sculptor, was known initially for his mobile sculptures. In later years he was known for his stabiles, monumental and motionless structures in sheet metal or steel plate.

title: Bargain Seekers Fill Short Flights As HalfFare Coupons Near End
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  The great halffare coupon craze comes to an end Sunday night amid such a flurry of shorthaul airline reservations that it is almost impossible to buy a United or American Airlines flight out of Washington, Boston, New York or Philadelphia this weekend.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 1107
description: MOSCOW, June 15 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union launched a new satellite today, the official press agency, Tass, reported. It said the satellite, Cosmos 1107, was carrying equipment designed for continuing the exploration of outer space.

title: Officer Is Slain and 2 Hurt In Three Separate Attacks
description: A housing policeman was killed and two other officers  one a member of the New York City Police Department, and the other a transit policeman  were seriously wounded yesterday in three separate incidents. The officers had been either investigating crimes or attempting to make arrests.

title: Vienna in Summit Time: The Press of History and Hotels
description: VIENNA, June 15  Vienna is bursting.

title: Antitrust Action on TV Commercials: Industry and Admen Fear an Exercise in Futility
description: Advertising, broadcasting and consumer leaders expressed doubts yesterady that there would be any public-interest benefits from a Justice Department suit that seeks to remove the television industry's own restrictions on the

title: Subway Riders Taking Shorter Trains in Stride
description: Yesterday morning's rush hour appeared to move at a normal pace on the three IND lines and one BMT subway line that were affected by the withdrawal from service of 109 cars for inspection because of cracked undercarriages

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Friday, June 15, 1979

title: BREZHNEV ARRIVES IN VIENNA AND SEES CARTER FOR 1ST TIME
description: VIENNA, June 15  Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, met President Carter for the first time today.

title: Long Lettuce Strike Tests Chavez Union's Strategy
description: LOS ANGELES, June 15  A strike by the United Farm Workers of America against major California vegetable growers will be five months old on Tuesday, and there are still no indications of settlement in the increasingly violent dispute.

title: TruckingBill Accord Cited
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, have agreed on a trucking deregulation bill and will propose it jointly next week, aides to Senator Kennedy said today.

title: Thomas Severo Is Dead at 87; Long a Newburgh Businessman
description: Thomas Severo, a Newburgh, N.Y., businessman for more than 50 years, died Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: 2 in New Jersey Indicted On FakeCharity Charge
description: CAMDEN, N.J., June 15 (AP) A New Jersey couple who allegedly operated fraudulent charity with a catchall name in six states were indicted today by Camden County grand jury on charges of embezzlement, conspiracy, extortion and threat to kill.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Opera: The Old Maid
description: The New Renaissance Opera Wing is presenting a double bill of Menotti's The Old Maid and the Thief and WolfFerrari's Secret of Susanna for a run through June 24 at the WPA Theater, 138 Fifth Avenue. The openingnight performance Thursday showed that the group has quite a bit going for it.

title: BUSINESS_ Digest
description: The oil industry said It was operating its refineries at the maximum rates permitted by the available supplies of crude oil. Expressing surprise at critical remarks by Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger, spokesmen for the industry said more time would be required to expand the output of gasoline and other products from the nation's refineries, even assuming a continuation of the high level crude oil imports reported for last week. [Page 1.]

title: G.E. AND 13 UNIONS TO INTENSIFY TALKS
description: Employees Seeking Pay Rise and Cost-of-Living Adjustment Contract Expires June 30

title: The New York Times/ Paul J. Sutton
description: WALNUT, Calif., June 15  His career has been filled with oneshot successes and might-have-been performances. What would have happened if he had been healthy for the Montreal Olympics three summers ago? How fast can he run 100 meters when it all falls into place?

title: Why Moscow Harries the Helsinki Monitors
description: While President Carter is in Vienna for talks with Soviet leaders, he should review the text of the Helsinki accord and consider the alight of the 15 Hel- sink monitors who are now held in Soviet prisons or camps in what must be seen as a violation of the accord. This is all the more pressing since Mr. Carter seems to be on the verge of recommending that we grant Moscow most-favored-nation status without the monitors release.

title: Notes on People
description: Judge Orders. Medical Test for. Rep. Daniel Flood

title: A Subway Scandal, Bribe or No Bribe
description: It isn't necessary to believe the charge of bribery of Transit Authority officials to be horrified by the revelations about subway car procurement in New York City. Bribery, of course, would be a horrifying ex- planation for the authority's approval of 754 subway cars which developed 1,058 dangerous cracks within two years. But even if there were no bribes, one would have to conclude that officials of the world's biggeit subway don't know how to order cars without endangering passengers, . and that the nation's foremost manufacturer of cars doesn't know how to build them. The story is a horror either way. It isn't surprising that Mayor Koch has ordered the city's Corporation Counsel tO: sue both Pullman Standard and its subcontractor, Rockwell International. But it won't be surprising either if the blame spills all over the lot. A thorough investigation by an outside agency is essential.

title: Mets Top Braves, Acquire Ellis
description: The longawaited revamping of the Mets crippled pitching staff took a couple of steps forward last night when the Mets beat the trading deadline by acquiring Dock Ellis from the Texas Rangers and Andy Hassler from the Boston Red Sox.

title: Big Board Halts Credit For Charter Oil Trades
description: The New York Stock Exchange, temporarily halting customary credit arrangements, told Wall Street brokers yesterday that all orders placed for Charter Company securities must be paid for in cash. It announced the unusual move after the 4 P.M. market close. Charter has interests in the petroleum industry, communications and insurance.

title: WhaleOil Regulations Are Repealed by Carey
description: ALBANY, June 15  In the 19th century, when the whaleoil industry was big business, the New York State Legislature undertook to regulate it.

title: Around the Nation
description: AUGUSTA, Me., June 15 (AP)  State health officials warned canoeists today not to fish or drink the water in a lake along the Allagash Wilderness Waterway betause of a pesticide spill.

title: Ballotage First In a Jump off at Ox Ridge Show
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 15  Ballotage, who made the journey from Argentina with impressive  if vague credentials a little over a year ago, won the open jumper class in the first timed jumpoff today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club Horse Show.

title: Italian Businessman Kidnapped
description: MANTUA, Italy, June 15 (AP)  Four bandits ambushed and kidnapped Lucio Vaccari, a 27-year-old owner of a Milan demolition company, near his home outside this northern town, the police reported today. Mr. Vaccari is the 23rd victim of Italy's kidnapping rings this year.

title: Associated Press
description: ANOTHER MILESTONE: Willie McCovey of Giants heads for home after belting homer against Cubs Thursday in San Francisco. Homer was 513th of McCovey's career, moving him to ninth on baseball list. Giants lost to Cubs, 84.

title: James McLure Can Write Plays He Can Act in Now
description: Ask James McLure, who has just made his Broadway debut as a playwright with two well received oneact comedies, Lone Star and Pvt. Wars, what made him turn to writing. and he will say unemployment. What the. 27-year-old author means is that it was not until he came East from California three years ago and could not find work as an actor that he had the time to devote himself seriously to writing.

title: Stock Definition Sought For New Market System
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a formal definition today for stocks that are to be traded in the emerging national market system.

title: Books of The Times The Shopping Mystique
description: SHOPPING IN STYLE: London From the Restoration to Edwardian Elegance. By Alison Adburgham. Illustrated. 192 pages. Thames Sc Hudson. $14.95.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  President Carter's decision last week to begin fullscale development of the MX mobile intercontinental missile culminates .. a longrunning debate over American strategic policy.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 15, 1979

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SUCCESS STORY Visitors and nearby residents who like to stroll and rest in Lincoln Center these warmweather weekends without stepping indoors for a performance should remember the al fresco movie scheduled through the month. The sound and light offering is a halfhour documentary on center activities, projected on huge screen virtually covering the facade of the Metropolitan Opera House, except for the entrance, and visible across the fountain plaza. It goes on at 9 o'clock on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays.

title: The City
description: Owners of rentstabilized apartments in New York City yesterday recommended large rent increases for tenants whose leases take effect in the year beginning July 1.

title: Track Shut by Derailment Opens
description: LANCASTER, Pa., June 15 (AP) Amtrak workers yesterday reopened one of two tracks closed by a passenger train derailment that resulted in the hospitalization of five passengers. Four cars of the National Limited bound for St. Louis jumped the track Wednesday on an old stone railroad bridge 80 feet above the Conestoga River, the authorities said.

title: DOUGLAS H. THAYER
description: Douglas H. Thayer, past president and general counsel of Multicon Properties of Columbus, Ohio, a construction company and a subsidiary of Bethlehem Steel, died Wednesday in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Thayer, who lived in Delray Beach, Fla., and Point 0 Woods, L.I., was 68 years old.

title: U.S. Offers New Rules On Foreign Tax Credits
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)  The Treasury Department proposed new rules today that are intended to tighten the use of foreign tax credits to offset Federal income taxes. The greatest and most controversial use of the credits has been by oil comnanies.

title: 10 States Cite Wide Enthusiasm For Curbing Spending and Taxes
description: DENVER, Colo., June 15  Representatives from all 10 states that have passed spending limits and Proposition 13style tax cuts met in Denver today, to discuss how the results looked one year after the first was passed. There was an uneasy consensus that the limits are a little like fragmentation bombs  no one is entirely sure yet just where they are going to hit or what their effect will be  but there was still considerable enthusiasm for them.

title: The Ballet: Baryshnikov In Premiere of Opus 19
description: Drama in which things are left unsaid rather than fully stated had long been a hallmark of Jerome Robbins ballets since the late 40's. But in maior works such as Dances at a Gathering and The Goldberg Variations after 1969, Mr. Robbins's interests seemed to go into a more neoclassical and puremovement area.

title: Firmani Named Coach in A.S.L.
description: VANCOUVER; British Columbia, June 15  Eddie Firmani, who was dismissed by the Cosmos 14 days ago, has signed a threeyear contract to coach the New Jersey Americans of the American Soccer League. The official announcement:will be made at a new conference in New York next Monday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly reported the interest of Khodadad Farmanfarrnaian in the Bank Sanaye Iran and incorrectly stated that he had left Iran last year. His interest in the bank was less than percent and he has remained in Iran.

title: Official of Southern Baptists. Plans Inquiry on New President's Election
description: HOUSTON, June 14  A top official of the Southern Baptist Convention has decided to investigate the denomination's presidential election, following complaints about voting procedures and political maneuvering at the annual meeting here, which ended tonight.

title: Thorpe Defense Makes Final Plea; Jury Expected to Get Case Monday
description: LONDON, June 15  Jeremy Thorpe's lawyer completed his defense against murder conspiracy charges today with an attack on what he called the weak and unproved prosecution case against his client.

title: Darla Hood of Our Gang
description: HOLLYWOOD, June 15 (AP)  Darla Hood, the darkeyed, curly haired female member of the Our Gang kid comedy troupe of the 30's, died Wednesday in Canoga Park hospital. She was 48 years old.

title: Order for Six DC10's Suspended by Alitalia
description: ROME, June 15 (AP)  Alitalia, Italy's national airline, has suspended plans to buy six DC10's for $310 million because of the plane's safety problems, the airline's chairman, Umberto Nordio, said today.

title: Your Money
description: Advantages Of 2d Mortgage

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Marshak Vision of City College
description: The place was a shambles when Robert Marshak assumed the presidency of New York's City College 1970. A student revolt and racial conflict had convulsed the campus. An open admissions policy. new and hardly under control, threatened to drown the scholarly traditions that had made C.C.N.Y. the flagship of City University and of urban higher education. The prevailing mood was to eulogize a glorious past and write off the future.

title: Dad's Contract
description: AGREEMENT

title: Yoshimura Conviction Upheld
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 (AP)  The California Supreme Court refused today to overturn the 1977 weapons conviction of Wendy Yoshimura, the fugitive who was captured with Patricia Hearst two years earlier. Miss Yoshimura's netition had claimed six grounds for reversal of her conviction by an Alameda County Superior Court jury and its affirmation by the state Court of Appeal April 5. The jury had found her guilty of unlawful possession of explosives, of a machine gun and of substances and materials with intent to make destructive devices and explosives. The 35-year-old artist had remained free on bail.

title: Missing Boy's Mother in Appeal
description: The mother of the missing Etan Patz renewed her plea yesterday that whoever has the 6-year-old boy send him home. Julie Patz said on WABC's AM New York program: It's not fair. If you have Etan, send him home. He is a part of our family and we want him back. Her son disappeared four Fridays ago on his way to catch a school bus two blocks from the family loft apartment in the SoHo area of Manhattan.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Friday, June 15, 1979

title: Rev. Robert Rodenmayer, Noted As Teacher and Writer, Dies at 70
description: The Rev. Robert Rodenmayer, an Episcopal clergyman, educator and writer, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Margaret Gadon Married To Dr. Richard A. Brown
description: Margaret E. Gadon, daughter of Herman Gadon of Durham, N.H., and Elinor Weiner Gadon of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard A. Brown, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Brown of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Marlboro, Vt. Rabbi Leslie Gutterman of Providence, R.I., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Iran Prints Draft of a Constitution For Islamic State Under President
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 15  A draft constitution aimed at giving Iran a political syteni based on Islamic law has been forwarded to Ayatollah Ruhollah IChomeini,.thetiovemment announced today.

title: The Abitene Reporter News/David Leeson, via Associated Press
description: JET FUEL EXPLODES AT TEXAS REFINERY: A worker running for cover Thursday at the Pride Oil Refinery in Abilene, Tex., after a fire in a fuel storage tank set off a series of explosions. Thirteen persons were hurt, cluding the photographer who made this picture. Blaze destroyed fuel supplies for three Air Force bases and put the refinery out of service for a month.

title: Koch Urges End to Budget Haggling
description: Mayor Koch yesterday urged prompt action in approving the longdelayed New York City budget.

title: Castner Team Triumphs
description: RIVER.VALE, N.J., June 15- They arenot related but Sharon Castner of Harker's Hollow and Linda Castner of Beaver Brook, combined today and won the Garden State Women's Golf Association's 19th betterball team championship at the Edgewood Country Club. Linda Castner's par 3 on the 18th hole provided a 1up triumph over Mary Ann Farmer of Glen Ridge and Elizabeth Wood of Spring Lake.

title: Gasoline Outlook for Weekend
description: Gasoline stations are prohibited from giving special treatment to preferred customers or requiring other purchases to get gasoline, the Federal Department of Energy has warned. It urges motorists who believe the prohibition against favoritism is being violated to telephone the tollfree number (800) 4249246. Motorists are advised also that some stations are refusing to accept charges on their company's own credit cards.

title: About New York
description: Just in time for his 50th wedding anniversary, a father came home from the hospital with terrible but funny tales of the man in the next bed in the middle of the night.

title: Israeli Prices Up 4.8% in May
description: TEL AVIV, June 15  Israel's inflation rate slowed somewhat in May as the consumer price index rose by 9.8 percent over April, compared with an 8.7 percent rise in April over March.

title: Mrs. King Gains in Upset
description: CHICHESTER, England, June 15 (AP)  Billie Jean King crushed the current Wimbledon champion, Martina Navratilova, 6.1, 62, in 48 minutes today and advanced to the semifinals of the $75,000 Chichester grass tennis tournament.

title: Series of Mendharn Student Deaths Troubles Classmates
description: MENDHAM, N.J., June 15  The $150 scholarship that Patty McKinnell was awarded at commencement exercises Wednesday night came from donations by her fellow members of the Class of 1979 at West Morris Mendham High School. It was given in memory of Karen Ehrle, Rosalind Hammerle, David Horn and Michael Murphy four classmates who had died of illness or in accidents over the course of the academic year.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON MPROVEMENTS on both ends of the television system  the camera and the receiver  were patented this week. One invention automatically sets a color camera for optimum performance in a matter of seconds. The other is a filter for the receiver, which increases picturesharpness and eliminates color crawls.

title: U.S. Considering Rules On Thermostat Controls
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) Starting July 1, the temperature in office, industrial and governmental buildings, as well as in stores, restaurants and theaters, could be forced to rise, under a Federal plan aimed at conserving 195,000 to 390,000 barrels of oil a day.

title: Apollo Beaten, 21
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., June 15  The New York Apollo lost their third consecutive American Soccer League game tonight, bowing to the New Jersey Americans, 21, before about 2,500 fans. The Apollo (9-5-2) got its only goal on John Motta's breakaway. Alex Pringle of New Jersey scored two minutes later and Angrik Stepanow added the deciding goal 44 minutes for the Americans (37).

title: ALEX WITTENBERG
description: Alex Wittenberg, a hotel owner in Livingston Manor, N.Y., who operated the Edgewood Inn from 1916 until his retirement in 1968, died yesterday at his home in the Catskills. He was 93 years old.

title: Soviet Emigres Will Play In Festival at Carnegie Hall
description: A sixday festival of concerts featuring the participation of recent Soviet migrs will be presented for the first time by Jay K. Hoffman in Cameeie Hall next month. The concerts will be played by an ensemble of 19 Soviet and American string players organized by Lazar Gosman, conductor and concertmaster of the Leningrad Chamber Orchestra from 1962 until he left the Soviet Union in 1977. Other Soviet and American artists will be heard as soloists with the group.

title: Drivers in Capital Line Up for Gas by Dawn's Early Light
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  Three cars away from the gas pump, a sleeping driver nestled crosswise in his car, his head out the driver's side, his feet oppo. site, and the radio blaring.

title: Amtrak Will Raise Fares 7% July 15
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) Amtrak passenger train fares will increase by 7 percent on July 15, the national railroad corporation announced today. All regular coach and sleeping car fares and accommodation charges will be subject to the increase, except for some commuter fares

title: John D. Murchison Dies
description: John Dabney Murchison, the Texas multimillionaire financier, died Thursday night on the way to St. Paul Hospital in Dallas. He was 57 years old.

title: United Press International
description: BURNING FREIGHTER CARRIED MARIJUANA: A Coast Guard fireboat fought blaze near New Orleans aboard the Norderkroon, abandoned in the Mississippi River. Marijuana was found in its bold; whereabouts of crew was unknown.

title: U.N. Reports Increase In Indochina Refugees
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15 (AP)  The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today that 134,386 Indochinese refugees from Southeast Asia had been resettled in the West since August 1975 but more than twice that number remain stranded in the Far East.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yeslarday's Weedily at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmoephmic Administration/UPI

title: Susan Lynn Lehrer, Teacher, Wed to Michael J. Silverstein
description: Susan Lynn Lehrer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lehrer of Woodbury, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael J. Silverstein, son of Mrs. Herbert Gerson of Bayside, Queens, and Henry Silverstein of New York. The ceremony was performed in Temple Aloheim in Old Bethpage, L.I., by Rabbi Louis Stein.

title: More Stations, Out of Gasoline, Shut Yesterday
description: Scores of gasoline. stations in the metropolitan area were closed yesterday and others severely limited their hours. Long lines of frustrated and angry motorists formed at the few stations that were still pumping gasoline.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, June 15  President Ferdinand E. Marcos has halted construction on a 620megawatt nuclear power plant in the. Bataan Peninsula until doubts about itssafety are resolved:

title: NOW Members Take a Stand In Front of Tiffany's Window
description: Mendelssohn would probably have been more appropriate but it was the music of Mozart, performed by band of street musicians, that wafted across Fifth Avenue to Tiffany, where three women wearing bridal veils along with their street clothes were handing out leaflets to passersby the other afternoon.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: The Tree That Didn't Qualify
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, June 15  From the knoll behind the seventh green at the Inverness Club today, Lon Hinkle smiled when he saw the tree that had not been there in the opening round of the United States Open championship. When he strode onto the tee of the 528yard eighth hole, a dogleg left, he stared at the 25-foot-high

title: Industrial Output Up 1.3% in May
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Industrial production rebounded 1.3 percent last month from the strike-depressed level of April, but still signaled slow secondquarter growth for the nation's economy, the Government said today.

title: Manila Gives Clemency to 714
description: MANILA, June 15 (Reuters)  President Ferdinand E. Marcos granted clemency today to 714 prisoners to mark the 81st anniversary of the independence of the Philippines from Spain, the Presidential Palace announced.

title: Judge Reaffirms Ban on an Article On HBomb but Withholds Reason
description: MILWAUKEE, June 15  A Federal District Court judge today denied a motion to vacate the preliminary injunction that has kept The Progressive magazine from publishing an article about the hydrogenbomb.

title: Ban's Effect On Concern Seen Slight
description: Efforts by the Carter Administration to deny Federal contracts to two companies that it said had violated its voluntary guidelines on price increases apparently will have little impact on one of them.

title: Beaths
description: KINGSFORDWilmer Hoffman. On June 15, 1979, husband of Marlon, father of Alesandra and Cynthia. Memorial Service at Calvary Episcopal Church Summit NJ 11AM Tuesday June 19. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Calvary Church thru Drew University or Hospice Service Overlook Hospital, Summit appreciated.

title: ProspectLefferts Gardens Community Is Battling for Racial Stability
description: Last spring, in Brooklyn's ProspectLefferts Gardens community, Malcolm Brown and his wife,- Patricia, bought burnedout fourstory brick building .from the city at auction for $5,000. They spent about twice that amount on materials, and Mr. Brown, a carpenter, quit his construction job to devote full time to rebuilding one of the apartments.

title: Author's Query
description: For a new translation of and expanded compendium to Apologia de Barbis, I would appreciate any information, reproductions, illustrations and anecdotes about beards.

title: Anderson Picks Campaign Chief
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)  Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois has announced that he has named William G. Bradford, United States Ambassador to Chad, as director of his campaign for the Republican nomination for President. Mr. Bradford will resign his diplomatic post in the African nation, where he has been assigned since 1976, Mr. Anderson said.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY OMITTED A FINDING ON 1977 IND CRASH
description: TRANSIT AUTHORITY OMITTED A FINDING ON 1977 IND CRASH

title: TicketSales Program For Olympics Delayed
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 16 (AP) - Another snag has developed in the sale of tickets for February's Winter Olympics.

title: Elizabeth de Murga Bride of Mark Spradlinz
description: Elizabeth Susana de Murga and Mark Raymond Spradling, graduates of Dartmouth College, were married yesterday at the Convent of the Sacred Heart. The Rev. Jude Gray performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Arthur Miller Says The Time Is Right For The Price
description: When I wrote this play it ran across the grain of the moment in 1968. It wasn't about the war in Vietnam. It wasn't about being 16 and on dope. It wasn't multimedia. It was regarded as though it were something that had dropped out of a car.

title: Iran Orders Gunmen to Kill Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 16 (UPI)  A revolutionary court has ordered a team of Iranian gunmen to Mexico to try to assassinate the exiled Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who has been condemned to death in absentia, officials said today.

title: 2 Congressmen Urge Black and Hispanic Coalition
description: BALTIMORE, June 16  Two black Congressmen today asked for 'support for a national black and Hispanic coalition to serve the political interests of both groups and urged that more .such coalitions be formed locally.

title: R. A. Pastor Weds Miss McNamara
description: Margaret E. McNamara, daughter of Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank and former Secretary of Defense, and Mrs. McNamara of Washington, was married at Chilmark, Mass., yesterday to Robert A. Pastor. son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Pastor of Florham Park, N.J. Justice of the Peace John Alley performed the ceremony on the South Beach cliffs.

title: THE KENNEDY MYSTIQUE
description: He's ahead in the Presidential polls, sparring with Jimmy Carter. But as his boosters enthusiasm mounts, the key question about Edward Kennedy is his character. The first of a twopart series.

title: Notes: Vermont Inns Beckon carless
description: As a result of the concern over the cost and availability of gasoline during the summer a group of 20 country inns in Vermont has organized hiking, biking and canoeing tours that allow vacationers to leave their cars home.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY My Father, at an August Age in
description: YOU cannot call my father a senior citizen. But at 85, you can call him old. Having reached such an august age, he explains, gives him a statistical chance of living 8.7 more years.

title: Packers Profit With TV Money
description: Network television's tremendous impact on the profit picture of pro football recently came to light when the Green . Bay Packers issued their annual finandal statement. The Packers net profit for last season increased by $1.25 million, to $1,520,903, in the first year of the National Football League's current contracts with the three major television networks. Green Bay's equal share of television income jumped by $3 million, from $2.2 million to $5.2 million.

title: SHOP TALK Babylon's Variety
description: BABYLON

title: A Dip in the Prime
description: The parade started on Tuesday when the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reduced its prime lending rate, the one that banks charge their best corporate customers, by a quarter of a point to 111/2 percent. By the end of the week Citibank, the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Bank of America and a number of others had fallen in line.

title: Nukes or No Nukes, That Is the Question
description: THE current debate over the use of nuclear plants to provide part of our national energy needs leaves me with a feeling of deja vu. I am taken back to the early Years of the Vietnam war, when I experienced similar mixed emotions of resentment and trust, alienation and respect.

title: The Fourth R Real Estate May Put Brokers Back in School
description: The vision, for real estate brokers, is fascinating: real estate superstars like Harry B. Helmsley sitting in class taking notes and cramming for their final exams so they can keep their real estate licenses.

title: Realty News
description: Construction has resumed on a 40story hotel and apartment tower a few doors east of Carnegie Hall despite the wishes of local residents expressed through their Community Board.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Kurt Jooss's Vision

title: Lyrical Paintings, Subtle Sculptures
description: WATER MILL IT is always pleasurable to watch the development of favorite artists, especially their discoveries and breakthroughs. It is akin to watching the progress of our friends. James Brooks and Betty Parsons, whose works are on view at the Louise Himelfarb Gallery, are two of my favorite artists. They are to my mind worth seeing no matter what direction they are taking. Even when they are doing what must appear to be more of the same thing, they are never repetitive.

title: A Nightmare for the Truckers And Everybody Else
description: An air of romance may linger about the open road in America and those who ply it for a living, but the trucker's lot has never been an easy one even in the best of times. When there isn't enough fuel to go around, and when the experts say the supply may never again be really ample, it can become nightmare.

title: Engagenuntts
description: GRIMESSOLOMON

title: 100Mile Nocturnal Jaunt Ends in the Park
description: Immediately after he won the New York Invitational 100mile run early yesterday morning, Don Ritchie was carried away from the finish line. Within two minutes he was lying on a cot in the Flushing Meadow amphitheater, as race officials pulled his shoes off to examine his bandaged feet. He did not put his feet on the ground again for some time.

title: The Pinch Of SALT
description: VIENNA  It has become the custom of the Carter Administration, since the bruising disillusionment of its first foreign policy mishaps two years ago, to play down the prospects of Presidential missions in advance and thus make any achievements seem more substantial and impressive. So it is only natural that the Carter entourage has come to this old world capital for the first meeting of Soviet and American leaders in close to five years burdened with lowkey forecasts and warnings about false illusions.

title: P.C. Vallieres Weds Linda Ely

title: Past Vienna Woods, Treaty's Next Test Is Senate Thicket

Tomorrow in Vienna, he and Soviet President Leonid I. Brezhnev will sign a strategic arms limitation treaty that has been his Administration's most sought foreign policy goal. Yet, because his domestic standing is at an alltime low, the fight for SALT II ratification is more chancy than any other, from Panama to Rhodesia, to China and the Middle East.

title: Voices Of War
description: B if LOOD OF SPAIN opens with an apologia for the appearance of a new book on the Spanish Civil War. That piece of selfjustification arguably the only redundant section of a moving and original work that will immediately take its place among the dozen or so truly important books about the Spanish conflict. Ronald Fraser's remarkable achievement is to have captured from hundreds of interviews the feel of what it was like to be in Spain during the civil war, something hitherto seen only fleetingly in specific, trench-eye-view memoirs. He has then modeled his material into an overview of the war that provides insights of a kind that might have been reasonably expected only in a great novel..

title: What's Doing in CYPRUS
description: POLITICS  Political troubles have dominated the existence of the Mediterranean island of Cyprus, frequently with unhappy results for its people. The last traumatic event took place in July 1979, when a Greekorganized coup caused an invasion from nearby Turkey. Turkish troops are still on the 3,500-square-mile island (about twothirds the size of Connecticut), which is divided into two zones, the southern, predominantly Greek and Christian, the northern, Turkish and Moslem. A United Nations peacekeeping force has been in Cyprus since early 1964, more frequently than not a helpless witness to its various convulsions. Despite its vicissitudes, Cyprus has shown an admirable capacity for recovery. Today, nearly five years after the invasion, tourism is booming and, at the height of the summer season, hotel rooms are sometimes hard to find, particularly in the Greek

title: First Heat for 1980
description: Although the Republican field is fat with declared, articulate Presidential hopefuls, two undeclared Democrats  the President and the senior Senator from Massachusetts  have been far more diverting. Last week, Mr. Kennedy revealed that in a private talk two months ago he gave Mr. Carter a pledge of his tentative support in 1980. This is the same photogenic, ambitious Senator man who also said last week: If I were to run, which I don't intend to, I would hope to win. As of now, it's widely believed that many Democrats would prefer to see Mr. Kennedy heading the party's national ticket next year. Nevertheless, the President reportedly told White House diners last week that lie was ready for 1980 and, behind as he is in the polls, would stomp Mr. Kennedy in any oneonone primaries.

title: The Liberation of Fathers

Dad is dressed conservatively in the loosefitting style of the early 60's. We are smiling, but it looks forced, and we are very stiff and formal. We are not touchine.

title: DINING OUT Hotel Dining Put to the Test
description: AN unfortunate (and often impractical) rule of gastronomy is, Never eat in an American hotel dining room, where, with few excep- tions, the cuisine is generally a notch or two above airline food, the prices are exorbitant and geared to the expense account, and portion control takes precedence over good taste. On my first visit to Penfield's, the goodlooking, rather masculine dining room at the Rye Town Hilton, I felt that my prejudices might be dispelled by a very good and interesting meal. By my second visit I was disappointed. By my third, after management had made extensive menu changes, I was more convinced than ever that American hotel food is better for business luncheons than for serious dining.

title: The Gas Dealers Also Wait in Line
description: WHITE PLAINS THEY need gasoline, so they come to the County Office Building, to Room 916. It is there that the pipeline to Albany begins. The servicestation owners appear in a steady stream, seeking allocations from the state's emergency reserves, and in Room 916  the office of the County Energy Coordinator - they fill out a form and leave, not with gasoline but with at least a hope of additional supplies.

He was, by anybody's lights, riding high.

The future bride's father is a certified public accountant. Dr. Forrest is an orthodontist.

title: Music: Miss Hillis's Bach

title: For the First Time in 15 Years, a Republican Is Head of Mayors Conference

In the more subdued 1970's, city halls across the, country are increasingly inhabited by less flamboyant species, somewhat less dependent on largesse from Washington and more likely to seek local solutions to problems.

title: CHESS

When it became clear whose idea was better, it also became clear who was the victor and who the vanquished. Today this seems almost funny; nowadays if one idea does not work, we try another.

title: Carter Health Plan Has Poor Prognosis
description: For decades, Washington has wrung its hands at regular intervals over the often ruinous costs of health. Every Democratic President since Harry S. Truman has wheeled out a plan to help those who can't afford to get sick, only to see it die of neglect or abuse. me latest debate over national health care began last week with President Carter presenting his proposals. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, one of the White House's least favorite people these days, promptly asserted that Mr. Carter had once again been too late with too little. Mr. Carter called for a program that, starting in mid1983, would cover a family's hosital and medical costs above $2,500, at an eventual annual cost of $24.3 billion, including $6.1 bil lion in employer contributions. A uni. versal, comprehensive program would come later, he said. That approach, Mr. Kennedy said, would result in out-of-control spending and shoddy medical care for the poor. He wants comprehensiveness right away, in a bill to be introduced later that would combine $11.4 billion in private funds and $28.6 billion in Federal.

At the .center of the room is a 27-foot-long, $48,000 oval table of Japanese cherrywood veneered with gleaming mahogany. title: JAPANESE REFUSING TO CUT ENERGY USE
description: TOKYO, June 16  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira modeled a new summer jacket with short sleeves for photographers and television cameras the other day.

title: Miami Beach Fights to Regain Its Superstar Billing
description: Welcome to the World's Greatest Resort Hotel. Thus did the reborn Fontainebleau Hilton of Miami Beach  with characteristic understatementgreet its guests this winter after nearly two years in the limbo of bankruptcy and reorganization. Is it still  or again  the greatest? Does its revival signal any upturn in the lagging fortunes of Miami Beach?

title: Cosmos Beaten On Coast, 4 to 1
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 16  The Vancouver Whitecaps toyed with the Cosmos defenders at Empire Stadium tonight and posted 41 victory over the defending North American Soccer League champions. Giorgio Chinaglia scored the only goal for the Cosmos on a penalty kick with five minutes left in the game.

title: LETTERS
description: Womanhood

title: COURTROOM CLOSING LEADS TO NEW TRIAL
description: The New York State Court of Appeals has ordered a new trial for a defendant convicted on charges of selling heroin to undercover police officers because the judge had closed the courtroom while one of the undercover agents testified.

title: Chirac's Haze Political Appetite Makes Him Hungriest for France's Presidency
description: PARIS  France's Fifth Republic was virtually the personal creation of Charles de Gaulle, and his role gave sense of proprietorship to those French who identify themselves as Gaullists.

title: NewLook Cabinet For South Africa
description: South Africa's Information Ministry scandal, unless it ensnares him, too, may turn out to be the biggest boon for P. W. Botha's prime ministership. With the father figure of the ruling National Party, John Vorster, forced Into retirement, Mr. Botha finally has been able to fashion a Government reflecting his more moderate (in a South African context) racial views.

title: Mechanical Snag Delays Lottery
description: TRENTON, NJ., June 18 (AP)  After a machine malfunctioned, two New Jersey PickIt Lottery numbers were drawn tonight.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE state's chief administrative judge, Justice Herbert B. Evans, responded to a particularly effusive introduction at judiCial forum in White Plains recently by recounting an incident that he said placed his importance in proper perspective. It dealt with two classic figures, a Manhattan cabby and a policeman.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMOWITZIda. Devoted mother of Ben, Fay, Rose and Jack and departed Max and Henry. Beloved Grandmother and great grandrwther. Services Sunday 10:30 AM Garlick Funeral Chapel, 1139 Unionport Rd., (Parkchester) Bronx, N.Y.

title: The Stubborn Spirit Of Stony Creek, Conn.
description: A political critic once said of Stony Creek, Conn., Every town has its village idiot, but only Branford has its idiot village. Stony Creek glories in the epithet. A stubbornly independent appendage of the town of Branford, the village is quirky, eccentric, a place unto itself even geographically, for it reaches like a hand into Long Island Sound eight miles east of New Haven, and all its roads south of the rail line run into dead ends. As one resident put it, There's a special flavor here  a crazy, mixedup collection of prides.

title: Diane Norfleet, Teacher, Is Bride
description: Christ Episcopal Church was the setting in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday for the marriage of Diane Norwood Norfleet, daughter of Mrs. Henry Fairfax Ayres Jr. of Greenwich and Norwood Norfleet of Tannersville, N.Y., td Ni- colas Ignacio Quintana. He is the son of Edith Seyburn Quintana of New York and Manuel Quintana of Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic. The Rev. James Kellaway performed the ceremony.

title: SpeedyTrial RulePelay Voted by Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)  The Senate Judiciary Committee has voted to postpone for up to two years a requirement that Federal criminal cases be dismissed if they are not brought to trial within 100 days.

title: Critics Assert Oil Price Decontrol May Not Spur Production in U.S.
description: With oil companies typically reaping returns of 20 percent and more from their investments in domestic exploration and production, the industry's critics are increasingly questioning whether still higher profits are needed to encourage the search for new oil reserves.

title: New Jersey MobileHome Owners Rise in Status: They'll Pay Taxes
description: HIGH BRIDGE, N.J.  In a wooded setting in this Hunterdon County hamlet stands Solitude Village, a community of 100 mobile homes that, belying its tranquil name, is causing a stir in New Jersey with reverberations likely to be felt in the housing industry nationally.

title: A Blow to New Rochelle's Democrats
description: AS recently as a month ago the Republican Party in New Rochelle seemed in disarray and unlikely to be able to mount strong campaign in the November general election. Saddled with a lameduck chairman and old rivalries, many pally members clOubted that they could even present a unified front at election time, much less beat the incumbent Democratic Mayor, Vincent Rippa.

title: Debra Lynne Mayer Fiancee
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Saul Mayer of Harrington Park, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Debra Lynne Mayer, to Frederick Wasserman, son of Mrs. Bernard Banks of Edison, N.J., and the late Milton Wasserman. A November wedding is planned.

title: A Correction

description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.  Howard Hughes was a businessman, and he made a lot of money. But if his profitmaking instincts were working during his later years, they weren't immediately apparent in some of the deals he made then.

title: FATHER
description: Researchers have lately probed the fatherinfant relationship and found few significant differences in the way children relate to fathers and to mothers Their studies may sharply alter our concepts of what parenting is all about.

description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 16 (UPI) A fire ignited by the explosion of a tanker truck ripped through a fuel distribution plant today, causing secondary explo- sions and forcing more than 5,000 people from their homes.

description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 16 (AP) The costs of staging the 1980 Winter Olympics here could top $190 million, or six times an original estimate, according to sfigures compiled by The. Associated Press.

description: WHILE the salary increase awarded recently by arbitration to the 2,500 members of the Suffolk County police force will cost the county an estimated $3 million over the next year and a half, the decision at the same time signals the beginning of a trend to demand more work time from police officers, according to county officials.

title: OffRoad Vehicles to Be Limited On Government Land in the West
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)  Public lands in the West will be divided into three categories to govern the use of offtheroad vehicles on lands managed by the Bureau of Reclamation and Bureau of Land Management, the Department of the Interior announced today. The three categories are open, limited and closed.

Yet a recent spate of Walter re- leases and rereleases, the bulk of them on the budget Odyssey label, suggests that his image may be an exaggerated one.

title: Over the Waves In a Flying Bike
description: Man first flew 75 years ago last December, and plenty of people are still alive who didn't believe it when it happened. Last week, in full view of a world that no longer doubts anything, an airplane powered only by a man pushing pedals flew the Eng- lish Channel, making the 22 miles from Folkestone, England, to Cap GrisNez, France, in 2 hours and 55 minutes. The plane, called the Gossamer Albatross, was an improved version of the Gossamer Condor, the machine that, in 1977, won the $102,500 Kremer Prize for the world's first controlled manpowered flight. Like the Condor, the Albatross was piloted by. Bryan Allen, a biochemist and bike racer from California, and designed by Paul MacCready, an engineer from the same state.

description: Incoming

description: VIENNA, June 16  Leonid I. Brezhnev's spokesman said today that prognoses about the Soviet leader's health, slurred speech and lack of stamina published in the western press were nothing but speculation.

title: GARDENING A New Variety of County Agent
description: YEARS ago, in the good old days, when a farmer had a problem with his field crops or dairy herd he would ask his county agent for some help. If the agent was not too busy he would often drop by the farm, have a friendly visit over the fence, maybe even a cup of coffee. Time was easy then and the doling out of helpful information was relaxed and generous.

title: Hazardous Waste Disposal Lags
description: ALBANY, June 15  Thirty percent of the more than one million tons of hazardous waste produced in New York State each year is not properly disposed of, according to a survey released today by the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Cable Television: Boon or Bane For Sports?
description: ON a typical summer night, cabletelevision subscriber in upper Manhattan spins the dial. The Mets are on Channel 9 and the Yankees on 11. The Philadelphia Phi!lies are on Channel I, followed by the Atlanta Braves in a West Coast game, and the Boston Red Sox are on Channel F. The same Telenromnter subscriber, who pays a basic fee of $10 a month, sees Knick and Ranger home games during the winter months, along with selected Net and Islander games. In the near future, Teleprompter may offer games from Chicago and San Francisco and an additional sports channel for $4.95 a month.

title: Malaysia Is Said to Drop Plan to Fire on Refugees
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 16  The principal United Nations refugee official in Malaysia said today that he had been assured by authorities there that Malay, sia did not plan to shoot arriving Vietnamese refugees or push those already in camps back out to sea.

title: James Gleick Weds Cynthia Crossen
description: Cynthia Crossen, managing editor of The American Lawyer, and James Gleick, an editor on the metropolitan desk of The New York Times, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Judge Burton S. Sherman of the Civil Court in the Manhattan home of the bridegroom's parents, Donen and Beth Y. Gleick.

title: Headliners
description: among tne 81 west German representatives in the newly elected European Parliament, one will stand out whether tries to or not. He is Otto von Hapsburg, eldest son of the last Austrian emperor and a panEuropean propagandist of long standing. Mr. von Hapsburg, who became a German citizen only last year, was elected on the slate of the conservative Bavarian Christian Social Union Party. He is presumably the first Hapsburg to run for office since 1792, when his greatgreat-great-grandfather, Francis II, won the last election of Holy Roman Emperor. Francis election was fixed, but his descendant won fair and square.

title: Catherine Oliva to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent V. The future bride is a member of the class of 80 at Vassar College. Mr. Lebowitz, who graduated from the New York Institute of Technology, is With Stanley B. Bell & Company, member of the New York Commodities Exehange.

Astrue of Milton, Mass. The Rev. Andrew Fiddler performed the ceremony.

description: WASHINGTON, June 16  So many refugees are now fleeing Indochina that the exodus has become one of the most serious and tragic since World War II, a human and logistical problem that is severely straining the patience and resources of sympathetic nations.

title: MARGUERITE K. PRIMERANO
description: Marguerite K. Primerano, who had been night supervisor of nurses at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and at the Sloan Hospital for Women before her retirement in 1976, died Thursday at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. Mrs. Primerano, who lived at 720 Baldwin Place in Mamaroneck, N.Y., was 66 years old.

title: Correction
description: In John Irving's review of The Living End by Stanley Elkin (June 10), a sentence was garbled because of a technical error. The sentence should have read: His [Mr. Elkin's] descriptions of hell lose nothing by comparison to those of Bosch, Brueghel and Dante; Elkin's heaven is infuriating in its treachery, its deception, its rarefied air of phony goodness.

title: Jazz: James (Blood) Ulmer
description: The James (Blood) Ulmer quartet, which has been attracting a great deal of attention at the Tin Palace, moved a few blocks uptown for a concert at the Public Theater on Friday night. Mr. Ulmer, an electric guitarist, has been associated with Ornette Coleman for several years now, and his group's music reflects the impact of Mr. Coleman's harmolodic theory.

title: DINING OUT Updated Versions of the Steak Barn
description: THE most popular kind of restaurant in New Jersey, as elsewhere, is the American surf and turf barn, a current version of the old steak barn that provides a standardized menu at relatively low prices. It also aims to provide edible items for the whole family, fair value in drinks, fast service, funny things to look at and folksy entertainment for those who want it.

title: Rhodesia Votes Show Congress Is 2 Houses, Divided
description: Playing a losing hand shrewdly, the White House bounced triumphantly back last week from an apparent defeat on Zimbabwe Rhodesia. First, the Senate voted for an amendment that would have forced President Carter to lift sanctions. But his aides made much of the narrowness of the 52-to-41 vote, noting that opponents lacked the sufficient twothirds strength to override a threatened veto.

title: Truckers Meet at White House
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  Representative.s of some independent truckers said at a White House meeting today that they welcomed the new Interstate Commerce Commission regulation that gives them higher payments to meet increased diesel fuel costs, but they demanded assurances that the fuel would be in greater supply, Carter Administration officials said.

title: Author's Query
description: For a comprehensive biography of music critic Lawrence Gilman (18781939), I would appreciate hearing from his friends, associates or relatives who would be willing to share reminiscences and provide access to correspondence, diaries and manuscripts bearing upon his career as author, critic, composer and radio personality.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Gold of Roslyn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Minette Susan Gold, to Dr. Frederick N. Herman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris M. Herman of Miami. A November wedding is planned.

description: Edith Ellen Morrison and Dr. Christopher Jeffrey Morren were married yesterday at the Grace Episcopal Church in City Island, the Bronx. The Rev. Richard Smith performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Willard Bicket.

title: Other Regional Events
description: The police said it resulted from a lover's quarrel, but it was heavy with political implications. John Flynn, former supervisor of the scandalridden Southwest Sewer District in Suffolk County, was found stabbed to death Friday morning in the home of Sue A. Quinn, a former employe with whom he had been living. Mr. Flynn's death came a few hours before he was to be arraigned on charges involving doublebilling for equipment for the county's environmental control laboratory. Mrs. Quinn, who heads the laboratory, had testified before the grand jury that indicted Mr. Flynn.

title: Abby Aldrich, Banker, Bride Of David Gray
description: Abby P. Aldrich, an assistant treasurer and a financial analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank, and David M. Gray, a member of the class of 80 at thewliarvard Graduate School of Business Administration, plan to be married Aug. 18.

title: Casablanca, A Jumper, Takes Title
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 16  There was a time not long ago when Betsie Bolger had the uneasy feeling that she was spending more time on the ground than riding her jumper, Casablanca.

title: S.J. Poritz to Wed Diane Segal

Miss Segal teaches at the Bement School in Deerfield, Mass., and her fianc teaches art education at Skidmore College. A July 25 wedding is planned in Skaneateles.

title: Law Firm Plans Separate Inquiry Into Harrisburg Nuclear Accident

Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, expressed mutual desire at the opening of their summit conference here today to continue efforts to control nuclear arms. They agreed, in words attributed to Mr. Brezhnev, that God will not forgive us if we fail.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: One of the few known specimens of the Roosevelt/ SaintGaudens MCMVII $20 gold coins in extremely high relief will be auctioned on Friday. A similar coin sold in 1974 set an auction record of $200,000. The sale will take place at Stack's Coins Dealers, 123 West 57th Street, New York.
