description: To the Editor:

title: Events Today
description: Fifth Annual Std Street Festival: Food, music, entertainment, arts and crafts, book fair, antiques; 11 A.M. to P.M.; 52d Street from First Avenue to Ninth Avenue.

title: Official Says Bosworth Is Planning to Resign From Inflation Panel
description: Special to The New York Thews

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Greeks, Now Europeans
description: ATHENS  On June 25 the Greek Parliament will be the first to ratify the treaty of Greece's accession to the European Economic Community, and the other nine European parliaments are expected to follow suit within the year

title: Robert Arthur O'Brien Marries Carolyn Rogers
description: Carolyn Candace Rogers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Armistead Courtenay Rogers of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Arthur O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur O'Brien of Houston. Msgr. Francis X. McGuire performed the ceremony in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church. The bride, who served with VISTA in Illabun County, Ga., is an alumna of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Conn., and Skidmore College. She has a master's degree from the University of Chicago, where her husband received a Master of Business Administration.

title: Difficult Journeys
description: THE title is misleading. Eleanor Munro writes about Americas women artists not because they are American (as Gertrude Stein or Clement Greenberg might have done), and not really because they are women, except insofar as their being women helps her discover what she is looking for: some defini-

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: SOME of the campaign strata gists for Ronald Reagan, including John. P. Sears, the na tional campaign manager, and Senator Richard Schweicker of Pennsylvania, were at the State Capitol last Monday to announce the names of some 300 Connecticut Republicans who were supportingthe former California Governor's bid for the party's Presidential nomination.

title: Mime: Body
description: Dramatic situation rather than physical dexterity is the governing ingredient in the mimedramas of Claude Kipnis. The situations or precise activities enacted in a program by the Claude Kipnis Mime Theater on Friday at race university's Schimmel Center were often unclear. But several vignettes in Mr. Kipnis's new The Body came through clearly and hilariously.

title: FINLAND CONSIDERS POSTKEKKONEN ERA
description: Concern Mounting Over Question Of Who Will Be His Successor As Age Begins to Show

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: State Audit Finds Laxity In Drunken Driver Cases
description: ALBANY, June 16 (UPI)  The State Department of Motor Vehicles cannot effectively deal with the problem of drunken drivers if courts continue to reduce alcoholrelated charges to lesser offenses, a legislative audit said today.

title: Gwynne MacColl Becomes a Bride
description: Gwynne MacColl and Douglas Camp. bell 3d, both of Charlottesville, Va., were married yesterday afternoon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, Mass., by the bride's uncle, the Rev. Dr. James R. MacColl 3d, rector of St. Andrews Episcopal Church in Wellesley, Mass.

title: Delayed Alarm Said to Have Let Macy's Fire Grow
description: At least seven minutes and possibly as many as 13 minutes elapsed before the Fire Department was called Thursday to battle the blaze that killed a fireman, injured 19 other people and routed thousands of shoppers at Macy's Herald Square department store, store officials and fire authorities disclosed yesterday.

title: THEATER Westport: Offstage Tales
description: WESTPORT

title: SHOCKING THE DEPRESSED BACK TO LIFE
description: Despite its reputation as a weapon of the mad scientist, electricshock therapy is now frequently used, with carefully refined techniques, for a variety of mental disorders, such as severe depression or passive suicide.

title: ART
description: NEW CANAAN

title: Strategy Against Shrinking Enrollment
description: EVERY school district should force itself to the kind of selfexamination we're going through, said Donald Ryan, president of the White Plains school board.

title: New Laws for Old: Congress Designs an Antiquities Act to Suit Modern Times
description: They're known as pothunters and  alas! their vandal tribe increases. With eyes on the growing international market for American Indian artifacts  pottery, baskets, masks, weapons, tools, rock paintings and carvings  they wreak havoc on prehistoric sites, digging up burial grounds, bulldozing ruins, scattering relics. According to archaeologists, they are destroying an irreplaceable legacy. But if a bill now under consideration in the Congress passes, it would put a dent in potprofiteering.

title: Europe Watches, Relieved but Edgy
description: WASHINGTON  As Jimmy Carter arrived in Vienna this weekend to sign a strategic arms treaty with Leonid I. Brezhnev, America's allies in Western Europe watched nervously from the sidelines.

title: America at the Edge of a Wrenching Transition
description: WASHINGTON  A country's life, like that of a person, is written in chapters. Eras begin, take sudden twists, turn and end, sometimes unexpectedly. Each has a mix of problems and advantages.

title: Nuclear Waste: State Moves To Regulate Transportation
description: TRENTON

title: Miss Baldwin Becomes Bride Of Jerry Fall
description: Deborah Gay Baldwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. B. Baldwin of New Vernon, N.J., and Bridgehampton, Li., was married yesterday afternoon to Jerry Fall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry J. Fall of Riverdale, the Bronx. me ReV. John F. Corr performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon.

title: Garbage: Sorting Out the Options
description: ONE part of the solution to Connecticut's garbage problem was not mentioned in Diane Henry's June 3 article [For the Garbage Problem, No Magic Solution]: Reduce the amount of garbage generated.

title: Hedges That Flower Are a Different Kind Of Screening
description: Ahedge doesn't have to be privet. Why settle for dull green when, for at least few weeks each year, you can have brilliant gold, shimmering coral or cascades of snowy white? Dozens of flowering shrubs make fine hedges. Some even have at- tractive berries or colorful foliage. A few even produce edible fruit.

title: The Daytons of Dayton Hudson
description: MINNEAPOLIS  No surprises says sign prominently displayed on the desk of William Andres, chief executive officer of the Dayton Hudson Corporation. The same message is conspicuously displayed on other desktops throughout the company's headquarters here as a reminder of management's commitment to minimize the unexpected in the often frantic world of retailing.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT was a rainy Sunday and the subject under discussion was: where to go to eat. This is a subject on which Long Islanders must spend astronomical totals of man/woman hours thrashing out. I have known cases where the decisionmaking process ran longer than the eating process. Once it ran right through the dinner hour and we ended up snacking from the icebox.

title: Opera at GlyndebourneAn Elitist Treat
description: Quintessentially British and unashamedly elitist, Glyndebourne is a real music festival in every sense of the word. Its physical setting, on a 16 century Tudor estate in the rolling pastoral county of Sussex in soutnern England, is uniquely beauti ful. The repertory each summer focuses primarily on works that are either rarely performed or too difficult for the average opera house to prepare adequately during a busy winter season. Thanks to its relative isolation from the welltraveled European festival circuit, Glyndebourne can count on the full atention of its handpicked artists.- every production receives the kind of intensive rehearsal and polishing that quite literally defines the term festival conditions.

title: IN THE NATION Carter and Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  A good political fight at the Presidential level is like a heavyweight championship bout  it gets more headlines than it may deserve and promises more action than it may deliver. And everyone seems to enjoy the spectacle, no matter how senseless.

title: Judith Landon, Dancer, Bride
description: Judith Arm Landon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gardner Fairlamb Landon of Delray Beach, Fla., and Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Anthony Andre Tron, son of Joan Tron Ruggles of Washington and Rene A. Tron of Arlington, Va. The Rev. David Stewart Hoag performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Parish of Christ the Redeemer in Pelham Manor.

title: U.S. Allies Have 3 Concerns on Treaty
description: VIENNA, June 16  America's NATO allies will receive the text of the strategic arms treaty and accompanying documents for the first time on Tuesday, United States officials said here today.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Applause, musical by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, starring Deborah Nielson. Wednesday to Saturday 8:30 P.M., Sundays 8 P.M. Through July 1.: $5.50 to $7.50. Discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Country Cabaret, with entertainment and crepe kitchen, featured Friday and Saturday, after show. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Route 6 and 118. 6281169.

title: Miss Caldwell Is the Fiance Of Engineer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Caldwell of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dsire Branch Caldwell, to William Fiank Armitage Jr. of Burlington, Mass. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Armitage of Hamilton Square, N.J. A July 14 wedding is planned.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS All for an Entertaining Summer
description: THE ISLAND will be a summer festival this year. From Floral Park to Montauk, all within a few gallons of gas from home, there will be a full schedule of entertainment that could keep Long Islanders on the eo every night in the week.

title: The CorporateRelocation Merry-Go-Round Slows
description: AFTER moving six times in 20 years, C. Boardman Thompson 2d of Wilton decided he had had enough. He was growing older, and the thought of spending the remaining years of his career on the corporate carrousel relocating every three or four years no longer appealed to him, despite the incentives offered.

title: Britain Makes a Quick. Right Turn
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's new Government wheeled out drastic cure for the British disease of highcost, lowproductivity economic hemorrhaging last week. The proposed Tory budget puts pounds sterling in the pockets of highincome taxpayers, cuts Government spending and raises sales taxes to make worthwhile to work.

title: Hearing for Polygamist Leader
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 16 (AP) Ervil LeBaron, a polygamist leader, has been scheduled for a twoday preliminary hearing on murder and conspiracy charges beginning July 12 in Fifth Circuit Court. Mr. LeBaron, 54-year-old head of the Church of the Lamb of God, was arraigned Tuesday and charged with homicide.

title: Affable Mullah Rules Iranian Town With Wide Authority
description: ZORABAD, Iran, June 14  The facade of the former military governor's compound here still looks as forbidding as it did when the Shah was in power: a concrete wan topped by rolls of barbed wire, a metal;door guarded by men with Machine guns, and army vehicles lined up along the periphery.

title: Abrams's Grandmother Dies
description: Ida Abramowitz, the grandmother of Robert Abrams, the State Attorney General, died Friday in a nursing home in the Bronx. Mrs. Abramowitz, who had lived for many years in the Pelham Bay section of the Bronx, was 96 years old. She was born in Minsk, Russia, and came to this country in 1900. She is survived by two sons and two daughters.

title: MUSIC Caramoor Season
description: LAST night was the gala opening of the Caramoor season, in Katonah, and it's good to have this celebrated summer festival with us again. Here, of course, is one of the most gorgeous concert sites in the country, linked to a long tradition of innovative programming and appearances by major international personalities.

title: HOME CLINIC Sealing a Blacktop Driveway to Insure Long Life
description: BLACKTOP driveways will last for a great many years if they have been properly installed  and if they are properly maintained by the homeowner.

title: Light at the End of the Pipeline
description: For the past five years, OPEC has been making American energy policy because America wouldn't make its own. But there's reason to hope now that this country's political stalemate, which has allowed the drift toward ever greater dependence on Arab oil, may be broken.

title: SPORTS Olympic Classic
description: PISCATAWAY

title: THE MUPPET MOVIEKermit, Miss Piggy and the rest of Jim Henson's puppets are joined by live stars in cameo appearances in a film directed by James Frawley. It opens at the Ziegfeld on Friday.
description: THE MAIN EVENTBarbra Streisand I masterminds the comeback of boxer Ryan O'Neal in a romantic comedy directed by Howard Zieff. The film opens at the Sutton, Murray Hill, Embassy 1 and Embassy 72d Street on Friday.

title: HOME CLINIC Sealing a Blacktop Driveway to Insure Long Life
description: BLACKTOP driveways will last for a great many years if they have been properly installed  and if they are properly maintained by the homeowner.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: The Chinese Admit Hard Times Persist
description: For 30 years, many outsiders thought that China was the shining example of the Communist future that worked. The Chinese knew better, but why should they ruin their reputation? Last week an appraisal by Peking's senior economic policymakers published in Hong Kong reported the latest truth  a surprisingly frank new admission of failure.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE CARMEN MIRANDA MEMORIAL FLAG- POLE, by Gerald Rosen. (Avon, $3.95.) An accountant and a novelist, twin brothers scarred by the Vietnam War, move from New York to begin new lives in northern California. What follows is  according to our re-

title: The Nation
description: For those convinced that history repeats itself, the week's economic reports produced sinking sensations.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Seeing Through Period Glass Fakery

title: N.B.A. Heads Select Their Dream Fives
description: PAT WILLIAMS, the general manager of the Philadelphia 76ers, was asked to select five players to start an expansion franchise. He failed to select Julius Erving, the 76ers forward and one of the National Basketball Association's most exciting players. Carl Scheer, the president and general manager of the Denver Nuggets, was asked the question and left off George McGinnis, his highscoring forward. Frank Layden, the general manager of the Utah Jazz, did not include his own Pete Maravich, one of the game's top scorers.

title: JETS TO BE REMOVED FROM SKYLAB'S PATH
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI)  In an extraordinary safety move, the Federal Aviation Administration plans to order commercial airliners out of the area where the Skylab space station is expected to fall to earth next month.

title: W.A. Slivka, Miss Citron Are Married
description: Alisande Lemaire Citron, daughter of Mrs. John Harmon Noble Jr. of Pasadena, Calif., and Essex, N.Y., and Casper Henry Citron of New York and North Salem, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Alan Slivka, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Slivka of Cleveland. The Rev. Daniel Miner performed the ceremony in St. Matthews Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Recordings
description: Without doubt, the Crickets are the loud- est, noisiest trio I've ever heard in my life, a reviewer from New Musical Express complained when Buddy Holly and his band made their first and only tour of England in 1958. How these boys manage to make

title: Nancy Mulford Married To Douglas Lloyd Burrill
description: The Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Nancy M. Mulford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Mulford of Bryn Mawr, to Douglas Lloyd Burrill of San Francisco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Lloyd Burrill of Portola Valley, Calif. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Timothy Pickering.

title: Overskate Is Victor; Wa.y a 2d
description: Dave Whiteley moved his'magic act from the dirt to the grass yesterday at Belmont Park, but the 33-year-old trainer's latest trick fell apart.

title: Mailbox: Don't Take Him Out to the Ball Game
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: F.D.A. CHIEF HEADING FOR LESS TRYING JOB
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  Dr. Donald Kennedy, head of the Food and Drug Administration .for the last two years, is to return, to Ihe tranquillity of a college campus atahe end of the month ,after being a sitting target for food and health faddists and the powerful drug and farm lobbies and after losing. almost every Policy battle in which he has engaged.

title: 4 Themes Knit Newport Jazz Festival
description: The centerpieces of this year's Newport Jazz Festival will be four theme productions, one of which will celebrate the contributions of black performers to Broadway during thefirst half of this century. The three others will be built around Hoagy Carmichael, the songwriter and singer; Billie Holiday and a panorama`of American popular songs.

title: THE MARKETS Prime Rate Cut Buoys Trading
description: The stock market, buoyed by a cut in the prime lending rate, advanced moderately last week heavy trading. It was also a week, however, that saw the nation's money supply surge to a record level.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: HIS is the time of year when Michael J. Ferro Jr., a lawyer in Hackensack, runs away to sea in his 37-foot-long sports_fishing boat. He holds papers as a licensed fishing captain and prefers the shorts, windbreaker and deck shoes of the seagoing set to the vested suits complete with a gold watch chain and a Penn Relays medal  that he usually wears when practicing law.

title: Photographer in the Assembly Won't Let Sleepy Members Lie
description: ALBANY, June 16  As several legislators began dozing off in.the Assembly chamber late last night, Daniel B. Walsh, the Assembly majority leader, rose to make an unusual introduction.

title: Buffalo Seeks a Review Of School-Bias Decision
description: BUFFALO, June 16  Reacting to Federal Court order scrapping large portions of the racial integration program for Buffalo's public schools, the city's Board of Education has asked for reconsideration of the order and a public meeting with the judge who wrote it.

title: Sanitation Unit Head Releases New Listing Of Dumping Violators
description: As part of a program instituted last month to cut back on illegal dumping in New York City, Norman Steisel, the city's Sanitation Commissioner, last week released a second list of violators of the citv's dumoine laws.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area

title: Lopez Stops Ayala and Retains Title
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 17 (UPI)  Danhy (Little Red) Lopez caught the No. 1 challenger, Mike (El Cyclone) Ayala, with a left hook In the 15th round today to score a knockout and retain his World Boxing  Council featherweight title.

title: Jury Due in Texas Murders
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 17 (AP)  A jury is expected to be sworn tomorrow for the retrial of Elmer Wayne Henley, charged with killing six youths in homosexual torture ring. Mr. Henley, 23 years old, was convicted in 1974 and sentenced to six consecutive 99year prison terms, but he was granted a new trial last year on grounds that a changeofvenue request had been improperly denied. The charges arose from the murder of 26 persons in Houston in the early 1970's.

title: Deaths
description: HARTZGeorge E. of Summit, N.J. formerly of Glen Ridge on June 16, 1979. Husband of Helen Quade Hartz, father of George E. Hartz Jr., and Mrs. Dorothy Robinson. Grandfather of eight grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Relafives and friends are invited to atfend a memorial service in Central Presbyterian Church, Summit, Tuesday at 4 PM. Should friends desire contributions may be made to the Memorial Fund, Central Presbyterian Church or Summit First Aid Squad.

title: Martin Is Called Back As Yankees' Manager
description: George Steinbrenner, owner of the New York Yankees, and Billy Martin, the team's former manager, met secretly in Columbus, Ohio, yesterday and Martin was renamed manager.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: The New York Rangers unusual feat of scoring two opennet goals, in the final game of their playoff series against the Philadelphia Flyers last April, does not appear to have drawn much comment. Has it ever been done before?

title: Draths
description: LESSERAlex S. Beloved husband of Matilda. Devoted father of Barbara and Peter Scher, David and Fran Lesser. Loving grandfather of Amy and Allison, dear brother of the late Abraham. Services Tuesday, June 19, 1:30PM, Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapels, Queens Blvd. & 76 Rd, Forest Hills.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, which had marched confidently ahead for five straight weeks, became confused late last week after the Federal Reserve reported a record surge in the money sup, ply and a strong gain in industrial production in May. After the figures were released, the debate over the outlook for interest rates seemed to get louder, but not clearer.

title: Chess:
description: How does one loaf through a tournament and still take first prize?  that's a secret known only to Ulf Andersson, the Swedish grandmaster.

title: LOST FARM LAND USE PROMPTS U.S STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  Each year more than 3 million acres of this nation's farm land are lost to development, and Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland announced last week that the Federal Government would undertake an 18month study to see what remedies Washington might apply.

title: Increase in Postal Rates Forecast for April 1981
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)  Another rise in postal rates is likely in the spring of 1981, even though the Postal Service expects to have a surplus this year for the first time in three decades, Postmaster General William F. Bolger says.

title: ESSAY Stumbling At the Summit
description: VIENNA  Once again, the leader of the Soviet Union stumbled in public, and was aided this time by the President of the United States. The moment was awaited with macabre fascination by 2,000 reporters and pundits avid for signs of either man's physical or political weakness.

title: Growth in Population Dropping Worldwide, But Problems Remain
description: The world's populationgrowth rate continued to decline last year and there is a definite trend toward smaller families in both industrial countries and many developing nations, according to a report prepared by the United Nations Fund for Population Activities.

title: Miss Blalock Wins
description: ROCHESTER, June 17 (A1)  Jane Blalock shot a oneunderpar 72 today to run away With her fourth Ladies Professional Golf Association victory this year, winning by six strokes from Alice Ritzman.

title: AT HOME ABROAD A Very Small Missile
description: LONDON, June 17  The road to the Vienna summit has been so long, the argument about strategic arms limitation so often abstruse, that we are in danger of forgetting the fundamental reason Jimmy Carter and Leonid Brezhnev are there. We may be losing sight of the reality that underlies all the acronyms and statistics of the SALT debate.

title: Carter Speech Tonight Is Being Broadcast Live
description: President Carter's address tonight before a joint session of Congress will be broadcast live by the television networks and their affiliated radio networks and by the Public Broadcasting Service, National Public Radio and the Mutual Broadcasting System.

title: TV SPORTS
description: 9:00 (31)German soccer (tape)

title: Frank Mason, 86, Former Official Of News Service and Later NBC
description: LEESBURG, Va., June 17 (UPI)Frank Earl Mason, who served as president of the International News Service in the 1920's and was a vice president of NBC for 14 years, died in his sleep last night. He was 86 years old.

title: Eric Jacobson, Photographer, Marries Bonnie Lynn Segal
description: Bonnie Lynn Segal, daughter of Mrs. Bob Shepard of Bronxville, N.Y., and Wilmington, Vt., was married yesterday to Eric Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Jacobson of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi David W. Gordon performed the ceremony at the Vermont home of the bride's mother and stepfather. The bride is a daughter also of the late Jacques Segal.

title: Leverett Saltonstall Is Dead at 86; Revived the Massachusetts G.O.P.
description: DOVER, Mass., June 17 (AP)  Leverett Saltonstall, who served 22 years in the United States Senate and occupied a seat of power in Massachusetts politics for more than four decades, died today at his Dover home. He was 86 years old.

title: Valerie Fischer Is Wed to Lars BangJensen
description: The marriage of Valerie Bree Fischer, who teaches sixth grade at the Riverdale Country School, to Lam BangJensen, a lawyer with the New York firm of Shearman & Sterling, took place yesterday at the Amherst (Mass.) Women's Club. The Rev. Laverve Anderson, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony, which he described as a civil one.

title: Savona Dale: The Fantastic Filly of Calumet Farm
description: ELMONT, L.I. CROUCHING in the saddle, the filly's English exercise rider talks to her soothingly as they begin the earlymorning jog. Steady, girl, croons Graham Bell. Whoa, girl. The filly's ears are up, and they wiggle back and forth as she listens to the exercise rider. Easy, Big Debbie. She relaxes and moves slowly along the outer rail at Belmont Park, past the infield grave where Ruffian is buried.

title: Ireland's Birth Control Bill Stirs Rancorous Debate
description: DUBLIN  Legislation to permit the sale of contraceptives in Ireland has started a rancorous national debate.

title: California's Supreme Court: How a Model For Nation Became Target of Investigators
description: Once the California Supreme Court was considered the premier state court in the country. But, its national standing has been slipping year by year, slipping rapidly since last fall, under the weight, of series of personnel changes, a highly News AnalysIs charged political atmosphere, an unwieldy caseload and infighting among the Judges.

title: BLACKS IN MARYLAND SET POLITICAL GOALS
description: BALTIMORE, June 17  The Maryland Black People's Assembly, a prototypical political convention that the Congressional Black Caucus wants to see repeated in black communities around the nation, ended its weekend meeting here today with a recommendation for a blockbyblock drive to register black voters.

title: Peter Sherman, Lawyer, Weds Jo Ann Ferdinand
description: At the Kane Street Synagogue in Brooklyn yesterday, Jo Ann Ferdinand, an assistant commissioner with the New York City Department of Sanitation, was married to Peter Sherman, an associate with the New York law firm of Migdal, Tenney, Glass & Pollack. Rabbi Howard Gorin performed the ceremony.

title: Erskine Scores Jersey Tennis Upset
description: KEARNY, N.J., June 17  Ron Erskine of Glen Ridge, N.J., upset eighthseeded Terrence Jackson of Plainfield, N.J., 75, 60, today in the second round of the New Jersey State men's singles championship at the Arlington Players Club.

title: Ghana's Military Rulers May Yield Control Soon
description: ACCRA, Ghana, June 17 (Reuters)  Ghana's new military rulers say they might be prepared to hand over power before Oct. 1 to the new civilian Government being elected tomorrow, they felt it would pursue the drive against corruption.

title: Motorists Endure Driest Sunday Since Start of Gas Crisis
description: Police officials in the New York metropolitan area said that yesterday was the worst Sunday for motorists trying to buy gasoline since the current crisis began two months ago.

title: Alydar Victor
description: Alydar served notice yesterday at Belmont Park that he is still one of the thoroughbred leaders in the handicap division.

title: Theater: Americas Festival Opens
description: TWO vastly different works have opened the Theater in the Americas Festival in New York. Each in its own way accomplishes what a festival play should do: showing us something we do not know and can benefit from.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. (RaclioWMCA, WGBB, 8:30 P.M.)

title: Martin and Yankees: Tumultuous Kinship
description: As they have several other times in their fiery relationship, Billy Martin and George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner and the volatile former infielder, have apparently again come to an agreement.

title: Dynamite Finder Takes It Home
description: A Manhattan man found a stick of dynamite in Riverside Park Sunday and brought it up to his West Side apartment before calling authorities who carted it away, the police said. They said that the unidentified man, who lives at 254 West 72d Street, apparently brought the dynamite to his home to keep it out of the hands of children.

title: Thousands of Ugandans Flee to the Sudan
description: NIMULE, the Sudan  A Ugandan came across the wooden bridge into this Sudanese border town a few weeks ago with a spear stuck in his back.

title: Last Week's Active Issues
description: Price and Volume

title: Technology Sales Rules Under Fire
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  The Carter Administration's system for controlling exports to the Soviet Union is suddenly under fire. Businessmen and politicians complain that it is too cumbersome, and securityminded Government officials fear that it has failed to keep American equipment from being used for military purposes.

title: Oil Output Lag Cited by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, June 17 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union's oil production has fallen well behind target for this year, giving cause for alarm, an official newspaper said yesterday.

title: Chinese Parliament to Meet
description: PEKING, June 17 (Reuters)  China's Parliament is scheduled to meet tomorrow for the first time in 16 months to approve several new senior government posts and changes in the country's local government and legal systems.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. ScherzoValse, Chabrier; Trio Sonata No. 2, Sammartini ; Piano Quartet No. 1, Brahms; Excerpt from the Anna Magdalena Notebook, Bach.

title: Commodities
description: UPWARD pressure on wheat prices, which had been quietly gathering force since early spring, finally exploded last week, sending grain and soybean futures skyward. Left shattered by the price explosion were hopes for a slower rise in food costs and the rate of inflation.

title: Col. Charles B. Millican, ExChief Editor in Army
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  Col. Charles B. Millican, U.S.A., retired, who served as chief editor of Army Intelligence publications in World War H, died today at Walter Reed Army Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: WNBCTV Leaves Show Of N.Y. Emmy Awards
description: WNBCTV has withdrawn from the annual New Yorkarea Emmy Awards presentations. The awards are given each year by the New York chapter of the Television Academy of Arts and Sciences.

title: Around the Nation
description: In an apparent effort to hold back trucking shutdown, the White House yesterday invited representatives from newly formed coalition of Independent truckers to discuss problems that have led to a nationwide protest marked with scattered sniping incidents.

title: News Summary
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev warned the U.S. that the strategic arms limitation treaty, which is to be signed today, could collapse if it is amended during the ratification process in Congress. Changes in the treaty, he said at a dinner for President Carter at the Soviet Embassy in Vienna, would have grave and even dangerous consequences for our relations and for the situation in the world as a whole. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Hispanic. Group Chooses Texas Lawyer as Leader
description: HOUSTON, June 17  The League of United Latin American Citizens, the nation's oldest, largest and most conservative Hispanicrights group, moved to shed its establishment image today by electing as its president an outspoken Texas lawyer who vowed to extend the organization's influence into the external political world.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: David C. Farrell, president of the May Department Stores Company, has been elected chief executive officer. He succeeds David E. Babcock, who will continue as chairman until his retirement at the age of 65 next April.

title: Hale Irwin's Sleepless Night
description: TOLEDO, OHIO FIVE years ago Hale Irwin dreamed that he would win the United States Open championship that week Winged Foot  and he did. But Saturday night he did not dream. He hardly even slept. Maybe a couple hours, he was saying now. Just a few winks. And perhaps that is the difference between winning the Open for the first time and then for the second time. The first time, a golfer dreams of winning it. The second time, a golfer cannot sleep because he's hoping he won't lose it. At Inverness yesterday Hale Irwin did not lose It in the swirling winds that blew his score to a fouroverpar 75 for a 72hole total of even par 284, two strokes better than both Jerry Pate and Gary Player.

title: Humm, 60, Is Oldest L.I. Amateur Victor
description: SANDS POINT, L.I., June 17  FortpOne years older, nearly 100 pounds heavier,. and tiring Visibly with each rainsplashed hole, John Humm struck a blovi. for the older generation today by outlasting, John Mattiace for the Long Island amateur golf championship.

title: Jazz: Salute to Parker and Young
description: ATRIBUTE to Charlie Parker and Lester Young at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon could, in less imaginative hands, have been just another rehash of the recorded solos of Mr. Parker and Mr. Young. But it was even more interesting as a stimulating conjunction of young, promising musicians and a variety of experienced older hands.

title: Tigers Win for Anderson
description: DETROIT, June 17 (AP)  Jason Thompson's basesloaded single in the eighth inning broke a 44 tie and led Detroit to an 84 victory over the California Angels today, giving Manager Sparky Anderson his first American League triumph after three losses.

title: Sports Briefs
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 17  Jet Run, who once competed for Mexico, won the $10,000added SkoalHappy Days GrandrPrix today at the closing session of the 50th edition of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show.

title: Billy the Kid Rides Again
description: THE question was: what happened to George M. Steinbrenner 3d? Had he lost the power of speech or had we all gone deaf? Here were the Yankees running fourth in the American League East, seven games from the top, and not a squawk out of their proprietor. No leaked stories that the manager's job was in jeopardy. never was like this in Billy Martin's time.

title: New York Appears Leading Choice For 1980 Democratic Convention
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  New York appears to be the leading contender for the 1980 Democratic National Convention, according to leaders in the party, with assurance of support for a major party fundraising dinner in the city this fall apparently the final step needed to clinch the deal.

title: 43 Concerns Cited For Aid to the Arts
description: Gifts of a fleet of 30 trailers and grants for research, public television programs, dance companies here and abroad as well as help for a variety of other cultural activities brought Business in the Arts awards for outstanding programs in support of the arts during 1978. to 43 United States companies.

title: Woman in Steel: Drive for Equality
description: CHICAGO, June 14 Alice Peurala has been fighting with her supervisors at the United States Steel Corporation's South Works plant here since she became convinced that women employees were being relegated to deadend lobs.

title: The New York Times/Sara Krulwich
description: The American Airlines DC10 crash that claimed 273 lives has brought a bit of an increase to sales of flight insurance, that extra layer of death benefits purchased by uneasy air travelers on the way to the departure gate.

title: Carter's Objectives in Vienna
description: VIENNA, June 17  Relaxing on the flight here from the United States, President Carter fell to talking with his aides about charges made by Senator Henry M. Jackson, the Washington Democrat, that Mr. Carter was guilty of appeasement of the Russians. Somebody mentioned that the weather in Vienna was overcast.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in Business Day on Friday that Eastern Air lines was withdrawing from some East Coast markets. It is National Airlines that is withdrawing.

title: McEnroe Gains
description: LONDON, June 17 (AP)  John McEnloe argued with an umpire for the second straight clay today, but quieted down and won two matches to reach the final of the $125,000 Stella Artois grass tennis tournament.

title: GOING OUTGUIDE
description: BLUE IN THE NIGHT Some acclaimed exponents of jazz are assembling tonight at the Village Gate in threesection marathon performance honoring the trumpeter Blue Mitchell, who died last month in Los Angeles. Proceeds from the jazz community's salute will go to the Mitchell family. Tickets for each of tonight's performances are $6.

title: Carter to Name Watson of To Be Ambassador to Soviet Union
description: VIENNA, June 17  President Carter will soon name Thomas J. Watson Jr., former chairman of the board of the International Business Machines Corporation, as Ambassador to Moscow, replacing a career diplomat, Malcolm Toon, State Department official said today.

title: Higher Profits In Japan
description: TOKYO, June 17 (Reuters)  A survey by the Tokyo Stock Exchange showed a total of 695 Japanese listed companies, excluding banks and insurance companies, reported an average increase of 24.5 percent in pretax profits in the fiscal year ended March 31.

title: C.I.A. Aide Says News Leaks in U.S Worry Allies
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  The problem of leaks of sensitive information to the press, is inherent in the American political system, but Frank C. Carlucci, the Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, says he believes leaks now are the, worst he has seen in 23 years of Governmeht service.

title: Robin Carol Rtunelt Married To Dr. Joel Jack Kassimir
description: Robin Carol Rumelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Rumelt of New City. N.Y., was married yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J., to Dr. Joel Jack Kassimir, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Kassimer of Lido Beach, LI. Rabbis Arnold A. Marans and Asher H. Abittan officiated.

title: Accord on 1st National Contract Reached by Teamsters and U.P.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)  The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the United Parcel Service announced today a tentative agreement on a threeyear contract covering 220 locals and 70,000 employees.

title: Dr. Judith Anne Forrest Bride
description: Dr. Judith Anne Forrest, a pediatric resident at St. Vincent's Hospital, was married yesterday to Dr. Joseph Gregory Throw, assistant professor df cornImunications at Purdue University. The ceremony was performed at the Bayside (Queens) Jewish Center by Rabbi William Orentlecher and Cantor Joseph Eidelson. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Forrest of the Bronx. Her husband's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Turow, live in Brooklyn. The bride expects to continue her residency at the James Whitcomb Riley Children's Hospital in Indianapolis.

title: Phenix City, Ala., Leaves Ashes of Sin in the Past
description: PHENIX CITY, Ala., June 17  In the late 1800's, while its neighbors up and down the Chattahoochee River valley were building respectable textile mills and fertilizer plants, Phenix City embraced sin instead.

title: Activist Neighborhood Groups Are Becoming a New Political Force
description: CHICAGO, June 14  A strong new political force  forged from the proliferating local activist organizations formed to stabilize and renew neighborhoods has grown to maturity in America. Through recent victories in Washington and across the country, this lobby is replacing traditional institutions that have lost their vigor or their credibility.

title: The Right Accent in Black English
description: A generation ago, a poor black girl who complained in class that Dis boy, he be boverin me was apt to be ridiculed by her teacher for slovenly speech or, worse, written off as illiterate. With the rise black consciousness in the 1960's, however, educators and linguists became embroiled in a spirited debate over whether black dialects should be recognized as unwritten languages, codified and even taught in school.

title: Protesters in West Bank Clash With Israeli Soldiers
description: JERUSALEM, June 17  Arab demonstrators clashed with Israeli soldiers in Nablus, the largest city in the West Bank, today in a protest against a new Jewish settlement on a nearby hill.

title: Market Place
description: HOW to get a piece of the commodity action without losing your shirt, said the headline in an advertisement for Comvest, a Massachusetts brokerage firm specializing in managed commodity accounts.

title: U.S. Drug Investigation Brings a Round of Arrests for Hell's Angels
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 16  For 29 years local law enforcement officers across California have concentrated on taming the Hell's Angels motorcycle club, only to watch it flourish.

title: ELENA CHESSIN PAULL
description: Elena Chessin Paull, a former patroness of the arts in Europe and Canada who was born in St. Petersburg, Russia, died yesterday at the Manhattan home of her daughter, Anna Gertler. Mrs. Paull, who lived in Hollywood, Fla., was 84 years old.

title: Queens Boy Is Killed When Father Shoots at 2 Robbers in Restaurant
description: The 8yearold son of a Queens restaurant owner died of a gunshot wound of the head early yesterday after his father opened fire during an attempted holdup of his ChineseAmerican restaurant late Saturday night.

title: The Lost Poodle
description: The Government banned all but the official celebration that Friday. Still there were rumors of possible rallies. My husband advised me not to wander far from the hotel. His office, like all activities, was closed but he was attending a meeting at the home of the local manager.

title: Bridge:
description: It often seems to the experts that the scales of justice need some mechanical repair, or even some oil. If the opposition goes completely off the rails in the bidding and reaches a ridiculous slam, a satisfying profit seems certain. But there are days when fortune favors the foolish.

title: Jacqueline Cohen Bride Of Jeffrey David Marcus
description: Jacqueline Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Cohen of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to Jeffrey David Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Marcus, also of Brooklyn. Rabbis Jacob Kassin and Zvulun Lieberman performed the ceremony at Temple BethE1.

title: The City
description: A Housing Authority policeman who was stabbed in the chest early yesterday escaped injury because he was wearing a bulletproof vest, according to a spokesman for the Housing Authority Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. The officer had purchased the vest himself, the spokesman said.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Big retailers reported a slowdown for May after unexpectedly strong sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter. Many now say they.cliscern a significant slowing in consumer spending, which could herald an economic downturn. [Page D1.]

title: City Ballet: 3 Faces of The Dance
description: AUDIENCES attending both the Saturday matinee and evening programs of the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater could have seen the season's first performances of three unusual works by George Balanchine: a ballet like a Renaissance ball, a ballet like calligraphy and a ballet like coloratura singing.

title: CityHospital Bill Collection Lags
description: It has been taking New York City's municipal hospitals an average of 129 days from the time they bill for patient care to collect outstanding fees, compared with 60 days for voluntary hospitals, according to the president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Treasury Issues Crowd Sale List
description: The Federal Government will be busy this week selling bills and notes each day from Monday through Thursday, and it may announce plans to make an offering of 15year bonds next week as well.

title: Dr. Susan C. Well Wed to Biochemist
description: Dr. Susan Caroline Well, daughter of Dr. Annemarie Well of New York and the late Dr. Frederic S. Weil, was married yesterday to Gideon Dreyfuss, son of Adina Dreyfuss of Tel Aviv and the late Prof. Fritz Dreyfuss. Rabbi Bernhard Cohn performed the ceremony at the Carlyle.

title: Weekend Ballooning Party Has an International Air
description: BALLEROY, France, June 17  Ballooning, once associated with such madcap adventurers as Phileas Fogg and Babar the Elephant, is well on its way to becoming the new glamor sport, judging from the assemblage of French aristocrats and wellheeled Americans here this weekend for the fifth annual International Invitational Balloon Meet.

title: Washington Watch
description: PRESIDENT Carter has not completely ruled out a tax cut for next year even though he still badly wants to send Congress a balanced budget in January. The spring budget review, just completed, concludes that he will not be able to do both.

title: TV. Women in Prison Studied bv Bill Movers
description: OVER the last several days, public television has visited major prison, Inside San Quentin, and a correction center for young adults, Tatooed Tears. In both cases, the inmates were men. Tonight, at 9 o'clock on WNET, Channel 13, the subject changes to women in trouble with the law.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLYCommittee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Getting Yourself Ready for the Maiathon
description: THREE weeks have passed since the New York Road Runners Club began taking applications for the New York Marathon in October. Fred Lebow, the club's president, had believed that, after last year's record field of 9,875, the rush to apply this year would pose a problem. He was light.

title: Carter, Kennedy and Health
description: The main entries in this year's debate over national health insurance are now in the field. Senator Kennedy proposes to provide, gradually, for comprehensive coverage for all Americans. President Carter would begin more modestly to cover catastrophic illnesses for all and the bills of the needy and aged. Senator Russell Long offers an even more limited measure, but he and the President appear to be moving toward compromise. So the conflict boils down to one between Mr. Carter and Mr. Kennedy.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Threeday latespring minicarnps for veteran National Football League players are now commonplace, but their origin  in replacing the illegal, camouflaged outofseason workouts that were held for decades  is relatively recent, and interesting. In fact, Terry Bledsoe, the Giants assistant general manager and once a member of the league's Management Council, believes that the minicamps can be traced directly to Ed Podolak's mustache.

title: Mayor of Norwalk Protests Financing of Suburb's Park
description: NORWALK, Conn.  Representatives of the seven wealthy communities surrounding this lessaffluent city have voted to use $1.7 million in Federal funds for a 32acre park in the heart of Westport's shopping district, despite the opposition of Mayor William A. Collins of Norwalk, who argued that the public money should be used to shoulder some small share of the the area's housing burden.

title: REBELS IN NICARAGUA NAME FIVE TO FORM PROVISIONAL JUNTA
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 17 Confident that their latest offensive to overthrow President Anastasio Somoza Debayle will soon succeed, Nicaragua's Sandinist guerrillas have announced the names of five opposition figures who are scheduled to form a provisional government.

title: Architecture: 4 Honor Buildings
description: IT takes a lot more than buildings to make a civilized urban envirmrnent, and that fact seems to have gotten through to the City Club of New York this year. Tomorrow evening, when the club presents its annual Albert S. Bard Awards for excellence in urban design, it will honor not just four buildings but also a law, pedestrian shelter and a lighting program. The Bard Awards, considered among the most prestigious architectural awards given in New York, have often gone to things other than buildings, but this is the, first time that Bard Award has been given to a piece of legislation.

title: Margaret Simons Is Married
description: Margaret Allison Simons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Simons of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gary David Egerman, a student at the University of Miami Law School. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Egerman of Yonkers. Rabbi Joseph H. Wise performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: A Parliament, of Sorts, for Europe
description: The European Community now has its first popularly elected Parliament. That fact, in itself, is far more important than the modest size of the vote that brought it into being, the conservative cast of its members and the limited powers they will have. After 21 years, the Common Market of nine nations has finally acquired electoral legitimacy.

title: An Air of Aloofness Covers Tensions in Crovvn Heights
description: It is a common scene along the shaded boulevard of Eastern Parkway in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn: blacks and bearded, darksuited Lubavitcher Hasidim strolling or hurrying past one another, rarely sharing a word or gesture of acknowledgment. Their aloofness apparently is not that of enemies, but rather of strangers who wish to remain uninvolved.

title: JACKSON PROPOSES RENEGOTIATING PACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, announced today that he planned to promote a Senate measure that would ask President Carter to renegotiate several aspects of the new strategic arms accord with the Soviet Union.

title: The New York Times/Joyce Dopkeen
description: Twoyearold Mary Kate and her father, Kenneth Burke, enjoyed Father's Day at a Buskers Day celebration at Wave Hill in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. What is a busker? Wave Hill residents definedthe word as a street performer, and many, including musicians, jugglers and clowns were on hand entertain at the estate overlooking the Hudson River.

title: Baker Drives to Title In FreeforAll Race
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., June 17 (AP)  Buddy Baker ran away from an eightway scramble for the lead and built up a 1.5second advantage that handed him victory when a caution flag came out two laps from the finish of today's $165,000 Grand National stockcar race here.

title: C.I.A. Says It Dismissed Officer After. House Files Were Searched
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  A Central Intelligence Agency officer who was assisting a Congressional committee in, the investigation of the 1963 assassination of President Kennedy was dismissed after his fingerprints were found on sensitive evidence kept in a committee safe,, the C.I.A. acknowledged today.

title: Paper Money
description: GLADWYNE, Pa.  While cutting my hair, my barber explained that big business is creating inflation to increase profits. Since I was eager to improve my company's profit, pressed for more details of how I could make inflation work for me. As my barbereconomist went on, his explanation developed that wellknown Washington fuzziness.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Some Sideshows Provide Diversion at Summit Conference
description: VIENNA, June 17  SovietAmerican summit conferences have always been part theater, and by far the most popular performances at this gathering have been the nightly news conferences given jointly by Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, and his Soviet counterpart, Leonid M. Zamyatin, who have been playing to packed houses in the There, beneath the crystal chandeliers and gold leaf of the palace opera house, more than 2,000 reporters from around the world have gathered each evening at 8 for an hour of questions and answers heavily laced with propaganda and polemics.

title: Music: Caramoor Opens. With AllRespiNii Bill
description: KATONAH, N.Y., June 16  The 34th Caramoor Festival got oft to an enterprising start tonight with an allRespighi program in celebration of the composer's centenary. The two featured works were both unusual ones, a choreographed version of his orchestral suite Gli Uccelli (The Birds) and the American premiere of his last opera, Lucrezia, a double bill that will be nirepeated next Friday and Saturday ghts.

title: Dr. Diana Wasserman, Pediatrician, a Bride
description: Dr. Diana Ruth Wasserman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Wasserman of New Haven, was married in Philadelphia yesterday to. Dr. John Prescott Glazer. He is the son of Tom Glazer of Scarborough, N.Y., and Miriam Glazer of Briarcliff, N.Y. Judge Louis H. Pollak of the Federal District Court performed the ceremony at the WhartonSinkler Center at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: BOSTON STUDY FINDS GUN LAW IS WORKING
description: BOSTON, June 17  A Massachusetts law that mandates a oneyear jail term for anyone found carrying a pistol illegally has resulted in a significant drop in the use of guns in assaults, robberies and murders, according to a study by the Center for Applied Social Research at Northeastern University here.

title: Outdoors Unspoiled Woods Near the City Beckon to Hikers
description: POUND RIDGE, N.Y. AWALK in the woods, perhaps capped by a night of sleeping out, is excellent therapy for many of the ills that flesh is heir to. And those who live in New York City and environs are particularly fortunate in having a remarkably varied choice of closeathand state and county parks to visit.

title: Cosmos Perturbed By Dismal Defense
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 17  Everyone on the Cosmos, including the coaches, wants to take the blame for last night's 41 thrashing by the Vancouver Whitecaps before a sellout crowd of 32,500 at Empire Stadium.

title: Lawyer Is Found Shot to Death; Motive Sought in Killing on L.I
description: A 49yearold lawyer was found shot to death in his office in Hauppauge, L. I., late Saturday night, and Suffolk County detectives said last night they had no idea who had killed him or why.

title: Scott Outkicks Paige in 1,500
description: WALNUT, Calif., June 17  Steve Scott reaffirmed his status as America's premier middledistance runner today by outkicking Don Paige in a furious finalAtep duel of the 1,500meter run during the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor track and field championships.

title: Ruth Kevess Bride Of David J. Cohen
description: Ruth Margot Kevess and David Jonathan Cohen were married yesterday in Temple Habonim by Rabbi BenZion Gold, director of the Hillel Foundation at Harvard University.

title: Their Wheelchairs Are No Handicap
description: THERE was only the slightest hint of bitterness in the voice of Larry Callaghan when he talked about the Vietnam War. There was no bitterness in the voice of Harvey Martin. They are two of the 371 athletes who competed in the 23d annual National. Wheelchair Games, which ended yesterday at St. John's University in Queens.

title: Music: 53 Composers in 9Day Festival
description: THE KITCHEN'S nineday, 53composer festival called New Music, New York came to close Saturday night. Despite flaws and variabilities of quality, it has been a remarkable affair. Above all, it's been an attestation of community on the part of a numerous, highly selfaware group of composers.

title: Ballet: The Birds, by Robert Weiss
description: KATONAH, N.Y., June 16 Robert Weiss, who is a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet but also a young choreographer with works in several companies, did a very nice job with his new curtainraiser for the opening of the Caramoor Festival tonight.

title: Advice on Skylab Is Pouring In, And Not All of It Is Too Helpful
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  All the letters are about it. They are usually politely prefaced Dear President Carter, before spewing out a profusion of advice and ideas so ingenuously wacky as to bring comfort to the soul of Rube Goldberg.

title: Can Competition Hurt?
description: PITTSBURGH  Many questions are being raised about the DC10 disaster, but one is not. The evidence suggests that competition itself is the problem. Should we rethink the desirability of allout competition among airlines and, in this instance, among aircraft manufacturers?

title: Leather: Supple And Flowing
description: Brazil, which gave the world the samba and the string bathing suit, may be the source of a new approach to leather fashions. Rogerio Brasil, who was born there 26 years ago, has worked out a new system of styling leather so it looks soft and sexy.

title: Prearranged Curfew Suspends Mets in 8th
description: After 4 hours 6 minutes of play and watchful waiting through two downpours of rain, the New York Mets and Atlanta Braves found themselves suspended in a 11 tie yesterday at Shea Stadium. The game was called at the end of eight innings because of a curfew instituted before the contest to enable the Mets to catch a 7:30 P.M. flight to Houston. The game will be cornvleted at Shea on Aug. 27.

title: Yankees Lose, 63; Symptoms the Same
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., June 17  Just in case there were any doubts in George Steinbrenner's mind, just in case he ever thought that he was being a little hasty, the Yankees went out and did the same things tonight that had irritated their principal owner and had pushed him into action.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Heavy clouds cover the Midas Atlantic States where a storm system Is centered. A band of clouds extend along a front from the northern lake region to the Central Plain States, while a large mess of clouds covers the Pacific Northwest and the Central Pacific States. Clear skies are apparent elsewhere.

title: Mansfield for Concerted Effort on Energy
description: TOKYO, June 17  Mrconditioners have been switched off all over Japan this spring at Government request, and one of the best places to feel the effect of this energysaving measure is the office of the American Ambassador to Japan, Mike Mansfield  the windows of the boxlike new Embassy Building in Tokyo were designed in such a way that they do not open.

title: A River of Food, a Tide of Visitors
description: It was a typical Manhattan street fair, partly rainy with occasional zeppole.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: DID the third quarter of the. American 20th century really belong to baseball's Willie Mays, as the title of Charles Einstein's history, Willie's Time, suggests? No more than it did to Richard M. Nixon or John Wayne or anyone WILLIE'S TIME. A Memoir. By Charles Einstein. 352 pages. Lippincott. 512.95. THE SEVENTH BABE. By Jerome Charyn. 347 pages. Arbor House. $9.95. else whose career happens to have flourished between 1950 and 1975. Naming eras after individuals tends to skew the true character of those eras, if any era can be said to have a true character that everyone can agree on. Nor does it serve anyone's historical imagination to associate Mays's career with the end of steam engines or the transit of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy or the rise of the Polish joke. To do so is to indulge in the lazy trafficking of images that is the province of advertising art, bad movies and historical writing without a point of view.

title: Advertising
description: GILBERT C. MAURER, who has spent most working days since 1952 in magazine publishing, was holding forth on the subject of how many publishers go about introducingnew publications, a system he favors not.

title: IRWIN WINS U.S. OPEN: Hale Irwin in final round of tournament at Toledo, Ohio. Page Cl
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, June 17  Hale Irwin won his second United States Open golf championship this afternoon in what he and his confreres rated as one of the sloppiest final rounds they had played in recent years. In his own phrase Irwin hacked it around today to a 75 on a doublebogey, bogey finish.

title: Currency Shift Possible
description: BONN, June 17  After three months in operation, the European Monetary System, the arrangement linking the values of seven European currencies to one another, appears headed for a realignment, possibly this summer.

title: Music: Sturk's Motet Choir
description: THE New York Motet Choir is 22voice chorus conducted by Stephen Sturk, a young tenor who formed the group in 1976. It presents an annual series of concerts at Grace Episcopal Church, and has also performed at Carnegie Recital Hall. Saturday night, Mr. Sturk and his singers, who claim a considerable following, turned up at Alice Tully Hall their most prominent showcase to date. Artistically, the move seemed entirely warranted. The Motet Choir is clearly a firstrate chorus. The singers sound handpicked, and balances, attacks and blends were generally excellent.

title: Miss Goolagong Triumphs in Final
description: CHICHESTER, England, June 17 (AP)  Evonne Goolagong defeated Britain's Sue Barker, 61, 64, in the final of the $75,000 Chichester grass tennis tournament today.

title: Koch Warns He Intends To Criticize More Judges
description: A roomful of judges heard a warning from Mayor Koch that he would speak out critically whenever he thought judge gave an improper sentence.

title: Associated Press
description: CHRISTINA ONASSIS AT WEDDING OF MARIA NIARCHOS: Christina Onassis Kamm and her husband, Sergei, at church in Lisieux, France, Saturday to attend the wedding of the daughter of Stavros Niarchos, the Greek shipping magnate, to Ails Cbevassus, heir to a French chemical fortune.

title: Tough New Problems Stand in the Way of the Next Step in Arms Control
description: VIENNA, June 17  The next and far more difficult step in nuclear arms control was broached today by President Carter and the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, even before the signing tomorrow of the second accord limiting strategic arms.

title: Shell Cutting Gas Octane
description: LOS ANGELES, June 17 (UPI) The Shell Oil Company has announced that it is reducing the octane rating of its unleaded gasoline for the West Coast in an effort to increase availability. A statement released by the company said the octane rating of Shell's super regular unleaded grade would be temporarily cut to 89.5 from 90.8 octane, thereby increasing gasoline supplies by about 500 to 1,000 barrels a day. That amounts to between 21,000 and 92,000 gallons.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Hinkle's Hemlock Adds Chapter To Open's History of Incidents
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, June 17  Although Hale Irwin won the 79th United States Open championship today, this major tournament at the Inverness Club will probably be best remembered as the Open with the tree known as Hinkle's Hemlock.

title: ISTANBUL IS CHOKING ON OWN POLLUTION
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey  This city, once the crown of the Byzantine Empire, the center of Ottoman luxury, a city with perhaps the finest natural setting in the world, is choking to death on its own pollution.

title: Deborah Brown Is Wed To. Peter Michael Procino
description: Deborah Robbins Brown, a research analyst at the Bankers Trust Company, and Peter Michael Procino, an associate account manager with the Burroughs Corporation in New York, were married yesterday in Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Charles Copenhaver performed the ceremony in the Reformed Church.

title: Events Today
description: WINE UNTOUCHED, by Biotic Vlk; directed by Lynne Guerra, at the Harold Clurtnan Theater. 412 West 42d Street, 6:45.

title: Books
description: Many beginners have found sound advice about running in general in such primers as James Fixx's The Complete Book of Running (Random House) and Bob Glover's The Runner's Handbook (Penguin). The following deal in greater depth with endurance training and particularly the marathon:

title: E.J. Linehan, a Psychologist, Weds Ann Gross in Brooklyn
description: Ann L Gross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Grose of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Edward J. Linehan, son of Helen Linehan of Bethpage, LI., and the late Edward H. Linehan. The ceremony was performed at the Brooklyn Ethical Culture Society by M. Michael Grupp, the society's leader.

title: Deaths
description: AmINOFFFalzullah, beloved husband of Devora, devoted father of Sheila Ebrahimian, Linda Schiffman, and Jacob. Dear brother of Rachel Ebrahirnian. Dearly beloved grandfather of Robert, Steven, Caroline, Benlamin, Jonathan, and David. Services were conducted on June 17, 1979.

title: Martin's Takeover: Lemon Noncommittal
description: ARLINGTON, TEX. B OBLEMON had nothing to say. There were not many reasons to think he would be the manager of the Yankees very long, but he had not been told that he was not the manager, either. So far, he said, after the team's 63 loss here last night, all I know is we've got a day off.

title: Architect Marries Karin V. Nystrom
description: The marriage of Karin Verna Nystrom and Roger W. Sauinter, graduates of the New York Institute of Technology, took place yesterday at the Altamont Inn in Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. John C. Beaven performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Army Criticized for Youth Focus
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)  The emphasis on youth over experience in the United States armed forces may be a mistake, with only three out of every five military persons regarded as being fully productive, a Brookings Institution study reported today.

title: Susan D. Freedman Wed to Mark Zeidel
description: Susan Dee Freedman and Mark Lawrence Zeidel, students at the Columbia University College of Physicians. and Surgeons, were married yesterday at Hampshire House. Rabbi Arnold Jacob Wolf, a chaplain at Yale University, performed the ceremony.

title: The New York Times/Gary David Gold
description: STATE LEGISLATURE ENDS BUSINESS FOR NOW: Assemblyman Clark C. Wemple of Schenectady yawned as Leonard F. Bersani of Syracuse spoke into the early morning yesterday. Legislators adjourned after approving state takeover of Rikers Island and many other lastminute bills. Page B1.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon; June 17 (Reuters)  The Presidents of Syria and Iraq conferred in Baghdad today on merging their countries.

title: Ballet: Two Stuttgart Onegins
description: THE late John Cranko would probably have been delighted by the reception accorded his Eugene Onegin on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. At a moment in which the elegant stranger Onegin rejects the impressionable young Tatiana, a woman yelled out: Why do you treat her that way? What the hell's the matter with you?

title: Notes on People
description: Thirteen friends of Jacob K. Javits threw a 75th birthday party for the Senator last night at the Four Seasons, inviting 200 people to hear laudatory remarks from Dr. Henry. Kissinger, Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Edward M. Kennedy and Howard H. Baker Jr., and former Senator Edward W. Brooke.

title: Savak Agent Describes How He Tortured Hundreds
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 17  Nobody knows how terrible torture is and how painful it is to talk about it, sobbed Tehrani, a former interrogator for the Shah's secret police as he faced a revolutionary court today.

title: Indian State Orders Power Cut
description: NEW DELHI, June 17 (AP)  The western Indian state of Maharashtra began a 75 percent power cut for all industries today in a move that will force an almost total industrial shutdown and the layoff of an estimated two million; workers. Sharad Pawar, chief minister of Maharashtra state, in the heart of India's cotton industry, said the power cut, which will last at least until Thursday, was necessary because the monsoon rains are late this year, reducing the flow of water to the hydroelectric generating stations.

title: Malaysia Reported to Send 500 Refugees Back to Sea
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 17 (AP)  Malaysian authorities were re. ported today to have sent back to sea about 500 Vietnamese refugees who landed on the northeast coast of the country during the weekend. Other reports said as many as 2,500 refugees may have been forced to leave.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Express Company announced that Jackson N. Huddleston Jr. has joined the company as a senior vice president in the card division.

title: NICHOLAS RAY, 67; DIRECTOR OF FILMS
description: Nicholas Ray, who directed the films Johnny Guitar, Rebel Without Cause, a remake of King of Kings, Run for Cover and 55 Days at Peking, died Saturday of lung cancer after a I2year battle with the disease. Mr. Ray, who was 67 years old, died at the Sloan Kettering Institute for Cancer.

title: Sporting Gear.
description: One new item for backpackers is a boat. That's right, an inflatable flatbottom boat, called the Sea Eagle 3, that weighs just eight pounds and can be folded to take up less space than a small sleeping bag. It has a deep cockpit, holds up to 250 pounds and includes four separate air compartments, oarlocks and a rope lacing around the perimeter. With standard foot pump ($15 extra), it can be fully inflated in three to five minutes. Included in the $55 price are an airpressure gauge, a carrying bag and a 16page manual. Oars are optional, at $12. Order directly (add $5 for postage) from Leisure Imports, 104 Arlington Avenue, St. James, L.I. 11780, (516) 7248900.

title: Transit Advisers Issues: Safety and Money Woes
description: On Friday morning, a lawyer named Michael Gerrard waited on the platform at the Delancey Street station to transfer to the F line on which he finishes his daily ride to his office. The wait was longer than usual. Mr. Gerrard recalled the Urban Affairs other day, and when the sleek F train made up of silver and blue R48 cars arrived, the crush on the platform was enormous. He couldn't board the train.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON (UPI)  One man was killed and three children were injured in a fire that swept through three row houses in Trenton's Mill Hill section.

title: BREZHNEV DECLARES PACT MAY COLLAPSE IF SENATE ALTERS IT
description: VIENNA, June 17  On the eve of signing the second SovietAmerican strategic arms limitation treaty, Leonid I. Brezhnev warned tonight that the agreement could collapse if it was amended or changed during the ratification process, with grave and even dangerous consequences for our relations and for the situation in the world as a whole.

title: The New York Times and Associated Preis
description: Pat Maloney, center, a lawyer, was hired by Jim Ashley, wet at left, to sue Southwestern Bell Telephone after Mr. Ashley was dismissed by Bell, where he worked 23 years.BLANCO, Tex.  On Route 281 north of San Antonio, the megalopolis has not yet come in and cattle and goats continue to graze. The region, with its gently rolling hills and meandering rivers is a dreamy weekend retreat for wellT.O. Gavitt, a good friend of Mr. Ashley, committed suicide after he became involved in investigation, but not before leaving memo charging company with wrongdoing. fixed city dwellers. It is a wonderful place for a real estate broker  most pirticularly in the commercial concentration on the very fringe of Blanco, population 1,300. This is the site of Jim Ashley Real Estate. One afternoon, the telephone rang there. Jim Ashley picked it up.

title: Carter Aides Strive to Contain Wages
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  The Administration's senior economic advisers, convinced that the risks of a severe recession will increase if organized labor tries to catch up with inflation, are groping for ways to persuade unions to hold back on wage demands.

title: Source:merIcan Iron and Steel Institute, production data are estimated from A.I.S.I. material
description: WARREN, Ohio  Joseph Gallagher, general superintendent of the complex of mills and furnaces of the Republic Steel Corporation here, clambered to the top of a new $100 million coke plant where construction workers were putting the finishing touches to get it ready to begin operating this month.

title: May. Sales Weak, Say Retailers
description: The nation's big retailers, having basked in an especially good fiscal first quarter, are reporting disappointing results for May. They are beginning to express fear that consumers spending Is slowing down.

title: Restoration of Times Sq. Moving Closer to Reality
description: While some of the more elaborate plans to reclaim the heart of Manhattan's blighted Times Square entertainment center appear as far off as ever, half dozen less ambitious efforts at improvement are moving forward. And if a longpromised 2,020room hotel planned for the west side of Times Square finally becomes a reality, 1979 could be the turnaround year for the Great White Way.

title: Miss,Oechsle Takes Jersey Girls' 18 Title
description: Special to The New York Times

title: A Brooklyn Store Owner And Clerk Shot to Death
description: The owner of a Brooklyn grocery store and his clerk were shotgunned to death early this morning during a holdup of the small grocery at 2909 Fulton Street in the East New York section, according to police of the 75th Precinct.

title: Detroit Woman Is 4th to Be Held In Shooting of Father of Singer
description: DETROIT, June 17(AP)  A fourth person has been jailed in the shooting of the father. of Aretha Franklin, the soul singer. Bond was set at $500,000 Friday in Detroit Recorder's Court for Patricia Walker, 29 years old, who was charged with assault with intent to commit murder, breaking and entering and using a firearm during a felony.

title: Connecticut and Florida Conducting a Joint Inquiry on Jai Alai Wagering
description: HARTFORD, June 16  Law enforcement officials in Connecticut and Florida have opened investigations into alleged betting irregularities in jai alai matches, a multimilliondollar sport of growing popularity that is now legal in four states and under consideration in several others.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY
