description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: U.S. Planners Expect Auto's Role To Be Unaffected by Gas Scarcity
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  The Carter Administration is committed to a national transportation policy that keeps the automobile at the center of America's travel plans, despite the prospect that today's gasoline lines may be a sporadic problem for some time to come.

title: De Gustibus A Word or Two About Passionfruit
description: When that exotic product of the passion fruit tree was mentioned in this space recently, it scarcely occurred to me that the delicacy is quite pointedly named. I have learned, to my surprise and amusement, that my thoughts based on a smattering of ignorance can arouse a good bit of passion, in the form of ire, in the bosoms of good number of Australians and New Zealanders.

title: Question Raised Of Safety Rules On Conrail Line
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y.  An inspection of Conrail track here that turned up joints with loose or missing bolts has stirred questions among rail officials about whether the affected joints meet state and Federal rail safety standards.

title: Bridge:
description: The World Bridge Federation, founded in Oslo in 1958, has come of age this year. Member countries now total 70, a record. The newest of these is tiny Mauritius, an island jewel in the middle of the Indian Ocean.

title: Oil and Gaming Issues Shift Sharply As General Market Retreats Modestly
description: Specialsituation issues produced wide price swings yesterday, while the general market engaged in a modest retreat.

title: New Trial Set In Fraud Case
description: A new trial will begin Aug. 13 for Jerome Castle on charges that he defrauded Penn Dixie Industries when he was the company's chief executive officer. The date was set yesterday by Judge John M. Cannella of Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Text of the Joint Communiqu by Carter and Brezhnev
description: VIENNA, June 18 (AP) Following is the official text of the joint United StatesSoviet communique issued today at the end of the Vienna meeting between President Carter and President Leonid I. Brezhnev of the Soviet Union:

title: PBS Frames Proposals To Broaden Content
description: Recommendations for a reorganization of public television, to increase its ability to provide national programming, were framed late last week by the executive committee of the Public Broadcasting Service.services  as promotion, advertising, program development and research. A new organization would be established. separate from PBS, to assume its present trade association, lobbying and planning functions.

title: Dance: Trust Company
description: AS one entered the ARC Studio in the Cornerstone Lutheran Center for Sunday afternoon's, dance concert, there sat William Dunas, the Trust Company's choreographer and director, distributing programs and chatting with friends. After a while, he got up and started dancing. Apparently, he wished to indicate, through his informality, that he considered dancing a part of ordinary life.

title: Carter's Speech to Congress Asking Approval of Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 Following is a transcript of President Carter's address to a joint session of Congress tonight as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Freighter Sinks in Tanker Collision
description: CHATHAM, Mass., June 18 (UPI)  A freighter loaded with 3,000 tons of scrap iron sank off fogshrouded Cape Cod tonight after colliding with a tanker loaded with asphalt. All 38 crew members aboard the freighter abandoned ship in life rafts and were rescued, the Coast Guard said.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: John D. Ong, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, has been elected to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive officer, effective July 1. He succeeds 0. Pendleton Thomas, who will retire at the age of 65.

title: Siegel Gains in Jersey
description: KEARNY, N.J., June 18  Steve Siegel of Teaneck, hoping to regain the title he won in 1976, opened with two easy victories today in the New Jersey state men's tennis championships at the Arlington Players Club.

title: The City
description: A 16yearold Brooklyn youth was struck by a stray bullet and fatally Wounded last night when an unidentified gunman shot two men during an argument on a Williamsburgh street.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, June 18, 1979

title: ArmsPact Foes Cite 3 Issues
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  Opponents of the new arms treaty object to the accord on three counts: They argue that it does not provide for true equality in strategic forces; they assert that it excludes important Soviet systems from ceilings placed on missiles and bombers, and they question whether it can be adequately verified.

title: Memorial Rite Tonight For A. Philip Randolph
description: Governor Carey heads a list of scheduled speakers at a public memorial service tonight for A. Philip Randolph in Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.

title: Duffy Lewis, 91, Played In Outfield for Red Sox
description: SALEM, N.H., June 18 (UPI)  Duffy Lewis, former Boston Red Sox outfielder who played with three world championship teams while roaming Duffy's Cliff in Fenway Park, died yesterday at his home. He was 91 years old.

title: A Calm McEnroe Overcomes Pecci in Final
description: LONDON, June 18  John McEnroe overcame an erratic serve in the opening set and defeated Victor Pecci of Paraguay in the final of the $125,000 Stella Artois grass tennis tournament today, 67,61,61.

title: U.S. Calls Off Textiles Duties
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)  The Treasury Department announced today that it would not impose special duties against imports of textiles and men's and boys apparel from Singapore and Thailand as had been contemplated.

title: About New York
description: Back in 1963, when give a damn was not yet a clich of urban public relations, George Harvey decided to be a mindblowing basketball coach.

title: HENRY T. PEREZ
description: Henry T. Perez, a civil engineer who retired in 1977 as editor in chief of Construction Methods and Equipment, a professional journal formerly published by McGrawHill, died last Friday of cancer at his home in White Plains. He was 63 years old.

title: Leaders Make Signing of Treaty A Warm and Poignant Closing
description: VIENNA, June 18  It could have been a stiff and formal moment, and in stead it turned into a spontaneous and poignant one, charged with the symbolism of parting and farewell and the respect and sympathy of a younger man before the painful infirmity of old age.

title: Details
description: GALTIrving. The Officers and members of the Manhattan Region, Zionist Organization of America records with profound sorrow the passing of a dedicated Zionist. Irving Galt was a Past President of the Manhattan Region and member of the National Executive Committee of the ZOA. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Bernard M. Rifkin, President.

title: Martin Gets a Hero's Welcome
description: Flashing a big smile and goodnaturedly answering questions that might have been embarrassing at other times, Billy Martin returned to New York and a hero's welcome yesterday.

title: May's Rise In Housing Trails 1978
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) Homebuilders had their best month of the year in May as housing starts rebounded from April's weak performance, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: The Editorial Notebook The Season of Aquarius
description: It's time to take to the waters again. Fountains, pools, sprays and jets are becoming a focus of street activity as the sun warms the city and the lunch break takes on its seasonal aspect of dolce far niente  doing nothing, pleasantly.

title: A.T.&T. Earnings Up 9.3% for Quarter
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the three months ended May 31 rose 9.3 percent while revenues rose 10.5 percent.

title: DC10'S WING CRACK IS LAID TO OVERHAUL
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI)  The chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board told Congress today that the DC10 that crashed in Chicago in the nation's worst air disaster was probably critirchcally damaged during an overhaul in Ma..

title: Parks Concerts To Start Aug. 8
description: The 15th season of free park concerts by the New York Philharmonic will begin on Aug. 8 in the Sheep Meadow of Central Park. Andre Kostelanetz will conduct. The program  RimskyKorsakov's Scheherazade, Stravinsky's Firebird and four Sousa marches will end with the traditional fireworks display.

title: Glossary of Terms in Nuclear Arms Agreement
description: ABM  Antiballistic missile, or defensive missile capable of destroying an offensive missile before it reaches its target. ABM's are limited by a United StatesSoviet treaty signed in 1972.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Solar power and other renewable sources would provide 20 percent of America's energy needs by the year 2000 under goals to be announced by President Carter, according to. Government sources. At ceremony on Wednesday marking installation of a solar heating system for the White House, the President is expected to unveil details of a Solar Development Bank. Further details of his plan are to contained in a message to Congress. [Page Al.]

title: EDUCATION City Weighs More Explicit Sex Education
description: IN an effort to curb teenage pregnancies and be more responsive to student needs, Board of Education officials have prepared a new curriculum that would permit far more explicit instruction in sexeducation classes in New York City's public schools.

title: The Return of Gustave Tassel
description: The word today is minimal. It used to be understated. The meaning hasn't changed, however. Clothes that are simple, uncluttered and spare have an instantly recognizable cachet.

title: Private World of Supreme Court In California Depicted at Hearing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 18  Life within the California Supreme Court's private world is so unstructured that no record is kept of most of the voting on whether to grant hearings to petitioners whose files are considered at the court's weekly conferences where the seven justices meet with no one else present.

title: Private Study Attributes Sheep Deaths to Fallout of 53 Atomic Tests
description: WASHINGTON June 18  The deaths of thousands of sheep after a series of atomic tests in the spring of 1953 can definitely be attributed to nuclear fallout, according to a private report that for the first time makes a direct scientific link between the deaths and radiation.

title: Restrictions on Buying of Gas
description: NEW YORK: An oddeven plan to take effect tomorrow morning will govern sales in New York City, Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland and such other counties as require it. The details of the system are to be announced this morning.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: After hearing almost two hours of argument in the Marvin Webster compensation case, Federal Judge Robert L. Carter reserved his decision until next month.

title: Two Leaders Agree, in Private Meeting, to Consult More Frequently
description: VIENNA, June 18  In their only private meeting this morning, President Carter and the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, agreed to increase the frequency of SovietAmerican summit conferences as a way of improving communication between the two superpowers.

title: Rabbi Jesse J. Finkle Dead at 69; Led Newport News Congregation
description: Rabbi Jesse J. Finkle, rabbi emeritus of Rodef Sholom Congregation in Newport News, Va., died Sunday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Orange, N.J. He was 69 years old and his home was in Orange, where in recent years he had been interim rabbi at Beth Torah Congregation.

title: More Banks Cut Prime to 11%
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the nation's fourthlargest bank, and several other banks announced a quarterpoint reduction in their prime lending rates to 11 percent yesterday.

title: Susan F. Paull, a Student Married to Melville Straus
description: Susan F. Paull, daughter of Rose Paull of New York and the late Edward Paull, was married yesterday to Melville Straus, son of Mrs. Norman DeRoy and Milton Straus, both of Tucson, Ariz. Criminal Court Judge Jay Gold performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment.

title: If Only Horses Could Talk
description: He never said he was the greatest horse ever to look through a bridle, and he never boasted that he could have beaten Man o War, Secretariat or Seattle Slew. He didn't even say he was a cinch to win the Triple Crown. His trainer, Bud Delp, said all that.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Television Channel 11, 8 P.M. RadioWINS, 8 P.M.)

description: SCHMELLHarry. The Officers and Directors of Yeshiva Toras Emes, Joseph S. Gross High School deeply regret the passing of Harry Schrnell, father of Israel Schnell, Chairman of our board.

description: STONY CREEK. Conn.  Someone told me I should take balloons to China. The children would love them for the color.

description: The SovietUnited States treaty to limit offensive nuclear arms, to be valid until Dec. 31, 1985, stipulates two principal ceilings.

title: Teamsters Lose Key Bargaining Case at N.L.R.B.
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The National Labor Relations Board voted today against ordering an employer tobargain with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, even though the board said that the company had engaged in outrageous and pervasive unfair labor practices.

title: Treasury Bills Drop in Yield
description: Yields of Treasury bills dropped yesterday to their lowest levels since last tall, pushing the rate on money market certificates below 9 percent for the first time since October 1978.

title: Pact Gives Soviet Data On Arms for First Time
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Soviet Union, as part of the new arms treaty, has made public, for the first time, figures on its strategic arsenal.

title: Alaska Oil Profits Up 70%
description: Three United States oil companies that produce Alaskan North Slope oil have beeriable to increase their profits by more than 70 percent this year because they have followed the producers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in raising their prices, an authoritative petroleum publication said yesterday.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: TWOHIT PERFORMANCE: Nolan Ryan of the Angels following through with a pitch last night during game against the Texas Rangers in Anaheim, Calif. Ryan, who did not allow a hit until the eighth inning, struck out 10 batters, walked two and allowed only two singles in his nine innings on the mound. The Angels won, 50.

title: 16YearOld Floridian Conquers Sue Barker on Grass by 76, 60
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 18 (AP)  Sixteenyearold Bettina Bunge of Florida upset Sue Barker, Britain's No. 2 player, 76, 60, today at the start of the $100,000 Eastbourne grass tennis tournament.

title: Lemon Backs Move To Get Club Going
description: It had happened to Hob Lemon before, and he knew it would happen again. So last Friday, when he learned his services as the Yankee manager were no longer required, it was not so bad. Very soft. he called it.

title: Koch, Furious at Legislature, Asks Governor to Veto Pension Measure
description: I'm furious over the way the State Legislature ripped us off over the weekend. Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Steel Output Down by 0.6%
description: Steel production declined to 2.823 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of sixtenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.840. million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: The Drug That Was Denounced And Hailed for 3 Decades in U.S.
description: It has been hailed by some cancer patients as a beacon of hope and denounced by medical experts as a worthless nostrum of quacks. It has been studied and restudied,. outlawed and legalized, banned and smuggled and made the focus of countless battles in state legislatures, courts and doctors offices.

title: Texts of the U.S.Soviet Treaty and Agreed Statements
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  Following are the official Englishlanguage versions of the treaty on strategic nuclear weapons, widely known as SALT II, signed in Vienna today by President Carter and Leonid Brezhnev of the Soviet Union, a protocol to the treaty, statements of understanding on the treaty anda Statement of Principles:

title: Kingman Hits 24th Homer
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18 (UPI) Dave Kingman of the Cubs continued his torrid homerun pace tonight, hitting his 29th of the season, but Dusty Baker hit two homers for the Dodgers and Steve Garvey clouted a basesempty shot as Los Angeles beat Chicago 73.

title: Ancient Mounds Taken as Clues to Advanced Culture
description: SANTA FE, N.M. AS early as 300 B.C., and lasting at least through A.D. 1300, a civilization thrived in the farflung Mississippi River system from the Great Lakes to the Gulf of Mexico. Its thousands of mounds have now been found to manifest a culture that was far more sophisticated than previously believed. The earthworks include the most massive monuments built north of Mexico before Europeans arrived in North America.

title: Texts of Carter's and Brezhnev's Remarks at Signing of the Treaty
description: VIENNA, June 18 (AP)  Following are the text of President Carter's remarks and the official Russian translation of Leonid I. Brezhnev's remarks at the signing of the strategicarms treaty here today:

title: Women Anchors on TV In Japan Go Unwatched
description: TOKYO, June 18 (AP)  Since early this year, Japanese television networks have put more than 30 women in key Slots in primetime news programs. Viewers have not been enthusiastic, and critics have accused stations of using the women for show while keeping men in charge.

title: About Education
description: IN 1972, The Club of Rome, then a little known group of international intellectuals, set off a worldwide debate with the publication of its first report, The Limits to Growth, establishing its reputation as a gadfly in global economics. Last week, at a meeting in Salzburg, Austria, the group issued a plea for education.

title: Shoe Crisis For South Koreans
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 18.South Korea's footwear industry, critically dependent on exports, is in a slump that some industry sources say could force major manufacturers to turn to other businesses.

title: Veteran Wall Street Regulator Retiring at S.E.C.
description: When it comes to Federal oversight of the securities business, William D. Moran, administrator of the New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has just about done it all. In almost 40 years with the commission, he has broken up bucket shops that were using highpressure tactics to sell securities to the unwary, nipped fraud in the bud and brought any number of enforcement actions against investment firms that were operating in one way or another on the shady side of the street.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1979

title: The Court and the Handicapped
description: Has the Supreme Court injured the handicapped by ruling against Frances Davis? Mrs. Davis is hard of hearing but claimed to be qualified for a Federally funded nurses training program in North Carolina. Her setback in court has been seen as a terrible blow to those who counted on using the 1973 Vocational Rehabilitation Act to break down discrimination against the physically disadvantaged.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SIGN STRATEGIC ARMS TREATY; CARTER URGES CONGRESS TO SUPPORT ACCOR
description: VIENNA. June 18  President Carter and Leonid I. Brezluiev, the Soviet leader, signed an arms control treaty today that for the first time limits both sides to the same maximum number of longrange bombers and missiles.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, June 18 (AP)  Power blackouts were reported in areas of three New England states today as utilities trimmed their output because of equipment failure and an electricity drain from the heavy use of airconditioners and fans.

title: U.S. Car Makers. See Slow Year
description: DETROIT, June 17  American automobile makers, their traditionally strong spring selling season blunted this year by a gasolineconscious public resisting big cars and trucks, are preparing for a continued sales decline for the remainder of the year.

title: Morris Udall Is Ordered to Repay $74,136 in Election Funds to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Federal Election Commission disclosed today that it had ordered the 1976 Presidential primary committee for Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, to repay to the Treasury $74,136, most of which was for insufficiently documented campaign expenses.

title: U.S. Air Traffic Up 16.2% in 1979
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The nation's 27 airlines carried 16.2 percent more passengers in the first five months of 1979 than they did in the same period last year, the Air Transport Association reported today.

title: OddEven Sales of Gasoline Due Tomorrow in New York
description: An oddeven system of gasoline sales will begin at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow in New York City and the surrrounding suburban counties of Westchester, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk. Governor Carey announced yesterday.

title: Publication Designers Give Art Work Awards
description: Awards honoring art work in publications during 1978 have been presented in the 14th annual competition of the Society of Publication Designers.

title: Saudis Said to Plan Added Oil
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  Saudi Arabia was reported today to be contemplating an Increase in oil production next month to 9.5 million barrels a day from 8.5 million barrels, but authoritative oil executives here said they could not confirm it.

title: Individuals Emerge In China
description: One area where China and the United States differ radically, although the gap will gradually lessen, is over the vital question of space for the individual to be himself or herself.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: TOKYO, June 18 (AP)  The Yokohama Rubber Company, Japan's secondlargest rubber producer, said today that it would establish a joint venture with the B.F. Goodrich Company of Akron, Ohio, to market automobile tires and parts in Japan.

title: Maremont Board Approves Merger
description: Directors of the Maremont Corporation of Chicago, an automotive equipment supplier, said its directors had approved its merger into Swiss Aluminum Ltd, known as Alusuisse. The agreement, which was previously announced, has already been approved by the Swiss company.

title: The Region
description: MORRISTOWN. N.J. (AP)  A retarded teenager would be able to enjoy a better life if a court granted her parents request to have their daughter sterilized, the parents lawyer told a court here yesterday.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Children and All That Jazz

title: High Court Rejects Suit Against Auditing Firm
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Supreme Court ruled today that customers of a defunct securities firm cannot recover their losses by suing the firm's outside auditors for failing to alert Federal regulators tope firm's precarious condition.

title: Deaths
description: HECHTJennie. The Officers and Membership of Temple Israel, Long Beach and its Sisterhood note with sadness the passing of the sister of its beloved member and former President, Dr. Leo Gordon. May the family be comforted.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Medical International, Beverly Hills, Calif., an international health services company, announced that effective Sept. 1 Royce Diener will become chairman and chief executive officer and Walter L. Weisman will become president and chief operating officer.

title: Earlier Accords Helped to Mold The Arms Pact
description: The treaty that was signed in Vienna yesterday by President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev flowed from two earlier accords on strategicarms limitations between the United States and the Soviet Union, the first signed in Moscow in 1972 and the other in Vladivostok in 1974.

title: Leon Green, 91, of Northwestern; Professor and Law School Dean
description: EVANSTON, Ill., June 18 (UPI) Leon Green, professor of law and former dean of the Northwestern University School of Law, died Saturday in Austin, Tex., and was buried there yesterday. He was 91 years old.

title: Chicago Crash: The Legal Aftermath
description: The lawyers speak in geographical shorthand  the Everglades, Pagopago, Paris, Tenerife, Bombay, San Diego, Portland. They speak of these places without emotion and from a distance, as if they were retired generals reliving past battles.

title: Bees Action May Curb Apple Yield
description: ACORNELL UNIVERSITY researcher is believed to. have discovered the answer to a question that has plagued scientists and apple growers for years: Why are the yields of Delicious apples, the bright red fruit that is the nation's most popular variety, consistently lower than those of other species?

title: 2 Leading Defendants Convicted In 18 South African Blacks Trial
description: BETRAL, South Africa, June 18 (Reuters)  Two principal defendants in political trial of 18 blacks were found guilty today of conspiring to overthrow the whitedominated South African Government.

title: U.S. Reducing Sugar Supports
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) Federal price supports for United States raw sugar are being lowered by 1.73 cents a pound to 13 cents a pound in an attempt to move more of it into consumer channels and less into government storage.

title: Deaths
description: AMYCol.Henry J.,on June 17,1979 of Eastchester, N.Y. Beloved husband of Aline, dear brother of Rev.E. Paul Amy, S.J., Marie O'Gorman, Sr.Marie Madeleine, and devoted uncle. Mass of Christian Burial in the Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe Tuesday, June 19 at 11AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to Lawrence Hosp. Development Fund would be appreciated.

title: Now Tugmen Consider A Halt Over Fuel Price
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 18 (UPI) Tugboats on the Mississippi River may come to a standstill if fuel prices continue to soar.

title: Pfizer to Market New Sleeping Aid
description: Pfizer Inc., a pharmaceuticals company based in New York, announced that it would begin marketing within few weeks, through its Leeming/Pacquin division, a new nonprescription sleep aid called Unisom.

title: South Korea Opposition Leader Barred from Meeting Dissidents
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 18  Government security agents thwarted an attempt by opposition politicians and dissident groups to link forces today in a united call for the restoration of democratic freedoms in South Korea a week before President Carter's scheduled state visit.

title: IN THE NATION The Elected Illusion
description: On May n, 1979, Gladys Smith died at the age of 88. On June 11, Marion Morrison died at age 72. On Jan: 20, 1981, someone named Carter or Reagan or Connally or Kennedy, or none of the above, will be inaugurated as the 39th President of the United States.

title: Firmani Signs to Coach New Jersey Americans
description: Eddie Firmani, who was dismissed as head coach of the Cosmos on June 1 after having led them to two straight North American Soccer League championships agreed yesterday, after a week of negotiating, to coach the New Jersey Americans of the American Soccer Leaeue throueh the 1982 season.

title: Utility in Jersey Wins Rate Rise Tied to Accident
description: NEWARK, June 18  The New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commisioners today approved a $45 million rate increase for the Jersey Central Power and Light Company. The increase represents slightly more than onethird of what the utility said it needed to pay for power it has had to buy since the March 28 shutdown of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant near Harrisburg, Pa.

title: Brascan Chief Plans
description: TORONTO, June 18  J.H. Moore, chairman and chief executive officer of Brascan Ltd., intends to resign following the company's annual meeting next week and hand over the leadership to his rival, Peter Bronfman, the company has disclosed.

title: JAPANESE TO SOFTEN POLICY ON REFUGEES
description: TOKYO, June 18 Japanese Government officials indicated today that they were preparing to ease their policy on the issue of admitting refugees from Indochina., Only three such refugees have been allowed to settle permanently here.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 18 (UPI) Forces loyal to Pol Pot, the ousted Cambodian Prime Minister, said today that they had totally liberated a district north of the Cambodian capital but the proHanoi Government in Phnom Penh said they were only imaginary victories.

title: Death
description: CERVERAArchimedes. Suddenly on June 16, 1979, of Bayshore, L.I. Beloved husband of Nellie. Devoted father of Rebecca Ann, Pamela Ruth and Stephen Mark. Loving son of Rosaria. Fond brother of Ruth Murray and Yolanda Rivero. The family will receive friends at the George C. White Funeral Home, 364 E. Main St, Bayshore, today 25 and 79 PM. Funeral services Wednesday, 10:30 A.M. at the Presbyterian Church of Islip. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, N.Y.

title: Plan to Take Bus Shelters Alleged
description: An auditor in the New York City Comptroller's office says in an affidavit that two of the Comptroller's aides planned to recommend that the city take title to all 500 shelters built by Bustop Shelters Inc. without compensating the company. The EMICISV1I says MIS was planned before the Board of Estimate voted to terminate the company's franchise to operate the shelters.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Heavy clouds blanket New England and the North Atlantic States while skies over Middle and South Atlantic States remain clear. Clouds also cover the lower lake region, the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys, the Northern Plains States, the Cascades and the cific Northwest. Skies over the rest of the country remain clear.

title: U.S. Balks At Uranium Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)  The Justice Pepartment balked today at a request by the Senate Judiciary Committee to turn over secret grand jury testimony in an investigation into price fixing in the uranium industry.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange; (A) the American Exchange and (O) overtheCounter.

title: Private Group to Run A Coast Think Tank On University Campus
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 18 The financially troubled Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions found new life and a new location today when its directors turned over its operation to a private foundation at the University of California campus here.

title: Rock: 55,000 at Stadium In jersey Hear 4 Acts
description: ON Sunday, 55,000 people thronged Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., for an afternoon of rockandroll that may prove to be the summer's biggest rock event in terms of sheer numbers in the New York area. The kids are fantastic, John Scher, the New Jersey promoter, said. They make the event bigger and bigger until it transcends the individual acts that are playing. In this instance, that wasn't terribly hard to do: Poco, Todd Rundgren and Utopia, and the Outlaws are not superlative bOnds, and even Boston, the headliner, is uneven.

title: Jurors Picked for Murder Retrial
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 18 (AP)  After two weeks of questioning prospective jurors, attorneys agreed today on 12 persons to hear the retrial of Elmer Wayne Henley on six murder charges stemmine from the deaths of 26 boys in Houston. Mr. Henley's first conviction was thrown out by an appeals court that ruled the defense should have been grcmted a hearing on a motion to move the trial frorn San Antonio, where it had been movkd from Houston.

title: Malaysia Cancels Threats to Refugees
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 18  Malaysia in effect withdrew its threat today to force the 75,000 Vietnamese refugees in camps here back out to sea and to shoot on sight any newcomers nearing its chores.

title: U.S.Portuguese Pact Is Signed
description: LISBON, June 18, (Reuters)  The United States and Portugal signed an agreement today extending American military use of Portugal's Lajes air base in the Azores until February 1983, it was announced. Secretary of State Vance flew in frqm Vienna to sign the treaty, where he had attended the fourday summit confererice between President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, which culminated in the signing of a new strategicarms limitation treaty.

title: Genoa Bomb Explosion Injures
description: GENOA, Italy, June 18 (AP) A bomb exploded during the night outside the Palace of Justice here today, slightly injuring three policemen on duty and shattering windows of the building. The police said they had no clue to the bombers.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Trading Mixed; Price of Gold Declines
description: The dollar rose sharply against the Swiss franc but declined against most other major currencies in exchange markets yesterday. The price of gold fell.

title: PRESIDENT SETTING SOLAR POWER GOAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  President Carter plans to announce Wednesday that the nation will aim at obtaining 20 percent of its energy needs from solar power and other renewable sources by the year 2000, Government and private experts said today.

title: New Cottage Industry in Washington: Congressmen's Wives Writing Novels
description: WASHINGTONBooks about life in the nation's capital are being written these days by a new breed of novelist the wives of Congressmen.

title: Accord Reached On City Budget; Up to Koch Now
description: Almost two weeks after the legal dead. line for enactment of a New York City budget, the Board of Estimate and City Council yesterday approved a package of amendments that risked vetoes by Mayor Koch.

title: Javits Predicts Bank Could Aid City
description: Establishment of a federally sponsored bank that would subsidize loans to cities for rebuilding deteriorated water mains, sewers, bridges, tunnels and other essential facilities could make $500 million a year available to New York City, Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday.

title: For FactionRidden Chad, Peace Appears Far Away
description: NDJAMENA, Chad  The last thing. this impoverished, landlocked nation needs is more war. The last thing it is likely to stet is neace.

title: 15 Killed in Floods in a Polish City
description: WARSAW June 18 (AP)  Five persons drowned when heavy rains flooded the western Polish city of Walbrzych, the official Polish press agency reported today. The agency said the rain had swept sand and slime into the city, clogging the sewage system.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Prices of Bonds Rise Moderately
description: The credit markets, unperturbed by news of a rebound in housing starts and an increase in utilization of the nation's indlistrial capacity, rose moderately in price yesterday. Longterm Governmetit and corporate bond prices generally rose a quarterpoint.

title: Texas Preacher Urges Continuation of Battle Over Licensed Homes
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 18 (UPI)  The evangelist Lester Roloff, backed by more than 2,000 handclapping, singing supporters, urged his followers tonight not to lay down and play dead in an upcoming confrontation with the state over licensing of his three controversial homes for children.

title: Advertising
description: ONE reason that there has been a SCAN/New York program working to eliminate child abuse for the last year and a half is that Nancy Fisher, once a copywriter with Vick International, could not get back into the advertising business.

title: Associated Press
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 18  The mood inside the Nicaraguan rebels headquarters in eastern Managua contrasts sharply with the tensions elsewhere in this city.

title: Researchers Find Surprises in Process of Aging
description: THEY were two men almost as different as life and death: one vigorous, erect, active in mind and body; the other stooped, shuffling and seemingly fading into extreme old age. Paradoxically, they had one thing in common. They were both 65 years old.

title: Theater: Class Enemy, Set in Slums of London
description: CLASS Enemy by Nigel Williams is a serious and provocative play, blessed with fine performances and generally expert staging by Tony Tanner. It was a success in. London last year, when Mr. Williams was hailed for his promise as a playwright, and now it is at the Perry Street Theater. Class Enemy is the cry of the dispossessed, done in the accents of the London slums, and for the most part it is without selfpity. When it works, it works splendidly.

title: Hua Concedes Economic.Coals Were Too Ambitious
description: HONG KONG, June 18  Hua Guofeng, China's Communist Party chairman and prime Minister, conceded today that economic plans he put forward only last year had been too ambitious and that three years of economic readjustment would be necessary.

title: Thinking Small in Cape Breton
description: GLACE BAY, Nova Scotia  Economic planners, stymied by failures and the inertia of underdevelopment, are taking a new tack in the decadeslong struggle to give this impoverished section of Canada a more promising future.

title: 15th State Outlaws Blind Bidding on Films
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18  The blind bidding on motion pictures, a practice that requires theater owners to commit themselves to showing a new movie before they have seen it  sometimes even before the picture has been made  may be on the way out.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: EDWARD ABBEY and his 9yearold daughter have just walked 10 miles  there and back  through the Canyonlands National Park in southeast Utah tainspect, from a 500foot overlook, the confluence of the Green and Colorado Rivers. The bad guys want to build a highway to the overlook. Mr. Abbey asks his daughter whether the bad guys should be allowed to get away with it. She. says no; people should walk. He says:

title: TV: Taxi Rolls Into Superior SitCorn
description: GENERALLY speaking, situation comedies get a bad deal from reviewers. The form itself tends to be patronized, quite unfairly. And then, opinions are frequently based on first episodes. The opening episode of ht*APW. for instance, was not nearly as interesting as the original Robert Altman movie, But, subsequently, the CBS series has proved to be outstanding television. ABC's Barney Miller began as standard domestic sitcorn but has evolved into :a clever commentary on urban vagaries.

title: Bail Denied TortureDeath Suspect
description: TRENTON, June 18  A 27yearold South Amboy man accused of murdering an 18yearold Princeton Township girl was denied bail after the judge was told he had confessed to torturing her with a live electrical wire.

title: Steinbrenner Hails Martin as Man for Job; New Manager Calls Jackson's Role Crucial
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, said yesterday that he was overlooking his stormy past with Billy Martin because he felt Martin was the best man to spark the Yankees out of the doldrums.

title: Vermont National Guard Plans Training at Home to Save Fuel
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., June 18 (AP)  In an effort to save fuel, the Vermont National Guard has decided to train at home rather than travel to New York State.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: The divorce rate in the United States shows some signs of leveling off, according to figures released by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: Voting Begins in Ghana Elections
description: ACCRA, Ghana, June 18 (UPI) Ghanaians voted today for the civilian President and Parliament that the West African country's military rulers have promised will be permitted to take power in three to four months.

title: Volunteer Gives Science A Lifelong Yardstick
description: EVERY 18 months or so, I become a human guinea pig for three days on a hill two miles north of the Baltimore Harbor Tunnel. If you pass by on the Thruway, you are within hailing distance of the gerontological outpost I have visited periodically for the last 16 years. I expect to continue visiting it for the rest of my life.

title: OBSERVER Cheese & Macaroni
description: After 30 years of the soft life, Americans seem to have forgotten how to moderate their passion for easy living. The working stiff nowadays insists his car is not a luxury but a necessity. while ownership of a color television set is regarded even among paupers as one of the rights of man, just as precious as the right to dine seven days a week on hamburger.

title: Taxes
description: WHEN the bubble burst at Equity Funding six years ago last March, it revealed one of the and most startling frauds in American business history. To outward appearances, the Equity Funding Corporation of America had devised a novel and immensely successful way of marrying mutualfund investments to insurance coverage: Its customers bought fund shares, then borrowed against the shares to pay for life insurance.

title: Ruling in Cancer Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Supreme Court unanimously upheld today the Federal Government's authority to ban distribution of laetrile, the purported cancer cure.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Launch on Warning (LOW), advocated by Prof. Jerry F. Hough in his May 29 letter, is not the crass stupidity or suicidal option charged by two of your readers (letters June 5).

title: Ouster of deRoos Asked Over SubwayCar Flaws
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy and Stephen Berger, both board members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, called on fellow board members yesterday to remove John G. deRoos as senior executive officer of the city's masstransit system.

title: Sadat Calls on Khalil To Form New Cabinet Reflecting Vote Result
description: CAIRO, June 18 President Anwar elSadat instructed Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil today to form a new Cabinet, in the wake of the overwhelming election victory of the National Democratic Party.

title: Levi Strauss Lifts Net 46%
description: Levi Strauss & Company reported yesterday that profits surged 46 percent in the second fiscal quarter ended May 27 to a record $49.8 million, or $7.21 a share, compared with $30.7 million, or $1.39 a share, for the similar three months last year. Sales reached a new high of $494.5 million, up 30 percent from a year ago.

title: COMMODMES
description: Prices of grain and soybean futures came under pressure yesterday as traders holding large, recent paper profits liquidated positions in the face of several bearish news reoorts.

title: Down From the Summit Clouds
description: Watchinglimmy Carter through the summit rituals that culminated in Congress last night, we kept wondering whether the President had enough fuel for all the missiles he'd won the right to keep building under the next arms control treaty. This was, admittedly, a parochial, even frivolous response. But on the East Coast these last three days, a good portion of the President's prime television audience was sitting home against its will while a portion that wanted to watch him was out on the gasoline lines. All this speaks reams about the nation's preparedness and vulnerabilities, several of which SALT was supposed to fix. We half expected an agreement to limit missile loadings to alternate days  Trident I's and SS9's on odd days, Minuteman II's and SS18's on even. Unverifiable though this might be, it would at least aim to control arms to an extent that SALT II can't even pretend to do.

title: Off Off Broadway Theaters Terminate Equity Rules
description: After five years of what it says have been frustrating discussions, the Off Off Broadway Alliance has notified Actors Equity that as of yesterday its member theaters will no longer operate under an Equity showcase code that sets the conditions under which Equity actors work in Off Off Broadway productions. Some 60 theaters are involved.

title: The Alternative to Gas Pump Anarchy
description: First it was California: endless gas station lines, economic disaster for resorts, frayed tempers, even shootouts at the pumps. Now this rash has broken out in the East, forcing commuters around the District of Columbia to begin the search for fuel before dawn. New York has yet to feel the shortage so dramatically. But gas has become very hard to find on weekends, and the first serious symptoms of the new pathology have already appeared.

title: Notes on People
description: Patricia Hearst Shaw with husband, Bernard, yesterday in New YorkSteele of The Philadelphia Inauirer. As it happened, in the office one day with William Plummer, the magazine's book editor, was Clifford Irving, who got some mileage and time in jail with his ersatz Hughes autobiography a few years ago.

title: Beyond the Vienna Meeting
description: VIENNA, June 18  Whether the Vienna summit meeting has reversed the deterioration in relations between the United States and the Soviet Union or simply braked it is not yet clear. President Carter himself warned in a dinner Mood of the Talks Was Mature and the Prospect For Cooperation Appears Good on Several Points toast that cooperation or confrontation remained possible alternatives.

title: Swiss Club Denies Lemaire Will Get $172,000 Salary
description: SIERRE, Switzerland, June 18 (AP)  The vice president of the Sierre hockey club denied reports today that Jacques Lemaire, the new playercoach, would get a salary of $172,000 in his first year, starting Aug. 4.

title: Astros Defeat Mets In 18 Innings by 32
description: HOUSTON, June 18  In the longest game in the major leagues this season, the Houston Astros beat the Mets, 32, tonight, with an 18th inning single by Craig Reynolds. Reynolds's sharp drive down the rightfield line scored Julio Gonzalez, a pinchrunner, with the winning run exactly five hours after the game began.

title: Europe Cites Plan To Curb Oil Prices
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 18 (AP) Common Market energy ministers unveiled today a major proposal to curb oil prices by registering and publishing transactions of petroleum products and said that if America and Japan did not cooperate, Europe might have to create its own oil exchange.

title: House Votes to Place Inspectors. At All Nuclear Generating Plants
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)  The House voted overwhelmingly today to require the presence of Federal safety inspectors at all American nuclear power facilities, but refused to halt construction of plants in states that do not have evacuation plans.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Details

title: From Golding, First Novel in 12 Years
description: It has been 12 years since the British writer William Golding, author of the memorable Lord of the Flies, has had a novel published. But such are the psychological turnings and twistings of a writer's creative life that Mr. Golding has not only'completed one novel, Darkness Visible, which Farrar, Straus & Girouxwill publish early next year, but he has also finished the first draft or most of it of another. About the second book, information is understandably meager, but Robert Giroux, who is Mr. Golding's editor, was willing to throw light on Darkness Visible.

title: 1,500 Firemen Attend L.I. Rites for Macy's Victim
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., June 18  Fifteen hundred firefighters from ladder companies in the city and volunteer forces throughout Nassau and Suffolk Counties paid tribute today to Walter J. Smith Jr., a 31yearold fireman who died last Thursday fighting the fouralarm blaze at Macy's department store.

title: Drama Is Used to Aid Mentally Ill
description: THE world of the theater and the world of the mental hospital seem far apart, too far apart ever to meet. In fact, they are linked in an unusual therapeutic endeavor that will mark its 10th anniversary in September.In the Imagination Workshop, as the project is called, actors and actresses use the techniques of their craft to help seriously ill mental patients. The program of. theatrical exercises, improvisations and skits is not therapy, but it appears to have therapeutic effects.

title: Albany Clears Cut In Mutual Fund Tax
description: ALBANY, June 18  The New York State Legislature has quietly approved a bill that would in effect repeal the state's corporate tax on mutual funds.

title: Soviet Lifts Its Secrecy On Arms Designations
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  Breaking with tradition, the new strategic arms treaty includes the Soviet Union's own designations for its new generation of missile systems.

title: Hal Trosky, Played at First Base For Indians, White Sox Till 1946
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, June 18 (UPI) Hal Trosky, former slugging first baseman for the Cleveland Indians and Chicago White Sox, died today of a heart ailment. His age was 66.

title: A Victory for Hebtoski
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Supreme Court ruled today that a bribery prosecution of a member of Congress could not include any evidence that refers to the Congressman's past support of bills in exchange for money.

title: Letters
description: The column The Doctor's World on May 1, devoted to the Oath of Hippocrates, failed to recognize a major purpose of reciting the Hippocratic Oath.

title: Market Place
description: THE pressure is building for a decision on the Securities and Exchange Commission's complaint in the Sun CompanyBecton, Dickinson takeover struggle. The S.E.C. has charged that Sun made a tender offer without complying with Federal rules in acquiring 35 percent of Becton.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOUND AND SIGHT The warmweather concerts in the sculpture garden of the Whitney Museum are a pleasant diversion on the upper East Side these Wednesdays through Fridays from 5:30 to 7:15 P.M. The sounds are soothing, the setup is delightful and prices are reasonable.

title: PANEL ON TALMADGE REACHES CROSSROADS
description: WASHINGTON, June,18  The Senate inquiry into the financial affairs of Senator Herman E. Talmadge will reach an important crossroads tomorrow when the Select Committee on Ethics considers whether the evidence of wrongdoing presented thus far against the Georgia Democrat is sufficient to warrant a continuation of the investi2ation.

title: Blues: Julius Hemphill
description: IN Julius Hemphill's music, pitch is relative and flexible, blues feeling is almost always present, improvising soloists are able to move freely into areas that interest them, and rhythmic structures tend to be very sharolv defined. In recent years, Mr. Hemphill has explored several different areas, including overdubbed solos recordings in which he plays dialogues with himself, but the paradigm of his musical ethos is still Dogon A.D., a piece he recorded in 1972. His concert at the Public Theater on Saturday night was a kind of reinvestigation of this paradigm, using two of the musicians from the original recording. He performed Dogon A.D. itself at the end of the set, but by that time one was ready to hear it alto. gether differently.

title: There's Hot Air to Spare at Harbor Affair
description: The balloon never did go up yesterday.

title: BEIRUT SENDS ARMY TO SUBDUE SUBURBS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 18  The Lebanese Army moved today to restore the Government's authority in Beirut's troubled southeastern suburbs after fierce fighting there between rival Christian militia forces.

title: Uniroyal Agrees to 3 Year Accord, Paving Way for Industry Settlement
description: FAIRLAWN, Ohio, June 18  Uniroyal Inc. and the United Rubber Workers reached tentative agreement early this morning on a threeyear contract, ending a sixweek strike and paving the way for the union and major tire makers in the United States to conclude negotiations by late next week involving 58,000 workers.

title: U.S. Orchestras Granted $10.8 Million
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has distributed $10.8 million for the support of American symphony orchestras during the 1979.80 season. This is $1.6 million more than the previous year and the lamest sum granted so far by the endownient in the symphony. field. The total disbursement includes $2.3 million from private matching sources, which are funneled through the agency.

title: Independent Truckers Calling National Work Stoppage
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  Leaders of the independent truckers called for a nationwide work stoppage at midnight Wednesday after a meeting today with a Presidential adviser failed to produce any immediate solutions to their fuel problems and other grievances.

title: News Summary
description: The new arms treaty was signed in Vienna by President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader. Mr. Carter, seeking to sustain the momentum, flew home at once to address Congress and urge Senate approval of the pact. Mr. Brezhnev said the new treaty went far beyond the first nucleararms limitation pact signed in Moscow in 1972 in imposing equal numerical ceilings and limits on qualitative improvements in longrange bombers and missiles. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Loser of Primary in Philadelphia Drops His Fight for New Election
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (UPI) Charles Bowser, who was defeated in the primary election for the Democratic nomination for Mayor two months ago, has ended his fight for a new election.

title: House Approves Funds To Finish Tellico Dam
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)  The House voted today to provide funds to complete the Tellico Dam in Tennessee if the project's backers win their battle with the snail darter.

title: PASSENGERS SURVIVE CAPE COD AIR CRASH:
description: David Graham of Massachusetts Aeronautical Commission examining crumpled nose of Air New England twinengine plane after it crashed in woods near Yarmouthport, Mass., on Cape Cod. The pilot died in the crash, but nine passengers survived with varying degrees or injuries. Senator Edward M. Kennedy had been a passenger on plane's immediate previous flight, from Hyannis, Mass., to New York. On return flight, to New Bedford, Mass., plane was diverted to Cape Cod by dense fog.

title: Q&A
description: Q.What is the content of bones that allows them to remain intact for thousands or millions of years?

title: Radio
description: 74 A.M., WNCN. The Bartered  Bride, Overture, Smetana; Rule Britannia with Variations, Latour; 6 Country Dances (K. 606), Mo. zart; Waltz, The Grenadiers, Waldteufel; Euryanthe: Hunting Chorus, Weber; Suggestion diabolique, Prokofiev; Carmen: Intermezzo from Suite No. 1, Bizet.

title: The Dance: Anthony. Theater
description: MARY ANTHONY has long been one of the most quietly influential of New York moderndance teachers. On Sunday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, it was her turn in the spouignt, ana tier wenDaiancea ana polished program and the fine dancers of the Mary Anthony Dance Theater proved that those oldfashioned virtues of craftsmanship and professionalism can be a lot more vibrant than they sound.

title: Midwives: Acceptance Is Growing Nationwide
description: LOS ANGELES, June 16  Leigh Kilgore, a 29yearold librarian, expects to deliver her first child next month in the alternative birth center of San Francisco's Mt. Zion Hospital. Tekoa King, nurse:. midwife, rather than a physician, will be on hand to assist.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AFRICAN COMET (Farrell Lines). Azores June 24, Casablanca 28, Alicante July 2, Tunis 4, Barcelona Alexandria 13, Izmir 17, Salonika 20, Naples 23 and Casablanca 25; sails from Pler 11, Brooklyn.

title: Don. Mdon Dies at 66; Briton Wrote Column While Living in U.S.
description: Don Iddon, a United Statesbased British journalist whose weekly column Don Iddon's Diary appeared in newspapers, around the world for 20 years, died Sunday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan and Westhampton. L.I. tie wrote tor ine Daily Mail of London about America and Americans as seen through critical British eyes, and his column, which was also published in about 160 papers at its peak, periodically raised American hackles. The late Westbrook Pegler, a fellow columnist and passionate isolationist, devoted considerable space to attacking Mr. Iddon for his support of the United Nations.

title: President, Warning of Arms Race, Sets Theme for Debate on the Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  President Carter told a joint session of Congress tonight that the strategic arms limitation treaty he signed today in Vienna with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, would help prevent an uncontrolled and pointless nuclear arms race that would damage the security of all countries including our own.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on Peaceful Uses of Out Space10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Aging Seems to Vary by Nation
description: AN interesting sidelight on the aging process is the fact that signs of aging seem to vary among people living in different countries.

title: Lord & Taylor Planning Fashion Clearance Outlet
description: Lord & Taylor, in a highly unusual move for a quality, women's apparel specialty store chain, is planning to open a clearance center in about four weeks in Huntington, L.I.

title: Study Traces Progiess of Blacks Since 1790
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Bureau of the Census today issued a statistical portrait of the uneven progress of blacks in America since 1790.

title: Arms Pact Faces Senate Challenge In the Fall and an Uncertain Fate
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The strategic arms treaty concluded today with the Soviet Union now faces long deliberation, with an uncertain future, in the United States Senate.

title: Subwaycar Problem: Reliability and Cost
description: The cracks that have developed in onethird of the undercarriages, or trucks, of 754 of the Transit Authority's new subway cars appear to be evidence of faulty engineering, faulty materials, faulty manufacturing procedures, faulty testing or all four.

title: Events Today
description: THE PRICE by Arthur Miller; directed by John Styx; starrino Joseph Buie, Mitchell Ryan, Fritz Weaver and Scotty Bloch. At the Playhouse Theater, 359 West 48th Street, 6:15.

title: Caracas Plans Oil Outlays
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 18 (UPI)  The Venezuelan state oil monopoly, Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., plans to spend $25.3 billion in a 10year investment program, according to Julio Cesar Arreaza, company vice president, who made the announcement over the weekend in releasing the company's 1978 annual report. He also said that 1978 net earnings were about $1.4 billion, compared with $1.7 billion year earlier.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, June 19.(AP)  President Carter has obtained an option to buy the 15 percent share of his brother, Billy, in the family peanut business in Plains between now and January 1981, court records show.

title: Seewagen Wins Net Final
description: Butch Seewagen won the New York State men's clay tennis title for the fifth time yesterday. He defeated Carlos Lando of Brazil, 64, 76, in the final at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

title: Rivera Sketches Shown
description: DETROIT, June 19  The original sketches for Diego Rivera's massive mural depicting Detroit's rising industrial empire were proudly unveiled by the Detroit Institute of Arts today, and the fanfare was a far cry from the howls that greeted the Mexican Communist's work at its unveiline in 1933.

title: Books of The Times
description: HAS Bloomsbury been written about so much that even the distinguished biographer Leon Edel can't rescue the subject from stale'ess? I'm afraid that is the case, as Mr. Edel himself seems to have anticipated in his Preface to Bloomsbury: A House of Lions, in which he explains how, having planned some 15 or 20 years ago to treat the group in a series of biographical essays, he found, when he had finally completed his fivevolume biography of Henry James, that there had been such an outpouring of Bloomsbury biographies, letters, memoirs, diaries, posthumous papers, bedroom histories and critical writings  a vertitable deluge  that he would have to alter his project to an account of the story of Bloomsbury and how it came to be.

title: Space Shuttle's Flight Along Suborbital Path Is Weighed by NASA
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)  On its maiden voyage, the space shuttle may make only a suborbital flight to the edge of space and back to earth instead of twoday orbit of the earth, the dirctor of the shuttle project said today.

title: WINE TALK A Calm Look at Sulfur Dioxide
description: IS the sulfur used in wine dangerous? Recently, an importer of Italian wines, Villa Banfi, of Farmingdale, N.Y., took a fullpage advertisement in The New York Times warning that even moderate consumers of French wine were being exposed to up to three or four times the daily maximum dose of sulfur dioxide as set by the World Health Organization. Anyone drinking a bottle of wine a day could be ingesting far more, the advertisement said.

title: A Nuclear Financing Sells Well
description: In a fresh test of the credit market's attitude toward nuclear financing, the Washington Public Power Supply System sold $150 million of tripleA revenue bonds yesterday, and investors quickly purchased most of them by late afternoon.

title: Notes on People
description: Baron Enrico diPortanova and his wife, Sandra, yesterday filed a $200 million damage suit against ABCTV in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, maintaining that, as a result of an ABC news report about them, their very lives are endangered.

title: Schlesinger Memo Cited
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)Representative Toby Moffett, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that heating oil in the Northeast could be in such short supply this winter that people might have to abandon their homes and flock tb public centers to keep warm.

title: Music: Newman's Bach
description: ANTHONY NEWMAN'S ideas about Baroque performance practice are well known, and he applied them vigorously at Monday night's Basically Bach concert in Avery Fisher Hall. Presiding at the harpsichord and assisted by eight friends, Mr. Newman made the sparks fly in four works: the Clavier Concertos in D minor and F, a Trio Sonata in C and the Brandenburg Concerto No. 5.

title: U.S. Backs British Call for Talks on Vietnam Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  The United States has decided to Join with Britain in seeking an early international conference, probably a meeting of the Security Council next month, to bring world pressure on Vietnam to stop forcing its ethnic Chinese population to flee by the thousands, Administration officials said today.

title: ODDEVEN GAS SALES BEGIN FOR THE AREA ON JERSEY PARKWAY
description: An oddeven system of gasoline sales went into effect yesterday on the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey as a prelude to imposition, of the plan today throughout the New York metropolitan area.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 20,1979

title: Outlook Gloomier In Business Survey
description: Corporate executives have become less confident about the outlook for the nation's economy than they were a year ago, according to the results of a survey released yesterday by the Conference Board.

title: The Region
description: A father and stepson from Cincinnati, wanted on charges of taking nearly $400,000 yesterday from the Wells Fargo truck on which they worked, were captured early this morning in Rochester where, armed with M16 rifles, they had barricaded themselves in a house.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: SO many people are leery of food additives and of excess fat that the very thought of a sausage is enough to fill them with dread, and the eating of it fills them with guilt.

title: Judge, Defending His Move, Issues Minimum Sentence in Murder Case
description: Declaring that this court can't be whore and impose a sentence which will please the public, State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts yesterday gave a defendant the minimum sentence of 15 years to life for the murder of a 20yearold man in October 1977.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar in Sharp Decline As Gold Prices Advance
description: The United States dollar fell sharply against major currencies in Europe yesterday as gold prices rose. Foreignexchange dealers said European central banks did not intervene to aid the American currency.

title: Daniel Daly, 74, Dies; Had Been Police Chief Of Housing Authority
description: Daniel J. Daly, a former chief of the Housing Authority police in New York City, died Monday of a heart attack at Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived in Bayside. Oueens.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, doubleheader. at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, first game, 5:30 P.M. (Television  Cablevision, 5:30 P.M. Radio WINS, 5:30 P.M.)

title: Tenacious Is Victor In Race to Newport
description: NEWPORT, R.I. June 19  The Atlanta Braves, his baseball team, remain in last place but Ted Turner and his yacht, Tenacious, were in first place today as the AnnapolistoNewport ocean race went into its concluding hours.

title: Main Lafrentz Planning Merger With. Hurdman
description: Main Lafrentz & Company, the nation's 10thlargest accounting firm, and Hurdman and Cranstoun, the 15th largest, announced yesterday tentative plans to merge.

title: The City
description: Fire officials said yesterday that human failure in overlooking a valve that should have been opened was the reason Macy's sprinkler system did not operate during a fire last Thursday. One fireman was killed and 14 persons were injured in the blaze.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: F I were to name the one ingredient that is often elaborately overcooked in American kitchens, it would certainly be shrimp. It is beyond me how any, home cook and certainly any professional chef refuses to understand that only the briefest simmering, a minute or two, is all that is needed to keep the texture of shrimp firm and intact In addition to requiring so short a cooking time, shrimp happen to be one of the world's great food delicacies and should have a special appeal for those who must  or prefer  to cook in a brief time period. I can recall several happy midsummer occasions dining on a shrimp feast with family and friends. It was generally out of doors at a table covered with newspapers, with only a hot butter and lemon sauce for dipping the shrimpsteamed with beer and seasoning  after they were peeled.

title: Carter Sends Congress Trade Bill for Approval
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 President Carter formally sent Congress today a bill that would implement the new round of international trade liberalization agreed on by major industrial nations after years of neeotiation.

title: Fuel Hopes Spur Dynalectron
description: MCLEAN, Va.  The current petroleum shortfall and renewed interest in synthetic fuels have made the stock of Dynalectron, a small suburban Washington concern with a coaltooil process, one of the hottest issues on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Industry Experts Say Heating Oil Will Cost 80 and May Run Short
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  Consumers will pay far more for heating oil next winter, but supplies may still run short, according to experts in the oil industry.

title: Dr. Franz J. Polgar, 79, Hypnotist
description: Dr. Franz J. Polgar, a leading hypnotist, died yesterday in a nursing home in Miami after an illness resulting from brain tumor. He was 79 years old and lived in Mamaroneck. N.Y.. and Florida.

title: The New York Times
description: The Gertz department store in Jamaica, Queens, will probably be closed next year, Thomas M. Macioce, president of the Allied Stores Corporation, the parent company, said yesterday.

title: Venezuela Oil Output
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 19 (UPI)  Production of crude oil in Venezuela through June 13 averaged 2.34 million barrels a day, the Energy and Mines Ministry said in its latest weekly newsletter released today. The figure represented an increase of 16 percent over daily production in the similar period last year, the ministry said. Daily crude oil production for all of 1978 averaged 2.17 million barrels, the ministry said.

title: 15 JURY CANDIDATES INDICTED ON BRIBES
description: Fifteen Manhattan residents were indicted yesterday on charges that they had paid bribes of $10 to $200 to avoid jury duty. They included bushiessrnen, stockbrokers and members:of the entertainment bidustrv.

title: Carey Asks Aid On New Amex
description: ALBANY, June 19Governor Carey proposed legislation today under which state agencies would develop and finance a $45 million headquarters for the American Stock Exchange in lower Manhattan.

title: Kuwaiti Oil Price Reportedly Rising
description: The national oil company of Kuwait reportedly informed its customers yesterday of a fundamental change in its pricing policy that will probably mean a $2.90abarrel increase to $19.30 a barrel.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Kaiser Cement Corporation filed suit yesterday charging top officials of the Florida Mining and Materials Corporation with violating securities laws to frustrate Kaiser's takeover bid.

title: $831 Million Cut Planned In Medicaid and Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Federal Government abruptly moved today to cut off $831 million in Medicaid and welfare funds to all 50 states to comply with what it said was a new interpretation of a law enacted last year to curb fraud and abuse.

title: Susan Vare, an Actress, Wed to David Liederman
description: Susan Richardson Vare, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. L. Anthony Richardson of Lake Charles, La., was married yesterday evening to David Liederman, son of Adele Kaplan of New York and Donald E. Liederman of Beverly Hills, Calif. State Supreme Court Justice Maxine K. Duberstein performed the ceremony at the Penthouse Club.

title: Tug Strike Talks Move Along
description: Negotiations to end the tug strike crippling freight movement in New York Harbor picked up steam as they shifted to the executive committee level yesterday, the 80th day of the walkout. Talks between the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association and United Marine Division Local 333 of the International Longshoremen's Association continued to progress, but sources close to the scene said several major, key issues still remained. The talks had moved on to economic items after a tentative accord on the question of job security.

title: Careers
description: THE management consulting field has been growing rapidly in recent years. Billings have been increasing by 20 to 25 percent a year, according to some estimates. Even allowing for inflation it seems safe to put the increase at 15 nercent a year.

title: Deaths
description: FAKRELLMabel C. June 18, 1979. Beloved wife of the late Sgt. John Howard. Devoted and beloved mother of Genevieve Danzl, beloved grandmother of Jennifer. Brian, Amanda and Michael Danz. Dee rest sister of Lucille Murphy, Alfred, Edith, William, and Emma. Olga Cutillo. Also survived by 9 nieces and nephews and 21 great nieces and nephews. Reposing at The Thomas J. Reynolds Funeral Home, 15814 Northern Blvd, Flushing. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 9:30AM at St. Andrew's Avollino RC Church.Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Life of Georgia Sold
description: The Life Insurance Company of Georgia said yesterday that its acquistion by Nationale Nederlanden N.V., a large Dutch insurance complex, had been completed. Life of Georgia said that 97 percent of its 6 million shares had been tendered to the Dutch company under its offer to pay $60 a share.

title: Ugandan Cabinet Shuffled Again In Effort to Strike Tribal Balance
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, June 19  President Yusufu K. Lule today announced the second major shakeup of his Cabinet in two weeks.

title: Carpet Outlook: Quiet Growth
description: GLASGOW, Va.  Gargantuan carpettufting,machines stand like woolly mammoths as yard after yard of undyed carpeting slowly streams out of their complicated gears, eventually winding into giant. rolls weighing half ton each.

title: A Good Principal on the Job
description: Gloria Johnson waits in the school gymnasium, a whistle around her. neck. In flat blue canvas shoes she.stands 5 foot 2, not much taller than the throng of fourth graders who surround her.

title: Preacher at End of Legal Trail on ChildCare Issue
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 19  Time appeared to have finally run out today for Brother Lester Roloff, the flamboyant radio preacher who has been fighting for nearly six years to keep his home for troubled teenagers free from state regulation.

title: U.S. Steel Gets Plant Permit
description: The United States Steel Corporation received a permit yesterday from the Army Corps of Engineers to build one of the world's largest steel mills on 2,800 acres along Lake Erie in northeastern Ohio. Construction affecting the shoreline requires Army approval.

title: U.S. Aides Say American Airlines Did Not Break Maintenance Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  Federal officials testified today that American Airlines not violate any rules when it changed its procedure for installing engine mounts of DC10 jumbo jets from the method recommended by the builder and aonroved by the Government.

title: Ballet: Soloists From the Royal Danish
description: THE sunniest choreography in New York can be seen at the City Center55th Street Theater, where soloists of the Royal Danish Ballet opened a twoweek season last night.

title: The New York Times/Joe McNally
description: IT takes more than a good teacher to teach about musical comedy, and even then. it takes someone special to make it sing. That is what Sylvia Fine Kaye has set about doing.

title: Mrs. Douglas Asks U.S. Cancer Funds
description: From the bedroom of her 12thfloor apartment overlooking Riverside Drive, Helen Gahagan Douglas, cancer victim, renewed an appeal yesterday for Federal financing for cancer research she personally pressed on the floor of Congress 33 years ago.

title: Expos Hand LaCoss Of Reds First Defeat
description: MONTREAL, June 19 (AP)  Bill Lee and Woodie Fryman combined on sixhitter and Lee contributed a runscoring single as the Montreal Expos beat the Cincinnati Reds, 32, tonight, handing Mike LaCoss his first defeat in nine decisions.

title: Added Oil Called Possible by Saudi
description: LONDON, June 19 (UPI) Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said today that he would not rule out the possibility that Saudi Arabia would increase oil production by one million barrels a day to help bring order to the world market.

title: AllisChalmers Acquisition
description: The AllisChalmers Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Barron Industries for an undisclosed amount. Barron, which operates in Birmingham and Leeds, Ala., employs 250 people and has annual sales of about $20 million. It makes heavyduty fans, dust collecto and heatrecovery and recycling eq pment.

title: The Art of Hollerin Is Still Resoundin in North Carolina
description: SPIVEY'S CORNER, N.C., June 16.  Well, now, yellin and hollerint are two different things, said H.H. Oliver, a towering, erect figure with the aspect of a Methodist deaCon. He looked thoughtful, adjusted the brim of his straw hat for emnhasis and want nn Yellin is just fussin', it's a quarrelsome thing. You holler because you want to. Makes you feel good.

title: Vote More, Get More?
description: ROCHESTER  President Carter seems to have discovered the tactic of blaming the victim in fending off criticism from blacks on the Administration's policies on racial equality and poverty.

title: KuwaitJapan Oil Cost Up
description: TOKYO, June 19 (UPI)  Kuwait has told the Japanese oil industry it will invoke a mostfavoredseller clause into its contracts retroactive to May 1, thereby raising its prices for heavy crude oil to as much as $19.31 a barrel, industry sources said today.

title: G.A.O. Critical Of Procedures
description: The General Accounting Office sharply criticized the Food and Drug Administration yesterday for the length of time it takes to approve new drugs, especially those considered therapeutically significant.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300: NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691900; CONNECTICUT (203) 3407767.

title: Thais on Refugees: West Must Take Them
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 18  The forcible expulsion of more than 50,000 Cambodian refugees from Thailand so far has provoked no public expressions of disapproval here.

title: Carey Lauds Randolph at Service
description: When he began his struggle, most people thought it was hopeless, Governor Carey said last night at memorial services for A. Philip Randolph, the black labor leader.

title: DC10'S ARE CLEARED BY EUROPE AIRLINES
description: ZURICH, June 19  The aviation authorities in a succession of countries cleared most of the 58 DC10's based in Europe to fly again. today, and the craft have already taken travelers to Israel and to Spanish resorts on the Mediterranean.

title: S.E.C. Sues 2 Concerns On Merger
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  In an unusual action, the Securities and Exchange Commission has filed suit against both the United Financial Corporation of California and the National Steel Corporation, accusing them of failing to disclose important information in connection with their proposed merger.

title: Art Expert Was Head of Institutes in Williamstown and Chicago and the Atheneum.
description: Charles C. Cunningham, former chief curator of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., died Sunday at the home of a son, Charles C. Cunningham Jr., in Brookline, Mass. He was 69 years old.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: The forecast is for sun in the morning and possibly showers in the afternoon. What to wear in summer when a raincoat is a nuisance? You might consider the attractive jumpsuits chic young women are snapping up at Bergdorf's. They're made of waterrepellant parachute cloth and come in cheerful colors such emerald green, bright red, yellow, blue, orange and black. The suits are equipped with Velcro fastenings at the bodice and the skinny legs; one merely adds a Tshirt to be dressed for the day. They're $75 on the sixth floor.

title: Deaths
description: SCHOENStanley. Adored husband and father died Monday June 18th at his home on Long Island. He Is survived by his wife Ramona, daughter Mildred Schoman, son Marc, and four grandchildren Matthew, Rachel and Jeremy Schoman and Cortney Schoen. Stanley also is survived by three sisters Sylvia Shields, Charlotte Kishner, Joan Shields and two brothers Seymour and Nanny Schoen. Funeral services will be held at Guttermans Funeral Home on Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury. LI. NY at 1 o'clock, Wednesday afternoon. June 20th.

title: The Myth of the Obstinate Amish
