description: To the Editor:

title: Koch Rules Out Small Additions To City's Budget
description: Asserting that these are not normal times; Mayor Koch vetoed yesterday $8.5 million in additions to his $12.8 billion budget that the Board of Estimate and City Council had agreed upon for the coming fiscal year.

title: 4 Players and 2 Writers Are Elected to Tennis Hall
description: Margaret Smith Court, Frank Sedgman and Jack Crawfor,d of Australia, the late Rafael Osuna of Mexico, and two writers, Gladys Heldman of Houston and Al Laney of Spring Valley, N.Y., were elected to the International Tennis Hall of Fame yesterday.

title: AkiiBua in West Germany To Consider Training Sites
description: HERZOGENAURACH, West Germany, June 20 (AP)  John AkiiBua, the Ugandan track star, is in West Germany to consider offers to train for the 1980 Moscow Olympics, his German sponsors said today.

title: Approval Given For Homosexual To Adopt a Boy
description: A homosexual minister, the Rev. John Kuiper of Catskill, N.Y., has been granted permanent custody of a 13-yearold boy he adopted a year ago.

title: Refugee Admitted by Japan Tells of Difficult Adjustment
description: KITAKYUSHU, Japan, June 20  Huu Loi Mai doubled up in a 90 degree bow that brought his head to the level of visitor's knees. The 36yearold Vietnamese refugee, straightening out of his Japanesestyle greeting, appeared worn and beaten man with hollow eyes and a slim, fragile looking body.

title: United Press International
description: SENATORS ATTEND SALTONSTALL SERVICE: Senators Claiborne Pell, left, Edward M. Kennedy and Paul E. Tsongas arriving at Harvard University Memorial Chapel yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., for a memorial service in honor of Leverett Saltonstall. he former Senator and Governor of Massachusetts died on Sunday.

title: Doubt Cast on Uranus Rings
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)  The nine narrow rings discovered circling the planet Uranus in March 1977 actually may be gaseous material trailing in the orbits of small natural satellites, according to an astronomer at the United States Naval Observatory.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Brown & Williamson Industries announced that the department store operations of the Kohl Corporation had been established as a separate division of the retail group and that William S. Kellogg had been appointed its president and chief executive officer.

title: Insider Reports for Exchanges
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Vietnam Approves Refugee Talks With Conditions
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 Vietnam has agreed to a proposed international conference on Indochinese refugees, but only if it deals with humanitarian, not political, considerations.

title: Amtrak to Ease Service Cutback
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) Transportation Secretary Brock Adams and Congressional leaders, reacting to a surge in train travel caused by gasoline shortages, agreed today to retain Some Amtrak system trains gist were slated for retirement. The Administration said it would provide an additional $65 million for the system.

title: Administration Wins Crucial Vote In the House on Panama Canal Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  The House of Representatives defeated an attempt tonight to cripple the legislation to carry out the Panama Canal treaties, giving President Carter a significant foreignpolicy victory.

title: CREDIT MARKETS U.S. Bills Sell at Average 8.83%
description: In another reflection of the recent decline in interest rates, the Treasury sold oneyear bills yesterday at an average rate of 8.83 percent, their lowest rate since October. The Government also announced plans to sell 15year bonds next Wednesday.

title: Florida Mining Favors Moore Offer
description: Directors of the the Florida Mining and Materials Corporation agreed unanimously yesterday to support a takeover bid by Moore McCormack Resources Inc. at $40 a share.

title: Americans Stepping Into Bedroom Farce
description: I THINK we're in imminent need of a hotwater bottle,. Robert Coote said to his wife, played by Mildred Natwick, as he lay in bed, on the stage of the Brooks Atkinson Theater a couple of days ago.

title: Bratflo
description: ANDERSOWMirlam C., of Great Neck on June 18, 1979. Beloved wife of George, devoted mother of Miriam T. Levings, Peter P. Smith III and Cora Lynn Andrews. Also survived by 11 grandchildren. Reposing Great Neck Funeral Home, Middle Neck Rd and Arrandale Ave, Great Neck. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Aloysius Church Friday 1 at 9:45 AM.Visiting hours 35 and 79 PM.

title: The Placid but Productive 202d Legislature
description: ALBANY, June 19  There was little drama, no threat of bankruptcy, no forthcoming elections for which to posture. But the 202d New York State Legislature, which ended nearly six months of passionless debate this week.

title: Bench Warmers and Shirtsleeves
description: Two Federal judges in the Southwest have decided to disobey President Carter's order to turn off the air conditioning until their courtroom temperatures reach 80 degrees. Not in their courts. Judge Joe Fisher, who sits in the sticky city of Beaumont, Tex., declared that 74 degrees was hot enough. The court and its person- nel, he explained, cannot possibly operate efficiently and effectively and without great discomfort under the arbitrary ruling of 80 degrees. Judge Edwin Mechem of Albuquerque ruled that no litigant before him could suffer more than 70.

title: Loan Rates Up in Japan
description: TOKYO, June 20 (AP)  The interest rates on business loans charged by 13 major Japanese commercial banks in May rose by 0.145 percentage point from April to 5.629 percent a year, the Bank of Japan said today. The monthly rise was the steepest since March 1974 and followed an April increase in the Japanese official discount rate from 3.5 percent to 4.25 percent. The rate is that at which commercial banks may borrow from the central bank.

title: Two Bowls Bring Ton Auction Prices
description: Two bowls auctioned in New York and Geneva yesterday set records for American silver and Art Nouveau. An outsized New York silver punch bowl sold at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, for 5103,UUU, tne highest price ever paid at auction for American silver. About the same time in Geneva at Christie, Manson & Woods, an Emile Galle bowl sold for $222,000, the highest ever paid at public sale for the French artist and for Art Nouveau.

title: Nuclear Device Tested
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., June 20 (UPI)A lowyield weaponsrelated nuclear device was detonated today 1,100 feet beneath the Nevada Test Site. The test, codenamed Chess, was not felt in Las Vegas 95 miles south of Yucca Flat and no radiation leaked into the atmosphere, Department of Energy spokesman said. Chess had a yield of less than 20,000 kilotons.

title: Merger Talks Fuel Eltra Stock
description: The Eltra Corporation rose more than 10 points to a record price yesterday as takeover developments once again dominated the spotlight on Wall Street.

title: Cabaret: Tasha Thomas
description: TASHA THOMAS'S Shoot Me (With Your Love) was one of the grittiest and most rousing disco records of the last year and will probably become a classic of erotic dance music. It was so good one wondered whether Miss Thomas would be able to butld a career on its success instead of falling prey to the one-hitwonder syndrome so prevalent in disco. An uneven but promising first album didn't really answer the question, and neither did Miss Thomas's appearance at the Bottom Line on Tuesday night.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) Hundreds of police officers, augmented by state troopers and Federal marshals, patrolled a southwest Philadelphia neighborhood today after three days of racial tension that flared with the fatal shooting of a black youth.

title: France Adopts New Plan To Cut Oil Consumption
description: PARIS, June 20  The French Government announced today a wideranging energy conservation program that will be presented at the upcoming economic summit meeting in Tokyo as a model for other nations to emulate.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices Reverse a Decision That Gave Land to Indians
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  The Supreme Court, in a decision with potential implications for disputes over Indian land ownership throughout the country, today set aside a lower courtruling that had given the Omaha Indian Tribe title to 2,900 acres of bitterly contested land along the Missouri River.

title: Details
description: MAIDENBAUMNathan. The officers and directors of the Hebrew Academy of Long Beach note with profound shock and sorrow the sudden passing of Nathan Maidenbourn, beloved father of Hadassah Schreiber, leading member of our Wonen's League and father-In-law of David Schreiber, our esteemed President. May the Almighty console the bereaved family with the mourners of Zion.

title: Bridge:
description: Two Safety Plays in a Deal Made by a Maryland Player

title: GemTheft Report Draws Doubts
description: The robbery of more than S2 million in jewels  diamonds, emeralds and other gems, both set and unset  was reported to the police yesterday by RAC Jewels, a jewelry- and goldbuying office at 630 Fifth Avenue between 50th and 61st Streets. Investigating detectives, however, later expressed doubt about the retort.

title: Spring Cleaning on Fifth Avenue
description: Using portable scaffolding, workmen washed the windows of a shop on Fifth Avenue yesterday as the facades of all the buildings along the famed thoroughfare were cleaned of the ravages of winter. The traditional sprucing up included a steamcleaning  a gift to the city by a maintenance company--of the promenade in front of the New York Public Library at 92d Street.

title: Produce Shortages and Price Rises Are Feared as Crops Spoil in South
description: ATLANTA, June 20  The bitter and violent truckers strike appears certain to have a modest to sharp impact on supermarket prices as some crops in the critical Southeastern agricultural sector begin to dry out and rot, and there is the prospect of far more serious damage within a week if the strike does not break.

title: Syrian Leader to Visit Soviet
description: DAMASCUS, June 20 (Reuters) President Hafez alAssad of Syria will pay a state visit to the Soviet Union late this month, the staterun Damascus radio said today. President Assad will hold talks on Middle East developments and relations between the two nations, the radio said.

title: Boxing Joins The Art Circle
description: It was a wedding of the arts  the lovely lyric art of Beverly Sills, the seemingly disembodied art of Mikhail Ba. ryshnikov, the savage art of Larry Holmes and Roberto Duran. It was a marriage made, in Madison Square Garden and solemnized in Walter Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center, the cultural hub of New York City.

title: Business Records
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 20, 1979

title: Malaysia Bars 585 New Refugees
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 20 (Reuters)  Six boats carrying 585 Vietnamese refugees trying to land in Malaysia have been towed back out to sea in the last two days, Malaysian officials said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Saudi Prince Bars OilOutput Rise; Big OPEC Price Increase Indicated
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, June 20 Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia said in an interview today that the Saudi Government had no plans to raise oil production above the present rate of 8.5 million barrels a day  now or at any time soon.

title: Ethiopia's Black Jews
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y.  In the rugged,,isolated villages of Ethiopia live 28,000 blaCk JeWs who are being annihilated. They are called Falashas, which paeans strangers or exiles. They are caught between revolution and civil war.

title: A Summer Celebration Of City's Open Spaces
description: A summerlong celebration of outdoor publid places is planned by the CooperHewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design. Immovable Objects III, Urban Open Spaces will be launched Tuesday as part of the Museum Mile street festival, which will .close off Fifth Avenue from 82d to 105th Streets from 7 to 9 P.M.

title: Court Summons Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, June 20 (Reuters) Foimer Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and five others were ordered today to appear before a court on July 18 on charges that they conspired to induce businessmen to supply 139 jeeps without payment for use in the 1977 elections.. Mrs. Gandhi is already being charged in another case with falsely prosecuting four officials inquiring into a business deal involving her son, Sanjay. In each case, Mrs. Gandhi and the others face a maximum sentence of seven years jail if convicted.

title: Met's Holbeins Back on View
description: Portraits by Hans Holbein the Younger and paintings by Lucas Cranach are among works in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art that are on display again in seven newly installed galleries. The museum has been refurbishing its European paintings galleries. These seven rooms are devoted to art of the Northern Renaissance and of 14th- and 15thcentury Italy.

title: DC1,0's Maker, Citing Adequacy Of Tests, Urges End to Grounding
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  The mEinufacturer of the DC10 jumbo jet told House hearing today that there was no reason to keep the domestic DC10 fleet grounded because inspections of engine mounts were fullyadequate to prevent a repetition of the crash in Chicago last month:

title: NICARAGUANS OPEN A COUNTEROFFENSIVE AGAINST INSURGEND,
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 20 President Anastasio Somoza Debayle, who is under international pressure to accept a political solution to the civil war, has opened a counteroffensive against guerrillas seeking his overthrow.

title: Skylab Shifted in Orbit To Help Control Reentry
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  The doomed Skylab space station was maneuvered by ground command today into a slightly different position, which space agency officials said would give them greater flexibility in controlling where the vehicle will reenter the earth's atmosphere.

title: Judge Orders Stamford Reporter To Disclose Confidential Sources
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 20 (AP) A judge has ordered a Connecticut newspaper reporter to identify some of his sources for a story that prompted a libel suit by a former Connecticut State Senator, William E. Strada Jr.

title: Cuba Impugns U.S. Motives
description: MIAMI, June 20 (AP)  In a broadcast monitored here, Cuba charged today that the United States wanted to establish a military presence in Nicaragua and said such a move could create a Vietnam in the very heart of Latin America.

title: FiveDay Harbor Festival 1979 Shapes Up
description: Vestiges of the city's monumental 1976 Bicentennial harbor celebration, Operation Sail, will highlight this year's Harbor Festival 1979. It will be a fiveday affair involving cruise ships and power boats, symphonies and jazz, ballets and hoedowns, parachutists, amusement rides and fireworks. All of these events will pop up around the city from June 30 through July 4.

title: Import Fears Downgraded
description: PARIS, June 20  Western industrial governments are exaggerating their fears that imports from emerging industrialized countries of the third world will undermine their domestic markets, according to a report released today by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Elise Bailen, 62, Former Member Of Boards of Community Centers
description: Elise Bailen, a member of the board of the United Neighborhood Houses and of the James Weldon Johnson Community Centers Inc., in East Harlem, died of cancer Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: About Muttontown
description: MUTTONTOWN, L.I., June 19  The thoroughbred stallion was led out by a stablehand to prance before the tall blond woman in the summer straw hat, a stylish human who stared at the horse as he reared and whinnied. The woman

title: 43,952 See Kicks Defeat Cosmos
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 20 The Cosmos have lost two games in a row for the first time since the second week in July of 1977.

title: OilSale Registration Pressed by Europe
description: PARIS, June 20  Guido Brunner, Energy Commissioner of the Europea Economic Community, discussed details today of the Common. Market's proposal for a worldwide register of all petroleum transactions. The plan is to be presented next week at the economic summit conference in Tokyo of seven maior industrial nations.

title: U.S. Eases Pension Investing
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  The Labor Department made it clear today that the Employee Retirement Income Safety Act is not intended to discourage the investment of private pension funds in small or new businesses or other lesstraditional ventures.

title: Drugs on a Harlem Block Drive Parents to Despair
description: The kids on this block don't jump rope, play handball or hopscotch, an angry Harlem parent said recently, because the streets and the sidewalks are filled with people buying and selling drugs.

title: Protests From U.S. Jews Stir Controversy in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, June 20  The reaction of American Jews to the establishment of new Israeli outposts in densely populated Arab areas in the West Bank has become a major topic in Israel's press during the last few days.

title: Big Board Seeks Futures Market
description: The New York Stock Exchange, the nation's largest equities market, said yetterday that it had asked the Government's permission to offer trading in commodity futures through a new unit, the New York Futures Exchange.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 21, 1979

title: FRANK DUN SCHATZMAN
description: Frank Dun Schatzman, who had served as the county clerk of Middlesex County, NJ., from 1963 until his retirement last April, died Tuesday at his home in Highland Park, N.J. He was 75 years old and had lived in Highland Park for 40 years. Mr. Schatzman is survived by his wife, the former Ruth Silberman; two sons, Frederick of Great Falls, Va., and Richard of Highland Park, and two grandchildren.

title: Harris Plans to Buy Consolidated Video
description: MELBOURNE, Fla., June 20 (AP) The Harris Corporation said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement to buy Consolidated Video Systems Inc. for $13 million in cash.

title: Taiwan to Buy in U.S.
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 20 (UPI)  A 26member delegation from Taiwan will leave here June 27 to purchase $900 million worth of industrial and agricultural products in the United States, Official sources said today. Their purchases will include $150 million worth of nuclearcower ReneratinE facilities. $17 million worth of oildrilling equipment, $200 million in grains and $350 million for three Boeing passenger planes and one cargo plane.

title: Dr. Harry E. Rauch, 53; Mathematics Professor
description: Dr. Harry E. Rauch, Distinguished Professor of Mathematics at the Graduate School of the City University of New York, died Monday at his home in White Plains. He was 53 years old.

title: Franklin Is Grounded By Trainer
description: Bud Delp said yesterday that he was grounding Ron Franklin until the 19yearold jockey explains the circumstances of his arrest in Anaheim, Calif., on Monday on drug charges.

title: Truckers
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 20 Communication on a highw,ay.is a little like conversation at a crowded cocktail party. Strangers drift into range and converse  using, in this situation, their ciitikens band radios  and

title: Hartnett's Team Wins Golf on 58
description: HARRISON, N.Y., June 20  In the quiet of the first green of the Westchester Country Club at 8:30 this morning, two robins were pecking away at the wellmanicured grass.

title: GARDENING Overgrown Shrubs: Prune Now
description: MANY gardens this year do not seem to be what they used to be. Vegetables are not thriving. Flowers are developing slowly. The ground is damp. Hedges look rank and untidy.

title: ABC Reporter and Aide Killed By Soldier in Nicaraguan Capital
description: Bill Stewart, a television correspondent for ABCTV, and his Nicaraguan interpreter were shot to death today by a Nicaraguan soldier in Managua, the Nicaraguan capital.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our large upstairs bedroom adtwo joins our tenant's living room, the two being separated by a drywall with about a twoinch space in its middle. Sounds transmit so easily through this well that we can hear their television, even their conversation, as though we were in the same room. My husband is not an expert carpenter, but he is handy. Can you give us some suggestions as to what we can do to stop the transmission of sounds from one room to the other? M.N., Buffalo, N.Y.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 20, 1979

title: The City
description: The deputy chancellor of the New York City public school system said yesterday that two public schools scheduled for possible closing over the next two years would remain open because they had achieved the highest academic ratings in their districts.

title: Barefoot Girl, 12, Wins 1,500
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 20 (AP)  A 12yearold barefoot Kenyan girl stole the thunder from an international field today when she won the women's 1,500meter race at the first Jomo Kenyatta invitation meet.

title: 24 Food Establishments Named Health Violators
description: The New York City Department of Health named 24 food establishments yesterday that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named two restaurants that had corrected earlier violations and three restaurants that had reopened after correcting earlier violations.

title: Working With a Landscape Architect
description: IF you are planning a landscaping project that is expected to cost more than a few hundred dollars (the cost of a single shade tree), a landscape designer, employed by most large nurseries, may be able to offer valuable advice, usually free. But if the landscaping is complicated by such things as poor drainage or a longrange plan to add a swimming pool, a landscape architect is the likeliest professional to consult. Although generally associated with park and estate planning, many landscape architects specialize in small residential designs and some charge only $15 fora house call.

title: Justice Defends California Court's Closed Sessions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 20  Justice Mathew 0. Tobriner, a central figure in the disputes that led to an investigation of the California Supreme Court, testified today that he believed whatever the justices said in their weekly conferences should be held in sacred confidence.

title: Texas Preacher Concedes Defeat on Refuge
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 20 Conceding that all was lost, Brother Lester Roloff stood under a broiling South Texas sun today and waited for the state Welfare Department to arrive to close down the home for troubled children that he has operated here for the last dozen years.

title: New YorkChicago Jet Hijacked; Passengers Free, It Returns Here
description: CHICAGO, June 20  The American Airlines jet was hijacked over Flint, Mich., about 11:20 A.M. by a man identified by law enforcement officials as Nikola Kajava, 45 years old, of Paterson, N.J. He allegedly burst into the cockpit carrying several bags that he said contained plastic explosives.

title: Rangel Resisting Hospital Closings
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem said yesterday that he had asked the Justice Department to enjoin Mayor Koch from carrying out his planned municipalhospital closings and cutbacks.

title: Clashing YugoslavAmericans Studied by Grand Jury
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  A Federal grand jury in New York has opened a nationwide investigation of violence and extortion among groups in the YugoslavAmerican community, that have been connected to four deaths in less than a year and numerous other acts of terrorism. Government officials said today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: British BOC Finds Chief At Trans Atlantic Unit

title: $50 Billion Production Of Synthetic Fuel Urged
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  Shifting his focus from New York City finances to nationwide energy. problems, Felix G. Rohatyn today proposed the creation of a Governmentsponsored corporation to issue $50 billion in bonds for the developmerit of synthetic fuel from coal, shale and tar sands.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table accompanying the Market Place column in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the latest quarterly results of the General Tire and Rubber Company. The company earned 53 cents a share in the quarter. Also, a report in Business Day last Saturday on the Novo Corporation reversed the financial results for 1977 and 1978. Corrected results are included in today's report on company earnings, which appears on Page D4.

title: Hers
description: IT'S finished, says Maude Gallavante. It's all over  steamer trunks; shipboard romance, dinner at the captain's table. Maude is so distinguished in her faded Portuguese skirt and frayed peasant sandals. There is significant disdain for the present about her white hair twisted into a crown of Scandinavian braids. Wonderful figure still. Long brown legs stretched out on a chaise under the maple tree. One of the great travel snobs, she has come to rest, finally, in her own backyard.

title: Musical B.B.
description: B.B., a onewoman musical about the pains of being an emigrant, starring the Rumanian actress Helene Cara, will open Monday at the Academy Arts Theater, 931 First Avenue. The production is adapted by Miss Cara from works by Benoit Brecht and Kurt Weil. Jared Walker will do the musical arrangements.

title: Charlotte Seitlin Is Dead at 72; An Editor for Simon &
description: Charlotte Seitlin, a former editor with Simon & Schuster, died of a brain tumor yesterday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 72 years old and lived in New York City and Weston, Conn.

title: Associated Press
description: BATTLING GRASSHOPPERS IN SOUTH DAKOTA: Jerry Ireland watching a cropduster spraying a field covered with grasshoppers on his ranch near Belvidere, S.D. With as many as 200 Insects per square yard in some areas, officials are saying infestation may be the worst since the 1930's.

title: Notes on People
description: Hemingway's Son Finds Someone Unexpected in Paris

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Peter A. Magowan has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of Safeway Stores, the nation's largest supermarket chain, with almost 2,500 stores and annual sales of $12.6 billion. Effective Jan. 1, 1980, he will succeed William S. Mitchell, whO will retire at the age of 65.

title: A Calendar of Who 's Playing, Where and When
description: A schedule of events follows for the Newport Jazz Festival, which begins today and continues until July 1. Included are days, times, places, performers and ticket prices. For further information, call 7872020..

title: Thorpe Jury Spends 2d Day Considering Its Verdict
description: LONDON, June 21  The jury considering the case against Jeremy Thorpe spent a second day deliberating today without reaching a verdict.

title: Rising Food Costs Cause an Upsurge In Freezer Sales
description: On the theory that a pound of meat in the freezer may soon be worth two on the hoof, shoppers have begun what is expected to be a prolonged homefreezer buying binge. The surge in sales has created some spot shortages and manufacturers predictions of a boom year.

title: Baker Informs Carter He Cannot Back Pact Without Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate Republican leader, told President Carter today that he could snot support the strategic arms treaty unless it was amended.

title: Topics
description: OddEven Summer

title: Officials Unable To Gain Accord On Koch Vetoes
description: The Board of Estimate and the City Council were unable to reach agreement last night on overriding any of Mayor Koch's 11 vetoes of $8.5 million in additions to his $12.8 billion municipal budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1.

title: Status of Jersey ReliWous Enclav nconsfitutional
description: OCEAN GROVE, N.J., June 21 Ocean Grove, a seaside sanctuary for Methodists where strict seligious tenets have, for over a century, prohibited  wide variety of activities on Sundays, including swimming, was today declared an unconstitutional creation of the state.

title: U.S. Aides Ask a Halt To Spraying Paraquat, Citing Smoker Hazard
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  Federal health officials have concluded that paraquat, the herbicide used to kill marijuana plants, may seriously harm the lungs of smokers and have suggested that spraying of Mexican fields be stopped.

title: Mondale to Visit China in August For Talks on a Range of Subjects
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)  Vice President Mondale will make an official visit to China in late August as President Carter's personal representative, the White House announced today.

title: Rep. Anderson Asserts He Is Only Moderate In Republican Contest
description: Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois declared yesterday that he was the only moderate Republican in the race for his, party's Presidential nomination despite the claims of other contenders such as Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. and George Bush to the center of the political svectrum.

title: Business Records
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 21, 1979

title: Picasso Show to Fill Modern Museum
description: THE LARGEST PICASSO EXHIBITION ever displayed in the United States will arrive at the Museum of Modern Art in May. Show will include over 700 works, in all of the late artist's media, including; SelfPortrait, above, and Still Life on a Pedestal Table. Page C23.

title: Critic's Notebook: The Screenwriters
description: JOHN GREGORY DUNNE and Joan Didion are a formidable team, whether they're writing movies (they have collaborated on screenplays) or writing about them (both Mr. Dunne and Miss Didion, his wife, include essays about Hollywood in their most recent books). They are most formidable of all when eviscerating anyone who writes about films without firsthand. knowledge of how they are made. Much of what is written about pictures and about picture people approaches reality only occasionally and accidentally, notes Miss Didion in her new book, The White  Album. Or, as Mr. Dunne puts it, in Quintana and Friends': One does not set out in life to become a movie critic; it is where one ends up.

title: Enigmatic Leader of the Truckers
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  Although he has been described as a leader of the independent truck drivers now disrupting traffic across thg country, William John Hill is, by his own account, a general in search of an army.

description: Shift to an Economic Role Is Outlined at Forum

description: FLYING TIGER: Detroit's Mark Wagner sailing over Butch Hobson of Red Sox to complete fourthinning double play Wednesday in Boston. Red Sox defeated Tigers, 133.

description: HE trial and conviction of Alger Hiss is slowly taking on the character of another famous trial, that of Sacco and Vanzetti, in the sense that it will not go away. Every time a book comes out designed to establish Mr. Hiss's guilt or innocence once and for all, the arguinent simply heats  ni) all over aeain. The release of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's files on the Hiss case was supposed to clear matters up; but readers will recall the furor kicked up by the publication last year of Allen

title: Meet Entry For Maree Is Reiected
description: Sydney Maree's entry for tomorrow's New Jersey Olympic Track Classic at Piscadwity was rejected yesterday. 24 hours after it was accented.

title: Stage: Father's Day
description: WHEN Oliver Hailey's Father's Day was first performed here eight years ago it was poorly received and quickly closed. Since tnen it has had a much better reception in more than a half dozen productions around the country, with the author modifying and adjusting as it went.

title: For Children
description: WILDLIFE THEATER BIRD SHOW, featuring seven parrots. Including Cookie, a whitecrested cockatoo and two macaws, that will perform five times a day: 11 A.M., 12:30,2, 3:30 and 4:30 P.M., at the Zoological Park at the Bronx Zoo. Show free; zoo admission: children, 75 cents; adults, $1.50, Friday through Monday. Parking. S2. Call 2205100.

title: Dissidents in Seoul Say Repression Is Growing As Carter's Visit Nears
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 21  South Korean dissidents are charging that President Carter's visit next week has touched off a wave of repression, including house arrests, kidnappings and beatings by government agents at a time when both South Korean and United States officials are reporting improvements in human rights policies.

title: Radio Pulses May Back Black Hole Theory
description: It has been found that, like a cosmic machine gun, the turbulent galaxy Messier 87 is emitting rapidfire radio pulses less than a thousandth of a second long, each carrying the energy that 10 million suns would radiate_

title: F.B.I. ROLE DISPUTED IN ADMINISTRATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  Bucking tradition, the Carter Administration has been trying to get the Federal:: Bureau of Investigation to turn bank robbery over to local law enforcer:dent. asencies whenever oostible.

title: Option Is Granted to Partnership To Buy Times Tract on West Side
description: An option to buy a fourblock tract on the West Side of Manhattan owned by The New York Times Company has been granted to a partnership of two New York realtors considering largescale development of the orobertv.

title: Bridge:
description: Half a century ago, bidding theory in the new game of contract bridge was quite primitive. Although it was Ely Culbertson who became the big name for the general public, there were plenty of other theorists.

title: Agency Approves the Reopening Of Rancho Seco Nuclear Plant
description: WASHINGTON,. June 21 (AP)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today tentatively approved the reopening of the Rancho Seco nuclear plant in California after the commission staff said that prob. lems that forced the shutdown had been corrected.

title: BOLIVIANS ARE TENSE AS ELECTION NEARS
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 17  The entrance hall of San Andris University, Bolivia's center of higher studies, is filled each evening with thousands of students talking excitedly over the din of competing loudspeakers proclaiming political statements.

title: Hilton in Casino Deal
description: Hilton International will manage 550room luxury casinohotel planned for Atlantic City by the Cavanagh Cornmtutities Corporation of Miami, it was announced today. The two companies said they had reached an agreement on managing the Vista Royale Hotel, part of an $80 million hotel casino complex scheduled to open in 1981..

title: The Summer, It's Here; All Give a Loud Cheer
description: Walt Whitman liked summer evenings. For him, last night would have been the first mad naked summernieht of 1979.

description: WASHINGTON, June 21  James R. Schlesinger, the Secretary of Energy, said today that he was disappointed because the nation's oil industry failed to increase its output of gasoline and beating oil last week, but added that oil executives had assured him that they would step up refinery runs in July.

description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 11, 8 P.M. RadioWINS, 8 P.M.)

title: Ballet: Danes in Bruges
description: IT takes a little getting used to, but a halfhour or so in the company of the Royal Danish Ballet soloists now at the City Center55th Street Theater is enough to acclimate even the ardent devotee of Russianstyle. pyrotechnics to the gentler art of August Bournonville, the 19thcentury Danish choreographer. A central Das de deux from me second act of Kermesse in Bruges looked distinctively understated in its New York premiere Wednesday, however, pointing up a problerri inherent in this kind of excerpt program

description: Jogger Regulations Rejected in Jersey

title: Big Board Reports Short Interest at Record Level
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 8 million shares in the month ended June 15, the largest increase for one month on record, to 97.6 million shares, also a record. The previous high for a onemonth increase was in the month ended April 19, 1978, when the short interest was up 6.2 million shares. The previous record for total shares was 93.2 million on April 12, 1979. Short interest on June 15, 1978, totaled 39.6 million shares.

title: Neighboring Vermont and New Hampshire Far Apart on Growth and Development Policies
description: CONCORD, N.H.  On the map and in the civics textbooks, It would be hard to find two states that seem as neatly paired as Vermont and New Hampshire.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Continental Corporation has named George S. Zacharkow chairman and chief executive of its subsidiary, the Marine Office of America Corporation, and appointed Arnold C. Avitabile president and chief executive officer of the Underwriters Adjusting Company, another subsidiary.

title: The Screen: Muppets Go to Hollywood:Roadiest Road Picture
description: "THE Muppet Movie," which introduces to motion pictures Kermit the Frog, Fozzie the Bear, Miss Piggy and the rest of Jim Henson's extraordinary puppets we know from "Sesame Street" and "The Muppet Show," demonstrates once again that there's always room in movies for unbridled amiability when it's governed by intelligence and wit.The film, opening today at the Ziegfeld Theater, is a straight-from-the-shoulder Muppet spoof of all those movies in which real-life celebrities like Audie Murphy and Wrong-Way Corrigan re-enact the lives that led them to become famous enough for movies to be made about them.The saga of the Muppets begins in a Georgia swamp where, one halcyon afternoon, Kermit is sitting atop a log, playing his guitar and contemplating the perfection of all natural things, when Dom DeLuise, as a hyperventillating Hollywood agent, drifts by in an out-of-control rowboat."I've lost my direction," says the agent. "Have you tried Hare Krishna?" replies Kermit. One thing leads to another and the agent persuades Kermit that there's a future in Hollywood for a frog of his talents."The Muppet Movie" is the last word in "road" pictures, being the story of Kermit's crazy cross-country trip to Hollywood, much of it in the company of Fozzie the Bear, who drives not well but often.."Ah," says Fozzie as they go swerving down life's highway, "a bear in his natural habitat! A Studebaker!" The Muppets they meet and take aboard are extremely good company, as are their friends, including Mr. DeLuise, Mel Brooks, Madeline Kahn, Milton Berle, Orson Welles and Richard Pryor, each of whom turns up briefly. The trip, though, is not all bread, honey and flies. Kermit is pursued relentlessly by Doc Hopper (Charles Durning), the greedy, ambitious head of a fast-food chain specializing in deep-fried frogs legs. Doc sees himself as the rival of Colonel Sanders if he can persuade Kermit to be his spokesman on television. That, naturally, is an offer that Kermit rejects. "All I can see," says Kermit, suppressing a tear, "is a million frogs on tiny crutches."At one point Doc Hopper hires a mad scientist, played by Mr. Brooks, who attempts to change Kermit by subjecting him to what he calls "an electronic cerebrectomy." Miss Piggy, a karate expert, saves the day and wins Kermit's respect.One of the movie's funniest sequences is a montage that dramatizes in lyrical slow-motion how Kermit and Miss Piggy discover their love as they gambol across meadows, stop by a waterfall and punt across a still lake until their passion takes control. I should stress, though, that "The Muppet Movie" is always discreet.It's also very well written by Jerry Juhl and Jack Burns and directed by James Frawley ("Kid Blue," "The Big Bus") with a comic touch that never becomes facetious.I'm in particular awe of the techniques by which these hand puppets are made to walk, run, sing and play musical instruments. As do the other actors in the movie, we very quickly come to accept the Muppets as real people who just happen to be made largely of felt

title: Drifter, Short of Bail, Is Freed
description: A 46-year-old drifter from Georgia who spent almost six months in jail  part of the time on a murder charge of which he was innocent  was freed yesterday after the city's Commissioner of Social Services Intervened. The prisoner, Charles Brooks, had been held since April 3, when the murder charge was dropped, because he could not raise $150 bail on an autotheft charge.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 22, 1979

title: SUDAN GETS ARAB AID DESPITE SADAT LINKS

Lule after only 68 days as President. Two persons were reported killed and 50 people injured in series of demonstrations that began after midnight last night.

title: LAWRENCE S. LESSER, AN EXU.S. AIDE, DIES
description: Lawrence Stanley. Lesser, a former New York and Washington lawyer, died Wednesday in Good Samaritan Hospital in Baltimore after a brief illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Washinaton.

title: Soviet Buys U.S. Grain
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)  An additional 730,000 metric tons of United States grain, equivalent to 26.8 million bushels, has been sold to the Soviet Union, the second big sale reported this week, the Agriculture Department said today. Sales of 700,000 tons of corn to the Soviet Union were announced on Wednesday. The latest sale included 550,000 tons of corn and 180,000 of wheat. Counting the latest sales, purchases by the Soviet Union so far this year total about almost 2.9 million tons, or 106.9 million bushels, of wheat and 9.1 million tons, or 334 million bushels, of corn.

title: New Zealand Devaluation
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 21 (UPI)  New Zealand devalued its dollar by 5 percent today to a near parity with the United States dollar. Before the devaluation, the New Zealand dollar was worth $1.0551 in United States currency. The devaulation made the New Zealand dollar worth $1.0023, a spokesman for the nation's reserve Pank said.

title: Mr. Carter Breaks the Timber Line
description: President Carter needs to give a much better justification for his unprecedented order to increase the timber harvest from national forests. These lands have hitherto been managed to produce a sustained yield and even flow of timber from year to year cutting has been held to the rate at which new trees replace the felled ones. But now Mr. Carter wants a decade of faster cutting on lands administered by the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management, to raise the harvest by 1 to 3 billion board feet a year over the current rate of about 12 billion.

Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, Washington's desire to fly U2 aircraft over Turkey to monitor Moscow's compliance with the new strategicarms agreement, but the issue has not yet been resolved, Administration sources disclosed today.

title: Screen: 'Alcatraz' Opens:With Clint Eastwood
description: DON SIEGEL'S "Escape From Alcatraz" is not a great film or an especially memorable one, but there is more evident skill and knowledge of movie making in any one frame of it than there are in most other American films around at the moment. It's the kind of movie that could be more profitably studied in film courses than all of the works of Bergman and Fellini combined. That's not to say that Mr. Siegel ("Dirty Harry," "The Beguilded," "Riot in Cell Block 11," etc.) outweighs those masters but that film students have a way of leaping into the art while still ignorant of the craft. Craft is something that a Siegel film demonstrates without half trying."Escape From Alcatraz" is based on, and is a speculation upon, the true story of the successful escape of three men from San Francisco's island-prison in 1960. Because neither the men nor their bodies were ever found, many of the film's details, I assume, are the work of the screenwriter, Richard Tuggle, and J. Campbell Bruce, who wrote a book about the case.What Mr. Siegel has made is fiction, a first-rate action movie that is about the need and the decision to take action, as well as the action itself. In this particular case, the action is the escape from "the rock," a maneuver masterminded by a tough con named Frank Morris (Clint Eastwood) with two cronies, Clarence Anglin (Jack Thibeau) and John Anglin (Fred Ward).In such movies, characters function primarily as components of the movement. It's with something of a shock that you realize at the end of the film you still know hardly anything about the fellow Mr. Eastwood plays, neither why he was in prison to start with nor anything about his life outside. When someone asks him, "What kind of childhood did you have?" his answer is sufficient to the circumstances. "Short," he says.This kind of terseness is characteristic of the entire movie, which opens with Frank Morris being escorted to Alcatraz under armed guard, late at night, during a heavy rainstorm. From that sequence on, the audience, like Frank Morris, is on the inside peering out. The movie operates entirely within the present tense. We don't worry about Frank Morris's past, only about what's happening now.Mr. Siegel evokes the dehumanizing routine of Alcatraz life so vividly that the film's principal question is not if he's going to escape, but how. Says the warden (Patrick McGoohan), a fellow to warm the heart of Captain Bligh, as he explains the prison's lack of any rehabilitation programs: "We don't make good citizens. We make good prisoners."As Mr. Siegel and his screenwriter have not provided their characters with lengthy case histories, they have also refrained from imposing on the film hints of larger meanings. The meanings are there if you want to search, but they aren't spelled out as if to justify the existence of the film.In a couple of brief sequences, "Escape From Alcatraz" looks as if it were going to succumb to sentiment, but mostly it's tough in the way that Sam Peckinpah's films once were, before he began to take himself so seriously. I should also add that it's terrifically exciting.Mr. Eastwood fulfills the demands of the role and of the film as probably no other actor could. Is it acting? I don't know, but he's the towering figure in its landscape. Among the fine supporting performances are those of Roberts Blossom, Frank Ronzio, Bruce M. Fischer, Larry Hankin and Mr. McGoohan, who pushes unmotivated nastiness to its outer reaches.The movie opens today at the Forum and Trans-Lux East Theaters."Escape from Alcatraz," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), includes some explicit violence and bloodshed and obscene language.

The theme of the workshops, conducted by the Touchstone Players, will be the four natural elements (air, earth, tire and water). Participants of all ages are invited. Admission to the grounds is $1 (those under 21 admitted free). If it rains, the workshops will be moved indoors. Information: 5492055.

title: Blues and Weakfish Plentiful Off Jersey
description: AREA A  The Avalon Shoals area off Margate has come alive with blue. fish and weakfish in large numbers. Fishermen have made catches of up to 50 fish, each running between a pound and two pounds. The action has been heavy off the lower end of the Stone Beds, using any number of rigs and trolling. Some bucktails, 8 to 12 pounds, have been taken. The rental boats have had good catches of summer fluke in Margate Bay. At the Lighthouse Marina in Barnegat, blues have been caught by chumming and trolling, and the charter boats have caught bonita. Bottom fishing for sea bass and flounder is good. Crabbing has been reported excellent. Art Giglio's at Sea Bright reported excellent fluke catches in the Atlantic off Sandy Hook. In Sandy Hook Bay and the Shrewsbury River, fluke have been plentiful by drifting with killies, squid, eels and spearing. Weakfish up to 7 pounds have been caught with worms and squid as bait and some striped bass have been snared in the Atlantic by trolling.

title: Film: Streisand Stars in 'Main Event':A Reluctant Warrior
description: "THE Main Event," which opens today at the Sutton and other theaters, is the kind of comedy in which the funniest person is a secondary character, a young woman with a terrible cigarette cough, and the funniest dialogue is an exchange between her and another secondary character, a young man. He: "My name is David....as in Camp David?" She: "You're kidding! That's you?"Most of the film is not on this elevated level. It's about a high-powered cosmetics executive, played by Barbra Streisand, who, after her accountant runs off with her fortune, tries to recoup by managing a prizefighter whose contract she had bought earlier for tax-loss purposes.The prizefighter, played by Ryan O'Neal, doesn't want to fight because he doesn't like to get hurt. He much prefers to run a driving school that's in the shape of a boxing glove. Barbra pushes him. He holds back. With Barbra as the go-getting aggressor and Ryan as the passive nincompoop, they fall in love.This sort of situation could only be funny if it's out of character, and it is out of character for Mr. O'Neal. The pushy cosmetics executive, however, seems to be an extension of the role played in real-life by Miss Streisand, who coproduced the movie, stars in it and seems to have ordered every close-up and line-reading. Miss Streisand has become a contradiction: she's too much without being enough.In her early films  "Funny Girl," "On a Clear Day," "What's Up Doc?" and even "Hello, Dolly," she gave signs of attempting to stretch her talent. Now that she's appearing in her own, made-to-order productions, the talent appears to have shrunk and become inflexible. The performance here is blunt, rude, unpleasant and inescapable. At one point the camera even follows her to her exercise class, a scene that has no purpose except to demonstrate that she's limber, something of more interest to her immediate family, perhaps, than to us slobs in Movieland.The two supporting actors who supply comic first-aid from time to time are Paul Sand and Patti D'Arbanville. Whitman Mayo is also funny as Mr. O'Neal's wise, skeptical trainer.Gail Parent ("Sheila Levine Is Dead and Living in New York") and Andrew Smith wrote the screenplay, which was directed by Howard Zieff ("Slither," "Hearts of the West"). With any other star-producer they might have made this into the zany comedy I think they had in mind. Miss Streisand obviously doesn't need advice from the likes of them."The Main Event," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains some suggestive situations and dialogue.

title: Soviet Buying Lifts Grain Price

title: 2 Robbed of $100,000 in Bronx

title: Carter Tells of Nation's Dream
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)  President Carter, in a Fourth of July statement, said today that freedom and justice were not permanent and must be constantly rewon in a thousand daily battles. He saidthe heritage received from our forefathers was not a perfected nation, but the dream of a nation dedicated to the fulfillment of the highest human ideals and aspirations.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury's Notes to Yield 8.89%

title: A Filly, a Grace, a Joy

It is not, of course, unusual for the owners of thoroughbreds to christen their speedy pets with singular names and the owner of this particular 3yearold must have known that Euphrosyne was one of the three Graces in Greek mythology and that it translates to Joy.

description: Thousands of independent truckers have begun what their organizers call an extended, vacation, forcing a halt to much transport by a combinathm of violence and fuelpump blockade. They vow to obstruct the nation's hauling until the Government meets their demands for higher shipping rates, more diesel fuel and relief from limitations on the weights they may carry and the speeds at which they may drive.

They will be Dart of an ambi- tious festival of ethnic and folk music, crafts and food likely to draw some. 20,000 people tomorrow and Sunday to the banks of the Hudson River at Croton Point Park in Westchester. When it's over, not a crumb of baklava is likely to remain on the bucolic site.

title: Art: Israeli Painters In Brooklyn Show
description: THE conventions governing the creation of modernist art have long been thoroughly internationalized. Modernist artists the world over tend to be more loyal to certain styles or ideas  to Minimal art. say. or to Expressionism. or what- ever  than to national traits or regional points of view. In giving priority to ideas over experience, modernism universalizes the language of art, allowing it swift passage beyond the specific cultural situation that has produced it.

title: Auctions
description: IN sheer numbers, the musicill instruments and reiated material that will be dispersed at auction in New York today through next Tuesday is stamering. All three of the Britishbased auction houses are offering sales of the rare and the not so rare; In all, more than 550 lots of highly specialized collectibles will go on the block. Each auction is dominated by vintage stringed instruments and bows, but none of the sales are expected to rewrite any records.

title: Soviet Grain Deals In Australia Rise
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 21 The Soviet Union has increased its purchases of Australian wheat, ordering more than 40 million bushels in the last month, an action that Government agricultural officials here see as confirming predictions of a poor, harvest in Russia this year.

description: There really is nothing quite like a dancing Dane. Danish dancers have the works of August Bournonville, the great 19thcentury Danish choreographer, to perform. They do possess that fabled sunny, Danish charm. title: Music: Goldman Time
description: IT was appropriate that the Guggenheim Concerts given. by the Goldman Band should open on the eve of summer, for they form one of New York's most durable and likable institutions associated with the spasm, They were entering their 62d year, and the initial program on Wednesday night in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park was played under auspicious circumstances. The beguiling weather lured a large audience to the park. It filled the rows of chairs in front of the spinnakershaped bandshell and dotted the back area where sycamore and red maple trees spread their branches.

title: Republic, J.&L. Raise Steel Prices
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth largest steel producer and the Jones 8e Laughlin Steel Corporation, the third largest, yesterday joined other industry giants in increasing prices on a variety of products. The rises are effective July 1.

description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) - Presi dent Carter today signed a bill that softens some provisions of the new Ethics in Government Act.

The match was even after 33 holes of the scheduled 36hole final but the victor, from Bloomfield, N.J., took the next two holes.

description: WASHINGTON, June:22 (AP) The flow of funds into mutual funds last month totaled $2.7 billion, a record monthly gain, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: The Crime That Courts Can't Handle
description: The New York Court of Appeals has sent a disappointing but truthful message to parents who want sue society for failing to educate their children. Charges of educational malpractice have been filed courts across the country by the dismayed parents of illiterate and unemployable young people, seeking payment for damages and other relief. In a decision likely to set a pattern, New York's highest court has ordered judges not to entertain such complaints. For better or worse, education remains the business of teachers and other professionals, not of judges. And so it should, much as we sympathize with the plaintiffs.

title: Syria Says Moslem Militants Killed 32 Artillery Cadets of Assad's Sect
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 22 - The Syrian Government said today that religious zealots Of the Moslem Brotherhood movement raided a military academy at Aleppo last Saturday, killing 32 cadets and wounding 59. The Government vowed to liquidate the movement, which it had tolerated.

The pose was very proper and dignified, and if the building had had any residents, they would surely have been impressed.

title: Cambodia Says Thai Troops Killed 300 Refugees Forced Over Border
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 22 - The proVietnamese Government of Cambodia charged today that Thai military forces had killed more than 300 of the 45,000 Cambodian refugees it drove back across the Cambodian border by shooting them or by forcing them to march across mine fields. Many others died as the result of illness. Cambodia alleeed.

title: $5.95 Million Koch Budget Vetoes Are Overridden by the City Council
description: The City Council and the Board of Estimate overrode Mayor Koch's veto of revisions in the $12.8 billion budget for fiscal year 1980 yesterday, adding $5.95 million for fire protection, libraries and sanitation police.

Two bridges were damaged, and the river was turned into a national symbol of environmental degradation.

title: Surgery for Cheevers
description: BOSTON, June 22 (AP)  Gerry Cheevers, the Boston Bruins No. goaltender, had torn cartilage removed from his left knee through an arthroscope today. He was expected to have some use of the knee within a week. He is the only goalie virtually certain to be back with the team next season. Gilles Gilbert and Jim Pettie are free agents.

title: U.S. COURT DECIDES CARTER CAN IMPOSE WAGEPRICE POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 - A United States Court of Appeals overturned today a decision by a lower court and ruled that President Carter had the authority to use the Government's purchasing power to enforce wage and price guidelines.

title: Deaths
description: Bernstein, Harold Klein. Harriette Elirrberg, Charles Lesser, Lawrence

title: H. R. A. Charges Misuse of Funds By Poverty Units
description: New York City investigators are looking into charges of mismanagement and misappropriation of Federal and city funds at 10 South Bronx _poverty programs that receive a total of more than $13 million a year in government funds.

title: Ray Whittaker Is Dead at 79; Shubert Theatrical Manager
description: Ray Whittaker, a retired theatrical manager for Shubert enterprises, died Thursday at his retirement home in Ormond Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Burton's 69.42Carat Gift to Miss Taylor Is Sold

title: U.S. Ends PrisonerDeath Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) - The Government said today that it would not bring charges in the investigation of the death of a MexicanAmerican who died while in a county jail in Odessa, Tex., and who was allegedly beaten by the authorities.

title: Candy Collins Is Married Ta Charles Bell of I.B.M.
description: In the Chapel of Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., yesterday, Eda Grace Collins and Charles Christopher Bell, 1977 alumni of St. Lawrence University, were married by the Rev. Robert J. McDermott, pastor of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn.

description: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

title: Officials Urge Driving Limits This Weekend
description: The American Automobile Association, some government officials and police officers advised motorists yesterday to limit their driving over the weekend because of difficulty in obtaining gasolhie.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The board of directors of the Monsanto Company voted yesterday to shut down the company's nylon manufacturing and support facilities in Europe, effectively withdrawing the company from the nylon segment of the European fiber business.

title: Carter to Address Governors
description: WASHINGTON, June 72 (AP) - President Carter will address the opening sessia of the National Governors Association July 8 in Louisville, Ky., the White House press office announced today. It Sala mat Mr. carter would fly to Louisville July 7, would attend a state Democratic Party barbecue to raise funds that evening, and that the next morning he would attend a breakfast of Democratic governors before addressing the national association.

title: Islamic Zealots in Iran Rout Liberals Seeking To Denounce Charter
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 22 - Groups of rockthrowing Moslem zealots broke up rally today of leftists and moderates calling for an elected assembly to draft a new constitution.

title: HAROLD D. ROMANOW
description: Harold D. Romanow, who had practiced law in New York City for more than 90 years, died Thursday at his home in Montauk, L.I. Mr. Romanow, who was 71 years old, also had a home on Singer Island in Florida.

title: U.S. Envoy to Uruguay Picked
description: WASHINGTON, Jtine 22 (Reuters) President Carter said today that he would nominate Lyle F. Lane to be Ambassador to Uruguay. Mr Lane, principal officer of the American Interest Section in Havana since 1977, will replace Lawrence A. Pezullo, who has been appointed envoy to Nicaragua.

title: Money
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 22, 1979

title: Thorpe Not Guilty of Plotting to Kill Former Friend
description: LONDON, June 22 - At the end of long and dramatic trial, Jeremy Thorpe was found not guilty today of having conspired to murder a man who claims to have been his lover.

title: Watson, on 69435, Leads by
description: OAKVILLE, Ontario, June 22 (AP) Tom Watson fought his way through gusty winds to a two-under-par 69 today and took a threestroke lead in the second round of the $350,000 Canadian open golf tournament.

title: Connecticut Bars Entry By OutsideBank Units
description: HARTFORD, June 22 - Gov. Ella T. Grasso has signed into law a bill barring for one year nonbanking subsidiaries of out-of-state bankholding companies from moving into the state, her office said today.

title: Former U.S. Envoy Is Sentenced For Spending U.S. Cash on Home
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 - Robert A. Hurwitch, the former Ambassador to the Dominican Republic, was sentenced to two years of probation today after he pleaded guilty to five charges of misusing Government funds.

title: Sheila Turner Seed, 42, Editor and Photographer
description: Sheila Turner Seed, a former editor at Scholastic magazines and a freelance writer and photographer, died of a brain aneurysm yesterday in Evanston (Ill.) Hospital. She was 42 years old and had recently moved back to the United States from her home in England.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BAYOU ECHOES Folk music concerts abound in the Big Apple, but songs colorfully rooted in the remote byways of rural Louisiana are a novelty. Tonight at 8 o'clock, the Ardoin family, one of the bestknown exponents of traditional black Cajun music, will appear at the Alternative Center for International Arts at 28 East Fourth Street. Admission is $3.50; reservations are at 4736072.

title: EARNINGS Bulova Loses $2.7 Million As Sales Decline by 10%
description: The troubled Bulova Watch Company, acquired by the Loews Corporation last March, reported yesterday that had a $2.7 million loss for the fourth quarter of its fiscal year, which ended March 31.

title: China Is Reported Delivering MIG19 Jets to Egypt
description: CAIRO, June 22 - Egypt, while waiting for a promised $1.5 billion in American tnilitary credits to overhaul its armed forces, has reportedly carried out a mutually satisfactory exchange of Soviettype jet fighters with China.

title: New Ugandan Leader consolidates Position as Kampala Protests End
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, June 22 - Ugan. da's political crisis eased today as demonstrators left the streets and the new Government of President Godfrey L. Binaisa consolidated its hold on the cowl-try.

title: Misses Alcott and Britz Share Lady Keystone Lead
description: HERSHEY, Pa., June 22 (AP) Amy Alcott and Jerilyn Britz posted rounds of four-under-par 68 today to share the firstround lead in the $100,000 Lady Keystone open at Hershey Country Club's West Course.

title: OBSERVER To the Seashore, Jimmy
description: The trouble with the world as defined by this week's news is too many bombs and not enough gas.

title: Stage: Bjorg Vik's Wine Untouched
description: A strong cast has been assembled to perform. Bjorg Vik's Wine Untouched, a Norwegian play about five women - childhood friends who meet to compare the wounds of midlife.

title: Embattled deRoos Resigns His Job As Chief of City Transit Authority
description: John G. deRoos resigned yesterday as senior executive officer of the New York City Trangit Authority.

title: Library Shows Manuscripts of 1890's
description: The 1890'S rank, in retrospect, among the golden ages of European literature. With Ibsen, .Chekhoy, Shaw and Wilde in full production, the drama was in as good shape as it had been for many years. The new first book of poems was by William Butler Yeats. Marcel Proust published his first book, too. With The Time Machine, The Invisible Man and The War of the Worlds, H.G. Wells proved that science and the storyteller could work as predestined allies. Thomas Hardy with Jude the Obscure and Zola with more than one volume of the RougonMacquart series showed that the novel could still be a great force for social justice. There were periodicals like The Yellow Book in London and Ver Sacrum in Vienna that still strike us as the epitome of their age in one or another of its aspects.

title: JAZZ EVENTS
description: Following is a schedule of today's Newport Jazz FestivalNew York events:

title: Anxiety and Anger, but Not Much Gas
description: On Long Island, onewoman jockeyed two automobiles through a gas line for 90 minutest jumping from car to car. It is not known how she got the vehicles to or from the station.

title: Haig Gets Festival Under Way With Waltz and Quiet Numbers
description: The Newport Jazz Festival began on a quiet, discreet note late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. The first official event of the 1979 festival was not a gala evening affair - that came later in the main auditorium of Carnegie Hall with Dizzy Gillespie and an ensemble of nine drummers. It was. instead, a piano recital by Al Haig, the first of six such recitals that will be given at 5 P.M. each weekday through next week.

title: Meyer, Buehning to Meet In Wimbledon First Round
description: The luck of the draw has paired two metropolitan area players, Rick Meyer and Fritz Buehning, in a firstround meeting at Wimbledon on Monday.

title: Chinese Emporium Sets Out to Lure Big Spenders
description: In recent weeks strollers along Fifth Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets were always stopping to ask the workmen at No. 675 if it was going to be Chinese restaurant. The facade certainly looks like one, with its red and gold paint and its carved wooden balcony.

title: The Dance: City Ballet Returns Coppelia
description: The New York City Ballet may have acquired the threeact story ballet, Coppelia, as family entertainment. And the City Ballet dancers may be unpracticed actors. But you couldn't have proved that on Thursday when the George BalanchineAlexandra. Danilova version of the 19thcentury FrancoRussian classic reentered the spring repertory at the New York State Theater. Amid the swirl of mazurka dancers, mechanical toys and rednosed mayors there is some very grownup choreography. And Thursday's cast was a most believable chorus of happy young Galician townspeople, led by Patricia McBride, Helgi Tomasson and Shaun O'Brien in their original roles of Swanilda, her fickle suitor, Frantz, and the misanthropic old dollmaker, Dr. Coppelius.

title: Bridge:
description: Picture Can Sometimes Lie, A Vugraph Incident Proves

title: Around the Nation
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.y. June 22 (UPI) - The Florida Supreme Court denied stays of execution tonight, for Robert A. Sullivan and Charles W. Proffitt, convicted murders scheduled uled to die Wednesday:morning in the electric chair.

title: A.T.&T. Case Gets Trial Date
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) - A Federal judge today set a trial date of Sept. 1, 1980, for a Government suit charging the American Telephone and Telegraph Company with monopolizing markets for telecommunications services and equipment.

title: New York Faces Loss of U.S. Aid Over Car Fumes
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency, is threatening the New York metropolitan area with the loss of millions of dollars because the state has no program for yearly emission inspections of the reelon's 3.5 million cars.

title: Patricia Clare Kerman Bride Of Sylvain Lerner in Scarsdale
description: Patricia Clare Kerman, director of the speech pathology and audiology service at Goldwater Memorial HospitalNew York University Medical Center, was married in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday to Sylvain S. Lerner, vice president of the Controlled Acoustics Corporation in Hartsdale, N.Y., specialists in noise control. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony in his study at the Westchester Reform Temple.

title: Clarence S. A. Williams Is Dead; An Associate of Thomas Edison
description: Clarence S. A. Williams, who once worked for Thomas A. Edison and went on to become a friend and business associate of the inventor, died yesterday in a nursing home in Lawrenceville, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 89 years old and lived in South Orange. N.J.

title: Graduation Day a Milestone for an Immigrant Family
description: It will be a day that had been planned and prayed for years ago, when Christos and Joanna Kapelonis were still living in a small house behind a grove of fig trees in central Athens.

title: Sports Today
description: Taped highlights of the Michigan 400 stock car race, at Michigan International Speed. way. The A.A.U. outdoor track and field championships, taped at Walnut, Calif., will also be shown. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M.)

title: Extra Gravy for Washington to Share
description: Felix Rohatyn has a bright idea, one that could help financially pressed cities at low cost. The wizard of New York's financial recovery plan reminds us that state and local taxes are deductible from Federal taxable income. Thus whenever a local government seeks to halt the outflow of business and jobs by cutting its taxes a dollar, Washington collects an extra 30 to 35 cents. Why shouldn't the Federal Government help these communities, Mr. Rohatyn asks, by sharing the gravy?

title: NASA Advisory on Skylab's Fall: 'slightly Safer Indoors Than Outdoors
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday that when Skylab is coming down it may be slightly safer to be indoors than outdoors but did not recommend that people change their plans or make special attempts to seek shelter.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, June Z2,1979

title: United tree International
description: SELFSERVICE STATION IN PARIS: A French cab driver filling his tank this week in Paris. Unleaded regular gasoline sells there for 2.88 francs a liter, or about $2.52 a gallon.

title: Only Half Tank of Gas For Some Rental Cars
description: While the Hertz, Avis, National and Olins carrental services all maintain policy of giving customers a full tank of gas, some drivers will be starting trips this weekend with as little. as half a tank.

title: Rafshoon Agency Loan to Carter in 1976 Is Denied
description: ATLANTA, June 72 (AP) The trustee handling the finances of Gerald M. Ratshoat, President Carter's communications adviser, lias released a report that says Mr. Rafshoon's advertising agency did not advance money to Mr. Carter's 1976 Presidential campaign.

title: Gas Prices: Some Why's
description: Gasoline prices increased sharply and erratically at some service stations in New York City and on Long Island in the last few days. Complaints from motorists, already angered by the short supply of gasoline and long lines at the pump, are growing stronger.

title: Cotton Club's Last Song: Urban Renewal Blues
description: COLORADO SPRINGS - Fannie Mae Duncan was accustomed to being in the news here four or five years ago when Urban Renewal closed down her legendary Cotton Club, named after Harlem's Cotton Club.

title: Irate Sports Fan Succeeds in Bid To Roll Back Price for Hot Dogs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 - It started last year as a routine matter when the San Francisco Recreation and Park Commission raised by 5 cents the price of hot dogs and beer at Candlestick Park, home of the Giants baseball team and the football 49ers.

title: U.S. Proposals on Nicaragua Crisis Meet Sharp Criticism From O.A.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 - The United States proposal for urgent consideration of , an interAmerican peace force for Nicaragua encountered severe criticism and won no support today at an emergency meeting of the Organization of American States on the Nidaraguan crisis.

title: Bullets Acquire Rights To Malovic of San Diego St
description: LANDOVER, Md., June 22 (AP) -In exchange for the 22d pick in the 1979 National Basketball Association draft and their thirdround choice in 1980, the Washington Bullets said today, they had acquired the rights to San Diego State's centerforward; Steve Malovic, from the Phoenix Suns.

title: State Is Upheld On Supervising Abortion Clinic
description: A decision strongly supporting New York State's authority to regulate abortion facilities was issued yesterday by Federal district iudee in Manhattan_

title: The Region
description: TRENTON (AP) - A bill backing up Governor Byrne's building moratorium in New Jersey's Pinelands received final legislative approval yesterday in the State Assembly.

title: The City
description: A former Staten Island Republican; leader, Philip Fitzpatrick, was sentenced yesterday to 90 days in jail and six months probation for lying to a grand jury about his efforts to influence a narcotics case.

title: Nevada Banks Join in the Action
description: RENO - In a town that thrives on gambling, getting investors to take chance on financing a casino isn't easy, said John Douglass, general manager and a partner in the new 172room Comstock Hotel & Casino.

description: Music

title: NBC Theater
description: A new-two-hour production of William Gibson's The Miracle Worker, starring Melissa Gilbert and Patty Duke Astin, will be one of three plays presented under the rubric of NBC Theater next season, the network announced yesterday.

title: Cairo Says Two Agents for Libya Infiltrated to Blow Up a Rail Line
description: CAIRO, June 22 (UPI) Two arrested men are described as Libyan intelligence agents who planned to blow up a main railway line west of the Mediterranean city of Alexandria, the Middle East News Agency. said today.

title: A Parting Shot From Teacher
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa - Yesterday saw you for the last time in a series of instructional periods called school and right now I am figuring the grade for my English class that will go on your permanent record. Lots of luck, kid, you're going to need it.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Orders Shutdowns. and Checks For Flaws at Two Makers
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 - The Nuclear Regulator) Commission has decided to order that nuclear reactors built by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and Combustion Engineering Inc. be closed down in the next 90 days so that cracks in the steam generator nozzles can be inspected.

title: Hunter and Yankees Defeat Indians by 32
description: With only 100 days remaining in his illustrious baseball career, Catfish Hunter, the $3.35 million man, gained his first victory of his last season last night. But it was not easy.

title: Study Asserts Chemical Concern Knew of Michigan Pollution in 68
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 - The Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation knew as early as 1968 that it was contaminating the ground water below its plant site in Montague, Mich., and that the contamination was spreading toward a nearby lake, according to a 1968 study that was made available today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary of the screen director David Butler in The New York Times Wednesday incorrectly stated that he directed Seventh Heaven with Janet Gaynor. The director was Frank Borzage.

title: Newport Jazz At. Gracie Mansion, Joint Was Jumpin
description: There was, even with the lousy piano, a lot of good music yesterday afternoon at the first Live at Gracie Mansion broadcast from the official mayoral residence. Despite an overcast sky, there was evident delight with the music, which was provided by Benny Goodman and an ad hoc quartet and a 20member youth jazz ensemble, inaugurating not only the broadcasts but also the Newport Jazz Festival, which opened last night.

title: METROPOLITAN AREA FACES TIGHTEST TIME FOR SUPPLY OF GAS
description: Motorists in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut today face what is expected to be the worst weekend since the gasoline shortage developed.

title: Deaths
description: BERNSTEINHarold B. On June 20, 1979. Cherished father of Froma B. Lippmann. Devoted father-in-law of John F. Lippmann. Loving grandfather of Ellen and Charles Lippmann. Betoyed brother of Lionel Caring. Brother-In-law of Rita Bernstein and Harriet Brous. Services were held. In lieu of flowers please donate to a charity of your choice.

title: Red Sox Hit Four Home Runs; Send Blue Jays to a 121 Defeat
description: BOSTON, Jline 22 (AP) - Jim Rice drilled two homers and Bob Watson and Fred Lynn one each tonight as the Boston Red Sox rode a 15hit attack home to a 121 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Let In More Asian Refugees
description: People who need the help of the United States do not always suit our national or personal convenience. We would like distressed people to fit into established programs of aid. They rarely do. We would also like to settle some problems. We rarely do.

title: Death of Harlem Man After Arrest Is Linked To Action by Officers
description: New York City's Medical Examiner, Dr. Michael M. Baden, said yesterday that the death of a Vietnam War veteran in Harlem had been caused in part by multiple bluntforce injuries" that he suffered during a struggle when the police tried to arrest him after his car crashed in the Bronx.

title: Rikers Inmate Is Found Hanged
description: A 20-year-old Rikers. Island inmate, who had alleged he was sexually assaulted last week, hanged himself after again being attacked by other orisoners. authorities reported yesterday. The Correction Department said the inmate, Vernell Boros of 427 Baltic Street, Brooklyn, was found at 6:30 P.M. Thursday, hanging from a bedsheet tied to a light fixture in the Adolescent Detention Center. He was the fifth suicide at the jail this year and had been held in $5,000 bail at Rikers Island since May 25.

title: Troy Archer Killed
description: Troy Archer, defensive lineman for the New York Giants, and another man driving with him were killed in an auto accident in North Bergen, N.J. An obituary is on page 26.
