description: The. Economy

title: Take the Taxi Commission for a Ride
description: No proud city deserves the kind of taxi service that has been the lot of New Yorkers in recent years. And no taxi industry should be run by a Taxi and Limousine Commission cast in the image of Tammany Hall. These rattletraps need an overhaul.

title: U.S. Envoy's Lukewarm Approval Of Arms Pact Irks Administration
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 - Malcolm Toon, the United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, has stung the Carter Administration by refusing to give an allout endorsement to the strategic arms limitation treaty that was signed by President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, four days ago in Vienna.

title: HEADY PLAY: Johan Neeskens, left, latest International star Join Cosmos, heading ball to Gary Etherington in practice session yesterday at Giants Stadium.
World Gold
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 22, 1979

title: Netherlands Dancers Coming to New York
description: After a sevenyear absence, the Netherlands Dance Theater will return to New York for a twoweek season at the City Center 55th Street Theater, 131  West 55th 'street. starting July 9. The company will perform eight works Dy Kylian, the Czechoslovak choreographer who now heads the company with Carel Birnie, and one by Hans van Manen.

title: TROY ARCHER DIES; LINEMAN FOR GIANTS
description: Troy Archer, a 24-year-old defensive lineman for the New York Giants, was killed last night in an accident in North Bergen, N.J., involving a pickup truck and a telephone pole, according to the police. Few details of the accident were available.

description: Questions are based on news reports In The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 26.

description: ST. LOUIS, June 22  The St. Louis Cardinals, thriving on home cooking tonight, used two home runs by Ted Simmons to hand the Mets their fourth straight loss on their current road trip, 42.

title: The Vicars of Christ On..EAtth
description: THE MAKING OF THE POPES 1978 The Politics of Intrigue in the Vatican. By Andrew M. Greeley. Illustrated. 302 pp. Kansas City, Kan.: Andrews and McMeel. $12.95. IT is almost a plunge into nostalgia now, only nine months after the events themselves, to relive the three months of the three Popes: when the television camera peered benevolently.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS A Briton Looks at Nicaragua
description: LONDON  When Augusto Cesar Sandino was murdered in 1939 by Anastasio Somoza Garcia, the first Somoza, his body was hastily buried. under the tarmac of Managua Airoort.

title: Getting There Without a Car
description: ASBURY PARK BY USING public transportation in these days of gasoline rationing, New Jerseyans can avail themselves not only of the state's many beaches, but also tennis courts, golf courses, skateboard parks, dinnertheaters and more.

description: THE YAWNING HEIGHTSIN 1790 Alexander Radishchev, one of the earliest of Russian intellectuals and dissidents, brought out his Journey From Petersburg to Moscow.

title: Carey Signs Bill Giving Suburbs More Representation on M.T.A.
description: ALBANY, June 23  Governor Carey signed bills this week expanding suburban representation on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and setting up an agency that will provide cheap loans to businesses locating or expanding on Long Island.

title: District 65 to Join the U.A.W.
description: District 65, an independent, New Yorkbased union with 35,000 members in the city and around the country, is affiliating with the 1.5 million member United automobile Workers union, the U. A. W: announced yesterday in Detroit.

title: Farm Workers Excluded At a Labor Import Parley
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., June 23  All morning they stood silently in the shimmering, 90degree heat outside the Rancho Viejo Country Clubdozens of farm workers who had walked 50 miles to this border town in the hope of meeting with the Governors of Texas, Arizona and New Mexico, the three states in which they are struggling naraest to vim mow recogmtion for their embattled union.

title: Jane M. Lord Wed to Richard Andrews Jr.
description: Jane Morris Lord and Richard Hale Andrews Jr. were married yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston. The Rev. David L. Bynum performed the ceremony.

title: Leading Japanese Politician Suggests Oil Users Cartel
description: TOKYO, 4 June 23  In a sharp fesponse to the recent surge in international oil, prices, a leading Japanese politician has called on Western industrial nations and Japan to form an oil consumers cartel to bring pressure Q11 the oil mite!, the Orsanitation of Petroleum Exporting Cow. tries.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: 1 SCRUPLES, by Judith Krantz. (Warner, $2.75.) A woman's rise in the fashion world: fiction.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The quarterFranklin, is a neat little thing in the shape of a coin and pure gold. Its nickname belongs to the quarterounce size of the Franklin Mint Gold Pieces. These new bullion coins are being minted in 24karat gold (.999 fine), in three weights: a full troy ounce, a halfounce and a quarterounce.

title: A Child's View of Architecture
description: YONKERS MOST of us, while we are growing up, hardly ever think of buildings as anything other than already built. People live and work in them. They protect us from the rain and snow. But we rarely consider how they are conceived, how they use space or how their appearance has been made more pleasing. And schools usually don't teach us such things.

title: The Right Marriage Split
description: Many oncemarried women were properly envious when Lee Marvin was ordered to pay his former mistress of six years $104,000 for support. That is because Michele Triola Marvin was being treated more fairly by the courts of California than many formally married women have been treated in regular divorce proceedings.

title: Get'm!
description: It turns out there is one inventor left in the world who has been doing what inventors are supposed to do: search for a better mousetrap. And a year ago this inventor, Lennart Lindblad, who lives and works in a small town in Sweden and who is better known for his car safety devices, found one, or so he believes.

title: 192 Nuclear Protesters Guilty
description: ST. HELENS, Ore., June 23 (UPI) The 192 members of the Trojan Decommissioning Alliance, on trial for criminal trespass stemming from last August's fourday occupation of the Trojan Nuclear Plant, were found guilty yesterday.District Judge Robert Redding set sentencing for next week.

title: O.A.S. MEASURE ASKS IMMEDIATE OUSTER OF SOUZA'S REGIME
description: WASHINGTON. June 23  The Organization of American States called today for the immediate and definitive replacement in Nicaragua of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle's regime by broadly based democratic government.

title: Sailing to Nassau On a Tryout Cruise
description: For many of the 700odd passengers, it was a shakedown cruise. They had never been to sea before and had a lot of doubts about how they would fit in with the others on the liner, what to wear, what the abundance of food might do to their waistlines and, most of all, whether the ship would rock and make them seasick.

title: Republican Candidates Scurry to Organize in New Hampshire for 1980's First Primary.
description: CONCORD, N.H., June 23  George Bush was through the state this week again, warning Rotarians of dangers from the Russians Backfire bomber to little bad Yemen, and from Laconia to Nashua he was shaking hands, making friends. His state campaign manager, former Gov. Hugh Gregg, was following, taking names.

title: Second 'salute to Women in Jazz Set
description: While the Newport Jazz Festival is attracting jazz buffs to Carnegie Hall and Avery Fisher Hall this week, the work of women in jazz will be put on display at Lincoln Center and in Greenwich Village with daily concerts, workshops and conferences starting Tuesday and running through next Sunday.

title: Mary O'Connell Is Married To Maxwell D. Bardeen Jr.
description: Mary Elizabeth O'Connell and Maxwell Dickerman Bardeen Jr. were married yesterday In St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Thomas Guinan.

title: Truckers Abduct and Rob Driver, Then Lecture Him on Their Strike
description: GLEN BURNIE, Md., June 23 (UPI) A truck driver was forced off a superhighway by two tractortrailer rigs whose drivers abducted, robbed and lectured him about observing the independent truckers strike, the state police said today.

title: Adele F. Slaughter, Teacher, Is Married
description: Adele Francis Slaughter, daughter of Lieut. Col. Stephen F. Slaughter, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Slaughter of Myersville, Md., was married yesterday afternoon to Fredeiick Curtis Woolverton. He is the son of Mrs. Curtis E. Calder of Dallas and Oyster Bay, L.I., and William H. Woolverton Jr. of New York and Oyster Bay.

title: In an Apartment
description: When I was a child and lived in the suburbs, my father had a compost bin at the back of the garden. We put in grass clippings, leaves and afterdinner garbage and took out crumbly. rich soil. When I moved to the city, compost seemed out of the question. But I felt regret every time I dumped my afterdinner garbage into the trash can. I got to thinking. Why couldn't I make compost? What rule said that a compost heap had to be big or outdoors? Why couldn't I make mini compost piles right in my kitchen?

title: Trailways Driver Is Slain on Bus; Assailant Is Hit by Car and Killed
description: RICHMOND, Va., June 23 (AP)  A passenger on a Trailways bus stabbed the driver to death on Interstate 95 near here today, then was himself killed when he stepped from the bus and was struck by a hit and run driver, the police said.

title: Rumania Gives U.S. Data in Case Against Bishop Called ExFascist
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  The Justice Department said yesterday that Rumania had sent a large number of documents intended to assist in the prosecution of Rumanian Orthodox Bishop who has been accused of concealing fascist activities in Rumania in order to obtain American citizenship.

title: Far Away From Home
description: A LONG DESIREEVAN S. CONNELL'S 11th book is one of those pleasure books of nonfiction that a good novelist will pause to write once in a while as a relief from the rigors of invention. A Long Desire is a survey of great feats of exploration, a compendium of 275 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $10.95. lifetime's reading of adventure, a book of wonders, florid history, provisional facts and catchy ironies, laconic heroism and scabrous villainies, cryptic deaths and other endings. It celebrates the glitter of world newly created by God, yet nonetheless to be conquered for God, as Balboa did when he waded into the water at the Isthmus of Darien with a naked sword to take possession of the whole Pacific for Christ and Castile.

title: Questions/Answers
description: Several of my rhododendrons and azaleas had excellent leaf growth this year but no blooms. The soil tests 6.5. The plants were fertilized last year in spring and in June. 1 added aluminum sulfate this year. Why have they not bloomed? J.A.B., Toledo, Ohio

title: Fund Camp Is Family Tradition for 2 Boys
description: Morris and Troy Duncan will not be leaving for the Fresh Air Fund's Camp Hidden Valley for another month, but the brothers are eagerly planning ahead. For Troy, 9 years old, it's the swimming every day that he is looking forward to the most. For Morris, 12, it's the chance to renew friendships.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The small exhibition of 19thcentury photographs from the Arnold Crane collection at the Museum of Modern Art through July 29 is the most enjoyable exhibition of photographs now in town. Though perhaps the word to describe it is not just enjoyable but fun.

title: Assessments Also Tax Owners Patience
description: AREVOLT over inequitable tax assessments Is growing. In some areas of Suffolk County, angry residents, primarily residents of newhome developments in the Town of Brookhaven, are discovering that their homes are being assessed for a great deal more than they are actually worth. Also, homeowners all over the Island are beginning to question the meaning of their fractional assessments, and a bill recently signed into law by Governor Carey is expected to simplify assessment appeals.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: If the weather is fair, or even passable, it is hard to imagine a more pleasant way to spend a June evening than at an outdoor performance of Johann Strauss Jr.'s Joyous comic opera Die Fledermaus.

title: INTERVIEW
description: BERGENFIELD THER4 were mixed emotions in Joseph E. Scuro's home the day after the recent Board of Education election here. Mr. Scuro, president of the fivemember board for the last three years, was gratified that he was reelected, but sorry to see the proposed school budget reiected.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The first year. How does massmarket paperback publishing compare with hardcover publishing? We asked that leading question of one of the few people who has occupied a high office on both sides of Publishers Row. Richard Krinsley moved across the street last July to head Ballantine Books after 25 years in sales and managerial positions at Simon & Schuster and Random House.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: MOUNT vERNON'S auxiliary officers have not patrolled the city's streets since May 4, when the entire 40member squad was dismissed by the city's Civil Defense Director for refusing to report to work on the nights of April 28 and 29.

title: Linda Garrett Martin Married To George E. McLaughlin Jr,
description: Linda Garrett Martin and George Edwin McLaughlin Jr., alumni of Coe College, were married yesterday in Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. Donald W. Emig performed the ceremony in the United Church.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Book Ends may as well be the first to light the literary cake for the birthday boy, E.B. White, who will turn 80 years old July 11. And to conress mat wnenever i write about him, or speak with him, I rediscover all my mixed metaphors and grammatical faults that show kup in his Elements of Style.

title: Elizabeth Marden Wed in Connecticut
description: Beatrice Elizabeth Marden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Walker Marden of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Matthew Marshall 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Marshall Jr. of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Stanley Lyon Houston performed the ceremony in the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

title: ANTIQUES
description: After a threeyear lull, English period furniture has rebounded dramatically, with prices for Georgian designs escalating at auction, twice in six months. That, in turn, has caused a ripple effect on prices paid in antiques galleries both here and abroad.

title: TV VIEW
description: Sportly after a recent threeclay Rockefeller Foundation Seminar involving independent producers, New York's Channel 13 announced a summer schedule. While both events were ostensibly unrelated, together they provide insight into the current and possibly future state of nroerammin2 on public television. WNET/13 hardly represents all of public television, but it does account for at least 20 percent of the system's total audience, and that adds up to clout and influence. For the next couple of months, the station will be experimenting with what it calls ways to broaden its audience. On tap, for the most part, is a discouraging combination of reruns and superficial packaging.

title: Black Film Festival
description: NEWARK THE Newark Black Film Festival, an event that has been steadily increasing in stature, is being presented for the fifth consecutive year.

title: Israel's Other Enemy: Inflation
description: When the Israelis joke these days about inflation, it's perilously close to gallows humor, for inflation has soared from 50 percent last year to an annual rate near 100 percent during recent months.

title: Riches in ClosemVp at Auctions
description: Glamorous public auctions in major capitals and resorts these days are attracting a heavy flow of the merely curious, right along with dealers and serious collectors. Most are free shows at which travelers get a chance to see valuable works of art up close, to see huge amounts of money change hands and to witness firsthand the drama of competition for antiaue treasures.

title: The Knowns and Unknowns
description: One day in the fall of 1972 Senator George McGovern, the Democratic candidate for President, made a campaign stop in rural Illinois. His campaign aides had chosen the place with some care; it was an agricultural area. Wheat was a basic crop, and the candidate had a serious charge to make. He had the facts of what became known as the Great Grain Robbery. Officials in the Nixon Administration, he said, had conFrank Mankfewicz, the president of National Public Radio, is the author of Perfectly Clear, a, book about television, and other books on American politics.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Polypropylene mesh netting over berries will keep birds out while fruit ripens. When mowing, leave short clippings on the lawn; they will return nitrogen to the soil. Last call to sow lima beans and sweet corn for late season harvest. There is still time to sow dwarf marigolds and nasturtiums for bloom in August. Keep after caterpillars; use BT, a biological control.

title: Police Use TV Camera, Arrest 2 in Auto Thefts
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 23 (AP) The police, using a closedcircuit television camera mounted in a tree, have arrested a couple allegedly stealing valuables from cars parked in a tourist area.

description: Day by day, last week's parade of economic tidbits offered something for everyone.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from a study tour of the Soviet legal system. While there I came to the frightening realization that the odds in the economic cold war may now favor the U.S.S.R. because of the energy situation. The Soviets assert they are immune to energy crises.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Those who have worked at his side are intensely loyal, in part because of it. Financiers and investors who have cut deals with him say they envy it and crave an understanding of its source. Skeptics who doubted it are stepping forward for conversion.

title: All the Summer's a Stage
description: ON the eve of the opening of the Island's summer theater season, Anthony Stimac has problem. While problems are common to all summer theater managers, Mr. Stimac, who runs the show at the John Drew Theater in East Hampton, is faced with an unusual puzzler.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The representative of the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the strategic arms negotiations in Geneva was incorrectly identified in a report from Vienna in The Times last Sunday. Lieut. Gen. Edward L. Rowny has represented the Joint Chiefs at the negotiations since 1973.

title: Suburban Recipe
description: Bwilding a compost pile can be as simple as dumping a bucket of garbage or as elaborate as trimming a Christmas tree. The pile can be as small as a trash can or it can be a vast mound weighing several tons.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: Had the brothers Naipaul not existed, would you have had to invent them? One suspects so. For how else would it have been possible for little brother Shiva to pontificate in your columns [Shiva Naipaul's North of South: An African Journey reviewed by John Darnton] that the African soul is a blank slate on which anything can be written, onto which any fantasy can be transposed. That was May 6. In your May 13 issue, senior brother Vidiadhar compounds the nonsense by intoning dramatically, to the quite evident titillation of interviewer Elizabeth Hardwick, that Africa has no future.

title: Detroit Is Running on Less Gas
description: DETROIT  The fuel shortage spells trouble for the American automobile industry, and trouble for the auto industry spells trouble for the nation's economy. So goes the timetested theory. Things have changed so much since the last fuelrelated sales slump, however, that many analysts believe the theory no longer holds as firmly.

title: Pentecostals Hold Fast in Moscow Embassy
description: MOSCOW, June 23  Seven Russian Pentecostals who took refuge in the American Embassy a year ago, breaking past the Soviet police guards at the gate, say they are determined to stay indefinitely, praying that God will make possible for them to emigrate to the United States.

title: Biths
description: Dr and Mrs Bruce L. Halbridge (nee Penny Abrams) are happy to announce the birth of Adam Stuart on June 10, 1979. Thousand Oaks. Calif. Proud grandparents are Mr and Mrs Al Abrams and Mr and Mrs Alexander S. tisibridge.

description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 23Chris Evert Lloyd avenged last year's loss here today, toppling Martina Navratilova in a threehour final of the Colgate international women's tennis tournament, 75, 5.7,1311.

title: GARDENING
description: MY battle cry is water, water! said Mrs. Frederick Austin. The summer sun is so strong, and people who grow plants in containers always tend to underwater plants. Mrs. Austin, after many years of experience growing flowering plants in containers  indoors and out in her northern Westchester County gardenhas learned how to keep plants thriving.

description: THE tangled web of family relationships, the comfort of familiar places and things, old friends  these are the themes that concern Roberta Silman in her new novel, Boundaries.

title: The Making of a Social Conscience
description: THE EDUCATION OF CAREY McWILLIANIS By Carey McWilliams. 363 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $11 95.CAREY McWILLIAMS is a significant figure the history of contemporary journalism. bright young litterateur in California in the 1920's, he became a brilliant social investigator in the 30's and 90's. In the 50's, he moved to New York and edited the famous old liberal weekly The Nation for 20 years. He has had an interesting life and ought to have written a more interesting book.

title: Board of Public TV Station on L.I. To Look Into Divisive Accusations
description: The board of trustees of Long Island's publictelevOlon station, WLIW, Channel 21, is to meet tomorrow to act on divisive accusations that include conflicts of interest. nenotismaxi incompetence.

description: THE green of summer makes New Jersey a softer, gentler place in which to live. If nothing else, summer seems to celebrate abundance and complexity.

description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts holds an overwhelming lead among Democratic voters as their choice for their party's 1980 Presidential nomination, jiccording to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Biaggi Seeks New Water Safety Plan
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of New York, has introduced a bill in Congress that would require the money raised by the Federal Marine Fuel Tax, about $30 million a year, to be used to support the State Boating Safety Programs and to build recreational boating facilities.

title: Egyptian Students Art on Peace Stirs Emotions in Israel Museum
description: JERUSALEM, June 23  The theme is peace, and a 13yearold student painted President Anwar elSadat of Egypt riding in a motorcade with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel. Its coloring is vivid. The influence of television is evident.

title: The New York Times/Joyce Dopkeen
description: Birdwatching, a competitive sport. Page 13

title: DANCE VIEW
description: It is 30 years since Britain's Royal Ballet, then known the Sadler's Wells Ballet, made its United States debut the Metropolitan Opera House and not so coincidentally, Dame Ninette de Valois, its founder and former director, happened to be in town recently. The Royal Ballet begins its 30th anniversary North American tour this Tuesday near Washington, D.C. at Wolf Trap Farm Park, Va., and Dame Ninette has, by her own account, come over to talk about the company. If it may seem strange to see one of the foremost cultural figures in history embarked on the public relations circuit, it is equally clear why the same figure is so effective. Anyone who claims to have just turned 81 but looks 20 years younger than her photographs and who also proclaims a passion for whiskey sours is bound to win every heart. Of course, her formidable reputation has preceded her. Without Ninette de Valois, or at least the young Irish dancer who changed her name from Edris Stannus to Ninette de Valois, there would be no Royal Ballet. She founded it in 1931 and she molded it totally until handing over the directorship to Sir Frederick Ashton in 1963.

title: Susan Stroud Bride Of John Kleinfelder
description: The marriage of Susan de Forest Stroud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Stroud of Fort Washington, Pa., to John McCarter Kleinfelder took place yesterday In St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chestnut Hill. Philadelphia. The Rev. James J. Moody, the rector, performed the ceremony.

title: In Russia
description: MOSCOW  The facade of order and unanimity that masks Communist Party life in the Soviet Union has proved especially sturdy and opaque in recent weeks. Leonid I. Brezhnev, the party chief, prepared for his Vienna meeting \b}b}vim rresiaent carter last weekend in an atmosphere of outward calm, without any open debate over the strategic arms treaty, and without any hint that the 72yearold Soviet leader's failing health has jeopardized the moderate themes of his foreign and domestic policies.

title: Ford Criticizes Carter But Bars Race in 80
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, June 23 (UPI)  Former President Gerald R. Ford is critical of his successor's fiscal  and energy policies but still says he will not seek the Republican Presidential nomination next year.

description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPILow level clouds cover New England, the North and Middle Atlantic States and the lower lake region. Scattered clouds and thunderstorms also cover the lower Mississippi Valley, the Northern and Central Plains States, the Intermountain region and the northern Rockies. Skies are clear elsewhere In the country.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: ACROWD of the state's brightest aspiring Democrats are eyeing the job of retiring Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, and wondering about the best time to jump into the race. But all of them. even the two 34yearold upwardly mobile Congressmen, Christopher J. Dodd and Anthony Toby Moffett, have been beaten to the punch by 73yearold Thomas Suplna Jr., in a 57yearold automobile.

description: 9 P.M. (7) HOLLOW IMAGE. This twohour drama by Lee Hunkins about a successful black fashion executive who is drawn back to her old Harlem neighborhood is the second presentation of the New Drama for Television Project at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center.

Silha, president of the Star and Tribune Company, and in Buffalo by William J. Conners III, publisher of the CourierExpress.The purchase price was not revealed.

title: In China, the Communist Party Reviews its Faults
description: HONG KONG  Wang Xiaoping should have been a paragon of Communist virtue. His father had been the party leader of a prefecture in Shanxi province and was recently promoted to a ranking lob in the Shanxi party headquarters.

description: PLAINFIELD IT ALMOST seemed like a point of honor. At stake was the reputation of the City of Plainfield among the realestate and banking community, and among those who rose to sing its praises were the City Administrator, the Tax Assessor and the Superintendent of Sschols.

title: Canada Seen Suspending Shift of Embassy in Israel
description: OTTAWA, June 23  The transfer of the Canadian Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, to which the new Progressive Conservative Government has committed itself, appears to have been put off indefinitely after a barrage of criticism at home and strong pressure from American and other sources.

title: Roth Again Takes Final Of Oregon Bowling Event
description: PORTLAND, Ore., June 23 (AP) Mark Roth became the first bowler to win the Rose City open in two straight years as he defeated Dennis Lane, 257195, in the final of the $70,000 tournament.

title: REVOLUTIONARY ART
description: Few exhibitions of modern art have been as eagerly anticipated as the mammoth ParisMoscow show that has now come to the Georges Pompidou National Center of Art and Culture Paris for a long stay (through Nov. 5). A major show of the Russian avantgarde is something that museums specializing in modern art have long wanted to present, but the obstacles were known to be formidable. The bulk of the work essential to such a show lay sequestered in the socalled reserve, or forbidden, sections of the museums in the Soviet Union, and official Soviet policy remained opposed to open recognition of the modernist movement. The release of this art for exhibition in the West seemed to require a political or diplomatic miracle, and this is what ParisMoscow promised to be.

By 1927 I had been invited to join the special organizing staff Wimbledon engaged annually for the two weeks of its championships.

description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 23  Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus paid rather extraordinary courtesy call here today to explain the latest rung in the Carter Administration's climb toward national water policy.

title: Philanthropy
description: WASHINGTON  The Young Men's Christian Association is now a standard recipient of charitable contributions.. But if George Williams, the 22yearold drygoods clerk who started the Y.M.C.A. more than a century ago in England, were starting up America today, he would have great difficulty getting philanthropic funds for his work. According the National Committee on Responsive Philanthropy, Mr. Williams venture, like today's women's groups, minority organizations and public interest organizations, would be a nontraditional donee, too new, too risky and too controversial to get money from traditional charity sources. In addition, his age and occupation, like those of many in today's nontraditional organizations, would effectively make him unable to influence the philanthropic circles of power  mainly the white, middleaged and successful males who govern corporate and foundation giving.

title: Holmes May Delay Title Match

Koornhof.

title: Legislature Still Revising Penal Code
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH the state's new Penal Code  the first major overhaul of the criminal statues in 80 years  is to take effect Sept. 1, committees in the Senate and Assembly are still working on an omnibus bill flit will amend more than 80 sections of the new code.

Klein, the incumbent, prepares to confront a Democratic opponent, County Legislator Martin J. Feldman, and a possible Republican challenger, Islip Town Supervisor Peter F. Cohalan.

title: CAMERA
description: To most people the summer means lots of sun, heat and frolicking in or near the water. While tanned human bodies can easily enjoy these elements, camera bodies are more likely to malfunction under these same conditions. Like sun worshippers, who must take steps to protect their bodies against excessive heat and sunshine, photoworshippers must also take steps to protect their equipment.

title: The Moral Equivalent of the Gas Line
description: For one poignant moment last week, between grandiose journeys to foreign summits, Jimmy Carter had a chance to experience the humiliation that the OPEC cartel daily inflicts on his country. For a President, should have been the moral equivalent of the as line.

description: Dressed as she usually is, in jeans, a sweater, a denim jacket and a denim hat, Vinnette Carroll stood 10 front of her Urban Arts Theater's actors, singers and dancers: She watched them carefully, and occasionally.hoomed Out comments or orders to the cast going through their Daces. rehearsing When Hell Freezes Over, I'll Skate; which will be televised on WNETTV on Wednesday at 9 P.M.

By the time they take the field for the first New Jersey High School AllStar football game at Rutgers Stadium next Saturday, a few new stories will be told.

description: Two authors who have been researching the Soviet atomic espionage case in which Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were executed in 1953 have concluded that Julius Rosenberg was indeed at the hub of an espionage network that continued to operate until his arrest in 1950, but they say that his wife was not.

The name is a play on numbers, 411 referring both to the Bleecker Street address as well as the telephone directoryassistance number 411, always a busy number, as they say on the matchbooks at the restaurant.

title: 12 Men Arrested at Jersey Shore With a 40Ton Cargo of Marijuana

description: PARIS, June 23  Raymond Aron, one of France's most distinguished journalists and teachers, has just published in English a remarkable book with the odd title In Defense of Decadent Europe. Henry Kissinger calls it one of the most important intellectual statements of our time.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A cool spray from the garden hose and a gulp of water in a paper cup will be welcome additions to prearranged water stations along the route of the Third Annual Westchester HalfMarathon  13.1 miles  starting off at 10 A.M. today from Martine and Lexington Avenues in White Plains. More than 4,000 runners are participating under the auspices of the City of New Rochelle and the New York Road Runners Club, traversing the Bronx River Parkway to Greenacres Avenue in Scarsdale, across to New Rochelle and down Pinebrook Boulevard, ending at Iona College.

title: A.D.A. Is Urged to Shun Carter in 1980 Election
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP)  Arthur Schlesinger Jr. told the Americans for Democratic Action today that the liberal element of the Democratic Party must select a candidate other than President Carter to carry the party's banner next year. sir. Schlesinger, a White House aide in the Administration of John F. Kennedy, said that if Senator Edward M. Kennedy could not be persuaded to run for the Democratic Presidential nomination In 1 0, party liberals should look for another alternative.

title: CRIME
description: Add THE BOTTICELLI MADONNA by Richard Cox (McGrawHill, $9.95) to your already large list of mystery stories revolving around the art world. It is better written than most and full of inside information about the way dealers, critics and auction houses operate.

title: Sarah Ogden Hoffman Bride of Clergyman
description: Sarah Ogden Hoffman, daughter of Mrs. James Drier of West Brighton, S.I., and C. Fenno Hoffman Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday in Cambridge to the Rev. Gary Vaughn Partenheimer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Partenheimer of Ambler, Pa. The Rev. Mary Scherm performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Episcopal Divinity School, of which the bridegroom is a graduate.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biography of Pierre Caline (190036), the French composer, I would appreciate any information, letters, manuscripts or personal reminiscences.

title: The Region
description: John G. deRoos, the senior executive officer of the New York City Transit Authority, became R46's first known casualty last week. Mr. deRoos resigned, saying that he was very tired. That was probably true. For two weeks, he had been at the center of a controversy involving subway cars that were first expensive, then hazard. ous and finally politically explosive.

title: Jump to Higher Level Helps Youth Mature
description: In elementary school, they teased Scott Flack about his size and weight. When a window in the school was broken or fights started, Scott's name invariably was mentioned, even if he was not involved.

title: Suburban G.O.P. Bastions Are Cracking Suffolk, Too
description: Not so long ago, New York suburban politics was, for the most part, synonymous with Republican politics. Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk counties were solid G.O.P. territory. Things aren't so predictable anymore. In Republican Westchester, the county executive is a Democrat, Alfred DelBello. In Nassau, the Republican organization, which usually walks in lockstep, was split two years ago as the party hierarchy turned on the incumbent county executive, Ralph G. Caso, and ousted him from office in favor of Francis T. Purcell.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: FINISHING up a college course last summer that had delved into what was being done to save some of Connecticut's older houses and buildings liprh Innick, a history professor at Western Connecticut College in Danbury, was somewhat surprised to find his students eager to form a preservation group in their own city.

title: Trade Accord Expected to Aid 2 Industries
description: WASHINGTON NEW JERSEY'S two largest industries chemicals and electronics  are expected to benefit greatly from the liberalized terms agreed upon in the socalled Multilateral Trade Negotiations, according to a Department of Commerce analysis expected to be released soon.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Rubin Sanders is a veteran performer who has appeared with the Amato Opera, Paterson Lyric Opera and New Jersey Philharmonic. On June 16, the bassbaritone gave his first solo recital in Carnegie Recital Hall, and his performances had the poise and ease to be expected from a singer of his experience.

title: Fashion
description: pholographs by Tito Barberis; hair and makeup by Wendy Whitelaw.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Like an illusionist pulling an endless handkerchief from his sleeve, Robert Craft continues to draw Stravinsky memorabilia from apparently inexhaustible files. The composer's onetime secretary, close friend, musical assistant and literary collaborator  and, finally, ghost writer  might be expected to run low on material one of these clays, having cosignea nair a dozen fascinating books of memoirs with Stravinsky during the composer's life as well as turning out others since his death. Then, of course, there has been, early and late, the staggering outpouring of interviews, critical essays, commentaries, polemical blasts and biographical snippets appearing over the years in popular magazines, scholarly journals and publications of every stripe and complexion. What, one might wonder, is there left to learn about Igor Stravinsky that Robert Craft has not combed through again and again?

title: Jill Greenwood Becomes Bride Of A.I. duPont
description: Jill Greenwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs., Ronald E. Greenwood of HastingsonHudson, N.Y., and Chilmark, Mass., and Augustus Irenee duVont, son of Rosamond Lee duPont of Landenberg, Pa., and FranciS I. duPont of Chadds Ford, Pa., were married yesterday at the West Tisbury Congregational Church on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. The Rev. John E. Wallace performed the ceremony.

title: How to Wipe Out the Graffiti
description: Nov. 10, 1976, became a redletter day for residents of one suburban school district. A gang of disgruntled students made taxpayers see red by leaving their crude calling cards in classrooms, the cafeteria, library, teachers lounge and new gymnasium. The graffiti blitzkrieg forced a weeklong halt in extracurricular activities and led the principal to declare the damage the most extensive in his 18 years with the district.

title: A.S.L. Stars Play a Scoreless Tie
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 23  The American Soccer League staged the first allstar game by a professional soccer league in the United States tonight, but only 2,321 fans turned out at Hofstra Stadium to watch a scoreless tie between the top players from the East and West Divisions.

title: ART
description: G ATES AND FENCES is. a large and complex show devoted to the estheticssometimes accidental  of enclosure and the marking of boundaries. It can be seen at Thorpe IntermeOa Gallery, which is on the estate of the Dominican convent in Sparldll (Route 340, through July 1). The exhibition is in large part the work of David Weinrib, a sculptor of some prominence who some years ago diversified by becoming the director of the Intermedia Foundation in Garnerville Besides having designed the inStallation, Mr. Weinrib is responsible for the 119 color photographs that comPrise about half of the exhibition and, in a sense, introduce it.

title: Behind the Scenes of IllFated Joley
description: JOLEY,the musical about the life and times of Al Jolson that began a preBroadway tryout at the Northstage TheaterRestaurant in Glen Cove on March 2, in a flurry of fanfare, good will, optimism and all that, concluded its scheduled run on April 22, in a great huff of aidmosity, misunderstandings, miscalculations, pending lawsuits and no intention whatever of opening on Broadway the next month, as originally planned.

title: Joanne Eastman Is Married
description: Joanne Eastman and Jeremiah Evarts were married in Windsor, Vt., yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Prescott Everts, by the Rev. Arthur E. Bello, an Episcopal priest. The bride and bridegroom, both of whom were previously married and divorced, are teaching at the Dalton School in New York. The bride is head of the history and, social sciences departments and Mr. Evarts is headl of the English department. Mrs. Evarts is a daughter of John A. Curtis of Williamsburg, Va., and the late Helen Curtis.

title: Linda Bienenstock Is Married To Thomas Purcell, a Lawyer
description: Linda Bienenstock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Bienenstock of Putnam Valley, N.Y., was married in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday to Thomas Fitzgerald Purcell, son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Purcell of Rye, N.Y. Msgr. Edward M. Connors performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: J.C. Cox Weds Emily Ford
description: In the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Emily Van Orden Ford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Richards Ford 3d of Greenwich, was married to John Charles Cox, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Cox of Rock Port, Mo. The Rev. Robert E. Sanders performed the ceremony.

title: Soviet Liner Will Visit Sound on a Minicruise
description: The liner Kazakhstan embarked yesterday on a minicruise that, for the first lime, was scheduled to take a Soviet passenger ship into Long Island Sound.

title: Police Affidavit Describes Planning of Purolator Robbery
description: TWO couples accused of murdering three security guards during the $1.7 million robbery of a Purolator Security Company garage here had discussed, during the planning of the crime, how they could spare the lives of the guards, according to a previously undisclosed police affidavit. The affidavit also suggests that the robbery at the Purolator garage had been inspired by the earlier burglary of a social club next door to the garage.

title: Michael J. Horvitz, Lawyer, Is Fianc Of Jane Rosenthal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leighton A. Rosenthal of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jane Rosenthal, to Michael John Horvitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Horvitz, also of Shaker Heights.

title: Byrd to Tell Moscow Of Senate Treaty Role
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, said today that he would tell Soviet leaders in Moscow next week that the Senate is under no obligation to support the stridegic arms treaty just because of Leonid I. Brezhnev's warnings against any attempt to change it.

title: Feuds, Ethnic Pressures Marked Hunt for Brooklyn College Head
description: In May, the Board of Higher Education unanimously elected Robert L. Hess, 46yearold historian and associate vice chancellor of the University of Illinois at Chicago Circle, as the sixth president of Brooklyn College.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Less than four months after the incident at Three Mile Island, we are faced with the possibility that something picturesquely described as being about the size of a Dutch windmill, but weighing a good deal more, will come crashing into our atmosphere on or about July 16 to spread debris around the world. Are our chickens coming home to roost? When you are told that your chance of being hit by a piece of Skylab is no more than one in 600 billion, do you quake anyway and say, Just my luck? When you read about an engine mount falling off the wing of a DC10 and about cracks in subway cars, are you convinced that these things are the beginning of the end? I amat least in the middle of the night.

title: United Press International
description: WHAT GOES UP: Mickey Rivers of Yanks watching foul pop drift toward stands in game against Indians Friday at Stadium. Yanks won. 32.

description: The engagement of Deborah E. Strauss to John A. Droney 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Droney of West Hartford, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Curt L. Strauss of Scarsdale, N.Y.

description: Sarah Jane Orr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Orr of Montclair, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to David Timothy Read, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Read of Lakewood. Calif.

title: It's Frantic Time on the Straw Hat Circuit
description: On Cape Cod, a caretaker throws open the doors and the old theater  once a barn  seems to sigh, expelling in a single breath the cold, musty air of winter. The staff arrives, followed by apprentices and a procession of painters, plumbers, crew members and carpenters.

title: Mailbox: The Fear of Success Is Worse Than the Fall From It
description: To the Sports Editor: Dr. Stanley Cheren (Success in Sports Often Breeds Failure, May 27) has described an interesting but relatively infrequent syndrome in athletes who fail after reaching the pinnacle of success. Its low incidence in star athletes is not surprising. To reach the top levels of any sport, many prior competitive successes must have been achieved and tolerated.

title: Belden Triumphs In Rowing
description: Bill Belden of the New York Athletic Club established himself as the No. singles sculler in the United States yesterday when he defeated a teammate, Larry Klecatslcv in an elite lightweight race in the 79th annual metropolitan rowing championships at the Orchard Beach Lagoon, the Bronx.

title: Support of the Military Brass Is Vital for SALT Approval
description: WASHINGTON  In early January, President Carter received a disturbing memorandum from the Pentagon, informing him that the nation's senior military ieaaers, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had seri. ous doubts about entering into a new strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union. Agitated White House aides discussed the implications for the coming Senate debate on the proposed accord. It was unthinkable that Gen. David C. Jones, handpicked by Mr. Carter for the chairmanship of the Joint Chiefs, would actually oppose a new treaty in his Senate testimony. But he and his colleagues could probably scuttle it with faint praise.

title: POINTS. OF VIEW
description: Various government sources have been putting up sinister trial balloons recently on the subject of Federal chartering of corporations. This concept would involve issuing specific operating rules, or charters, governing corporate activities, and would totally change the face of American business  in my opinion, for the worse.

title: IN THE NATION Routine Of Death
description: Gov. Robert Graham of Florida signed warrants last week for the execution of two men convicted of murder in that state. The courts will probably intervene in their CSLSPS_ but if not, me two win go to the electric chair at 7 A.M. Wednesday, June 27, less than a month after the State of Florida executed John Spenkelink by sending three massive surges of electricity through his body over a period of six minutes.

title: Technology
description: WASHINGTON  Nathan A. Allen left his Job on the swing shift at the Bethlehem Steel plant in Sparrows Point, Md., one day last month, walked to his Dodge pickup in the company lot, got in, inserted the ignition key, and turned it. In the split second that the key actuated the starter it also energized a blasting cap that in turn detonated two sticks of dynamite under the driver's seat. Mr. Allen was catapulted outward through the windshield, mortally wounded.

description: Mary Genevieve Salvia, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gaspare Anthony Salvia of New York, was married yesterday to Edward Randolph Pezzaro, son of Mr.. and Mrs. Rudy Pezzaro of Fort Lee, N.J. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony in St.Thomas More Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Anthony Bumscano.

title: what's Doing in ANCHORAGE
description: NOT SO ICY  To dispel a popular misconception, Anchorage is not bound by ice and snow, even in winter. The city has paved streets, modern hotels, highrise office buildings and views of the Chugach Mountains on three sides.

title: BRIDGE
description: If there were an award for the weirdest hand of the year, it might well go to the diagramed deal, played last month in the Cavendish Invitational Pair Championship in New York. Before reading about it, the reader should study the diagram and try to find answers to four tricky questions:

title: CALENDAR
description: Friday  July 1. Reenactment of British invasion of Greater New Haven; at Lighthouse Point, Friday afternoon; at Fort Nathan Hale, Saturday afternoon; at West Haven Green, Sunday afternoon.

title: PRESIDENT DEPARTS FOR TALKS IN JAPAN
description: ANCHORAGE, June 23  President Carter, departing for a sevennation economic summit meeting in Tokyo, warned today that the industrialized democracies must coordinate their energy policies to avoid being set against each other in a desperate competition for every barrel of oil, regardless of price.

title: Finding Gasoline By Telephone
description: The operator was quick and concise. Lynchburg, Virginia? she said. One moment please. A few seconds later, she relayed the information supplied her by computer: I can tell you only about a fivemile radius of the city. There is no limit to the auantitv of gasoline you can buy. It is available after 6 P.M. on weekdays and on Saturday and Sunday, as well.

title: Energy Drama in Two Acts: OPEC on Tuesday, Tokyo Summit on Thursday
description: PARISFresh on the heels of still another OPEC price rise, expected at Geneva on Tuesday, leaders of the West's seven leading industrial nations are meeting in Tokyo on Thursday to try to regain control of their economies.

title: Notes: Ways to Cut Costs Abroad
description: Inflation and the declining value of the dollar will make a vacation abroad more expensive for Americans this summer, but an increasing number of costcutting plans are being offered to ease the financial pain of travel.

title: Inez Hutton, D. T. Coffin Are Married
description: Inez Chapin Hutton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Hutton of Locust Valley, L.I., and Nantucket, Mass., was married in Nantucket yesterday to D. Tristram Coffin, son of Prof. and Mrs. David Robbins Coffin of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket. The Rev. Edward Anderson performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church.

title: Robin Wilkerson Is Bride of Stephen Atlas
description: Robin Elizabeth Wilkerson, daughter of Mrs. Harlan Logan of Meriden, N.H., and James P. Wilkerson of Admington, Warwickshire, England, was married yesterday to Stephen Donald Atlas, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald H. :Atlas of La Jolla, Calif.

title: THEATER
description: WHAT with Tonys, Emmys, Oscars, Grammys and Obies being tossed about like confetti  and often having the same value  I've decided to start my own yearly awards, good and bad, to the theaters of Connecticut and Westchester based on all the evenings I have sat in them, smiling or cursing.

title: La Soufriere Pays $81.60 for Belmont Upset
description: Unable to read the tote Ware, wnere the yellow numbers showed that hardly anyone at Belmont Park gave her chance, a filly named La Soufriere beat the best mare from the United States yesterday, as well as a Brazilian that had been undefeated,

title: Starting July 15, Mail Must Meet Size Rules
description: Starting July 15, mail will have to measure up, or down, to new Postal Service regulations, according to The Associated Press.

title: Bicyclist Killed by Bus in City
description: A 25yearold Manhattan woman was killed yesterday when the bicycle she was riding became caught between a moving city bus and parked cars on 57th Street, west of Fifth Avenue, and she was thrown beneath the wheels of the bus. The victim was identified by the police as Robin Miller of 421 West 57th Street.

title: Baseball's Senior Stars Aim at Records, Not Retirement
description: IT may be a coincidence, a trend or a phenomenon of the science of aging, but some of the oldest baseball players in the world are passing some of thefanciest milestones in the business. And in recent days the procession has turned into a stampede.

title: Spinks, 25, With New Outlook, Is Eager to Make a Comeback
description: SAN REMO, Italy IT had all come so quickly and it went back the same way. After eight professional fights, heavyweight champion of the world. After nine professional fights, people said he was so dissipated he'd never box again. At the age of 25, not even at the peak age for heavyweights, Leon Spinks is coming back only 16 months after taking the heavyweight title.

title: GARDENING
description: MY battle cry is water, water! said Mrs. Frederick Austin. The summer sun is so strong, and people who grow plants in containers always tend to underwater plants. Mrs. Austin, after many years of experience growing flowering Plants in containers  indoors and out in her northern Westchester County gardenhas learned how to keep plants thriving.

title: Education In College, Education With a Big Union Label
description: Maneuvering is well under way for what will be one of the largest collective bargaining elections ever held in the United States, a contest starting (officially) next Sunday to determine the union representative for 17,500 West Coast workers. But hard hats and blue collars will not appear in this campaign, waged among employees for whom the tools the trade are not wrenches or welding torches but books and ideas.

title: Design
description: A New York family traded a 25room Victorian mansion in the suburbs for the cellar and basement floors of a Manhattan townhouse. Thanks an architect's wizardry, the renovated duplex is just what they want. After four years in a rabbit warren of a late Victorian house in Westchester County, George and Louise Beylerian have returned to Manhattan. Their new home is less than onefifth the size of their former 25room dwelling, an 1890's threestory residence framed by porches, trees and tall grasses, that reigns with dowager dignity on a twoacre site in Irvington, N.Y.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALL the rain that we have had in this area during the last couple of months has led.to a virtual epidemic of damp basement problems. Since water that seeps into the basement comes from the soil surrounding the house, the logical first step is to do everything practical to keep water from soaking into the ground near the house foundation.

title: In Praise of Decadence
description: The year is half over, the deade nearly spent. Commentators of every political and cultural persuasion are scrambling to characterize, even to pigeonhole, the 1870's. The pages of diverse magazines resound with the windy rhetoric of hastily assembled stateoftheculture addresses. The word being bandied about most frequently by these commentators as they struggle to come to grips with the forces now transforming American society is decadence.

title: DINING OUT
description: WESTCHESTER has always had a number of dining spots that I call Eisenhower restaurants  large, pretty dining rooms frequented by those who were in their 30's in the 1950's and who like an atmosphere that reminds them of a country club and their daughter's catered wedding. Many of these. such as Patricia Murphy's, Schrafft's, the Birch Brook Inn and the Washington Arms, are long gone, but the Water Wheel lingers on after 22 years.

title: ldeas &Trends
description: Skylab, the 77.5ton space station that served as a highlevel mobile home for three crews of American astronauts in 1973 and 1979, is slowly winding down. Nothing and nobody can stop it, but last week, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration successfully played its nexttolast card in a try to exert some control over the location of the crash. NASA used ground commands to rotate the spacecraft 90 degrees so it is now moving broadside to the upper layers of the atmosphere whose drag will bring it to earth between July 7 and July 17, the North American Air Defense Command now calculates.

title: The NoRisk Portfolio Of Barr Rosenberg
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Barr Rosenberg is a man who deals with numbers and speaks a funny language. He talks of a high beta and a low alpha and of quantifying return. He is a man who is obsessed with uncertainty, and has turned his fascination with the uncertainties of the economy and the stock market into a career based on attempting to eliminate the risks that investors run in buying stocks.

title: Putting the Future On a Credit Card
description: SEYMOUR FLUG of Plainview is back at Diners Club International again. This time, he's No. 1  chairman of the board, president and chief executive officer and his goal is to make Diners Club No. 1 again.

title: Patricia McDonnell Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Patricia McDonnell to Simon Pearce has been anflounced by Mr. and Mrs. T. Murray McDonnell of Pleasant Valley Farm, Peapack, N.J., parents of the future bride. Mr. Pearce is a son of Philip Pearce of ShElnagarry, County Cork, Ireland. and the late Lucy Pearce.

title: Choosing Pro Basketball's Future Stars Takes a Little Bit of Luck
description: Who will the ICnicks take with the No. 3 selection in the National Basketball Association college draft tomorrow?

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WASHINGTON  Administration reassurances to the contrary, it now looks as if the most widely advertised recession has already begun, and the question now being asked by those who monitor statistics inside and outside the Government is how long and how deer) it will be.

title: New Recordings. Recall. Opera Under Tyrants
description: Music criticism has no doubt had its share of unqualified practitioners, and two of the more unsavory examples were undoubtedly Joseph Stalin and Adolf Hitler. Both dictators interfered vigorously with the artistic affairs of their respective countries, and the disastrous effects of their meddling in the work of composers and musicians have never been fully. measured. An indication of what they were capable of perpetrating has just been provided by Angel Records with the first complete recordings of Dmitri Shostakovich's Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk and Richard Strauss's The Silent Woman. The Shostakovich opera received its premiere in 1.939 and the Strauss opera in 1935. Both works were officially suppressed as unworthy artistic expressions of the new order soon after they reached the stage.

title: Mozambique, With Cuban Help, Is Shoring Up Its. Internal.Security
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique  An American wandering through Maputo on a're, cent Sattirday came upon an unexpected sight. In a small park, not far from Ho Chi Minh Avenue, a group of soldiers in Tshirts and khaki pants were caught up in a lively game of baseball.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Bill authorizing funds for fiscal 1980 for International Development Assistance, passed, 70 to 25, June 19.

title: Teheran Entertainment District Is Adapting Itself to the Revolution
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 23  For decades, LalehZar Street was the subject of fireandbrimstone sermons in the mosques of Teheran.

title: Troy Archer: End to a Boyhood
description: Troy Archer, the Giants defensive tackle who was killed Friday night when his 1979 Dodge pickup truck crashed into a pole in North Bergen, N.J., was at the end of a prolonged boyhood, according to some of his friends.

title: County's Power Rises In Albany
description: ALBANY IN the power structure that controls the State Legislature here, the Westchester delegation has never been regarded near the top. Almost everyone bows Brooklyn. After all, that's where the current Governor and Speaker of the Assembly come from. New York City is a force, if only in sheer number of representatives. Long Island has its powerful committee chairmen, and upstate has its own political bases in places likg Binghamton and Buffalo.

title: A Manager for Every Occasion
description: THE events of the last week seem to show that George Steinbrenner's choice of managers is reflected by team play. When the Yankees are too subdued, in comes Billy Martin to pep up the team; when the Yanxees are playing like rowdy kids on a sandlot, in comes Bob Lemon. For this reason it seems logical that in 1980 he keep both skippers. Naturally, two managers, especially those with the opposite schools of thought that Lemon and Martin represent, cannot manage simultaneously. For this reason, Steinbrenner should simply rotate his managers in much the same way that managers rotate pitchers.

title: CHESS
description: Boris Spassky plays for mate patiently  yes, patiently. Others may believe that patience is a virtue required only of the defender in a difficult situation and that all attacks should be prosecuted in hot blood, but the man who held the world championship from 1969 to 1972 is more sophisticated.

title: Boxing's His Business
description: The moon is dimming in the earlymorning sky over Landover, Md., as two men appear at the top of a hilly street called Belle Haven.

title: Bridgeport Lays Groundwork For Greater School Integration
description: IN the years to come, observers of public education here will refer to an agreement on school integration between the state and city and 12 citizens and civil rights groups that became formal policy last week.

title: Associated Press
description: Willie Mays Alkens of Angels Is hitting 301 and has hit two grand slams this month.

title: Prison Population Is Up Again
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP)  The Law Enforcement Assistance Administration has found that the number of state and Federal prisoners rose by 3 percent in 1978, to a record 307,384.

title: New Season, New Trouble For the Shore Business
description: LONG BEACH ISLAND EVERY year seems to bring new troubles for those businessmen who rely on the annual migrations of tourists to the sunny and sandy beaches of the Jersey Shore.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: In answer to the article by Dan Collins regarding Catholic schools ('Catholic School the Way It Used to Be, May 20], I am a practicing Roman Catholic and a graduate of Catholic schools.

title: MOBILE SOVIET ICBM HELD KEY TO PEACE
description: Research Officer in Air Force Seei Best Hope if Each Side Has Missile It Can Count On

title: FIREMEN TURN OUT THEIR UNION LEADER
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association, the union that represents New York City's 8,900 firemen, turned its president, Richard J. Vizzint, out of office yesterday.

title: Ouake Hurts Mexico City Power
description: MEXICO CITY, June 22 (UPI)  An earthquake shook Mexico City early today, rocking buildings and downing power lines. There were no immediate reports of damages or injuries. Residents of Veracruz, 185 miles east of the capital, said they also felt the tremor.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: OFFICIALS at Rutgers are admitting that crime has become a very serious problem at all three campuses of the state university  New Brunswick, Newark and Camden. In fact, letters alerting students to the problem will be mailed in August in the hope that many will take precautions when school resumes.

title: A Regular Job and Communist Menace Have Proven Strong Incentives
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Opponents of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle have always described Nicaragua's National Guard as the dictator's private army. But, until recently, even they could not conceive that the Guard would be willing to destroy much of the country to preserve the Somoza family dynasty.

title: Nominee for Air Force Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI)President Carter has nominated Hans Michael Mark as Secretary of the Air Force.. Mr. Mark, 50 years old, Under Secretary of the Air Force since 1977, has served as Acting Secretary since the resignation last month of John C. Stetson. Mr. Mark, a native of Germany who became a United States citizen in 1945, has a doctorate in physics.

title: Brazil N Criticized for Its Refusal To Allow Extradition of ExNazi
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 23  A ruling by Brazil's Supreme Court blocking the extradition of a former Nazi who is alleged to have been a highranking concentration camp official has produced expressions of dismay here and abroad.

title: THE ARAB STAKE IN AMERICA
description: Like modernday Paul Reveres, news reports warn of a new kind of foreign invasion. On Wall Street, in banking, industry, real estate, the clarion sounds: The Arabs are corning! The Arabs are coming! Flushed with Petrodollar surpluses, the governments and oil millionaires of the Middle East are said to be invading American markets in a colossal buying binge.

title: New York Leads Convention Poll
description: DETROIT, June 23 (UPI)  A survey of the 29member Democratic site selection committee appears to leave little doubt that the party will choose New York as the site of the 1980 Democratic National Convention. The Detroit News, which polled the committee Members, said today that 16 favored New York, three favored Detroit and one was for Philadelphia. Nine members could not be reached, were undecided or unwilling to disclose their preferences.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: EARL WARREN:

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: Middle Class Is a State of Mind, Not Money
description: NEW ARK They are refuges for blacks who are making it, these treelined midlleclass New Jersey neighborhoods thriving in the shadow of Newark and nestled among white sections in such comfortable towns as Montclair, Orange and East Orange. Residents, many the sons and daughters of janitors, domestic workers and laborers, guard the homey, livable character of their communities with a fierce protectiveness born of the knowledge that such comfort was difficult to come by but is easy to lose.

title: NBC Puts Its Money On a News Show
description: Tonight at 10, with the premiere of its new weekly newsmagazine Prime Time Sunday, NBCTV ventures for a second time into an area of progratiyming that puts its national prestige on the line. It is an area dominated by CBS's 60 Minutes and in which ABC has begun to carve out a place for itself with a similar program, 20/20.

title: OddEven': A Hope for Safety
description: GOVERNOR CAREY'S midweek imposition of oddeven gasoline rationing may have come just in time to control a dangerous situation that began to develop a week and a half ago on the county's parkways: lines of gashungry vehicles extending up to a quarter of a mile into busy traffic lanes.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Are those long motorist lines for gasoline signaling a recession? Is the dollar due for another battering? Will interest rates move up in the second half of this year?

title: VW, Chrysler: A $1 Billion Marriage?
description: It certainly sounds plausible. The Chrysler Corporation, America's third biggest automobile manufacturer, has been faltering badly and is in need of cash. Volkswagen, the West German giant of the smallcar trade, has a whole lot of cash and wants to expand in the American market. So why not get together?

title: Amtrak Gets a Second Wind
description: Remember trains? They still run between most cities, they are just about as fast as cars or buses, and they do not require gasoline.

title: The Home That Gave Little House Books Life
description: In Mansfield, Mo., 200 miles southeast of Kansas City  a drive of under five hours  an old frame house sits on a wooded rise and waits. No one lives in it  not any more  but the house is seldom empty, for it is a special place. it is special to each of the thousands of children and adults who yearly pass through its doors, because each is intimately familiar with the childhood of the tiny woman who once lived in the house. And it is special for the thrill each feels when recognizing a treasure from those pioneer days.

title: Food
description: It is hard to believe that any patissierie, no matter how inventive or talented, could conjure up desserts more sweetly luxurious than the honeyripe fruits nature will provide in the summer months ahead. The berry family alone would be cause enough for celebration with the warm sweetness of raspberries, strawberries, blackberries and blueberries that need only splash of cream (sweet, sour or crme fraiche) and a sprinkling of white or brown sugar to turn them into opulent desserts.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: The British are back, in facsimile, for the New Haven bicentennial. A reenactment of the invasion of the city 200 years ago will begin Friday evening with the encampment of the troops at Lighthouse Point Park and a concert by the New Haven Symphony on the green downtown.

title: He Focuses on the Humanity Of Folk Musicians
description: Les Blank is not a wellknown name for the casual moviegoer, and even less for the average fan of pop or folk music. Yet he deserves attention, as a twoweek retrospective of his films at the Museum of Modem Art will demonstrate. The retrospective begins at 6 P.M. tomorrow and continues somewhat erratically through July 9.

title: The Making
description: The Making of a Pop Heroine WHEN Martha Mitchell was buried at Pine Bluff, Ark., on June 3, 1976, a large green and white floral piece was delivered to the grave from an anonMARTHA

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: THE best kind of vacation for some people is visiting friends hi a country house, loafing around the pool, browsing in a. private library and having plenty of delicious things to eat.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Faces Key Meeting With Union Chiefs
description: LONDON, June 23  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is holding her first meeting with Britain's powerful trade union leadership next week, in an attempt to lessen tension in an area that is expected to be her greatest political problem.

title: AN ADDED PRECINCT CONSIDERED BY CITY
description: The city is considering the establishment of a new police precinct in the Clinton section on the West Side of midtown Manhattan.

title: Carter Race Is Backed By Father of Dr. King
description: WILBERFORCE, Ohio, June 23 (AP)  The Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. says he will actively support President Carter for reelection in 1980.

title: ART
description: MORRISTOWN ALL revolutions to the contrary, art remains an undemocratic enterprise, with its lesser exponents seldom getting a chance to measure up to the masters. However,. Invitational 1979: Sculpture, an exhibition now on view at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences, is an attempt to effect just such a contrast.

title: The Word That Names No Thing
description: DECADENCE RICHARD GILMAN'S argument is delivered two assertions. One: there is no such thing as decadence. Two: nonetheless, the word decadence persists, and is enjoying a revival, with lurid consequences. The first assertion is like the argument.

title: Flood Disaster in New Mexico
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP)  President Carter declared a major disaster today because of flooding in New Mexico caused by storms and melting snow. The declaration makes Federal money available for lowinterest home and business loans to victims and for the repair of public facilities.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BRIDGEPORT Barnum Festival Juried Art Show, Museum of Art, Science and Industry, 4450 Park Ave., through July 8. Information 3723521.

title: Sarah Wright Cooper Married
description: Sarah Wright C6OPer and Charles Paul Klingenstein, cum laude alumni of Utah State University, were married yesterday in Little Compton, R.I. The Rev. Thomas E. Ahlburn, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the United Congregatiaal Church. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth McNair Cooper of Alta, Wyo., teaches in Bennington, Vt. where her husband is an employment and training specialist with the Champlain Valley Work and Training Programs.

title: DINING OUT
description: OLIVER TWIST, which calls itself a restaurant and pub and offers a whimsical bookletmenu entitled The New Adventures of Oliver Twist, is a pub in name only. Actually, it is a familiar American roadhouse, what with a fourpiece dance band, an Italianate menu and the usual interior of Tiffanytype lamps and Naugahydebanquettes.

title: Susan P. Davis Married To William Flanagan 3d
description: St. John Berchmans Roman Catholic Co;Cathedral in Shreveport, La., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Susan Patricia Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Beauregard Davis of Shreveport, to William Joseph Flanagan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Flanagan Jr. of Allenhurst, N.J. The Rev. James Ryan Hughes, a Maryknoll missionary, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: First published in West Germany in 1976, this picture book has a definite foreign flavor. There is something rather oldfashioned and severe  though not disagreeably so  about its text and illustrations. But it is no weightier than most American picture books, although we sometimes think Europeans know something vital about life that we've somehow missed out on.

title: Anderson for OilImport Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 Representative John B. Anderson, Republican of Illinois, urged President Carter today to follow the lead of West European leaders in calling for a freeze on oil import at present levels for the next five years.

title: Linda O'Connor Married to Drew J. Casertano, Teacher
description: At the Union Chapel on, Shelter Island, L.I., yesterday, Linda Sturges O'Connor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hartley O'Connor of Bromine, N.Y., and Shelter Island, was married to Drew Jon Casertano, son of Nicholas D. Casertano of Woodbury. Conn., and Dolores Ca.sertano of Cheshire, Conn. The Rev. PeterMacLean, rector of St. Mary's Episcopal Church on Shelter Island, performed the cermony.

title: Music Notes: Operatic Twins
description: Next season a 29yearold director named Christopher Alden will make his debut with the New York City Opera staging a new production of Rossini's Count Ory. Also next season another 29yearold director named David Alden will make his debut with the Metropolitan Opera restaging its production of Berg's Wozzeck. Are the Aldens related? They most certainly are. They are twins, and the coincidence of their double debut at Lincoln Center is almost worthy of an opera libretto.

title: Wine
description: Even those who are not engrossed in wines are attracted to the Bordeaux region. Though the area is adapting to its popularity, those wanting to visit chateaus should plan well in advance. A friend of mine once worked for one of the famous Bordeaux wineshipping firms. He was diligent and knowledgeable and got along well with his superiors, mostly longtime Bordeaux residents. Even so, for the two years he was with the firm, he was never invited into the homes of any of the people for whom he worked.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE EYE OF THE NEEDLE, by Ken Follett. (NAL/Signet, $2.95.) Heinrich Rudolph Hans von MuellerGueder a.k.a. Faber, Nazi spy in wartime Britain, undertakes to tell Hitler where the DDay invasion will take place. Richard Freedman called it a thriller that really thrills, on both the visceral and intellectual levels.

title: The Moving Spirit Of Williamstown
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. In many ways, Nikos Psacharopoulos is the Williamstown (Mass.). Theater Festival, which opens its 25th season on Thursday with a production of Tennessee Williams's Camino Real. Mr. Psacharopoulos cofounded the festival and has been its artistic director for all but its first year. He involves himself in virtually every aspect of its operation, from approving advertising copy to raising funds. Over the years, he has inspired fervent loyalty in many of the people whose careers were launched or nourished in the Adams Theater on the beautiful Berkshire campus of Williams College.

title: Back to the Basics Of Baroque Music
description: Baroque music could be said to have been growing in popularity with performers and public ever since Mendelssohn took up the cause of Bach and Handel in the 1820's. The revival of interest In their works that he helped to stimulate focused largely upon choral music, but little by little knowledge of and interest in other aspects of the longdormant repertory began to develop in the 19th century. Albert Schweitzer's enthusiastic writings about Bach in the early years of this century stimulated the movement greatly, and by the 1930's musicologists seemed to be uncovering forgotten Baroque works by the carload.

title: Sally Chesson Is Married To Ronald Sutherland 2d
description: Sally Chesson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Chesson of Gladstone, N.J., was married yesterday to Ronald Duffus Sutherland 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Sutherland of Los Angeles, formerly of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. L. Lee Curtis, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Chesson home.

title: A Southerner Gone North
description: ONE NUM, ONE VOICE CHARLES MORGAN JR., one of the handful white Southerners who actively supported the civil rights movement of the 1960's, has the valuable habit of pausing every decade or so to issue an installment of his autobiography, his publiclifeinprogress.

title: Northern Area Gets Burn Unit
description: THIS fall, the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla will open the only burn unit in the northern metropolitan region, an area that includes Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess, Rockland, Orange, Sullivan and Ulster Counties.

title: ExArchitecture Student Facing Charges of Smuggling Art Works
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 23 (UPI)  A former architecture student faces Federal charges of smuggling art works worth at least $10,000 from Europe into the United States. Dennis A. Wetzell, 22 years old, of rural Crothersville was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday after an international investiRat ion.

title: Motoring Triumphs In Cane
description: YONKERS, June 23  There was no energy shortage tonight for Happy Motoring, a big and rugged colt, as he drove off with New York's richest horseracing prize, the $336,420 Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Mets Rainout Foils Dock Ellis's 2d Start
description: ST. LOUIS, June 23  Just before Dock Ellis, the Mets new pitching acquisition, went out on Busch Stadium's damp artificial turf tonight to warm up for his confrontaton with the Cardinals, Manager Joe Torre ushered the tall righthander into his office.

title: Priscilla J. Lindsey Is Married To Scott Sager, Art Director
description: Priscilla Joan Lindsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Lindsey of Pembroke, N.H., was married yesterday to Scott Elton Sager, son of Dr. and Mrs. George F. Sager of Cape Elizabeth, Me. The Rev. Eugene Malek, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Concord, N.H.
