title: 1,000 to Compete for Table Tennis Prizes
description: AMERICAN table tennis is corning out of the basement. The game once regarded as either a child's rainyday pastime or a tool of international diplomacy is bidding for its own identity as a fullfledged spectator sport.

title: Director Tells Of Departure From Guthrie
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 23  Alvin Epstein, who resigned Thursday as artistic director of the Tyrone Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, spoke with occasional bitterness yesterday about his departure. What prompted it, he said, was that the support for the things I want and see positively was not forthcoming; that the things that I feel good about, other people look upon negatively.

title: Lisa Heidi Ehret Is Married
description: Lisa Heidi Ehret, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Ehret of Fort Lee, N.J., was married last evening to Gregg Charles Weingeroff, son of Frederick Weingeroff of Providence, R.I., and Mrs. Eli Ehrlich of New York. Rabbi Solomon Rothstein, assisted by Cantor Meir Berger, performed the ceremony at the WaldorfAstoria. The bride is in her second year at the Suffolk p Law School. Mr. Weingcroft is vice president of sales at Weingeroff Enterprises, jewelry manufacturer in Providence.

title: Research Fellow Weds Dr. Barbara Turner
description: The marriage of Dr. Barbara Jean Turner, a resident in medicine at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, to Dr. Francisco Antonio GonzalezScarano, a research fellow at Pennsylvania's School of Medicine, took place yesterday in Villanova. Pa. The Rev. Ralph Moore of the Christian Association of the University of Pennsylvania performed the garden ceremony at Appleford, a former private estate now the property of Lower Merlon Township.

title: Yankees Explore Trading of Jackson
description: The Yankees, apparently faced with irreconcilable differences between Reggie Jackson and Billy Martin, have held preliminary talks with some American League clubs in the last few days about a possible trade for Jackson; sources within the league said yesterday.

title: Judy C. Beggs Wed in Texas
description: Judy Capera Beggs and James Higbie Clement Jr. were married yesterday in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Fort Worth by the Rev. Louis F. Martin, the rector emeritus.

title: The Hanging Tree of Peekskill
description: IN the chill dawn of Jan. 27, 1777, in Peekskill, Daniel Strang, a Tory sympathizer condemned to death by Revolutionary forces as a British spy, mounted a cart before a formation of Continental soldiers. A rope fastened to his neck was tied around a white oak tree and, at a signal from a Colonial officer, the tumbrel was drawn away, leaving the condemned man hanging. The Continental officers in charge, both on horseback, led their men in parade around the tree from which the victim swayed.

title: The Editorial Notebook That's the Way a Cartel Bounces
description: There is poetic aptness in the Brazilian decision to challenge the oil cartel by growing its own fuel in the form of distillable sugar cane. By turning to alcohol as a substitute for increasingly expensive gasoline, Brazil is in effect doing to others what was once done unto it.

title: Martin vs. Jackson
description: In an East Side restaurant the other night, Reggie Jackson ordered a beer at the bar while he waited for a table. Soon a nearby customer turned to him and said, Would Billy Martin want you drinking that beer? Looking up, Reggie Jackson said, As soon as I get Billy Martin's number, I'll give it to you. Then you can call him and find out.

title: The Big One That Got Away
description: It was Home Box Office's finest hour  finest three hours, to be exact. The big brains of television's three major networks turned down Friday night's boxing show in Madison Square Garden, so Home Box Office bought it for the cable system's two million subscribers and wound up with the best fight card in recent memory while the nets were regaling their viewers with an eightyearold movie, a warmedover soap opera and vet another whodunit.

title: Spiros Charles Droggitis Weds Ottilie Rosina King
description: Ottllie Rosina King, daughter of Henry Brazell King of Spring Lake and Washington and the late Mrs. King, was married yesterday to Spiros Charles Droggitis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Droggitis of Biddeford. Me.

title: How to Know If You're Happy
description: You probably think of the discomfort index, if you think of it at all, as the sum of temperature and humidity, that inspired creation of a generation of chatty weather forecasters on television. It is apples and oranges, of course, and it doesn't have any scientific standing, but it does serve a purpose. It gives you a pretty fair idea how miserable you're going to feel.

title: STAMPS
description: Four classic children's books beloved all over the world are remembered by Great Britain in a special Issue to mark the International Year of the Child.

title: Dispute Erupts At Channel 21 On Officials Roles
description: THE board of trustees of the Island's publictelevision station, WLIW, Channel 21, is to meet tomorrow to act on divisive accusations that have surfaced at a time when the station might otherwise be enjoying the celebration of its 10th anniversary on the air, a new transmitter pushing its signal farther and clearer than ever before and a new studio that offers the promise of more and better Long Islandoriginated programming.

title: ART
description: ALMOST from its beginnings, photography has occupied a controversial position in the hierarchy of the arts. The camera, once heralded as the destroyer of painting, has also been scorned as mere recording device incapable of creative uses. Highly acclaimed photographers in many cases regard themselves as reporters or craftsmen, while the rankest amateur may rate his Snapshots as artistic masterpieces. Contradictions abound.

title: DINING OUT
description: LUNCH can be a big deal, but for most of us it usually isn't. Sometimes, though, lunching on the road, en route to an appointment or between shopping forays, can be traumatic. The trauma comes in trying to find a decent place to eat that doesn't involve an elaborate outlay of cash or time.

title: Wheat at $4: Squeezing Food Costs
description: WELLINGTON, Kan.  Thomas Ostrander seemed to struggle to restrain a smile as he stood beside his pickup truck and watched three big combines chewing broad swaths through a yellow field of wheat. His truck radio squawkedone of his harvester drivers calling for more fuel. Mr. Ostrander leaped into his truck, which carries a tank of diesel, and raced across the stubble toward the combine.

title: Richard Charles Barton Weds Jane E. MacEwen
description: Jane Ellen MacEwen and Richard Charles Barton, alumni of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute College of Architecture, were married yesterday in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Richard Mobayed performed the ceremony in the Concord Presbyterian Church.

title: Billie Jean King Is Rarin to Go
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 23 Billie Jean King sat in the clubhouse here a few days ago, nursing a strained groin muscle and fighting off a case of nervous energy.

title: These Graduates Hold Tin Cups
description: FRESHLY graduated, walking in Manhattan, looking for a job in my first grim month among the unemployed, I saw recently two beggars whose misery exceeded my own.

title: 2 Injured in Theater District Fight
description: A taxi driver and a pedestrian were both charged with attempted murder last night after they seriously injured each other during a dispute on 45th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

title: He's Back to Sing
description: FLORAL PARK WHEN you're on the road for a long time, you begin to deteriorate mentally to the point where you feel you're about 12 years old, said Frank Carillo, toying with a green water pistol, a souvenir of his band's recent 26show, 34day American tour. The second half of that tour began last week and Mr. Carillo performs tonight with his quartet, called Carillo, at the Nassau Coliseum as the opening act for Bad Company, the British hardrock band.

title: Last 27 Worth of Gasoline Shows Station Is Givino All
description: The Power Test station at 63d Street and 11th Avenue  apparently the last open filling station on the avenue  was reeling in a line of cars that stretched down the boulevard at 11:49 A.M. yesterday when its pumps coughed out their last sale: 27 cents worth, to a customer who drove away in disgust.

title: Scholastic Study Disproves AgeOld Approach for Gifted Athletes
description: Young, gifted athletes who can hold their. own against rivals of any age have been an integral part of sports in recent years.

title: Nathan Fine, Author and Expert On Labor Movement in America
description: Nathan Fine, an authority on the labor movement in the United States, died June 7 at his home in Albany, Calif., where he had lived for the past 14 years. He was 86 years old.

title: Truckers' Anger Born of Threats To Their Self-Reliant Way of Life
description: DOSWELL, Va., June 23 The tieups that have halved highway hauling across the nation arise from the fears of the selfemployed trucker, the leathery loner who replaced the cowboy as the symbol of independence, that his way of life is being threatened by economic and political forces beyond his control.

title: Exempt Groups Politely Decline Invitation to Pay Taxes
description: An effort by the city to cajole owners of taxexempt real estate into making voluntary payments in lieu of property taxes has yielded many letters of explanation but few dollars.

title: Lefters
description: To the Editor: Since a recent Department of Housing and Urban Development study could have ramifications on housing policies that promote integration and the construction of lowrise developments, it is important to emphasize the evidence contrary to the results of this study.

title: Gas Crisis. Experts Find Mixture of Causes
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  Federal and private officials, besieged by questions from angry and puzzled motorists, are trying to.explain in detail to a doubting public the reasons for the current gasoline crisis. Questions are on everyone's lips.

title: Official of Teamsters Enters Plea of Guilty In Petty Larceny Case
description: Cirino (Charles) Salerno, a vice president of Local 272 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, pleaded guilty last week in New York State Supreme Court to a charge of petty larceny.

title: Pilots Hurt as Planes Collide
description: DUGWAY, Utah, June 23 (UPI)  Two Marine A4M jet fighters collided on training mission over the Great Salt Lake Desert yesterday. The pilots ejected safely but were critically injured. They were Capt. Kevin Lefler, 29 years old, of Dekalb, Ill., and Capt. William F. Bain, 28, of Mount Vernon, III.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from fiveweek trip abroad in the company of our two sons, 9 and 6, and Paddington Bear (whom we picked up enroute at Hamley's in London), my husband and I. were most interested in Anne Roiphe's article Going Abroad With Children: the Rigors, the Rewards (Travel Section, June 3).

title: Yanks Tie in 9th, Win in 10th
description: The Yankees ended their starvation diet in run production for Billy Martin last night by scoring a 65 victory over the Cleveland Indians in 10 innings at Yankee Stadium.

title: Where Gas Once Sold for a Dime a Gallon
description: BIDDEFORD, Me., June 21  At 9:30 on his first summer morning, the sun is up and so is Raymond Roy. The loons are hollering somewhere out on the water, and there is that sound and the sound of a Bangor & Aroostook train. Johnnyjumpups and ladyslinSpecial to The New York Times pers reach for the sky, and the corn (corn will always tell a traveler how late the local winter lasts) is only kneehigh to a grasshopper.

title: Convention Speech Stirs Foes of Abortion
description: CINCINNATI, June 23  The keynote address was entitled Medical Holocaust and the 2,000 or so delegates to the National Right to Life convention listened attentively as William C. Brennan, a professor of sociology at St. Louis University, compared abortions in America in the 1970's to the extermination of Jews by Nazi Germany in the 1940's.

title: Letter
description: Grigorenko Gets a Second Opinon (by Walter Reich, May 13) brings to mind vivid memories of Pyotr Grigorenko, who was visiting here at Harvard when he learned that his citizenship had been abrogated by a decree that said he had inflicted damage to Soviet prestige.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: AMAGANSE1T  The Baymen, paintings, drawings by Russell Lawson; 10:30 A.M. to P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays; Saturday through July 18; Town Marine Museum, Bluff Rd. Admission $1; children under 12, 50 cents. Reception 68 P.M. Saturday.

title: I Spoke My Mind
description: WILLIAM BLAKE THE only acceptable excuse for a new biography of Blake in 1979 would be the unveiling of what researchers call new material. In detail, this would mean the discovery of a large number of documents or an unexpected linking of Blake's personal viHis Life and Work. By Jack Lindsay. Illustrated. 334 pp. New York: George Braziller. $15. cissitudes with his imaginative development, or both. Otherwise, we have Alexander Gilchrist's twovolume biography (1880), a monument of Victorian scholarship with a Victorian depth of anecdotes, and more recently, Mona Wilson's Life of William Blake (1927; revised in 1948 and again by Geoffrey Keynes in 1970), a sympathetic portrait written with an ease now almost lost to the art of biography.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Singer Nancy Wilson and saxophonist Stan Getz kick off the annual Dr. Pepper Central Park Music Festival at Wollman Skating Rink Theater on Monday, heading a lineup of rock, jazz and pop performers on tap through August. Among those who have been recruited are Joan Baez, Judy Collins, Arlo Guthrie, Johnny Winter, B.B. King, Richie Havens and Taj Mahal. (For information, call 2498870.) (See Music)STRAW HAT

title: Alone in the Seventies
description: NEW AGE BLUES MICHAEL ROSSMAN was a student at the University of California at Berkeley when the Free Speech Movement came on the scene in the mid1960's, and he never left the town On the Politics of Consciousness. By Michael Rossman. 270 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. Paper, $6.95. the Movement, but keeps both alive in the fires of his mind. He became an eloquent spokesman and theoretician of the wouldbe revolutionaries and went charging into the 70's with more hope and energy than most of his friends had left. But as these New Age Blues make painfully clear, he has come to the end of the decade with a worried mind.

title: Fabled Doormen of New York: They Always Get Their Taxi
description: It may have been a long time since anyone saw a RollsRoyce with a retractable running board, or lines of chauffeured limousines patiently attending the reappearance of their owners, but the city hasn't gone completely downhill. New Yorkers may travel like moles underground or sardines above ground, they may be nervous wrecks when they get out of taxis, or exhausted from the perils of dodging taxis, but once they reach the portals of some retail establishments, all is again well. They, particularly the theys who are known as regulars, are made to feel cherished, wanted, needed. Even the nonregular theys can, if they wish, enter and leave with considerable panache.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Applause, musical by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, starring Deborah Nielson. Wednesday to Saturday 8:30 P.M., Sundays at 8. Through July 1. $5.50 to $7.50. Discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Country Cabaret, with entertainment and crepe kitchen. Fridays and Saturdays, after show. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rte. 6 and 118.6281169.

title: ANTIQUES
description: EAST HAVEN ON July 4, 1779, the evening before the British invaded New Haven, a pall of humid air hung over the township (then much larger in area than it is today, because it included the nowseparate towns of East Haven, North Haven, Hamden and West Haven and parts of Bethany and Woodbridge). The wind was almost dead still. Nonetheless, just after sunset, those who could bear the heat attended a community meeting at the Middle Church on the green to plan the next day's celebration of the third anniversary of the Declaration of Independence.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Today is Bat Day at Yankee Stadium, where the Yankees conclude their series against the Cleveland Indians at 2 P.M. The Mets have 8 P.M. games tomorrow and Tuesday night against the Pittsburgh Pirates Shea Stadium. The Boston Red Sox make their first trip into Yankee Stadium for a fourgame series Friday night at 8, followed by 2 P.M. games Saturday and next Sunday and an 8 P.M. contest July 2.

title: Anesthesiologist Unit Exonerated by a Judge On Fee Fixing Charge
description: A charge that the American Society of Anesthesiologists conspired to raise, fix and maintain fees for anesthesia services has been rejected by a Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Dire Forecast For County On Recession
description: WITHIN the next five years Westchester's economy will suffer more sharply than other areas of the country from the effects of a recession, according to a report on the county's future re cently completed by the Hudson Institute, the Crotonbased research organization.

title: Red Sox Turn Back Blue Jays in 11 th, 43
description: BOSTON, June 23 (AP)  Bob Watson hit a towering home run on the first pitch in the bottom of the 11th inning today, lifting the Boston Red Sox to a 43 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Is Storrs Too Far From Real Life?
description: DESTRUCTIVE endofterm celebrations at the Storrs campus of the University of Connecticut prompt questions about the educational climate there and the wisdom of maintaining residential state university.

title: Watson Posts 72 and Retains 3Shot Lead
description: OAKVILLE, Ontario, June 23 (AP)  Although strong winds and biting cold prevented any player from scoring lower than 72, one over par, Tom Watson retained a threestroke lead today in the third round of the $350,000 Canadian open golf tournament.

title: Jane E. Malcolm Married To Kyle Bern Van Saun
description: In St. Ann'sbytheSea Episcopal Church in Kennebunkport, Me., yesterday, Jane Elder Malcolm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Fraser Malcolm of Summit, N.J., and Drakes Island, Me., was married to Kyle Bern Van Saun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Van Saun of Goshen, N.Y., and Southbury, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Laman H. Bruner Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: It's Jazz Picnic Time Again at Waterloo Village
description: STANHOPE THE restored Colonial showplace called Waterloo Village has been wired for strictly modern sounds today, when a sparkling array of star musicians will be swinging from noon to sundown at the fourth annual Jazz Picnic.

title: Casinos Spreading Charitable Largesse
description: ATLANTIC CITY AS USUAL, the annual barbecue dinnerdance at the Linwood Country Club on July 8 will benefit the Ruth Newman Shapiro Cancer and Heart Memorial Fund, which buys muchneeded equipment for Atlantic City's only hospital.

title: Engagements
description: COHAN KUUCK

title: Linda Glazer Wed To M.J. Toohey 2d
description: Linda Ann Glazer, publisher of The Saratogian, a Gannett newspaper in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael J. Toohey 2d, a lawyer.

title: Sheepshead Bay Rides the Crest Of Strong Market
description: The decisions made by three recent home buyers in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn say something about the strength of the housing market there and the community itself.

title: First Class Headache at Pullman Inc.
description: CHICAGO  Three months ago, Pullman Inc. bailed out of the business that had once been its bread and butter. Its proud old railway passengercar operation had fallen on hard times and had been creating problems among them onerous losses  for nearly a decade. So Pullman washed its hands of the whole thing, taking a $40 million loss on the cost of phasing out operations and finishing uncompleted contracts.

title: Paige Defeats Walker in Jersey Mile
description: PISCATAWAY, NJ., June 23  All through the outdoor track season, Don Paige has been beating many of the world's best milers. Today, in the first New Jersey Olympic Track Classic, he beat the worldrecord holder, John Walker of New Zealand.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BEACH HAVEN (Stirflight Summer Theater, Engleside Avenue)  High Button Shoes (today and tomorrow) and Paint Your Wagon, opens Tuesday (through July 2).

title: Marguerite Dixon, Senate Aide, Bride Of Allan W. Ayers
description: Marguerite McPheeters Dixon, who is on the staff of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation in Washington, was married yesterday to Allan Winston Ayers of Ellicott City, Md., assistant construction manager for the Knott Company, general contractors in Baltimore.

title: A Life Going Down the Drain
description: EDUCATION is full of legitimate horror stories from teachers, students, parents and administrators. I'm a rarer complainant, an outraged grandmother with a harrowing tale about how a minor physical disability in a young child was compounded by professional helpers into a major psychological problem.

title: A Banner Year for Rain
description: RAIN, rain go away, come again another day, but please come if necessary during the week and at night. No, it is not your imagination, this year Westchester has had more than its share of precipitation.

title: KENNEDY: TIME OF DECISION
description: The youngest of the nine children of Joseph and Rose Kennedy, Edward Kennedy lost the last of his three brothorc nn Junp 6 1968 His father was still alive, but not able to speak because of a stroke. So on that June day, at the age of 36, Kennedy became not only a possible President but also the head of a large family emptied of its men, and he was not ready. His mourning for his last brother was a time of turmoil, ending somewhere near midnight in an overturned car, in a pond off Chappaquiddick Island. It was an accident which he did not report for 10 hours and which some still think stands between him and the Presidency  that and a troubled marriage, a wife living away from him trying not to drink. Yet all the polls indicate that Kennedy could beat anyone, Democrat or Republican, that many can forgive him for everything, but something stops him from running. The question is not whether he will or will not ultimately run. The question for now is: What makes Ted Kennedy run?

title: Sadat Proposes Talks In Sinai With His Foes
description: CAIRO, June 23  President Anwar elSadat extended an invitation tonight to his critics in the Arab world and the Soviet Union to attend a Middle East peace conference in El Arish, a city in Sinai, or in Geneva. But he said he doubted they would accept.

title: Martha Swope
description: Ahalf Century ago, August Bournonville was at the nadir of his cycle; today, he again approaches the zenith he earned and enjoyed in his own lifetime. Why should this be true? Because, in my opinion, Bounionville ballet is at one and the same time unique and universal.

title: Headliners
description: He lost his seat in Parliament, and his own lawyer admitted he had homosexual tendencies. But Jeremy Thorpe never tried to have anybody killed. That was the verdict, after 52 hours of brooding, of an Engtan jury ltsz week in Mr. Thorpe's trial for incitement and conspiracy to murder male model Norman Scott, who alleges (Mr. Thorpe denies it) that he had an affair with Mr. Thorpe in the 1960's. The judge's charge to the jury had called the case largely circumstantial, and identified Mr. Scott as a parasite and a crook. Also acquitted were three codefendants, all of whom had been accused of fomenting a bizarre plot to terminate Mr. Scott back in 1975. In the event, only Mr. Scott's Great Dane was killed. Whether there is a political future for Mr. Thorpe, once the leader of Britain's Liberal Party, remains to be seen.

title: Move to Aid L.I.'s Fuel Supply Is Pressed
description: WASHINGTON FOUR Congressmen from the greater New York metropolitan region are spearheading a new nationwide gasoline conservation proposal designed to assure supplies of both gasoline and home heating oil without rationing.

title: A Problem of Distrust
description: THE BLOOD OF PARADISE By Stephen Goodwin. A Henry Robbins Book. 242 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $8.95.

title: A Critic's Choices in the County and Connecticut
description: WHAT with Tonys, Emmys, Oscars, Grammys and Obies being tossed about like confetti  and often having the same value  I've decided to start my own yearly awards, good and bad, to the theaters of Westchester and Connecticut based on the evenings I have sat in them, smiling or cursing.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Idoubt that anyone remembers no but during the early days of transatlantic flying, there was a chap named Wrong Way Corrigan. It seems that anyone attempting to cross the ocean needed a permit of some sort  perhaps they still do or ought to  and he didn't have one. Took off anyway. made the hazardous trio successfully. landed in Ireland and cheerfully explained  when reprimanded for his highly unofficial behavior  that he'd really meant to cross America toward Los Angeles but somehow or other got turned the wrong way. Hence the name he was thereafter known by. I think that there is a bare possibility, now that I've seen a startling piece of stage business toward the end of Al Pacino's Richard III, that our present Duke of Gloucester, shriveled arm and all, may come to be known as Wrong Way Pacino.

title: A Plot of Land, a Yard of Food
description: IN Westbury, we no longer need to look to the calendar or the growth on the trees to know what time of year it is. A walk past a particular suburban house will provide the information. We know that spring is upon us when handpainted signs reading Strawberry Plants for Sale and 4Sale: Scallions  Spinach  Turnip Greens appear on the grass near the sidewalk. As the seasons change, so do the signs. Strawberries 4 Sale June; Tomatoes  midsummer; Pumpkins  autumn.

title: TurtleWatching on St. Croix
description: This summer, visitors to the United States Virgin Islands may find more than clear water and beautiful beaches as they stroll alone the island coast.

title: Food Critic Reduced to Dieting
description: WHEN I became food critic for this section last January, the news was greeted by friends with some concern that I would inflate to the size of Orson Welles. But, after months of eating out about four times a week, I doggedly refused to gain weight.

title: Realty News
description: Larry A. Silverstein has acquired the 26story office building at 530 Fifth Avenue between 44th and 45th Streets.

title: Gasoline: Supplies Spotty
description: WHY are gasoline stations in Fairfield County either closed or besieged by long lines of motorists, while in other areas of the state open stations sit with little traffic? Why are there long lines in West Hartford and none in Hartford itself? What makes Ras harder to get in New London than anywhere else on the eastern end of the shoreline?

title: Long Angry Lines and Meetings of Ministers
description: The world's oilconsuming nations were bracing last week for still another increase in the price of crude. And as representatives of the oilproducing nations were gathering in Geneva for the opening tomorrow of a conference on pricing, the last hope of tempering global shortages anytime soon  that Saudi Arabia would step up production  may have been dashed when Crown Prince Fand let it be known that his only role at the meeting would be to try to make whatever price rise emerges a reasonable one.

title: REVIVAL PLAN ALIVE IN THE SOUTH BRONX
description: The offices near the center of what is called the Hub, just off 149th Street and Third Avenue in the South Bronx, are unprepossessing. But when they opened for business early this month, they became the center of a grand plan of resurrection for a neighborhood pronounced dead by many and for a program thought to have been killed months ago.

title: News Summary
description: News Summary

title: Editors Choice
description: A BEND IN THE RIVER, by V.S. Naipaul. (Knopf, $8.95.) The ordeals and absurdities of living in a new thirdworld country, precisely observed by a toughspirited novelist.

title: The New York Times/Joe McNally
description: WHEN the Legislature enacted the landmark educationalfinancing bill last April, it tacked on measure that integrated the arts into the publicschool curriculum for the first time, a measure that is on the books of few other states. On the face of it the arcs anpeared to have shed their featherweight image as a frill and to have achieved the solid status of a basic.

title: Neeskens in Debut For Cosmos Today
description: Johan Neeskens, the latest addition to the Cosmos, will make his debut at Giants Stadium this afternoon when the Cosmos meet the New England Tea Men at 2:30.

title: A Day's Trip To the Ifugao Rice Terraces
description: We finally made the trip to the Ifugao rice terraces of Luzon to satisfy a yen to see the Filipino nation's roots and to respond to an American friend who taunted: You live here, yet you have not seen what's in all those tourist posters. The rice terraces are thought to have been created more than 2,000 years ago and have been called the eighth wonder of the world.

title: Woman Cabby on Coast Raped, Then Dismissed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 (AP)Rosemary Belson, a 22yearold rookie cab driver who was raped at gunpoint in her own cab, has been dismissed by her supervisor for not screening her customers carefully enough.

title: An Architect's Two Years in Middle School
description: STAMFORD THE trouble is that everything is taught separately, said Stanislaw Drziurzynski, a young architect who has just finished a twoyear residency at the Burdick Middle School in Stamford that he describes as both painful and revealing.

title: Cornelia D. Gilbert Sets Sept 15 Bridal
description: Mrs. Norton Gilbert of Upper Brookville, L.I., and Clinton Gilbert Jr. of Lo. cult Valley, L.I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cornelia Dean Gilbert, to Duncan G. Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Hoban Harris of Wilson Point in South Norwalk, Conn.

title: Solarville, Ariz.: Down to $7 a Watt
description: SCHUCHULI, Ariz.  This sunbaked village on the sprawling Papago Indian Reservation is not even listed on the 1979 official state road map, but its existence is wellknown in Washington and in many remote areas of the globe. For this is the site of the world's first solar village.

title: Deaths
description: SHAPIRORay, beloved wife of Lester, devoted mother of Marion, Fran and Alan, dear sister of Trudie and Bernie Panzer, dear aunt of Michael and Andrew. Funeral Services Sunday, Jun 24, at 10AM, Westminster Chapel, Coney island Ave and Ave H. Shiva will be observed at 1680 Ocean Ave, Bklyn NY.

title: Lydia Brown Is Married To James Alfred Soule
description: The marriage of Lydia Ann Brown, graduate of Bates College, to James Alfred Soule, an alumnus of Phillips Exeter Academy and Bowdoin College, took place yesterday in the chapel on the Bates campus in Lewiston, Me. The Rev. John R. Pearson, pastor of Emanuel Lutheran Church in Pleasantville, N.Y., perfornied the ceremony.

title: RS. Haskell, Credit Analyst, Weds Kathleen D. Van Vleck
description: Kathleen Dell Van Vleck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Van Vleck 3d of West Hartford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Scott Haskell, son of Richard B. Haskell, also of West Hartford, and the late Kathleen P. Haskell. The ceremony was performed in the First Church of Christ Congregational by the Rev. Dr. Henry Milian Jr.

title: Indictments of 4 Lefkowitz Aides Bring 2 Convictions, 2 Acquittals
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's investigation of political corruption in the office of Louis J. Lefkowitz when he was State Attorney General, which led to the indictment of four of his former aides in September 1976, ended last week after two convictions and two acquittals.

title: 40 Bills in Congress Promote Alternative Fuels
description: WASHINGTON  The day President Carter proclaimed his solar energy program from the White House roof last week, Senator Henry M. Jackson had been up and about for hours to dramatize a proposal of his own: a comprehensive energy supply act with heavy emphasis on oroduction of synthetic fuels.

title: The Democrats This Week Will Name the Lucky City for 1980
description: WASHINGTON For the privilege of playing host to 20,000 unruly Democrats, news people and assorted hangerson, New York City wants to cough up more than $6 million to pay for a return visit by the nartv's national convention next year. Detroit and Philadelphia have put together multimillion dollar packages of their own to entice the Democrats.

title: Other World Events
description: The first test of the new Brazilian Government's stated commitment to democracy will be how many opponents it allows to return to political life. The answer may come this week when the Government presents an amnesty plan affecting thousands of Brazilians jailed, tortured, exiled or otherwise silenced in 15 years of military rule. Only persons convicted of acts of terrorism are to be excluded. Some Brazilians, however, advocate a blanket amnesty, drawing a distinction between terrorism in a military dictatorship like Brazil and in a democracy such as Italy. The amnesty, which will allow the return of many exiled political leaders, is a precondition for multiparty democracy. Since 1965, Brazil has had only two political parties, both creations of the military.

title: MUSIC
description: FAMILIAR orchestral fare is the general rule in the New Haven Symphony Orchestra's free summer concerts on the green, with this evening's program listing Rossini's William Tell Overture,

title: ART VIEW
description: On the 25th anniversary of the death of Reginald Marsh (18981954), the Whitney Museum of American Art  with which Marsh was closely associated throughout his careerhas mounted a small exhibition of selections from the bequest of the artist's widow. The Felicia Meyer Marsh bequest is sato to consist of more than 800 items, including 130 paintings and some 450 drawings and sketches. The modest exhibition mounted in the museum's lobby gallery (through Aug. 26) can hardly be expected to do justice to a collection of this scale. There are fewer than a dozen paintings, a small selection of drawings, some photographs, and a couple of portraits of Marsh by Peggy Bacon and John Koch. Yet there is enough here to give us a very concrete sense of where Marsh's true artistic interests lay. And enough here, too, to illuminate the esthetic paradox at the heart of the kind of Realism that Marsh reveled in.

title: GARDENING
description: THE heavy rainfall of May and early June left behind a legacy of garden problems. Sunshine and a bit of attention will correct most of them  barring additional weather extremes, of course.

title: Niculae Asciu
description: EAST ENDERS are a breed apart. A stolid, fatalistic lot of third and fourthgeneration European immigrants work the land here on a tiny spit of sand at the end of the world.

title: Carless Days Proposed
description: WASHINGTON AGASOLINE conservation plan that includes taking every car off the road one day a week  the day be chosen by the owner  is being spearheaded by four Congressmen from the Greater New York metropolitan region. The proposal has been called the sticker plan because every car would have a windshield sticker indicating its offtheroad day.

title: LONG ISIA1VD JOURNAL
description: IT is the tradition in partisan matters for political parties to endorse candidates who come from within the parties. But even though he has never been involved in any political party or organization in Suffolk County, Dr. Eugene Reed, a dentist who announced that he was a candidate for the Suffolk County Legislature, received the Democratic Party's designation for the 14th District legislative seat  now held by Louis Petrizzo, a Republican  at the Democrats convention last Tuesday night.

title: Insurgency Poses Growing Threat To Afghanistan's ProSoviet Rulers
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, June 22 rapidly growing insurgency in Afghanistan is posing an increasingly serious threat to the proSoviet Government of President Noor Mohammad Taraki, according to diplomats and other observers here.

title: Filling Factories A Major Focus In South Bronx
description: The key is deliberately low in the South Bronx these days, with the emphasis shifted from housing production to longterm economic development in a blighted area in search of stability.

title: Cuttyhunk, Where Nothing. Much Happens Year Round
description: I should have known the island of Cuttyhtmk was special. My wife and I both grew, up in Massachusetts, yet until we planned a recent visit there we had never heard of this tiny island off its southern shore. And others we spoke to had not heard of it either.

title: Managing OPEC's Money
description: When the retired sea captain's sisterinlaw came to join his household, a Cape Cod story goes, the old salt demanded $10 a week from the lady for room and board. Her sister, the captain's wife, agreed to the arrangement, provided he gave the $10 to her. Without telling her husband, she routinely returned the money to her relative, thereby assuring the financial satisfaction of all parties.

title: Campers Increasing As Camps Dwindle
description: DESPITE a continued steep decline in the schoolage population in Connecticut, and drop in the number of available camps, a record 80,000 children are expected to attend resident or day camps throughout the state this summer.

title: Beachgoers Endanger Rare Terns
description: EATONS NECK ONCE again, the birds known as least term have survived the long journey from their winter home in South America to their summer nesting place at Eatons Neck. Now, these rare birds are engaged in a greater struggle  to protect their young against man and other foes, who could destroy their thriving colony in Northport Bay.

title: Sadat Asks Parliament To Grant Shah Asylum
description: CAIRO, June 23 (Reuters)  President Anwar elSadat asked Parliament today 0 adopt a resolution that would allow the exiled Shah of Iran and his family to take refuge in Egypt.

title: Carole E. McMahon Is Married in Illinois To Willard Butcher of Chase Manhattan
description: Carole Elizabeth McMahon, dadghter of Mr. and. Mrs. Harry Thomas McMahon Jr. of Kenilworth, Ill., was married yesterday in Wlnnetka, Ill., to Willard Carlisle Butcher of Wilton, Conn., president of the Chase Manhattan Bank. The bridegroom is the son of Willard Ferris Butcher of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late Helen Calhoun Butcher. Msgr. Eugene.F. Lyons performed the ceremony in SS. Faith, Hope and Charity Roman Catholic Church.

title: Banker Weds Mary Hinkle, Hospital Aide
description: Mary Susan Hinkle, an administrative assistant at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, was married yesterday to James Gordon Murray Jr., an officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: ANTIQUES
description: STONEWARE was brought out of the cellar about 20 years ago for use as pots in the garden and about the house. It looks now as if it might end up in the parlor as an art object.

title: Ballet: Danes Offer The Mirror Dance
description: EVERY art form has its famous set pieces, but histo has sometimes made them more talked about than experienced. Many balletgoers, for instance, have heard about but never seen the Mirror Dance from La Ventana, by the 19thcentury Danish choreographer August Bournonville.

title: Deaths
description: SCHROETEREllen Mullen, of 230 tonnes Ave, Allenhurst NJ (formerly of Brooklyn NY), on Sat, Jun 23, 1979. Wife of the late Charles E. Schroeter, devoted mother of John Schroeter. Funeral Mass In St Mary's Church, Deal, NJ, Tues, Jun 26, at 10AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn NY. No visiting hours.

title: Goldin Admits That Contribution Was Asked of a BusShelter Figure
description: New York City's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, acknowledged yesterday that in his presence an associate solicited a contribution for a Goldin political campaign from the head of a company that was seeking a multimilliondollar, busshelter franchise from the city.

title: Police in Suffolk Defend Methods Of Interrogation
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.  It had been an unusually busy time for the Suffolk County homicide squad. Detective Sgt. Robert Misegades was still on the job after 30 hours, but he was more exhilarated than tired. A suspect had been arrested in one murder case; and another murder seemed close to a solution.

title: Bikel Elected to 3d Term As President of Equity
description: Theodore Bikel has been reelected to his third term as president of the Actors Equity Association, the 29,000member performers union. Others elected to tnreeyear terms are: Barbara Colton, Nancy Lynch, Jeanna Belkin and Vincent Beck, vice presidents. Carl Harms was elected recording secretary and Randy Phillips, treasurer.

title: Sports World Specials
description: The world's two greatest hurdlers are concentrating on their specialties in preparation for the Olympic Games next summer in Moscow. Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah, in the 110meter highs, and Edwin Moses, in the 400meter intermediates, are both worldrecord holders.

title: Burgundy Vineyards Destroyed
description: DIJON, France, June 24 (Reuters) Storms have devastated Burgundy vineyards, ruining the region's wine prospects for 1979. According to unofficial estimates, some 1,500 acres of vines were stripped of grapes and leaves and another 1,000 acres were badly damaged by the storms.

title: Carey's Candor on a Bill Exceeded Hopes of City
description: ALBANY, June 22  Governor Carey likes to talk about how open and candid his administration is, but sometimes it can go a bit overboard. Take, for example, his approval of a bill that would prevent the owners of commercial and industrial property from suing to get their property taxes reduced by showing that they are assessed at proportionately higher rates than their residenAlbany Notes tial neighbors.

title: Market Place
description: IF you're looking for a bargain stock, don't buy Colonial Commercial Corporation, a splitpersonality company that makes blue Jeans and cement and is getting into the casino trade. With a price of 21% on the American Stock Exchange and with Co. lonial's earnings of 2.7 cents a share in 1978, the shares carry a priceearnings ratio of several hundred  one of the richest evaluations of a stock anywhere.

title: Long Gas Lines Have Dwindled On West Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 24  The long lines in California, which:signaled the beginning ofthe national gasoline crisis, have diViiidled.Californians have conserved gasoline, supplies have improved, and filling stations, most of which were closed on weekends and evenings last month, have returned to more normal hours.

title: SOMOZA DENOUNCES RESOLUTION BY 0.A.S, URGING NEW REGIME
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 24 President Anastasio Somoza Debayle of Nicaragua dismissed today a call for his resignation by the Organization of American States and vowed to continue the fight against Sandinist guerrillas seeking to overthrow him.

title: A Kit for the Newly Divorced
description: Sages say that it's an ill wind that blows no good. As evidence, look no farther than Split DeCisions, a kit for the newly divorced.

title: Three Doctored Pitches
description: The illustrations at left show three pitches that are prohibited by organized baseball. In each case, it is assumed that the batter is righthanded. Thus, for example, the cutball illustration, which shows the pitch breaking sharply from right to left, is labeled cut ball  inside. Cut and scuffed balls react similarly, with the pitch breaking in the direction opposite the side on which the ball is doctored.

title: JAZZ EVENTS
description: Following is a schedule of today's Newport Jazz FestivalNew York events:

title: Attempt to Steal Gas Creates Spill in Jersey
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J. June 24 (AP)  About 1,500 gallons of gasoline gushed over an acre of land here yesterday after someone tried to tap a 12inch highpressure line leading to a Shell Oil Company terminal.

title: Texas Preacher Begins Closing Of Girls Home
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex. June 24With both sides claiming a victory of sorts, state welfare workers departed here this weekend while Lester Roloff, the fiery evangelist who had held the state to a standoff, began what he said was a temporary closing of his controversial Rebekah Home for Girls.

title: Every $3 Billion Saving Helps
description: Governments used to complain that their low pay scales prevented their competing for talent with private industry. Today, Federal pay in some places exceeds that in the priyate sector and it is business that protests against the competition. Still, the picture is different in other places. There is no pattern of private and public pay and so there is no single remedy. President Carter, having won one complicated Civil Service reform, has wisely decided to seek another.

title: FOOD STAMP FUNDS MAY SOON RUN OUT
description: WASHINGTON, June 24Time is running short for the nation's food stamp program, which could be out of money by the end of August if Congress does not nrovide more funds soon.

title: Lucille Ball Joins NBC To Do a Comedy Show
description: Lucille Ball, who has been with CBS since 1951, has joined NBC and will start a new comedy production for the television network. Announcing the move at a press conference in Los Angeles, Fred Silverman, president of NBC, called it ode of my proudest moments.

title: Commodities
description: AS grain and soybean prices continued their stunning advances last week, adding to inflationary pressures, the markets for precious metals out on curious performances.

title: Cabby Chases and Seizes Suspect in Fire Fatal 2
description: A passing gypsycab driver who saw an exploding ball of flame that led to the death of two persons in a building early yesterday drove after a mat who ran from the building and, apprehended him by claiming he was a police officer and ordering him into the cab.

title: Letter: On Tuition Tax Credits
description: To the Editor: In The Times's June 6 editorial, Undermining Public Schools, you acknowledge the right of parents to send their children to nonpublic schools. It is regrettable, therefore, that you later identify. Senator Daniel Moynihan's fight for tuition tax credits for parents who send their children to nonpublic schools as a backdoor maneuver to jeopardize the public schools.

title: Refugee Tells of Comrades Plight
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 29  Thou. sands of Cambodians forced back into their country by Thailand this month are huddled starving in a forest at the foot of the cliffs that mark the border, waiting to be rescued, according to a refugee who made his way back into this country.

title: Barbara Allen Wed To Dr. L.S. Reich
description: Barbara Jane Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Heath Ledward Allen of Camp Hill, Pa. was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Leonard Sidney Reich. son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Reich of Silver Spring, Md. President Judge James S. Bowman of the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania performed the ceremony at the Allen home.

title: A.R. Frances Weds Pamela Ivy Koner
description: The marriage of Pamela Ivy Koner, daughter of Silvia Koner, articles editor of Redbook magazine, and Marvin Koner, a photojournalist. to Andrew Robert Frances took place yesterday at the Koner home in Manhattan. The bridegroom is the son of Evan Frances, editor in chief of 1,001 Decorating Ideas, and Alexander Frances, president of the Evans &; Frances Advertising Agency, also of New York. Rabbi Deborah Prinz performed the ceremony.

title: 50 Families Are Forced to Flee After Propane Tanks Explosion
description: WOODENSBURG, Md. June 24 (AP)  A liquid propane fire injured at least four persons yesterday and caused the temporary evacuation of all residents within a mile radius of the rural plant, the autharities said.

title: Yanks Take 4th in Row, 82
description: Don't stop now, the outfield mesL sage board at the Stadium pulsed during yesterday's game, and the Yankees didn't.

title: Jon Ormond Newman
description: HARTFORD  The elevation of Jon O. Newman today from Federal District judge here to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit seems a natural progression in the career of the 47yearold judge.

title: Richard Blodgett Weds Miss Virgil
description: The marriage of Carolyn Virgil, an artist, to Richard Blodgett, an author, took place yesterday in New York. The Rev. George H. LaPorte of the CommunitChurch of New York performed the ceremony at the apartment the couple will occupy. The bride, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Harvey Seifert of Claremont, Calif. graduated from the University of Redlands in California and received a Master of Fine Arts degree last year from Queens College. She will continue to use her name from her previous marriage, which ended in divorce. Her father is retired professor of Christian ethics at the Claremont School of Theology. Her mother, Lois C. Seifert, is a member of the national board of education of the United Methodist Church.

title: Gleaning From Farms to Feed the Elderly
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.  Two or three times a week, before the sun breaks over the mountains in the east a small caravan of trucks heads southwest out of town. The drivers and their helpers are retirees  insurance workers, teachers, farmers, professional men  and they are part of one of the more enterprising activities run for and by senior citizens in the country.

title: Trevino 3Shot Victor as Watson Falters
description: OAKVILLE, Ontario, June 24 (AP)  Lee Trevino seized the opportunity provided by Tom Watson's collapse in a flurry of bogeys and surged to a threestroke victory today in the Canadian open golf tournament.

title: Chess:
description: Boris Spassky and Yuri Balashov of the Soviet Union, Ulf Andersson of Sweden and Robert Hiibner of West Germany shared first place in the Munich International Tournament, each scoring 84.

title: U.S. Studies Big Dip in Domestic Oil Output
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)  Justice Department antitrust lawyers investigating the nation's gasoline shortage are trying to find out why crude oil production in the United States went into its deepest decline in seven years last winter, just as a revolution in Iran cut oil imports from that country.

title: Block Parties Sprout on City. Streets
description: In a dozen or more locations around the city, the weekend brought on the late bloomers in the annual spring crop of block parties and street fairs, large or small, of the kind that turn neighborhoods into urban counterparts of oldfashioned market days and gossip exchanges.

title: China Said to Weigh Refugee Camp
description: KUNMING, China, June 24 (AP) China has agreed to consider setting up a processing camp for Vietnam refugees, Joseph A. Califano, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.

title: AT HOME ABROAD The Riddle Of the Saudis
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia Saudi policy over recent months has puzzled many Americans. Why, we wonder, should a conservative Arab monarchy make common cause with radical regimes in Iraq and elsewhere? Why have the Saudis, after first taking a reserved position on Camp David, joined the Palestine Liberation Organization and others in bitter criticism and economic boycott of President Sadat?

title: Books of TheTimes
description: HOWEVER you feel about marijuana, you'll probably want to know where Albert Goldman stands on the subject before you consider reading his uneven but useful new book, GrassRoots: Marijuana in America Today. Well, the best way to illustrate how he feels is to summarize a bit of firstpersonsingular reportage that appears at the end of Chapter Two, The Threefold History of Hemp. It seems that a couple of years ago, Mr. Goldman, in a fit of hunger and curiosity, consumed three brownies cooked according to the recipe of Miss Alice B. Toklas. The initial rush he experienced was ecstatic enough, but during the downer that followed, Mr. Goldman became convinced that if he dared to swallow he would choke to death on his tongue.

title: Nancy Aleinikoff, a Teacher, Is Bride of Norman Silber
description: The marriage of Nancy Aleinikoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Aleinikoff of New York and Ancram, N.Y. to Norman I. Silber, son of Dr. and Mrs. Max N. Silber of Skokie, Ill. took place yesterday afternoon at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue. Rabbi Edward N. Klein performed the cere. mony.

title: Canada Delays Moving Embassy
description: OTTAWA, June 24  Canada's new Prime Minister, Joe Clark, left here today for Tokyo and the sevennation economic summit conference after a lastminute effort to end his first foreign policy crisis.

title: Notes From the Gas Line
description: Discothque habitus know the routine best. They sleep mostly in the evening and set alarms for the wee hours when the action at the discos gets going. Motorists in Medford, L.I. have now joined the reverse sleeping pattern, too.

title: The Marvelous Newark Bears
description: TELEVISION subsidizes most sports now. But through the years, television has had its hitandrun victims. Until the TV set dominated our sports consciousness, its absence enabled other sports to flourish, notably minor league baseball.: Before the televising major league games emptied the smalltown ball parks, minor league baseball was an industry. Some minor leagues have survived. The romance is still there  the kid Clawing his way to the bigs. But it's not the same. Until a kid brought up now, not many major league fans are aware him. But in those years managers argued with the front office to promote that kid down on the farm. That kid had a following. And each day The New York Times printed the standings of the high minor leagues. Perhaps the best minor league team was the Newark Bears of 1937, the Yankees farm club that won the InteniationahLeague pennant by 251/2 games, a team that was considered superior to many major league teams that year.

title: Barbara Geller Wed to Ira Schiffer, a Rabbinical Student
description: At the Oakland Jewish Center in Bayside, Queens, yesterday, Barbara Geller, who is completing work for a doctorate at Duke University, was married to Ira Schiffer, a student at the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College in Philadelphia. Rabbis Ira Eisenstein and Arnold Shevlin officiated.

title: Steel Output Off in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, June 29 (AP)  The European Commission said it expected raw steel production of the member nations of the European Economic Community to be 39.2 million tons in. the ultra quarter, sown rrom an estimated 34.5 million tons in the second. Prbduction was 34.4 million tons in the first quarter and 32.7 million tons in the final quarter last year, according to a commission report last week.

title: C.C. Cunningham Service Friday
description: A memorial service for Charles C. Cunningham, former director of the Art Institute of Chicago, will be held on Friday in the Memorial Church of Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. A report in The New York Times last Thursday gave an incorrect date for the service.

title: Gas Drought Reduces the Traffic To Resorts in Metropolitan Area
description: Cool weather and the fear of running out of gasoline kept the crowds thin yesterday at many resort areas in the metropolitan region, particularly at beaches on Long Island and in New Jersey.

title: Nancy Scott Is Married To Martin J. Newhouse
description: Nancy Scott, assistant professor of fine arts at Brandeis University, was married yesterday to Martin J. Newhouse, assistant professor of history at Columbia University. Justice Arnold L. Fein of the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division performed the ceremony at the Explorers Club.

title: Drexel Puts Specialists On Amex
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. the Wall Street brokerage firm, is to start up a specialist unit today on the American Stock Exchange to make markets in 21 stocks and two options.

title: Few Clues in Hunt for SoHo Boy
description: Shira Patz had her ninthbirthday party this month. But none of her friends showed up.

title: U.S. Is Sued On Oil Leasing
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI)  A coalition of consumer groups and unions has filed suit in United States District Court here asking that the Government stop leasing offshore oil and gas tracts until it imiilements a system that would enhance competition, increase production and assure receipt of full value for the public's property.

title: A.D.A. Votes to Oppose Carter and Press Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Americans for Democratic Action, a liberal stronghold within the Democratic Party, adopted a resolution today to deny President Carter renomination in 1980 and to try to create an irresistible national mandate for Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts to seek the Presidency.

title: Big Names Abound On Fall Fiction List
description: LIKE the nappy combination of sun, soil and pruning to produce potable wine, this autumn promises to be a vintage season for books in the fields of fiction. It happens every few years that the bigname novelists all deliver their manuscripts at about the. same time. A number of them  by coincidence, not design have books coming up in the months ahead.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Machine Tool Orders Up in May
description: Machine tool orders and shipments continued to rise during May, according to data released today by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

title: Sporting Gear
description: No more flats, no more pumping, no more valve problems for bicyclists. That's the prospect offered by the Airless Tire, introduced recently by Zeus Manufacturing of Costa Mesa, Calif. This nonpneumatic polyurethane tire eliminates most problems associated with airpressure tires  safety may be its best feature, since it does away with blowoutsand still gives a consistent ride. You can get the Airless Tire in either yellow or black, and it fits wheels 24, 26 or 27 inches in diameter. It must be measured against inside rim widths, with one model intended for American bike rims, of twelvesixteenths to fourteensixteenths of an inch, and another for the rims that predominate among foreign bikes, of ninesixteenths to elevensixteenths of an inch. Starting next month, the Airless Tire will be available at Two Guys and many bicycle shops in the metropolitan area. The price is about $14.

title: Where Will the Numbers. End?
description: The refugees pouring out of Indochina have finally stimulated international action to slow down their expulsions, to alleviate their misery in transit and, most important, to find them new homes. But until the appropriate conferences are held  and several countries would be content to see them drag indefinitely something must be done for the drifting thousands.

title: Private Relief Agencies to Lobby for Boat People
description: The tragedy of the Vietnamese boat people denied havens and turned back to sea has, evoked painful memories of the suffering of Jewish refugees from Nazi Germany and has sparked a demand by Jewish and Christian agencies for immediate and extensive governmental assistance.

title: Westinghouse Settles Vepco Suit
description: RICHMOND, Va. June 24 (AP)  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has agreed to pay the Virginia Electric and Power Company up to $380 million in cash, goods and services in settlement of Vepco's suit for breach of contracts to supply uranium.

title: The New York Times/Bob Glass
description: Archbishop Vasilios Constantinides kissed cross yesterday at Christ Church in Manhattan before elevation to be first Patriarch of Orthodox Church in America. The group broke away from Russian Orthodox Church in 1970.

title: Leonard Registers 23d Straight Victory
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. June 24 (AP) After absorbing four rounds of brutal punishment by Sugar Ray Leonard, Tony Chiaverini failed to answer the bell for the fifth round today in a nationally televised superwelterweight contest.

title: 2 Convicted of Torture Face Iran Firing Squad
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 24 (Reuters)Two former agents of the Shah's secret police were executed by firing squad today after being convicted of killing and mutilating political prisoners.

title: U.S. Envoy in Moscow in Middle of Storm
description: MOSCOW, June 24  For the United States Ambassador to Moscow, Malcolm Toon, the United StatesSoviet summit meeting in Vienna a week ago was an unhappy experience.

title: Rock Music: Lowell George And New Band
description: LITTLE FEAT, the Los Angelesbased rock group that recently disbanded, will undoubtedly have its fans for years to come. Some of those fans will probably never understand why Lowell George, Little Feat's most distinctive singer and songwriter, progressively lost interest in the group over the last several years. But nobody who heard Mr. George at the Bottom Line over the weekend, or at the other dates on his first solo tour, can be pondering this question very seriously.

title: CasinoGambling Coalition Asks High Priority for Issue in Albany
description: A weekold coalition that favors casino gambling in New York State urged yesterday that Governor Carey and the State Legislature give the issue high priority at the next legislative session, scheduled for September.

title: Notes on People
description: It may be true that jealousies rage in the arts and that cooperation among companies of artists is rare. But there are times when generosity of spirit abounds, and this is the story of one such time.

title: Jack Lusk, Lawyer, Weds Jane Herzog
description: Jane E. Herzog, a Project coordinator and educational specialist at the Lexington School for the Deaf in Jackson Heights, was married yesterdev to Jack a staff member of the general counsel of the United States Department of Transportation. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of White Plains.

title: Associated Press
description: GUNSHOT INTERRUPTS KLAN RALLY: Armed bodyguards surrounded a crouching Bill Wilkinson, Imperial Wizard of the Invisible Empire, after a shot was fired Saturday night during a rally in Decatur, Ala. Klan members had gathered for the burning of a school bus to protest busing as a means of desegregation, when a shot, possibly fired by a Klan guard as a warning, rang out, sending hundreds of Klansmen and spectators scurrying for cover.

title: Weather Report's Patato Valdes A Virtuoso on the Conga Drums
description: JACO PATORIUS, who plays electric bass with Weather Report, gave one of the most disappointing solo performances this listener has ever heard at the Newport Jazz FestivalNew York in Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday night. It was disappointing because Mr. Pastorius, player with a distinctive approach and formidable, if widely overrated, technique, depended almost entirely on speed, gadgetry and visual flash.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Thomas W. Strauss has spent his entire career at Salomon Brothers, the investment banking house, working his way up from salesman 16 years ago to partner in 1972. In the months ahead, as the executive in charge of the Governmentbond and moneymarket areas at his firm, he will be on the front line as Salomon prepares to enter the financial futures market on behalf of its institutional clients.

title: Israel Removes Weizman From Its Negotiating Team
description: JERUSALEM, June 24  The Israeli Cabinet today granted a request by Defense Minister Ezer Weizman that he be dropped from Israel's negotiating team in talks with Egypt and the United States about Arab selfrule on the West Bank and in Gaza.

title: Whey Disposal Troubles Vermonters
description: EAST GEORGIA, Vt. June 20  All Vermont wanted was a nice clean way to get rid of its whey.

title: 8 Lebanon Towns Bombed After a Blast in Tel Aviv
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24  Israeli jets attacked Palestinian targets in southern Lebanon today only a few hours after a bomb exploded near a bus station in Tel Aviv.

title: Spinks Stopped in First Round
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, June 24An overhand right with a hand that had undergone two operations sent Leon Spinks spinning toward a stunning firstround knockout loss tonight and put Gerrie Coetzee, an undefeated South African, into a bout this fall for one of the world heavyweight championships.

title: United Press International
description: FUNERAL FOR NEWSMAN SLAIN IN NICARAGUA: As Roone Arledge, president of ABC News, looked on at left, the coffin of Bill Stewart was carried past after funeral in Ashland, Ky. yesterday. Mr. Stewart, 37, a correspondent for the network, was shot in the head Wednesday by a Nicaraguan National Guardsman in Managua: Incident, which was filmed, prompted pullout of many reporters and camera crews from the ravaged country.

title: SteelDumping Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) The Treasury Department said that it had ended its investigation of alleged dumping of carbon steel plate by Belglum, terance, West Germany and Italy. The inquiry was begun in January on the basis of a petition filed by the Lukens Steel Company. Lukens has withdrawn its petition, officials said. Dumping is the practice of importing foreign products at prices below what it cost to produce them.

title: Italian Kidnapping Victim Freed
description: BERGAMO, Italy, June 24 (Reuters) Kidnappers released an Italian shoe manufacturer here today after payment of an undisclosed ransom, the police said. Francesco Doneda, 45 years old, was seized by masked gunmen in his office on May 21. He was the 27th kidnapping victim in Italy this year.

title: Irish Prosper From Ties With Common Market
description: DUBLIN  Out in the green, moist countryside to the west and south of here, Irish dairy farmers who five years ago were exporting milk to England for 25 cents a gallon are now gettine a dollar a aallon.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: American energy experts expect a substantial price rise out of the OPEC meeting that opens tomorrow. A jump of onethird above the official $14.55abarrel price, already superseded by large surcharges, is expected. page DL] Meanwhile, President Carter arrived in Tokyo to begin economic talks with Japan aimed at reaching a common position on the energy crisis. The talks precede a sevennation economic summit meeting starting:Thursday. [A1.]

title: New F.B.I. Crisis Control Center A Key to Saving 136 in Hijacking
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Sixteen minutes after Nikola Kavaja, a militant Serbian nationalist, informed the pilot of American Airlines Flight 293 that he was carrying a bomb and was taking control of the plane and its 136 passengers last Wednesday a red telephone rang at the Federal Bureau of Investigation's headquarters here.

title: More Driver Groups Add Trucker Strike Demands
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Representatives of striking independent truckers from nine Western and Southern states presented more demands on the Government here today as conditions for going back to work.

title: Radiation Found at Site of Radium Plant Dating From the 1920's
description: ORANGE, N.J.  On the site of the old United States Radium Corporation plant here, state officials have found traces of radiation  the legacy of an earlier and more nave era.

title: Alpaca Styles From Peru
description: Annie Hurlbut is an anthropologist who spent her sophomore summer when she was at Yale working at an archeological dig in Peru. There she encountered the alpaca, a cameloid animal related to the vicua and the llama. Although the airmen hac an unnleacant disposition  it spits at people, she says  it is the mainstay of the economy of the Andes, serving as food and, along with the llama, as beast of burden. That is, it will carry a 50pound load. Put 51 pounds on it and it balks, Miss Hurlbut explains.

title: Miss Lopez Wins Her 6th Tourney of 79
description: HERSHEY, Pa. June 24 (UPI)Nancy Lopez played steady golf as her challengers faltered today and her par 72 was good enough to win the,title in the $100,000 Lady Keystone open by two shots over Kathy Whitworth and Sally Little.

title: Bridge:
description: The great Italian Blue Team, which dominated world team championships for almost two decades, has been in eclipse since 1975 for reasons that include partnership problems and domestic bridge scandals. But the team is now back in operation, and a group headed by Benito Garozzo, Giorgio Belladonna, Arturo Franco and Vito Pittala, who rallied to beat the United States in Bermuda four years ago, will start as favorites in the European championships in Lausanne, Switzerland, next month.

title: Cases Force Value Conflicts on High Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The Supreme Court made the laetrile case look simple. Lzst week, by a vote of 9 to 0, in a short eight pages of analysis, it upheld the authority of the Federal Government to ban the purported cancer cure, even for patients who would die anyway.

title: Five Pianists Perform At Waterloo Village
description: STANHOPE, N.J. June 24 Even after a relatively small but determined audience, estimated at 2,000 people, managed to get to Waterloo Village yesterday despite the gasoline shortage for the first of two weekend Newport Jazz Festival presentations by the New Jersey Jazz Society; they could not escape reminders of their transportation difficulties. And they loved the reminders.

title: Carter, in Japan, Seeking to Unify Policy on Energy
description: TOKYO, Monday, June 25  President Carter began talks today with Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira with the goal of establishing a common position on the gravest energy crisis the industrial democracies have faced since 1973.

title: Nonalcohol Beer for Saudis
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (UPI) C. Schmidt & Sons, a Philadelphia brewery, said it had shipped 32,000 cases of alcoholfree beer to Saudi Arabia. The beer is in big demand there because of Islamic laws that forbid the drinking of alcoholic beverages, the company said..

title: N.B.A. Draft: A Scout's Evaluations
description: DUDLEY BRADLEY averaged 4.3 points a game in his four seasons at the University of North Carolina, Larry Demic 10.3 at Arizona, and. Wiley Peck 10.6 at Missicsleel State.

title: The City
description: A medical team at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx reattached the left leg of a man after it had been 90 percent severed in &motorcycle accident. The patient, 39yearold Ralph Pffeffer of Hackettstown, NJ. was listed in satisfactory condition yesterday after 16 hours of surgery. gleven physicians and I0 nurses took part in the operation.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1979

title: Arnalya Lyle Kearse
description: When Arnalya L: Kearse is sworn in to the United States Court of Appeals for the SecOnd Circuit, she will become the first woman ever to sit on the Federal anneals court in Manhattan and only the second black in the court's history. (Thurgood Marshall, now on the United States Supreme Court, was the first). At the age of 42, she will be one of the youngest persons to sit on what is Woman lithe News considered by many lawyers to be the most important court in the country, after the United States Supreme Court.

title: Affirmed First Horse To Earn $2 Million
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif. June 24 (AP)  Affirmed becarne today the first race horse to earn $2 million when he captured the $500,000 Hollywood Gold cup, coining within onetitth on a second of the world record for 1 miles.

title: Parkgoers Enjoy San Juan Fiesta
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke celebrated a mass in Spanish for 5,000 people at the Central Park band shell yesterday, while an estimated 100,000 others mingled at an openair market at tne parrs Betnesaa Fountain area. Both events were part of the city's 27th annual version of Puerto Rico's Fiesta de San Juan Battista.

title: Siegel Gains Title
description: KEARNY. N.J. June 24  Topseeded Steve Siegel of Teaneck scored a 75, 76 victory today over Ron Erskine. a 16yearold high school iunior from Glen Ridge, in the final of the New Jersey State men's singles championship at the Arlington Players Club.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A wide band of clouds extends from New England southwestward through the Ohlo, Tennessee and middle Mississippi Valleys to the Central Gulf States. Thunderstorms are embedded In the cloud band over Arkansas and Oklahoma. Scattered showers are apparent In the Northern Plalne States and the Southwest Desert region.

title: Maillol Sculpture Acquired By. Hirshhorn Museum
description: LOUNAuguste Blanqui'S 30 years in French prisons and five years in exile earned him the nickname The Prisoner. After his death in 1881. the French politician's friends wanted, to erect a monument to him and they commissioned Aristide Maillol to create it.

title: How National Academy of Science Decided to Halt a Nuclear Waste Report Is Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  A controversy has developed within the National Academy. of Sciences over the procedures it followeJ in deciding abruptly to halt the publication of a report on radioactive wastes.

title: Earthquake Felt in Alaska
description: TUNEAU, Alaska, June 24 (UPI)  A mediumsized earthquake registering 4.0 on the Richter scale rocked Juneau yesterday but caused no apparent damage.

title: Homosexuals Parade Marks 10th Year of Rights Drive
description: With sympathetic parents in the line of march, tens of thousands of homosexual men and women walked from Christopher Street to Central Park yesterday to Commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Stonewall Riot, which many consider the beginning of the national homosexualrights movement.

title: A Sampling of What's Legal
description: SINKER: The ball is held slightly off center, with more of it to the outside part of the hand than to the inside. For best results, the sinker is delivered with perhaps a threequarters release  that is, between overhand and sidearm. The ball is gripped hard, and it is thrown With a slight turn or the wrist. The hand should be kept on top of the ball. The ball sinks as it reaches the plate, though not so suddenly or so sharply as with a spitter. Tommy John of the New York Yankees and Mike Caldwell of the Milwaukee Brewers are two pitchers who get an unusually large number of ground balls with their sinkers, as batters often make contact only with the top part.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: The wind moves a golfer's ball before he can address it. He replaces it, in its original position, and boles out. Is this permissible?

title: Abbey Lincoln Giving Concert
description: Abbey Lincoln, the jazz singer, will give her first concert in New York in 10 years In a program called Welcome Home Abbey Lincoln at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday at 8 P.M. She will be assisted by the International AfrikanAmerican Ballet, Sweet Honey in the Rock and Dwain Jones.

title: OPEC Base May Rise About 33%
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Energy experts in the United States have become increasingly pessimistic in recent weeks about the likely outcome of this week's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Many now expect an increase of onethird in the cartel's base price of oil.

title: Test Lab for Atom Plants Has Had Its Accidents, Too
description: IDAHO FALLS  The Idaho National Engineering Laboratory was set up by the Federal Government in 1999 to test the efficacy and safety of various tines of nuclear reactors  matters of heightened concern since the accident last March 28 at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant near Harrisburg, Pa.

title: ARMS PACT FOES POSE DILEMMA FOR CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 When President Carter invited Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. the Republican leader, to the White /louse last week to ask what he wanted, the softspoken Mr. Baker was painfully clear. He wants amendments to the strategicarms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Block Island Race Week: Yachts, Drinks and Pranks
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R.I. OVER on the mainland  in Newport, for example  tourism has been off by 60 percent from last June. because of the fuel crisis. But there is no crisis here. The wind has brought 2,000 wellfinanced sailors to this island for the start today of Block Island Race Week, a biennial affair that blends boats, beverages and buffoonery.

title: Book Spurs Discussion Of Soviet Spy in F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation suspected that one of their New York agents was spying for the Soviet Union in the late 1960's, according to the memoirs of a former bureau executive.

title: World News Briefs
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 24 (Reuters) Syria and Libya stressed the importance of strengthening Arab resistance to the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty during talks here today.

title: Aretha Franklin's Father in Coma
description: DETROIT, June 24 (UPI)  Shot in robbery attempt, the Rev. Clarence L. Franklin, father of Aretha Franklin, the singer, is in a coma and near death. court testimony showed yesterday. A suspect in the case told Recorder's Court Judge Leonard Townsend how the wouldbe burglars botched the robbery on June 10 and ended up shooting the 63yearold civil rights leader. Mr. Franklin was listed in critical condition yesterday in Detroit's Henry Ford Hospital, where he has been in a coma since the shooting. Three suspects are being held.

title: Brown Cites Forces' Readiness In Reply to Question on Mideast
description: The United States has combatready forces capable of acting in the Middle East should the Western world's oil supply be Jeopardized, Defense Secretary Harold Brown said yesterday.

title: The Spitball and Other Stuff
description: TONIMY JOHN, the Yankee pitcher who has been accused of throwing scuffed baseballs, has finally confessednot to throwing scuffed baseballs. though.

title: NBC to Televise Debate On SALT II Ratification
description: NBCTV will preempt some of its primetime programming Tuesday night, July 10, to televise live a 90minute debate on whether the Senate should ratify SALT II.

title: OPEC Pricing: An Antitrust Question
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The Carter Administration, the nation's major oil companies and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will be following the action in a Los Angeles courtroom tomorrow morning, when a Federal judge is scheduled, to decide whether to issue a preliminary injunction against OPEC for price fixing and other antitrust violations.

title: Sports Briefs
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. June 24 Paul Friedman, a runner on the Rutgers University squad, was the upset victor today in the third annual Manufacturers Hanover Westchester HalfMarathon.

title: U.S. Plans Heavy Offering Schedule
