description: Treasury and Federal agency financing activity will be heavy on Wednesday as the Government, the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Farm Credit System borrow a total of S2.7 billion of additional cash.

title: An Artist Exhibits No Ill Will As Efforts Come Unwrapped
description: When an artist named Francis Hines wrapped an abandoned tenement at 605 East Fifth Street in gauze recently, no one seemed sure if he was creating art for the East Village, making a subtle political gesture or indulging in idle estheticism.

title: U.S. CleanWater Program Meeting Rising Resistance
description: MAYO, Md. June 20  The $4billionayear Federal program to build sewage treatment plants, second in size only to  the highway program in the Government's nonmilitary, construction effort, was intended to helpr'eities.:and towns cope with the rising flood of sewage that was polluting the nation's waters and creating public health problems.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW,June 26 SAGAFJORD (NorwegianAmerica Line). Left Bermuda June 20; due at 8 A.M. at West 55th Street.

title: Accountants Under Scrutiny
description: The accounting profession is coming under another round of scrutiny in Washington. This time, the concern is over management consulting, which has become big. Usihess for the nation's largest public accounting firms.

title: Davis, Brcic Lead Cosmos to Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. June 24  Rick Davis and David Brcic, two, young American players, were the stars of the Cosmos at Giants Stadium this afternoon.

title: Donald R. Hyman Weds Wendy Georgia Ronson
description: In the Dwight Memorial Chapel on the Yale campus in New Haven yesterday, Wendy Georgia Ronson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ronson of Trumbull, Conn. became the bride of Donald R. Hyman, son of Beatrice and Wilbur Hyman, both of Clifton, N.J. Justice of the Peace Mary P. Hayes performed the ceremony.

title: ESSAY Shaking The Red Train
description: PARIS  Where will Leonid Brezhnev rank in the pantheon of Communist heros?

title: Cara Nash Is Bride Of Lawrence Iason
description: Cara N. Nash, an associate with Weil, Gotshal & Manges, New York law firm, was married yesterday afternoon to Lawrence lason, an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New. York. Rabbi David Saperstein performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's brotherinlaw and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas May of Rye, N.Y.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PHEBE'S PROGENY  It has been 10 years since the Broadway success of Robert Patrick's drama Kennedy's Children and also the opening of Phebe's Restaurant, now known as the Sardi's of Off Off Broadway, where the play was originally set and much of it written. Hence a doubleanniversary party tonight at the downtown bistro, with the public invited to join Off Off Broadway celebrants, on their free evening, for wine and cheese on the house starting at 8:30, in the cashbar section.

title: 2 More Weeks on Ground Called Likely for DC10's
description: Government officials estimated yesterday that it would be two more weeks, if everything goes right, before the grounded DC10 fleet could be allowed back in the air.

title: Roger Kennedy New Head Of Smithsonian Museum
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Roger G. Kennedy, a vice president of the Ford Foundation, has been named director of the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of History and Technology. Mr. Kennedy, 52 years old, joined the Ford Foundation in 1970 and is vice president in charge of its office of the arts. He will go to the Smithsonian on Oct. 1, succeeding Otto Mayr, acting director in the year since the former director, Brooke Hindle, became the museum's senior historian.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, June 23 (UPI)  Sev. eral members of the Jewish Defense League used baseball bats today to break up a meeting of American Nazi Party members at a hotel in suburban Independence, the police said. A scheduled rally in another suburb had been disrupted earlier.

title: Jazz: Rivbea Festival
description: STUDIO RIVBEA'S summer jazz festivals have traditionally provided alternative programming during the more mainstream3riented Newport Jazz FestivalNew York. But this year, with new jazz more established as a concert draw and most of the musicianrun lofts closed, the Rivbea Festival, named for the saxophonist Sam Rivers and his wife, Bea, was held at Joseph Papp's Public Theater. There were four shows on Friday night, with Mr. Rivers leading a 30piece orchestra at each performance and using various small groups drawn from the orchestra as opening acts.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Unsettled Trading Expected for Week
description: After muddling through last week without any definite sense of direction, the credit markets are likely to continue to grove their way alone this week until they make better sense of what is happening in the economy, to the dollar and at the meeting of oilexporting countries this week.

title: Chase Unit Sees Rate Drop.
description: Kevin Hurley, director of financial forecasting at Chase Econometrics, a Chase Manhattan Bank subsidiary, is not waffling on interest rates. They have already peaked. he declares.

title: Right Decision, Months Late
description: BUD DELP is a good man, good copy and a good trainer of race horses. Though he has a temper, he does not often leap to hasty or illconsidered decisions, and in most circumstances this is a point in his favor. In most circumstances, but not always. It would have been better for all concerned if he had made last March the decision he didn't reach until,this weekend  to takeRon Franklin off Spectacular Bid.

description: Deaths

description: Closing of 95% of Area's Stations Cuts Sunday Auto Traffic $1.60 Price Is Reached

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON STEEL and farm lobbies are at loggerheads over who will represent their constituents in the restructured trade bureaucracy. It is only one of the battles sparked by proposals just placed on President Carter's desk by James T. McIntyre Jr. director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Robert S. Strauss, the special trade representative.

title: Status jeans: Lucrative Craze
description: More than ever before, customers are paying a premium for a patch of blueleans. that is.

title: Phils Beat Expos For First Time
description: After losing eight straight games to the Montreal Expos this season, the Philadelphia Mines went into yesterday's finale of a threegame series at Montreal desperate for a victory. To tie rescue came Larry t.nristenson, whose hitting and pitching led the way to a 52 triumph for the frustrated Phillies.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Pirates, at Shea Stadium, twilight night doubleheader, Roosevelt Avenue and 128th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 5:30 P.M. (RadioWhICA, WGBB, 5:30 P.M.)

title: Advertising
description: SCIENCE, the esteemed 131yearold publication of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, is about to spawn a sister publication called Science 80, to be positioned, according to Allen L. Hammond, its editor in chief, midway between Scientific American and Popular Mechanics.

title: Margaret Horstmann Is Wed to Paul Hodes
description: Margaret Anne Horstmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Horstmann of Holden, Mass. was married yesterday in Worcester. Mass.. to Paul William Hodes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Hodes of New York and Sag Harbor, L.I. The Rev. David C. Glendinning, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Higgins House of Worcester Polytechnic Institute.

title: Mets Pull Together and Beat Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, June 24  The New York Mets finally put together good pitching and substantial hitting to end their sixgame road trip today with a 62 victory river the Cardinals.

title: Splitting Dollars on the Continental Divide
description: This country's Eastern and Western states have almost opposite water troubles. The West has, in effect, too little water and, many would contend, too much Federal water money. The East has plenty of water and too little water money. Lately, the Senate and the House have been arguing over Tennessee's Tellico Dam and its threatened snail darter, that small fish that has legally blocked the dam's construction. But they would be spending their time more profitably they looked at a national map of Federal water projects and asked whether their distribution really met the nation's needs.

title: Wild Bill Davison to Open
description: Wild Bill Davison, the jazz trumpeter who lives in Copenhagen, is paying his annual visit to New York for a threeweek aupearance at Eddie Condon's. 144 West 54th Street, beginning today. Mr. Davison, who works most of the year in Europe, will perform in a sextet that includes Kenny Davern, who will alternate with Bobby Gordon, on clarinet; George Masso, trombonist; Red Balaban, bassist; Jim Andrews, pianist, and Ernie Hackett, drummer.

title: New Shange Play Will Aid Writers Workshop
description: ANEW Ntozake Shange play, Boogie Woogle Landscapes, will be presented tomorrow at the Symphony Space for the benefit of the Frank Silvera Writers Workshop, a sixyearold Harlem institution that is a training ground for black playwrights.

title: Foyt Easy Victor in Pocono 500 Race
description: LONG POND, Pa. June 24  A.S. Foyt won the Pocono 500mile auto race for a third time today before a crowd of about 30,000 at Pocono International Raceway.

title: O.A.S. Resists U.S. Viewpoint
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  After the Organization of American States had ended its emergency meeting on Nicaragua yesterday, Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher called the results unprecedented and Latin American delegates were even more effusive.

title: Bjorn Borg, Miss Navratilova Face Strong Wimbledon Foes
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 Bjorn Borg and Martina Navratilova, the defending men's and women's champions, will vie with eight other former champions beginning tomorrow for the coveted Wimbledon singles titles at the All England Tennis Club.

title: Events
description: GOT TU GO DISCO, a disco musical; artistic direction by Joe Eula; book by John Zodrow. Directed by Larry Ford. at the Minskott Theater, 45th Street and Broadway, 6:30.

title: Stemming Flow Of Street Drugs Eludes Harlem
description: If the woman standing with the shining clean child by hei side in front of the Ephesus Church of the SeVenth Day AdVentists had turned her head to the right, her line of sight Lenox Avenue and over the trees in Central Park would have carried to the Rockefeller Center skyscrapers on Sixth Avenue. And if she had taken two steps to the airner, she could have seen past the ugly gash of 123d Street to the top of Grant's TOmb on a high hill to the west.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Leader Says Kennedy. Would Have Wide Black Support
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. June 24 Benjamin L. Hooks, the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy could take more than 60 percent of the black vote if he were to challenge President Carter in the Democratic Presidential primaries.

title: Congressman Accuses Pentagon Of Buying Unnecessary Missile
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)  Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, accused the Pentagon today of approving production of the $3.7 billion Roland missile system when studies show two other missiles are just as good, and cheaper.

title: Josephine Ingersoll Is Married
description: The marriage of Josephine Ingersoll, widow of W. Fitch Ingersoll, to Donald W. Griffin took place yesterday at the home of the bride in Marion. Mass. The Rev. Charles Scott of St. Gabriel's Episcopal Church in Marion performed the ceremony. Mrs. Griffin, a graduate of Smith College, class of 24, was the first chairman of the board of the Friends of Smith College. Her husband served as a colonel in the Army Air Forces during World War H and, for 29 years, was the resident executive secretary of the Alumni Association of Princeton University. His first wife died. The couple will divide their time between Marion. and Mr. Griffin's home in Princeton.

title: Letters
description: 1,000 Gallons of To the Editor: Recent polls have shown that, a stronghanded President would be welcomed: a President who could solve our problems, including inflation and energy dependency. One response is described by Richard Halloran's June 11 news story predicting a tough Presidential demeanor at the Tokyo talks among the industrially advanced countries of Western Europe, North America and Japan.

title: Turkish General Opposes U2 Plan
description: ANKARA, Turkey, June 24 (Reuters)  The Turkish armed forces chief of staff, General Kenan Evren, was quoted today as saying Turkey could not allow American U2 spy planes to fly over its territory to verify the new strategic arms limitation treaty.

title: The Ballet: New Lovers At Stuttgart
description: JOHN CRANKO'S signature Romeo and Juliet could get by on its telling dramatic detail and period color alone. The ballet didn't have to rely on anythina but its dancing on Saturday night, however, when a very good new Stuttgart Ballet cast took the leads at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: The Region
description: WANTAGN, L.I. (AP)  About 800 swimmers and sunbathers were evacuated after a World War II airtoground rocket was found in the sand at Jones Beach yesterday, the Nassau County police reported.

title: Soprano: Susan Gregory
description: SUSAN GREGORY'S New York recitals in recent seasons have shown her to be a gifted singer and an engagingly communicative artist. Her latest concert, in Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night, was just as enjoyame, even through tier program might have been slightly more conventional than in the past.

title: TV SPORT
description: TODAY

title: Even the LawnMowing Trade Feels Pinch of Scarce Gasoline
description: The fuel crisis has not only begun to inconvenience suburbanites who use gasolinepowered mowers to cut their lawns; it has also Stirred deep concern at some of the smaller businesses that maintain lawns in the metropolitan area.

title: Minority Contractors Are Critical Of U.S. SmallBusiness Program
description: CHICAGO, June 21  Ten years ago Renard Vine, a Los Angeles contractor and developer, looked to the future hopefully as the promotion of black capitalism began to emerge as a national goal.

title: Dr. J.F. Pasternak Weds Dr. Barbara L. Trommer
description: Dr. Barbara Lois Trommer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Trommer of Kew Gardens. Queens. was married yesterday to Dr. Joseph Farrell Pasternak, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Joel Pasternak of Des Moines. The ceremony was performed at the St. Regis by Rabbi Emeritus David Seligson of the Central Synagogue.

title: Brooklyn Girl Sets Record
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. June 24 (AP)  Sandra Farmer, a highschool senior from Brooklyn, seta world junior record in the girls 400Meter hurdles today in the Amateur Athletic Union national junior track and field championships at Indiana University.

title: Gilda Brancato and Elliot Polebaum, Lawyers, Married
description: Gilda Brancato and Elliot Polebaum, Boston lawyers, were married yesterday in Laconia, N.H. Justice of the Peace Louis Athanas performed the ceremony with Judge James L. Oakes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Outdoors: Some Big Smallmouth Fishing
description: CORNISH, N.H. APASSION for trout and landlocked salmon on the part of most New Hampshire freshwater anglers has resulted in a sublime neglect of the smallmouth bass, one of the country's most exciting game fishes.

title: The Cry of the Panda Heard Again in China
description: TOKYO, June 24 (AP)  The severe winter of 1976 almost wiped out the rare giant pandas of China's southwestern mountains, but they have made comeback, the official New China News Agency said yesterday.

title: Ultranationalist Rabbi Sees Wes Bank s Jewith. Country
description: QIRYAT ARBA, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, June 21  Rabbi Moshe Levinger, the leader of a pugnacious group of Orthodox settlers, does not understand how anyone could propose selfgovernment for Arabs in the areas that Israel conquered in 1967. I'm not against autonomy, he said. You can't be against something that has no hand or foot or head. The Arabs don't understand it either.

title: De Gustibus.
description: A letter received recently from Marnie S. Schaefer of Scottsdale, Ariz. posed some of the most interesting inquiries about tinlined and untinned copper pots and pans that we've encountered in a long time.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Broadcasting Companies has named Sheldon M. Wool president and chief executive officer of its Travel Network Corporation subsidiary.

title: Financing Schools Fairly
description: The head man down at the Metropolitan has been hinting around that they'd be mighty happy to take care of this thing after I check out, said my grandfatherinlaw, some 20 years ago, smiling as he ran his hand over the corner of an exquisite 16thcentury desk the size of a pingpong table.

title: Dena Kleiman Bride of Ronald Shechtman
description: Dena Kleiman, a reporter for The New York Times, was married yesterday evening to Ronald H. Shechtman, a partner in the New York law firm of Gordon & Shechtman. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The bride, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. A.H. Kleiman of New York and Pornpano Beach, Fla. will keep her maiden name. She attended L'Institut d'Etudes Politiques in Paris and graduated from Wellesley College. Her father, a urologist and former physician for the New York State Athletic Commission, is an editor of Physician and Sports Medicine magazine.

title: City Ballet: Prodigal Returns
description: T HE Prodigal Son returned on Saturday afternoon. This particular prodigal was George Balanchine's version of the parable, presented for the first time this season by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows: MONDAY

title: Ugandans, Without Idi Amin to Fight, Fall Into Disunity.
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, June 20  Many of the political difficulties in Uganda stem from the makeup of the successful coalition of exiles that joined for one purpose, the overthrow of Field Marshal Idi Amin.

title: Firemen Have Hearts
description: A bill is now sitting on Governor Carey's desk that would extend for two years the Heart Law for New York City's firefighters and policemen. The law has been renewed, In the face of opposition, every year since 1970, and once again the critics are on the rampage.

title: James V. Joy Sr. ExChairman Of Fairfield University's Board
description: James V. Joy Sr. former chairman of the board of trustees of Fairfield University, died Saturday at the Carolton Nursing Home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: Arthur D. Gray, Educator, Dead
description: The. Rev. Arthur Douglass Gray, a prominent black educator who had served as president of Talladega College in Alabama from 1953 to 1963, died yesterday in Indianapolis while attending the United Church of Christ's 12th General Synod. He was 72 years old.

title: Drucie Rene Pomerantz Bride
description: Drucie Rene Pomerantz, a graduate of New York University and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Pomerantz of Great Neck, L.I. was married there yesterday to Gerald Alan Isenberg. He is a secondyear student at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Isenberg, also of Great Neck. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson, assisted by Cantor Barbara Ostfeld, performed the ceremony in Temple BethEl, of which Mr. Pomerantz is president. The bridegroom's father is a microbiologist.

title: Piano: Cruz's Ginastera
description: ALBERTO GINASTERA'S piano Sonata is evidently something of a specialty with Milton Cruz, and his performance of it has been enthusiastically endorsed by the composer himself. The pianist from Santo Domingo played the work at his concert in Carnegie Recital Hall late Saturday afternoon and it was by far the most imprestive part of his program.

title: Malaysia Reports 13,000 Refugees Expelled
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 25 The Malaysian Government said today that 13,000 Vietnamese refugees in 60 boats were forced out into international waters in the last week, raising to 55,000 the number expelled this year.

title: TV: Story Of a Sioux Militant
description: CROW DOG, the story of one of the leaders of the 71.day occupation by members of the American Indian Movement of Wounded Knee, S.D., in 1973, which will be seen from 10 to 11 tonight on WNETTV, raises once again the questiop of where the documentary approach leaves off and special pleading begins.

title: Health Care Rationing Is Suggested in a Study
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)  The nation may have to change its philosophy of providing medical care regardless of its cost, a study by the Brookings Institution says.

title: FixedIncome Prices Regain Strength
description: Shrugging off the mild decline that hit the credit markets late last week, prices of fbiedincome securities advanced from late morning until late afternoon yesterday. Interest rates declined, some to the lowest levels in eight months or more.

title: Train and Bus Ridership Is Up Sharply As Lack of Gas Keeps Autos off Roads.
description: The gasoline shortage has made substantial proportion of motorists in the New York area  perhaps as many as one in 10  take to trains and buses, where thousands of commuters and even midday travelers are now standing in the aisles.

title: High School Nongraduates Want to Join in Graduation
description: For Sally Nieves, high school graduation today will have pomp and very confusing circumstances.

title: MUCH OF U.S. FEELING IMPACT OF GAS CRISIS
description: The shortage of gasoline, which began on the West Coast and has now reached crisis proportions in much of the Northeast, is beginning to be felt in other parts of the country.

title: United Technologies Charged by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused the United Technologies Corporation of violating antifraud and reporting provisions of the securities laws in its efforts to acquire the Carrier Corporation.

title: Science Watch
description: The beneficial effects of chlorine, the chemical that purifies drinking water and prevents outbreaks of waterborne diseases, may be offset by an insidious  but as yet poorly understood threat it poses to man and his environment, studies at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution have shown.

title: Police Plan New Push To Reduce Drug Sales On Harlem's 123d St.
description: New York City's Police Department will dispatch officers from a variety of units to 123d Street in Harlem in an effort to stem the traffic in street drugs on that block, Chief of Patrol William R. Bracey promised angry residents last night.

title: Stock Market Retreats Moderately Amid Global Economic Uncertainties
description: The stock market staged a moderate retreat yesterday in the face of unsettling developments abroad.

title: The New York Times/Barton Silverman
description: Dress regulations aside, graduates let fly yesterday with their hats after commencement exercises for the 43d graduating class of Merchant Marihe Academy at Kings Point, L.I. Class of 253 midshipmen, including 15 women, was largest class to graduate since 1953. The graduates were awarded Bachelor of Science degrees.

title: Kuwait Backs $20 Oil
description: MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 25  The adoption of a $20abarrel minimum world oil price is the only solution to the international energy crisis acceptable both to oilconsuming nations and to oil producers, Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik All Khalifa alSabah, said here tonight.

title: Ship Will Cover 6,000 Miles In Search for Oil Off Alaska
description: ABOARD S.S. SURVEYOR, off Alaska, June 20  The 292foot steamship Surveyor, sailing cautiously but purposefully alongside the pineforested islands and coastal reaches of the inland waterway hetween the state of Washington and Ketchikan, Alaska, flies the flags of the United States and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration,

title: California Jurist Says Politics Did Not Affect Ruling
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 25  Justice Mathew O. Tobriner testified today that he thought of the political consequences, but was not swayed by them, when he signed a court order last Nov. 3 that returned a convicted rapist to Jail.

title: Dispute Ended Between State And Coop City
description: An end of the fivemonth dispute between New York State and the tenants of Coop City was announced yesterday. The tenants of the Bronx housing complex agreed to turn over $10.3 million in mortgage payment and other funds that they had withheld in return for state approval of repairs now under way.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: INSTANT TRIP To relax at the bar or in a summery wicker chair in the lounge of the Chateau Bahia (753.2960) and hear the music by Ainotiry Tristio is to realize why many people deem Brazil's contemporary, folkooted ballads an art form.

title: Nuclear Weapons Lab Assailed By Audit and a: RadiatiCin Expert
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 25  The Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, one of the nation's two nuclear weapons development facilities, came under attack last week for alleged deficiencies in financial management and radiation safety.

title: Small Quake Jars Arkansas
description: GOLDEN, Colo., June 25 (AP)  A small earthquake rattled the Marked Tree area of northeastern Arkansas today, the United States Geological Survey reported. The survey's national earthquake information center placed the magnitude at 3.2 on the Richter scale.

title: Taxes
description: WASHINGTON AS S the Internal Revenue Service tells it, the United States Government loses at least $1 billion a year because of tax evasion by salesmen, truckers, insurance salesthen and a great variety of other independent contractors.

title: For TeenAge Scholars, The Energy Shortage Sparks the Imagination
description: It's a bit disorienting to, hear children speaking like physics professors, but how else could winners of the National Energy Foundation awards describe their, complex solutions to the enemy crisis?

title: Deliveries of Oil and Gas To Distributors Down 4%
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Energy Department reported today that total deliveries; of, gasoline And oil to distributOrs in the United States were down 4 percent in the last fourweek reporting period compared with the yearago level.

title: U.S. and Japan Dubious on Idea OF an Oil Freeze
description: TOKYO, June 25  7 President Carter and Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira met today to prepare for a seversnation economic summit conference, and American officials said they expressed serious reservations about a fiveyear freeze on oil import levels proposed by Western European nations.

title: Talks on Palestinian Rule Resume
description: HERZLIYA, Israel, June 25  Representatives of Egypt, Israel and the United States met here today in the third round of talks on selfrule for Arabs in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Spokesmen said they had made some progress toward an agenda for more substantive talks later.

title: Bridge:
description: Several clubs might think that they have the strongest team game in the metropolitan area, but one club knows: The Grand Baldwin Bridge Studio in Baldwin, L.I., which has a 10team roundrobin event organized by Marty Lasher and extending over six months.

title: 76 Corporate Tax Topped $49 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) Corporations in the United paid $49.4 billion in Federal income tax for 1976, according to a preliminary. Internal Revenue Service report released today.

title: Court Says Unwed Couples Vows Can Form Contract
description: TRENTON, June 25  The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that promises made between two people living together can constitute a legal and binding contract.

title: The City
description: A 15yearold girl walking with schoolmates on 88th Street near Lexington Avenue was struck on the head yesterday by a piece of granite facing that fell from the Gimbels East building, the police said.

title: S.E.C. Judge Bars 3 at Firm
description: A Securities and Exchange Commission judge has ordered three former officers of Stilwell, Coker & Company barred from association with any broker, dealer, investment adviser or investment company.

title: Steel Output Up for Week
description: Steel production rose to 2.8 million tons in the week ended June 23, an increase of threetenths of 1 percent from the previous week's total, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Berkey Stock Sags on Disappointment
description: The stock of Berkey Photo Inc. fell sharply under heavy selling pressure yesterday, reflecting investor disappointment over a court decision to reverse a major antitrust award from the Eastman Kodak Company.

title: N.B.A. Draft Is Less Fun Now
description: The National Basketball Association draft has evolved into a precise, orderly event. Where there were once representatives from eight teams in a single room, now 22 teams are connected by telephone. Yesterday, in another departure from tradition, there were about 1,000 experts offering loud opinions in a ballroom at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Pop: The Village People
description: POPULAR music is as much game for the entrepreneur as it is for the musician, and the field is full of manufactured acts that went on to attain some success  the Monkees being a particularly wellknown examnle. The latect and most flamboyant result of this process is the Village People, who did the first of two soldout shows at Madison Square Garden Sunday night.

title: Drivers Waiting in Line Given Advice on Idling
description: The Automobile Club of New York had advice yesterday for motorists who want to know whether to keep the engine running or shut it off during long, slow crawl toward a service station.

description: Preparatory Committee for the Conference on Science and Technology for Development  10:30 A.M.

title: Theater: Cinderella Goes To Discotheque to Dance
description: LIKE the boxes that give off a neutral hum for insomniacs to sleep by, disco's music and strobelight spectacle exist not to be heard or seen but to shut out. hearing and seeing; to provide a neutral region where the customers can dance their fantasies alone.

title: Trade Is Giving Atlanta International Status
description: ATLANTA, June 25  Atlanta, long regarded as an important but essentially provincial regional center, is taking on the characteristics of an international city as it draws business from banks, corporations and airlines abroad.

title: Philippe Halsman, Photographer Took Portraits of the Famous
description: Philippe Halsman, the internationally known photographer whose subjects ranged front Albert Einstein, Winston Churchill and John F. Kennedy to Ingrid Bergman, Elizabeth Taylor and Marilyn Monroe, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: TENTH ROUND

title: Ballet: A Danish Flavor
description: THE grandeur of Marius Petipa's choreography for the Russian czar in the 19th century was never August Bournovine's style. As Denmark's great gift to Romantic ballet in the same century, he opted for a cozier, but perhaps even more colorful view of life.

title: John Collyer, at 86; ExGoodrich Official Held Top U.S. Award
description: John Lyons Collyer, a prominent rubber company executive for four decades and a recipient of the nation's highest civilian award in 190 for his role in the development of synthetic rubber in World War II, died early Sunday at his home in Vero. Beach. Fla. He was 86 years old.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Children and All That Jazz

title: On Cook's Day Off, A Picnic for Chefs
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 24  Gather a group of chefs and culinary matters will invariably dominate the conversation. Unless, of course, it happens to be the weekend that everyone talked of nothing but gasoline. And how to get it.

title: Pump's Eye View of GasHungry Drivers
description: PASSAIC, N.J., June 25  Fill it up, Maroon Chevrolet said, smiling and handing over the keys to her gasoline tank lock.

title: It's Not the Hunters
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  A recent skirmish between hunters and antihunters in America has demonstrated once again that both sides seem to have lost sight of the most sinister threat to wildlife  destruction of habitat.

title: Energy Top Issue At Comecon Talks
description: MOSCOW, June 25 (UPI)  As the world's seven Western industrialized nations converged on Tokyo today, the Council of Mutual Economic Assistance, or Comecon, the Sovietled economic bloc, met in Moscow for its annual meeting.

title: INDIAN ARMY FIGHTS STRIKING POLICEMEN
description: NEW DELHI, June 25  At least 26 soldiers and paramilitary policemen were killed today as the Indian Army moved to disarm striking notice units.

title: Binger Voices Dissent On Admitting 2 to Bar
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)  In a rare public comment, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today dissented from his colleagues' admission of two lawyers to practice before the Supreme Court.

title: Congress Acts to Spur Synthetic Fuels
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  After two years of quarreling with the Carter Administration over energy, Congress appears to have tried to seize the initiative with a flurry of bills to nromote synthetic fuels.

title: Further Hearings Ordered in Suit By Scientologists for F.B.I. Data
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)  A Federal appeals court ordered further proceedings today in the Church of Scientology's suit to obtain all records that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has on the church and its founder, L. Ron Hubbard.

title: Zayre Will Operate 5 Grandway Stores
description: The Zayre Corporation, a major operator of discount department stores, announced that it had reached an agreement to assume the leases of five Grandway general merchandise. discount department stores operated by a division of the Grand Union Company of Elmwood Park, N.J.

title: U.S. Data Show Business Slump For the Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Commerce Department has circulated to handful of Cabinetrank officials a preliminary calculation that the nation's business activity declined in the last three months at an annual rate of 2.4 percent.

title: NASA Revises Predicted Date Of Skylab's Fall
description: THE latest prediction is that Skylab will fall earth between July 11 and July 21, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday. There is a 50 percent probability that the reentry will come before July16.

title: Federal Official Expects Weekend DC10 Verdict
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25  A Federal official said today there was hope that, by the end of the week, the Government would know if the green light could be given to allow the nation's grounded fleet of DC10 Jumbo lets to return to the air.

title: About Education
description: SANDRA STOCK was describing her experiences in the School of International Studies program at Hillcrest High School in Queens. We weren't just spitting out what the book said, she said, stressing what she sees as the contrast between S.I.S. and ordinary social studies curriculums.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: CREDIT MARKETS

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1979

title: The $87 Million. Award to Berkey Mostly Reversed
description: Most of an $87 million award that Berkey Photo Inc. had won from the Eastman Kodak Company was overturned by a Federal Appeals Court yesterday in a farreaching decision intended to clarify important antitrust regulations.

title: Newsmen Beat Council But the Victory Is Brief
description: After losing 13 to 9 to City Hall newsmen in their annual softball game yesterday, members of the City Council held an extraordinary session at the Dellwood Country Club in New City, N.Y., and voted unanimously to override the result.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Vows Political Action
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 25  Leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People vowed today to take a more activist role in national politics through a variety of moves, including the submission of planks at the Democratic and Republican national conventions next year.

title: Fear Haunting Haitian Aliens In New York
description: Yves Masson needed help. The depression that the illegal immigrant from Haiti had been experiencbig for several weeks would not leave him even on weekends, when he danced the meringue in a friend's basement apartment or sipped his Johnny Walker Black Label scotch.

title: Studies Relate Physical Causes To Delinquency
description: WHILE most behavioral scientists favor sociological or psychological explanations for juvenile violence, four researchers at Yale University have found evidence suggesting that some such cases actually have biological underpinnings.

title: Japan Economic Growth
description: TOKYO, June 25 (AP)  The effects of crude oil price increases will slow Japan's real economic growth to 5.9 percent in the 1979 fiscal year, a private economic research group said today. The projection by the Japan Economic Research Center falls short of the 6.3 percent goal that the Japanese Government has set for the fiscal year ending next March.

title: Notes From the GasLine
description: A woodburning still to produce motor fuel for 43 cents a gallon, an electric car, an everready supply of cold drinks by vendors and a psychiatrist's advice for quick relief of gasline stress were all offered yesterday for the encouragement of harassed motorists as specialists of all kinds focussed on alleviating, if not solving, the gasoline crisis.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, Towson, Md., a maker of portable electric tools, has appointed John F. Gallagher to the new position of vice president and controller.

title: High Court Holds Jobless Mother Equal to Father on Welfare Right
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Supreme Court ruled today that in states where the Government pays welfare benefits to families in which the father is unemployed it must pay the same benefits to families left equally needy by the mother's loss of her job.

title: Shelley R. Patterson Dies at 77; Helped Found Town Hall of Air
description: Shelley Rodes Patterson, a cofounder in the 1930's of the popular radio forum, Town Hall of the Air, died Saturday night at Hightstown, N.J. She was 77 years old.

title: Choral: King Glee Club
description: THE senior members of the Martin Luther King Male Glee Club of New York City gathered in Alice Tully Hall Sunday night for a concert under the direction of Dr. Alphonso J. Patterson. Founded in 1969 by Dr. Patterson, the chorus is communitybased organization that regularly tours this country and Europe singing a repertory drawing on the full range of choral literature from medieval times to the present.

title: Ruling Put Off In OPEC Case
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25  Judge Andrew A. Hauk of the United States District Court today deferred until Aug. 20 a decision on the politically explosive antitrust suit brought by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers union against the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: President Carter has made the $30 billion decision to build the new MX strategic nuclear missile. The exact basing mode has yet to be decided, with three deployment possibilities currently under consideration: multihole (trucks), airborne (widebodied aircraft) and trenches (railroad cars).

title: Rangers Fight for Nykoluk
description: The Rangers asked Mike Nykoluk yesterday to succeed Fred Shero as coach in 1980 after Nykoluk told them he had received a mindboggling offer to coach the Toronto Maple Leafs for five years.

title: House Group Seeks Controls
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)  A group of 20 House Democrats called today for legislation giving President Carter authority to impose mandatory wage price controls.

title: Sandinists in South Are Stalled but Still High Spirited
description: PENAS BLANCAS, Nicaragua, June 25  Although you could not tell from the high spirits of the Sandinist guerrillas controlling this border town, the rebels have clearly stalled here in what they had hoped would be a rapid march to meet their comrades descending on the capital city of Managua from the north.

title: JAZZ EVENTS
description: Following is a schedule of today's Newport Jazz FestivalNew York events:

title: Events Today
description: THE IMPOSSIBLE H.L. MENCK EN (American Humorists Series) adapted by John Rothman; cli retied by Scott Redman; Presented by the American Place Theater, Wynn Handman, director: Julia Mlles, associate director, 111 West 46th Street, I. GERTRUDE STEIN, GERTRUDE STEIN, GER. TRUDE STEIN, by Marty Martin, directred by Milton Moss. Starring Pat Carroll, the Circle Repertory Theater, 99 Seventh Avenue South, 8.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, June 24 SAGAFJORD (tlarweglan Americal Line). Lett Bermuda June 20; due at 8 A.M. at West 55th Street.

title: Spain Awaits Guernica With Uneasy Emotions
description: MADRID, June 25  News that Picasso's Guemica may soon be transported to the Prado from New York was greeted today with a mixture of consternation, gratitude and embarrassment in official circles.

title: Trial Judge Allows Investigation On Surrogate Election to Proceed
description: A trial judge has ruled that Manhattan Surrogate Marie M. Lambert cannot block a confidential investigation into how funds were raised for her 1977 campaign.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Gold at Peak in London; Dollar Drops in Value

title: Mets Win, 40, After 81 Defeat
description: It was a fine night for Brooklynborn Pete Falcone of the Meth and New Yorkborn John Candelaria of the Pittsburgh Pirates. Falcone won his first game of the season, yielding only five singles while beating Pittsburgh, 40, to give the Nets a split of the doubleheader last night at Shea Stadium.

title: The Greatest Show on Earth
description: Whateveielse he may be, George Steinbrenner deserves recognition as baseball's foremost promotional genius. Only a man of P.T. Barnum's vision could have hit the kind of box, office home run Steinbrenner hit. when he replaced Bob Lemon with Billy Martin as manager of the Yankees.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The reasons for the A.D.A.'s disaffection from the Democratic Party's leader are not hard to find. The liberals say he is not a winner. They say he is too small a man, who can't proviae leadership in a time of crisis. He isn't even a liberal, in their view. Those around him aren't either, and are of no more stature than he is.

title: Head of OPEC Warns Radicals
description: GENEVA, June 25 (AP)  The president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that the cartel's moderate members might raise oil production in order to keep more radical members in line on increasing prices.

title: OBSERVER Hard Rain And Soft Soap
description: Although NASA assures us there is nothing to worry about when its 77ton space station comes down in a rain of metal next month, it is prepared for every contingency.

title: Business Records
description: MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1979

title: Mystery of Bering Sea Solved
description: Ajoint scientific expedition by the United States and Soviet Union has solved the mystery of why the Bering Sea  the forbidding, cold ana stormy bony or salt water separating the two nations  produces fish in greater abundance than almost any other oceanic body.

title: Plane Safe Despite Faulty Wheel
description: BOSTON, June 25 (UPI)  An Air New England plane carrying 50 persons had problems with its nose wheel on a flight from Cape Cod to Boston today, but landed safely at Logan International Airport. Sargent Shriver, former head of the PeaceCorps and onetime Presidential candidate, was aboard, flying to Washington after a weekend at the seaside home of Senator Edward M. Kennedy in Hyannis.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: RubberPact Talks Begin
description: GENEVA, June 25 (Reuters) Fortynine nations began three weeks of talks today aimed at completing the world's first agreement to stabilize rubber prices. The group, convened by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, had agreed on most parts of the proposed accord when they met last April. Issues still unresolved include a voting system to be used under the new agreement and the site of a proposed International Rubber Council to administer it.

title: Truckers Easing Strike in Places; Others Push On
description: Some independent truckers said yesterday that they would expand the strike that has curtailed the shipping of food and fuel, but it appeared to be sputtering in places.

title: Archdiocese and a Medical College at Odds
description: At least two members of/the board of trustees of New York Medical College have resigned in protest and several ohers are considering similar resignalions in a dispute with the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: Former Gov. J. Millard Tawes, 85
description: J. Millard Tawes, a former Governor of Maryland, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack in his home at Crisfield, Md. He was 85 years old.

title: Dtente With Vietnam?
description: WASHINGTON  There seems to be no end to the cruelty that governments can inflict on the people of Southeast Asia.

title: Japan's Press Buzzing a Soviet Carrier
description: TOKYO, June 25  Far away in the water off Taiwan a new Soviet aircraft carrier, the 43,000ton Minsk, and an escort flotilla of two guidedmissile cruisers and a tanklanding ship are steaming north toward Japan at about 12 knots.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 26, 1979Moscow warned Washington on arms, saying that if the Senate rejected or amended the treaty signed in Vienna last week, it would mean the end of negotiations. Foreign Minister Gromyko said that the pact was of exceptional importance, satisfied equally the interests of both countries and could lead to further limitation and even reduction of strategic nuclear weapons. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Proxmire Balks At Fed Choice
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reuters) William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said today that he would oppose the nomination of Frederick Schultz to the Federal Re. serve Board because of his political ties to President Carter.

title: Soviet Is Said to Develop 3 New Types of Bombers
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Soviet officials have said that Moscow is developing three new types of heavy bombers, according to American officials. The development plans were said to have been disclosed during talks leading to the new arms limitation treaty.

title: Rioting Follows Protests by Truckers in Levittown, Pa.
description: LEVITTOWN, Pa., June 25  The Board of Commissioners of Bristol Township declared a state of emergency today following two nights of rioting by 2,000 residents who had joined a protest by truck drivers.

title: Westinghouse Uranium Pact
description: PITTSBURGH, June 25 (UPI) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that it had reached final agreement with the Swedish State Power Board on a uranium supply lawsuit in Stockholm at an estimated pretax cost to Westinghouse of $85 million.

title: Yanks Lose
description: TORONTO, June 25  Billy Martin completed the first week of his second coming as Yankee manager tonight in the unusual position of apparently being an unwitting pawn in the Yankees newest feud  a battle of wits between George Steinbrenner and Rends Jackson.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: APPENDICITIS pain in the right side of the lower abdomen is a condition familiar to most people, even if they have not wellenced it. since it is so common.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of grain and soybeans futures broke sharply yesterday as local Chicago traders accurately spotted closely spaced stoploss orders placed by buyers during last week's strong advances.

title: Detroit Edison Faces Nuclear Plant Delay
description: The Detroit Edison Company said that completion of a nuclear plant, called the Fermi unit, would be delayed until 1982. Two other units will be delayed 18 months or so until 1990 and 1992. the comnanv said.

title: Study for Congress Challenges White House Trade Pact View
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Optimistic assertions by the Carter Administration about what new trade liberalization will achieve for the United States are challenged by a Congressional study that points to far more modest gains but says the benefits will be unevenly distributed.

title: Advertising
description: KELSO SUTTON was a 15yearold lad up in Maine when Sports Illustrated was started by Time Inc. Now, after 18 years on the fast track at the publishing company, he is its publisher. He's 40; the magazine is 25, and celebrating.

title: Gerulaitis and Ashe Upset at Wirnbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 Wimbledon, the revered mecca of an anachronism  tennis on grass courts  opened its 102d year today with a timemellowed style that was scarcely affected by its daily ration of rain.

title: About New York
description: The lady tourist's white hair was backlighted beautifully by the Manhattan sun, and she was told so and said, Why, thank you.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Supreme Court ruled today that evidence taken from a suspect during a presumably legal arrest can be admitted at the trial even if the law under which the arrest was made is in the meantime declared unconstitutional.

title: GROMYKO WARNS U.S. ANY CHANGES DOOM NUCLEAR ARMS PACT
description: HAILS CARTERBREZHNEV TALKMOSCOW, Sum 25  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko warned the United States Senate today that rejection, or even amendment, of the strategic arms limitation treaty signed in Vienna a week ago would mean the end of negotiations. That would be a fantastic situation. he said.

title: Around the Nation
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 25 (AP) A Federal judge granted a stay of execution today for Robert A. Sullivan, but the Florida Supreme Court rejected an appeal to keep another convicted slayer, Charles W. Proffitt, from being executed on Wednesday.

title: West German Insurer Buying 2d U.S. Concern
description: In its second major American takeover in less than two months, Allianz Versicherungs A.G., a leading West German insurance company, agreed yesterday to buy the Fidelity Union Life Insurance Company of Dallas for $72.50 a share, or about $370 million.

title: ExLaw Student on Trial in Deaths of Florida Students
description: MIAMI, June 25  Jury selection began today in the murder trial of Theodore Bundy, the former Seattle law student implicated by the police in a series of brutal slayings of young women from coast to coast.

title: Associated Press
description: FILING FOR UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION IN HOLLYWOOD: Twoyearold Elizabeth Alexandra King sitting on counter with her mother, Judith, as a clerk filled out appropriate forms. Elizabeth has been out of work for eight months, following the completion of three television commercials for which she was paid $3,000. But she was denied state benefits because, of ficialh said, she had not worked tie minimum number of days required.

title: Experts Speculate About Possible Life on Other Worlds
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. THE present level of human intelligence might have been reached 60 million years ago if the rapid evolution of nervous systems in the early development of life had continued, according to a report presented here last week at a meeting on the possibility that superior civilizations exist in other worlds.

title: Newport Jazz Black Broadway Salute With 3 Original Artists
description: PERFORMERS, songwriters and landmark events of the black musical theater were celebrated at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday in an evening that sparkled with the excitment of discovery, legends brought to life and reminders of a great heritage The occasion was Black Broadway, 19001995, produced by Bobby Short and Robert Kimball as part of the Newport Jazz Festival, one of the most successful events in the festival's 26 ear history.

title: U.S. Deficit Wider in May
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The United States Government spent $3.3 billion more in May than it collected in tax revenues, according to a statement from the Treasury. today.

title: The Odd View From the Court
description: The Supreme Court's decisions reflect not only the world of law but also, inevitably, the justices understanding of the society around them. But do the justices really live among the rest of us?

title: Engineers, in 1976, Sought Scrapping of Subway Trucks
description: Environmental engineers of the New York City Transit Authority recommended more than two years ago that the undercarriages of new subway cars be replaced because they produced noise and vibration levels 10 times greater than other subway cars.

title: Benny Goodman Swings With Octet
description: BNENNY GOODMAN'S Newport Festival concert at Carnegie Halls on Sunday night wasn't ..the; tort of affair that sends one reeling ont.into.the night in a state of ecstasy: But it did leave a warm glow, andin its Own, lowkey way it suggested some of the leasons Mr. Goodman has been so durable.

title: Syria Opens Drive on Moslem Militants
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 25  The Syrian Government has begun cracking down on rightwing Islamic groups accused of provoking sectarian strife with the aim of bringing down the country's socialist regime.

title: Market Place
description: THE key to the battle for the Florida Mining and Materials Corporation, according to analysts, is the oncetroubled, nowprofitable cement plant that the company operates in the Sunshine State.

title: CAREY DECREES USE OF RESERVES TO AID GAS FLOW THIS WEEK
description: JULY'S SUPPLY WILL BE TAPPED Governor Cites Critical Situation Motorists Said to Switch to MassTransit Lines Governor Carey said last night that he planned to use part of the state's emergency gasoline supply for July this Week because of what he characterized as an increasingly critical shortage, particularly in the New York City area.

title: Iran Executes 3 and Flogs 5
description: TEHERAN, Iran June 25 (Reuters) Three Iranians were executed today for rape, sodomy and highway robbery in a gang, the press here reported, and five men were sentenced to be flogged. A court in Meshed jailed eight members of the gang to terms up to 10 years. Two men were condemned to 200 lashes each and another to 100 lashes. In the town of Kazvin, west of here, two men were given 350 lashes each for seduction of a young woman.

title: Chinese Chemical Plant
description: PEKING, June 25 (UPI)  China's largest petrochemical plant, equipped with computercontrolled Japanese and West German machinery, went into full operation today, the New China News Aeenev said. The Shanghai PetroChemical Works is designed to produce 102,000 tons of synthetic fibers and 60,000 tons of highpressure polyethylene resin annually, according to the official press agency. More than 100,000 tons of synthetic fibers have been produced since the plant went into partial operation in July 1976.

title: Israelis Shell Lebanese After Palestinian Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 25  Israeli artillery pounded southern Lebanese towns today after Palestinian guerrillas fired rockets into a settlement in northern Israel.

title: Remains of 41 Beached Whales Buried in Sand Dunes in Oregon
description: FLORENCE, Ore.,June 25 (UPI) The remains of 41 sperm whales that beached themselves more than a week ago and died of unknown causes were burled yesterday in sand dunes.

title: U.S. Suit Accuses Mobil Of Overcharging on Gas
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)  The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission said today that it had filed a lawsuit accusing the Mobil Oil Corporation, the Mobil Corporation's principal subsidiary. of selling some Texas natural gas at prices higher than the legal maximum. The suit, filed Friday in Federal District Court, is the first brought under the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978.

title: TV: Prime Time Sunday Arrives
description: WITH a considerable flourish of publicity, Prime Time Sunday has moved the news special into the studio control room, precisely where it was in 1952 when Edward R. Murrow started See It Wow. So much for innovation and suspiciously bright ideas.

title: Lessing Rosenwald, Sears Head And Collector of Art, Dead at 88
description: Lessing J. Rosenwald, former chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Company, who gave the United States Government collections of prints, drawings and books now worth more than $35 million, died of a bronchial infection yesterday. Mr. Rosenwald, who was 88 years old, died at Alverthorpe, his estate at Jenkintown, 10 miles north of Philadelphia.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in Business Day last Wednesday a figure described as the 1978 sales volume of Lees Carpets, division of Burlington Industries was incorrect. The figure given, $340 million, was actually for all divisions of Burlington's carpet manufacturing group, including Lees. The figure for Lees alone was not available. In addition it was incorrectly reported that Lees plans to phase out its contract carpeting production for commercial and business accounts.

title: Lake George: Few Customers, Lots of Gas
description: LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., June 25 Webster Coon, the manager of Marine Village, a 70room motel on the lip of this 32milelong lake, dug down behind his counter and fished out a cony of Saturday's PostStar, the newspaper published in Glens Falls, N.Y. Running an index finger from right to left across the front page, he stopped at the top of column one and gave the leading paragraph a mighty thump.

title: Murray Schnee, Winner Of Many Titles in Bridge
description: One of New York's bestknown contract bridge players, Lieut. Col. Murray Schnee, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home, 25104 60th Avenue, Little Neck, Oueens, He was 65 years old.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Atlantic Steel Company said yesterday that its directors, who control less than 20 percent of the company's stock, would support an offer of $40 a share, or nearly $52 million, from Ivaco Ltd., a Canadian steel producer.

title: M. Thatcher Confers With Top Labor Chief
description: LONDON, June 25  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher held her first meeting with leaders of Britain's trade unions today at 10 Downing Street.

title: West Quits Post As Laker Coach
description: When Jerry Buss purchased the Los Angeles Lakens from Jack Kent Cooke earlier this month, it was rumored that Jerry West. would not, return to coach his fourth season.Yesterday. in New Writ for the National Basketball Association college draft, Buss made it official and announced that West was tired of coaching and had resigned.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What makes the stomach growl?

title: Many in IranSeek the Revival of an Effective Army
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 25  Nowadays, the colonel answers the door himself, runs for the telephone when it rings because nobody else will pick it up and depends on his own revolver instead of a 24hour armed guard.

title: NEW RIGHT CAUSES PRESSED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Twice in recent months Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, has taken the floor to denounce a group called the Steering Committee. In unusually harsh tones, Mr. Byrd has described the committee as shadowy, mysterious and arcane.

title: Sonny Rollins, as Ever
description: SONNY ROLLINS'S saxophone playing defies criticism. He has mastered the instrument so thoroughly, and he plays it with such eloquence, that one would be hard pressed to ask for anything more. if Mr. Rollins had also mastered the art of bandleading and was sure of how he relates to the newer directions in jazz, one could write nothing about his performances but strings of superlatives.

title: Pump Station Failure Lets Sewage Inundate North Jersey Reservoir
description: BLAUVELT, N.Y., June 25  At least 16 million gallons of raw sewage have spilled since Friday morning from disabled pumping station here into the Hackensack River about a mite above Lake Tappan, one of three major reservoirs providing drinking water to 800,000 people in 60 towns in northern New Jersey.

title: Iran Takes Over Insurers
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 25  The Iranian Government announced the nationalization of private insurance companies today.

title: Dollar Drops on OilPrice Fears
description: LONDON, June 25  The dollar is under pressure again on the currency markets, reflecting a new set of anxieties over the impact of rising oil prices on the world economic order.

title: 3Month Bills Drop to 8.802%
description: The average rate on threemonth Treasury bills dropped yesterday to 8.802 percent, the lowest since last November, but the rate on sixmonth bills rose to 8.903 percent, a slight increase from last week.

title: Savings Level Posts Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) Savings deposits at the nation's thrift institutions grew $1.6 billion in May, a sharp recovery from the $1.5 billion savings outflow of the previous month, Kenneth Biederman, chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: CONSIDER the turtle, urged Henry David Thoreau in journal entry dated Aug. 28, 1856, and then proceeded to do so. Perchance you have worried, despaired of the world, meditated the end of life, and all things seem rushing to destruction; but nature has steadily and serenely advanced with the turtle's pace  while [the turtle] rests warily on the edge of its hole, rash schemes are undertaken by men and fail. French empires rise or fall, but the turtle has developed only so fast.  One turtle knows several Napoleons.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS Of DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKE 33900; WESTCHESTER CO, AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 05300; NASSAU CO. 16) 7410500 SUFFOLK CO, (516)6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3484761.

title: Desk Officers Going From Seat to Feet for Summer
description: Several hundred ablebodied New York City police officers holding desk jobs in headquarters units will be temporarily transferred to field duties in a move to maintain minimum patrol strength during the summer.

title: Beaths
description: ALPRINMorris O.Beloved father of Glory Letter and Walter Alrin. Dear brother of Belle Kamen. Devoted grandfather of Gordon, Douglas, Elizabeth, Claudia, and Jessica, Service Tuesday, 11:45AM at The Riverside 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contribUtions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Northeast Assured On Oil for. Homes
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The Government will take drastic steps  including possible new curbs on gasoline and diesel fuel if needed to guarantee enough home heating oil this winter, Deputy Energy Secretary John F. O'Leary told ennaress today.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Serious reservations about a fiveyear oilImport freeze are being expressed by the United States and Japan, American officials said. These doubts about last week's Western European proposal emerged from the opening round of talks between President Carter and Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira. The two leaders are said to be likely to propose that the industrial countries reaffirm their commitment to a 5 percent reduction in oil imports this year and set a more ambitious goal for 1980. [Page A1.]

title: Chile Bans an Opposition Magazine
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 25  A news magazine here critical of the Chilean refusal to extradite three officers to the United States to stand trial on murder charges has been banned for two months by military decree.

title: EDUCATION Boyer Reviews Term in Office
description: ON Saturday, Ernest L. Boyer will step down as the United States Commissioner of Education. Since April 1, 1977, Mr. Boyer, the former Chancellor of the State University of New York, has been the principal educational snokesman for the Carter Administration and the chief administrator of the Office of Education's 312 billion budget, which covers areas ranging from compensatory reading programs to Indian education.

title: MidJune Auto Sales Off 26.2% From a Year Ago
description: DETROIT, June 25 (AP)  Fuelconscious Americans are showing a preference for smaller cars, although overall sales of new cars iii midJune were 26.2 percent below the record level of a year earlier, the nation's auto makers reported today.

title: 200 Convene to Study FundRaising for Arts
description: With speeches by Livingston L. Biddle Jr., head of the National Endowment for the Arts, and others to lead off and a series of workshops to follow, 200 persons gathered yesterday at the Sheraton Center to start a twoday conference on the very practical matter of Raisino Money for the Arts. They came from 30 states and Canada and represented performingarts groups, state and more local arts councils, legislative committees, community groups, small presses and universities..

title: Mr. Carter Flirts With the Sun
description: While visiting the White House between foreign journeys last week, President Carter proposed that the nation turn to the sun for 20 percent of its energy by the year 2000. Although this ambitious commitment can oner no solace to people on gas lines, it would be a significant part of the now developing effort to break the country's dependence on imported oil. The program serious but by no means sure of attaining its goal.

title: Knicks Select Cartwright First In Draft and Nets Choose Natt
description: Last year the Knicks were a team with no centers. Now_thay'are a team with too many.

title: Gen. Haig Unhurt as Car Is Target Of Bomb on Road to NATO Office
description: CASTEAU, Belgium, June 25  Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the commander of North Atlantic Treaty forces, survived an assassination attempt on his way to work this morning when a bomb explOded near his car, lifting it into the air and gouging a fivefootdeep hole in the pavement.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Four senior executives of Korvettes were given termination notices yesterday by the new owner of the 50store retail chain, the AgacheWillot Group of France. Among them was Philip Kaplan, executive vice president and chief financial officer, who was promoted from senior vice president just last April when the French company assumed control. Mr. Kaplan, 48 years old, joined Korvettes in 1968 when the chain was acquired by Spartan Industries. Before that, he was controller of the Spartan departmentstore division* of Spartan Industries.

title: North Country Diary
description: Big blue clouds, then mare's tails in the sky, the brook in perpetual motion. It's haying week in the north country, and a mowing machine decades old seems to do as good a job as anything newer. Afterward the cows are let into the stubble, where deer join diem in the evening, protesting like a trumpet sneezing if the farmer interrupts. The deer have turned from wintergray to summerred, arid woodchucks that were thin as rats in April have fattened magisterially.

title: McLean and Straub Tie For Westchester Golf Lead
description: SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 25 Jim McLean, the assistant pro at the Westchester Country Club, and. Austin Straub, the 1978 Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association champion, posted 68's in the first round of the Westchester open golf tournament today to share the lead in the $10,000 event.

title: Art and Nature in Porcelain Jewelry Designs
description: Mention porcelain and names like Meissen, Sevres and Limoges come to mind, names associated with dinner services and objets d'art. Porcelain, however, is also a fine material for jewelry, as is evident in the show at the Kruger Gallery through June 30, displaying porcelain pieces from 10 different artists and studios.

title: Rules on Purchasing Gasoline
description: Following is a summary or regulations governing the purchase and sale of gasoline in the New York City area and in New Jersey and Connecticut. The rules apply to diesel fuel in New Jersey and Connecticut, but not in New York.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: Associated Press

title: HandsOff Intervention in Nicaragua
description: The State Department now professes satisfaction with the resolution of the Organization of American States that calls for the immediate replacement of General Somoza's Government in Nicaragua. That is a tar cry, however, from secretary of state Vance's proposal last week for the dispatch of an interAmerican peacekeeping force, which the other nations of the hemisphere overwhelmingly opposed. Whatever prompted the change of heart, it was appropriate. The United States is better served by that toothless resolution than it would have been by an intervention force.

title: Researchers Race to Find Particle Vital to Atom Theory
description: BATAVIA, Ill. HOBBLED by chronic money shortages, scientists at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory here Are in a race against a wealthy European scientific consortium to find a hypothetical but vitally imoortant nuclear uarticle called the W.

title: The Region
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn.  The uncle of a slain medical student at Columbia University testified yesterday that another medical student on trial for the murder appeared to be drunk or on drugs the morning the victim's body was found last July 30.

title: Senate Votes Funds for More Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Senate gave overwhelming approval today to legislation that would enable the United States to admit 1,000 additional Indochinese refugees a month, raising the allowable total to 8.000.

title: Notes on People
description: Julian Beck and Judith Malina Are Back in the States It is four years since Julian Beck and Judith Malina were last in the United States, so in certain circles a reading that they will give tonight at Columbia University's International Affairs Auditorium is something of an event.

title: Nets Choices
description: 1Calvin Natt, forward. 2Cliff Robinson, forward. 3John Gerdy, guard. 4Joe Abramaitis, forward. 5Tony Smith, guard. 6Jim Strickland, center. 7Henry Hollingsworth, guard. 8Ricky Free, guard. 9Eric Fleisher, guard.

title: SOMOZA UNITS BOMB REBELS IN MANAGUA
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 25 With both sides seemingly resigned to prolongation of the Nicaraguan civil war, the guerrillas today resisted a Governpent offensive in the eastern part of this capital in the hope of winning time for an advance in other areas.

title: World News Briefs
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, June 25 (Reuters)  Renewed demonstrations in support of former President Yusufu K. Lule flared around Kampala today, with protesters setting up roadblocks and stoning vehicles in an attempt to stop workers and food from getting to the capital.

title: High Court Clarifies Racing Ban
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Supreme Court, in a case involving a New York harnessracing trainer, ruled today that, the Constitution does not require a state to hold a hearing before suspending a trainer's license once a postrace urinalysis has turned up evidence of drugs.

title: Defense Rests in Murder Trial
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 25 (AP)  The defense rested its case today without offering any witnesses or evidence after the Jury heard Elmer Wayne Henley's confessions to homosexual torture and mass murder. He is being tried in the deaths of six youths thought to be among 26 victims.

title: Bridge:
description: Schnee Is Hailed as Player And as Teacher of Novices

title: Screen: El Super,
description: FOR the last 10 of his 42 years, Roberto, a former bus driver in Havana, has been living in New York exile with his wife, AureHa, and their 17-year-old daughter, Aurelita. Roberto not only suffers the

title: Nicaragua Crisis: Was the U.S. Off Guard?
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 26  As the latest Sandinist offensive in Nicaragua approached, it was repeatedly announced by the guerrillas and denounced by the Somoza regime. When it began late last month, it almost seemed that the two News Analysis sides were following a script. Yet the Carter Administration appeared to be caught off guard.

title: On the Beach
description: It was upsetting but hardly shocking to learn that World War II rocket was found nestled in the sand Jones Beach last Sunday. All the best stretches of seacoast yield such treasures: a poisonous jellyfish, still quivering; an old ocean liner's deckchair that snaps shut like a mousetrap when some blithe beachcomber tries to sit in it; an indecipherable letter in a bottle Madeira dregs. The air-to-ground antitank rocket had an inert warhead, thank you, but still had enough of its propellant left to send it flying. A real toetickler mysterious, evocative and hairraising.

title: The Editorial Notebook The Real Price of Oil
description: It's the Next Barrel That Counts  and It Now Costs $100

title: Faster justice Well Delayed
description: Justice delayed is justice denied. But the cause of speedier justice calls for delaying the full execution the Speedy Trial Act for another two years. The Senate has decided to give the Federal courts until July 1, 1981, before requiring dismissal of criminal cases that are not brought to trial within 100 days after arrest. The reason for postponement is that the judicial machinery needs renair before it can function at that sneed.

title: Wine Talk
description: Frank J. Prial

title: COMMODITIES
description: Volatile price movements marked trading in Chicago grain and soybean futures yesterday, despite the absence of any significant developments in the trade.

title: Nykoluk Is Named Ranger CoCoach
description: Mike Nykolulewill coach the Rangers next season for some games, maybe as many, as half; maybe less, he disclosed yesterday in explaining why he turned down a lucrative offer to coach the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Notes From the Gas Line
description: On New York's East Side, Jaguars. Cadillac limousines and Lincoln Continentals snaked around First Avenue, from 61st Street to 53d. Many of the shiny black cars bore diplomatic plates, but the .limousines and luxury cars waited their turn with the Volkswagens and Chevrolets and the delivery trucks carrying potato chips, poultry, flowers and laundry.

title: Truckers Stall RushHour Traffic On the Long Island Expressway
description: COMMACK, L.I., June 26  Traffic on the Long Island Expressway was snarled for 30 miles during the morning rush hour today as more than 100 truckers drove their vehicles slowly in convoy to draw attention to.their problems, primarily the short supply of diesel fuel and its rising price.

title: TaxExempt Bonds Gain
description: Prices of taxexempt bonds rose yesterday  but not so strongly as those of other sectors of the credit markets  as a moderately large volume of new issues was offered for sale and dealers continued to advertise more than $1 billion of recently marketed bonds.

title: Hefty Pay Raises Proposed For Mavor, Other Officials
description: Pay rises of $20,000 for Mayor Koch and $10,000 for the City Council President, the Comptroller, the five Borough Presidents and each of the 43 members of the City Council were recommended yesterday by a special commission. The panel said the raises were not only justified but long overdue.

title: Miss Navratilova Triumphs at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 26Martina Navratilova, the defending chaMpion in the Wimbledon women's singles, gave her mother an emotional welcome-to-England gift today by winning her firstround match in the 1979 championships.

title: Personal Health
description: Jane E. Brody

title: High Court Ruling Hints Merger Laws
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The Supreme Court, ruling that a constitutional challenge to a state takeover law had been brought in the wrong court, today reversed a decision that had found the IRw unconstitutional.

title: Newport Jazz
description: M so hungry I feel like I'm broken in two, Hoagy Carmichael said to his wife and a luncheon guest at the Oak Room of the Plaza Hotel. Let's order.

title: Canadian Pacific Unit Plans Offering
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd., a Canadian railroad and hotel system, said that its 82 percent owned subsidary, Canadian Pacific Investments Ltd., plans a public offering of five million of its common shares beginning July 30.

title: Khomeini Is Reported to Put Ban On Consumption of Drugs in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 26 (Reuters)  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the revolutionary leader, today banned the use of drugs, the press agency Pars said. The state radio later said the ban would apply only to nonaddicts.

title: New Chamber Series
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will add a subscription series of seven concerts to its regular schedule next season. The new series will been Monday nights at 7:30 and will repeat. the programs being given the day. before (Sundays at 5) and the day after (Tuesdays at 7:30). A different set of programs will be presented, as before, on Fridays at 8 and on Sundays at 5.
