description: M ONTE CARLO, MONACO

title: The Region
description: U.S. Inquiry Asked On Suffolk Police

title: Shopping Nationwide Hurt by Gas Shortage
description: The gasoline shortage has begun to have a serious impact on sales in the nation's stores and supermarkets, particularly in suburbs and outlying areas, according to retailers across the country.

title: Congress Impasse on Aid to Turks Creates Arms Verification Problem
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  A Congressional impasse over military aid to Turkey has emerged as a serious obstacle to efforts by the Carter Administration to gain Turkish cooperation in verifying the new treaty with the Soviet Union limiting nuclear weapons, White House and State Department officials said today.

title: Yanks Trounce Blue Jays
description: Lis Tiant gained his third straight victory last night as the Yankees routed the Blue Jays, 112, scoring five runs in the first inning in Toronto. Page A26.

title: Draft Picks Analyzed By Werblin
description: Sonny Werblin sat in his 18thfloor office in Madison Square Garden yesterday and thought of what might have been.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, June 18, to Sunday, June, 24), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielson Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States fvuseholds with television sets.

title: Cities May Get More to Protect Foreign Aides
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)  The Treasury Department plans to change its rules so that cities such as New York can get more reimbursement for the cost of protecting visiting foreign dignitaries, according to docuhents released today.

title: Chess:
description: For Fast, Fast, Fast Relief, Try a WellExecuted Trap

title: Fitzsimmons Assails Bid to Cut Truck Regulations
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)  The head of the teamsters' union registered strong opposition today to the Administration's plan to reduce the regulations in the trucking industry as the Senate Commerce Committee opened hearings on the proposal.

title: PBS Member Stations Vote ThreeNetwork Plan
description: Officials of the 270 member stations of the Public Broadcasting Service, meeting in Los Angeles this week, have voted overwhelmingly to reorganize PBS by Jan. 1 and change it from trade association that distributes programming to the system's national program organization  in effect, its network.

title: First Appirent Success Reported In Treatment for a Form of V.D.
description: The first apparently successful drug treatment for a widespread form of venereal disease has been reported by two University of Pennsylvania researchers in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: SENATE TELLS N.E.W. TO SPEND 80 FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI)  The Senate told the Department of Health, Education and Welfare today to dip into next year's funds and not cut payments to states for welfare and medical care for the poor as planned.

title: Jackson Is Host to Ballet
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 26  A banner stretches across State and Pearl Streets proclaiming International Ballet Competition, Jackson, Miss. A flame burns high in an Olympicstyle brazier in front of Jackson's new Municipal Auditorium, and the studios and classrooms are bursting with young dancers. Dance teachers talk about their students, competition buffs about their favorite dancers, and JacLionites line up each morning to buy tickets to events. Varna, Bulgaria, has one. So do Moscow, Tokyo and Lausanne. And now the ballet competition is America's latest sport.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Bomb Attempt on Gen. Haig's Life Not Tied to Major Terrorist Groups
description: CASTEAU, Belgium, June 26  American officials at North Atlantic Treaty headquarters here said today that the bomb attack on Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the supreme commander,  did not bear the readily identifiable signature of any of the major terrorist groups, and that the investigation of the incident would be long and difficult.

title: H.E. W. Is Urged to Study Problem Over a Herbicide Used in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The politically sensitive Agent Orange mystery continued to ricochet around the Government today, with everybody agreeing that the mystery should be solved but with no consensus as to who should solve it, how or when.

title: All Sincerely Retires . . . but Don't Bet on
description: Associated Prose

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: U.S. Agrees With Japan On Oil Plan
description: TOKYO, June 26  Japan and the United States have agreed to fix specific oil import levels for 1979 and 1980, American officials said today. President Carter and Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira completed a twoday meeting in preparation for an economic summit conference involving seven nations here Thursday and Friday.

title: U.S. Official SaysSomoza's Ouster Would Not Lead to a Second Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The State Department's topranking officer for Latin America expressed confidence today that the removal of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle would not transform Nicaragua into a second Cuba ruled by a Marxist dictatorship.

title: Citicorp Note Rate Down
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of 91day notes yesterday at an average rate of 9.838 percent, down from 9.907 percent last week and the lowest rate since April 24. Bids accepted ranged from 9.825 to 9.849 percent, with 82 percent of. those at the high accepted. The bank holding company received $861.25 million in bids.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel company, announced yesterday a series of management changes in engineering and research. The realignment, will apparently bring those functions more directly under the control of William P. Roesch, U.S. Steel's new president.

title: Brooklyn Pig and Litter of Four Evicted
description: Amid much squealing and shoving, five pigs were removed from the backyard of a Brooklyn house yesterday by A.S.P.C.A officers armed with a search warrant. The owner of the house had apparently ignored a city Health Department directive ordering her to move the pigs  a sow and litter of four-outside city limits.

title: Prime Time
description: NBCTV's new newsmagazine series, Prime Time Sunday, with Tom Snyder as host, made an auspicious debut in the national A.C. Nielsen audiencepopularity ratings. The pro- gram, which is largely presented live, drew a 29 percent share of the audience from 10 to 11 P.M. on Sunday night, considered a respectable showing for telecast concerned with public affairs.

title: Rustlings of Fall
description: Adolfo's fans will be rustling in taffeta next fall. Stavropoulos followers will, as usual, be floating in chiffon. Either way, there will obviously be no dearth of romantic, decorative evening dresses.

title: Pianist: Gabriel Eghizi
description: GABRIEL EGHIZI, a Rumanian pianist who came to this country in 1966, showed himself to be a remarkably insensitive musician and unreliable technician in program at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night. He almost invariably chose tempos he could not control and works he was far from having mastered at any level.

title: Advertising
description: THE Canada Dry Corporation, subsidiary of Norton Simon Inc., thinks the time has come for an almost-caffeine-free cola. It incorrectly thought the same thing in 1968, but the world has changed a heap since that product failed. And Canada Dry has charmed. too.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Associated Press
description: UP AND OVER FOR A DOUBLE PLAY: Indians' Duane Kuiper leaping over Rick Dempsey of the Orioles, as Dempsey attempted to break up double play with his slide. Ktiiper was able to make the throw to first base in time for double play during third inning last night in Baltimore. The Orioles won, 43.

title: Textile Trade Talks
description: TOKYO, June 26 (UPI)  The United States, the European Economic Community and Japan will hold a meeting in Seattle next week to discuss international textile trade, Japanese trade, sources said today. The sources said the participants would specifically focus on Chinese textiles.

title: Palmer Hoyt, 82, Dies in Denver; ExEditor and Publisher of Post
description: Palmer Hoyt, editor and publisher of The Denver Post from 1946 until he retired in 1971, died Monday at Beth Israel Hospital in Denver. He was 82 years old and had been in poor health for several years.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: Gas Impact Is Slight, Big Companies Say
description: The gasoline shortage, at crisis proportions in many neighborhoods, is having surprisingly little impact on routine business operations, a spot check of companies in metropolitan New York suggests. Though some small merchants say they are hamstrung, larger companies say their main problem is getting their employees from home to work, not finding gasoline.

title: Million in Gifts Given By a Rockefeller Fund
description: The Rockefeller Family Fund made 55 grants last year totaling more than $1 million to nonprofit institutions and organizations, according to the fund's annual report released yesterday. orants were maae in tne tuna's Tour areas of education, equal opportunity for women, institutional responsiveness and conservation. Nearly half of the grants, which totaled $1,058,725, were for two years or more, Ann R. Roberts, the fund's president, wrote in the report.

title: Japan TV Plant for China
description: TOKYO, June 26 (UPI)  The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, major Japanese electric appliance manufacturer, said today that it had signed a contract to export to China a facility to manufacture television sets. The deal, concluded in Peking, calls for the construction of a plant that can produce 1.6 million tubes annually for 12inch and 14inch black-and-white receivers, Matsushita said.

title: BankTakeover Study Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) Senator H. John Heinz 3d, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that he would introduce legislation calling for a sixmonth moratorium on foreign takeovers of American banks while a study of the impact of such acquisitions is prepared.

title: Best Buys
description: WHEN it comes to superMarket trends, New York City generally lags behind the rest of the country. But it's about to catch up with one growing movement that of the nofrills store offering a limited variety of nonperishable food items.

title: COAST CHIEF JUSTICE CRITICAL OF INQUIRY
description: She Defends California High Court Against Charges That Politics Led it to Delay Decisions

title: Fund Dealers May Be Listed
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it was considering a proposal to make public the names of the top 10 securities dealers selling various mutual funds.

title: Efforts to Cut Use of Official Cars Are Spotty and of a Limited Effect
description: Government officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have started taking steps to cut gasoline consumption by the fleet of 50,000 vehicles they control, but so far their action has been spotty and of limited effect. Their orders often do not go into effect immediately and frequently can be circumvented.

title: I.B.M.Fails To Quash Subpoena
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has lost a bid to avoid producing voluminous documents in the four-year-old Government antitrust suit against it, an order that the company contends could require 62,000 manyears of work and cost more than $1 billion.

title: Many in Soviet Concerned Over a Surge of AntiSemitism
description: MOSCOW, June 26  Soviet anti-Semitism, in both official and unofficial varieties, has taken on new and unsettling forms at a time when the authorities are allowing more Jews than ever before to leave for Israel and the United States.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN a fashion magazine, an adver, tisemerit shows a model in an evening dress running in terror from a motel, Another model in a fur coat stands besides a burning automo bile. Still another wears a bracelet on an arm that is being bitten by a Doberman Pinscher.

description: Lawrence Van Gelder

title: Lower Eait Side Group Demanding Compliance on SchoolBias Ruling
description: A coalition on the Lower East Side announced yesterday a campaign to put pressure on the Board of Education and the District 1 Community School Board to comply with an order by the State Division of Human Rights to end discrimination against black and Hispanic employees.

title: Bell Bonds Priced to Yield 9.37%
description: Lowest Return Since January

title: Senate Opponents to Arms Treaty Propose Major Changes in Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  A conservative Senate opponent of the strategic arms treaty proposed major changes today in the agreement to reduce the nuclear arsenal of the Soviet Union, while the Senate Republican leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., prepared to unveil sweeping treaty amendments of his own.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Angela Taylor

title: 22 Reported Dead in Copter Raid By Rhodesia on Zambian Capital
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, June 26  Bishop Abel T. Muzarewa's blackled Government sent a helicopterborne assault force into the Zambian capital of Lusaka today, reportedly killing 22 people in what was presented as a preemptive strike against guerrillas.

title: Market Place
description: NO one in the gasoline line is happy about the fuel shortage but there may be good news for investors in auto parts stocks.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: THERE are some hasty foods in this world that I consider culinary abominations. I would count among them instant rice and the frozen dinners that abound on the freezer shelves of supermarkets. There are some precooked foods, however, that are an absolute boon to anyone who has menuplanning and cooking by the kitchen clock in mind, and one of them is sliced boiled or baked ham. Generally, the quality is uniform and the meat has been cooked in the simplest manner possible. Plain sliced boiled ham can be transformed a hundred different ways into main dishes, baked in cheese sauce, gratineed with potatoeS or tossed in cold salads for summer.

title: A Pointless Pressure on the Poor
description: It's awful to contemplate where America's poor would be without social welfare programs like food stamps, Medicaid and Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Yet Congress hardly seems concerned about the troubles they currently face  beyond their chronic troubles, an immediate shortage of cash.

title: Ice Cream Eases an Eager Wait for Summer Camp
description: Youngsters relished ice cream they were given yesterday as they waited at Grand Central Terminal for the train that would take them on a twoweek vacation in the country at one of the camps sponsored by Fresh Air Fund.

title: Justices, 63, Hold Wrong Arrest May Not Violate the Constitution
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The Supreme Court today threw out of Federal court a damage suit for false arrest, holding that the victim had failed to establish that the identification mixup that led to the mistaken arrest had deprived him of any constitutional rights. The 6-to-3 decision reversed a ruling by the the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, which had found the victim entitled to a jury trial in his suit against a Texas county sheriff. The majority opinion, written by Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist, said that while the detention may well have been wrong, that in itself did not satisfy the threshold requirement of also showing that it was unconstitutional.

title: Ballet: ModernDress Orpheus
description: OF all the Greek myths, that of Orpheus seems to come in for the most retelling. Now, the Stuttgart Ballet's young American resident choreographer, William Forsythe, has offered another moderndress version in his ballet Orpheus, which had its New York premiere Monday night at the Metro. WWII) Or era House.

title: HOUSE PASSES A BILL ON SYNTHETIC FUELS
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The House of Representatives has adopted by a wide margin the nation's first measure intended to promote the largescale production of synthetic fuels.

description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 26 Governor Carey signed a bill today authorizing the state, to clean up. emergency health hazards at chemicalwaste dumps and then to sue the polluters for the cost if they had refused to clean the areas themselves.

description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a rule today that is intended to encourage companies to disclose economic and related projections.

title: Dixie in New York: The Flavor of Home
description: CDME Friday around midnight, Mark Shaw, native son of Cartersville, Ga., heads to Pero's, a redfronted bar snuggled between a post office and a dry cleaner at 251 East 85th Street. He en- ters the oneroom establishment said to be a dead ringer for The Shack Chapel Hill, N.C., student hangout converted from a car repair shop. There's a bowling machine against one wall, a juke lick against another. Tending bar, Confederate cap pushed back from his forehead, is Shanton (Red) Granger, an Atlantabred actor.

title: Murcer Obtained by Yanks for Right Field
description: TORONTO, June 26  While intramural debate continued over the Yankee future of Reggie Jackson, a Yankee of the past became a Yankee of the present today when the team acquired Bobby Murcer from the Chicago Cubs for money and a minor league pitcher.

title: A RISE IN OIL PRICE TO $20 FOR BARREL INDICATED BY OPEC
description: GENEVA, June 26  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended the first day of a pricefixing conference here tonight amid strong indications that it would raise the cost of crude oil from the current $14.55 a barrel to as much as $20 before the meeting ends tomorrow.

title: HelpWanted Ads Declined in May
description: Dyne Associated Press

title: Maryland Sues Over Gasoline
description: BALTIMORE, June 26 (UPI) Maryland's Attorney General sued the United States Department of Energy today, challenging the Government's gasolineallocation formula and hoping to get more gas for his state.

title: All Again Retires; Says He Means It
description: Muhammad Ali officially retired for the third time yesterday, and this time he said he meant it.

title: Some Rises Set in Gasoline Deliveries
description: Gasoline supplies will remain tight as the nation enters the peak summer driving season, according to industry specialists. But some major oil companies said they planned to increase deliveries to gas stations in July in an effort to alleviate the shortage.

title: Around the Nation
description: STARKE, Fla., June 26 (AP)  Just 17 hours before he was scheduled to go to the electric chair, Charles W. Proffitt, a condemned killer, won an indefinite stay from a Federal district judge today.

title: About Real Estate Attraction of American Real Estate for Foreign Investors
description: The strong recovery of the market for cooperative and condominium apartments has greatly increased the attractiveness to investors of certain residential management companies.

title: Subway Inspections Cut for Redecoration, Report Says
description: Subwaycar inspections were cut back and millions of dollars were diverted from system maintenance last year to pay for a $6.8 million beautification program at 84 subway stations, according to a report issued yesterday by group of official citizenadvisers to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: New Regime in Ghana Executes 2 ExRulers And 4 Senior Officers
description: ACCRA, Ghana, June 26  Two former Ghanaian military rulers, Lieut. Gen. Frederick W. K. Akuffo and Lieut. Gen. A. A. Afrifa, were publicly executed by firing squad today on orders of young officers who seized power in a coup earlier this month.

title: Security Destroys Shimoda's Plans for Greeting Carter
description: SHIMODA, Japan, Wednesday, June 27  It was going to be a wonderful welcome.

title: Careers
description: EXPERTS in investment analysis talk about two sides of the street  the sell side and the buy side. Brokerage firms and other investment organizations constitute the sell side, utilizing investment analysts for re- search on securities to be recommended. The buy side consists of pension funds, insurance companies, banks and others whose analysts recommend investments to purchase.

title: Sabena to Take 4th DC10
description: BRUSSELS, June 26 (Reuters) Belgium's Sabena Airline said today that it would not cancel its order for a fourth DC10 airliner despite the United States ban on flights by the aircraft.

title: Both Offered Democracy
description: In July 1978, Lieut. Gen. Frederick W. K. Akuffo led the bloodless coup that overthrew the military regime of General Ignatius K. Acheampong as head of state.

title: Charles E. McCarthy; University Executive, ExAllied Siores Head
description: Charles E. McCarthy, vice president for business affairs at St. John's University and a former president and vice clzairman_ of the board of. Allied Stores Corporation, died Monday at his home in Westhampton Beach, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Two Concerns Indicted in Blasts That Killed 26 in Kentucky Mine
description: CATLETTSBURG, Ky., June 26 (AP)  A sixcount Federal criminal indictment has been returned against the Scotia Coal Company and its parent company in connection with two mine explosions that killed 26 persons in 1976.

title: New York Is Filled With Tourists, Who Are Filled With Wonder

title: Wheat Harvest Forecast Lifted
description: The International Wheat Council yesterday raised its estimate of this year's worldwide wheat harvest by 300,000 metric tons. The Londonbased organization now says the 197879 crop will be 441.7 million metric tons, compared with 385 million metric tons harvested in the previous crop year.

title: Church Shuns Divisions on Homosexuality
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 26  The Rev. Loey Powell publicly disclosed her lesbianism yesterday as she led worship at the United Church of Christ's biennial meeting, and her action added to the impression among many delegates that this mainstream Protestant denomination is further along than any other in accepting homosexuals into the clergy.

description: NYACK; N.Y.  Once he was bellhop at Kutsher's resort hotel in the Catskills, a black basketball player from the ghetto carrying luggage. Today he is a heart surgeon, implanting pacemakers in some of the very same people he served as a bellhop.

title: OPEC: Keeper of NonCommunist Oil
description: The 13 nations that make up the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries currently hold 80 percent of the nonCommunist world's proven oil reserves and more than twothirds of total world reserves. They supply roughly 30 million barrels of oil daily, or more than 63 percent of the nonCommunist world's crude oil.

description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The Supreme Court, ruling in two libel cases today, eased the barriers against successful libel suits by individuals who have not voluntarily become involved in public controversy.

title: Michigan, A State Of Mind
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich.  I am a citizen of the state of Michigan, born in Detroit, raised there and in its environs, and trained to regard the world from its geographical perspective. A Detroiter's horizons form over the waters of the Great Lakes. It is strange that the city of Detroit and the state of Michigan are so readily identified as part of the great, fertile and unexciting stretch of territory called the Midwest. A recent President of the United States helped to reenforce this image of dull decency, but the natural character of Michigan is much spicier than that of other Midwestern states.

title: New Music: A Festival
description: HOT on the heels of the Kitchen's New Music, New York's Festival of Experimental Music, another sort of newmusic festival is going on this week at the LaMama E.T.C. theater space, 74A East Fourth Street. It's called 1001. which is short for 1,001 instruments you've never heard or seen, which in turn means that supposedly at least this is a festival of music by people who use homemade or newly invented instruments. Monday night was a potpourri of all six groups of the festival, which in turn have evenings all their own starting last night and continuing through Sunday, in the following order: Zasis, Bob Wood, Boneworks, Nigel Rollings, Music for Homemade Instruments and Gamelan Son of Lion.

title: George Forbes, Harvard Teacher
description: George Shannon Forbes, professor emeritus of chemistry at Harvard, who taught more than 9,000 students in his 60year association, with the university, died Sunday at his home in Cambridge, Mass., after a brief illness. He was 97 years old. Professor Forbes was chairman of the department of chemistry from 1944 to 1947 and retired to emeritus status in 1948. He continued laboratory work at Harvard as a consultant to industry, particularly with the Mallinckrodt Chemical Company, until 1972, when he became 90. He also served as a parttime professor of chemistry at Northeastern University for 18 years.

title: TV: Urban Arts Salutes Black Music and Poetry
description: TONIGHT'S Theater in America presentation, on WNETTV at 9 o'clock, bears the ebulliently defiant title of When Hell Freezes Over, I'll Skate. This is a somewhat abbreviated version of the Urban Arts Theater production that opened the recent Black Theater Festival in New York.

And this predilection for the spice is no recent phenomenon, not by a long shot.

title: Drivers Gain Renewal Extension
description: ALBANY, June 26 (UPI)  Motorists whose drivers licenses or vehicle registrations were due to expire Saturday will have until July 6 to renew them, the State Department of Motor Vehicles said today. Commissioner James Melton said the extension had been granted because of delays in the New York City metropolitan area caused by staff members having to work on the oddeven gasoline distribution plan. Mr. Melton said another reason for the extension was the Fourth of July holiday.

That, in effect, is the overwhelming responsibility critics have put on Freely Girardet, who cooks at his very handSome and simple country restaurant in the Hotel de Ville of the tiny hamlet of Crissier, about 20 minutes from Lausanne. There seems to be no doubt in anyone's mind that if the Guide Michelin deigned to rate any restaurants in Switzerland (other than those in Geneva and Basel, which it does include in the French guide) Girardet would get three stars.

title: Ali's Retirement Reaffirmed

Ali, speaking over the phone Tuesday, told a news conference in Newark that he had sent a letter to the World Boxing Association resigning his heavyweight title. In his two previous retirements Ali gave new meaning to the word by fighting again within months.

description: TOKYO, June 27 (UPI)  Japan and Canada agreed today to start talks on reciprocal opening of banks if Parliament in Ottawa passes a law, as expected, allowing foreign banks to operate in Canada, Japanese officials said.

description: New supplies of gasoline trickled into the metropolitan area yesterday and more were promised as New York state and city officials stepped up their enforcement drive against price gouging at pumps.

title: The Weber Solution
description: Once again the Supreme Court has found a way to let affirmative action live. Against potent arguments in the name of white working men, the Court has approved an avowedly raceconscious plan  collectively negotiated between an employer and a union dominated by whites  for blacks to share in new job opportunities.

title: TEXAN GUILTY AGAIN IN MASSDEATH TRIAL
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 27 (AP)  Elmer Wayne Henley was convicted today for a second time in six murders carried out as part of a series of 26 homosexual tortures and slayings in Houston in the early 1970's.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Mets Top Pirates on 5 in 9th, 129
description: PITTSBURGH, June 27  In an unbelievable windup to a back-andforth game, the lastplace New York Mets, who have spent much of the season playing dead in the closing innings, scored nine runs in the last three tonight to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates. 129.

title: TV: Rejection Potpourri
description: EJECTED television sample shows, called busted pilots in the trade, are generally dropped into network schedules one at a time at odd hours. The idea is to get some small financial return out of what represents a substantial investment, without ruining a whole evening's schedule.

title: Newsweek Names New Editor, Lester Bernstein, ExStaff Member
description: In a move that took the staff by surprise, Edward Kosner was replaced as editor of Newsweek yesterday by Lester Bernstein, a former managing, editor of the magazine. Mr. Bernstein left Newsweek in 1972 to become a vice president for corporate communications at RCA.

title: U.S. Asks for Data On Beneficial Deal
description: The Beneficial Corporation, a diversified financialservices company based in Wilmigton, Del., said that the Justice Department had requested additional information on its proposed acquisition of the life, casualty insurance and finance interests of the Southwestern Investment Company, a subsidiary of the Beatrice Foods Company.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Soinoza Fights On as Aides Worry
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 27 Ensconced in the windowleSs war room of his concrete bunker, wearing combat fatigues that show his rank of fivestar general, surrounded by optimistic maps  and unquestioning aides and guided by a battalion of elite troops, President Anastasio. Somoza Debayle has decided to fight it out.

title: French Criticism Irks Carter
description: TOKYO, June 27  President Carter has become angry with what is considered European sniping at America's energy policies, according to United States officials.

title: The Glass Garage Door
description: It's such a long, lovely space, said the architect Norman Pfeiffer Harrison /Erickson's loft, we didn't want to break it up with a wall. But Wayde and Bonnie wanted an area that afforded some acoustical privacy, so the solution was the, glass garage door. It gives them what they wanted, and at the same time maintains the space.

title: I.B.M. Lifts Prices On Computer Rental
description: MONTREAL, June 27 (Reuters) Quebec's Superior Court today barred for 10 days an attempt by the provincial government to expropriate the assets of the Americancontrolled Asbestos Corporation.

title: Orioles 3, Indians
description: BALTIMORE, June 27 (AP)  The Baltimore Orioles rode the fourhit pitching of Jim Palmer to a 31 victory over Cleveland tonight for their 18th victory in the last 20 games.

title: Home Remedies For Cleaning Chores
description: THERE are a good many household problems that can be solved with simple and inexpensive home remedies - if only one can remember the process and ingredients when the emergency is at hand. The following are some of the most useful tactics.

title: Victoria T. Johnson Bride of a Professor
description: Victoria Taylor Johnson, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. E. Dudley H. Johnson of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Samuel Francis Pickering Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pickering of Nashville. Dean Ernest Gordon performed the Protestant ceremony in the Princeton University Chapel.

title: City's Rent Guidelines Board Votes Rise Up to 20% in Stabilized Units
description: In a meeting that grew so raucous that police officers were called in to calm protesters, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board voted yesterday to allow rents to be increased by as much as 20 percent in 350,000 rentstabilized apartments.

description: The Columbia Broadcasting System has given more than $2 million in grants to 22 Chicago youthoriented organizations as part of a program of corporate philanthrophy that emphasizes cities in which CBS operations are centered.

description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place
description: OULD there possibly be a valid reason for selling off crude oil reserves in a period of extreme shortages? Ashland Oil Inc. sold its Canadian producing properties inthe fiscal year ended March 31, 1978, and has completed the sale most of its domestic oil and gas properties. Mesa Petroleum also has sold some producing properties while the Clark Oil and Refining Company is reportedly planning to do so.

title: Mishap at Reactor in Michigan
description: BRIDGMAN, Mich., June 27 (AP)One thousand gallons of radioactive water accidentally sprayed the insides of a reactor at the Donald C. Cook nuclear plant in a test of the safety systems, according to Government officials. No radioactivity was released outside, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Monday.

title: RIGHTS LEADERS HAIL WEBER CASE DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Civil rights, labor and government leaders greeted the Supreme Court's decision in the Brian F. Weber case today with praise and calls for a renewed commitment to affirmafive action programs, while critics of the ruling warned about the dangers of establishing racial quotas and discriminating against whites.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Grain and soybean prices plunged in a speculative selloff yesterday as no new bullish news emerged to :support the elevated price levels of recent weeks.

title: Fox President Had Hoped to End Rift
description: LOS ANGELES, June 27  As the shocked movie industry discussed his unexpected plans to leave Twentieth CenturyFox next year, Alan Ladd Jr. said today that he was surprised that his philosophical difficulties with his studio could not be resolved.

title: U.S. Will Relax Limit on Cooling For Businesses
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  When thermostat restrictions go into effect early next month, the Carter Administration plans to set the lower limit for airconditioning in offices and other commercial buildings at 78 degrees instead of the 80 degrees originally envisioned.

title: Lone Star Acquires SanVel Concrete
description: Lone Star Industries, a Greenwich, Conn.based producer of cement and concrete, said it had acquired all the assets of the SanVel Concrete Corporation, of Littleton, Mass., for about $8.3 million In cash and notes.

title: White House Bid to Delay Primary In Massachusetts Meets Resistance
description: BOSTON, June 27  Aides in the White House and the Democratic National Committee are encountering opposition in trying to get the March 4 Presidential primary in Massachusetts pushed back until late spring, a change that would help President Carter and make a candidacy by Senator Edward M. Kennedy more difficult.

title: Students StripSearched in 2 Dutchess County Schools
description: AMENIA, N.Y. June 21  In the past few months, right up to the end of school last Monday, students at two Dutchess, County high schools have been pulled from classes or stopped unexpectedly in the hallways, brought into the principal's office and stripsearched for drugs.

title: Who Says We've Made It?
description: WASHINGTON - In an important sense, the case for substantial progress by blacks in recent years is a creation of neoconservative intellectuals who, radicalized to the right by the 1960's, learned to make their new principles pay. Broadcast and print journalists, receptive to these views, have packaged them for the general public. Inevitably, the emphasis of blacks on progress yet to be made has been discounted as a rhetorical tactic, if not selfinterested propaganda.

title: A Confrontation on Refugees
description: KUTA, Indonesia, June 27The West, principally the United States, and the Southeast Asian nations that gave first asylum to Vietnamese refugees will confront each other here this weekend.

title: Pay Rise in Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, June 27 (Reuters)  Australia's six million workers were given a 3.2 percent pay rise today to compensate for an increase in the cost of living in the six months ended March 31. The Arbitration Commission determines wages twice a year. A worker earning the average wage of $220 a week will now receive $7.10 more.

title: Kuwait Is Calming Down Afters Jitters About Iran
description: KUWAIT  This oilproducing, taxfree welfare state appears to have absorbed the shock of the revolution in neighboring Iran, but it is keeping a wary eye on the shaky Persian Gulf region and the constant impact on its own politics of the ArabIsraeli confrontation.

title: Technology
description: Turning TV Set Into a Computer

title: KlughFranks's Sugar
description: THE Earl KlughMichael Franks concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening was the Newport Jazz Festival's sugar course. Mr. Kiugh's set was very nearly all sweetness; Mr. Frank's was sweet and tour. Each artist purveys in his own way the sort of diluted but musicianly entertain.. ment a very large contemporary audience thinks of as Jazz.

title: No Lines at Pumps Fueling Planes
description: HARTFORD, June 27  Most gas stations here have purchase limits and hourlong lines, when they are open at all. But at one station, customers can roll up to the pumps and fill their tanks with 50 or 100 gallons with no wait, although the price is 20 cents a gallon higher than elsewhere. The only requirement is that the customer be in an airolane.

title: S.E.C. Orders Review Of Touche Ross Auditing
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered a complete review of the auditing practices of Touche Ross & Company, one of the Big Eight accounting firms.

title: Strikers Bring Valencia to Halt
description: VALENCIA, Spain, June 27 (AP) Workers responding to a call for a general strike brought most industrial concerns to a halt here today. Spain's five major unions called the 29hour strike to protest the killing of a man by the police on Monday. The killing is said to have occurred during a demonstration by market workers.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS

description: The transit police officer refused to disclose his name: At 2 A.M. in a New York City subway station, even armed men do not give much away.

title: ABROAD AT HOME

It would make relations with the new Government of Bishop Abel Muzorewa depend on convincing demonstrations that he and the black majority are really in charge in what is now called Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: Education Disgraced
description: The charge of racism is rolling too easily off too many tongues these days. Those who find such reckless smears politically useful should think again; their cynicism brings us close to the point where genuine complaints against racial discrimination are being discounted by serious people. These smear tactics debase not only language but politics itself.

title: Sandinist Chiefs Express Anger At U.S. for Not Making Contact
description: SAN JOSE, COSTA RICA, June 27 Sandinist rebel leaders today revealed the broad outlines of the government they hope to install in Nicaragua and said they were embittered by the fact that the United States had yet to express any interest in contacting them.

title: Bloc in Congress From New York Angry Over Gas
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Members of New York State's Congressional delegation, raising their voices and speaking heatedly, told Vice President Mondale today that the Carter Administration had shortchanged the state and had failed to provide credible' figUres. on gasoline distribution.. They demanded that the state receive its fair share of fuel in the nationwide gasoline shortage.

title: Young Says U.S. Should Hesitate To Criticize Hanoi on Refugees
description: BONN, June 27  Andrew Young, the chief American representative at the United Nations, cautioned today that in light of the United States past involvement in Vietnam it would be inappropriate for it to criticize Vietnam for the exodus of refugees.

title: At Age 84, Jack Dempsey Reflects on Boxing

title: Air Clash Not Viewed as Change In Syrian Policy of Avoiding War
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 27  Diplo mats here said today that Syria's decision to send up its planes to challenge Israeli air strikes on southern Lebanon apparently reflected no basic change in policy.

title: China Reports Trade Up 30%
description: TOKYO, June 27 (AP)  China's foreign trade last year jumped 30 percent from the 1977 level, with imports growing twice as fast as exports, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: ISRAEL TO CONVERT 6 SITES FOR SETTLERS
description: TEL AVIV, June 27  Israel decided today to set up six paramilitary agricultural settlements in occupied Arab territories. The sites are now military outposts.

title: Rock: 2 of the NoWave
description: NEW YORK'S no wave artrock scene began in private lofts and downtown art galleries, but more recently bands from that scene have begun to appear regularly at the same clubs that spawned the newwave scene of just few years ago - CBGB's and Max's Kansas City. Tuesday night two of the leading figures of the nowave world, Rhys Chatham and Robin Crutchfield, appeared at Maxs, along with their bands and interspersed with a representative example of the nowave underground film school of vital but crude little punk dramas shot in super8 (this one starred Pat Place and Lydia Lunch, for the record).

title: Saudi Forces Hold Maneuvers
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, June 27 (AP)King Khalid of Saudi Arabia and leaders of Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Yemen watched maneuvers of the Saudi armed forces in the southern province of Asir today.

title: Water Seepage Held Saudi Oil Threat
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Saudi Arabia has been forced by technical problems to lower its estimate of the maximum amount of oil it can produce on a sustained basis by 500,000 barrels a day, according to private oil analysts and United States Government officials.

title: Jury Is Given HoldupKilling Case In Trial Lasting Record 15 Months
description: The case of four men accused of killing a customer in a Harlem supermarket that they allegedly robbed in December 1978 went to the jury yesterday, a year, three months and one day after it began, making it the longest and one of the costliest criminal trials in the history of the New York State Supreme Court. The jury later retired for the night.

title: Recent Soviet ATest Is a Possible Violation Of '74 Pact With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Carter Administration officials said tonight that the Soviet Union recently conducted an underground nuclear test that may have exceeded the levels agreed to by Moscow and Washington five years ago.

title: Brazilian Wheat Outlook
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 27 (UPI)  Brazil has imported 2.2 million tons of wheat this year and may import 3.8 million more by the end of 1979 unless domestic production increases, Gazeta Mercantil said today. However, thebusiness newspaper quoted the Getulio Vargas Foundation as reporting good chances that the 197980 crop will surpass the record harvest of 3.2 million tons in 1976.

description: Alan Ladd Jr., the management force behind the resurgence of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, has announced that he intends to resign as the film company's president, effective December 1980.

title: 2 Bidders Raise Stakes In Florida Mining Quest
description: A highstakes bidding battle between two major companies for control of the Florida Mining and Materials Corporation intensified yesterday with both the Kaiser Cement Corporation and Moore McCormack Resources sharply increasing earlier offers to buy any and all stock in the Florida cement company.

title: Soviet Buys U.S. Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) United States exporters have sold another 235,400 metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union this week, bringing the Russians grain purchases for the yearto 13.4 million tons, the Agriculture Department said today. The transactions brought Soviet purchases of United States grain in the third year of a fiveyear agreement to 10.3 million tons of corn and 3.1 million tons of wheat.

title: Texan Removes Youths From Unlicensed Home
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 27 (AP)  The evangelist Lester Roloff has agreed to remove the last five girls from one of his homes for wayward youths, temporarily ending his sixyear battle with the state over his unlicensed facilities. state officials said

description: MEMPHIS, June 27 (AP)  Alan Fortas, nephew of the former Justice Abe Forms of the United States Supreme Court, has been charged with attempting to bribe a penal farm officer to place his brother on a workrelease program.

title: House Again Votes Stringent Limit On Federal Financing of Abortions,
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The House of Representatives reaffirmed tonight its position that no Federal funds should be spent on abortions unless the life of the mother would be endangered without such an operation.

title: Sara Sage Holds Golf Lead
description: JERICHO, L.I., June 27Sara Sage of Piping Rock, the 1978 winner, held twostroke lead after the second round of the 59hole Women's Long Island Golf Association tournament today at Meadow Brook Club. She added a 79 today to yesterday's 73 for 152.

title: Advice on Aiding Retired Parents
description: THE more things change, the more they stay the same. Years ago, before Social Security and before pension plans were common, people who were too old to work relied on their children for support. Now, despite all our advances in retirement planning, a growing number of retirees are being forced to ask their children for financial help. Inflation has shrunk the purchasing power of their pensions and made shambles of their investments. Such soaring rates of inflation are so new that a retiree would have needed the foresight of a Cassandra to prepare for the consequences.

title: Show Business Is Not Yet Running Out of Gas
description: Show business in the metropolitan area is not yet running out. of gas because'f the oil crisis. Presenters of entertainment, many of them by nature volatile and not reluctant to prophesy doom when it comes to the ill effects Of other disasters, such as strikes, negative reviews and taxes, maintained a facade of equanimity, albeit , somewhat tempered, when asked about the fuel shortage and the arts.

title: Iraqi Warning Given Canada
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 27 (AP) Iraq will halt exports of crude oil to Canada if Canada moves its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, an Iraqi Governmentcontrolled magazine said today.

title: 88Day. Tug. Strike Ends, Easing Shipments of Gas
description: Striking tugboat crewmen overwhelmingly ratified a new contract yesterday and began returning to their jobs. Their return to work assured a quick resumption of normal operations after an 88day strike that disrupted port operations and garbage collection in New York City.
The New York City Taxicab and Limousine Commission will hold a public hearing today to consider a 15cent passalong charge to be added to metered cab fares as relief for higher fuel costs.

description: Theodore M. Bernstein, a former assistant managing editor of The New York Times,, a journalism educator and an authority on use of the English language, died of cancer yesterday in his home at 2 Fifth Avenue. He was 74 years old.

title: Big Board Seeks To Delist Interway
description: The New York. Stock Exchange announced that it would suspend trading in the common stock of the Interway Corporation, a New Yorkbased holding company of trailer leasing and cargo container subsidiaries, before the opening of trading on Monday, July 2. Following the suspension, an application will be made to the Securities and Exchange Commission to delist the issue, the Big Board said.

title: Banned Pesticide Appears in Coast Drinking Water
description: VISALIA, Calif., June 27  Two years after California banned the toxic pesticide DBCP from agricultural use, the chemical has reappeared in drinking water in the San Joaquin Valley around Fresno.

description: LONDON, June 27  Lord Thomson, publisher of the strikebound Times of London and The Sunday Times, which have not appeared for nearly seven months, said here today that he had no

title: Steinbrenner: Yanks Need Jackson's Bat
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 27  George Steinbrenner reversed his strategy on Reggie Jackson today, emphasizing that he likes him, saying the Yankees need him to win the pennant again and predicting that he would return to the lineup in time for this weekend's series with Boston.

title: Mondale Offers Protection to Haulers Who Return
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The Carter Administration called on striking independent truckers today to go back to work and offered a plan to protect drivers who chose to defy pickets and return to the road.

description: We have never wavered in our understanding that Title VII prohibits all racial discrimination in employment, without exception for any particular employees.

Loving grandmother of Eleanor Stirling Folkman. Memorlei service at United Community Methodist Church, Jadcson Heights, 1PM, Friday. In lieu of flowers donations to the Heart Fund would be appreciated.

description: ELLEN GOULD, an attractivelooking singer and actress, is trying her big voice over an ambitious testing range in a short onewoman show called Confessions of a Reformed Romantic, subtitled A Classical Cabaret Piece, at the South Street Theater Company on West 42d Street.

title: Purge of Intellectuals By the Afghan Regime Reported Under Way

description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Republican Presidential candidates, united on most economic and foreign policy issues and unanimous in accusing President Carter otproviding weak leadership, have only tentative suggestions for dealing with the gasoline shortage and disagree over the ideas they have.

title: Postal Service Cancels Plan to Move Out of New York

It said yesterday it would not shift its Northeast regional headquarters out of New York City and that it was leasing offices at 1633 Broadway.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS A PREFERENCE PLAN FOR BLACKS IN JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The Supreme Court ruled today that private employers can legally give special preferences to black workers to eliminate manifest racial imbalance in traditionally whiteonly jobs.

It was the Americans first victory in the four-of-seven-game series.

title: Ann Bernard Sicher Wed To Richard E. Weinreich

title: Deaths

title: Carter's Measures On Prices Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  A coalition of organizations representing consumers, the elderly and labor attacked the Carter Administration's anti-inflation campaign today as inadequate and socially unjust.

title: Insurers Agree to Merge
description: Directois of the Lincoln National Corporation, an insurance holding company based in New York City, and of the SecurityConnecticut Life Insurance Company, Avon, Conn., agreed yesterday to merge Security into Lincoln. They smashed windows and light bulbs in a halfhour rampage.

title: Film: Audrey Hepburn in 'Bloodline':International Intrigue
description: "SIDNEY Sheldon's Bloodline," based on the recent Sheldon novel that sold well, is both better and worse than the film version of Sidney Sheldon's "The Other Side of Midnight," which was apparently made before Mr. Sheldon's agent had the clout to squeeze the Sheldon name into the title. "Bloodline" has a more attractive, more able cast, including Audrey Hepburn, James Mason, Ben Gazzara, Beatrice Straight and Gert Frbe and it has a lot more scenery (Sardinia, New York, London, Paris, Switzerland), but it seems constructed entirely of loose ends and superfluous information. "The Other Side of Midnight" was the undisputed junk-movie of its year, but it made a certain amount of narrative sense. "Bloodline" doesn't.The film, which opens today at the Loews Tower East and other theaters, pretends to be the story of a great international drug combine controllled by a family that's to pharmaceuticals what the Rothschilds were once to banking.When the family patriarch dies, the control of the company passes to his once-elfin daughter Elizabeth (Audrey Hepburn), whom we first meet in New York's American Museum of Natural History where she appears to be painting the rib cage of a dinosaur that's in process of being reconstituted.From this I think we're meant to believe that Elizabeth is some sort of anthropologist, but because it's never mentioned again, we begin to suspect toward the end of the film that she really wasn't working on the dinosaur but just looking for an earring lost the night before at a charity ball.As soon as Elizabeth takes control of the company at a board meeting in Zurich, it's apparent that the same person or persons who got dad are after her. The suspects, who aren't too numerous to mention, include handsome, suave Rhys Williams (Ben Gazzara), who was her father's chief aide, and various greedy cousins who want the company to go public, thus to sell their stock profitably. They include Sir Alec Nichols (James Mason), based in London, Ivo Palazzi (Omar Sharif) in Rome; and Helene Martine (Romy Schneider) in Paris, along with their various spouses.While Elizabeth is asserting her control of the international pharmaceutical market, people keep trying to bump her off. When she climbs into her Jeep to drive to the airport, the brakes fail. Someone cuts the cables to the elevator she almost boards. Standing on a Swiss ski slope, she narrowly misses death when a snowmobile brushes by her.As somebody is trying to tell her something, the movie makers are trying to tell us something, for running parallel to these events, is a subplot about the murders of a number of prostitutes whose lives are snuffed out in the course of shooting porn films. What is the connection to poor Elizabeth? Tenuous.As he demonstrated in his James Bond films ("Dr. No," "From Russia With Love" and "Thunderball"), Terence Young is a director of some comic style, but though "Bloodline" is often laughable, it has no sense of humor. It's the kind of fiction that is glumly disapproving of its own sordid details, such as one about a lady who has her knees nailed to the floor (offscreen) for not paying her gambling debts. "Bloodline" takes Miss Hepburn's Givenchy clothes more seriously than it does the actress who wears them, not always becomingly. Under these circumstances, there's no reason to comment on the quality of the individual performances

title: Art: Whitney Reviews the 70's
description: HE attempt to characterize the art of the 1970's - in effect, to label it with the name of some allenccimpassing movement is almost as old as the decade itself. But all such attempts have so far proved to be fruitless. The reasons.I think, are twofold.- First,the art is too various - and perceived to be too various - to be easily summed up in a phrase. And second, we have all become a little weary of attempts to confer an instant historical certification on works of art that may very well turn out to be highly perishable.

title: Screen: 'Moonraker' Puts Bond in Orbit:Old, Old Friends
description: AT a time when everything is being either inflated or devalued it's comforting to know that at least one commodity maintains its hard currency. That's James Bond, who, by all rights, should be an antique, as emblematic of the 60's as the Beatles and flowerpower, but who goes blithely on as if time has had a stop."Moonraker," which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, is the 11th in the remarkable series that began in 1963 with "Dr. No" and it's one of the most bouyant Bond films of all. It looks as if it cost an unconscionable amount of money to make, though it has nothing on its mind except dizzying entertainment, which is not something to dismiss quickly in such a dreary, disappointing movie season.What's it about? That's a silly question, though I suppose one might answer that it's about sleight of handsthose of all the people who worked on it. They include the indefatigable producer, Albert R. Broccoli (also known as Cubby), Lewis Gilbert, who directed it, Christopher Wood, who wrote the screenplay, Ken Adam, the production designer, and all of those far from little people who are responsible for the extraordinary tricks that persuade us to suspend our disbelief.Mr. Wood's screenplay begins when a United States space-shuttle craft mysteriously disappears as it's being ferried to England on the back of a Boeing 747. The fiend behind this remarkable theft is a French-accented American aeronautics tycoon named Drax (Michael Lonsdale), an eccentric fellow who lives in California in a transplanted French chateau and who surrounds himself with astronauts, all of whom are between the ages of 18 and 25, beautiful and female.The space-shuttle craft, called Moonraker, was actually built by Drax's company, so the mystery that James Bond (Roger Moore) must solve is why Drax would feel the need to hijack his own product. The trail leads from London to California to Venice to Rio de Janeiro and, after that, to Drax's jungle hideaway that takes in bits and pieces of settings filmed in Guatemala and Argentina as well as Brazil. Among other things "Moonraker" deals in creative geography. The climactic duel occurs in the only location leftouter space."Moonraker," like all of the better Bond pictures, returns us to a kind of film making that I most closely associate with the 15-part serials of my youth. Our astonishment depends on the ingenuity by which the writers and directors disentangle Bond from the impossible situations into which he seems to fall every seven minutes."Moonraker" begins with one of the funniest and most dangerous (as well as most beautifully photographed and edited) sequences Bond has ever faced. He's booted out of an airplane without a parachute and must do mortal combat, during a swooping, soaring free-fall, with an adversary who, luckily, does have a parachute. There are also a high-speed chase through Venetian canals (with one gondola a disguised Hovercraft), another chase on the Amazon, a fight on the roof of the funicular that goes to the top of Rio's Sugar Loaf mountain, and a final confrontation in space that is as handsome as anything in "Star Wars."What's it about? It's about movie making of the kind Georges Mlis pioneered in films like "Voyage to the Moon" (1902) and "Twenty Thousand Leagues under the Sea" (1907). It's the unimaginable most satisfactorily imagined.Almost everyone connected with the movie is in top form, even Mr. Moore who has a tendency to facetiousness when left to his own devices. Here he's as ageless, resourceful and graceful as the character he inhabits. Mr. Lonsdale is sometimes uncomfortably wooden and square, but then he's not supposed to be a barrel of laughs. Lois Chiles is lovely as Bond's Central Intelligence Agency vis--vis, who's just one of the sexually tireless Bond's conquests. Richard Kiel reappears as Bond's thug-enemy, the gigantic Jaws, who, you may be happy to learn, undergoes the kind of character transformation that means he'll probably turn up in yet another Bond film. Bernard Lee and Lois Maxwell, as, respectively, "M" and Miss Moneypenny, also are on hand.Welcome back to old friends."Moonraker," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), includes some suggestive situations and comically overstated violence.

Mexico, which is not a member of OPEC, currently sells its crude at $17.10 a barrel, reviewing the price every three months. It has a policy of pricing its oil higher than world levels.

description: AREA A  The report from Captain Andy's Marina in Margate, N.J., was enthusiastic about catches of blues and weakfish off Great Egg Inlet, 180 degrees and about eight miles out on the Atlantic, using mostly umbrella rigs as the lure. Fluke are running in the bay and there are fine catches of blue claw crabs. A few stripers are being taken off Longport Bridge at night with live bunker.

title: Insulin Research Raises Debate on DNA Guidelines
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 28  Genentech Inc., a private company experimenting with ways to synthesize commercial quantities of insulin using recombinant DNA techniques, has begun to produce the inactive protein strands for the product in amounts that exceed guidelines of the National Institutes of Health, which are binding only on federally financed research.

description: LONG WAIT: Candidates for ballboy and bailgirl await auditions yesterday at West Side Tennis Club. About 100 boys and girls turned up hoping to be one of 25 needed for Forest Hills Invitational, July 945.

title: Mets Subdue Pirates On Stearns Clout, 32

title: Publishing: A Thriller Fraught With Firsts
description: COMING from Charles Scribners Sons next November is novel over which the word first hovers like a good fairy. It is titled, First Strike, and is the first novel of a retired Air Force officer in his mid40's, Douglas Terman, who decided a couple of years ago that he had always wanted to, write a novel and sat down and did so. He brought the manuscript to a small New England publishing house, Vermont Crossroads Press, which read it, liked it and published it in an edition of 600. It was, as it happened, the publisher's first book, too.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE Sitwells belong to the history of publicity, rather than of poetry, pronounced F.R. Leavis, that surly custodian of English letters; and there is a measure ottruth to the charge. Edith, Osbert and Sacheverell. the nmlifie sib- lings whose collective talents made them England's reigning literary family for half a century, were formidable selfpromoters. Endowed with wealth, memorable features and an aristocratic lineage- quite apart from their genuine accomplishments - the Sitwells commanded attention from the moment of their more or less simultaneous debut just after World War I.

title: Market Place
description: THE biggest game in Wall Street these days corporate takeovers and anyone who plays this game with skill may make money. But to play, coattail investors should think like the individual who hopes to buy control. Investors usually don't think,that way, but now they can find helpful information on file with the Securities, and Exchange Commission. The authors of a new book, The Aggressive Conservative Investor, just published by Random House, offer a thesis worth considering by investors who may want to join the takeover game.

title: At 73, Billy Wilder's Bark Still Has Plenty of Bite
description: LOS ANGELES - Last Friday was Billy Wilder's 73d birthday, and he had been making movies for exactly 50 years. The morning was punctuated with telephone calls praising him for having reached both milestones with his teeth, appetite and biting wit intact.

Then we decided to announce an afternoon of folk music at the museum and 400 people showed up. We knew we had a winner.

title: Film: 'Nightwing' Gives Bats Their Scary Turn:A World Gone Bats
description: WHAT leaves bite marks no one has ever seen before as well as an all-pervading smell of ammonia? A depressed cleaning-woman? No, according to Arthur Hiller's not very horrifying new movie, "Nightwing."Hollywood's apocalyptic visions of mankind's doom have fingered locusts, grasshoppers, bees, Spanish moss, rabbits, frogs, sharks, worms, ants and carrots. "Nightwing" accuses vampire bats. Now I suppose bats  all bats  are innately more disturbing than Spanish moss and carrots, but as they are pictured in "Nightwing," they seem a good deal less ferocious than sharks or even ants obsessed with going their own way."Nightwing," which opens today at Loew's State 2 and other theaters, is set in the Southwest and adds one tiny variation to the familiar story, which is the one about nature being out of control. The two principal characters are American Indians. One, named Duran (Nick Mancuso) talks so elegantly you might think he were in a reservation production of "The Importance of Being Ernest." The other, Chee (Stephen Macht), wears modish sports clothes and uses the language of a Hollywood talent agent. "Not to worry, Roger," he calls cheerily over the telephone to someone who wants to buy the oil rights to the Indian land.The two other major characters are Anne Dillon (Kathryn Harrold), a pretty young white woman who works with Indians and loves Duran, and Philip Payne (David Warner), an English-born bat-killer who pursues his work with the scary dedication of the fanatic. Mr. Warner is quite funny  intentionally, I suspect  when he attempts to explain his fanaticism. He fairly shakes with moral indignation as he describes a typical bat cave with "millions of bats wrestling, fighting, mating, hanging upside down . . . They are the quintessence of eeevilll!"Mr. Hiller ("The In-Laws," "The Hospital," "Love Story,") is credited as the director of the film but it looks as if it had been put together from a child's instruction book. The screenplay, based on a novel by Martin Cruz Smith, is terrible and the special effects third-rate."Nightwing," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains some vulgar language and several scenes that make free use of fake blood.

title: StreetWise Goldfish
description: Large areas of Manhattan are afloat. I remember when the New Bellevue Hospital was being built, 15 years ago; the first stage was the most spectacular and satisfying, an error: mous square lake. It was there for the two years, named Lake Bellevue, while the diSconsolate Budget Bureau went looking for cash to build the next stage. It was fenced about and visible only from the upper windows of the old hospitali but pretty to look at, cool and blue in midsummer, frozen gleaming as Vermont in January. The fence, like all city fences, was always broken, and we could have gone down to the lake and used it, but it was known to be an upwelling of the East River.

description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 28 Costa Rica, a country with no army of its own, is.. actively aiding .,the Sandinist rebele., in . neighboring Nicaragua while jUse...is actively seeking to hide its  involvement.

title: Arab League, Meeting Without Egypt, Picks A Tunisian as Leader
description: TUNIS, June 28  The Arab League, meeting here without Egypt's participation in the first ministerial session since moving its headquarters from Cairo, today unanimously chose Chedli Klibi, Tunisia's Information Minister, as its new Secretary General.

title: Debbie Austin Shoots a 71 To Take Lead at Dearborn
description: DEARBORN, Mich., June 29 (AP) Debbie Austin battled a raindrenched Dearborn Country Club course for a one-under-par 71 to take a twoshot lead after two rounds of a $150,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Tournament today.

title: Wheat Farmers Happy: Good Crop and Good Price
description: LYONS, Kan., June 27  Farmers in central Kansas, one of the world's richest wheatgrowing areas, were waiting impatiently earlier this week for hot sunshine and winds, for the Department of Agriculture and for the Russians, in roughly that order.

title: Dunlop Tire Cutting Output at 2 Plants
description: BUFFALO, N.Y., June 29 (AP) The Dunlop Tire and Rubber Corporation said it would reduce prodgction at its plants in Tonawanda, N.Y., and Huntsville, Ala., because the fuel shortage has reduced demand for its product.

description: LOS ANGELES, June 29  A Strike of civil servants in Quebec has had the unexpected effect of blocking the openings of at least three American movies in that province this weekend.

title: Oil Pipeline Inspection Begun
description: ANCHORAGE, June 29 (UPI)  The Interior Department today began mechanical inspection of the 800mile TransAlaska oil pipeline after disclosures that leakdetection devices and computer system designed to forecast dangerous shifts in the pipe had not functioned properly.

title: Brascan Reports Outlay Of More Then $5 Million

title: Stevenson, Leaving the Senate, Says He Wants to Be President
description: CHICAGO, June 29 (UPI)  Senator Adlai E. Stevenson, Democrat of Illinois, said today that he wanted to be President of the United States in 1980  unless we can make it any earlier.

And if the Indians so desired, it seemed likely that Lemon would abandon his frontoffice job with the Yankees and return to managing.

The Rev. Bartley McPhaidin, a Roman Catholic priest and president of Stonehill College in North Easton, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: Business and the Law

Invariably in the last week in June, when courts at all levels are disgorging opinions, even the most conscientious lawyers cannot keep up. Their immediate response is to counsel caution.

Its handsome townhouses and apartment buildings, and the brownstones along Madison Avenue that are now fashionable boutiques, have an architectural richness and detail that set the area apart. But the small, older buildings that give the neighborhood its style also make it a sitting duck for redevelopment.

description: Men like Horne, the hero of The Great Buffalo Hotel, are becoming so popular in American fiction that they must represent a powerful urge. The urge would seem to be escapist, for Home has escaped from three marriages, nine jobs and adulthood. He has a boyish capacity for beginnings.

title: How to Draw in ? Chinese
description: Several weeks ago, I returned from a twoandahalfweek visit to China. As a guest, I was in China to initiate and direct the manufacture of a Ming Dynasty garden and Ming furniture gallery that will be fabricated in China and installed in the Metropolitan Museum of Art early next year. The project is unusually complicated by the fact that our contract for this work requires that 30 Chinese workers will be in residence in New York for period of three months performing this installation.

description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 29 (UPI)  Brazil raised the export price of its coffee by 10 percent today, fixing the cost of a pound of green coffee beans at $2.

title: Film: 'Good Guys' Opens:The Cast
description: Martial-arts films can usually be counted on to be long on action and short on plot, characterization and so on. "Good Guys Wear Black," which opened yesterday at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters, manages to be short on everything.In fact, an hour goes by before the star, Chuck Norris, a former karate champion who has taught the sport to many Hollywood notables, demolishes his first opponents. More amazingly, they stand up and come back for more after receiving the sort of punishment that would fell a rhinoceros.The notion upon which the film is based, that a raid late in the Vietnam War to free a group of captured Central Intelligence Agency operatives failed because the North Vietnamese knew it was coming, is not without promise.In fact, such an operation was actually attempted during the war. The film's scenes of nighttime close combat have a verisimilitude lacking in many more ambitious films. But that's about all that can be said on the credit side for "Good Guys Wear Black."Under the circumstances, there's little that Ted Post, who directed "Magnum Force," can do to bring the movie alive. Mr. Morris, a slim, blond fellow, does reasonably well, as do Anne Archer, James Franciscus, Dana Andrews and Lloyd Haynes.The film is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), probably because of some mildly rough language.

title: Paul Dessau, Composer; Wrote Songs for Brecht
description: Paul Dessau, a German composer who was the last of Bertolt Brecht's collaborators in the musical theater, died in East Berlin on Thursday at the age of 84. native of Hamburg and a conductor in Cologne. Mainz and Berlin in the early part of his career, he was an exile from Germany during the Nazi era. He lived in the United States from 1939 until 1948, when he returned to Berlin and became active in East German cultural life.

Yet you recently declared yourself a Sandinista, a member of the Sandinista National Liberatign Front. How do you reconcile your fbrmer belief in Ghandian nonviolence with armed revolutionary struggle?

That's enough to set him apart from most of his fellow fusion artists, who either fashion their solos out of stale licks  like Ramsey Lewis, Mr. Washington's banal, handfisted opening act at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night  or, if they are competent musicians, either condescend to their material or content themselves with skimming its surface.

title: Dolin, Elder Statesman of Ballet, Recalls Diaghilev
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 29  Things have a way of happening to Anton Dolin. The 74yearold choreographer and former dancer, who has been called one of the great pioneer personalities in English ballet, arrived at the First U.S.A. International Ballet

title: Letter: On Trucking Deregulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeals Court Rejects Complaint That CBS Coverage Was Unfair
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI)  A Federal appeals court today rejected complaint that CBS violated the Government's fairness doctrine for broadcasters with dovish coverage of national security issues in 1972.

title: National Public Radio To Carry SALT Hearings
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings on Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty II will be broadcast live by National Public Radio.

title: Opera: Barber of Seville
description: The weatherman had prophesied scattered thundershowers for Thursday night, but the only storm that invaded the performance of The Barber of Seville in Central Park was the one Rossini composed for his famous comic opera. The work was presented by the New York Grand Opera as the first of four that it is staging on successive Thursday nights in the old bandshell on the mall. Vincent La Selva, the company's artistic director and conductor, is the guiding spirit behind the enterprise.

title: The Theater: And the Soul Shall Dance
description: Not a great deal happens in And the Soul Shall Dance, the play by Wakako Yamauchi at La Mama, but what does happen is honest, touching and true. Two Japanese families  one still in thrall to an old culture, one adjusting to a new  work their farms in California in taco. The Iana is nara, me community is hostile, the Depression is upon them. All this, however, is incidental; the play is about the life and death of dreams.

title: NkomoMugabe Talk on Unity
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, June 29 (Reuters)  Joshua Nkomo and Robert Mugabe, coleaders of the Patriotic Front, which is battling the Government of Zimbabwe Rhodesia, are holding a new round of talks, this time in Maputo, Mozambique, on uniting the military wings of their organizations, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: Storage Halts Offering
description: LOUISVILLE, Colo., June 29 (Reuters)  The Storage Technology Corporation said today that it would not proceed with a proposed $50 million offering of 20year convertible subordinated debentures.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 30, 1979

title: 80 Convention Contract Delayed by Some Snags
description: A City Hall ceremony to sign the contract that will make New York City host to the 1980 Democratic national convention ran into some problems yesterday.

title: Tight Gas Weekend Is Expected in New York Area
description: Gasoline is expected to be in short supply in the metropolitan New York area this weekend, with perhaps 90 percent of the stations closed on Sunday. The availability of fuel will vary elsewhere in the Northeast, with 50 percent of the stations in Rhode Island and northern New Hampshire and a relatively high number in Maine and Vermont likely to be selling gas.

title: CARTER VISITS G.I.'S AT KOREAN BORDER
description: CAMP CASEY, South Korea, Saturday, June 30  President Carter, an 11year Navy veteran, got a taste of Army life this morning at this sprawling infantry base 25 miles south of the demilitarized zone separating North and South Korea.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 354.3900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M.
