title: Notes From the Gas Line
description: Governor Carey drove eight blocks to the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday, where he held a news conference and urged New Yorkers not to drive at all during the holiday weekend.

title: U.S TO ALLOW SHIFT OF SOME GAS STOCKS TO URBAN SECTIONS
description: To Let Companies Move Up to 5% of the Stores in Rural Areas That Are WellSupplied

title: State Investigating Theft of Materials for Private Uses
description: ALBANY, June 29  The state is investigating charges that materials valued at hundreds of thousands of dollars were stolen from a warehouse of the State Department of Correctional Services in Long Island City, Queens, and used to refurbish private homes, a beauty parlor and other businesses.

title: Around the Nation
description: DURHAM, N.C., June 29 (AP)  Dr. Clifton Kreps, husband of Juanita Kreps, the Secretary of Commerce, was hospitalized tonight after firing a gun into his mouth, the police said.

title: 4 Companies Fined On Aluminum Prices
description: HOUSTON, June 29 (AP)  Four of the nation's principal makers of aluminum roll jacketing were fined $50,000 each for their nocontest pleas to Federal pricefixing charges.

title: Commerce Dept.. Weighs Shifts
description: Secretary of Commerce Juanita M. Kreps said yesterday that she had called for a broad review of her department's International Trade Administration.

title: Newport Jazz
description: Even if Billie Holiday hadn't died 20 years ago this month, the Newport Jazz Festival could easily have justified the We Remember Billie program it staged Thursday night at Carnegie Hall. For the influence of Lady Day, unarguably the greatest female singer in the history of jazz, is still very much with us. The film and television clips of Miss Holiday in action that accompanied Thursday evening's salute seemed absolutely contemporary.

title: CHINA MAY PROCESS INDOCHINA REFUGEES
description: SHANGHAI, June 29  Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today. ,that the Chinese Government is giving active and urgent consideration to a proposal to set up a processing center in China for Vietnamese refugees.

title: Patents
description: Automatic Gas Meter Reading

title: Heinz Delays Data Pending Inquiry
description: PITTSBURGH, June 29  The H. J. Heinz Company, a major foods processor and distributor, said today that publication of its audited financial results for the fiscal year would be delayed until an audit committee inquiry has been completed.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, June 29 (Reuters)  The General Motors Corporation raised prices today on most of its smaller models by an average of $60, or 0.9 percent.

title: Stage: Little Eyolf,
description: The Roundabout Theater production of Ibsen's Little Eyolf has scarcity value; the play is rarely produced, and apparently there has not been a full professional production in New York for 15 years or so.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Fell 1% in June
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The prices that farmers got for raw food and fiber products dropped 1 percent this month from May, the Agriculture Department said today, indicating the possibility of lower meat prices at retail markets this summer.

title: A.&P. Profit Continues To Improve
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the nation's thirdlargest supermarket chain, reported continued improved performance in its first quarter following additional closings of unprofitable stores.

title: Pilot Blamed in Fatal Air Crash
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)  The National Transportation Safety Board has blamed the pilot for the crash of charter plane in which all nine persons aboard died in Indiana last year. It said that the probable cause of the accident was tne pilot's continuing to fly into an area of severe turbulence. The pilot was Don Mullendore, who had more than 32,000 hours of flying time.

title: Chemical Tied to Cancer Is Banned as Cattle Feed
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  After seven years of scientific, political and legal disputes, the Food and Drug Administration today banned the hormonal drug DES, which is useful in fattening cattle but also causes cancer in humans.

title: 5Cent Rise For Gas Is Doubted
description: Sorhe independent experts insist that the latest round of OPEC price increases will add considerably more to the price of gasoline at the pump than the 5 cents a gallon predicted by the oil industry and Government specialists.

title: $1 Billion Bid for U.S. Oil Tracts
description: LOS ANGELES, June 29 (AP)  011 and gas companies bid almost $1 billion today for the first Federal oil tracts to be leased off the Southern California coast in four wars.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Exxon and Texaco List Gasoline Plans
description: Exxon U:S.A. the distribution arm of the Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest producer of gasoline, and Texaco Inc., one of the nation's top five gasoline suppliers, announced their July gasolione allocations yesterday.

title: Associated Press and United Press International
description: Governor Byrne speaking at trade seminar at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel in New York City yesterday as Governor Carey and Mayor Koch listened in amusement. Also attending, inset, were Commerce Secretary Juanita M. Kreps; Robert S. Strauss, the President's special trade representative, and Gov. George Busbee of Georgia.

title: N.B.A. Releases 10 Referees
description: The National Basketball Association dismissed 10 officials yesterday as a result of last week's decision by the league's owners to return to the twoofficial system. The threeman crew was instituted last season, but the owners, citing exorbitant costs, vetoed the plan by coaches and general managers to continue its use.

title: Colleagues and President Honor ABC Reporter Slain in Nicaragua
description: More than 300 people attended memorial service yesterday for Bill Stewart, the ABCTV correspondent who was shot dead last week by a national guardsman while covering the civil war in Nicaragua.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: Connecticut Electricity Rate Is Pegged to Nuclear Output
description: HARTFORD, June 29  Most of the economic risks and some of the economic benefits of nuclearpower generation will be absorbed by customers of Northeast Utilities rather than by the company under a new rate structure approved today by the Division of Public Utility Control.

title: Sports Today
description: - BASEBALL

title: Japan Exports Of Vehicles Up
description: TOKYO, June 29 (AP)  Exports of Japanese motor vehicles rose sharply in May from a month earlier but remained well below last year's shipments, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: NO MAJOR HOARDING FOUND IN GAS CRISIS
description: Most Attempts Have Been Futile, Largely Because Fuel to Fill Storage Tanks Is Absent

title: A Threat to the Queen?
description: She wants to go on, the boss was saying, and I have to believe she's got the family for it.

title: Borg, Not Impeded by Injury, Wins Easily
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 Bjorn Borg, who is defending his Wimbledon title in men's singles for the third consecutive year, repudiated today the widespread report that there was a 25 percent chance he might have to withdraw from the tournament because of a pulled hamstring muscle in his left thigh.

title: The Shearing of Senator Proxmire
description: A member of Congress may say anything on the floor of the House and Senate or in committee without fear of prosecution. No matter how defamatory or inaccurate the speech, the Constitution immunizes the legislator, holding that he may not be questioned in any other place for speech or debate in either house.

title: Refugees Run Ship Aground
description: HONG KONG, June 29  In a bid to get ashore after more than four months of confinement on board a rundown freighter, leaders of about 2,600 Vietnamese refugees on the ship today cut its anchor and let the ship run aground.
